## CHAPTER I

***MISHNAH***. A MAIDEN IS MARRIED[^fn_2a_1] ON THE FOURTH DAY \[OF THE WEEK\] AND A WIDOW ON THE FIFTH DAY, FOR TWICE IN THE WEEK THE COURTS OF JUSTICE[^fn_2a_2] SIT IN THE TOWNS, ON THE SECOND DAY \[OF THE WEEK\] AND ON THE FIFTH DAY, SO THAT IF HE \[THE HUSBAND\] HAD A CLAIM AS TO THE VIRGINITY \[OF THE MAIDEN-BRIDE\] HE COULD GO EARLY \[ON THE MORNING OF THE FIFTH DAY OF THE WEEK\] TO THE COURT OF JUSTICE. {¶=1.1}

***GEMARA***. R. Joseph said: Rab Judah said \[that\] Samuel said: Why did they \[the Rabbis\] Say. A MAIDEN IS MARRIED ON THE FOURTH DAY? Because we have learned:[^fn_2a_3] 'If the time \[appointed for the marriage\] arrived and they[^fn_2a_4] were not married,[^fn_2a_5] they[^fn_2a_4] eat of his \[food\][^fn_2a_6] and they eat[^fn_2a_7] of terumah'[^fn_2a_8] — you might think that if the time arrived on the first day in the week he would have to supply her with food, therefore have we learned, A MAIDEN IS MARRIED ON THE FOURTH DAY.[^fn_2a_9] Said R. Joseph: Lord of Abraham![^fn_2a_10] He \[Samuel\] attaches a Mishnah which was taught, to a Mishnah which was not taught! Which was taught and which was not taught? This was taught and this was taught! — But \[put it this way\]: he attaches a Mishnah, the reason of which was explained,[^fn_2a_11] to a Mishnah, the reason of which was not explained.[^fn_2a_12] But if it was said,[^fn_2a_13] it was said thus; Rab Judah said \[that\] Samuel said: Why did they say, A MAIDEN IS MARRIED ON THE FOURTH DAY? Because IF HE HAD A Claim AS TO THE VIRGINITY HE COULD GO EARLY \[NEXT MORNING\] TO THE COURT OF JUSTICE — well, let her be married on the first day in the week, so that if he had a claim as to virginity he could go early \[on the morning of the second day of the week\] to the court of justice! \[The answer is:\] The Sages watched over the interests[^fn_2a_14] of the daughters of Israel so that \[the bridegroom\] should prepare for the \[wedding.\] feast three days, \[namely\] on the first day in the week, the second day in the week, and the third day in the week, and on the fourth day he marries her. And now that we have learned 'shakedu',[^fn_2a_15] that \[Mishnah\] which we have learned: If the time arrived and they were not married, they eat of his \[food\] and they eat of *terumah*, \[is to be understood as implying that if\] the time arrived on the first day in the week, since he cannot marry \[her, on the first day of the week, on account of the ordinance\], he does not give her food \[on the three days, from the first day of the week to the fourth day\]. Therefore[^fn_2a_16] \[R. Joseph concludes\], if he became ill or she became ill, or she became menstruous,[^fn_2a_17] he does not give her food.

Some \[scholars\] there are who put this as a question: If he became ill, what is \[the law\]?[^fn_2a_18] \[Shall I say:\] There.[^fn_2a_19] the reason \[he need not support her,\] is because he is forced,[^fn_2a_20] and here, he is also forced?[^fn_2a_21] Or shall I say\] perhaps, there.[^fn_2a_22] he is forced[^fn_2a_23] by an ordinance which the Rabbis ordained,[^fn_2a_24] \[but\] here, \[he is\] not?[^fn_2a_25] And if you will say:[^fn_2a_26] If he became ill he supplies her with food, \[then the question would still be:\] if she became ill, what is \[the law\]? Can he say unto her, 'I am here ready to marry you'? Or, perhaps, she can say unto him, 'His field[^fn_2a_27] has been flooded'?[^fn_2a_28] And if you will say \[that\] she can say to him \[when she falls ill\], 'His field has been flooded.' \[then the question is,\] if she became menstrous, what is \[the law\]? During her regular time there is no question [pg 2b]

that she cannot say to him, 'His field has been flooded'. When is the question asked? \[If she became menstruous\] not during her regular time, what is \[the law\]? Since it is not during her regular time, she can say unto him, 'His field has been flooded'? Or, perhaps, since there are women who change their periods. It is as if it was her regular time? R. Ahai explained:[^fn_2b_1] \[We learnt:\] When the time came and they were not married, they eat of his food and they eat of *terumah*.'[^fn_2b_2] It does not state. 'They \[the men\] did not marry them \[the women\]' but \[it says\] 'They \[the women\] were not married.' In what case? If they prevent,[^fn_2b_3] why do they eat of his food and eat of the *terumah*? Hence, you must say \[must you not\].[^fn_2b_4] that they were forced as in this case,[^fn_2b_5] and it states 'they eat of his food and they eat of terumah'? — R. Ashi said: Indeed I can say[^fn_2b_6] \[that\] in the case of an accident[^fn_2b_7] she does not eat \[of his\].[^fn_2b_8] And \[here\][^fn_2b_9] they \[the men\] prevented.[^fn_2b_10] And by right he ought to have stated, 'they \[the men\] did not marry \[the women\].'[^fn_2b_11] But since the first clause[^fn_2b_12] speaks of them \[the women\] the latter clause also speaks of them \[the women\]?[^fn_2b_13]

Raba said: And with regard to divorce[^fn_2b_14] it is not so.[^fn_2b_15] Accordingly Raba holds \[that\] accident is no plea in regard to divorce.[^fn_2b_16] Whence does Raba get this \[rule\]? Shall I say, from what we have learned: 'Behold this is thy bill of divorce if I come not \[back\] from now until twelve months,'[^fn_2b_17] and he died within the twelve months, there is no divorce.[^fn_2b_18] \[And we would conclude from this that only if\] he died there is no divorce,[^fn_2b_19] but if he became ill[^fn_2b_20] there is a divorce![^fn_2b_21] But perhaps indeed I might say \[that\] if he became ill there would also he no divorce.[^fn_2b_22] and \[the Mishnah\][^fn_2b_23] lets us hear just this \[rule\], that there is no divorce after death.[^fn_2b_24] \[That\] there is no divorce after death, a previous Mishnah[^fn_2b_25] teaches: 'Behold, this is thy bill of divorce if I die,' \[or\] 'behold, this is thy bill of divorce from this illness,'[^fn_2b_26] \[or\] 'behold, this is thy bill of divorce after \[my\] death,' he has not said anything.[^fn_2b_27] \[But\] perhaps \[that[^fn_2b_28] is\] to exclude from that[^fn_2b_29] of our teachers, for it has been taught: Our teachers allowed her to marry again.[^fn_2b_30] And we said: Who are 'our teachers'? Rab Judah said \[that\] Samuel said: The court that allowed the oil \[of the heathen\]:[^fn_2b_31] they[^fn_2b_32] hold like R. Jose who said, 'the date of the document shows it.'[^fn_2b_33] But from the later clause:[^fn_2b_34] '\[This is thy bill of divorce\][^fn_2b_35] from now if I come not \[back\] from now \[and\] until twelve months', and he died within the twelve months, it is a divorce. \[And we may deduce\] 'if he died', and the same rule applies if he became ill.[^fn_2b_36] \[But\] perhaps \[the divorce is effective\] only when he died, because it was not pleasing to him that she should become subject to[^fn_2b_37] the yabam![^fn_2b_38] — But \[the deduction can be made\] from this: There was a certain \[man\][^fn_2b_39] who said unto them:[^fn_2b_40] 'If I do not come \[back\] from now until thirty days it shall be a divorce.'[^fn_2b_41] He came \[back\] at the end of thirty days but the ferry stopped him.[^fn_2b_42] He said unto them,[^fn_2b_43] 'Look, I have come \[back\]; look, I have come \[back\]!'[^fn_2b_44] Said Samuel: This is not regarded as having come back.[^fn_2b_45] But perhaps an accident which is frequent[^fn_2b_46] is different,[^fn_2b_47] for since he ought to have stipulated it[^fn_2b_48] and he did not stipulate it, he injured himself![^fn_2b_49] — But \[we must say\] Raba expressed an opinion of his own:[^fn_2b_50] On account of the chaste women and on account of the loose women.[^fn_2b_51] On account of the chaste women,[^fn_2b_52] because if you will say that it should not be a divorce.[^fn_2b_53] [pg 3a]

sometimes \[it may happen\] that he was not held back by an accident,[^fn_3a_1] and she would think that he was held back by an accident[^fn_3a_2] and she would be tied, and sit.[^fn_3a_3] And on account of the loose women, because if you will say \[that\] it should not be a divorce, sometimes \[it may happen\] that he was held back by an accident[^fn_3a_4] and she would say[^fn_3a_5] that he was not held back by an accident[^fn_3a_6] and she would go and get married, and the result would be[^fn_3a_7] \[that\] the divorce was invalid[^fn_3a_8] and her children \[from the second marriage\] would be bastards.[^fn_3a_9] But is it possible[^fn_3a_10] that according to the law of the Bible it would not be a divorce[^fn_3a_11] and on account of 'the chaste women' and on account of the 'loose women' we should allow a married woman[^fn_3a_12] to the world?[^fn_3a_13] — Yes, every one who betroths in accordance with the sense of the Rabbis he betroths,[^fn_3a_14] and the Rabbis have annulled his betrothal.[^fn_3a_15] Said Rabina to R. Ashi: This might be well[^fn_3a_16] \[if\] he betrothed her with money,[^fn_3a_17] \[but if\] he betrothed \[her\] by act of marriage, what can one say \[then\]? — The Rabbis have made[^fn_3a_18] his act of marriage non-marital.[^fn_3a_19]

Some, \[however,\] say[^fn_3a_20] \[as follows\]: Raba said: And so \[also\] with regard to divorce. Accordingly Raba holds \[that the plea of\] accident applies to divorce.[^fn_3a_21] An objection was raised: 'Behold this is thy bill of divorce if I come not \[back\] from now \[and\] until twelve months,' and he died within the twelve months, there is no divorce. \[Now\] if he dies there is no divorce, but if he became ill there would be a divorce! — Indeed I might say \[unto thee\] that if he became ill there would be no divorce either, and \[the Mishnah\] lets us hear just this \[rule\]: that there is no divorce after death. \[That\] there is no divorce after death a previous Mishnah teaches! — Perhaps \[that is\] to exclude from that of our teachers. Come and hear:[^fn_3a_22] From now if I have not come \[back\] from now \[and\] until twelve months,' and he died within the twelve months.it is a divorce. Would not the same rule apply if he became ill? No, Only if he died, because it was not pleasing to him that she should become subject to the yabam. Come and hear: A certain \[man\] said unto them: 'If I do not come \[back\] from now \[and\] until thirty days it shall be a divorce.' He came \[back\] at the end of thirty days but the ferry stopped him. And he said unto them, 'Look, I have come \[back\]; look, I have come \[back\]!' And Samuel said: This is not regarded as having come back! — An accident which is frequent is different, for since he ought to have stipulated it and he did not stipulate it, he injured himself.

R. Samuel b. Isaac said: They have only taught[^fn_3a_23] since the institution of Ezra[^fn_3a_24] and after, \[according to which\] the courts of justice sit[^fn_3a_25] only on the second day and on the fifth day \[of the week\]. But before the institution of Ezra, when the courts of justice sat every day, a woman[^fn_3a_26] could be married on any day. Before the institution of Ezra, what there was there was![^fn_3a_27] — He means it thus: If there are courts of justice that sit now as before the institution of Ezra,[^fn_3a_28] a woman may be married on any day. But what of shakedu?[^fn_3a_29] \[We suppose\] that he[^fn_3a_30] had \[already\] taken the trouble.[^fn_3a_31] [pg 3b]

What is \[the reference to\] shakedu? \[For\] it has been taught: Why did they say that a maiden is married on the fourth day? 'Because if he had a claim as to virginity he could go early \[next morning\] to the court of justice. But let her be married on the first day in the week and if he had a claim as to virginity he could go early \[on the morning of the second day in the week\] to the court of justice? — The Sages watched over the interests of the daughters of Israel so that \[the man\] should prepare for the \[wedding-\]feast three days, the first day in the week, and the second day in the week, and the third day in the week, and on the fourth day he marries her. And from \[the time of\] danger and onwards the people made it a custom to marry on the third day and the Sages did not interfere with them. And on the second day \[of the week\] he shall not marry; and if on account of the constraint[^fn_3b_1] it is allowed. And one separates the bridegroom from the bride on the nights of Sabbath at the beginning,[^fn_3b_2] because he makes a wound.[^fn_3b_3]

What \[was the\] danger? If I say that they[^fn_3b_4] said, 'a maiden that gets married on the fourth day \[of the week\] shall be killed', \[then how state\] 'they made it a custom'? We should abolish it entirely! — Said Rabbah: \[That\] they said, 'a maiden that gets married on the fourth day \[of the week\] shall have the first sexual intercourse with the prefect.'[^fn_3b_5] \[You call\] this danger? \[Surely\] this \[is a case of\] constraint![^fn_3b_6] — Because there are chaste women who would rather surrender themselves to death and \[thus\] come to danger. But let one expound to them[^fn_3b_7] that \[in a case of\] constraint \[it\] is allowed?[^fn_3b_8] — There are loose women[^fn_3b_9] and there are also priestesses.[^fn_3b_10] But \[then\] let one abolish it?[^fn_3b_11] A decree[^fn_3b_12] is likely to cease, and \[therefore\] we do not abolish an ordinance of the Rabbis on account of a decree. If so, on the third day he \[the prefect\] would also come and have intercourse \[with the bride\]? — Out of doubt he does not move himself.[^fn_3b_13]

\[It is stated above:\] 'And on the second day \[of the week\] he shall not marry; and if on account of the constraint it is allowed.' What constraint \[is referred to\]? Shall I say \[that it is\] that which we have said?[^fn_3b_14] There,[^fn_3b_15] one calls it 'danger' 'and here, one calls it \[mere\] 'constraint'! And further, there \[it states\], 'they made it a custom', \[whilst\] here, 'it is allowed'![^fn_3b_16] — Said Raba: \[it is that\] they say 'a general has come to town.[^fn_3b_17] In what case? If he comes and passes by,[^fn_3b_18] let it be delayed![^fn_3b_19] — It is not necessary \[to state this but\] that he came and stayed. Let him, \[then\], marry on the third day \[of the week\]![^fn_3b_20] — His[^fn_3b_21] vanguard arrived on the third day. And if you wish I may say: What is \[the meaning of\] 'on account of the constraint'? As it has been taught: If his bread was baked and his meat prepared and his wine mixed[^fn_3b_22] and the father of the bridegroom[^fn_3b_23] or the mother of the bride died,[^fn_3b_24] they bring the dead \[person\] into a room and the bridegroom and the bride into the bridal chamber,[^fn_3b_25] [pg 4a]

and he performs the dutiful marital act[^fn_4a_1] and \[then\] separates \[himself from her\].[^fn_4a_2] And \[then\] he keeps the seven days of the \[wedding-\]feast[^fn_4a_3] and after that he keeps the seven days of mourning.[^fn_4a_3] And \[during\] all these days he sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women.[^fn_4a_4] And they do not withhold ornaments[^fn_4a_5] from the bride all the thirty days.[^fn_4a_6] \[But that is\] only \[if\] the father of the bridegroom or the mother of the bride \[died\], because there is \[then\] no one who should prepare for them \[for the wedding\], but not \[in case of\] the reverse.[^fn_4a_7] Rafram b. Papa said \[that\] R. Hisda said: They taught \[this\] only when water had \[already\] been put on the meat, but if water had not \[yet\] been put on the meat, it is to be sold. Raba said: And in a city, although water had been put on the meat, it is sold.[^fn_4a_8] R. Papa said: And in a village, although water had not been put on the meat, it is not sold.[^fn_4a_9] But where \[then\] will you find \[the rule\] of R. Hisda \[to apply\]? Said R. Ashi: For instance, \[in\] Matha Mehasia,[^fn_4a_10] which is neither a city nor a village.[^fn_4a_11]

It has been taught according to R. Hisda: If his bread was baked and his meat prepared and his wine mixed and water had been put on the meat and the father of the bridegroom or the mother of the bride died, they bring the dead \[person\] into a room and the bridegroom and the bride into the bridal chamber, and he performs the dutiful marital act and \[then\] separates \[himself from her\]. And \[then\] he keeps the seven days of the \[wedding-\]feast and after that he keeps the seven days of mourning. And all these days he sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women. And so \[also\] if his wife became menstruous does he sleep among the men and she sleeps among the women. And they do not withhold ornaments from the bride all the thirty days. In any case he must not perform the \[first\] marital act on the eve of Sabbath or in the night following the Sabbath.

The Master said \[above\]: 'He sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women.' This supports R. Johanan, for R. Johanan said: Although they said \[that\] there is no mourning on a festival, yet matters of privacy he keeps.[^fn_4a_12] R. Joseph the son of Raba lectured in the name of Raba: They taught[^fn_4a_13] only if he had yet no intercourse \[with her\],[^fn_4a_14] but if he had \[already\] intercourse, his wife may sleep with him.[^fn_4a_15] But here we deal with a case when he had intercourse, and still it teaches \[that\] he sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women? — When did he[^fn_4a_16] say \[it\]? With regard to his wife becoming menstruous. But it says. 'And so \[also if his wife became menstruous\]'![^fn_4a_17] [pg 4b]

— Thus he[^fn_4b_1] means to say:[^fn_4b_2] And so \[also\], if his wife became menstruous and he had not yet had intercourse \[with her\] he sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women. Is this \[then\] to say that he treats mourning more lightly than menstruation?[^fn_4b_3] Surely. R. Isaac the son of Hanina said that R. Huna said: All kinds of work[^fn_4b_4] which a wife performs for her husband, a menstruant[^fn_4b_5] may perform for her husband, except the mixing of the cup[^fn_4b_6] and the making[^fn_4b_7] of the bed and the washing of his face, his hands and his feet;[^fn_4b_8] while with regard to mourning it has been taught: Although they[^fn_4b_9] said: No man has a right to force his wife[^fn_4b_10] to paint \[her eyes\] or rouge \[her face\], in truth[^fn_4b_11] they said: She mixes him the cup[^fn_4b_12] and she makes him the bed and she washes his face, his hands and his feet?[^fn_4b_13] — \[This is\] not difficult; here[^fn_4b_14] \[it speaks\] of his mourning,[^fn_4b_15] there[^fn_4b_16] \[it speaks\] of her mourning.[^fn_4b_17] But it says:[^fn_4b_18] 'The father of the bridegroom or the mother of the bride \[died\]'?[^fn_4b_19] — This refers to the rest.[^fn_4b_20] But is there a difference between his mourning and her mourning? Surely it has been taught: If a man's father-in-law or mother-in-law died,[^fn_4b_21] he cannot force his wife to paint \[her eyes\] and to rouge \[her face\]. but he lowers his bed[^fn_4b_22] and keeps mourning with her. And so \[also\] if a woman's father-in-law or mother-in-law died[^fn_4b_23] she is not allowed to paint \[her eyes\] and to rouge \[her face\], but she lowers her bed and keeps mourning with him![^fn_4b_24] — Teach with reference to his mourning 'he sleeps among the men and his wife sleeps among the women'.[^fn_4b_25] But it says: 'And so \[also\]'?[^fn_4b_26] — This refers to painting and rouging.[^fn_4b_27] But it says 'with him'! Does this not mean,[^fn_4b_28] with him in one bed? — No, \[it means\] with him in one house, and as Rab said to his son Hiyya: In her presence[^fn_4b_29] keep mourning, in her absence do not keep mourning.[^fn_4b_30] R. Ashi said: Can you compare this mourning[^fn_4b_31] with ordinary mourning?[^fn_4b_32] Ordinary mourning is strict and one would not deal lightly[^fn_4b_33] with it. \[But\] this mourning, since the Rabbis were lenient \[about it\], one might deal lightly with it. What is the leniency? Shall I say. because it says he performs the dutiful act of marriage and separates \[himself from her\]? That is[^fn_4b_34] because the mourning has not rested upon him[^fn_4b_35] yet; \[namely\] if according to R. Eliezer, \[the mourning does not begin\] until the body has been taken out of the house,[^fn_4b_36] and if according to R. Joshua, \[the mourning does not begin\] until the golel[^fn_4b_37] has been closed![^fn_4b_38] — But \[the leniency is this,\] because it says: He keeps \[first\] the seven days of the \[wedding-\]feast and after that he keeps the seven days of mourning.

The Master said: 'In any case he must not perform the \[first\] marital act on the eve of Sabbath or in the night following the Sabbath. It is right \[that he may not perform it\] on the eve of Sabbath, because of a wound.[^fn_4b_39] But in the night following the Sabbath, why not? — Said R. Zera: [pg 5a]

Because of accounts.[^fn_5a_1] Said Abaye to him: And are accounts of a religious nature forbidden?[^fn_5a_2] Surely R. Hisda and R. Hamnuna both said: Accounts of a religious nature, one is allowed to calculate them on Sabbath; and R. Eleazar said: One may assign charity to the poor on Sabbath; and R. Jacob said \[that\] R. Johanan said: One may go to synagogues and to schoolhouses to watch over public affairs[^fn_5a_3] on Sabbath; and R. Jacob the son of Idi said \[that\] R. Johanan said: One may do any work to save a life[^fn_5a_4] on Sabbath; and R. Samuel the son of Nahmani said \[that\] R. Jonathan said: One may go to theatres and circuses[^fn_5a_5] to watch over public affairs on Sabbath; and \[a scholar\] of the school of Menashia taught: One may negotiate about the girls to be betrothed on Sabbath[^fn_5a_6] and about a boy to teach him the book[^fn_5a_7] and to teach him a trade? — But, said R. Zera, it has been prohibited[^fn_5a_8] lest he might slaughter a fowl.[^fn_5a_9] Said Abaye to him: But if this were so, then the Day of Atonement which fell on the second day of the week should be postponed[^fn_5a_10] for fear[^fn_5a_11] lest he might slaughter a fowl?[^fn_5a_12] — There,[^fn_5a_13] that \[he has to prepare only\] for himself he is not troubled \[so much\],[^fn_5a_14] \[but\] here,[^fn_5a_15] that \[he has to prepare\] for others,[^fn_5a_16] he is troubled.[^fn_5a_17] Or: there, he has an interval,[^fn_5a_18] \[but\] here, he has no interval.[^fn_5a_19] Now that you have come so far,[^fn_5a_20] the eve of Sabbath[^fn_5a_21] also is prohibited[^fn_5a_22] for fear lest he might slaughter a fowl.[^fn_5a_23]

The question was asked:[^fn_5a_24] \[Does the Mishnah mean:\] A maiden is married on the fourth day \[of the week\], and the intercourse takes place on the fourth day, and we are not afraid that he might be pacified?[^fn_5a_25] Or perhaps \[the meaning is\] a maiden is married on the fourth day \[of the week\], and the intercourse takes place on the fifth day[^fn_5a_26] because we are afraid that he might be pacified? — Come and hear: Bar-Kappara taught: A maiden is married on the fourth day \[of the week\] and the intercourse takes place on the fifth day[^fn_5a_26] because on it \[the fifth day\] the blessing for the fishes was pronounced.[^fn_5a_27] A widow is married on the fifth day \[of the week\] and the intercourse takes place on the sixth day[^fn_5a_28] because on it \[the sixth day\] was pronounced the blessing for man.[^fn_5a_29] \[We thus see that\] the reason is on account of the blessing, but as to \[his\] being pacified we are not afraid. If so,[^fn_5a_30] \[in the case of\] a widow also the intercourse should take place on the fifth day \[of the week\], because on it \[the fifth day\] was pronounced the blessing for the fishes?[^fn_5a_31] — The blessing for man is better for him.[^fn_5a_32] Or on account of 'they have watched,'[^fn_5a_33] for it has been taught: Why did they[^fn_5a_34] say \[that\] a widow is married on the fifth day \[of the week\] and the intercourse takes place on the sixth day? Because, if you will say that the intercourse should take place on the fifth day, in the morning[^fn_5a_35] he will rise and go to his work;[^fn_5a_36] therefore the Sages watched over the welfare[^fn_5a_37] of the daughters of Israel that he should rejoice with her[^fn_5a_38] three days, \[namely\] on the fifth day of the week,[^fn_5a_39] on the eve of Sabbath[^fn_5a_40] and \[on\] Sabbath.[^fn_5a_41] What is the difference between 'the blessing' and 'they have watched'?[^fn_5a_42] The difference is this:[^fn_5a_43] \[in the case of\] a man of leisure,[^fn_5a_44] or \[in the case\] when a festival falls on the eve of Sabbath.[^fn_5a_45]

Bar-Kappara expounded: The work of the righteous[^fn_5a_46] is greater than the work[^fn_5a_47] of heaven and earth, for in \[regard to\] the creation of heaven and earth it is written, Yea, My hand hath laid the foundation, of the earth, and My right hand hath spread out the heavens,[^fn_5a_48] while in \[regard to\] the work of the hands of the righteous it is written, The place which Thou hast made for Thee to dwell in, O Lord, the sanctuary, O Lord, which Thy hands have established.[^fn_5a_49] Replied[^fn_5a_50] one Babylonian, and R. Hiyya \[was\] his name: \[It is written.\] And the dry land his hands formed?[^fn_5a_51] — It is \[to be\] written, 'His hand'.[^fn_5a_52] But it is written, they formed?[^fn_5a_53] — Said R. Nahman b. Isaac: 'His fingers formed,'[^fn_5a_54] as it is written. When I behold Thy heavens, the work of Thy fingers, the moon and the stars which Thou hast established.[^fn_5a_55]

An objection was raised: \[It is written,\] The heavens declare the glory of God, and the work of His hands the firmament shows?[^fn_5a_56] — Thus he said:[^fn_5a_57] The handiwork[^fn_5a_58] of the righteous, who shews \[it\]?[^fn_5a_59] The firmament. And what is it? Rain.[^fn_5a_60]

Bar-Kappara \[also\] expounded: What \[is the meaning of what\] is written. And thou shalt have a peg among thy implements?[^fn_5a_61] Do not read,[^fn_5a_62] thy implements,[^fn_5a_63] but 'upon thy ear';[^fn_5a_64] \[this means to say\] that if a man hears an unworthy thing[^fn_5a_65] [pg 5b]

he shall plug his finger[^fn_5b_1] into his ears. And this is the same that R. Eleazar said: Why do the fingers of man resemble pegs? Why?[^fn_5b_2] Shall I say because they are divided?[^fn_5b_3] \[Surely\] each one has been made for its own purpose![^fn_5b_4]

         For a Master said: This one[^fn_5b_5] \[Is used for measuring\] the span;[^fn_5b_6] this one[^fn_5b_7] \[is used for\] taking a fistful of the meal-offering,[^fn_5b_8] this one[^fn_5b_9] \[is used for defining\] the cubit measure,[^fn_5b_10] this one[^fn_5b_11] \[is used for taking the measure of\] 'a finger',[^fn_5b_12] \[and\] this one[^fn_5b_13] \[is used for service with\] the thumb![^fn_5b_14] — But \[the question is\] why[^fn_5b_15] \[are the fingers\] pointed like pegs? \[The reason is\] that if a man hears an unworthy thing he shall plug his fingers into his ears. \[A member\] of the school of R. Ishmael taught: Why is the whole ear hard and the ear-lap soft? \[So\] that if a man hears an unworthy thing he shall bend the ear-lap into it.[^fn_5b_16]

Our Rabbis taught: A man shall not let his ears hear idle things,[^fn_5b_17] because they are burnt first of \[all\] the organs.[^fn_5b_18]

The question was asked: Is it allowed[^fn_5b_19] to perform the first marital act on Sabbath?[^fn_5b_20] Is the blood \[in the womb\] stored up,[^fn_5b_21] or is it the result of a wound?[^fn_5b_22] And if you will say[^fn_5b_23] \[that\] the blood is stored up \[in the womb, then the question arises:\] is he concerned about the blood,[^fn_5b_24] and it is allowed: or is he concerned

         with the opening,[^fn_5b_25] and it is forbidden?[^fn_5b_26] And if you will say \[that\] he is concerned with the blood and the opening comes of itself, \[then the question arises:\] Is the *halachah*[^fn_5b_27] according to R. Simeon who says: A thing which is not intended[^fn_5b_28] is allowed; or is the *halachah* according to R. Judah who says: A thing which is not intended is forbidden?[^fn_5b_29] And if you will say \[that\] the *halachah* is according to R. Judah \[then the question arises\], does he do damage in regard to the opening, or does he improve in regard to the opening?[^fn_5b_30] Some say:[^fn_5b_31] And if you will say that the blood is the result of a wound \[then the question arises\], is he concerned about the blood and it is forbidden,[^fn_5b_32] or is he concerned with his own pleasure, and it is allowed? And if you will say \[that\] he is concerned with his own pleasure and the blood comes out of itself,[^fn_5b_33] \[then the question arises\] is the *halachah* according to R. Judah or is the *halachah* according to R. Simeon? And if you will say \[that\] the *halachah* is according to R. Judah, \[then the question arises,\] does he do damage by \[making\] the wound, or does he improve by \[making\] the wound? And if you will say \[that\] he does damage by \[making\] the wound, \[then the question arises,\] with regard to one who does damage, is the *halachah* according to R. Judah, [pg 6a]

or is the law according to R. Simeon?[^fn_6a_1] In the

         school of Rab[^fn_6a_2] they said: Rab allowed[^fn_6a_3] and Samuel forbade.[^fn_6a_3]   In Nehardea[^fn_6a_4] they said: Rab forbade and Samuel allowed. Said R. Nahman b. Isaac: And your \[mnemotechnical\] sign \[is\]: These make it lenient for themselves, and these make it lenient for themselves.[^fn_6a_5]   But does Rab allow it? Surely R. Shimi b. Hezekiah said in the name of Rab: \[As regards\] that stopper of the brewing boiler, it is forbidden to squeeze it in[^fn_6a_6] on a festival day![^fn_6a_7] — In that \[case\][^fn_6a_8] even R. Simeon admits \[that it is forbidden\], for Abaye and Raba, both of them say: R. Simeon admits \[that it is forbidden\] in \[a case of\] 'Let his head be cut off, and let him not die!'[^fn_6a_9]   \[But\] R. Hiyya the son of Ashi said \[that\] Rab said: The *halachah* is according to R. Judah,[^fn_6a_10] and R. Hanan the son of Ammi \[said that\] Samuel said: The *halachah* is according to R. Simeon.[^fn_6a_11] And R. Hiyya the son of Abin taught it without \[naming the\] men:[^fn_6a_12] Rab said \[that\] the *halachah* is according to R. Judah. and Samuel said \[that\] the *halachah* is according to R. Simeon? — Still, Rab holds like R. Judah, \[but\] according to that version that says, 'the blood is stored up \[in the womb\],' he does damage in regard to the opening,[^fn_6a_13] \[and\] according to that version that says, 'the blood is the result of a wound,' he does damage in \[making\] the wound.[^fn_6a_13]

R. Hisda objected: If a girl, whose period[^fn_6a_14] to see \[blood\] had not arrived yet, got married, Beth Shammai[^fn_6a_15] say: One gives her four nights,[^fn_6a_16] and the disciples of Hillel say: Until the wound is

         healed up.[^fn_6a_17] If her period to see \[blood\] had arrived[^fn_6a_18] and she married, Beth Shammai say: One gives her the first night,[^fn_6a_19] and Beth Hillel say: Until the night following the Sabbath \[one gives her\] four nights.[^fn_6a_20]  [pg 6b]

\[Now\] does it not[^fn_6b_1] mean that if he had \[yet\] no intercourse \[with his wife\] he may have intercourse \[with her\] even on Sabbath?[^fn_6b_2]   — Said Raba: No, except Sabbath. Said Abaye to him: But it says, 'until the night following the Sabbath \[one gives her\] four nights'?[^fn_6b_3]   — Only, said Raba, when he already had intercourse \[with her\].[^fn_6b_4] If \[it were, as you say,\] after he already had intercourse, what does he let us hear?[^fn_6b_5] — He lets us hear that it is allowed to have intercourse on Sabbath, as that \[statement\] of Samuel \[teaches\], for Samuel said: One may enter into a narrow opening on Sabbath,[^fn_6b_6] although[^fn_6b_7] he causes pebbles to break loose.[^fn_6b_8]

         R. Joseph objected: A bridegroom is free from the reading of *Shema'*[^fn_6b_9] in the first night[^fn_6b_10] until the night following the Sabbath, if he has not performed \[yet\] an act.[^fn_6b_11] Is it not[^fn_6b_12] because he is anxious to perform the marital act?[^fn_6b_13] — Said Abaye to him: No; he is anxious because he has not had intercourse.[^fn_6b_14] Said Raba to him: And on account of anxiety \[only\][^fn_6b_15] he is free \[from reading *Shema'*\]? If this were so, then \[if\] his ship sank in the sea, he would also be free \[from the reading of *Shema'*\]! And should you say \[that\] it is really so, surely, R. Abba b. Zabda said \[that\] Rab said: A mourner is bound to observe all the precepts that are stated in the Torah except \[that\] of the Tefillin[^fn_6b_16] because it is said with regard to them an ornament'?[^fn_6b_17] — But, said Raba, this[^fn_6b_18] is a dispute of Tannaim,[^fn_6b_19] for one \[Baraitha\] teaches: If he[^fn_6b_20] did not do an act \[of coition\] in the first \[night\],[^fn_6b_21] he is free \[from reading *Shema'*\] also in the second \[night\]; in the second \[night\],[^fn_6b_22] he is free \[from reading *Shema'*\] also in the third \[night\].[^fn_6b_23] And another \[Baraitha\] teaches: \[In\] the first and second \[night\] he is free, \[but in\] the third \[night\] he is obliged \[to read *Shema'*\].[^fn_6b_24] And Abaye \[holds that\] there[^fn_6b_25] also          \[they\][^fn_6b_26] differ with regard to anxiety.[^fn_6b_27] And these Tannaim \[are\] like those Tannaim,[^fn_6b_28] for it has been taught \[in a Baraitha\]: He who marries a maiden shall not perform the first intercourse[^fn_6b_29] on Sabbath, and the Sages allow \[it\]. Who are the Sages? Said Rabbah: It is R. Simeon, who says: A thing which is not intended is allowed.[^fn_6b_30] Said Abaye to him: But R. Simeon admits (that it is forbidden\] in \[a case of\] 'Let his head be cut off and let him not die!'[^fn_6b_31] Said he to him: Not like those Babylonians who are not skilled in moving aside,[^fn_6b_32] but there are some who are skilled in moving aside.[^fn_6b_33] If so,[^fn_6b_34] why \[give the reason of\] 'anxious'?[^fn_6b_35] — For one who is not skilled. \[Then\] let them say: One who is skilled is allowed \[to perform the first intercourse on Sabbath\], one who is not skilled is forbidden? — Most \[people\] are skilled.[^fn_6b_36] Said Raba the son of R. Hanan to Abaye: If this were so, then why \[have\] groomsmen,[^fn_6b_37] why \[have\] a sheet?[^fn_6b_38] — He \[Abaye\] said to him: There \[the groomsmen and the sheet are necessary\] perhaps he will see and destroy \[the tokens of her virginity\].[^fn_6b_39]

         R. Ammi objected:[^fn_6b_40] He who pierces[^fn_6b_41] an abscess on Sabbath, if \[in order\] to make an opening[^fn_6b_42] to it, he is guilty,[^fn_6b_43] but if \[in order\] to cause pus to come out of it [pg 7a]

he is free from punishment\]?[^fn_7a_1]   — There[^fn_7a_2] it is[^fn_7a_3] stored up[^fn_7a_4] and is \[entirely\] loose,[^fn_7a_5] here[^fn_7a_6] it[^fn_7a_7] is stored up[^fn_7a_8] but is not \[entirely\] loose.[^fn_7a_9] R. Ammi allowed to have first intercourse[^fn_7a_10] on Sabbath. Said the Rabbis to him: But her *kethubah*[^fn_7a_11] is not written yet! — He said to them: Let her seize movable goods.[^fn_7a_12] R. Zebid permitted to have the first intercourse on Sabbath. Some say: R. Zebid himself had the first intercourse on Sabbath. Rab Judah allowed to have the first intercourse on a festival. R. Papi said in the name of Raba: You shall not say \[that\] on a festival it[^fn_7a_13] is allowed, but \[that\] on Sabbath it is forbidden. It is just as well allowed on Sabbath; only it happened so.[^fn_7a_14] R. Papa said in the name of Raba: On a festival it is allowed, on Sabbath it is forbidden. Said R. Papi to R. Papa: What is your opinion? Since a wound[^fn_7a_15] has been permitted \[on a festival\] for a necessity. it has been permitted also when there is no necessity? If that were so, it should be permitted to put spices on coals[^fn_7a_16] on a festival, for since the kindling of fire has been allowed \[on a festival\] for a

         necessity, it should be allowed also when there is no necessity![^fn_7a_17] Said he to him.[^fn_7a_18] Concerning this[^fn_7a_19] the Biblical verse said, save that which every man must eat,[^fn_7a_20] \[this means\] a thing which is useful[^fn_7a_21] for every man.[^fn_7a_22] R. Aha, the son of Raba, said to R. Ashi: If this were So,[^fn_7a_23] then if a deer happened to come to the hands of a person[^fn_7a_24] on a festival, \[shall we say that\] since it is not of equal usefulness for every person,[^fn_7a_25] is it really so that it would be forbidden to kill it? Said he[^fn_7a_26] to him:[^fn_7a_27] I say, 'a thing that is needful for every person,'[^fn_7a_28] \[and\] a deer is needful for every person.[^fn_7a_29] R. Jacob, the son of Idi, said: R. Johanan gave a decision[^fn_7a_30] in Zaidan:[^fn_7a_31] It is forbidden to perform the first intercourse on Sabbath. — And is there an instructive decision for a prohibition?[^fn_7a_32] — Yes, we have learned in a Mishnah:[^fn_7a_33] The school of Hillel gave a decision regarding her[^fn_7a_34] that she[^fn_7a_35] should be a Nazirite yet another seven years. Or indeed it is as that which has been taught: If the cord of the spinal column is severed in its larger portion \[the animal is *trefa*\],[^fn_7a_36] \[this is\] the view of Rabbi.[^fn_7a_37] R. Jacob Says: Even if it[^fn_7a_38] is \[only\] perforated \[the animal is *trefa*\]. Rabbi gave a decision[^fn_7a_39] according to R. Jacob.[^fn_7a_40]

R. Huna said: The *halachah* is not as stated by R. Jacob. R. Nahman b. Isaac taught thus: R. Abbahu said: R. Ishmael b. Jacob, from Tyre asked R. Johanan in Zaidan, and I heard \[it\]: Is it allowed[^fn_7a_41] to have the first intercourse on Sabbath? And he[^fn_7a_42] said to him:[^fn_7a_43] It is forbidden. — And the law is: It is allowed to have the first intercourse on Sabbath.[^fn_7a_44]

R. Helbo said \[that\] R. Huna said \[that\] R. Abba, the son of Zabda, said \[that\] Rab said: A maiden as well as a widow requires a benediction.[^fn_7a_45] — But did R. Huna say so? Did not R. Huna say: A widow does not require a benediction? — It is not difficult.[^fn_7a_46] Here[^fn_7a_47] \[it speaks\] of a young man[^fn_7a_48] who marries a widow, there[^fn_7a_49] of a widower who marries a widow. And when a widower marries a widow \[a benediction\] is not required? Did not R. Nahman Say: Huna b. Nathan said to me: A Tanna taught: Whence \[is it derived that\] the benediction of the bridegrooms[^fn_7a_50] \[has to be said\] in the presence of ten \[persons\]? Because it is said, And he took ten men of the elders of the city, and said: 'Sit ye down here'. And they sat down.[^fn_7a_51] And Boaz was a widower, who married a widow![^fn_7a_52] — What is \[the meaning of the words\] 'she does not require a benediction' which R. Huna said? She does not require a benediction during all the seven days. but on one day[^fn_7a_53] she requires a benediction. But that which has been taught:[^fn_7a_54] 'The Sages were anxious for the welfare of the daughters of Israel, that he[^fn_7a_55] may rejoice with her[^fn_7a_56] three days' — how is this to be understood?[^fn_7a_57] If \[it speaks\] of a young man, did you not say — seven;[^fn_7a_58] if of a widower, did you not say — one day?[^fn_7a_59] — If you wish, you may say \[that it speaks\] of a widower \[and in this case\] one day is for the benediction and three days are for rejoicing. And if you wish, you may say \[that it speaks\] of a young man \[and in this case\] seven \[days\] are for the benediction and three \[days\] for rejoicing. [pg 7b]

An objection was raised: \[It has been taught:\] The benediction is said \[at the celebration of the marriage\] for a maiden seven \[days\] and for a widow one day. Is it not \[to be understood that\] even \[in the case of\] a widow who marries a young man \[the benediction is said only on one day\]? — No \[only when the widow marries\] a widower. But \[if the widow marries\] a young man, what \[then\]? Seven \[days\]?[^fn_7b_1] If that is so, let it be taught:[^fn_7b_2] The benediction is said for a maiden[^fn_7b_3] seven \[days\], and for a widow who marries a young man[^fn_7b_4] seven \[days\], and for a widow \[who marries a widower\][^fn_7b_5] one day? — It taught a decided thing:[^fn_7b_6] That there is no maiden who has less than seven \[days\],[^fn_7b_7] and there is no widow who has less than one day.[^fn_7b_8] The \[above\] text \[says\]: R. Nahman said: Huna b. Nathan said to me: A Tanna taught: Whence \[is it derived that\] the benediction of the bridegrooms \[has to be said\] in the presence of ten \[persons\]? Because it is said, And he took ten men of the elders of the city, and said: 'Sit ye down here'.[^fn_7b_9] But R. Abbahu said \[that it is derived\] from here: In assemblies bless ye God, the Lord, from the fountain of Israel.[^fn_7b_10] And how does R. Nahman expound this verse of R. Abbahu?[^fn_7b_11] — He requires it for the same purpose as has been set out in a Baraitha:[^fn_7b_12] R. Meir used to say: Whence \[can it be derived\] that even embryos in the bowels of their mothers sang[^fn_7b_13] a song[^fn_7b_14] by the sea?[^fn_7b_15] Because it is said, In assemblies bless ye God, the Lord, from the fountain of Israel.[^fn_7b_16] And the other one?[^fn_7b_17] — If \[that were\] so, let the verse say,[^fn_7b_18] 'from the womb.'[^fn_7b_19] Why \[does it say\], 'from the fountain'?[^fn_7b_20] \[To show that it is\] concerning the affairs of the fountain.[^fn_7b_21] And how does R. Abbahu expound that verse of R. Nahman?[^fn_7b_22] — He requires it for expounding: an Ammonite, and not an Ammonitess, a Moabite, and not a Moabitess.[^fn_7b_23] For if you would think \[that the presence of the ten men was required\] for \[the saying of\] the benediction, would it not have been sufficient if they had not been elders?[^fn_7b_24] And the other one?[^fn_7b_25] — If you would think \[that the verse was to be used\] for that exposition, would it not have been sufficient if there had not been ten \[persons\]?[^fn_7b_26] — Yes, to make the matter public[^fn_7b_27] — and as Samuel said to R. Hanna of Bagdath:[^fn_7b_28] Go out and bring me ten[^fn_7b_29] \[persons\] and I will say unto thee in their presence; If one assigns \[property\] to an embryo, it acquires it. But the law is: If one assigns \[property\] to an embryo, it does not acquire it.[^fn_7b_30]

The Rabbis taught: The benediction of the bridegrooms is said[^fn_7b_31] in the house of the bridegroom.[^fn_7b_32] R. Judah says: Also in the house of the betrothal[^fn_7b_33] it is said.[^fn_7b_34] Abaye said: And in \[the province of\] Judah they taught \[the opinion of R. Judah\] because \[in the province of Judah\] he[^fn_7b_35] is alone with her.[^fn_7b_36]

Another \[Baraitha\] teaches: The benediction of the bridegrooms is said in the house of the bridegrooms and the benediction of betrothal in the house of betrothal. \[As to\] the benediction of betrothal — what does one say?[^fn_7b_37] — Rabin b. R. Adda and Rabbah son of R. Adda both said in the name of Rab Judah: Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the Universe, who has sanctified us by his commandments and has commanded us concerning the forbidden relations and has forbidden unto us the betrothed[^fn_7b_38] and has allowed unto us the wedded[^fn_7b_39] through \[the marriage\] canopy[^fn_7b_40] and sanctification.[^fn_7b_41] R. Aha 'the son of Raba, concludes it.[^fn_7b_42] in the name of Rab Judah, \[with the words\]: Blessed art Thou, O Lord, who sanctifies Israel through canopy and sanctification. He who does not seal[^fn_7b_43] \[holds that\] it is analogous to the blessing over fruits and to the benediction \[said on performing\] religious commandments.[^fn_7b_44] And he who seals[^fn_7b_45] \[holds that\] it is analogous to the kiddush.[^fn_7b_46]

Our Rabbis taught: The blessing of the bridegrooms is said in the presence of ten \[persons\][^fn_7b_47] all the seven days.[^fn_7b_48] Rab Judah said: And that is only if new guests[^fn_7b_49] come.[^fn_7b_50] What does One say?[^fn_7b_51] Rab Judah 'and: 'Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the Universe, [pg 8a]

who has[^fn_8a_1] created all things[^fn_8a_2] to his glory'. and[^fn_8a_3] 'the Creator of man', and 'who has created man in his image. In the image of the likeness of his form, and has prepared unto him[^fn_8a_4] out of himself[^fn_8a_5] a building forever.[^fn_8a_6] Blessed art thou, O Lord, Creator of man'.[^fn_8a_7] 'May the barren[^fn_8a_8] greatly rejoice and exult[^fn_8a_9] when her children will be gathered[^fn_8a_10] in her midst in joy.[^fn_8a_11] Blessed art Thou, O Lord, who maketh Zion joyful through[^fn_8a_12] her children'[^fn_8a_13] 'Mayest Thou make the loved[^fn_8a_14] companions greatly to rejoice, even as of old[^fn_8a_15] Thou didst gladden Thy creature[^fn_8a_16] in the Garden of Eden. Blessed art Thou, O Lord, who maketh bridegroom and bride to rejoice'.[^fn_8a_17] 'Blessed art Thou, O Lord our King, God of the universe, who has created joy and gladness, bridegroom and bride, rejoicing, song, mirth, and delight,[^fn_8a_18] love, and brotherhood, and peace, and friendship.[^fn_8a_19] Speedily, O Lord our God, may be heard in the cities of Judah, and in the streets of Jerusalem, the voice of joy and the voice of gladness, the voice of the bridegroom and the voice of the bride, the voice of the singing[^fn_8a_20] of bridegrooms from their canopies[^fn_8a_21] and of youths from their feasts[^fn_8a_22] of song. Blessed art Thou, O Lord, who maketh the bridegroom to rejoice with[^fn_8a_23] the bride'.[^fn_8a_24]

Levi came[^fn_8a_25] to the house of Rabbi to[^fn_8a_26] the wedding-feast of R. Simeon his son \[and\] said five benedictions.[^fn_8a_27] R. Assi came[^fn_8a_25] to the house of R. Ashi to[^fn_8a_26] the wedding-feast of Mar his son \[and\] said six benedictions.[^fn_8a_28] Does it mean to say that they differ in this: that one holds that there was one formation,[^fn_8a_29] and the other holds that there were two formations?[^fn_8a_30] — No. All[^fn_8a_31] agree \[that\] there was \[only\] one formation, \[but they differ in this:\] one holds \[that\] we go according[^fn_8a_32] to the intention,[^fn_8a_33] and the other holds \[that\] we go according[^fn_8a_32] to the fact,[^fn_8a_34] as that \[statement\] of Rab Judah \[who\] asked:[^fn_8a_35] It is written, And God created man in his own image,[^fn_8a_36] and it is written, Male and female created He them.[^fn_8a_37] How is this \[to be understood\]? \[In this way:\] In the beginning it was the intention[^fn_8a_38] \[of God\] to create two \[human beings\], and in the end \[only\] one \[human being\] was created.

R. Ashi came to the house of R. Kahana.[^fn_8a_39] The first day[^fn_8a_40] he said all the benedictions.[^fn_8a_41] From then and further on;[^fn_8a_42] if there were new guests[^fn_8a_43] he said all the benedictions, but if not \[he declared\] it to be merely a continuance of the same joy[^fn_8a_44] \[in which case\] one says \[only\] the benedictions 'in whose dwelling there is joy'[^fn_8a_45] and 'who has created'.[^fn_8a_46] From the seventh day to the thirtieth day.[^fn_8a_47] whether he[^fn_8a_48] said to them[^fn_8a_49] 'because of the wedding[^fn_8a_50] or whether he did not say to them 'because of the wedding', one says the benediction 'in whose dwelling there is joy'.[^fn_8a_51] From then[^fn_8a_52] and further on;[^fn_8a_53] if he said to them 'because of the wedding' he says the benediction 'in whose dwelling there is joy', but not otherwise.[^fn_8a_54] And if he says to them 'because of the wedding', until when \[is this benediction said\]?[^fn_8a_55] Said R. Papi in the name of Raba: Twelve months \[forming\] a year.[^fn_8a_56] And at first[^fn_8a_57] from when?[^fn_8a_58] Said R. Papa: From the time that they put barley into the mortar.[^fn_8a_59] But this is not so? Did not R. Papa busy himself for his son Abba Mar[^fn_8a_60] and say the benediction[^fn_8a_61] from the time of the betrothal? — It was different \[in the case of\] A. Papa, because he took the trouble \[of preparing everything for the wedding\].[^fn_8a_62] Rabina busied himself for his son[^fn_8a_63] in the house of R. Habiba and said the benediction[^fn_8a_61] from the time of the betrothal. He said: I am sure with regard to them that they will not retract \[the betrothal\].[^fn_8a_64] \[But\] the matter was not successful[^fn_8a_65] and they did retract. R. Tahlifa, son of the West,[^fn_8a_66] came to Babylon \[and\] said six long benedictions.[^fn_8a_67] But the law is not according to him. R. Habiba came into the house of a circumcision[^fn_8a_68] \[and\] said the benediction 'in whose dwelling there is joy.' But the law is not according to him, since they are distressed because the child has pain.

R. Nahman said \[that\] Rab said: Bridegrooms are of the number, and mourners are not of the number.[^fn_8a_69] An objection was raised: Bridegrooms and mourners are of the number? — You ask \[from\] a Baraitha against Rab?[^fn_8a_70] Rab is a Tanna and differs![^fn_8a_71] It has been said: R. Isaac said \[that\] R. Johanan said: Bridegrooms are of the number, and mourners are not of the number. An objection was raised: Bridegrooms and mourners are of the number?[^fn_8a_72] — [pg 8b]

With regard to what was that taught?[^fn_8b_1] With regard to Grace after meals;[^fn_8b_2] \[and\] with regard to what did R. Johanan say \[this ruling\]?[^fn_8b_3] With regard to the line \[of comforters\].[^fn_8b_4] But \[then\] what of the dictum[^fn_8b_5] of which )R. Isaac said \[that\] R. Johanan said: 'One says the benediction[^fn_8b_6] of the bridegrooms in the presence of ten \[male persons\] and the bridegrooms are of the number, and \[one says\] the benediction of the mourners[^fn_8b_7] in the presence of ten \[male persons\] and the mourners are not of the number' — is there a benediction \[said\] in the line \[of comforters\]?[^fn_8b_8] — But \[the answer is\]: With regard to what did R. Johanan say \[this ruling\]?[^fn_8b_3] with regard to the \[benediction recited in the\] open space.[^fn_8b_9] But \[then\] what of the dictum which R. Isaac said \[that\] R. Johanan said: 'One says the benediction of the bridegrooms in the presence of ten \[male persons\] all the seven \[days\][^fn_8b_10] and the bridegrooms are of the number, and \[one says\] the benediction of the mourners in the presence of ten \[male persons\] all the seven \[days\][^fn_8b_11] and the mourners are not of the number — is the benediction \[recited in\] the open space said all the seven days?[^fn_8b_12] — It is possible in the presence of new friends[^fn_8b_13] — as in the case of[^fn_8b_14] R. Hiyya. the son of Abba, \[who was\] the Bible teacher of the son[^fn_8b_15] of Resh Lakish, or, as some say,[^fn_8b_16] the Mishnah teacher of the son of Resh Lakish. \[It happened as follows:\] A child \[of R. Hiyya, the son of Abba\] died,[^fn_8b_17] The first day[^fn_8b_18] he \[Resh Lakish\] did not go to him. The next day[^fn_8b_19] he \[Resh Lakish\] took with him[^fn_8b_20] Judah the son of Nahmani,[^fn_8b_21] his meturgeman.[^fn_8b_22] \[and\] said to him: Rise \[and\] say something[^fn_8b_23] with regard to[^fn_8b_24] \[the death of\] the child. He spoke[^fn_8b_25] and said: \[It is written.\] And the Lord saw and spurned, because of the provoking of His sons and His daughters.[^fn_8b_26] \[This means, in\] a generation \[in which the fathers spurn the Holy One, blessed be He, He is angry with their sons and their daughters and they die when they are young.[^fn_8b_27] And some say \[that\] he \[the child of R. Hiyya, the son of Abba, that died\] was a young man[^fn_8b_28] and that he \[Judah the son of Nahmani\] said thus to him:[^fn_8b_29] Therefore the Lord shall have no joy in their young men, neither shall He have compassion on their fatherless and widows; for every one is profane and an evil-doer, and every mouth speaketh folly. For all this His anger is not turned away, but His hand is stretched out still.[^fn_8b_30] (What is the meaning[^fn_8b_31] of 'but His hand is stretched out still'? Said R. Hanan, the son of Rab:[^fn_8b_32] All know for what purpose[^fn_8b_33] a bride is brought into the bridal chamber, but whoever disgraces his mouth and utters[^fn_8b_34] a word of folly-even if a \[divine\] decree[^fn_8b_35] of seventy years of happiness[^fn_8b_36] were sealed \[and granted\] unto him,[^fn_8b_37] it is turned for him into evil.) — He came to comfort, \[and\] he grieved him? This he said to him: Thou art important enough to be held responsible[^fn_8b_38] for \[the shortcomings of\] the generation.[^fn_8b_39] He[^fn_8b_40] \[then\] said to him:[^fn_8b_41] Rise \[and\] say something with regard to the praise of the Holy One, blessed be He He spoke and said: The God,[^fn_8b_42] who is great in the abundance of His greatness, mighty and strong in the multitude of awe-inspiring deeds, who reviveth the dead with his word,[^fn_8b_43] who does great things that are unsearchable[^fn_8b_44] and wondrous works without number.[^fn_8b_45] Blessed art thou, O Lord, who revivest the dead.[^fn_8b_46] He[^fn_8b_47] then 'said to him:[^fn_8b_48] Rise \[and\] say something with regard to the mourners. He spoke and said: Our brethren, who are worn out, who are crushed by this bereavement,[^fn_8b_49] set your heart to consider[^fn_8b_50] this: This it is \[that\] stands for ever,[^fn_8b_51] it is a path from the six days of creation.[^fn_8b_52] Many have drunk, many will drink,[^fn_8b_53] as the drinking of the first ones, so will be that of the last ones. Our brethren, the Lord of consolation comfort you. Blessed be He who comforteth the mourners. (Said Abaye: 'Many have drunk' he should have said, 'many will drink' one should not have said, 'the drinking of the first ones', he should have said, 'the drinking of the last ones' one should not have said, for R. Simeon, the son of Lakish,[^fn_8b_54] said, and so one has taught in the name of R. Jose: Man should never open his mouth to Satan.[^fn_8b_55] Said R. Joseph: What text \[shows this\]? We should have been as Sodom, we should have been like unto Gomorrah.[^fn_8b_56] What did He[^fn_8b_57] reply unto him?[^fn_8b_58] Hear the word of the Lord, ye rulers of Sodom, etc.[^fn_8b_59] ) He[^fn_8b_60] \[then\] said to him:[^fn_8b_61] Rise \[and\] say something with regard to the comforters of the mourners.[^fn_8b_62] He spoke and said: Our brethren, bestowers of lovingkindnesses, sons of bestowers of lovingkindnesses, who hold fast to the covenant of Abraham our father[^fn_8b_63] \[for it is said, For I have known him, to the end that he may command his children, etc.\],[^fn_8b_64] our brethren, may the Lord of recompense pay you your reward. Blessed art Thou who payest the recompense. He[^fn_8b_65] \[then\] said unto him:[^fn_8b_66] Rise \[and\] say something with regard to the whole of Israel. He spoke and said: Master of the worlds, redeem and save, deliver \[and\] help Thy people Israel from pestilence,[^fn_8b_67] and from the sword, and from plundering,[^fn_8b_68] and from the blast, and from the mildew, and from all kinds of calamities that \[may\] break forth and come into[^fn_8b_69] the world. Before we call, mayest Thou answer,[^fn_8b_70] Blessed art Thou who stayest the plague.[^fn_8b_71] 'Ulla said, and some say \[that\] it was taught in a Baraitha: Ten cups \[of wine\] the scholars have instituted \[to be drunk\] in the house of the mourner: Three before the meal in order to open the small bowels, three during the meal in order to dissolve the food in the bowels, and four after the meal: one corresponding to 'who feedeth',[^fn_8b_72] one corresponding to the blessing of 'the land',[^fn_8b_72] one corresponding to 'who rebuildeth Jerusalem,[^fn_8b_72] and one corresponding to 'who is good and doeth good'.[^fn_8b_72] They \[then\] added unto them \[another\] four \[cups\]: one in honour of the officers of the town, and one in honour of the leaders of the town, and one in honour of the Temple. and one in honour of Rabban Gamaliel. \[When\] they began to drink \[too much\] and to become intoxicated, they restored the matter to its original state.[^fn_8b_73] What \[about\] Rabban Gamaliel? — As it has been taught: At first the carrying out of the dead[^fn_8b_74] was harder for his relatives[^fn_8b_75] than his death,[^fn_8b_76] so that they left him[^fn_8b_77] and ran away, until Rabban Gamaliel[^fn_8b_78] came and adopted a simple style and they carried him out[^fn_8b_79] in garments of linen, and \[then\] all the people followed his example and carried out \[the dead\][^fn_8b_80] in garments of linen. Said R. Papa: And now it is the general practice \[to carry out the dead\] even in rough cloth worth \[only\] a *zuz*.[^fn_8b_81]

R. Eleazar said: [pg 9a]

He who says. I have found an 'open opening'[^fn_9a_1] is trusted to make her forbidden for him.[^fn_9a_2] Why?[^fn_9a_3] It is a double doubt:[^fn_9a_4] It is a doubt \[whether she had the intercourse with the other man while\] under him,[^fn_9a_5] or,[^fn_9a_6] \[while\] not under him.[^fn_9a_7] And if you say[^fn_9a_8] that \[she had that intercourse while\] under him, \[there is\] the \[other\] doubt \[whether she had that intercourse\] by violence or[^fn_9a_9] by \[her free\] will! — It was necessary[^fn_9a_10] \[to state this rule\] in the case of the wife of a priest.[^fn_9a_11] And if you wish, you may say \[that it speaks of\] the wife of an Israelite,[^fn_9a_12] and for instance when her father received the betrothal for her \[when\] she was less than three years and one day old.[^fn_9a_13] What does he[^fn_9a_14] let us hear by \[this since\] we have already learnt \[it\]:[^fn_9a_15] 'If a man says[^fn_9a_16] to a woman, "I have betrothed thee \[to myself\]", and she says, "Thou hast not betrothed me \[to thyself\]," she is allowed \[to marry\] his relatives, but he is forbidden \[to marry\] her relatives.'[^fn_9a_17] — What you might have supposed is that there[^fn_9a_18] \[he causes a prohibition to himself\] because it is certain to him,[^fn_9a_19] but here it is not quite certain to him.[^fn_9a_20] \[Therefore\] he[^fn_9a_21] lets us hear \[this rule\].[^fn_9a_22] But did R. Eleazar say so? Did not R. Eleazar say: The wife does not become forbidden for her husband save in the case of[^fn_9a_23] warning[^fn_9a_24] and seclusion,[^fn_9a_25] and as \[we find in\] the occurrence that happened?[^fn_9a_26] But how can you \[in any case\] understand it?[^fn_9a_27] Was the occurrence that happened accompanied by warning and seclusion? And again, did they[^fn_9a_28] declare her[^fn_9a_29] forbidden?[^fn_9a_30] — This is no difficulty, \[for\] thus he[^fn_9a_31] means to say:[^fn_9a_32] The wife does not become forbidden for her husband save in the case of warning and seclusion, \[and this we learn\] from the occurrence that happened, because \[there\] there was no warning and seclusion and \[therefore\] she[^fn_9a_33] was not forbidden.[^fn_9a_34] But \[the former question\] is nevertheless difficult. In the \[case of\] warning and seclusion but not \[in the case of\] 'an open opening'![^fn_9a_35] — But according to your argument[^fn_9a_36] \[the question could be asked\]: \[in the case of\] warning and seclusion, yes, \[and in the case of\] witnesses,[^fn_9a_37] no! Hence he[^fn_9a_38] means to say thus: The wife does not become forbidden for her husband through one witness[^fn_9a_39] but through two witnesses;[^fn_9a_40] but in the case of warning and seclusion:[^fn_9a_41] even through one witness,[^fn_9a_42] and 'an open opening' is like two witnesses.[^fn_9a_43] And if you will say: \[In the case of\] the occurrence that happened. why did they not declare her forbidden?[^fn_9a_44] \[The answer is:\] There it was compulsion.[^fn_9a_45] And if you wish you can say as R. Samuel the son of Nahmani said[^fn_9a_46] \[that\] R. Jonathan said: [pg 9b]

Everyone who goes out into the war of the House of David writes for his wife a deed of divorce,[^fn_9b_1] for it is written, And to thy brethren shalt thou bring greetings, and take their pledge.[^fn_9b_2] What \[is the meaning of\], 'and take their pledge'? R. Joseph learnt: Things which are pledged between him and her.[^fn_9b_3]

Abaye said: We have also learned[^fn_9b_4] \[this\]:[^fn_9b_5] A MAIDEN IS MARRIED ON THE FOURTH DAY OF THE WEEK. \[This implies\] only on the fourth day, but not the fifth day.[^fn_9b_6] What is the reason? \[Presumably\] on account of the cooling of the temper.[^fn_9b_7] Now in which respect \[could the cooling of the mind have a bad result\]? If with regard to giving her the *kethubah*,[^fn_9b_8] let him give it to her.[^fn_9b_9] Consequently[^fn_9b_10] \[we must say only\] with regard to making her forbidden for him;[^fn_9b_11] and \[it is a case where\] he puts forward a claim.[^fn_9b_12] Is it not that he puts forward the claim of 'an open opening'?[^fn_9b_13] — No, \[it is a case where\] he puts forward the claim of blood.[^fn_9b_14]

Rab Judah said \[that\] Samuel said: If any one says. 'I have found an open opening', he is trusted to cause her to lose her *kethubah*. Said R. Joseph: What does he[^fn_9b_15] let us hear? We have \[already\] learned \[this\]:[^fn_9b_16] He who eats[^fn_9b_17] at his father-in-law's \[between the time of betrothal and the time of marriage\] in Judaea,[^fn_9b_18] without witnesses, cannot \[after the marriage\] raise the claim of \[the loss of\] virginity, because he is alone with her.[^fn_9b_19] In Judaea he cannot raise this claim, but in Galilee[^fn_9b_20] he can raise it. Now in which respect? If to make her forbidden for him, why \[should he\] not \[be able to raise this claim\] in Judaea?[^fn_9b_21] Consequently[^fn_9b_22] \[we must say it is\] to cause her to lose her *kethubah*;[^fn_9b_23] and \[it is in a case\] when he raises a claim. Is it not that he raises the claim of 'an open opening'? — No, when he raises the claim of blood.[^fn_9b_24] [pg 10a]

It was stated: Rab Nahman said \[that\] Samuel said in the name of R. Simeon b. Eleazar: The scholars ordained for the daughters of Israel \[as follows\]: for a maiden two hundred \[zuz[^fn_10a_1]\] and for a widow a *maneh*[^fn_10a_2] \[one hundred *zuz*\].[^fn_10a_3] And they trusted him, so that when he said, 'I have found an open opening', he is believed.[^fn_10a_4] If so, what have the Sages accomplished with their ordinance?[^fn_10a_5] — Said Raba: The presumption is \[that\] no one will take the trouble of preparing a \[wedding-\]feast and will then spoil it.[^fn_10a_6] One has taught: Since it[^fn_10a_7] is a fine \[instituted\] by the sages she[^fn_10a_8] shall collect only from the worst land[^fn_10a_9] \[of the husband's estate\]. \[You say\] a fine! Why a fine?[^fn_10a_10] — Say then: since it is an ordinance of the sages,[^fn_10a_11] she shall collect only from the worst land \[of the husband's estate\]. Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel says: The *kethubah* of a wife is from the Torah.[^fn_10a_12] But did Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel say so? Surely it has been taught: \[It is written in the Torah\] He shall pay money according to the dowry of virgins;[^fn_10a_13] \[this teaches us that\] this[^fn_10a_14] is \[as much\] as the dowry of the virgins[^fn_10a_15] and the dowry of the virgins is \[as much\] as this.[^fn_10a_16] But,[^fn_10a_17] the Sages found a support for \[the rule that\] the *kethubah* of a wife is from the Torah. Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel Says: The *kethubah* of a wife is not from the words of the Bible, but from the words of the *Soferim*![^fn_10a_18] — Reverse it.[^fn_10a_19] And why does it appear to you right to reverse[^fn_10a_20] the latter \[teaching\]? Reverse the former \[teaching\]![^fn_10a_21] — We have \[already\] heard that R. Simeon the son of Gamaliel said that the *kethubah* is from the Bible, for we learnt: Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel says: He[^fn_10a_22] gives her[^fn_10a_23] \[the *kethubah*\] in Cappadocian coins.[^fn_10a_24] And if you wish, you may say: The whole of it[^fn_10a_25] is \[according to\] Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel. only[^fn_10a_26] it is defective[^fn_10a_27] and it teaches thus:[^fn_10a_28] Here the Sages found a support for \[the rule that\] the *kethubah* of a wife is from the Torah. The *kethubah* of a widow \[however\] is not from the words of the Torah but from the words of the *Soferim*, for Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel Says: The *kethubah* of a widow is not from the words of the Torah but from the words of the *Soferim*.[^fn_10a_29]

Someone came before R. Nahman \[and\] said to him: I have found an open opening.[^fn_10a_30] R. Nahman answered:[^fn_10a_31] Lash him with palm-switches; harlots[^fn_10a_32] lie prostrate before him.[^fn_10a_33] But it is R. Nahman who said that he \[the husband\] is believed![^fn_10a_34] — He is believed, but \[at the same time\] one lashes him with palm-switches. R. Ahai answered: Here[^fn_10a_35] \[it speaks\] of a young man,[^fn_10a_36] there \[it speaks\] of one who was married before.[^fn_10a_37]

Some one came before Rabban Gamaliel \[and\] said to him, I have found an 'open opening'. He \[Rabban Gamaliel\] answered him: Perhaps you moved aside.[^fn_10a_38] I will give you an illustration: To what is this like? To a man who was walking in the deep darkness of the night[^fn_10a_39] \[and came to his house and found the door locked\];[^fn_10a_40] if he moves aside \[the bolt[^fn_10a_41] of the door\] he finds it open, if he does not move aside \[the bolt of the door\] he finds it locked. Some say \[that\] he \[R. Gamaliel\] answered him thus: Perhaps you moved aside wilfully[^fn_10a_42] and you tore away the door and the bar.[^fn_10a_43] I will give you an illustration: To what is this like? To a man who was walking in the deep darkness of the night \[and came to his house and found the door locked\]; if he moves aside \[the bolt of the door\] wilfully[^fn_10a_44] he finds it open, if he does

         not move aside \[the bolt of the door\] wilfully he finds it locked.

Some one came before Rabban Gamaliel the son of Rabbi \[and\] said to him, 'My master, I have had intercourse \[with my newly-wedded wife\] and I have not found any blood.' She \[the wife\] said to him, 'My master, I was a virgin.' He said to them: Bring me that cloth.[^fn_10a_45] They brought him the cloth, and he soaked it in water and he washed it and he found on it a good many drops of blood.[^fn_10a_46] \[Thereupon\] he \[Rabban Gamaliel\] said to him \[the husband\]: Go, be happy with thy bargain.[^fn_10a_47] Huna Mar the son of Raba of Parazika,[^fn_10a_48] said to R. Ashi: Shall we also do it?[^fn_10a_49] He answered him: [pg 10b]

Our[^fn_10b_1] laundry work[^fn_10b_2] is like their[^fn_10b_3] washing.[^fn_10b_4] And if you will say let us do laundry work,[^fn_10b_5] \[my answer is\] the smoothing stone will remove it.[^fn_10b_6] Someone came before Rabban Gamaliel the son of Rabbi \[and\] said to him, 'My master, I have had intercourse \[with my newly-wedded wife\] and I have not found any blood.' She \[the wife\] said to him, 'My master, I am still a virgin.' He \[then\] said to them: Bring me two handmaids, one \[who is\] a virgin and one who had intercourse with a man. They brought to him \[two such handmaids\], and he placed them upon a cask of wine. \[In the case of\]

         the one who was no more a virgin its smell[^fn_10b_7]   went through,[^fn_10b_8]   \[in the case of\] the virgin the smell did not go through.[^fn_10b_9] He \[then\] placed this one \[the young wife\] also \[on a cask of wine\]. and its smell[^fn_10b_10] did not go through. He[^fn_10b_11] \[then\] said to him:[^fn_10b_12] Go, be happy with thy bargain.[^fn_10b_13] — But he should have examined her from the very beginning![^fn_10b_14] — He had heard a tradition,[^fn_10b_15] but he had not seen it done in practice.[^fn_10b_16] and he thought. The matter might not be certain[^fn_10b_17] and it would not be proper[^fn_10b_18] to deal lightly with daughters of Israel.[^fn_10b_19]

Someone came before Rabban Gamaliel the elder \[and\] said to him, 'My master, I have had intercourse \[with my newly-wedded wife\] and I have not found any blood. She \[the wife\] said to him, 'My master, I am of the family of Dorkati, \[the women of\] which have neither blood of menstruation nor blood of virginity.' Rabban Gamaliel investigated among her women relatives and he found \[the facts to be\] in accordance with her words. He \[then\] said to him: Go, be happy with thy bargain. Happy art thou that thou hast been privileged \[to marry a woman\] of the family of Dorkati. What is \[the meaning of\] Dorkati? — A cut-off generation.[^fn_10b_20] — R. Hanina said: Vain consolation Rabban Gamaliel offered[^fn_10b_21] to that man, for R. Hiyya taught: As the leaven is wholesome for the dough, so is blood wholesome for a woman. And one has \[also\] taught in the name of R. Meir: Every woman who has abundant blood has many children. It has been said: R, Jeremiah b. Abba said: He \[Rabban Gamaliel\] said to him \[the husband\]: Be happy with thy bargain. But R. Jose b. Abin said: He said to him: thou hast been punished with thy bargain.[^fn_10b_22] We quite understand

         the one who says 'Thou hast been punished' with thy bargain — this is \[according to the view\] of R. Hanina. But according to him who says 'Be happy' \[with thy bargain\], what is the advantage \[of such a marriage\]? — He \[the husband\] does not come to any doubt regarding menstruation.

Someone came to Rabbi \[and\] said, 'My master, I have had intercourse \[with my newly-wedded wife\] and I have not found any blood.' She said, 'My master, I was \[and am\] still a virgin, and it was \[a period of\] years of dearth.' Rabbi saw that their faces were black,[^fn_10b_23] \[and\] he commanded concerning them, and they[^fn_10b_24] brought them[^fn_10b_25] to a bath and gave them to eat and to drink and brought them to the bridal chamber, and he had intercourse with her and found blood. He[^fn_10b_26] \[then\] said to him: Go, be happy with thy bargain. Rabbi applied to them the verse:[^fn_10b_27] *Their skin is shrivelled upon their bodies,' it is withered, it is become like a stick*.[^fn_10b_28]

***MISHNAH***. A MAIDEN — HER *KETHUBAH* IS TWO HUNDRED \[*ZUZ*\],[^fn_10b_29] AND A WIDOW — A *MANEH*.[^fn_10b_30] A MAIDEN, WHO IS A WIDOW, \[OR\] DIVORCED, OR A *HALUZAH*[^fn_10b_31] FROM BETROTHAL[^fn_10b_32] — HER *KETHUBAH*[^fn_10b_33] IS TWO HUNDRED \[*ZUZ*\], AND THERE LIES AGAINST THEM THE CHARGE OF NON-VIRGINITY.[^fn_10b_34] {¶=1.2}

***GEMARA***. Why \[is a widow called\] 'almanah'? R. Hana of Bagdad said: because of the *maneh*.[^fn_10b_35] But what can be said with

         regard to a widow from the betrothal?[^fn_10b_36] — Because that one is called 'almanah'[^fn_10b_37] this one is also called 'almanah.'[^fn_10b_38] What can be said with regard to \[the word\] 'almanah', that is written in the Bible?[^fn_10b_39] — \[The woman\] for whom the Rabbis will in future institute \[the *kethubah* of\] a *maneh*. But does the Bible speak of a thing which will be in the future?[^fn_10b_40] — Yes, for it is written: And the name of the third river is Hiddekel, that is it which goeth towards the east of Ashur,[^fn_10b_41] and R. Joseph learnt: Ashur, that is Seleucia. But was \[Seleucia\] already then in existence? But \[it is mentioned\] because it will exist in the future. Here also 'almanah' is mentioned in the Bible\] because it \[the *kethubah* of *maneh*\] will exist in the future.

R. Hana of Bagdad also said: The rain waters, saturates and manures \[the earth\] and refreshes[^fn_10b_42] and enlarges[^fn_10b_43] \[the fruits\]. Raba the son of R. Ishmael, and some say R. Yemar the son of Shelemiah, said: Which is the verse?[^fn_10b_44] \[It is this:\] Thou waterest the ridges abundantly, thou settlest the furrows thereof, thou makest it soft with showers, thou blessest the springing thereof.[^fn_10b_45]

R. Eleazar said: The altar removes and feeds, makes beloved, atones.[^fn_10b_46] Have not 'atones' and 'removes' the same meaning?[^fn_10b_47] It removes \[evil decrees\][^fn_10b_48] and atones for sins R. Hana of Bagdad also said: Dates warm, satisfy, act as a laxative,[^fn_10b_49] strengthen[^fn_10b_50] and do not make \[one\] delicate.

         Rab said: If one has eaten dates, he should not give a legal decision. An objection was raised. Dates are wholesome morning and evening, in the afternoon they are bad, at noon they are incomparable.[^fn_10b_51] and they remove three things: evil thought, stress          of the bowels, and abdominal troubles! — Do we say that they are no good? They are indeed good. only for the moment \[they cause\] unsteadiness. It is analogous to wine, for the Master said:[^fn_10b_52] He who has drunk[^fn_10b_53] one-fourth \[of a *log*\][^fn_10b_54] of wine shall not give a legal decision.[^fn_10b_55] And if you wish you may say: There is no difficulty: This is before a meal and that is after a meal,[^fn_10b_56] for Abaye said: Mother[^fn_10b_57] told me: Dates before a meal are as an axe to the palmtree,[^fn_10b_58] after a meal as a bar to the door.[^fn_10b_59] Dasha \[door\], Raba explained:[^fn_10b_60] derek sham[^fn_10b_61] \['the way there'\].[^fn_10b_62] Darga \[stairs, ladder\]. Raba explained:[^fn_10b_63] derek gag \[the way of the roof\].[^fn_10b_64] Puria \[bed\], R. Papa explained: sheparin we-rabin 'aleha \[because one is fruitful and multiplies on it\]. R. Nahman b. Isaac said: [pg 11a]

We will also say:[^fn_11a_1] ailonith \[the barren woman that is\] a man-like[^fn_11a_2] woman, who does not bear children.[^fn_11a_3]

***MISHNAH***. A WOMAN PROSELYTE, A WOMAN CAPTIVE, AND A WOMAN SLAVE, WHO HAVE BEEN REDEEMED, CONVERTED, OR FREED \[WHEN THEY WERE\] LESS THAN THREE YEARS AND ONE DAY OLD — THEIR *KETHUBAH* IS TWO HUNDRED \[*ZUZ*\]. AND THERE IS WITH REGARD TO THEM THE CLAIM OF \[NON-\]VIRGINITY.[^fn_11a_4] {¶=1.3}

         ***GEMARA***. R. Huna said: A minor proselyte[^fn_11a_5]   is immersed[^fn_11a_6] by the direction[^fn_11a_7] of the court.[^fn_11a_8] What does he let us know? That it is an advantage[^fn_11a_9] to him and one may act for a person in his absence[^fn_11a_10] to his advantage? \[Surely\] we have learned \[this already\]: One may act for a person in his absence to his advantage. but one cannot act for a person in his absence to his disadvantage! … What you might have supposed is that an idolator[^fn_11a_11] prefers a life without restraint[^fn_11a_12] because it is established for us that a slave certainly prefers a dissolute life,[^fn_11a_13] therefore, he[^fn_11a_14] lets us know that this is said[^fn_11a_15] \[only in the case\] of a grown-up person who has already tasted sin,[^fn_11a_16] but \[in the case of\] a minor, it is an advantage to him.[^fn_11a_17] May we say that \[this Mishnah\] supports him:[^fn_11a_18] A WOMAN PROSELYTE, A WOMAN CAPTIVE, AND A WOMAN SLAVE, WHO HAVE BEEN REDEEMED, CONVERTED, OR FREED \[WHEN THEY WERE\] LESS THAN THREE YEARS AND ONE DAY OLD \[etc.\]? Is it not that they immersed them[^fn_11a_19] by the direction of the Court?[^fn_11a_20] No, here we treat of the case of a proselyte whose sons and daughters were converted with him, so that they are satisfied with what their father does.[^fn_11a_21]

R. Joseph said: When they[^fn_11a_22] have become of age they can protest \[against their conversion\].[^fn_11a_23]

Abaye asked:[^fn_11a_24] A WOMAN PROSELYTE, A WOMAN CAPTIVE, AND A WOMAN SLAVE, WHO HAVE BEEN REDEEMED, CONVERTED OR FREED \[WHEN THEY WERE\] LESS THAN THREE YEARS AND ONE DAY OLD — THEIR *KETHUBAH* IS TWO HUNDRED \[*ZUZ*\]. Now if you indeed mean to say \[that\] when they have become of age they can protest \[against their conversion\],[^fn_11a_25] would we give her the *kethubah* that she may go and eat \[it\] in her heathen state? — When she has become of age.[^fn_11a_26] \[But\] when she has become of age, too, she can protest and go out![^fn_11a_27] — As soon as she was of age one hour, and did not protest, she cannot protest any more.[^fn_11a_28]

Raba raised an objection: These maidens receive the fine:[^fn_11a_29] if a man has intercourse with[^fn_11a_30] a bastard,[^fn_11a_31] a Nethinah,[^fn_11a_32] a Cuthean,[^fn_11a_33] a proselyte, a captive. or a slave, who have been redeemed, converted, or freed \[when they were\] less than three years and one day old-they have to be paid the fine.[^fn_11a_34] Now if you say \[that\] when they have become of age they can protest, would we give her[^fn_11a_35] the fine that she may go and eat it in her heathen state? — When she has become of age.[^fn_11a_36] When she has become of age too she can protest and go out![^fn_11a_37] — As soon as she was of age one hour and did not protest she cannot protest any more.[^fn_11a_38] Abaye did not say as Raba \[said\][^fn_11a_39] \[because\] there[^fn_11a_40] \[where it speaks of fines

         we can say\]: This is the reason:[^fn_11a_41] that the sinner should not have any benefit.[^fn_11a_42] Raba did not say as Abaye \[said\][^fn_11a_43] because in the case of the *kethubah* \[we can say that\] this is the reason:[^fn_11a_44] that it[^fn_11a_45] should not be a light matter in his eyes to send her away.[^fn_11a_46]

***MISHNAH***. WHEN A GROWN-UP MAN[^fn_11a_47] HAS HAD SEXUAL INTERCOURSE WITH[^fn_11a_48] A LITTLE GIRL,[^fn_11a_49] OR WHEN A SMALL BOY[^fn_11a_50] HAS INTERCOURSE WITH A GROWN-UP WOMAN, OR \[WHEN A GIRL WAS ACCIDENTALLY\] INJURED BY A PIECE OF WOOD[^fn_11a_51] — \[IN ALL THESE CASES\] THEIR *KETHUBAH* IS TWO HUNDRED \[*ZUZ*\]; SO ACCORDING TO[^fn_11a_52] R. MEIR. BUT THE SAGES SAY: A GIRL WHO WAS INJURED ACCIDENTALLY BY A PIECE OF WOOD — HER *KETHUBAH* IS A *MANEH*. A VIRGIN, WHO WAS A WIDOW, A DIVORCEE, OR A *HALUZAH* FROM MARRIAGE[^fn_11a_53] — HER[^fn_11a_54] *KETHUBAH* IS A *MANEH*.[^fn_11a_55] [pg 11b] {¶=1.4}

AND THERE IS WITH REGARD TO THEM NO CHARGE OF NONVIRGINITY. A WOMAN PROSELYTE, A WOMAN CAPTIVE AND A WOMAN SLAVE, WHO HAVE BEEN REDEEMED, CONVERTED, OR FREED \[WHEN THEY WERE\] MORE THAN THREE YEARS AND ONE DAY OLD — THEIR *KETHUBAH* IS A *MANEH*, AND THERE IS WITH REGARD TO THEM NO CHARGE OF NON-VIRGINITY.

***GEMARA***. Rab Judah said that Rab said: A small boy who

         has intercourse with a grown-up woman makes her \[as though she were\] injured by a piece of wood.[^fn_11b_1]   When I said it before Samuel he said: 'Injured by a piece of wood' does not apply to[^fn_11b_2] flesh. Some teach this teaching by itself:[^fn_11b_3] \[As to\] a small boy who has intercourse with a grown-up woman. Rab said, he makes her \[as though she were\] injured by a piece of wood; whereas Samuel said: 'Injured by a piece of wood' does not apply to flesh. R. Oshaia objected: WHEN A GROWN-UP MAN HAS HAD INTERCOURSE WITH A LITTLE GIRL, OR WHEN A SMALL BOY HAS INTERCOURSE WITH A GROWN-UP WOMAN, OR WHEN A GIRL WAS ACCIDENTALLY INJURED BY A PIECE OF WOOD — \[IN ALL THESE CASES\] THEIR *KETHUBAH* IS TWO HUNDRED \[*ZUZ*\]; SO ACCORDING TO R. MEIR. BUT THE SAGES SAY: A GIRL WHO WAS INJURED ACCIDENTALLY BY A PIECE OF WOOD — HER *KETHUBAH* IS A *MANEH*![^fn_11b_4] Raba said, It means[^fn_11b_5] this: When a grown-up man has intercourse with a little girl it is nothing, for when the girl is less than this,[^fn_11b_6]   it is as if one puts the finger into the eye;[^fn_11b_7]   but when a small boy has intercourse with a grown-up woman he makes her as 'a girl who is injured by a piece of wood,' and \[with regard to the case of\] 'a girl injured by a piece of wood,' itself, there is the difference of opinion between R. Meir and the Sages.

Rami b. Hama said: The difference of opinion[^fn_11b_8] is \[only\] when he[^fn_11b_9] knew her,[^fn_11b_10] for R. Meir compares her[^fn_11b_11] to a mature girl,[^fn_11b_12] and
