         the Sages compare her to a woman who had intercourse with a man.[^fn_11b_13] But if he did not know her,[^fn_11b_14] all agree[^fn_11b_15] that she has nothing.[^fn_11b_16] And why does R. Meir compare her to a mature girl? Let him compare her to a woman who had intercourse with a man! — \[In the case of\] a woman who had intercourse with a man, a deed had been done to her by a man;[^fn_11b_17] but in her case[^fn_11b_18] — no deed has been done to her by a man. — And why do the Rabbis compare[^fn_11b_19] her to a woman who had intercourse with a man? Let them compare her to a mature girl! \[In the case of\] a mature girl no deed whatsoever has been done to her,[^fn_11b_20] but in her case — a deed has been done to her.[^fn_11b_21]

'But if he did not know her, all agree that she gets nothing'.[^fn_11b_22] R. Nahman objected: If she says. 'I was injured by a piece of wood,' and he says. 'No, but thou hadst intercourse with a man', Rabban Gamaliel and R. Eliezer say \[that\] she is believed![^fn_11b_23] But, said Raba, whether he knew her[^fn_11b_24] and whether he did not know her,[^fn_11b_25] according to R. Meir \[her *kethubah* is\] two hundred \[*zuz*\];[^fn_11b_26] \[whereas\] according to the Rabbis, if he knew her \[her *kethubah* is\] a *maneh*, \[if\] he did not know her, she gets nothing.[^fn_11b_27]

Raba however changed his opinion,[^fn_11b_28] for it has been taught: How \[does\] the bringing out of an evil name[^fn_11b_29] \[take place\]? He[^fn_11b_30] comes to court and says, 'I, So-and-so,[^fn_11b_31] have not found in thy daughter the tokens of virginity.' If there are witnesses that she has been unchaste under him,[^fn_11b_32] she gets a[^fn_11b_33] *kethubah* of a *maneh*.[^fn_11b_34] \[But surely\] if there are witnesses that she has been unchaste under him, she is to be stoned![^fn_11b_35] — It means this: If there are witnesses that she has been unchaste under him, she has to be stoned; if she was unchaste before \[the betrothal\], she gets a *kethubah* of a *maneh*. Now R. Hiyya b. Abin said \[that\] R. Shesheth said: This teaches:[^fn_11b_36] If he married her in the presumption that she is a virgin and she was found to have had intercourse with a man,[^fn_11b_37] she gets a *kethubah* of a *maneh*. Whereupon R. Nahman objected: 'If one marries a woman and does not find in her virginity, \[and\] she says, "After thou hadst betrothed me \[to thyself\] I was forced[^fn_11b_38] and \[thus\] thy[^fn_11b_39] field has been inundated," and he says, "No, but before I betrothed thee \[unto me\] \[thou hadst intercourse with a man\], my bargain is \[thus\] a mistaken one." \[etc.\]'[^fn_11b_40] and \[this assuredly means\] she is to get nothing![^fn_11b_41] And R. Hiyya b. Abin said to them: Is it possible! R. Amram and all the great ones of the age sat[^fn_11b_42] when R. Shesheth said that teaching and they found it difficult[^fn_11b_43] and he[^fn_11b_44] answered: In which respect is it indeed a mistaken bargain? In respect of two hundred \[*zuz*:\], but a *maneh* she gets \[as a *kethubah*\]. And you[^fn_11b_45] say \[that it means\] she gets nothing! Whereupon Raba said: He who asked \[this question\][^fn_11b_46] has asked well, for a mistaken bargain' means entirely.[^fn_11b_47] But \[then\] that \[other teaching\] presents a difficulty.[^fn_11b_48] Put \[it\] right[^fn_11b_49] and say thus: If there are witnesses that she was unchaste under him[^fn_11b_50] she has to be stoned, if she was unchaste before \[the betrothal\], she gets nothing, if she was found to be injured by a piece of wood, she has a *kethubah* of a *maneh*. But Surely it was Raba who said \[above that\], according to the Rabbis, if he did not know her, she gets nothing![^fn_11b_51] Hence you must conclude[^fn_11b_52] from this[^fn_11b_53] that Raba retracted from that \[opinion\].[^fn_11b_54]

Our Rabbis taught: If the first \[husband\] took her \[the bride\] to his home for the purpose of marriage. and she has witnesses that she was not alone \[with him,\][^fn_11b_55] or even if she was alone \[with him\]. but she did not stay \[with him\] as much time as is needed for intercourse, the second \[husband\][^fn_11b_56] cannot raise any complaint with regard to her virginity, for the first \[husband\] had taken her to his home \[for the purpose of marriage\].[^fn_11b_57] [pg 12a]

Rabbah said: This teaches that if he married her in the presumption that she was a virgin and she was found to have had intercourse she gets a *kethubah* of a *maneh*.[^fn_12a_1] R. Ashi said: \[No.\] generally.I can tell you. she receives indeed nothing; but it is different here, because the first one had married her.[^fn_12a_2] But let us apprehend that perhaps she was unchaste under him![^fn_12a_3] — Said R. Sherabia: \[We\] suppose he betrothed her to himself and had immediately intercourse with her.[^fn_12a_4]

Some[^fn_12a_5] there are who refer this[^fn_12a_6] to our Mishnah: A VIRGIN, WHO IS A WIDOW, A DIVORCEE OR A *HALUZAH* FROM MARRIAGE, — HER *KETHUBAH*[^fn_12a_7] IS A *MANEH* AND THERE IS NO CLAIM OF VIRGINITY WITH REGARD TO THEM. A VIRGIN FROM MARRIAGE' — how is it possible? — When she was brought into the bridal chamber and no intercourse took Place. Rabbah said: This teaches that if he married her in the presumption that she was a virgin and she was found to have had intercourse she gets a *kethubah* of a *maneh*.[^fn_12a_8] R. Ashi said: \[No.\] indeed, I can tell you. generally she gets nothing; but it is different here, because she was brought into the bridal chamber.[^fn_12a_9] But let us apprehend that perhaps she was unchaste under him![^fn_12a_10] — Said R. Sherabia: When he betrothed her to himself and had immediately intercourse with her.[^fn_12a_11] He who refers this[^fn_12a_12] to the Baraitha,[^fn_12a_13] how much more \[would this apply\] to our Mishnah.[^fn_12a_14] But he who refers this to our Mishnah would not apply it to the Baraitha, because he could say unto her, 'I have relied upon the witnesses.'[^fn_12a_15]

***MISHNAH***. HE WHO EATS WITH HIS FATHER-IN-LAW IN JUDAEA WITHOUT THE PRESENCE OF WITNESSES CANNOT RAISE A COMPLAINT REGARDING THE VIRGINITY. BECAUSE HE HAS BEEN ALONE WITH HER.[^fn_12a_16] {¶=1.5}

***GEMARA***. Since it says[^fn_12a_17] in the Mishnah HE WHO EATS,[^fn_12a_18] It follows that there are places also in Judaea where one does not eat.[^fn_12a_19] Abaye said: Conclude from this that in Judaea, too, the places differ in their custom, as it was taught: R. Judah said: In Judaea they used formerly to leave the bridegroom and the bride alone one hour before their entry into the bridal chamber, so that he may become intimate with her,[^fn_12a_20] but in Galilee they did not do so. In Judaea they used formerly to put up two best men,[^fn_12a_21] one for him and one for her, in order to examine the bridegroom and the bride when they enter the bridal chamber,[^fn_12a_22] and in Galilee they did not do so. In Judaea. formerly. the best men used to sleep in the house in which the bridegroom and the bride slept, and in Galilee they did not do so. And he who did not act according to this custom could not raise the charge of non-virginity.[^fn_12a_23] To which \[does this[^fn_12a_24] refer\]? Shall I say \[that it refers\] to the first clause?[^fn_12a_25] \[If so,\] It ought to read, 'He who acted[^fn_12a_26] \[according to this custom\]!' Again[^fn_12a_27] \[if you will say that it refers\] to the last clause,[^fn_12a_28] it ought to read, 'He who was not examined!'[^fn_12a_29] — Abaye said: Indeed \[it refers\] to the first clause, so read.[^fn_12a_30] 'He who acted \[according to this custom\].' Said Raba to him: But it reads,[^fn_12a_31] He who did not act!' But. said Raba. it means thus: He who did not act according to the custom of Galilee in Galilee but \[acted\] according to the custom of Judaea in Galilee cannot raise the claim of virginity. R. Ashi said: Indeed \[it refers\] to the last clause,[^fn_12a_32] and we should read,[^fn_12a_33] 'He who was not examined.'[^fn_12a_34]

***MISHNAH***. IT IS ALL ONE WHETHER \[THE WOMAN IS\] AN ISRAELITISH WIDOW OR A PRIESTLY WIDOW[^fn_12a_35] — HER *KETHUBAH* IS A *MANEH*. THE COURT OF THE PRIESTS[^fn_12a_36] COLLECTED FOR A MAIDEN[^fn_12a_37] FOUR HUNDRED *ZUZ*, AND THE SAGES DID NOT PROHIBIT \[IT\] TO THEM.[^fn_12a_38] {¶=1.6}

***GEMARA***. A Tanna taught: And the priestly widow-her ketubah is two hundred \[*zuz*\]. But we have taught in our Mishnah: AN ISRAELITISH WIDOW AS WELL AS A PRIESTLY WIDOW — HER *KETHUBAH* IS A *MANEH*! — Said R. Ashi: There were two ordinances. At first they[^fn_12a_39] ordained for a maiden four hundred *zuz* and for a widow a *maneh*. [pg 12b]

When they saw that they[^fn_12b_1] treated them[^fn_12b_2] lightly.[^fn_12b_3] they ordained for them[^fn_12b_4] two hundred \[*zuz*\]. When they saw \[again\] that they[^fn_12b_5] kept away from them,[^fn_12b_6] for they[^fn_12b_7] said, 'Instead of marrying a priestly widow, we shall rather marry[^fn_12b_8] the virgin-daughter of an Israelite,'[^fn_12b_9] they restored their \[former\] ordinance.[^fn_12b_10]

THE COURT OF OUR PRIESTS, etc. R. Judah said \[that\] Samuel said: They[^fn_12b_11] did not say it only \[regarding\] the court of the priests.[^fn_12b_12] but even the noble families[^fn_12b_13] in Israel, if they want to do as[^fn_12b_14] the priests do,[^fn_12b_15] may do \[so\]. An objection was raised: If one wants to do as[^fn_12b_14] the priests do,[^fn_12b_15] for instance \[if\] the daughter of an Israelite \[gets\] married to a priest. or the daughter of a priest \[gets married\] to an Israelite, one may do \[so\]. \[We would infer from this that only if\] the daughter of an Israelite \[gets married\] to a priest, or the daughter of a priest \[gets married\] to an Israelite, \[it is allowed to do as the priests do\], because there is \[then\] one side of priesthood.[^fn_12b_16] but if the daughter of an Israelite \[gets married\] to an Israelite, it is not \[allowed to do as the priests do\]![^fn_12b_17] — The Mishnah states here a case of 'not only'; not only \[is it allowed[^fn_12b_18] in the case of\] the daughter of an Israelite \[getting married\] to an Israelite, who cannot say to her 'I raise thee' \[to a higher position\];[^fn_12b_19] but \[in the case of\] the daughter of an Israelite \[getting married\] to a priest. who can say to her, 'I raise thee \[to a higher position\].'[^fn_12b_20] I might think that it is not allowed;[^fn_12b_21] \[hence\] he lets us hear \[that this is not so\].[^fn_12b_22]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN[^fn_12b_23] MARRIES A WOMAN AND DOES NOT FIND[^fn_12b_24] IN HER VIRGINITY \[AND\] SHE SAYS, AFTER THOU HADST BETROTHED ME \[UNTO THEE\][^fn_12b_24] WAS FORCED AND \[SO\] THY FIELD HAS BEEN INUNDATED'[^fn_12b_25] AND HE SAYS, 'NO, BUT \[IT OCCURRED\] BEFORE I BETROTHED THEE \[TO ME\] AND MY BARGAIN WAS A MISTAKEN BARGAIN' — RABBAN GAMALIEL AND R. ELIEZER SAY \[THAT\] SHE IS BELIEVED. \[BUT\] R. JOSHUA SAYS: WE DO NOT LIVE FROM HER MOUTH,[^fn_12b_26] BUT SHE IS IN THE PRESUMPTION OF HAVING HAD INTERCOURSE[^fn_12b_27] BEFORE SHE WAS BETROTHED AND HAVING DECEIVED HIM, UNTIL SHE BRINGS PROOF FOR HER STATEMENT.[^fn_12b_28] {¶=1.7}

***GEMARA***. It was stated: \[If one person says to another person\]. 'l have a *maneh* in your hand,'[^fn_12b_29] and the latter[^fn_12b_30] says. 'I do not know[^fn_12b_31] — Rab Judah and R. Huna Say: \[He is\] bound \[to pay\].[^fn_12b_32] and R. Nahman and R. Johanan Say: \[he is\] free \[from the obligation to pay\].[^fn_12b_33] R. Huna and R. Judah say: \[he is\] bound \[to pay\]. \[because they hold that\] in the case of 'sure', and 'perhaps'. 'sure' has it.[^fn_12b_34] R. Nahman and R. Johanan say: \[he is\] free \[from the obligation to pay\] \[because they hold the view\]: leave[^fn_12b_35] the money in the possession of its present owner.[^fn_12b_36] Abaye said to R. Joseph: The opinion[^fn_12b_37] of R. Huna and Rab Judah corresponds with the view of Samuel,[^fn_12b_38] for we have learned: \[If\] she[^fn_12b_39] was pregnant, and they said to her, 'What is the nature of this embryo?'[^fn_12b_40] \[and she answered\]. 'It is from the man So-and-So, and he is a priest.' Rabban Gamaliel and R. Eliezer say \[that\] she is believed. And Rab Judah said \[that\] Samuel said \[that\] the *halachah* is according to Rabban Gamaliel. And R. Samuel b. Judah said to Rab Judah: Sharpwitted one![^fn_12b_41] You said to us in the name of Samuel \[that\] the *halachah* is according to Rabban Gamaliel also in the first[^fn_12b_42] \[Mishnah\]. \[Now what means\]: 'also in the first \[Mishnah\]'? \[Assuredly it must mean\]. although one could say[^fn_12b_43] 'leave the money in the possession of its \[present\] owner.' \[still\] Rabban Gamaliel said: 'sure' has it.[^fn_12b_44] Is it \[then\] to say that R. Judah and R. Huna follow the opinion of Rabban Gamaliel, and R. Nahman and R. Johanan follow the opinion of R. Joshua? — R. Nahman can answer you:[^fn_12b_45] I even follow the opinion of[^fn_12b_46] Rabban Gamaliel; only Rabban Gamaliel says it there[^fn_12b_47] because there is *miggo*.[^fn_12b_48] but what *miggo* is there here?[^fn_12b_49] Or \[again\]: Rabban Gamaliel says it only there, because we Say: leave her in her presumptive state,[^fn_12b_50] but here what presumptive state has he got?[^fn_12b_51] It is also evident that \[it is right\] as we have answered, that R. Nahman follows the opinion of[^fn_12b_52] Rabban Gamaliel, [pg 13a]

for if it were \[not\] so, there would be a difficulty between one law and another law, for it is established for us \[that\] in civil matters the law is according to R. Nahman, whereas in this \[case\][^fn_13a_1] R. Judah \[said\] that Samuel said \[that\] the *halachah* is according to Rabban Gamaliel,[^fn_13a_2] Is it not then to be concluded from this \[that it is\] as we have answered?[^fn_13a_3] Conclude \[so\] from this.

***MISHNAH***. \[IF\] SHE[^fn_13a_4] SAYS, 'I WAS INJURED BY A PIECE OF WOOD', AND HE SAYS, 'NO, THOU HAST HAD INTERCOURSE WITH A MAN[^fn_13a_5] — RABBAN GAMALIEL AND R. ELIEZER SAY: SHE IS BELIEVED, AND R. JOSHUA SAYS: WE DO NOT LIVE FROM HER MONTH,[^fn_13a_6] BUT SHE IS IN THE PRESUMPTION OF HAVING HAD INTERCOURSE WITH A MAN,[^fn_13a_7] UNTIL SHE BRINGS PROOF FOR HER STATEMENT.[^fn_13a_8] {¶=1.8}

***GEMARA***. With regard to what are their claims?[^fn_13a_9] — R. Johanan Says: With regard to two hundred[^fn_13a_10] \[*zuz*\] and a *maneh*.[^fn_13a_11] R. Eleazar says: with regard to a *maneh* and nothing.[^fn_13a_12] R. Johanan says: With regard to two hundred \[*zuz*\] and a *maneh*, \[because\] he[^fn_13a_13] shares the opinion of R. Meir who says \[that\] whether he knew of her or did not know of her[^fn_13a_14] \[she gets as her *kethubah*\] two hundred \[*zuz*\]. And R. Eleazar says: With regard to a *maneh* or nothing, \[because\] he shares the view of the Rabbis who say \[that\] whether he knew of her or did not know of her,[^fn_13a_14] \[she gets as her *kethubah*\] a *maneh*. It is quite right that R. Eleazar does not say as R. Johanan \[says\]. because he establishes it[^fn_13a_15] according to the Rabbis.[^fn_13a_16] But why does not R. Johanan say as R. Eleazar \[says\]? — He holds \[that when\] he[^fn_13a_17] married her in the presumption of \[her being\] a virgin and she is found to have had intercourse, she has a *kethubah* of a *maneh*.[^fn_13a_18] \[According to this view\] here[^fn_13a_19] he would say. 'a *maneh*,'[^fn_13a_20] and she would say. 'a *maneh*,'[^fn_13a_21] \[and\] what difference would there be between his claim and her claim?[^fn_13a_22] \[Now\] it is quite right according to R. Eleazar[^fn_13a_23] that we have stated[^fn_13a_24] two cases,[^fn_13a_25] one[^fn_13a_26] it to exclude the opinion of Rami b. Hama,[^fn_13a_27] and one[^fn_13a_28] to exclude the opinion of R. Hiyya b. Abin in the name of R. Shesheth.[^fn_13a_29] But according to R. Johanan why are two cases necessary?[^fn_13a_30] — One to show you the strength[^fn_13a_31] of Rabban Gamaliel, and one to show you the strength of R. Joshua. The first case to show you the strength of R. Joshua, that, although one could say \[there\] *miggo*,[^fn_13a_32] she is not believed. The second case to show you the strength of Rabban Gamaliel, that, although one cannot say \[there\][^fn_13a_33] *Miggo*, she is believed.

***MISHNAH***. \[IF\] THEY[^fn_13a_34] SAW HER[^fn_13a_35] TALKING WITH SOMEONE,[^fn_13a_36] AND THEY SAID TO HER, 'WHAT SORT OF A MAN IS HE?[^fn_13a_37] \[AND SHE ANSWERED, 'HE IS\] THE MAN SO-AND-SO AND HE IS A PRIEST — RABBAN GAMALIEL AND R. ELIEZER SAY: SHE IS BELIEVED,[^fn_13a_38] AND R. JOSHUA SAYS: WE DO NOT LIVE FROM HER MOUTH,[^fn_13a_39] BUT SHE IS IN THE PRESUMPTION OF HAVING HAD INTERCOURSE WITH A NATHIN[^fn_13a_40] OR A MAMZER,[^fn_13a_41]-[^fn_13a_42] — UNTIL SHE BRINGS PROOF FOR HER STATEMENT. \[IF\] SHE[^fn_13a_43] WAS PREGNANT AND THEY[^fn_13a_44] SAID UNTO HER, 'WHAT IS THE NATURE OF THIS FOETUS.'[^fn_13a_45] \[AND SHE ANSWERED, 'IT IS\] FROM THE MAN SO-AND-SO AND HE IS A PRIEST — RABBAN GAMALIEL AND R. ELIEZER SAY: SHE IS BELIEVED,[^fn_13a_46] AND R. JOSHUA SAYS: WE DO NOT LIVE FROM HER MOUTH,[^fn_13a_47] BUT SHE IS IN THE PRESUMPTION OF BEING PREGNANT FROM A NATHIN OR A MAMZER,[^fn_13a_48] UNTIL SHE BRINGS EVIDENCE FOR HER STATEMENT. {¶=1.9}

***GEMARA***. What is the meaning of 'TALKING'? Ze'iri said: She was hidden.[^fn_13a_49] R. Assi said: She had intercourse.[^fn_13a_50] It is quite right according to Ze'iri that it Says[^fn_13a_51] 'TALKING',[^fn_13a_52] But according to R. Assi why \[does it say\] 'TALKING?' — \[It is\] a more appropriate[^fn_13a_53] expression, as it is written:[^fn_13a_54] 'She eateth,[^fn_13a_55] and wipeth her mouth,[^fn_13a_56] and saith, 'I have done no wickedness.'[^fn_13a_57] It is quite right according to Ze'iri that he teaches \[in the Mishnah\] two \[cases\]: 'TALKING' and 'PREGNANT,[^fn_13a_58] But according to R. Assi, why \[does the Mishnah teach\] two \[cases\]? — One case[^fn_13a_59] to declare her fit[^fn_13a_60] and one case[^fn_13a_61] to declare her daughter[^fn_13a_62] fit.[^fn_13a_63] That is quite right according to him who says \[that\] he who declares her fit declares \[also\] her daughter fit.[^fn_13a_64] But according to him who says \[that\] he who declares her fit declares her daughter unfit,[^fn_13a_65] what is there to say? — R. Assi holds the view of him[^fn_13a_66] who says \[that\] he who declares her fit declares \[also\] her daughter fit.

R. Pappa said to Abaye: According to Ze'iri who said: What Is TALKING?' She was hidden, and R. Joshua said \[that\] she is not believed — did not Rab say: We punish with lashes for the privacy[^fn_13a_67] but we do not prohibit[^fn_13a_68] on account of the privacy? Is it to say that it is not according to R. Joshua?[^fn_13a_69] — You may even say \[that it is according to\] R. Joshua. \[for\] they set a higher standard in matters of priestly descent.[^fn_13a_70]

An objection was raised: \[If\] they[^fn_13a_71] saw her go in[^fn_13a_72] with someone[^fn_13a_73] Into a secret \[place\] [pg 13b]

or into a ruin,[^fn_13b_1] and they said to her, 'What sort of a man is he?' \[and she answered\]. 'he is a priest and he is the son of the brother of my father' — Rabban Gamaliel and R. Eliezer say: She is believed. R. Joshua says: We do not live from her mouth, but she is in the presumption of having had Intercourse with a Nathin or a Mamzer, until she brings proof for her statement. Now it is quite right according to Ze'iri,[^fn_13b_2] that he teaches[^fn_13b_3] two \[cases\]: into a secret \[place\] or into a ruin.[^fn_13b_4] But according to R. Assi who said: She had intercourse,[^fn_13b_5] why does it teach[^fn_13b_6] two cases?[^fn_13b_7] — It teaches \[only\] one \[case\]: into the secret \[place\] of the ruin.[^fn_13b_8] But it teaches: into a secret \[place\] or into a ruin! — \[But say\] one \[expression stands\] for a ruin of a town and one \[expression stands\] for a ruin of a field. And they are \[both\][^fn_13b_9] necessary. for if it[^fn_13b_10] had told us \[only\] concerning a ruin of a town \[one might have said that\] in this \[case\] Rabban Gamaliel declares her fit because most[^fn_13b_11] \[of the men\] of the town are fit with regard to her,[^fn_13b_12] but in \[the case of\] a ruin of a field, when most \[of the men\][^fn_13b_13] are unfit with regard to her.[^fn_13b_14] I might say that he agrees with R. Joshua.[^fn_13b_15] And if it[^fn_13b_16] had told us \[only\] this \[case\][^fn_13b_17] \[I might have said that only\] in this case[^fn_13b_18] did R. Joshua say \[that she is not believed\], but in that \[case\][^fn_13b_19] I might say \[that\] he agrees with Rabban Gamaliel;[^fn_13b_20] \[therefore\] it was necessary \[to state both cases\].

An objection was raised:[^fn_13b_21] This[^fn_13b_22] is a testimony with regard to which the woman is fit.[^fn_13b_23] But R. Joshua Says: She is not believed. Said R. Joshua to them:[^fn_13b_24] Do you not agree that in the case of a woman[^fn_13b_25] who was captured, and there are witnesses that she was captured, and she says. 'I am pure.'[^fn_13b_26] she is not believed? They said to him, 'Yes: but what a difference there is between this case and that case.'[^fn_13b_27] In this case[^fn_13b_28] there are witnesses,[^fn_13b_29] and in that case[^fn_13b_30] there are no witnesses.[^fn_13b_31] He said to them: In that case too[^fn_13b_32] there are also witnesses, for her stomach reaches up to her teeth.[^fn_13b_33] They said to him, 'Most of the idolators are unrestrained in sexual matters.' He said to them: 'There is no guardian against unchastity.'[^fn_13b_34] This applies[^fn_13b_35] only in the case of the testimony of the woman with regard to herself.[^fn_13b_36] but in the case of the testimony of the woman with regard to her daughter. all agree that the child is a shethuki.'[^fn_13b_37] — \[Now\] what did he[^fn_13b_38] say unto them[^fn_13b_39] and what did they answer him? This they said unto him: 'You have answered us with regard to the pregnant woman,[^fn_13b_40] what will you answer us with regard to the woman \[whom they saw\] talking \[to a man\]?'[^fn_13b_41] — He said to them: The woman \[whom they saw\] talking \[to a man\] is the same as the captive woman.[^fn_13b_42] They said to him, 'The captive woman is different, for most of the idolators are unrestrained in sexual matters.'[^fn_13b_43] He said to them: Here also,[^fn_13b_44] since she hid herself,[^fn_13b_45] there is no guardian against unchastity.[^fn_13b_46] \[Now\] at all events he teaches two \[cases\]: The woman \[whom they saw\] talking \[to a man\] and the pregnant woman![^fn_13b_47] \[This is\] a refutation of R. Assi,[^fn_13b_48] \[This is indeed\] a refutation,[^fn_13b_49] — But let this difference weigh with him[^fn_13b_50] There[^fn_13b_51] most of the men are unfit with regard to her, but here[^fn_13b_52] most of the men are fit with regard to her! — This[^fn_13b_53] supports the opinion of R. Joshua b. Levi, for R. Joshua b. Levi said: He who declares her fit[^fn_13b_54] declares her fit even when most of the men are unfit,[^fn_13b_55] and he who declares her unfit declares her unfit even when most of the men are fit.[^fn_13b_56]

R. Johanan said: He who declares her fit declares also her daughter fit, \[and\] he who declares her unfit declares also her daughter unfit. And R. Eleazar said: \[Even\] he who declares her fit declares her daughter unfit. Rabba said: What is the reason of R. Eleazar? \[This:\] It is quite right \[with regard to her\], she has the presumption of fitness,[^fn_13b_57] \[but\] her daughter has no presumption of fitness.[^fn_13b_58] R. Eleazar objected to \[the ruling of\] R. Johanan: This only applies to the testimony of the woman with regard to herself, but in the case of the testimony of the woman with regard to her daughter, all agree that the child is a shethuki.[^fn_13b_59] Does this not \[mean\] a shethuki and unfit? — No, a shethuki and fit. But is there a shethuki \[who is\] fit? — Yes, according to Samuel, for Samuel said: \[If\] ten priests are standing together and one of them goes away[^fn_13b_60] and has intercourse \[with a woman\], the child is a shethuki. Now what \[means here\] a shethuki? Is it to say that he is 'silenced' from the property of his father?[^fn_13b_61] This is evident! Do we know who his father is? — It means one silences him from the rights of priesthood,[^fn_13b_62] for it is written: 'And it shall be unto him and to his seed after him the covenant of an everlasting priesthood.[^fn_13b_63] \[that is, only\] one whose seed is legitimately descending from him, excluding this one,[^fn_13b_64] whose seed is not legitimately descending from him.[^fn_13b_65]

A bridal couple[^fn_13b_66] once came before R. Joseph. She said, 'It[^fn_13b_67] is from him'.[^fn_13b_68] and he said, [pg 14a]

'Yes. \[it is\] from me.' R. Joseph said: Why should we be afraid? First,[^fn_14a_1] he admits, and moreover, Rab Judah said \[that\] Samuel said: The *halachah* is according to Rabban Gamaliel.[^fn_14a_2] Abaye said to him: And in this \[case\]. if he did not admit, would Rabban Gamaliel declare her as fit? Did not Samuel say to Rab Judah: 'Sharp-witted one! The *halachah* is according to Rabban Gamaliel, but you should not act upon it,[^fn_14a_3] unless most men are fit for her,' whereas here most men are unfit for her![^fn_14a_4] — And according to your reasoning is not this \[statement\] in itself difficult? \[First he says\] 'The *halachah* \[is. etc.'\] \[and then\] 'do not act in practice \[on it\]'![^fn_14a_5] Hence you must say: The one ruling applies before[^fn_14a_6] the other after it was done,[^fn_14a_7] and in this case also it is like 'after it was done.'[^fn_14a_8]

Abaye asked[^fn_14a_9] Raba: Did R. Joshua Say: She is not believed? This would be in contradiction with the following: R. Joshua and R. Judah b. Bathyra testified concerning the widow[^fn_14a_10] \[of one who was\] of a mixed family[^fn_14a_11] that she is fit to marry a priest![^fn_14a_12] — He said to him: Now is this so?[^fn_14a_13] There[^fn_14a_14] the woman marries, and \[in that case\] she examines[^fn_14a_15] and \[then\] marries; but here[^fn_14a_16] the woman misconducts herself; does she first examine and then misconduct herself?[^fn_14a_17]

Raba said: Is the contradiction \[only\] between \[one statement of\] R. Joshua and \[the other Statement of\] R. Joshua. \[but\] not[^fn_14a_18] between \[one Statement of\] Rabban Gamaliel and \[another Statement of\] Rabban Gamaliel?[^fn_14a_19] Surely the concluding clause[^fn_14a_20] teaches: Rabban Gamaliel said to them: We accept your testimony,[^fn_14a_21] but what can we do, since Rabban Johanan b. Zakkai decreed that no court be set up for this purpose.[^fn_14a_22] because the priests will obey you to remove[^fn_14a_23] but not to bring near?[^fn_14a_24] — But, said Raba; there is no contradiction between \[the statement of\] Rabban Gamaliel and \[the other statement of\] Rabban Gamaliel, \[because\] there[^fn_14a_25] it is sure'[^fn_14a_26] \[and\] here[^fn_14a_27] it is 'perhaps.'[^fn_14a_28] Neither is there a contradiction between \[the one statement of\] R. Joshua and \[the other statement of\] R. Joshua, \[because\] there[^fn_14a_29] there is one doubt[^fn_14a_30] \[and\] here[^fn_14a_31] there is a double doubt.[^fn_14a_32] Therefore, according to Rabban Gamaliel the 'sure' is \[so\] strong[^fn_14a_33] \[a plea\] that even where \[there is only\] one doubt[^fn_14a_34] he declares \[her\] fit,[^fn_14a_35] and the 'perhaps' is \[so\] weak \[a plea\][^fn_14a_36] that even where there is a double doubt[^fn_14a_37] he declares \[her\] unfit.[^fn_14a_38] \[And\] according to R. Joshua one doubt[^fn_14a_39] is \[so\] strong that even in the case where \[she pleads\] 'sure' he declares \[her\] unfit,[^fn_14a_40] and a double doubt[^fn_14a_41] is \[so\] light[^fn_14a_42] that even in the case where \[she pleads\] 'perhaps' he declares \[her\] fit.[^fn_14a_43]

Our Rabbis taught: Which is the widow[^fn_14a_44] \[of one\] of a mixed family? When there is with regard to it[^fn_14a_45] \[no doubt\] on account of mamzeruth,[^fn_14a_46] nathinuth[^fn_14a_47] and on account of slaves of the kings.[^fn_14a_48] R. Meir said: [pg 14b]

I have heard that when there is none of these \[defects\] in the family one permits \[its members\] to marry into the priesthood. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said in the name of R. Meir. and R. Simeon the son of Menasia also said it:[^fn_14b_1] Which is the widow \[of one\] of a mixed family? When a doubtful halal[^fn_14b_2] was mixed up[^fn_14b_3] in it, \[for\] the Israelites know the mamzerim who are among them, but they do not know the halalim who are among them.[^fn_14b_4]

The Master said: 'Which is the widow \[of one\] of a mixed family? When there is with regard to it \[no doubt\] on account of mamzeruth, nathinuth and on account of slaves of the kings'. \[This would show that if there is a doubt on account of\] a halal \[in the family\] it is fit.[^fn_14b_5] Why should these[^fn_14b_6] be different? \[Because\] these are Biblical? A halal is also Biblical![^fn_14b_7] And further:[^fn_14b_8] 'R. Meir said: I have heard that when there is none of these \[defects\] in the family one permits \[its members\] to marry into the priesthood'. This is the same \[as that which\] the first Tanna[^fn_14b_9] \[taught\]! And further:[^fn_14b_10] 'R. Simeon b. Eleazar said in the name of R. Meir, and R. Simeon b. Menasia also said it: Which is the widow \[of one\] of a mixed family? When a halal was mixed up in it, \[for\] the Israelites know the mamzerim who are among them, but they do not know the halalim who are among them.' Surely it says in the first clause \[that if there is a doubt regarding\] a halal \[in the family, the family is\] fit \[to marry into the priesthood\]! R. Johanan said: There is a difference between them \[concerning a person who when he is called\] mamzer protests and \[when he is called\] halal is silent. The first Tanna holds \[that\] every person who when called 'unfit' is silent is \[considered\] unfit, and thus the first Tanna said: Which is the widow \[of one\] of a mixed family? When there is in it no one who is silent if he is called mamzer or nathin, or slave of the king, or halal. Whereupon R. Meir said to him: This applies only to \[each of\] these cases[^fn_14b_11] since \[he who calls him thus is liable to\] render him unfit \[to enter\] into \[the congregation,\] but he who is called a halal and is silent,[^fn_14b_12] is fit, and the reason he is silent is that it does not trouble him.[^fn_14b_13] Whereupon R. Simeon b. Eleazar said to the first Tanna[^fn_14b_14] of R. Meir: If you have heard that R. Meir declares the person fit in the case of silence, this is not when he is called halal and is silent, but when he is called mamzer and is silent, for the reason he is silent is because he says to himself; 'a mamzer is well-known'.[^fn_14b_15] But \[if he is called\] mamzer and he protests. or \[he is called\] halal and is silent he is unfit,[^fn_14b_16] for the reason he is silent is because he thinks, 'it is enough if he is not excluded from the congregation'.[^fn_14b_17]

One Baraitha taught: R. Jose says: \[if he is called\] mamzer and is silent, he is fit, and if he is called halal and is silent, he is unfit. And another Baraitha taught: \[if he is called\] halal and is silent he is fit, \[but if he is called\] mamzer and is silent, he is unfit. There is no difficulty;[^fn_14b_18] the one[^fn_14b_19] is according to the first Tanna in the sense of R. Meir, and the other one is according to R. Simeon b. Eleazar in the sense of R. Meir.

***MISHNAH***. R. JOSE SAID: IT HAPPENED THAT A GIRL. WENT DOWN TO DRAW[^fn_14b_20] WATER FROM A SPRING AND SHE WAS RAVISHED. R. JOHANAN B. NURI SAID: IF MOST OF THE INHABITANTS[^fn_14b_21] OF THE TOWN MARRY \[THEIR DAUGHTERS\] INTO THE PRIESTHOOD,[^fn_14b_22] THIS \[GIRL\] MAY \[ALSO\] MARRY INTO THE PRIESTHOOD.[^fn_14b_23] {¶=1.10}

***GEMARA***. Raba said to R. Nahman: According to whom did R. Johanan b. Nuri say \[this n the Mishnah?\]. If according to Rabban Gamaliel, \[surely\] he declares as fit even when there is a majority of unfit![^fn_14b_24] \[And\] if it is according to R. Joshua, \[surely\] he declares as unfit even when there is a majority of fit![^fn_14b_25] — He said to him: Rah Judah said \[that\] Rab said: [pg 15a]

The incident[^fn_15a_1] happened at the springs[^fn_15a_2] of Zepphoris, and the ruling followed R. Ammi, for R. Ammi said: and that is when a company of unfit men passed by there,[^fn_15a_3] and also R. Jannai. for R. Jannai said: if she had intercourse at the springs she is fit for the priesthood. — Do you really mean to say at the springs? — But rather \[say\]: If she had intercourse at the time of \[the people visiting\] the springs she is fit for the priesthood. But if someone went[^fn_15a_4] from Zepphoris and had intercourse \[with her\], the child is a shethuki.[^fn_15a_5] This is according to the following: When R. Dimi came[^fn_15a_6] he said that Ze'iri said \[in the name of\] R. Hanina, and some say: Ze'iri said \[in the name of\] R. Hanina:[^fn_15a_7] One goes after the majority of \[the inhabitants of\] the town and one does not go after the majority of the \[passing\] company. — Just the reverse! These[^fn_15a_8] move about and those[^fn_15a_9] are stationary![^fn_15a_10] — But \[say thus\]: One goes after the majority of the \[inhabitants of the\] town, but only when there is \[also\] the majority of the \[passing\] company with it, but one does not go after the majority of the \[inhabitants of the\] town alone, nor after the majority of the \[passing\] company alone.[^fn_15a_11] — What is the reason?[^fn_15a_12] — It is prohibited[^fn_15a_13] \[to go after\] the majority of the \[passing\] company in order to prevent[^fn_15a_14] \[going after\] the majority of \[the inhabitants of\] the town. But even \[in the case of\] the majority of \[the inhabitants of\] the town, if he, went[^fn_15a_15] to her, \[let us say that\] he who separates himself separates himself from the majority?[^fn_15a_16] — It speaks of a case[^fn_15a_17] when she went to him.[^fn_15a_18] so that he was stationary,[^fn_15a_19] and R. Zera said: All that is stationary is considered as half to half.[^fn_15a_20] But do we require two majorities? Has it not been taught: if nine \[meat\] shops.[^fn_15a_21] all of them, sell ritually killed meat. and one \[shop sells\] meat not ritually slaughtered and he bought in[^fn_15a_22] one of them and he does not know in which of them he bought. it is prohibited because of the doubt;[^fn_15a_23] but if \[meat\] was found,[^fn_15a_24] one goes after the majority?[^fn_15a_25] And if you will say that \[it speaks of a case\] when the gates of the city are not closed,[^fn_15a_26] so that a majority[^fn_15a_27] came \[also\] from outside,[^fn_15a_28] did not R. Zera say: even when[^fn_15a_29] the gates of the city are closed? — Where purity of descent is concerned they[^fn_15a_30] put up a higher standard.[^fn_15a_31]

The text says: 'R. Zera said: All that is stationary is considered as half to half.' \[This apparently means\] whether it is for leniency or for strictness.[^fn_15a_32] Whence does R. Zera take it? Shall I say from \[the Baraitha which teaches that\] if nine \[meat\] shops, all of them, sell ritually killed meat and one \[shop sells\] meat not ritually slaughtered and he bought in one of them[^fn_15a_33] and he does not know in which of them he bought, it is prohibited because of the doubt; but if \[meat\] was found, one goes after the majority? There it is for strictness![^fn_15a_34] But \[he derives it\] from \[the following\]: If there were \[in a certain place\] nine frogs and one reptile[^fn_15a_35] and he touches one of them and he does not know which of them he touched he is unclean because of the doubt? — There also it is for strictness![^fn_15a_36] — But \[rather\] from \[the following\]: If there were \[in a certain place\] nine reptiles and one frog and he touches one of them and he does not know which of them he touched, \[if this happened\] on private ground he is unclean because of the doubt, \[but\] if this happened in a public place,[^fn_15a_37] he is clean because of the doubt.[^fn_15a_38]

And how do we know this[^fn_15a_39] from the Bible? — The verse says: And if he lie in wait for him and rise up against him,[^fn_15a_40] \[that is to say that he is not guilty of murder\] until he intended \[to kill\] him. And the Rabbis? — They said in the school of R. Jannai: This excludes one who throws a stone into \[a group of people\]. What case do you mean? Do you mean a case when there are nine idolators and one Israelite? Let it be sufficient for him[^fn_15a_41] that the majority are idolators, \[and\] even if \[you will say that it is considered as\] half to half, \[the rule is that\] when there is a doubt in capital cases one takes a lenient view! — It speaks of a case when there are nine Israelites and one idolator, so that the idolator is stationary, and whatever is stationary is considered as half to half.[^fn_15a_42]

It was stated: R. Hiyya b. Ashi \[said that\] Rab said \[that\] the law is according to R. Jose.[^fn_15a_43] And R. Hanan b. Raba \[said that\] Rab said \[that\] it was \[only\] a decision for the hour.[^fn_15a_44] R. Jeremiah argued: And for pure descent we do not require two majorities? Have we not learned: [pg 15b]

\[If\] one found in it[^fn_15b_1] an abandoned[^fn_15b_2] child — if the majority \[of the inhabitants of the town consist of\] non-Israelites \[the child is\] a non-Israelite, if the majority \[of the inhabitants of the town consist of\] Israelites \[the child is\] an Israelite, \[and if the inhabitants of the town are\] half to half, \[the child is\] an Israelite.[^fn_15b_3] And Rab said: They have taught this only with regard to sustaining it,[^fn_15b_4] but not with regard to pure descent. And Samuel said: \[They have taught this only\] with regard to removing debris[^fn_15b_5] for its sake?[^fn_15b_6] — That which Rab Judah said in the name of Rab[^fn_15b_7] \[namely, that\] the incident happened at the springs of Zepphoris,[^fn_15b_8] escaped his[^fn_15b_9] attention.[^fn_15b_10] But according to R. Hanan b. Raba who said \[that\] it was a decision for the hour,[^fn_15b_11] it is difficult![^fn_15b_12] He who taught this[^fn_15b_13] did not teach that.[^fn_15b_14]

The \[above\] text \[says\]: '\[If\] one found in it an abandoned child — if the majorlty \[of the inhabitants of the town consist of\] non-Israelites \[the child is\] a non-Israelite. if the majority \[of the inhabitants of the town consist of\] Israelites \[the child is\] an Israelite, \[and if the inhabitants of the town are) half to half \[the child is\] an Israelite. Rab said: They have taught this only with regard to sustaining it, but not with regard to pure descent. But Samuel said: \[They have taught this only\] with regard to removing debris for its sake.' But did Samuel say so? Did not R. Joseph say that R. Judah said in the name of Samuel: We do not go with regard to saving life after the majority?[^fn_15b_15] — But the saying of Samuel referred[^fn_15b_16] to the first clause: 'If the majority \[of the inhabitants of the town consist of\] non-Israelites \[the child is\] a non-Israelite.' \[Upon this\] Samuel said: And with regard to removing debris it is not so,[^fn_15b_17] 'If the majority \[of the inhabitants of the town consist of\] non-Israelites \[the child is\] a non-Israelite' — for what practical purpose \[is this taught\]? — R. Papa said: To allow him to eat \[meat of\] animals not ritually slaughtered. — 'If the majority \[of the inhabitants of the town consists of\] Israelites \[the child is\] an Israelite,' — for what practical purpose \[is this taught\]? — R. Papa said: That one returns to him a lost object.[^fn_15b_18] If \[the inhabitants of the town are\] half to half \[the child is\] an Israelite' — for what practical purpose \[is this taught\]? Resh Lakish said: With regard to damages.[^fn_15b_19] How shall we imagine this case? Shall we say that an ox of ours[^fn_15b_20] gored[^fn_15b_21] an ox of his?[^fn_15b_22] \[In this case\] let him[^fn_15b_23] say to him.[^fn_15b_24] 'Bring evidence that you are an Israelite — and take![^fn_15b_25] It speaks of a case when an ox of his[^fn_15b_26] gored an ox of ours[^fn_15b_27] — one half he[^fn_15b_28] pays, and with regard to the other half he says to them,[^fn_15b_29] 'Bring evidence that I am not an Israelite and I will pay[^fn_15b_30] you.[^fn_15b_31]

## CHAPTER II

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN BECAME A WIDOW OR WAS DIVORCED[^fn_15b_32] \[AND\] SHE SAYS, 'THOU DIDST MARRY ME \[AS\] A VIRGIN,'[^fn_15b_33] AND HE SAYS, 'NOT SO, BUT I MARRIED THEE \[AS\] A WIDOW,'[^fn_15b_34]-[^fn_15b_34] — IF THERE ARE WITNESSES THAT SHE WENT OUT[^fn_15b_36] WITH A HINUMA[^fn_15b_37] AND HER HEAD UNCOVERED,[^fn_15b_38] HER KETHUBAH IS TWO HUNDRED \[ZUZ.\][^fn_15b_39] R. JOHANAN THE SON OF BEROKA SAYS: ALSO THE DISTRIBUTION OF ROASTED EARS OF CORN IS EVIDENCE.[^fn_15b_40] AND R. JOSHUA ADMITS THAT, IF ONE SAYS[^fn_15b_41] TO HIS FELLOW,[^fn_15b_42] THIS FIELD BELONGED TO YOUR FATHER AND I BOUGHT IT FROM HIM. HE IS BELIEVED, [pg 16a] {¶=2.1}

FOR THE MOUTH THAT BOUND IS THE MOUTH THAT LOOSENS.[^fn_16a_1] BUT IF THERE ARE WITNESSES THAT IT[^fn_16a_2] BELONGED TO HIS FATHER AND HE SAYS, 'I BOUGHT IT FROM HIM.' HE IS NOT BELIEVED.

***GEMARA***. The reason[^fn_16a_3] is that there are witnesses,[^fn_16a_4] but if there are no witnesses the husband is believed. Is it to say that the anonymous and undisputed decision[^fn_16a_5] recorded in our Mishnah is not according to Rabban Gamaliel? For if it were according to Rabban Gamaliel, did not he say that she is believed?[^fn_16a_6] — You may even say \[that it is according to\] Rabban Gamaliel; \[for\] Rabban Gamaliel says \[it\][^fn_16a_7] only there in \[a case of\] 'sure' and 'perhaps'.[^fn_16a_8] but here[^fn_16a_9] where they are both[^fn_16a_10] sure[^fn_16a_11] \[in their statements\] he[^fn_16a_12] did not say \[it\][^fn_16a_13] — But he who raised the question, how could he raise it at all?[^fn_16a_14] Surely this is a case where they are both 'sure' \[in their statements\]! — Since most women get married as virgins \[you might say that\] it[^fn_16a_15] is like 'sure and perhaps'.[^fn_16a_16] This[^fn_16a_17] may also be proved by the following reasoning, since it is stated: AND R. JOSHUA ADMITS \[etc.\][^fn_16a_18] It is well if you say \[that\] Rabban Gamaliel admits.[^fn_16a_19] But if you say \[that\] Rabban Gamaliel does not admit.[^fn_16a_20] to whom does \[then\] R. Joshua admit?[^fn_16a_21] Do you think \[that\] R. Joshua refers to this chapter?[^fn_16a_22] He refers to *miggo*[^fn_16a_23] in the first chapter.[^fn_16a_24] To which?[^fn_16a_25] Is it to say \[that he refers\] to this: If she was pregnant, and they said to her. 'What is the nature of this embryo'. \[and she answered, 'it is\] from man So-and-so and he is a priest'. Rabban Gamaliel and R. Eliezer say: She is believed, \[and\] R. Joshua says: We do not live from her mouth?[^fn_16a_26] What *miggo* is there in that case?[^fn_16a_27] Behold, her stomach reaches up to her teeth![^fn_16a_28] Again \[should it refer\] to this: They saw her talking with someone and they said to her: 'what is the character of this man?' \[and she answered, 'it is\] man So-and-so and he is a priest'. Rabban Gamaliel and R. Eliezer say: She is believed \[and\] R. Joshua says: We do not live from her mouth?[^fn_16a_29] \[There too.\] what *miggo* is there? True, there is according to Ze'iri, Who says \[that\] 'she was talking' means 'she was hiding herself' \[with a man\]. \[in which case she has\] a *miggo*, for if she wished she could say. 'I had no intercourse,' and \[still\] she said, 'I had intercourse,' \[therefore\] she is believed. But according to R. Assi, who says \[that\] 'she was talking' means 'she had intercourse, what *miggo* is there?[^fn_16a_30] Or again \[should he refer\] to this: She says. 'I was injured by \[a piece of\] wood,' and he says. 'Not so, but thou wast trodden by a man.' Rabban Gamaliel and R. Eliezer say: She is believed, and R. Joshua says: We do not live from her mouth?[^fn_16a_31] \[There too\] what *miggo* is there? True, there is according to R. Eliezer, who says that \[the dispute between the husband and the wife is\] with regard to a *maneh* and nothing.[^fn_16a_32] \[In which case she has\] a *miggo*, for if she wished she could say. 'I was injured by a piece of wood under thee,'[^fn_16a_33] and she would get two hundred \[zuz.\],[^fn_16a_34] and \[still\] she said \[that she was injured\] earlier,[^fn_16a_35] \[therefore\] she is believed. But according to R. Johanan who says that \[the dispute between the husband and the wife is\] with regard to two hundred \[*zuz*\] and a *maneh*,[^fn_16a_36] what *miggo* is there?[^fn_16a_37] — But \[he refers\] to this: If one has married a woman and has not found in her virginity \[and\] she says. 'After thou hadst betrothed me \[to thyself\] I was violated and thy field has been inundated,' and he says, 'Not so, but \[it happened\] before I betrothed thee \[to myself\]'. Rabban Gamaliel and R. Eliezer say: She is believed, and R. Joshua says: We do not live from her mouth,[^fn_16a_38] For \[here there is\] a *miggo*, because if she wished she could say. 'I was injured by a piece of wood under thee,' and \[by saying this\] she would not make herself unfit for the priesthood. and \[still\] she said, 'l have been violated', and \[by saying this\] she made herself unfit for the priesthood; therefore Rabban Gamaliel said that she is believed. And R. Joshua said to Rabban Gamaliel: With regard to this *miggo* here,[^fn_16a_39] I agree with you, but with regard to that *miggo* there,[^fn_16a_40] I differ from you. Now, this is a *miggo* and that is a *miggo*, what difference is there between this *miggo* and that *miggo*.? Here[^fn_16a_41] there is no slaughtered ox before you, there[^fn_16a_42] there is a slaughtered ox before you.[^fn_16a_43]

But since most women get married as virgins.[^fn_16a_44] \[even\] if no witnesses came,[^fn_16a_45] what of it?[^fn_16a_46] — Rabina said: Because one can say:[^fn_16a_47] most women marry as maidens and a minority as widows. And whenever a maiden gets married, it is spoken about,[^fn_16a_48] [pg 16b]

and since this one was not spoken about,[^fn_16b_1] \[the presumption that she belonged to\] the majority has become shaken. — But if \[you maintain that\] whenever a maiden gets married it is spoken about, \[then even\] when witnesses come,[^fn_16b_2] what of it?[^fn_16b_3] They are false witnesses![^fn_16b_4] — But, said Rabina: most marriages of maidens are spoken about,[^fn_16b_5] and \[in the case of\] this one, since it was not spoken about, \[the presumption that she — the bride — belonged to\] the majority has been shaken.[^fn_16b_6]

IF THERE ARE WITNESSES THAT SHE WENT OUT WITH A HINUMA, etc. Should we not be afraid that perhaps she might produce witnesses before this court and get \[her *kethubah*\] paid and \[later\] she might produce the written document \[of the *kethubah*\] before another court and get \[her *kethubah*\] paid \[a second time\] by that \[document\]? — R. Abbahu said: This teaches \[that\] one writes a quittance.[^fn_16b_7] R. Papa said:[^fn_16b_8] It speaks of a place in which one does not write a *kethubah* document.[^fn_16b_9]

Some refer[^fn_16b_10] this[^fn_16b_11] to the \[following\] Baraitha: If she lost her *kethubah* document, or she hid it, or it was burnt, \[then the matter is as follows:\] if they danced before her, played before her, passed before her the cup of \[glad\] tidings,[^fn_16b_12] or the cloth of virginity[^fn_16b_13] \[and\] if she has witnesses with regard to one of these \[things\],[^fn_16b_14] her *kethubah* is two hundred \[*zuz*\]. Now should we not be afraid that perhaps she might produce witnesses before this court and get \[her *kethubah*\] paid and \[later\] she might produce the written document before another court and get \[her *kethubah*\] paid \[a second time\] by that document? — R. Abbahu said: This teaches \[that\] one writes a quittance. R. Papa said: It speaks of a place in which one does not write a *kethubah* document. But does it not say '\[if\] she lost her *kethubah* document'?[^fn_16b_15] — \[It so happened\] that he wrote her \[one\]. But may she not after all produce it and get \[her *kethubah*\] paid \[a second time\] with it! The meaning of 'she lost \[it\]' is 'she lost \[it\] in fire.'[^fn_16b_16] If so, it is the same as 'it was burnt!' And then, what can you say with regard to 'she hid \[it\]?'[^fn_16b_17] And furthermore, why \[mention\] 'she lost \[it\]'?[^fn_16b_18] — But \[this is what the Baraitha means\]: if she lost it, it is as if she had hidden it before us, and we do not give her \[the *kethubah* money\] until witnesses say \[that\] her *kethubah* document has been burnt.[^fn_16b_19] He who refers this[^fn_16b_20] to the Baraitha, all the more \[does he refer it\] to the Mishnah. But he who refers this to our Mishnah \[does\] not \[refer it\] to the Baraitha, because of the difficulty.[^fn_16b_21]

IF THERE ARE WITNESSES, etc. Should we not be afraid that perhaps she might produce witnesses of hinuma before this court and get \[her *kethubah*\] paid and \[later\] she might produce \[other\] witnesses of hinuma before another court and get \[her *kethubah*\] paid \[a second time\]? — Where it is not possible otherwise,[^fn_16b_22] we certainly write a quittance. \[It is said above in the Baraitha\]: '\[If\] they passed before her the cup of \[glad\] tidings.'[^fn_16b_23] What is the cup of \[glad\] tidings? R. Adda the son of Ahaba said: One passes before her a cup of wine of *Terumah*,[^fn_16b_24] as if to say. 'This one is worthy of eating *Terumah*.'[^fn_16b_25] R. Papa demurred to this: Does not a widow eat *Terumah*?[^fn_16b_26] But, said R. Papa \[as if to say\] 'This one is "first"27 as *Terumah* is "first".'[^fn_16b_28] It has been taught: R. Judah says: One passes before her a cask of wine. R. Adda the son of Ahaba said: \[If she was\] a virgin one passes before her a closed one, \[and if\] she has had intercourse with a man one passes before her an open one. Why? Let us pass \[a cask of wine\] before a virgin and let us not pass \[a cask of wine\] at all before one who had intercourse? — \[It may happen\] some times that she has seized[^fn_16b_29] two hundred \[so\] and \[then\] says. 'I was a virgin and they did not pass \[a cask of wine\] before me because they were prevented by an accident.'[^fn_16b_30] Our Rabbis taught: How does one dance[^fn_16b_31] before the bride? Beth Shammai say: [pg 17a]

The bride as she is.[^fn_17a_1] And Beth Hillel say: 'Beautiful and graceful bride'![^fn_17a_2] Beth Shammai said to Beth Hillel: If she was lame or blind, does one say of her: 'Beautiful and graceful bride'? Whereas the Torah[^fn_17a_3] said, 'Keep thee far from a false matter.'[^fn_17a_4] Said Beth Hillel to Beth Shammai: According to your words,[^fn_17a_5] if one has made a bad purchase in the market, should one praise it[^fn_17a_6] in his eyes or depreciate it?[^fn_17a_7] Surely,[^fn_17a_8] one should praise it in his eyes. Therefore,[^fn_17a_9] the Sages said: Always should the disposition of man be pleasant with people. — When R. Dimi came,[^fn_17a_10] he said: Thus they sing before the bride in the West:[^fn_17a_11] no powder[^fn_17a_12] and no paint[^fn_17a_13] and no waving[^fn_17a_14] \[of the hair\], and still a graceful gazelle.

When the Rabbis ordained R. Zera they sang before him thus: No powder and no paint and no waving \[of the hair\], and still a graceful gazelle. When the Rabbis ordained R. Ammi and R. Assi they sang before them thus: Such as these, such as these ordain unto us, \[but\] do not ordain unto us of the perverters[^fn_17a_15] or babblers,[^fn_17a_16] and some say: of the half-scholars[^fn_17a_17] or one-third-scholars.[^fn_17a_18] — When R. Abbahu came from the Academy to the court of the Emperor,[^fn_17a_19] hand-maids[^fn_17a_20] from the Imperial house went out towards him and sang before him thus, 'Prince of his people, leader of his nation, shining light,[^fn_17a_21] blessed be thy coming in peace!'

They tell of R. Judah b. Ila'i that he used to take a myrtle twig and dance before the bride and say: 'Beautiful and graceful bride.' R. Samuel the son of R. Isaac danced with three \[twigs\].[^fn_17a_22] R. Zera said: The old man is putting us to shame.[^fn_17a_23] When he[^fn_17a_24] died,[^fn_17a_25] a pillar of fire came between him and the whole \[of the rest of the\] world. And there is a tradition that a pillar of fire has made such a separation[^fn_17a_26] only either for one in a generation or for two in a generation only.[^fn_17a_27] R. Zera said: His twig[^fn_17a_28] \[benefited\] the old man, and some say: His habit[^fn_17a_29] \[benefited\] the old man, and some say: his folly[^fn_17a_30] \[benefited\] the old man. — R. Aha took[^fn_17a_31] her[^fn_17a_32] on his shoulder and danced \[with her\]. The Rabbis said to him: May we \[also\] do it? He said to them: If they[^fn_17a_33] are on you[^fn_17a_34] like a beam,[^fn_17a_35] \[then it is\] all right. and if not, \[you may\] not.

R. Samuel b. Nahmani said \[that\] R. Jonathan said: it is allowed to look intently at the face of the bride all the seven \[days\][^fn_17a_36] in order to make her beloved to her husband.[^fn_17a_37] But the law is not according to him.

Our Rabbis taught: One causes a funeral procession[^fn_17a_38] to make way[^fn_17a_39] for a bridal procession,[^fn_17a_40] and both of them[^fn_17a_41] for the King of Israel. One tells of King Agrippa that he made way for a bride, and the Sages praised him. — They praised him — from this it would seem that he did well. Did not R. Ashi say: Even according to him, who says \[that\] if a king forgoes his honour, his honour is forgone, if a king forgoes his honour, his honour is not forgone. for a Master said:[^fn_17a_42] 'Thou shalt set a king over thee,'[^fn_17a_43] \[this means\] that his awe shall be over thee?[^fn_17a_44] — It was \[at\] a cross-road.[^fn_17a_45]

Our Rabbis taught: One interrupts[^fn_17a_46] the study of the Torah for the sake of a funeral procession[^fn_17a_47] and the leading[^fn_17a_48] of the bride \[under the bridal canopy\]. They tell of R. Judah b. Ila'i that he interrupted the study of the Torah for the sake of a funeral procession[^fn_17a_49] and the leading[^fn_17a_50] of the bride \[under the bridal canopy\]. This applies only[^fn_17a_51] when there are not sufficient people at the funeral procession,[^fn_17a_52] but if there are sufficient people one does not interrupt \[the study of the Torah\].[^fn_17a_53] And how many are sufficient? R. Samuel the son of Ini said in the name of Rab: Twelve thousand men and six thousand trumpets.[^fn_17a_54] And some say: Twelve thousand[^fn_17a_55] men and among them six thousand trumpets.[^fn_17a_56] 'Ulla said: For instance when people form a line from the city-gate to the burial place. R. Shesheth, and some say R. Johanan said: Its taking away[^fn_17a_57] is like its giving.[^fn_17a_58] As its giving was in \[the presence of\] sixty myriads[^fn_17a_59] \[of people\], so \[has\] its taking away \[to be\] in \[the presence of\] sixty myriads \[of people\]. And this is the case only[^fn_17a_60] with regard to one who read \[the Bible\] and studied \[the Mishnah.\] [pg 17b]

But for one who taught \[others\] there is no limit.[^fn_17b_1]

AND IF THERE ARE WITNESSES THAT SHE WENT OUT WITH A HINUMA etc. What is hinuma.? — Surhab b. Papa said in the name of Ze'iri: A myrtle-canopy.[^fn_17b_2] R. Johanan said: A veil under which the bride \[sometimes\] slumbers.[^fn_17b_3]

R. JOHANAN THE SON OF BEROKA SAYS, etc. It was taught: This was \[regarded as\] a proof in Judaea; what is \[the proof in\] Babylonia? — Rab said: The dripping of oil on the heads[^fn_17b_4] of the scholars.[^fn_17b_5] R. Papa said to Abaye: Did the master speak of oil \[used\] for cleaning \[the head\]?[^fn_17b_6] — He said to him:[^fn_17b_7] Orphan,[^fn_17b_8] did not your mother do the dripping of the oil on the heads of the scholars at the time[^fn_17b_9] of the event?[^fn_17b_10] As that \[case when\] one of the scholars was occupied with \[the wedding of\] his son in the house Of Rabbah b. 'Ulla — and some say, Rabbah b. 'Ulla was occupied with \[the wedding of\] his son in the house of one of the scholars — and he dripped oil on the heads of the scholars at the time of the event.[^fn_17b_11] — What \[sign is there at the wedding of\] a widow? — R. Joseph taught: A widow has no roasted ears of corn \[distributed at her wedding\].[^fn_17b_12]

AND R. JOSHUA ADMITS THAT IF ONE SAYS TO HIS FELLOW etc. But let him[^fn_17b_13] teach: R. Joshua admits that in \[the case when\] one says to his fellow,'this field belonged to you[^fn_17b_14] and I have bought it of you' \[he is believed\]? — Because he would have to teach \[in\] the last clause: If there are witnesses that it was his and he says. 'l have bought it of you'. he is not believed.[^fn_17b_15] \[And\] how shall we imagine this case? If he ate \[the fruits of\] it \[during the\] years of *hazakah*[^fn_17b_16] why should he not be believed? And if he did not eat \[the fruits of\] it \[during the\] years of *hazakah* it is self-evident that he is not believed![^fn_17b_17] — If so, with regard to his father[^fn_17b_18] also \[one could argue\]: If he[^fn_17b_19] ate \[the fruits of\] it \[during the\] years of *hazakah*. why should he not be believed?[^fn_17b_20] And if he did not eat \[the fruits of\] it \[during the\] years of *hazakah*, it is self-evident that he is not believed! We grant you with regard to his father, \[because\] there may be a case, as, for instance, when he ate \[the fruits of\] it two \[years\] during the life of the father and one \[year\] during the life of his son.[^fn_17b_21] And \[this would be\] according to R. Huna, for R. Huna said: One does not acquire the ownership of the property of a minor by the undisturbed possession of it during the prescribed period. even if \[he continued in the possession after\] the minor had become of age.[^fn_17b_22] But R. Huna comes to let us hear \[what is already taught In\] our Mishnah![^fn_17b_23] — If you wish. you may say. R. Huna says. 'what is to be derived from our Mishnah by implication.'[^fn_17b_24] And if you wish, you may say, 'he lets us hear, even if he had become of age'.[^fn_17b_25]

But let him[^fn_17b_26] \[after all\] teach with regard to himself[^fn_17b_27] and put the case when he[^fn_17b_28] ate \[the fruits of\] it two \[years\] in his presence[^fn_17b_29] and one \[year\] in his absence,[^fn_17b_30] and, for instance, when he[^fn_17b_31] fled? — Because of what did he flee? If he fled because of \[danger to his\] life,[^fn_17b_32] it is self-evident that he[^fn_17b_33] is not believed. since he cannot protest![^fn_17b_34] And if he fled because of money \[matters\].[^fn_17b_35] he ought to have protested.[^fn_17b_36] because it is established for[^fn_17b_37] \[that\] a protest in his absence[^fn_17b_38] is a \[valid\] protest![^fn_17b_39] For we have learned: There are three countries with regard to *hazakah*: Judaea, Trans-Jordan and Galilee.[^fn_17b_40] \[If\] he[^fn_17b_41] was in Judaea and someone took possession \[of his land\] in Galilee, \[or he' was\] in Galilee and Someone took possession \[of his land\] in Judaea, it is no *hazakah*[^fn_17b_42] until he is with him in the \[same\] province.[^fn_17b_43] And we asked[^fn_17b_44] concerning it,[^fn_17b_45] What opinion does he[^fn_17b_46] hold? If he holds that a protest in his absence[^fn_17b_47] is a \[valid\] protest,[^fn_17b_48] this should apply also to Judaea and Galilee.[^fn_17b_49] And if he holds \[that\] a protest in his absence is not a \[valid\] protest. it should not he \[a valid protest\] even if they are both in Judaea?[^fn_17b_50] \[And\] R. Abba the son of Memel said: Indeed, he holds \[that\] a protest in his absence is a \[valid\] protest, but our Mishnah speaks[^fn_17b_51] of a time of lawlessness.[^fn_17b_52] — And why does he just speak of Judaea and Galilee?[^fn_17b_53] ' [pg 18a]

Because \[the condition of the relations between\] Judaea and Galilee is usually as in time of lawlessness.[^fn_18a_1] But let him teach: R. Joshua admits \[that\] when one says to his fellow, 'I borrowed from you a *maneh* and paid it \[back\] to you.' he is believed![^fn_18a_2] — Because he would have \[in that case\] to teach \[in\] the last clause: 'If there are witnesses that he borrowed from him \[a *maneh*\] and he says. "I have paid it \[back\]" he is not believed', but it is established for us[^fn_18a_3] \[that\] if one lends \[money\] to his fellow before[^fn_18a_4] witnesses, he need not pay it \[back\] to him before witnesses.[^fn_18a_5] — But let him \[then\] teach: R. Joshua admits \[that\] if one says to his fellow, 'I owed to your father a *maneh*[^fn_18a_6] and I returned to him half'[^fn_18a_7] he is believed![^fn_18a_8] — According to whose opinion?[^fn_18a_9] If according to the opinion of the Rabbis. surely they say \[that he is regarded as\] one who returns a lost thing;[^fn_18a_10] \[and\] if according to R. Eliezer b. Jacob. surely he says that he must take an oath![^fn_18a_11] For it has been taught:[^fn_18a_12] R. Eliezer b. Jacob says: Sometimes \[it may happen\] that a man has to take an oath because of his own statement. How \[is it\]? \[If one says to his fellow\]. 'I owed to your father a *maneh* and I returned to him half,' he must take an oath.[^fn_18a_13] And this is \[a case\] where one takes an oath because of one's statement.[^fn_18a_14] But the Sages say: He is \[regarded\] only as one who returns a lost thing and he is free. And does not R. Eliezer b. Jacob hold \[that\] one who returns a lost thing is free?[^fn_18a_15] — Rab said: \[It speaks here of a case\] when a minor claimed from him.[^fn_18a_16] But did not a Master say: One does not take an oath because of a claim by a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor?[^fn_18a_17] — What is \[meant by\] 'minor'? A grown-up person, and why does he call him 'minor'? Because with regard to the affairs of his father he is \[regarded as\] a minor. If so, \[how can you say\] 'his own statement?' It is a claim \[made\] by others! — It is a claim \[made\] by others and \[also\] his own admission. But all claims \[consist of\] a claim \[made\] by others and one's own admission![^fn_18a_18] — They differ here with regard to \[an opinion of\] Rabbah, for Rabbah said: Why did the Torah say \[that\] he who admits a part of the claim must take an oath? \[Because\] it is a presumption \[that\] no man is insolent in the face of his creditor. He would \[indeed\] like to deny the whole \[debt\]. but he does not do it[^fn_18a_19] because no one is \[so\] insolent. [pg 18b]

\[Indeed\] he would like to admit the whole of it,[^fn_18b_1] only he does not do it in order to slip away from him \[for the present\].[^fn_18b_2] and he thinks, 'as soon as I will have money I will pay it'.[^fn_18b_3] And \[therefore\] the Divine Law[^fn_18b_4] said: Impose an oath on him, so that he should admit the whole of it.[^fn_18b_5] \[Now\] R. Eliezer b. Jacob holds \[that\] he is not insolent against him nor against his son, and therefore he is not \[regarded as\] one who returns a lost thing. And the Rabbis hold \[that\] against him he is not insolent, but against his son he might be insolent, and since he is not insolent,[^fn_18b_6] he is \[regarded as\] one who returns a lost thing.[^fn_18b_7]

***MISHNAH***. IF WITNESSES SAID, 'THIS[^fn_18b_8] IS OUR HANDWRITING, BUT WE WERE FORCED,[^fn_18b_9] WE WERE MINORS, WE WERE DISQUALIFIED WITNESSES,[^fn_18b_10] THEY ARE BELIEVED.[^fn_18b_11] BUT IF THERE ARE WITNESSES THAT IT IS THEIR HANDWRITING, OR THEIR HANDWRITING COMES OUT FROM ANOTHER PLACE,[^fn_18b_12] THEY ARE NOT BELIEVED.[^fn_18b_13] {¶=2.2}

***GEMARA***. Rami b. Hama said: They taught[^fn_18b_14] this[^fn_18b_15] only when they[^fn_18b_16] said: We were forced \[by threats\] with regard to money.[^fn_18b_17] but \[if they said\]. we were forced \[by threats\] with regard to \[our\] life, they are believed. Raba said to him: Is it so? After he has once testified. he cannot again testify![^fn_18b_18] And if you will say \[that\] this applies only to an oral testimony but not to testimony In a document — did not Resh Lakish say: If witnesses are signed on a document it is as if their testimony had been examined in court?[^fn_18b_19] No; if it has been said,[^fn_18b_20] it has been said with regard to the first clause, \[where it is stated:\] THEY ARE BELIEVED. Whereupon Rami b. Hama said: They taught this[^fn_18b_21] only when they[^fn_18b_22] said, 'We were forced \[by threats\] with regard to \[our\] life.' but if they said, 'we were forced \[by threats\] with regard to money. they are not believed. because no one makes himself \[out to be\] a wicked man.[^fn_18b_23]

Our Rabbis taught: They[^fn_18b_24] are not believed to disqualify[^fn_18b_25] it.[^fn_18b_26] This is the view of R. Meir; but the Sages say \[that\] they are believed. This is right according to the Rabbis,[^fn_18b_27] who follow[^fn_18b_28] their principle[^fn_18b_29] 'the mouth that bound is the mouth that loosened,'[^fn_18b_30] but what is the reason of R. Meir?[^fn_18b_31] I grant you \[with regard to\] 'DISQUALIFIED WITNESSES.'[^fn_18b_32] \[because\] the creditor himself examines well \[the witnesses\] beforehand and \[then\] lets \[them\] sign.[^fn_18b_33] \[With regard to\] 'MINORS' also \[it can be explained\] according to R. Simeon b. Lakish. for Resh Lakish[^fn_18b_34] said: [pg 19a]

It is a presumption that the witnesses do not sign a document unless \[everything\] was done by adults.[^fn_19a_1] But what is the reason with regard to 'FORCED?'[^fn_19a_2] — R. Hisda said: R. Meir holds that if one said to witnesses, 'sign a falsehood and you will not be killed,' they should rather be killed and not sign a falsehood.[^fn_19a_3] Raba said to him: Now. if they would come to us to ask \[our\] advice, we would say unto them: Go \[and\] sign and do not be killed, for a Master said: 'There is nothing that comes before the saving of life except idolatry, incest and bloodshed only.'[^fn_19a_4] Now that they have signed, can we say to them: why have you signed?[^fn_19a_5] But the reason of R. Meir is in accordance with what R. Huna \[said in the name of\] Rab: for R. Huna said \[that\] Rab said: If he[^fn_19a_6] admits that he has written the bond,[^fn_19a_7] there is no need[^fn_19a_8] to confirm it.[^fn_19a_9]

\[To revert to\] the main text:[^fn_19a_10] R. Huna said \[that\] Rab said: If he[^fn_19a_11] admits that he has written the bond, there is no need to confirm it. R. Nahman said to him: Why do you go round about?[^fn_19a_12] If you hold with R. Meir, say: the *halachah* is according to R. Meir.[^fn_19a_13] He[^fn_19a_14] \[then\] said to him:[^fn_19a_15] And how do you Sir, hold?[^fn_19a_16] He[^fn_19a_17] said to him:[^fn_19a_18] When they come[^fn_19a_19] before us in court,[^fn_19a_20] we say to them: go \[and\] confirm your documents[^fn_19a_21] and \[then\] come to court.[^fn_19a_22]

Rab Judah said \[that\] Rab said: If one said: This is a \[loan-\] deed of trust,[^fn_19a_23] he is not believed. Who said \[it\]? If the debtor said it, it is plain; why should he be believed? If the creditor said \[it\], may a blessing come upon him![^fn_19a_24] And if the witnesses said \[it\], — \[then\] if their handwriting comes out from another place, it is plain that they are not believed,[^fn_19a_25] and if their handwriting does not come out from another place, why should they not be believed?[^fn_19a_26] (Mnemonic: *BASH*)[^fn_19a_27] Raba said: Indeed, the debtor said \[it\], and \[it is\] according to R. Huna, for R. Huna said \[that\] Rab said: If he[^fn_19a_28] admits that he has written the document, there is no need to confirm it.[^fn_19a_29] Abaye said: Indeed, the creditor said \[it\], and it is a case where he would injure others.[^fn_19a_30] And \[this is\] according to R. Nathan, for it has been taught:[^fn_19a_31] R. Nathan says: Whence \[do we learn that\], if one has a claim of a *maneh* against his fellow and that fellow against another fellow,[^fn_19a_32] we[^fn_19a_33] take out \[the sun, of a *maneh*\] from this one and give it to that one?[^fn_19a_34] The Writ says[^fn_19a_35] And he shall give \[it\] to whom he owes \[it\].[^fn_19a_36] R. Ashi said: Indeed, the witnesses said \[it\], and \[it is in a case\] where their handwriting does not come out from another place; and as to your question,[^fn_19a_37] Why should they not be believed, \[the answer is\] as stated by R. Kahana, for R. Kahana said: It is forbidden for a man to keep[^fn_19a_38] a \[loan-\] deed of trust in his house, because it is said: Let[^fn_19a_39] not unrighteousness dwell in thy tents.[^fn_19a_40] [pg 19b]

And R. Shesheth, the son of R. Idi, said: From \[the words of\] R. Kahana can be inferred[^fn_19b_1] \[that\] if witnesses said, 'Our words were \[regarding a matter of\] trust,'[^fn_19b_2] they are not believed, for this reason:[^fn_19b_3] Since it is 'unrighteousness' \[we say that\] they must not sign on \[what is\] unrighteousness.[^fn_19b_4]

R. Joshua b. Levi. said: It is forbidden for a man to keep a paid bill of indebtedness in his house, because it is said: 'Let not unrighteousness dwell in thy tents'.[^fn_19b_5] In the West[^fn_19b_6] they said in the name of Rab: \[It is said\]: If iniquity be in thy hand, put it far away.[^fn_19b_7] This is a \[loan-\] deed of trust and a deed of good-will;[^fn_19b_8] \[and it is said\]: 'And let not unrighteousness dwell in thy tents'. This is a paid bill of indebtedness. He who says \[that it[^fn_19b_9] applies to\] a paid bill of indebtedness, how much more \[does it apply to\] a \[loan-\] deed of trust.[^fn_19b_10] \[And\] he, who says \[that it applies to\] a \[loan-\] deed of trust, \[would hold that it does not apply to\] a paid bill of indebtedness,[^fn_19b_11] because sometimes they keep it on account of the scribe's fees.[^fn_19b_12]

It has been stated: A book[^fn_19b_13] that is not corrected[^fn_19b_14] — R. Ami said: Until thirty days one is allowed to keep it, from then and further on, it is forbidden to keep it, because it is said: 'Let not unrighteousness dwell in thy tents.[^fn_19b_15]

R. Nahman said: If witnesses said, 'Our words were \[regarding a matter of\] trust.'[^fn_19b_16] they are not believed; \[if they said\]. 'Our words were \[attended by\] declaration,'[^fn_19b_17] they are \[also\] not believed.[^fn_19b_18] Mar. the son of R. Ashi. said: \[if witnesses said\]. 'Our words were \[regarding a matter of\] trust,' they are not believed; \[but if they said\], 'Our words were \[attended by\] declaration,' they are believed, for this reason:[^fn_19b_19] this one[^fn_19b_20] was allowed to be written[^fn_19b_21] and that one[^fn_19b_22] was not allowed to be written.[^fn_19b_23]

Raba asked of R. Nahman: How is it \[if witnesses say\], 'Our words were \[subject to\] a condition'?[^fn_19b_24] \[Are they not believed in the case of\] 'declaration' and 'trust' because[^fn_19b_25] they invalidate[^fn_19b_26] the document, and \[in\] this \[case of 'condition'\] they also invalidate the document? Or is perhaps 'condition' a different thing?[^fn_19b_27] — He[^fn_19b_28] said to him:[^fn_19b_29] When they[^fn_19b_30] come before us in court, we say to them: go \[and\] fulfil your conditions and \[then\] come to court.

If one witness says \[that there was\] a condition,[^fn_19b_31] and one witness says \[that there was\] no condition R. Papa said: they both testify to a valid document and only one says \[that there was\] a condition, and the words of one \[witness\] have no value where there are two witnesses.[^fn_19b_32] R. Huna the son of R. Joshua demurred to this: If so,[^fn_19b_33] even if they both say \[that there was a condition\] \[their words should\] also \[have no value\]![^fn_19b_34] But we say \[that\] they come to uproot their testimony,[^fn_19b_35] and this one also comes to uproot his testimony.[^fn_19b_36] And the law is according to R. Huna, the son of R. Joshua.

Our Rabbis taught: If two \[witnesses\] were signed on a document and died, and two \[witnesses\] came from the street and said, 'We know that it is their handwriting, but they were forced, they were minors, they were disqualified witnesses, they[^fn_19b_37] are believed. But if there are \[other\] witnesses that this is their handwriting. or their handwriting comes out from another place, \[namely\] from a document, the validity of which was challenged,[^fn_19b_38] and which was confirmed[^fn_19b_39] in Court,[^fn_19b_40] they are not believed. — And we collect[^fn_19b_41] with it as with a valid document? Why? They are two and two![^fn_19b_42] — Said R. Shesheth: This teaches \[that\] contradiction[^fn_19b_43] is the beginning of rebuttal,[^fn_19b_44] [pg 20a]

and as witnesses can be rebutted only in their presence,[^fn_20a_1] so can they be contradicted only in their presence.[^fn_20a_2] R. Nahman said to him: If they[^fn_20a_3] had been before us and \[the other two witnesses\] had contradicted them, it[^fn_20a_4] would hake been a contradiction,[^fn_20a_5] and we would not have paid any attention to them,[^fn_20a_6] because it[^fn_20a_7] is a contradicted testimony. Now that they[^fn_20a_8] are not here[^fn_20a_9] — \[when it could be maintained\] that if they had been before us, they[^fn_20a_10] might \[even\] perhaps have admitted to them[^fn_20a_11] — should they be believed? No, said R. Nahman; set the two \[witnesses\][^fn_20a_12] against the two \[witnesses\][^fn_20a_13] and leave the property[^fn_20a_14] in the possession of its master.[^fn_20a_15] It is analogous to the \[case of the\] property of a \[certain\] madman. A \[certain\] madman sold property. Two \[witnesses\] came \[and\] said \[that\] he sold \[the property\] when he was insane, and two \[witnesses\] came and said \[that\] he sold \[the property\] when he was sane.[^fn_20a_16] \[And\] R. Ashi said: Set the two \[witnesses\][^fn_20a_17] against the two \[witnesses\][^fn_20a_18] and leave the property[^fn_20a_14] in the possession of the madman. And we say \[this\] only when he has the ownership-right of his forefathers,[^fn_20a_19] but if he has not the ownership-right of his forefathers, we say that he bought \[the property\] when he was insane and that he sold \[It\] when he was insane.[^fn_20a_20] — R. Abbahu said: One rebuts[^fn_20a_21] witnesses only in, their presence, but one contradicts them also in their absence. And a rebuttal in their absence — granted that it is not an \[effective\] rebuttal,[^fn_20a_22] but it is a contradiction.[^fn_20a_23]

The Master said \[above\]: 'If there are witnesses that this is their handwriting, or their handwriting came out from another place. \[namely\] from a document which was contested and was confirmed in court, they are not believed'. \[This is only\] if it was contested, but not, if it was not contested.[^fn_20a_24] This is a support[^fn_20a_25] for R. Assi, for R. Assi said: A document[^fn_20a_26] is confirmed only from a document, which was contested and was confirmed in Court. The Nehardeans[^fn_20a_27] said: A document is confirmed only from two *kethuboth* or from two fields,[^fn_20a_28] and \[only\] when their owners[^fn_20a_29] used[^fn_20a_30] them for three years, and \[that\] in comfort.[^fn_20a_31] R. Shimi b. Ashi said: And \[only\] when it is produced by another person,[^fn_20a_32] but not \[if it is produced\] by himself.[^fn_20a_33] — Why not \[if from\] under his own hand? Because he may have forged \[the signatures of the witnesses\].[^fn_20a_34] \[If so\]. even when produced by another person also, perhaps he went[^fn_20a_35] and saw[^fn_20a_36] and forged?[^fn_20a_37] — So clearly[^fn_20a_38] he cannot fix \[it in his mind\].[^fn_20a_39]

Our Rabbis taught: A person[^fn_20a_40] may write \[down\] his testimony in[^fn_20a_41] a document[^fn_20a_42] and may, through it,[^fn_20a_43] give evidence even after many years. R. Huna said: Only when he remembers it[^fn_20a_44] by[^fn_20a_45] himself. R. Johanan said: Even if he does not remember it by himself.[^fn_20a_46] Rabbah said: You may infer from \[the words of\] R. Johanan \[that\] if two \[persons\] know evidence[^fn_20a_47] and one of them has forgotten \[it\], the other one may remind him[^fn_20a_48] \[of it\]. They asked: \[In the case of\] himself[^fn_20a_49] — what is \[the law\]?[^fn_20a_50] — R. Habina said: Even he himself \[may do so\]. Mar b. R. Ashi, said: He himself \[may\] not. And the law is: he himself \[may\] not. [pg 20b]

But if he[^fn_20b_1] is a scholar,[^fn_20b_2] even he himself[^fn_20b_3] \[may remind the witness\].[^fn_20b_4] As that case of R. Ashi: He knew evidence for R. Kahana, \[and\] he[^fn_20b_5] said to him:[^fn_20b_6] Does the master remember that evidence?[^fn_20b_7] And he[^fn_20b_8] said to him:[^fn_20b_9] No. But was it not so and so?[^fn_20b_10] He[^fn_20b_11] replied: I do not know. In the end, R. Ashi reminded himself, and he gave evidence for him.[^fn_20b_12] He[^fn_20b_11] saw that R. Kahana was surprised,[^fn_20b_13] \[so\] he[^fn_20b_11] said to him:[^fn_20b_14] Do you think \[that\] I relied upon you? I threw it upon my mind[^fn_20b_15] and I remembered it.[^fn_20b_16]

We learnt elsewhere:[^fn_20b_17] Mounds which are near a town or a road, whether they are new or old, are unclean;[^fn_20b_18] those \[mounds\] which are distant — if they are new,[^fn_20b_19] they are clean,[^fn_20b_20] and if they are old,[^fn_20b_21] they are unclean.[^fn_20b_22] What is near? Fifty cubits.[^fn_20b_23] And what is old? Sixty years.[^fn_20b_24] \[This is\] the view[^fn_20b_25] of R. Meir. R. Judah says: 'near', \[denotes\] when there is none nearer; 'old', when one remembers it.[^fn_20b_26] \[Now\] what is \[meant by\] a town and what is \[meant by\] a road? Shall I say: \[by\] a town is \[meant\] an ordinary town, \[and by\] a road is \[meant\] an ordinary road? Do we presume uncleanness out of doubt? Did not Resh Lakish say: They[^fn_20b_27] found some pretext[^fn_20b_28] and declared the land of Israel unclean?[^fn_20b_29] — Said R. Zera: \[By\] a town is \[meant\] a town which is near a burial place, and \[by\] a road is \[meant\] a road \[leading\] to a burial place. I grant you \[in the case of\] a road \[leading\] to a burial place,[^fn_20b_30] because sometimes it might happen \[that a funeral took place\] at twilight, and it chanced that they buried it[^fn_20b_31] in the mound.[^fn_20b_32] But \[in the case of\] a town which is near a burial place — all go to the burial place![^fn_20b_33] — Said R. Hanina: Because women bring there[^fn_20b_34] their abortions and lepers[^fn_20b_35] \[bring there\][^fn_20b_36] their arms.[^fn_20b_37] \[And it is assumed that\] till fifty cubits she[^fn_20b_38] goes alone,[^fn_20b_39] but for a longer distance[^fn_20b_40] she takes a man with her and \[then\] she goes to the burial place.[^fn_20b_41] Therefore, we do not presume uncleanness in Eretz Israel.[^fn_20b_42] R. Hisda said: You may infer from \[the words of\] R. Meir[^fn_20b_43] \[that\] one remembers[^fn_20b_44] evidence till sixty years, for a longer[^fn_20b_45] \[period than sixty years\] one does not remember.
