But it is not so, \[for\] there[^fn_20b_46] \[he does not remember the evidence after sixty years\] because it[^fn_20b_47] is not his concern,[^fn_20b_48] but here,[^fn_20b_49] since it is his concern, even for a longer \[period[^fn_20b_50] he\] also \[remembers the evidence\].

***MISHNAH***. \[IF\] ONE[^fn_20b_51] WITNESS SAYS, 'THIS IS MY HANDWRITING AND THAT IS THE HANDWRITING OF MY FELLOW, AND THE OTHER \[WITNESS\] SAYS, 'THIS IS MY HANDWRITING AND THAT IS THE HANDWRITING OF MY FELLOW,' THEY ARE BELIEVED. \[IF\] ONE SAYS, 'THIS IS MY HANDWRITING,' AND THE OTHER SAYS, 'THIS IS MY HANDWRITING,' THEY MUST JOIN TO THEMSELVES ANOTHER \[PERSON\].[^fn_20b_52] \[THIS IS\] THE VIEW[^fn_20b_53] OF RABBI. BUT THE SAGES SAY: THEY NEED NOT JOIN TO THEMSELVES ANOTHER \[PERSON\], BUT A PERSON IS BELIEVED TO SAY, 'THIS IS MY HANDWRITING'.[^fn_20b_54] ***GEMARA***. If you should find \[that\] according to the view of Rabbi [pg 21a] {¶=2.3}

they[^fn_21a_1] give evidence with regard to their handwriting.[^fn_21a_2] according to the Sages they[^fn_21a_3] give evidence with regard to the *maneh*[^fn_21a_4] in the deed.[^fn_21a_5] This is self-evident! — You might have said that Rabbi was in doubt whether they[^fn_21a_3] testified to their signature or to the *maneh* in the deed.[^fn_21a_6] And the difference[^fn_21a_7] would be when one of them died. \[Here\] we need two witnesses[^fn_21a_8] from the street to testify regarding it,[^fn_21a_9] because otherwise,[^fn_21a_10] the whole of the money less a quarter would go out[^fn_21a_11] by the mouth[^fn_21a_12] of one witness, and both here and there the stricter rule would prevail.[^fn_21a_13] Therefore, he teaches that it is clear to Rabbi,[^fn_21a_14] whether the result is lenient[^fn_21a_15] or strict.[^fn_21a_16] For Rab Judah said \[that\] Rab said: If two \[witnesses\] are signed on a document and one of them died, two \[persons\] from the street are required to give evidence with regard to him.[^fn_21a_17] In this[^fn_21a_18] it would be lenient[^fn_21a_19] according to Rabbi and it is strict[^fn_21a_20] according to the Rabbis. And if there are not two, but there is only one,[^fn_21a_21] what \[then\]? — Said Abaye: He[^fn_21a_22] shall write his signature on a piece of clay[^fn_21a_23] and place it before the court, and the court confirms it,[^fn_21a_24] and he need not testify to his own signature,[^fn_21a_25] and he \[then\] goes with that one[^fn_21a_26] and they \[together\] testify to \[the signature of\] the other \[witness\].[^fn_21a_27] And only on a piece of clay[^fn_21a_28] but not a scroll,[^fn_21a_29] lest a bad[^fn_21a_30] man may find it and write on it whatever he likes,[^fn_21a_31] and We have learned: If one person produces the handwriting[^fn_21a_32] of another person[^fn_21a_33] that he owes him \[money\], he collects \[the debt\] from unmortgaged[^fn_21a_34] property.[^fn_21a_35] Rab Judah said \[that\] Samuel said. The *halachah* is according to the Sages[^fn_21a_36] This is obvious! \[When there is a dispute between\] one \[authority\] and many \[authorities\] the law is according to the many (authorities\]! You might have said: since the *halachah* is according to Rabbi as against one of his fellow-scholars, it is also against many of his fellow-scholars,[^fn_21a_37] so be lets us hear[^fn_21a_38] \[otherwise\].

(Mnemonic: *NaH, NaD, HaD*.)[^fn_21a_39] R. Hinena b. Hiyya said to R. Judah, and some say (that\] R. Huna b. Judah \[said\] to Rab Judah, and some say \[that\] R. Hiyya b. Judah \[said\] to Rab Judah: And did Samuel say so? Surely once a deed came out[^fn_21a_40] from the court of Mar Samuel and there was written in it, 'Whereas R. 'Anan b. Hiyya came and testified to his own signature and to that of his fellow-witness,[^fn_21a_41] namely,[^fn_21a_42] R. Hanan b. Rabbah, and whereas R. Hanan b. Rabbah came and testified to his own signature and to that of his fellow-witness, namely R. 'Anan b. Hiyya,' we have verified[^fn_21a_43] it, and we have confirmed it,[^fn_21a_43] as it is proper![^fn_21a_44] — He said to him: That deed belonged to orphans, and Samuel was afraid of an erring court.[^fn_21a_45] Samuel thought: There might be someone who held that the *halachah* is \[generally\] according to Rabbi as against one fellow-scholar, and not as against many of his fellow-scholars, but \[that\] in this[^fn_21a_46] \[the *halachah* is according to Rabbi\] even as against many of his fellow-scholars,[^fn_21a_47] I will make relief,[^fn_21a_48] so that the orphans should not suffer any loss.

Rab Judah said \[that\] Samuel said: Witness and judge are joined together.[^fn_21a_49] Rami b. Hama said: How excellent is this tradition! Said Raba: What is the excellence? What the witness testifies to the judge does not testify to, and what the judge testifies to the witness does not testify to?[^fn_21a_50] And indeed, when Rami b. Ezekiel came he said: Do not heed those rules which my brother Judah[^fn_21a_51] laid down in the name of Samuel. [pg 21b]

Rabbanai, the brother of R. Hiyya b. Abba, came to buy sesame and he said: Thus Samuel said: Witness and judge are joined together. Amemar said: How excellent is this tradition! Said R. Ashi to Amemar: Because the father of your mother[^fn_21b_1] praised it, you also praise it! Raba has already refuted it.

R. Safra said \[that\] R. Abba said \[that\] R. Isaac b. Samuel b. Martha said \[that\] R. Huna said, and some say \[that\] R. Huna said \[that\] Rab said: If three[^fn_21b_2] sit together to confirm a deed, and two \[of them\] know[^fn_21b_3] the signatures of the witnesses and one does not know,[^fn_21b_4] before they sign,[^fn_21b_5] they may testify[^fn_21b_6] before him,[^fn_21b_7] and he[^fn_21b_8] \[then\] signs[^fn_21b_9] \[with them\]; after they have signed, they may not testify before him and he may not sign. But do we write \[the attestation\]?[^fn_21b_10] Did not R. Papi say in the name of Raba: The judge's attestation which is written before the witnesses give evidence as to their signatures is invalid, because it looks like a lie? \[And\] here also it looks like a lie! — But say: Before they have written \[the attestation\] they may testify before him and he \[then\] signs \[with them\]; after they have written \[the attestation\], they may not testify before him and he may not sign. We may infer from this three things.[^fn_21b_11] We may infer that a witness may be[^fn_21b_12] a judge;[^fn_21b_13] we may \[also\] infer that, if the judges know the signatures of the witnesses, there is no need to testify[^fn_21b_14] before them;[^fn_21b_15] and \[again\] we may infer that, if the judges do not know the signatures of the witnesses, it is necessary to give evidence before every one.[^fn_21b_16] R. Ashi demurred to this: Agreed[^fn_21b_17] that we may infer from it that a witness may be a judge, but \[how can we infer from it that\], if the judges know the signatures of the witnesses, there is no need to testify before them? Perhaps, indeed, I can say to you \[that\] this is necessary, but it is different here, because the telling[^fn_21b_18] has been fulfilled before one.[^fn_21b_19] And \[further, how can we infer from It that\], if the judges do not know the signatures of the witnesses, it is necessary to give evidence before every one?[^fn_21b_20] Perhaps, indeed, I can say to you \[that\] this is not necessary, but it is different here, because the telling[^fn_21b_21] would not have been fulfilled at all.[^fn_21b_22]

R. Abba sat and reported[^fn_21b_23] this law, that a witness may be a judge. R. Safra \[then\] objected to R. Abba: If three[^fn_21b_24] saw it[^fn_21b_25] and they are \[of\] the court, two[^fn_21b_26] shall stand up and set \[two\] of their fellows[^fn_21b_27] beside the one, and they[^fn_21b_28] shall testify before them,[^fn_21b_29] and \[then\] they say: Hallowed is the new moon, hallowed; for one person is not believed by himself. Now, if you assume that a witness may be a judge, what do we want all this for? Let them sit in their places[^fn_21b_30] and proclaim[^fn_21b_31] \[the new moon\] is hallowed! — He said to him: That was also difficult to me, and I asked R. Isaac b. Samuel b. Martha. and R. Isaac \[asked\] R. Huna, and R. Huna \[asked\] Hiyya b. Rab, and Hiyya b. Rab \[asked\] Rab, and he said to them: Leave alone the testimony as to the new moon, \[for it is\] Biblical, and the confirmation of documents is Rabbinic.[^fn_21b_32]

R. Abba said \[that\] R. Huna said \[that\] Rab said: If three sit to confirm a document and an objection is raised[^fn_21b_33] against one of them,[^fn_21b_34] they[^fn_21b_35] may, before they have signed \[the attestation\], give evidence regarding him,[^fn_21b_36] and he may \[then\] sign; after they have signed, they may not give evidence regarding him[^fn_21b_37] and he may not sign. On what ground was that objection raised? If the objection was on the ground of robbery,[^fn_21b_38] [pg 22a]

they are two and two.[^fn_22a_1] \[And\] if it is a protest regarding family blemish,[^fn_22a_2] \[then all that is required is\] merely a revealing of the matter.[^fn_22a_3] — Indeed, I will tell you, it is a protest regarding robbery, and these say: We know of him that he has repented.[^fn_22a_4] 

R. Zera said: This thing I have heard from R. Abba, and if not for R. Abba of Acco, I would have forgotten it: If three sit to confirm a document and one of them dies,[^fn_22a_5] they must write, 'We were In a session of three, and one is no more.'[^fn_22a_6] R. Nahman b. Isaac said: And if it is written in it: This document has been produced[^fn_22a_7] before us \[as\] a court of law, more is not necessary.[^fn_22a_8] But perhaps it was an arrogant court, and \[that is\] according to Samuel, for Samuel said: If two have judged,[^fn_22a_9] their judgment is a judgment,[^fn_22a_10] only they are called an arrogant court?[^fn_22a_11] — When it is written in it, \[e.g.\] 'The court of our Master Ashi.'[^fn_22a_12] But perhaps the scholars of the school of R. Ashi hold with Samuel? — When it is written in it, 'And our Master Ashi told us.'[^fn_22a_13]

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN SAYS. 'I WAS MARRIED[^fn_22a_14] AND I AM DIVORCED', SHE IS BELIEVED, FOR THE MOUTH THAT FORBADE IS THE MOUTH THAT PERMITS. BUT IF THERE ARE WITNESSES THAT SHE WAS MARRIED, AND SHE SAYS. 'I AM DIVORCED', SHE IS NOT BELIEVED. IF SHE SAYS. 'I WAS TAKEN CAPTIVE BUT I HAVE REMAINED CLEAN.'[^fn_22a_15] SHE IS BELIEVED, FOR THE MOUTH THAT FORBADE IS THE MOUTH THAT PERMITS. BUT IF THERE ARE WITNESSES THAT SHE WAS TAKEN CAPTIVE AND SHE SAYS, 'I HAVE REMAINED CLEAN,' SHE IS NOT BELIEVED. BUT IF THE WITNESSES CAME AFTER SHE HAD MARRIED, SHE SHALL NOT GO OUT.[^fn_22a_16] {¶=2.4}

***GEMARA***. R. Assi said: Whence \[do we know\] from the Torah \[the principle of\] 'the mouth that forbade is the mouth that permits'? Because it is said: 'My daughter I gave to this man as a wife.'[^fn_22a_17] \[By saying\] 'to man', he made her forbidden,[^fn_22a_18] \[by saying\] 'this', he made her permitted.[^fn_22a_19] Why is a Scriptural verse necessary? It stands to reason: he made her forbidden, and he made her permitted! — The Scriptural verse is required according to what R. Huna \[said that\] Rab said, for R. Huna said \[that\] Rab said: Whence \[do we know\] from the Bible that the father is believed to make his daughter forbidden?[^fn_22a_20] Because it is said: 'My daughter I gave to \[this\] man as his wife.'[^fn_22a_21] Why \[is it said\] 'this'?[^fn_22a_22] — It is required for what R. Jonah taught, for R. Jonah taught: 'My daughter I gave to this man': '\[To\] this \[man\]', and not to the brother-in-law.[^fn_22a_23] Our Rabbis taught: If a woman says, I am married', and then she says.[^fn_22a_24] 'I am unmarried', she is believed. But she made herself forbidden![^fn_22a_25] — Said Raba the son of R. Huna: When she has given a plausible reason for her words.[^fn_22a_26] We have also a Baraitha to the same effect. If she says, 'I am married', and then she says, 'I am unmarried', she is not believed, but if she gives a plausible reason for her words, she is believed. And so it once happened with a great woman, who was great in beauty, and men were eager[^fn_22a_27] to betroth her, and she said to them, 'I am betrothed'. After a time she became betrothed.[^fn_22a_28] The Sages said to her: Why have you chosen[^fn_22a_29] to do this?[^fn_22a_30] She answered them,[^fn_22a_31] 'At first, when unworthy men came to me, I said, "I am betrothed"; now that worthy men come to me, I became betrothed'. And this law R. Aha, the prince of the castle, brought before the Sages[^fn_22a_32] in Usha, and they said: If she gives a plausible reason for her words she is believed.

Samuel asked Rab: If \[a woman\] says,[^fn_22a_33] 'I am unclean',[^fn_22a_34] and then she says. 'I am clean',[^fn_22a_35] what is \[the law\]?[^fn_22a_36] He[^fn_22a_37] answered him:[^fn_22a_38] Also in this case if she gives [pg 22b]

a plausible reason for her words she is believed. He learned it from him forty times, and still Samuel did not act accordingly with regard to himself.

Our Rabbis taught: When two \[witnesses\] say \[that the husband of the woman\] has died, and two \[witnesses\] say \[that\] he has not died, or two \[witnesses\] say \[that\] she has been divorced, and two \[witnesses\] say \[that\] she has not been divorced, she shall not marry \[again\], but if she has married \[again\], she shall not go out. R. Menahem b. Jose says: She shall go out. R. Menahem b. Jose said: When do I say \[that\] she shall go out? — When witnesses[^fn_22b_1] came and then she married, but if she married and then came witnesses,[^fn_22b_1] she shall not go out. Now, they are two and two,[^fn_22b_2] \[and\] he who has intercourse with her[^fn_22b_3] is liable to a doubtful guilt-offering![^fn_22b_4] Said R. Shesheth: When she married one of her witnesses.[^fn_22b_5] Then she herself should bring a doubtful guilt. offering! — When she says. 'I am sure'.[^fn_22b_6]

R. Johanan said: When two \[witnesses\] say \[that the husband of the woman\] has died, and two \[witnesses\] say \[that\] he has not died, she shall not marry \[again\], but if she has married \[again\], she shall not go out. When two \[witnesses\] say \[that\] she has been divorced, and two \[witnesses\] say \[that\] she has not been divorced, she shall not marry \[again\]. and if she has married, she shall go out. What is the difference between the first case and the second case? — Abaye said: Explain it[^fn_22b_7] \[that it speaks\] of one witness.[^fn_22b_8] When one witness says \[that\] he has died, the Rabbis believe him as two \[witnesses\].[^fn_22b_9] And \[this is\] according to 'Ulla, for 'Ulla said: Wherever the Torah makes one witness credible. \[it is as if\] there are two, whereas he who said that he has not died is one, and the words of one have no validity against two.[^fn_22b_10] If so, \[she should be allowed to marry again\] from the beginning? — Because of that \[saying\] of R. Assi, for R. Assi said: 'Put away from thee a froward mouth, and perverse lips put far from thee'.[^fn_22b_11] In the second case \[however\] one witness says \[that\] she has been divorced, and one witness says \[that\] she has not been divorced, they \[therefore\] both testify to a married woman, and he who says \[that\] she has been divorced is one, and the words of one have no validity against two. Raba said: Indeed, they are two and two, and R. Johanan regards \[as right\] the words of R. Menahem b. Jose[^fn_22b_12] in \[the case of\] divorce, but not in \[the case of\] death. Why? — In the case of death, she cannot contradict him,[^fn_22b_13] \[but\] in the case of divorce, she can contradict him.[^fn_22b_14] But would she be as impudent as all that?[^fn_22b_15] Did not R. Hamnuna say: If a woman says to her husband, 'thou hast divorced me,' she is believed, \[for\] the presumption is \[that\] a woman is not insolent before her husband?[^fn_22b_16] — This is the case only when there are no witnesses who support her; but when there are witnesses who support her, she is indeed insolent. R. Assi says: When the witnesses say, 'he has died just now, he has divorced her just now.' Death one cannot prove,[^fn_22b_17] divorce one can prove, for we say to her, 'if it is so, shew us thy document of divorce'.[^fn_22b_18]

Our Rabbis taught: If two \[witnesses\] say that she has been betrothed, and two \[witnesses\] say \[that\] she has not been betrothed, she shall not marry, and if she has married, she shall not go out. If two \[witnesses\] say \[that\] she has been divorced, and two \[witnesses\] say \[that\] she has not been divorced, she shall not marry, and if she has married, she shall go out. [pg 23a]

What is the difference between the first case and the second case? — Abaye said: Explain it[^fn_23a_1] \[that it speaks\] of one witness.[^fn_23a_2] When one witness says \[that\] she has been betrothed and one witness says \[that\] she has not been betrothed, they both testify to an unmarried woman, and he who says \[that\] she has been betrothed is one, and the words of one have no validity against two. In the second case \[where\] one witness says \[that\] she has been divorced and one witness says \[that\] she has not been divorced, they both testify to a married woman, and he who says that she has been divorced is one, and the words of one have no validity against two. R. Ashi said: Indeed, they are two and two, and reverse it.[^fn_23a_3] When two say, 'we have seen[^fn_23a_4] that she has been betrothed', and two Say, we have not seen that she has been betrothed, she shall not marry \[another man\], and if she has married she goes out.' \[But\] this is obvious! 'We have not seen' is no evidence! — It is not \[so obvious\], as it is needed for the case when they dwelt in one courtyard; one might say, 'if she had been betrothed it would have been known,'[^fn_23a_5] so he lets us hear that there are people who get betrothed quietly. In the second case, when two say, 'we have seen that she has been divorced,' and two say, 'we have not seen that she has been divorced, she shall not marry again, and if she has married she shall not go out,' what does he let us hear \[by this case\]?[^fn_23a_6] Although they live in the same courtyard! \[But then\] this is the same![^fn_23a_7] — One might say that with regard to betrothal it happens that people get betrothed quietly. but with regard to divorce. if she had been divorced, it would have been known, so he lets us hear that there are people who get betrothed and get divorced quietly.

AND IF WITNESSES COME AFTER SHE GOT MARRIED. SHE SHALL NOT GO OUT. R. Oshaia refers it[^fn_23a_8] to the first clause.[^fn_23a_9] Rabbah b. Abin refers it to the second clause.[^fn_23a_10] He who refers it to the first clause, how much more \[does he refer it\] to the second clause, for in the case of a captive woman they have made it lenient.[^fn_23a_11] But he who refers it to the second clause does not refer it to the first clause.[^fn_23a_12] Is it to say that they differ concerning the view of R. Hamnuna: that he who refers it to the first clause holds the view of R. Hamnuna,[^fn_23a_13] and he who refers it \[only\] to the second clause does not hold the View of R. Hamnuna? — No, all hold the view of R. Hamnuna. and here they differ in this: one argues: When was that of R. Hamnuna said?[^fn_23a_14] In his presence,[^fn_23a_15] but in his absence she is impudent,[^fn_23a_16] and one holds \[that\] in his absence also she is not impudent.[^fn_23a_17] 

AND IF WITNESSES CAME AFTER SHE GOT MARRIED. etc. The father of Samuel said: 'SHE GOT MARRIED', does not mean, 'she actually got married'. but 'as soon as they[^fn_23a_18] allowed her to get married', even if she did not get married yet. But it says: SHE SHALL NOT GO OUT'![^fn_23a_19] — \[This means\] she shall not go out from her first permission.[^fn_23a_20] 

Our Rabbis taught: When she says. 'I was taken captive. and I am pure, and I have witnesses that I am pure. they[^fn_23a_18] do not say: We will wait until the witnesses come, but they[^fn_23a_18] allow her at once \[to marry\]. If they[^fn_23a_18] allowed her to marry and then the witnesses came and said, 'we do not know',[^fn_23a_21] then she shall not go out. But if witnesses of defilement[^fn_23a_22] came, even if she has many children she shall go out.[^fn_23a_23] 

Certain women captives came once to Nehardea. The father of Samuel[^fn_23a_24] placed watchmen with them.[^fn_23a_25] Said Samuel to him: And who watched them till now? Said he to him: 'If they had been thy daughters wouldst thou also have spoken of them so lightly?' It was 'as an error which proceedeth from before the ruler,'[^fn_23a_26] and the daughters of Mar Samuel were taken captive. And they were brought[^fn_23a_27] to the Land of Israel. They let their captors stand outside and they went in into the school of R. Hanina. This One[^fn_23a_28] said, 'I was taken captive and I am pure,' and that one said. 'I was taken captive and I am pure. \[So\] they[^fn_23a_18] allowed them.[^fn_23a_29] Then the captors entered. R. Hanina \[thereupon\] said: They are the children of a Scholar.[^fn_23a_30] It \[then\] became known[^fn_23a_31] that they were the daughters of Mar Samuel. R. Hanina \[thereupon\] said to R. Shaman b. Abba: Go and take care of thy relatives.[^fn_23a_32] Said he to R. Hanina: But there are witnesses in the country beyond the sea![^fn_23a_33] — Now, however. they are not before us. Witnesses are in the North,[^fn_23a_34] and \[therefore\] she shall be forbidden \[to marry\]? \[Now\] the reason[^fn_23a_35] is because no witnesses came,[^fn_23a_36] but if witnesses came she[^fn_23a_37] is forbidden! But did not the father of Samuel say: As soon as they allowed her to get married, even if she did not get married?[^fn_23a_38] R. Ashi said: It was stated: Witnesses of defilement.[^fn_23a_39] [pg 23b]

***MISHNAH***. IF TWO WOMEN WERE TAKEN CAPTIVE, \[AND NOW\] ONE SAYS, 'I WAS TAKEN CAPTIVE AND I AM PURE, AND THE OTHER ONE SAYS. I WAS TAKEN CAPTIVE AND I AM PURE.' THEY ARE NOT BELIEVED. BUT WHEN THEY TESTIFY TO ONE ANOTHER, THEY ARE BELIEVED. {¶=2.5}

***GEMARA***. Our Rabbis taught: \[If she says\]. 'I am impure and my friend is pure,' she is believed; 'I am pure and my friend is impure', she is not believed; 'I and my friend are impure', she is believed as to herself and she is not believed as to her friend; 'I and my friend are pure'; she is believed as to her friend and she is not believed as to herself.

The Master said: '\[If she says\]. "I am pure and my friend is impure", she is not believed'. How shall we imagine this case? If there are no witnesses,[^fn_23b_1] why is she not believed as to herself? She says, 'I was taken captive and I am pure!'[^fn_23b_2] Hence it is plain that there are witnesses. \[Now\] read the middle clause: '"I and my friend are impure"; she is believed as to herself and she is not believed as to her friend'. But if there are witnesses, why is she not believed?[^fn_23b_3] Hence it is plain that there are no witnesses. \[Now\] read the last clause: '"l and my friend are pure"; she is believed as to her friend and she is not believed as to herself'. But if there are no witnesses, why is she not believed as to herself? Hence it is plain that there are witnesses. The first clause and the last clause when there are witnesses, \[and\] the middle clause when there are no witnesses? — Abaye said: Yes, the first clause and the last clause when there are witnesses, \[and\] the middle clause when there are no witnesses. R. Papa said: The whole of it \[speaks\] of where there are witnesses, but there is one witness who reverses.[^fn_23b_4] \[If\] she says, 'I am impure and my friend is pure', and the one witness says to her, 'thou art pure and thy friend is impure', she has declared herself forbidden,[^fn_23b_5] \[and\] her friend becomes permitted through her testimony.[^fn_23b_6] If \[she says\] 'I am pure and my friend is impure', and the one witness says to her, 'Thou art impure and thy friend is pure', since there are witnesses,[^fn_23b_7] she is not believed[^fn_23b_8] \[as to herself\], \[and\] her friend becomes permitted through the testimony[^fn_23b_9] of the \[one\] witness. \[If she says\], 'I and my friend are impure.' and the one witness says to her, 'thou and thy friend are pure,' she has declared herself forbidden, \[and\] her friend becomes permitted through the testimony of the \[one\] witness. What need is there again for this?[^fn_23b_10] It is \[the same as in\] the first part![^fn_23b_11] — You might have said \[that\] they are both pure and the reason why she says so[^fn_23b_12] is that she acts \[in accordance with the saying:\] 'Let me die with the Philistines',[^fn_23b_13] so he lets us hear.[^fn_23b_14] \[If she says\] 'I and my friend are pure', and the one witness says to her, 'Thou and thy friend are impure', since there are witnesses,[^fn_23b_15] she is not believed,' \[and\] her friend becomes permitted through her testimony.[^fn_23b_16] What need is there again for this? It is \[the same as in\] the very first clause![^fn_23b_17] — You might have said \[that\] she is believed[^fn_23b_18] only when she declares herself as unfit,[^fn_23b_19] but when she declares herself as fit[^fn_23b_20] I might say that she is not believed,[^fn_23b_21] so he lets us hear[^fn_23b_22] \[that this is not so\].

***MISHNAH***. AND LIKEWISE TWO MEN, \[IF\] ONE SAYS, 'I AM A PRIEST',[^fn_23b_23] AND THE OTHER SAYS. 'I AM A PRIEST', THEY ARE NOT BELIEVED.[^fn_23b_24] BUT WHEN THEY TESTIFY TO ONE ANOTHER, THEY ARE BELIEVED. R. JUDAH SAID: ONE DOES NOT RAISE \[A PERSON\] TO THE PRIESTHOOD THROUGH THE TESTIMONY[^fn_23b_25] OF ONE WITNESS. R. ELEAZAR SAID: ONLY THEN, WHEN THERE ARE PEOPLE WHO OBJECT;[^fn_23b_26] BUT WHEN THERE ARE NO PEOPLE WHO OBJECT. ONE RAISES \[A PERSON\] TO THE PRIESTHOOD THROUGH THE TESTIMONY OF ONE WITNESS. R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL SAYS IN THE NAME OF R. SIMEON: THE SON OF THE CHIEF OF THE PRIESTS:[^fn_23b_27] ONE RAISES \[A PERSON\] TO THE PRIESTHOOD THROUGH THE TESTIMONY OF ONE WITNESS. {¶=2.6}

***GEMARA***. What need is there for all these \[cases\]?[^fn_23b_28] They are needed. For if he had stated \[only the case of\] 'R. Joshua admits'[^fn_23b_29] \[I might have said that only in that case is that principle applied\]. because there is a possible loss of money.[^fn_23b_30] but \[in the case of\] 'If witnesses say this is our handwriting'[^fn_23b_31] where there is no possible loss of money.[^fn_23b_32] I would not say so.[^fn_23b_33] And if he had stated \[the case of\] 'If witnesses say this is our handwriting'. \[I might have said that Only in that case does that principle apply\] because \[their statement concerns\] other people.[^fn_23b_34] but where it concerns himself[^fn_23b_35] [pg 24a]

I would not say so. And if he would let us hear these two \[cases. I might have said\] because \[both cases deal with\] money matters but \[in the case of\] 'a married woman',[^fn_24a_1] which is a matter of \[sexual\] prohibition.[^fn_24a_2] I would not say so.[^fn_24a_3]

What need is there for \[the case of\] 'I was taken captive and I am pure'?[^fn_24a_4] — Because he wants to teach 'But if witnesses came after she got married, she shall not go out'.[^fn_24a_5] — That is quite right according to him who refers this to the second clause, but according to him who refers this to the first clause,[^fn_24a_6] what is there to say? Because he wants to teach \[the case of\] 'If two women were taken captive'.[^fn_24a_7] — And what need is there for \[the case of\] 'If two women were taken captive'? — You might have said \[that\] we may be afraid that they favour one another,[^fn_24a_8] so he lets us hear \[that we do not say so\].[^fn_24a_9] What need is there for \[the case of\] 'AND LIKEWISE TWO MEN'?[^fn_24a_10] Because he wants to teach the difference of opinion between R. Judah and the Rabbis.[^fn_24a_11] 

Our Rabbis taught: \[If one says:\] I am a priest and my friend is a priest. he is believed to the extent of allowing him to eat *terumah*,[^fn_24a_12] but he is not believed to the extent of allowing him to marry a woman[^fn_24a_13] until there are three, \[and\] two testify to one and two testify to the other. R. Judah says: He is not believed even with regard to allowing him to eat *terumah* until there are three, \[and\] two testify to one and two testify to the other. Is this to say that R. Judah is afraid that they might favour one another,[^fn_24a_14] and the Rabbis are not afraid that they might favour one another? Surely \[from the following Mishnah\] we understand just the reverse! For we have learned: When ass-drivers[^fn_24a_15] come to a town and one of them says, 'Mine[^fn_24a_16] is new[^fn_24a_17] and my friend's is old mine is not prepared[^fn_24a_18] and my friends is prepared'; he is not believed;[^fn_24a_19] R. Judah says: He is believed![^fn_24a_20] — Said R. Adda b. Ahaba, in the name of Rab: The statement must be reversed.[^fn_24a_21] Abaye said: Indeed, there is no need to reverse It;[^fn_24a_22] in \[the case of\] *demai*,[^fn_24a_23] they[^fn_24a_24] have made it lenient, for most of the 'amme ha-'arez[^fn_24a_25] separate the tithes. Raba said: Is the question \[only\] of R. Judah against R. Judah? Is there no question \[also\] Of the Rabbis against the Rabbis?[^fn_24a_26] No, \[they answer\]: there is no question of R. Judah against R. Judah. as we have \[just\] explained,[^fn_24a_27] \[and\] there is no question of the Rabbis against the Rabbis, for \[the case[^fn_24a_28] is similar to that with regard to which\] R. Hama b. 'Ukba said that \[it speaks of\] when he has his trade-tools in his hand; [pg 24b]

so here also[^fn_24b_1] \[we deal with\] when he[^fn_24b_2] has his trade-tools[^fn_24b_3] in his hand.[^fn_24b_4] And with regard to what[^fn_24b_5] was that of R. Hama. b. 'Ukba said?[^fn_24b_6] With regard to what we have learned: If a potter left his pots[^fn_24b_7] and went down to drink \[water from the river,\][^fn_24b_8] the inner ones are pure and the outer ones are impure.[^fn_24b_9] But it has been taught[^fn_24b_10] that these and those are impure? — Said R. Hama b. 'Ukba: \[it speaks of a case\][^fn_24b_11] when he had his trade-tools in his hand,[^fn_24b_12] so that[^fn_24b_13] the hand of all touches them.[^fn_24b_14] But it has been taught:[^fn_24b_15] These and those are pure? — Said R. Hama b. 'Ukba: When his trade-tools are not in his hand.[^fn_24b_16] But \[then\] the case that we have learnt:[^fn_24b_17] 'The inner ones are pure and the outer ones are impure' — how is that possible?[^fn_24b_18] — When they[^fn_24b_19] are near the public road and \[they are impure\] because of border stones of the public road.[^fn_24b_20] And if you wish you may say: R. Judah and the Rabbis differ as to whether one raises \[a person\] from *terumah* to the status of a priest.[^fn_24b_21]

The question was asked: What is \[the law\]? Does one raise[^fn_24b_22] \[a person\] from documents[^fn_24b_23] to the full status of a priest?[^fn_24b_24] — How shall we imagine this case? If we say that it is written in it: 'I, So-and-so, a priest. have signed as witness' — who testifies to him?[^fn_24b_25] — No, \[but\] it must be when it is written in it: I, So-and-so, a priest, have borrowed a *maneh* from so-and-so, and witnesses have signed \[the document\]. What \[then\] is \[the law\]? Do they[^fn_24b_26] testify \[only\] to the *maneh* \[mentioned\] in the document, or do they testify to the whole matter?[^fn_24b_27] — R. Huna and R. Hisda \[give opposing answers\]: One says: One raises,[^fn_24b_28] and one says: One does not raise.[^fn_24b_28]

The question was asked.[^fn_24b_29] What is \[the law\]? Does one raise \[a person\] from the lifting up of the hands[^fn_24b_30] to the status of a priest?[^fn_24b_31] This is asked according to him who says \[that\] one raises \[a person\] from *terumah* to the status of a priest[^fn_24b_32] and this is asked according to him who says \[that\] one does not raise \[a person from *terumah* to the status of a priest\].[^fn_24b_33] It is asked according to him who says \[that\] one raises: When is this said?[^fn_24b_34] \[In the case of\] *terumah*, which \[if eaten by one who is not a priest\] is a sin punishable with death;[^fn_24b_35] but \[in the case of\] 'lifting up the hands', which \[if one who is not a priest performs the pronouncing of the priestly blessing\] is \[only transgressing the\] prohibition of a positive command,[^fn_24b_36] \[I would say\] no.[^fn_24b_37] Or perhaps there is no difference,[^fn_24b_38] \[and\] it is asked according to him who says \[that\] one does not raise: When is this said? \[In the case of\] *terumah*, which is eaten in privacy;[^fn_24b_39] but \[in the case of\] 'lifting up the hands,' which \[is done\] in public \[I might say that\] if he were not a priest he would not have the impudence[^fn_24b_40] \[to act as a priest\]. Or perhaps there is no difference?[^fn_24b_41] — R. Hisda and R. Abina \[give opposing answers to this question\]: One says: One raises,[^fn_24b_42] and One Says: One does not raise.

R. Nahman b. Isaac said to Raba: What is \[the law\]? Does one raise \[a person\] from 'lifting up the hands' to the full status of a priest? Said he to him: \[With regard to this\] there is a difference of opinion between R. Hisda and R. Abina. What is the \[adopted\] law? Said he to him: I know a Baraitha: For it has been taught: R. Jose said: Great[^fn_24b_43] is presumption.[^fn_24b_44] for it is said: And the children of the priests: the children of Habaiah, the children of Hakkoz, the children of Barzillai, who took a wife of the daughters of Barzillai the Gileadite, and was called after their name. These sought their register. of those that were reckoned by genealogy, and they were not found,' therefore were they deemed polluted and put from the priesthood. And the Tirshatha[^fn_24b_45] said unto them, that they should not eat of the most holy things, till there stood up a priest with Urim and Thummim.[^fn_24b_46] He[^fn_24b_47] \[thus\] said to them: You remain[^fn_24b_48] in your presumptive state; what have you eaten in exile?[^fn_24b_49] The holy things of the country.[^fn_24b_50] So here also \[you shall eat\] the sacred things of the country.[^fn_24b_51] Now if we were to assume \[that\] one raises \[a person\] from 'lifting up the hands' to the state of a priest, since these spread out their hands,[^fn_24b_52] one might raise them?'[^fn_24b_53] — It is different here,[^fn_24b_54] for their presumption has been impaired[^fn_24b_55] For if you will not say so.[^fn_24b_56] \[then\] according to him who says \[that\] one raises \[a person\] from *terumah*, since they eat *terumah*. one might raise them to the status of priests! Hence, \[you must say it is\][^fn_24b_57] because their presumption has been impaired.[^fn_24b_58] [pg 25a]

If so,[^fn_25a_1] what \[do the words of R. Jose mean\] 'Great is the presumption'?[^fn_25a_2] — Till now[^fn_25a_3] they ate \[only\] Rabbinical *terumah*.[^fn_25a_4] \[and\] now they ate Biblical *terumah*.[^fn_25a_5] And if you wish, you may say: now also they ate Rabbinical *terumah*[^fn_25a_6] \[and\] did not eat Biblical *terumah*,[^fn_25a_7] and when does one raise \[a person\] from *terumah* to the status of a priest. In the case of Biblical *terumah*, but in the case of Rabbinical *terumah* one does not raise. If so,[^fn_25a_8] what \[is the meaning of the words\] 'Great is the presumption'?[^fn_25a_9] — Although one might have forbidden \[Rabbinical *terumah*\] because of Biblical *terumah*,[^fn_25a_10] this has not been forbidden. But did they not eat Biblical *terumah*? Surely it is written: 'that they should not eat of the most holy things', \[implying\] 'the most holy things' they did not eat, but Biblical *terumah* they did eat! — \[No\]. He means thus: Neither \[may they eat\] anything that is called 'holy thing's[^fn_25a_11] as it is written: 'And no stranger shall eat of the holy thing', nor anything which is called 'holy thing'. for it is written: 'And if a priest's daughter be married into a stranger. she shall not eat of the peace-offering of the holy things'[^fn_25a_12] — and a Master said: \[that this means\] that which has been set aside from the holy things she shall not eat.[^fn_25a_13]

Come and hear: A presumption for the priesthood is constituted by the 'lifting up of the hands' in Babylonia, and the eating of the *hallah*[^fn_25a_14] in Syria, and taking a share in \[the priestly\] gifts[^fn_25a_15] in large cities.[^fn_25a_16] In any case he mentions \[here\] the 'lifting up of the hands'; is it not with regard to the full status of the priest?[^fn_25a_17] — No, with regard to *terumah*.[^fn_25a_18] But he teaches \[the ruling regarding *terumah*\] as analogous to the eating of *hallah*,' just as the eating of *hallah* \[entitles a person\] to the full status of a priest, so does the lifting up of the hands \[entitle a person\] to the full status of a priest? — No. the eating of the *hallah* itself merely \[serves as evidence\] regarding *terumah*, \[for\] he holds that *hallah* in our days[^fn_25a_19] is Rabbinical and *terumah* is Biblical and one raises \[a person\] from Rabbinical *hallah* to Biblical *terumah*.[^fn_25a_20] and \[it is\] as R. Huna. the son of R. Joshua. reversed \[the words of\] the Rabbis.[^fn_25a_21]

Come and hear: A presumption for the priesthood is \[constituted by\] the 'lifting up of the hands' and taking a share \[at the distribution of the \[priestly gifts\] at the threshing floors[^fn_25a_22] in the Land of Israel;[^fn_25a_23] in Syria and in all places to which the messengers of the new moon come[^fn_25a_24] the 'lifting up of the hands' is evidence, but not taking a share at the threshing floors.[^fn_25a_25] Babylonia is like Syria. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel, says: Also Alexandria in Egypt formerly. because there was there a permanent court of law.[^fn_25a_26] In any case he teaches \[here\] the 'lifting up of the hands'; is it not with regard to the full status of the priest? — No, with regard to *hallah*. But he teaches \[the rule regarding the lifting up of the hands\] as analogous to taking a share at the threshing floors: just as taking a share at the threshing floors \[serves as evidence\] in respect of the status of a priest, so does the 'lifting up of the hands' \[serve\] in respect of the status of a priest! — No, taking a share at the threshing floors itself \[serves as evidence only as\] to *hallah*, for he holds that *terumah* in our days is Rabbinical and *hallah* is Biblical and one raises \[a person\] from Rabbinical *terumah* to Biblical *hallah*, even as the Rabbis. whom R. Huna the son of R. Joshua found \[in discourse\]. For R. Huna, the son of R. Joshua, found the Rabbis in the School of Rab sitting[^fn_25a_27] and saying: Even according to him who says that *terumah* in these days is Rabbinical. *hallah* is Biblical, for during the seven \[years\] that they[^fn_25a_28] conquered \[the Land\] and during the seven \[years\] that they distributed \[it\][^fn_25a_29] there was a duty upon them \[to separate\] *hallah*, but there was no duty upon them \[to separate\] *terumah*. And I said to them: On the contrary, even according to him who says \[that\] *terumah* in these days is Biblical, *hallah* is Rabbinical, for it has been taught: \[It is written:\] 'In your coming'.[^fn_25a_30] If 'in your coming'[^fn_25a_31] you might think as soon as two or three spies had entered it? \[Therefore\] it is said in your coming'.[^fn_25a_32] I have spoken of the coming of all and not of the coming of a portion of you. Now when Ezra brought them up[^fn_25a_33] [pg 25b]

not all of them went up.[^fn_25b_1]

Come and hear: A presumption for the priesthood \[is constituted by\] the 'lifting up of the hands' and taking a share at the threshing floors and testimony.[^fn_25b_2] Now is testimony a presumption?[^fn_25b_3] Hence he means thus: The 'lifting up of the hands is like a testimony'; as a testimony \[raises one\] to the status of a priest, so the 'lifting up of the hands' \[raises one\] to the status of a priest![^fn_25b_4] — No. \[what it means is\] a testimony that comes on the strength of a presumption[^fn_25b_5] is like a presumption. as when a man came once before R. Ammi \[and\] said to him: I am convinced that he[^fn_25b_6] is a priest. So he said to him: What have you seen? And he answered him: He read first in the Synagogue.[^fn_25b_7] — As[^fn_25b_8] priest or as prominent man?[^fn_25b_9] — After him a Levite read.[^fn_25b_10] And R. Ammi raised him to the priesthood on the strength of his testimony.[^fn_25b_11]

Someone came before R. Joshua b. Levi, \[and\] said to him: am convinced that he[^fn_25b_12] is a Levite. He said to him: What have you seen? He answered him: He read second in the Synagogue. As Levite or as a prominent man? — A priest read before him.[^fn_25b_13] And R. Joshua b. Levi raised him to the status of Levite[^fn_25b_14] on the strength of his testimony.

Someone came once before Resh Lakish \[and\] said to him: I am convinced that he[^fn_25b_15] is a priest. He 'said to him: What have you seen? \[He answered him:\] He read first in the Synagogue. He[^fn_25b_16] asked him: Have you seen him take a share at the threshing floors?[^fn_25b_17] — Said R. Eleazar to him. And does the priesthood cease if there Is no threshing floor there?[^fn_25b_18] — Once they sat before R. Johanan \[and\] there came such a case before them. Resh Lakish asked him:[^fn_25b_19] Have you seen him take a share at the threshing floor? So R. Johanan said to him: And does the priesthood cease if there is no threshing floor there? — He[^fn_25b_20] turned round, looked at R. Eleazar with displeasure[^fn_25b_21] and said: You have heard something from the smith's son[^fn_25b_22] and you did not say it to us in his name.[^fn_25b_23]

Rabbi and R. Hiyya, one raised a son to the priesthood on the testimony of his father, and one raised a brother to the state of Levite on the testimony of his brother. It can be proved that it was Rabbi who raised the son to the priesthood on the testimony of his father, for it has been taught: If one comes and says: 'This Is my son and he is a priest,' he is believed with regard to allowing him to eat *terumah*, but he is not believed with regard to allowing him to marry a woman.[^fn_25b_24] This is the opinion[^fn_25b_25] of Rabbi. Said R. Hiyya to him: If you believe him so as to allow him to eat *terumah*, believe him \[also\] so as to allow him to marry a woman, and if you do not believe him so as to allow him to marry a woman, do not believe him also as to allow him to eat *terumah*. He answered him: I believed him so as to allow him to eat *terumah* because it is In his hands to let him eat *terumah*,[^fn_25b_26] but I do not believe him so as to allow him to marry a woman because it is not in his hands to let him marry a woman.[^fn_25b_27] It' is proved.[^fn_25b_28] And since it was Rabbi who raised the son to the priesthood on the testimony of his father, \[it follows that\] it was R. Hiyya who raised the brother to the status of Levite on the testimony of his brother, But \[according to\] R. Hiyya, why is the son different that \[he is\] not \[raised\]?[^fn_25b_29] Because he is related to his father. A brother. too, is related to his brother?[^fn_25b_30] — [pg 26a]

When he was talking in his simplicity.[^fn_26a_1] As that \[story which\] Rab Judah related in the name of Samuel: It happened that a man was talking in his simplicity and said: 'I remember when I was a child and rode on my father's shoulder, they brought me out from school and stripped me of my shirt and immersed me[^fn_26a_2] so that I could eat *terumah* in the evening.'[^fn_26a_3] And R. Hiyya added:[^fn_26a_4] 'And my friends held aloof from me and called me "Johanan the halloth-eater".'[^fn_26a_5] And Rabbi raised him to the priesthood on his testimony.

It has been taught: R. Simeon b. Eleazar, says: Just as *terumah* is a presumption for the priesthood, so is the first tithe a presumption for the priesthood,[^fn_26a_6] but he who takes a share \[at the threshing floors\] through the court — \[this\] is not a presumption.[^fn_26a_7] The first tithe belongs to the Levite?[^fn_26a_8] — \[This is\] according to R. Eleazar, the son of Azariah, for it has been taught: *Terumah* belongs to the priest, the first tithe to the Levite-this is the view of R. Akiba, R. Eleazar, the son of Azariah, says: The first tithe belongs also to the priest. \[But\] R. Eleazar, the son of Azariah, says: 'also to the priest'; does he say: to the priest and not to the Levite? — Yes. after Ezra had punished them.[^fn_26a_9] But perhaps it happened that they gave it to him?[^fn_26a_10] — Said R. Hisda: Here we treat of a case where we know that the father of that \[per. son\] is a priest and a rumour[^fn_26a_11] came Out concerning him that he is the son of a divorced woman[^fn_26a_12] or a *haluzah*[^fn_26a_13] and \[yet\] they gave him tithe at the threshing floor. \[He could not be regarded as\] a Levite, because he was not a Levite.[^fn_26a_14] What then could you say? That he was the son of a divorced woman or the son of a *haluzah*? \[But as to this\] there is no question that according to him who says \[that\] the first tithe is forbidden to strangers.[^fn_26a_15] they would not have given \[it\] to him. For even according to him who says: The first tithe is permitted to strangers.[^fn_26a_16] it is only to sustain them[^fn_26a_17] but as a distribution \[due to him as of right\] they do not give it to him.[^fn_26a_18]

'But he who takes a share \[at the threshing floors\] through the court \[this\] is not a presumption.' If it is not a presumption through the court, when is it a presumption? — Said R. Shesheth: he means thus: If one shares the *terumah* in the property of his father[^fn_26a_19] through the court, it is not a presumption. — This is obvious![^fn_26a_20] — You might have said \[that\] just as those[^fn_26a_21] \[get their share of *terumah*\] for eating. this one also \[gets his share of *terumah*\] for eating, so he lets us hear \[that\] those \[get the *terumah*\] for eating and this one for selling.[^fn_26a_22]

R. Judah says: ONE DOES NOT RAISE \[A PERSON\] TO THE PRIESTHOOD ON THE TESTIMONY OF ONE WITNESS, etc. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel says the same as R. Eliezer?[^fn_26a_23] And if you will say \[that\] they differ with regard to an objection raised by one person. \[in\] that R. Eliezer holds that an objection \[may be admitted if cooling from;\] one \[person\] and R. Simeon b. Gamaliel holds that an objection \[must come from at least\] two \[persons\] did not R. Johanan say' All agree that an objection \[must come from\] at least two persons? — But we treat here of a case where the father of this \[person\] is a priest and a rumour[^fn_26a_24] came out concerning him that he is the son of a divorced woman or the son of a *haluzah* and they put him down,[^fn_26a_25] and one witness came and said, 'I know that he is a priest.'[^fn_26a_26] [pg 26b]

and they raised him \[again\] and \[then\] came two \[other witnesses\] and said \[that\] he is the son of a divorced woman or the son of a *haluzah*. and they put him, down \[again\]. and \[then\] came one witness and said, 'I know that he is a priest'. \[Now\] all agree[^fn_26b_1] that they[^fn_26b_2] are joined into one testimony, and they differ as to whether we are afraid of bringing contempt on the court.[^fn_26b_3] The first Tanna[^fn_26b_4] holds: Since we put hill, down we do not raise him, \[again\]. because we are afraid of bringing contempt on the court.[^fn_26b_5] Whereas R. Simeon b. Gamaliel, holds: we have put him down and we can raise him, \[again\].[^fn_26b_6] and we are not afraid of bringing contempt on the court. R. Ashi asked against this: If so, even \[when there are\] two and two[^fn_26b_7] also?[^fn_26b_8] But, said R. Ashi, they differ as to whether they[^fn_26b_9] are joined into one testimony. And they have the same difference of opinion as these Tannaim,[^fn_26b_10] for it has been taught: Their testimonies are not joined together unless they have both seen[^fn_26b_11] at the same time;[^fn_26b_12] R. Joshua b. Korha. says: Even when \[they have seell\] one after another. Their testimonies are not established[^fn_26b_13] in court until they both give evidence at the same time; R. Nathan says: We hear the evidence of one to-day. and when the other one comes to-morrow we hear his evidence.[^fn_26b_14]

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN WAS IMPRISONED BY HEATHENS, IF FOR THE SAKE OF MONEY, SHE IS PERMITTED TO HER HUSBAND, AND IF FOR THE PURPOSE OF \[TAKING HER\] LIFE,[^fn_26b_15] SHE IS FORBIDDEN TO HER HUSBAND. {¶=2.7}

***GEMARA***. R. Samuel b. Isaac said \[that\] Rab said: They have taught \[this\] only when the hand of Israel is strong over the heathens.[^fn_26b_16] but when the hand of the heathens is strong over themselves,[^fn_26b_17] even if for the sake of money, she is forbidden to her husband. Raba raised an objection: R. Jose the priest and R. Zechariah b. ha-Kazzab[^fn_26b_18] testified regarding an Israelitish woman, who was pledged[^fn_26b_19] in Ashkelon and her family[^fn_26b_20] put her away.[^fn_26b_21] and her witnesses[^fn_26b_22] testified \[concerning her\] that she did not hide herself \[with a man\] and that she was not defiled \[by a man\]. \[that\] the Sages said to them: If you believe \[the witnesses\] that she was pledged believe \[them also\] that she did not hide herself and that she was not defiled, and if you do not believe \[them\] that she did not hide herself and that she was not defiled, do not believe \[them\] that she was pledged.[^fn_26b_23] Now Ashkelon \[was a town in which\] the hand of the heathens was strong over themselves and he teaches [pg 27a]

'when she was pledged' but not 'when she was imprisoned'?[^fn_27a_1] — \[No\] the same applies also to \[the case if\] she had been imprisoned. only it happened so.[^fn_27a_2]

Some say. Raba said: We have also learned \[in a Mishnah\] to the same effect: R. Jose the priest and R. Zechariah b. ha-Kazzab testified regarding an Israelitish woman. who was pledged in Ashkelon and her family put her away and her witnesses testified concerning her that she did not hide herself \[with a man\] and that she was not defiled \[by a man\]. \[that\] the Sages said: If you believe \[the witnesses\] that she was pledged believe \[them also\] that she did not hide herself and that she was not defiled, and if you do not believe \[them\] that she did not hide herself and was not defiled, do not believe \[them\] that she was pledged. In Ashkelon \[it happened\] for the sake of money, and \[yet\] the reason \[why the Sages permitted her to her husband was\] because witnesses testified concerning her, but if witnesses did not testify concerning her \[she would\] not \[have been permitted\]; and is it not \[also to be supposed\] that there is no difference whether she was pledged or imprisoned?[^fn_27a_3] — No, when she was pledged it is different.[^fn_27a_4] 

Some put \[this argument\] in the form of a contradiction. We have learned: IF FOR THE SAKE OF MONEY SHE IS PERMITTED TO HER HUSBAND. But here is a contradiction: 'R. Jose testified etc.' \[Now\] in Ashkelon \[it happened\] for the sake of money and \[yet\] the reason \[why she is permitted to her husband\] is because witnesses testify concerning her, but if no witnesses testify concerning her, \[she would\] not \[have been permitted\]. And it is answered: R. Samuel b. Isaac said: It is no contradiction; here[^fn_27a_5] \[it speaks\] when the hand of Israel is strong over the heathens, \[and\] there[^fn_27a_6] when the hand of the heathens is strong over themselves.

IF FOR THE PURPOSE OF \[TAKING HER\] LIFE SHE IS FORBIDDEN \[TO HER HUSBAND\]. Rab said: As, for instance, the wives of thieves.[^fn_27a_7] Levi said: As, for instance, the wife of Ben Dunai.[^fn_27a_8] Hezekiah said: This is only[^fn_27a_9] when they have \[already\] been sentenced to death — R. Johanan says: Even if they have not yet been sentenced to death.

***MISHNAH***. IF TROOPS OF SIEGE HAVE TAKEN A TOWN. ALL THE PRIESTS' WIVES[^fn_27a_10] WHO ARE IN IT ARE UNFIT.[^fn_27a_11] IF THEY HAVE WITNESSES,[^fn_27a_12] EVEN A SLAVE.[^fn_27a_13] EVEN A HANDMAID,[^fn_27a_14] THEY ARE BELIEVED. NO ONE IS BELIEVED AS TO HIMSELF. {¶=2.8}

***GEMARA***. There is a contradiction against this: If a reconnoitering troop comes to a town in time of peace the open casks \[of wine\] are forbidden[^fn_27a_15] and the closed ones are permitted.[^fn_27a_16] In times of war both are permitted, because they have no time to offer libations.[^fn_27a_17] — R. Mari answered: To have intercourse they have time.[^fn_27a_18] To offer libations they have no time. R. Isaac b. Eleazar said in the name of Hezekiah: There[^fn_27a_19] \[it speaks\] of a besieging troop of the same kingdom.[^fn_27a_20] here[^fn_27a_21] \[it speaks\] of a besieging troop of another kingdom.[^fn_27a_22] \[Even in the case of a besieging troop\] of the same kingdom it is not possible that one of them does not run away[^fn_27a_23] \[from the rest of the troop\]![^fn_27a_24] — Rab. Judah answered in the name of Samuel: When the guards[^fn_27a_25] see one another.[^fn_27a_26] \[But\] it is not possible that one does not sleep a little![^fn_27a_27] — R. Levi answered: When they placed round the town chains. dogs. trunks of trees and geese.[^fn_27a_28] R. Abba, b. Zabda said: With regard to this R. Judah Nesi'ah[^fn_27a_29] and the Rabbis differ: one said \[that\] there[^fn_27a_30] \[it speaks\] of a besieging troop of the same kingdom. and here[^fn_27a_31] of a beseiging troop of another kingdom, and he found no difficulties, whereas one[^fn_27a_32] raised all those questions[^fn_27a_33] and answered \[them by saying\] when they placed round the town chains, dogs. trunks of trees, and geese.

R. Idi b. Abin said in the name of R. Isaac b. Ashian: If there is there one hiding place. it protects all priests' wives.[^fn_27a_34] R. Jeremiah asked \[a question\]: What is \[the law\] if it holds only one? Do we say of each one:[^fn_27a_35] This is the one[^fn_27a_36] or not? — But why should it be different from \[the following case\]? There were two paths, one was clean[^fn_27a_37] and one was unclean, and someone walked in one of them and \[then\] prepared clean things.[^fn_27a_38] and another person came and walked in the second path and \[then\] prepared clean things. R. Judah says: If each one comes to ask[^fn_27a_39] separately,[^fn_27a_40] they are \[declared\] clean;[^fn_27a_41] \[but\] if they both come together, they are \[declared\] unclean;[^fn_27a_42] R. Jose Says: In either case[^fn_27a_43] they are \[declared\] unclean.[^fn_27a_44] \[Whereon\] Raba, and some say R. Johanan said: \[if they come to ask\] at the same time, all agree that they are \[declared\] unclean, if they come one after another, all agree that they are \[declared\] clean; they differ only when one comes to ask for himself and for the other one; one[^fn_27a_45] regards this as[^fn_27a_46] \[if it were\] at the same time, and the other[^fn_27a_47] regards this as \[if it were\] one after another. Now here[^fn_27a_48] also, since all \[women\] \[are declared\] permitted.it is like \[the case where they came\] at the same time?[^fn_27a_49] — How is this so?[^fn_27a_50] There[^fn_27a_51] there is certainly an impurity,[^fn_27a_52] \[but\] here[^fn_27a_53] who says that any one[^fn_27a_54] has been defiled?[^fn_27a_55]

R. Ashi asked: If she[^fn_27a_56] says. 'I have not hidden myself and I have not been defiled', what is \[the law\]? Do we say [pg 27b]

'why should she lie,'[^fn_27b_1] or do we not say it? But why should this be different from the following case? Once someone hired out an ass to a person, and he said to him, 'Do not go the way of Nehar Pekod. where there is water,[^fn_27b_2] go the way of Naresh, where there is no water. But he[^fn_27b_3] went the way of Nehar Pekod and the ass died.[^fn_27b_4] He[^fn_27b_3] \[then\] came before Raba[^fn_27b_5] and said to him. 'Indeed, I went the way of Nehar Pekod, but there was no water. Said Raba: 'Why should he lie?' If he wished he could say 'l went the way of Naresh.' And Abaye said to him: we do not say 'Why should he lie?' where there are witnesses.[^fn_27b_6] — Now is this so? There there were witnesses that there certainly was water on the way of Nehar Pekod. but here has she certainly been defiled? It is \[only\] a fear,[^fn_27b_7] and in the case of a fear we say \['why should he lie?'\]

IF THERE ARE WITNESSES, EVEN A SLAVE, EVEN A HAND' MAID, THEY ARE BELIEVED. And even her own handmaid is believed. But there is a contradiction against this:[^fn_27b_8] She[^fn_27b_9] must not be alone with him[^fn_27b_10] unless there are witnesses, even a slave, even a handmaid[^fn_27b_11] except her own handmaid,[^fn_27b_12] because she[^fn_27b_13] is familiar with her own handmaid![^fn_27b_14] — R. Papi said: In \[the case of\] a woman captive[^fn_27b_15] they[^fn_27b_16] have made it lenient. R. Papa said: In the one case[^fn_27b_17] \[it speaks of\] her handmaid, in the other case[^fn_27b_18] \[it speaks of\] his handmaid. But her handmaid is not believed? Does he not teach \[that\] no one may testify as to himself? \[This would imply that\] her handmaid is believed![^fn_27b_19] Her handmaid is like herself.[^fn_27b_20] R. Ashi said: In both cases \[it speaks of\] her handmaid, but \[what we maintain is that\] the handmaid sees and is silent.[^fn_27b_21] \[Consequently\] there,[^fn_27b_22] where her silence makes her permitted.[^fn_27b_23] she is not believed, but here,[^fn_27b_24] where her silence makes her forbidden.[^fn_27b_25] she is believed. Now also, she may come and tell a falsehood?[^fn_27b_26] Two \[things\] she would not do[^fn_27b_27] as in the case of Mari b. Isak \[or as some say of Hana b. Isak\]: To him there came a brother from Be-Hozae and said to him: Give me a share in the property of our father. He answered him: I do not know you. He[^fn_27b_28] \[then\] came to R. Hisda, and he[^fn_27b_29] said to him: I he[^fn_27b_30] answered you well, for it is written:[^fn_27b_31] 'And Joseph knew his brethren, and they knew not him.' This teaches that he went away before he had grown a beard and he came back after growing a beard.[^fn_27b_32] \[Then\] he[^fn_27b_29] said to him: I Go and bring witnesses that you are his brother. He[^fn_27b_28] answered him:[^fn_27b_29] I have witnesses, but they are afraid of him,[^fn_27b_33] because he is a powerful man. He[^fn_27b_29] \[then\] said to the other man: Go you and bring witnesses that he[^fn_27b_28] is not thy brother. He[^fn_27b_30] answered him:[^fn_27b_29] Is this the law? \[Surely\] he who claims must produce evidence![^fn_27b_34] He[^fn_27b_29] said to him.[^fn_27b_30] So I rule for you and all who are powerful like you![^fn_27b_35] But they[^fn_27b_36] may also come and lie?[^fn_27b_37] Two things they[^fn_27b_36] will not do.[^fn_27b_38] 

May we say that this difference[^fn_27b_39] is like that between \[these\] Tannaim? \[For it was taught in a Baraitha:\] This testimony[^fn_27b_40] a man and a woman, a boy and a girl, her father and her mother, her brother and her sister \[may give\], but not her son and her daughter, nor her slave and her handmaid. And \[in\] another \[Baraitha\] it was taught. All are believed to testify \[for her\] except herself and her husband.[^fn_27b_41] Now the views of R. Papa and R. Ashi are \[certainly\] according to the difference of the Tannaim.[^fn_27b_42] But is the view of R. Papa according to the Tannaim?[^fn_27b_43] R. Papa can answer you: That Baraitha[^fn_27b_44] \[speaks of a case\] when she[^fn_27b_45] talked in her simplicity.[^fn_27b_46] As that which R. Dimi said when he came: R. Hanan of Carthagene told a story: A case came before R. Joshua b. Levi (or as some say R. Joshua b. Levi told a Story: A case came before Rabbi): Someone was talking in his simplicity and said: I and my mother were taken captives among heathens. When I went out to draw my water, my mind was on my mother.[^fn_27b_47] \[When I was out\] to gather wood, my mind was on my mother. And Rabbi allowed her to marry[^fn_27b_48] a priest[^fn_27b_49] by \[the words of\] his mouth.[^fn_27b_50]

***MISHNAH***. R. ZECHARIAH B. HA-KAZZAB[^fn_27b_51] SAID: BY THIS TEMPLE[^fn_27b_52] HER HAND[^fn_27b_53] DID NOT MOVE OUT OF MY HAND[^fn_27b_54] FROM THE TIME THAT THE HEATHENS ENTERED JERUSALEM UNTIL THEY DEPARTED. THEY[^fn_27b_55] ANSWERED HIM: NO ONE MAY TESTIFY CONCERNING HIMSELF.[^fn_27b_56] {¶=2.9}

***GEMARA***. It has been taught: And notwithstanding this[^fn_27b_57] he appointed for her a dwelling place[^fn_27b_58] in his court-yard. and when she was out, she went out at the head of her children,[^fn_27b_59] and when she came in, she came in at the head other children.[^fn_27b_60] Abaye asked: May one do so with regard to one's' divorced wife?[^fn_27b_61] \[Do I say:\] There[^fn_27b_62] it was allowed because in \[the case of\] a captive woman[^fn_27b_63] they[^fn_27b_64] made it lenient, but not here.[^fn_27b_65] or is there no difference? — Come and hear: It has been taught: If someone has divorced his wife, she shall not get married \[and live\] in his neighbourhood.[^fn_27b_66] [pg 28a]

and if he[^fn_28a_1] was a priest she must not live with him in the \[same\] alley.[^fn_28a_2] If it was a small village[^fn_28a_3] — such a case happened, and they said: A small village is considered[^fn_28a_4] a neighbourhood.[^fn_28a_5]

Who must give way before whom? — Come and hear' It has been taught: She must give way before him, and not he before her, but if the court-yard[^fn_28a_6] belonged to her, he must give way before her.

The question was asked: If the court-yard belonged to both, what is \[the law\]? Come and hear: 'She must give way before him.' In what case?[^fn_28a_7] If the court-yard belongs to him it is obvious; and if the court-yard belongs to her, has it not been taught: 'If the court-yard belongs to her, he gives way before her'? Hence \[it must be\] in a such case![^fn_28a_8] — \[No.\] Perhaps \[it deals with a case\] when they rented \[the court-yard\]. How is it then?[^fn_28a_9] — Come and hear: \[It is written:\] The Lord will hurl thee away violently as a man,[^fn_28a_10] and Rab said:[^fn_28a_11] moving about[^fn_28a_12] is harder for a man than for a woman.[^fn_28a_13]

Our Rabbis taught: If he[^fn_28a_14] borrowed[^fn_28a_15] from the property of her father,[^fn_28a_16] she collects the payment only through another person.[^fn_28a_17] R. Shesheth said: And if they \[both\] come before us to Court, we do not deal with[^fn_28a_18] them.[^fn_28a_19] R. Papa said: We excommunicate them. R. Huna, the son of R. Joshua. said: We even order them to be lashed. R. Nahman said: It is taught in Ebel Rabbathi:[^fn_28a_20] This is said only[^fn_28a_21] when she was divorced after[^fn_28a_22] marriage, but if she was divorced after betrothal, she may collect the payments herself, because he is not \[so\] familiar with her.

Once a betrothed and his \[former\] fiancee came before Raba, and R. Adda b. Mattena, sat before him. Raba placed a messenger[^fn_28a_23] between them.[^fn_28a_24] R. Adda b. Mattena said to him: Did not R. Nahman say: 'It is taught in Ebel Rabbathi etc.'?[^fn_28a_25] — He answered him: We see[^fn_28a_26] that they are familiar with one another.[^fn_28a_27] Some say: Raba did not place a messenger between them. R. Adda b. Mattena said to him: Let the Master place a messenger between them. He answered him:[^fn_28a_28] Did not R. Nahman say: 'It is taught in Ebel Rabbathi, etc.'? He[^fn_28a_29] said to him:[^fn_28a_28] This only when they are not familiar with one another, but \[as to\] these — I see that they are familiar with one another.[^fn_28a_27]

***MISHNAH***. THE FOLLOWING[^fn_28a_30] ARE BELIEVED ON TESTIFYING WHEN THEY ARE GROWN-UP[^fn_28a_31] TO WHAT THEY HAVE SEEN WHEN THEY WERE SMALL:[^fn_28a_32] — A PERSON IS BELIEVED ON SAYING 'THIS IS THE HANDWRITING OF MY FATHER.'[^fn_28a_33] 'THIS IS THE HANDWRITING OF MY TEACHER. 'THIS IS THE HANDWRITING OF MY BROTHER:[^fn_28a_34] REMEMBER THAT THAT WOMAN WENT OUT WITH A HINUMA AND UNCOVERED HEAD,[^fn_28a_35] 'THAT THAT MAN USED TO GO OUT FROM SCHOOL[^fn_28a_36] TO IMMERSE[^fn_28a_37] IN ORDER TO EAT TERUMAH'.[^fn_28a_38] 'THAT HE USED TO TAKE A SHARE WITH US AT THE THRESHING FLOOR, THAT THIS PLACE WAS A BETH HA-PERAS.'[^fn_28a_39] THAT UP TO HERE WE USED TO GO ON SABBATH.[^fn_28a_40] BUT A MAN IS NOT BELIEVED WHEN HE SAYS: SO-AND — SO HAD A WAY[^fn_28a_41] IN THIS PLACE, THAT MAN HAD A PLACE OF STANDING UP AND LAMENTATION[^fn_28a_42] IN THIS PLACE. {¶=2.10}

***GEMARA***. R. Huna b. Joshua said: \[This is\] only[^fn_28a_43] when a grown up person is with him.[^fn_28a_44] And it is necessary,[^fn_28a_45] for if he had taught us[^fn_28a_46] \[with regard to\] his father, \[I might say\][^fn_28a_47] that is because he[^fn_28a_48] was always[^fn_28a_49] with him,[^fn_28a_50] but \[with regard to\] his teacher. \[he would\] not \[be believed\]. And if he had taught us \[with regard to\] his teacher, \[I might say\][^fn_28a_51] that is because he had reverence[^fn_28a_52] for his teacher.[^fn_28a_53] And if he had taught us these two \[cases\],[^fn_28a_54] \[I might say[^fn_28a_55] with regard to\] his father, that is because he was always with him, and \[with regard to\] his teacher, because he had reverence for him, but \[with regard to\] his brother, in regard to whom there is neither this nor that ground.[^fn_28a_56] I might say \[that he is\] not \[believed\]; so he teaches us[^fn_28a_57] \[that\] since the confirmation of documents[^fn_28a_58] is \[only\] ordained by the Rabbis,[^fn_28a_59] so the Rabbis have believed him regarding what the Rabbis \[themselves\] have ordained.

I REMEMBER THAT THAT WOMAN WENT OUT WITH A HINUMA AND UNCOVERED HEAD. What is the reason?[^fn_28a_60] — Because most women get married as virgins, so this[^fn_28a_61] is only a declaration.[^fn_28a_62]

THAT THAT MAN USED TO GO OUT FROM SCHOOL TO IMMERSE IN ORDER TO EAT *TERUMAH*. But perhaps he was the slave of a priest?[^fn_28a_63] — This supports R. Joshua b. Levi; for R. Joshua b. Levi said: A man is forbidden to teach his slave[^fn_28a_64] the Torah. But is it indeed not \[permitted\]? Has it not been taught: If his master has borrowed from him[^fn_28a_65] or his master made him [pg 28b]

a guardian or he put on Tefillin[^fn_28b_1] in the presence of his master or he read three verses[^fn_28b_2] in the Synagogue, he does not become free![^fn_28b_3] — There[^fn_28b_4] it happened that he did it with his consent;[^fn_28b_5] \[for what case\] do we state \[our rule\]?[^fn_28b_6] When he treats him as a child.[^fn_28b_7]

TO IMMERSE IN ORDER TO EAT *TERUMAH*. \[Only\] with regard to Rabbinical *terumah*.[^fn_28b_8] THAT HE WAS TAKING A SHARE WITH US AT THE THRESHING FLOOR. But perhaps he was the slave of a priest? — We have learned \[this\] according to him who says: One does not distribute *terumah* to a slave unless his master is with him,[^fn_28b_9] for it has been taught: One does not distribute *terumah* to a slave unless his master is with him. This is the view of R. Judah. R. Jose says: He can say: 'If I am a priest, give me for my sake, and if I am the slave of a priest, give me for the sake of my master'. In the place of R. Judah they used to raise from *terumah* to the status of a priest; in the place of R. Jose they would not raise from *terumah* to the status of a priest.[^fn_28b_10]

It is taught:[^fn_28b_11] R. Eleazar, the son of R. Jose,[^fn_28b_12] said: I have never given testimony. Once I gave testimony and they raised a slave to the priesthood through my evidence.[^fn_28b_13] \[You say\] they raised! Do you indeed mean to say this? Now. if the Holy One, blessed be He, does not bring a stumbling[^fn_28b_14] through the animals of the pious men,[^fn_28b_15] how much less through the pious men themselves?[^fn_28b_16] — But,[^fn_28b_17] they wanted to raise a slave to the priesthood through my evidence. He saw it[^fn_28b_18] in the place of R. Jose,[^fn_28b_19] and he went and testified in the place of R. Judah.[^fn_28b_20]

THAT THIS PLACE WAS A BETH HA-PERAS Why?[^fn_28b_21] — Because \[the law of\] beth ha-peras is Rabbinical, for Rab Judah said in the name of Rab: One blows away \[the dust from\][^fn_28b_22] the beth ha.peras. and goes \[there\]. Rab Judah b. Ammi said in the name of Rab Judah: A beth ha-peras which has been trodden out is clean. What is the reason?[^fn_28b_23] It is impossible that a bone \[of the size\] of a barleycorn was not trodden down by the foot.[^fn_28b_24]

UP TO HERE HE USED TO GO ON SABBATH. He holds that the \[Sabbath\] limits[^fn_28b_25] are Rabbinical.

A MAN IS NOT BELIEVED WHEN HE SAYS: THAT MAN HAD A WAY IN THIS PLACE, SO-AND-SO HAD A PLACE OF STANDING UP AND LAMENTATION IN THIS PLACE. What is the reason? Money we do not extract.[^fn_28b_26]

Our Rabbis taught:[^fn_28b_27] A boy is believed when he says, 'Thus my father told me: this family is clean. this family is unclean. — \[You say,\] 'clean and unclean'! Do you indeed mean to say this?[^fn_28b_28] But \[say\]: 'this family is fit[^fn_28b_29] and this family is unfit', 'That we have eaten at the Kezazah[^fn_28b_30] \[on the occasion of the marriage\] of the daughter of So-and-so to So-and-so', 'that we used to bring *hallah* and \[priestly\] gifts[^fn_28b_31] to the priest So-and-so'. But only through himself,[^fn_28b_32] and not through someone else. In all these cases, if he was an heathen and he became a proselyte, a slave and he was set free, he is not believed.[^fn_28b_33] \[But\] he is not believed when he says 'that man had a way in this place, that man had a place of standing up and lamentation in this place'. R'. Johanan b. Beroka, said. He is believed. To which \[clause\] does R. Johanan b. Beroka, refer? Shall I say, to the last clause? This is extracting money?[^fn_28b_34] — But \[it refers\] to the first clause. In all these cases, if he was a heathen and he became a proselyte, a slave and he was set free, he is not believed. R. Johanan b. Beroka says: He is believed. In what \[principle\] do they differ? — The first Tanna holds: Since he was a heathen he would not pay special attention to it,[^fn_28b_35] and R. Johanan b. Beroka, holds: Since he had it in his mind to become a proselyte he would pay special attention to it.

What is KEZAZAH? — The Rabbis taught: In what manner does kezazah take place? If one of the brothers has married a woman who is unworthy of him, the members[^fn_28b_36] of the family come together, bring a cask full of fruit, break it in the middle of the open place[^fn_28b_37] and say. Brethren of the house of Israel, hear. Our brother So-and-so has married a woman who is not worthy of him, and we are afraid lest his descendants[^fn_28b_38] will be united with our descendants. Come and take for yourselves a sign[^fn_28b_39] for future generations, that his descendants shall not be united with our descendants'. This is kezazah with regard to which a child is believed when he testifies. [pg 29a]

## CHAPTER III

***MISHNAH***. THESE ARE MAIDENS[^fn_29a_1] TO WHOM THE FINE IS DUE.[^fn_29a_2] IF ANYONE HAD INTERCOURSE WITH A MAMZERETH,[^fn_29a_3] A NETHINAH,[^fn_29a_4] A CUTHEAN,[^fn_29a_5] OR WITH A PROSELYTE \[MAIDEN\].[^fn_29a_6] A CAPTIVE, OR A SLAVE-WOMAN,[^fn_29a_7] WHO WAS REDEEMED,[^fn_29a_8] CONVERTED,[^fn_29a_9] OR FREED \[WHEN SHE WAS\] UNDER THE AGE OF[^fn_29a_10] THREE YEARS AND ONE DAY.[^fn_29a_11] IF ONE HAD INTERCOURSE WITH HIS SISTER, WITH THE SISTER OF HIS FATHER, WITH THE SISTER OF HIS MOTHER, WITH THE SISTER OF HIS WIFE, WITH THE WIFE OF HIS BROTHER,[^fn_29a_12] WITH THE WIFE OF THE BROTHER OF HIS FATHER, OR WITH A WOMAN DURING MENSTRUATION,[^fn_29a_13] HE HAS TO PAY THE FINE,[^fn_29a_14] \[FOR\] ALTHOUGH THESE \[TRANSGRESSIONS\][^fn_29a_15] ARE PUNISHED THROUGH \[THE TRANSGRESSOR\] BEING CUT OFF,[^fn_29a_16] THERE IS NOT, WITH REGARD TO THEM, A DEATH \[PENALTY\] \[INFLICTED\] BY THE COURT.[^fn_29a_17] {¶=3.1}

***GEMARA***. \[Does it mean that only\] these blemished maidens get the fine, \[but\] unblemished ones \[do\] not?[^fn_29a_18] — He means it thus: These are blemished maidens who get the fine:[^fn_29a_19] IF ANYONE HAD INTERCOURSE WITH A MAMZERETH, A NETHINAH, A CUTHEAN,[^fn_29a_20] etc.

\[Only\] \[the Mishnah states\] a maiden \[receives a fine\],[^fn_29a_21] \[but not\] a small girl.[^fn_29a_22] Who is the Tanna \[who taught this\]? Rab Judah said in the name of Rab: It is R. Meir, for it has been taught:[^fn_29a_23] A small child from the age of one day[^fn_29a_24] until \[the time that\] she grows two hairs[^fn_29a_25] sale applies to her,[^fn_29a_26] but not the fine;[^fn_29a_27] from \[the time that\] she grows two hairs until she becomes mature,[^fn_29a_28] the fine applies to her, but not sale.[^fn_29a_29] This is the view of R. Meir; for R. Meir said: Wherever sale applies,[^fn_29a_30] the fine does not apply, and wherever the fine applies, sale does not apply. But the Sages say: A small child from the age of three years and one day until \[the time that\] she becomes mature — the fine applies to her.[^fn_29a_31] \[Does that mean\] only the fine \[and\] not sale![^fn_29a_32] — Say: [pg 29b]

also the fine \[applies\] when sale \[applies\].[^fn_29b_1]

But are these \[maidens\][^fn_29b_2] entitled to the fine! Why? Read here: 'and she shall be his wife', \[that means\] one who is fit to be his wife?[^fn_29b_3] — Said Resh Lakish: \[It is written:\] 'maiden', 'maiden', 'the maiden'[^fn_29b_4] once[^fn_29b_5] \[the word 'maiden' is necessary\] for itself,[^fn_29b_6] once to include \[those maidens, the marrying of whom involves the transgression merely of\] a plain prohibitory law,[^fn_29b_7] and once to include \[those maidens, the marrying of whom involves\] a transgression punishable with *kareth*.[^fn_29b_8] R. Papa said: \[It is written:\][^fn_29b_9] 'virgin','virgin', 'the virgins'; once \[the word 'virgin' is necessary\] for itself,[^fn_29b_10] once to include \[those virgins, the marrying of whom involves the transgression merely of\] a plain prohibitory law, and once to include \[those virgins, the marrying of whom involves\] a transgression punishable with *kareth*. Why does R. Papa not agree with Resh Lakish? — That \[verse\][^fn_29b_11] he requires for \[the same teaching\] as that of Abaye, for Abaye said: If he cohabited with her[^fn_29b_12] and she died, he is free,[^fn_29b_13] for it is said: 'And he shall give unto the father of he maiden';[^fn_29b_14] \[this means\]: To the father of a maiden,[^fn_29b_15] but not to the father of a dead \[person\].[^fn_29b_16] And why did not Resh Lakish agree with R. Papa? — That \[verse\][^fn_29b_17] he requires for an analogy[^fn_29b_18] for it is taught: \[\[t is written:\] — 'he shall pay money according to the dowry of virgins,[^fn_29b_19] \[this means that\] this[^fn_29b_20] shall be like the dowry of virgins,[^fn_29b_21] and the dowry of virgins shall be like this.[^fn_29b_22] But Resh Lakish also requires it[^fn_29b_23] for \[the same teaching\] as that of Abaye, and R. Papa also requires it[^fn_29b_24] for the analogy?[^fn_29b_25] — Take therefore six words:[^fn_29b_26] 'maiden', 'maiden', 'the maiden', 'virgin', 'virgins', 'the virgins': Two \[are necessary\] for themselves,[^fn_29b_27] one for the teaching of Abaye, and one for the analogy, \[and\] two remain over: one to include \[those maidens, the marrying of whom involves the transgression\] of a plain prohibitory law, and one to include \[those maidens, the marrying of whom involves\] a transgression punishable with *kareth*.

This[^fn_29b_28] \[Mishnah\] is to exclude \[the view of\] that Tanna.[^fn_29b_29] For it has been taught: \[It is written:\] and she shall be his wife.[^fn_29b_30] Simeon the Temanite says: \[This means:\] a woman who can become his wife;[^fn_29b_31] R. Simeon b. Menassia says: \[This means:\] a woman who can remain his wife.[^fn_29b_32] What difference is there between them?[^fn_29b_33] — R. Zera said: The difference between them is with regard to a mamzereth and a nethinah. According to him who says that there must be the possibility of her 'becoming' his wife, here[^fn_29b_34] also there is the possibility of her 'becoming' his wife.[^fn_29b_35] And according to him who says that there must be the possibility of her remaining his wife, here[^fn_29b_36] there is not the possibility of her remaining his wife.[^fn_29b_37] But according to R. Akiba, who says: Marriage takes no effect when there is a prohibitory law against[^fn_29b_38] it, what is the difference between them?[^fn_29b_39] — There is a difference between them in the case of a widow who marries a high priest, and this according to R. Simai, for it is taught:[^fn_29b_40] R. Simai says: Of all[^fn_29b_41] R. Akiba makes mamzerim,[^fn_29b_42] except \[the issue of\] a widow and a high priest, for the Torah says: 'he shall not take', and 'he shall not profane',[^fn_29b_43] \[this teaches that\] he makes \[his issue\] profane,[^fn_29b_44] but not mamzerim,[^fn_29b_45] And according to R. Yeshebab, who says: Come and let us cry out against Akiba b. Joseph, who says: Whenever the marriage is forbidden in Israel[^fn_29b_46] the child \[of such marriage\] is a mamzer,[^fn_29b_47] what is the difference between them?[^fn_29b_48] — The difference between them is [pg 30a]

with regard to the marriage with an Egyptian or an Edomite \[woman\], in which case there is a transgression \[merely\] of a positive law.[^fn_30a_1] — That is all right if R. Yeshebab \[by his statement\] only came to exclude the view of R. Simai.[^fn_30a_2] But if his statement was his own,[^fn_30a_3] whenever the marriage is forbidden in Israel, the child \[of such a marriage\] is a mamzer. It would include also a marriage with regard to which a positive law has been transgressed. What is \[then\] the difference between them? — The difference between them is with regard to a girl, who is no more a virgin, who married a high priest.[^fn_30a_4] — And why is this[^fn_30a_5] different?[^fn_30a_6] — It is a law which does not apply to all.[^fn_30a_7]

R. Hisda said: All agree that he who has intercourse with a woman during menstruation[^fn_30a_8] \[against her will\] has to pay the fine,[^fn_30a_9] for according to him who holds that there must be the possibility of her[^fn_30a_10] 'becoming' his wife, there is with regard to her[^fn_30a_11] the possibility of her becoming his wife,[^fn_30a_12] and according to him who holds that there must be the possibility of her[^fn_30a_13] remaining his wife, there is with regard to her[^fn_30a_14] the possibility of her remaining his wife.[^fn_30a_15]

Our \[Mishnah\][^fn_30a_16] likewise excludes the view of R. Nehunia b. ha-Kaneh, for it is taught: R. Nehunia b. ha-Kaneh, made the Day of Atonement equal to the Sabbath with regard to payment; as \[he who desecrates\] the Sabbath[^fn_30a_17] forfeits his life[^fn_30a_18] and is free from payment,[^fn_30a_19] so \[he who desecrates\] the Day of Atonement[^fn_30a_20] forfeits his life[^fn_30a_21] and is free from payment. What is the reason \[for the view\] of R.
