Nehunia b. ha-Kaneh? — Abaye said: It is said 'harm'[^fn_30a_22] \[in the case of death\][^fn_30a_23] by the hand of man,[^fn_30a_24] and it is said 'harm'[^fn_30a_25] \[in the case of death\] by the hand of heaven, \[so I say:\] As in the case of the 'harm' done by the hand of man one is free from payment,[^fn_30a_26] so also in the case of 'harm' done by the hand of heaven, one is free from payment.[^fn_30a_27] To this R. Adda b. Ahaba, demurred: Whence \[do you know\] that Jacob warned his sons[^fn_30a_28] against cold and heat,[^fn_30a_29] which are by the hand of heaven?[^fn_30a_30] Perhaps \[he warned them\] against lions and thieves, which are 'by the hand of man?'[^fn_30a_31] — Is it that Jacob warned them against this and did not warn then, against that? Jacob warned then, against every kind of harm.[^fn_30a_32]

\[But\] are cold and heat by the hand of heaven? Is it not taught: Everything is 'by the hand of heaven' except cold and heat, for it is said: 'Cold and heat are in the way of the froward; he that keepeth his soul holdeth himself far from them'?[^fn_30a_33] Further, are lions and thieves 'by the hand of man'? Did not R. Joseph say. and R. Hiyya teach: Since the day of the destruction of the Temple, although the Sanhedrin ceased,[^fn_30a_34] the four forms of capital punishment[^fn_30a_35] have not ceased? 'They have not ceased,' \[you say\]? Surely they have ceased! But \[say\] [pg 30b]

the judgment of the four forms of capital punishment has not ceased.[^fn_30b_1] He who would have been sentenced to stoning,[^fn_30b_2] either falls down from the roof or a wild beast treads him down.[^fn_30b_3] He who would have been sentenced to burning, either falls into a fire[^fn_30b_4] or a serpent bites him.[^fn_30b_5] He who would have been sentenced to decapitation.[^fn_30b_6] is either delivered to the government[^fn_30b_7] or robbers come upon him.[^fn_30b_8] He who would have been sentenced to strangulation, is either drowned in the river or dies from suffocation.[^fn_30b_9] But reverse it: Lions and thieves are 'by the hand of heaven', and cold and heat are 'by the hand of man'.

Raba said: The reason \[for the view\] of R. Nehunia b. hakaneh, is \[derived\] from here:[^fn_30b_10] \[It is written:\] And if the people of the land do not all hide their eyes from that man, when he giveth of his seed unto Molech, \[and put him not to death\]; then I will set my face against that man, and against his family, and will cut him off.[^fn_30b_11] \[With these words\] the Torah says:[^fn_30b_12] My *kareth* is like your death \[-penalty\]; as \[in the case of\] your death\[-penalty\] one is free from payment, so \[in the case of\] my *kareth* one is free from payment. What is the difference between Raba and Abaye? — The difference is \[with regard to\] a stranger[^fn_30b_13] who ate *terumah*.[^fn_30b_14] According to Abaye he is free \[from payment\],[^fn_30b_15] and according to Raba he is bound \[to pay\].[^fn_30b_16] But is he free \[from payment\] according to Abaye? Did not R. Hisda say: R. Nehunia b. ha-Kaneh admits that he who stole \[forbidden\] fat[^fn_30b_17] belonging to his neighbour, and ate it, is bound \[to pay\],[^fn_30b_18] because he was guilty of stealing before he came to \[the transgression of\] the prohibition with regard to \[forbidden\] fat?[^fn_30b_19] Hence \[you say that\] as soon as[^fn_30b_20] he lifted it[^fn_30b_21] up he acquired it,[^fn_30b_22] but he did not become guilty of the transgression[^fn_30b_23] punishable with death until he had eaten it. Here[^fn_30b_24] also, when he lifted it[^fn_30b_25] up he acquired it, but he did not become guilty of the transgression[^fn_30b_26] punishable with death until he had eaten it![^fn_30b_27] — Here we treat of a case where his friend stuck it[^fn_30b_28] into his mouth.[^fn_30b_29] \[But\] even then,[^fn_30b_30] as soon as he chewed it, he acquired it, but he is not guilty of the transgression punishable with death until he has swallowed it![^fn_30b_31] — When \[his friend\] stuck it into his oesophagus.[^fn_30b_32] How shall we imagine this case? If he can give it back,[^fn_30b_33] let him give it back.[^fn_30b_34] And if he cannot give it back, why should he be guilty?[^fn_30b_35] — It speaks of a case when he can give it back only with an effort.[^fn_30b_36] R. Papa said, When his friend put liquids of *terumah* into his mouth.[^fn_30b_37] R. Ashi said: \[it speaks of a case\] when a stranger ate his own *terumah*.[^fn_30b_38] [pg 31a]

and \[at the same time\] tore the silk garments of his neighbour.[^fn_31a_1]

The \[above\] text \[stated\]: 'R. Hisda said: R. Nehunia b. hakaneh admits that, if someone stole \[forbidden\] fat belonging to his neighbour and ate it, he is bound \[to pay\], because he was guilty of stealing before he came to \[the transgression of\] the prohibition with regard to \[forbidden\] fat.' Is it to say that he differs from R. Abin? For R. Abin said: If someone threw an arrow \[on Sabbath\] from the beginning of four \[cubits\] to the end of four \[cubits[^fn_31a_2]\] and it[^fn_31a_3] tore silk garments in its passage[^fn_31a_4] he is free \[from payment\],[^fn_31a_5] for the taking up[^fn_31a_6] was necessary for the putting down:[^fn_31a_7] Now here[^fn_31a_8] also the 'lifting up' was necessary for the eating.[^fn_31a_9] — Now, is this so?[^fn_31a_10] There[^fn_31a_11] 'the putting down' is impossible without the 'taking up'; but here[^fn_31a_12] the eating is possible without the 'lifting up', for, if he likes, he can bend down and eat.[^fn_31a_13] Or: there,[^fn_31a_14] if he wants to take it back, he cannot take it back;[^fn_31a_15] but here,[^fn_31a_16] he can put it back.[^fn_31a_17] — What is the \[practical\] difference between the one answer and the other answer? — The difference is: when someone carried[^fn_31a_18] a knife in the public road[^fn_31a_19] and it[^fn_31a_20] tore silk garments in its passage: according to the answer that the 'putting down' is impossible without the 'taking up', here[^fn_31a_21] also the 'putting down' is impossible without the 'taking up'.[^fn_31a_22] And according to the answer that he cannot take it back, here[^fn_31a_23] he can take it back.[^fn_31a_24]

The text \[stated above\]: 'R. Abin said: If someone threw \[on Sabbath\] an arrow from the beginning of four \[cubits\] to the end of four \[cubits\] and it tore silk garments in its passage he is free \[from payment\], for the "taking up" was necessary for the "putting down".' R. Bibi b. Abaye raised the following objection: If someone stole a purse[^fn_31a_25] on Sabbath he is bound \[to pay\],[^fn_31a_26] because he was guilty of stealing before he came to the \[transgression of\] the prohibition which is punishable with stoning,[^fn_31a_27] but if he dragged it along he is free \[from payment\], because the desecration of the Sabbath and the stealing come at the same time.[^fn_31a_28] And why?[^fn_31a_29] Here also we should say: The lifting up is necessary for the carrying out![^fn_31a_30] — Here we treat of a case when he lifted it up in order to hide it and changed his mind and carried it out.[^fn_31a_31] \[But\] is he, in this case, guilty \[of desecrating the Sabbath\]? Did not R. Simeon say \[that\] R. Ammi said in the name of R. Johanan: If someone was removing objects from one corner to another corner and changed his mind and carried them out he is free \[of the transgression of the desecration of the Sabbath\] because the taking up was not from the outset for that \[purpose\]? — Do not say: in order to hide it, but say: in order to carry it out, only it speaks here of a case when he \[paused and\] remained standing \[for a while\].[^fn_31a_32] For what purpose did he remain standing? If to adjust the cord on his shoulder, this is the usual way.[^fn_31a_33] — No; \[we speak of a case\] where he stood still in order to rest. But how would it be if \[he had remained standing\] in order to adjust the cord on his shoulder? [pg 31b]

He would be free \[from payment\]? \[If so\] instead of teaching 'but if he dragged it along he is free \[from payment\]', let him make the distinction in the same case.[^fn_31b_1] 'When is this said?[^fn_31b_2] If he stood still to rest; but if \[he stood still\] to adjust the cord on his shoulder, he is free \[from payment\]'? But \[answer thus:\] Whose opinion is this? It is that of Ben 'Azzai, who says: Walking is like standing.[^fn_31b_3] \[But\] how would it be if he threw \[the purse\]?[^fn_31b_4] He would be free \[from payment\].[^fn_31b_5] Let him then make the distinction in the same case,[^fn_31b_6] thus when is it said:[^fn_31b_7] 'When he walked,[^fn_31b_8] but when he threw it, he is free'? — The case of dragging it along is necessary \[to be stated\]. You might have said that this is not the way of carrying out,[^fn_31b_9] so he lets us hear \[that it is not so\]. Of what \[kind of purse does it speak\]? If of a large purse, this[^fn_31b_10] is the ordinary way \[of carrying it out\],[^fn_31b_11] and if of a small purse, this is not the ordinary way?[^fn_31b_12] — In fact \[it speaks\] of a middle-sized \[purse\]. But where did he carry it to? If he carried it into the public road, there is desecration of the Sabbath but no stealing,[^fn_31b_13] and if he carried it into private ground, there is stealing but no desecration of the Sabbath![^fn_31b_14] — No, it is necessary \[to state it\] when he carried it out to the sides[^fn_31b_15] of the public road. According to whose view?[^fn_31b_16] If according to \[that of\] R. Eliezer, who says: The sides of the public road are like the public road,[^fn_31b_17] there is desecration of the Sabbath but no stealing[^fn_31b_18] and if it is according to the view of the Rabbis, who say: 'The sides of the public road are not like the public road,' there is stealing but no desecration of the Sabbath?[^fn_31b_15] — Indeed, it is according to R. Eliezer, and when R. Eliezer says: 'The sides of the public road are like the public road', it is only with regard to becoming guilty of the desecration of the Sabbath,[^fn_31b_19] because sometimes, through the pressure of the crowd, people go in there,[^fn_31b_20] but with regard to acquiring, one does acquire there, because the public is not often there.[^fn_31b_21] R. Ashi said: \[We speak of a case\] when he lowered[^fn_31b_22] his hand to less than three \[handbreadths\][^fn_31b_23] and received it.[^fn_31b_24] \[And this is\] according to Raba, for Raba said: The hand of a person is regarded as \[a place of\] four by four \[handbreadths\].[^fn_31b_25] R. Aha taught so.[^fn_31b_26] Rabina \[however\] taught: Indeed, when he carried it out into the public road, for he acquires also in the public ground.[^fn_31b_27] \[And\] they[^fn_31b_28] differ with regard to a deduction from this Mishnah, for we have learned: If he[^fn_31b_29] was pulling it out[^fn_31b_30] and it died in the domain of the owner, he is free;[^fn_31b_31] but if he lifted it up or brought it[^fn_31b_32] out from the territory of the owner[^fn_31b_33] and it died, he is bound \[to pay\].[^fn_31b_34] Rabina makes a deduction from the first clause, and R. Aha makes a deduction from the second clause. Rabina makes a deduction from the first clause: 'If he was drawing it out and it died in the domain of the owner, he is free'. The reason \[for his being free\] is because it died in the domain of the owner, hut If he had brought it out[^fn_31b_35] from the domain of the owner[^fn_31b_36] and it died, he would have been hound \[to pay\].[^fn_31b_37] R. Aha makes a deduction from the second clause: 'but if he lifted it up or brought it out \[etc.\]' Bringing out is like lifting up; as lifting up is \[an act through which the object\] comes into his possession,[^fn_31b_38] so bringing out \[must he an act through which the object\] comes into his possession.[^fn_31b_39] According to R. Aha the first clause is difficult and according to Rabina the second clause is difficult? — The first clause is not difficult according to R. Aha, for as long as it has not come into his possession it is called: 'in the domain of the owner'.[^fn_31b_40] The second clause is not difficult according to Rabina, for we do not say \[that\] bringing out is like lifting up.[^fn_31b_41]

IF ONE HAD INTERCOURSE \[BY FORCE\] WITH HIS SISTER, OR WITH THE SISTER OF HIS FATHER, etc. There is a question of contradiction against this: The following persons receive \[the punishment of\] lashes: he who has intercourse with his sister, with the sister of his father, with the sister of his mother, with the sister of his wife, with the sister of his brother, with the wife of the brother of his father, or with a woman during menstruation,[^fn_31b_42] [pg 32a]

and it is established that one does not receive lashes and pay![^fn_32a_1] — 'Ulla said: There is no difficulty. Here[^fn_32a_2] \[it speaks\] of his sister \[who is\] a maiden,[^fn_32a_3] and there[^fn_32a_4] \[it speaks\] of his sister \[who is\] a mature girl.[^fn_32a_5] \[But in the case of\] his sister \[who is\] a mature girl, too, \[there are damages to be paid for the\] shame and deterioration?[^fn_32a_6] — \[It speaks of\] an idiot.[^fn_32a_7] But \[there are still damages to be paid for\] the pain?[^fn_32a_8] \[It speaks of\] a girl who was seduced.[^fn_32a_9] Now that you have come to this,[^fn_32a_10] you can even say \[that it speaks of\] his sister \[who was\] a maiden \[and namely when she was\] an orphan[^fn_32a_11] and \[she was\] seduced.[^fn_32a_12]

Consequently, 'Ulla holds the view that wherever there is money \[to be paid\] and the punishment of lashes \[to be inflicted\], he pays the money and does not receive the lashes,[^fn_32a_13] Whence does 'Ulla derive this? — He derives it from \[the law with regard to\] one person who injures another person. Just as when one person injures another person, in which case there is money to \[be paid\][^fn_32a_14] and the punishment of lashes,[^fn_32a_15] he pays the money and does not receive the lashes,[^fn_32a_16] so whenever there are payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes. \[But may it not be argued\] it is different with \[the case of\] one person who injures another person because he is liable for five things?[^fn_32a_17] And \[if you will say\] that \[the payment of\] money is lighter,[^fn_32a_18] \[one can say against this\] that \[here it has been excepted\] from its rule \[and\] permitted to the Court![^fn_32a_19] But he derives it from the refuted false witnesses.[^fn_32a_20] Just as in the case of refuted false witnesses, whose transgression involves the payment of money and the punishment with lashes,[^fn_32a_21] they pay the money but do not receive the lashes,[^fn_32a_22] so whenever there are payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes. \[But it may be argued\] it is different with the case of refuted false witnesses, because they do not require a warning?[^fn_32a_23] \[And if you will say\] that \[the payment of\] money is lighter, \[one can say against this,\] that they[^fn_32a_24] have not done any deed![^fn_32a_25] — But he derives it from both.[^fn_32a_26] The point common to both is that there are the payment of money and the punishment of lashes, and in either case he pays the money and does not receive the lashes. So whenever there are payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes. But \[it may be argued\] the point common to both is \[also\] that they both have a strict side?[^fn_32a_27] And if \[you will say that the payment of\] money is lighter, \[one can say against this\] that they have both a lighter side?[^fn_32a_28] [pg 32b]

— But 'Ulla derives it from the two words 'for'.[^fn_32b_1] It is written here for he hath humbled her[^fn_32b_2] and it is written there: 'Eye for eye'. As there[^fn_32b_3] he pays money and does not receive lashes, so wherever there are the payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays money and does not receive the lashes.

R. Johanan said: You can even say that it[^fn_32b_4] speaks of his sister who was a maiden. Only there[^fn_32b_4] it speaks of a case where they warned him,[^fn_32b_5] and here[^fn_32b_6] it speaks of a case where they did not warn him.[^fn_32b_7] Consequently R. Johanan holds the view that wherever there are the payment of money and the punishment of lashes and they warned him, he receives the lashes and does not pay the money. Whence does R. Johanan derive this? — The verse says: According to his guilt;[^fn_32b_8] \[from this I infer that\] you punish him because of one guilt but not because of two guilts, and immediately follow[^fn_32b_9] the words: Forty stripes he may give him.[^fn_32b_10] But behold when one person injures another person, in which case there are the payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays money and does not receive the lashes? And if you will say that this is only when they did not warn him, but when they warned him, he receives the lashes and does not pay — did not R. Ammi say in the name of R. Johanan that, if one person struck another person a blow, for which no *perutah*[^fn_32b_11] can be claimed as damages,[^fn_32b_12] he receives the lashes? How shall we imagine this case? If they did not warn him, why does he receive the lashes? Hence it is clear that they warned him, and the reason \[why he receives the lashes and does not pay\] is because the damages do not amount to a *perutah*, but if they amount to a *perutah* he pays the money but does not receive the lashes![^fn_32b_13] — \[It is\] as R. Elai said: The Torah has expressly stated[^fn_32b_14] that the *Zomemim* witnesses have to pay money; so \[here\] also the Torah has expressly stated that the person who injures another person has to pay money. With regard to what has that \[teaching\] of R. Elai been said? — With regard to the following:[^fn_32b_15] 'We testify that So-and-so owes his fellow two hundred zuz' and they were found to be *Zomemim*, they receive the lashes and pay,[^fn_32b_16] for it is not the verse that imposes upon them[^fn_32b_17] the lashes[^fn_32b_18] which imposes upon them[^fn_32b_17] the payment[^fn_32b_19] \[of money\]. This is the view of R. Meir; and the Sages say: He who pays does not receive lashes.[^fn_32b_20] \[And\] let us say: he who receives lashes does not pay?[^fn_32b_21] \[Upon that\] R. Elai said: The Torah has expressly stated that the *Zomemim* witnesses have to pay more money. Where has the Torah stated this? — Consider; it is written: 'Then shall ye do unto him as he had thought to do onto his brother'; why \[is it written further,\] 'hand for hand'?[^fn_32b_22] \[This means\] a thing that is given from hand to hand, and that is money. \[And\] the same applies to the case of[^fn_32b_23] one person who injures another person. Consider; it is written: 'As he hath done, so shall it be done to him';[^fn_32b_24] why \[is it written further\] 'so shall it be rendered unto him'?[^fn_32b_25] \[This means\] a thing that can be rendered,[^fn_32b_26] and that is money.

Why does R. Johanan not say as 'Ulla?[^fn_32b_27] — If so[^fn_32b_28] you would abolish \[the prohibitory law\]: The nakedness of thy sister thou shalt not uncover.[^fn_32b_29] [pg 33a]

\[But could not one say\] also \[in the case of\] one person who injures another person: If so[^fn_33a_1] you would abolish \[the prohibitory law\], 'he shall not exceed, lest, if he should exceed.'[^fn_33a_2] \[And in case of\] the *Zomemim* witnesses too, \[one could say\]: If so you would abolish \[the law\]: 'then it shall be, if the guilty man deserve to be beaten.'[^fn_33a_3] But \[you must say that in the case of\] the *Zomemim* witnesses it is possible to fulfil it[^fn_33a_4] when \[the witnesses testified falsely about someone[^fn_33a_5] that he was\] the son of a divorced woman or the son of a *haluzah*.[^fn_33a_6] \[Similarly in the case of\] a person who injured another person, it also is possible to fulfil it[^fn_33a_7] when he struck him a blow for which no *perutah* can be claimed as damages.[^fn_33a_8] \[And so you can say\] also \[with regard to\] his sister \[that\] it is possible to fulfil it[^fn_33a_9] in the case of his sister who was a mature girl![^fn_33a_10] — R. Johanan can answer you: \[The verse\] for he hath humbled her[^fn_33a_11] is required for \[the same teaching\] as of Abaye, for Abaye said: The verse says, 'for he hath humbled her'. This[^fn_33a_12] \[he shall pay\] for he has humbled her, \[from which we infer\], by implication, that there are also \[to be paid damages for\] shame and deterioration.[^fn_33a_13] And 'Ulla?'[^fn_33a_14] — He derives it from a teaching of Raba, for Raba said: The verse says: Then the man that lay with her shall give unto the father of the maiden it fifty *shekel* of silver;[^fn_33a_15] \[this means that\] for the enjoyment of lying \[with the maiden he has to pay\] fifty \[*shekel* of silver\], \[and we infer\], by implication, that there are also \[to be paid damages for\] shame and deterioration.

R. Eleazar[^fn_33a_16] says: The *Zomemim* witnesses pay money and do not receive lashes, because they cannot be warned.[^fn_33a_17] Raba said: You may know it \[from the following\]:[^fn_33a_18] When shall we warn them? Shall we warn them at first?[^fn_33a_19] They will \[then\] say: We have forgotten.[^fn_33a_20] Shall we warn them during the deed?[^fn_33a_21] They would \[then\] withdraw and not give any evidence.[^fn_33a_22] Shall we warn them at the end?[^fn_33a_23] \[Then\] what has been has been.[^fn_33a_24] Abaye demurred to this: Let us warn them immediately after they have given their evidence?[^fn_33a_25] R. Aha, the son of R. Ika demurred: Let us warn them at first[^fn_33a_26] and gesticulate to them \[afterwards\].[^fn_33a_27] Later[^fn_33a_28] Abaye said: What I said[^fn_33a_29] was nothing. For if one were to say[^fn_33a_30] that *Zomemim* witnesses require a warning, \[it would follow that\], if we have not warned them, we would not kill them.[^fn_33a_31] \[But then\] is it possible[^fn_33a_32] that who they wished to kill without a warning,[^fn_33a_33] that they should require a warning? Surely, it is necessary[^fn_33a_34] \[that the words be fulfilled,\] 'then shall ye do unto him as he has thought to do onto his brother',[^fn_33a_35] and this would not be \[the case here\]? To this R. Samma the son of R. Jeremiah demurred. But now \[according to your argument\], \[if the witnesses testified falsely about someone[^fn_33a_36] that he was\] the son of a divorced woman or the son of a *haluzah*,[^fn_33a_37] since this case is not included in 'as he had thought etc.' a warning should be required![^fn_33a_38] — The verse says: 'Ye shall have one manner of law';[^fn_33a_39] \[this means\] a law that is equal for you all.[^fn_33a_40]

R. Shisha, the son of R. Idi, said: That a person who injures another person pays money and does not receive the lashes is derived from this:[^fn_33a_41] \[It is written:\] And if men strive together and hurt a woman with child, so that her fruit depart.[^fn_33a_42] \[Upon this\] R. Eleazar said: The verse speaks of a striving with intent to kill, for it is written, But if any harm follow, then thou shalt give life for life.[^fn_33a_43] How shall we imagine this case? If they did not warn him, why should he be killed? Hence it is obvious that he was warned, \[and it is held\], when one is warned regarding a severe matter[^fn_33a_44] one also is warned for a light matter,[^fn_33a_45] and \[yet\] the Torah says: And yet no harm follow, he shall be surely fined.[^fn_33a_46] To this R. Ashi demurred: Whence \[do we know\] that when one is warned regarding a severe matter one also stands warned for a light matter? Perhaps it is not so![^fn_33a_47] And even if we will say that it is so, whence \[do we know\] that \[the penalty of\] death is severer? [pg 33b]

Perhaps \[the punishment with\] lashes is severer, for Rab said: If they had lashed Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah, they would have worshipped the \[golden\] image?[^fn_33b_1] R. Samma the son of R. Assi said to R. Ashi; and some say \[that\] R. Samma the son of R. Ashi \[said\] to R. Ashi: Do you not make a distinction between a beating that has a limit[^fn_33b_2] and a beating that has no limit![^fn_33b_3] R. Jacob from Nehar Pekod \[also\] demurred:[^fn_33b_4] That is alright according to the Rabbis who[^fn_33b_5] hold that life[^fn_33b_6] actually means \[life\].[^fn_33b_7] But according to Rabbi,[^fn_33b_8] who holds that it means money, what is there to say?[^fn_33b_9] — But, said R. Jacob from Nehar Pekod, in the name of Raba; \[it is to be derived\] from the following verse:[^fn_33b_10] \[It is written,\] 'If he rise again, and walk abroad upon his staff then shall he that smote him be quit.'[^fn_33b_11] Would it enter your mind that this one[^fn_33b_12] walks about in the street and that one[^fn_33b_13] should be killed?[^fn_33b_14] But it teaches that they imprison him;[^fn_33b_13] if he[^fn_33b_12] dies, they kill him; and if he does not die, 'he shall pay for the loss of his time, arid shall cause him to be thoroughly healed.'[^fn_33b_11] Now how shall we imagine this case? If they did not warn him, why should he be killed? Hence it is plain that they warned him, and \[it is held\], one who was warned for a severe matter stands warned for the lighter matter and \[yet\] the All-Merciful says \[that if he does not die\] 'he shall pay for the loss of his time, and shall cause him to be thoroughly healed'.[^fn_33b_15] To this R. Ashi asked: Whence \[do you know\] that one who was warned for a severe matter stands warned for a lighter matter? Perhaps not? And if you will even say that he does \[stand warned for the lighter matter\], whence \[do you know\] that death is severer? Perhaps \[the punishment with\] lashes is severer, for Rab said: If they had lashed Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah, they would have worshipped the \[golden\] image? R. Samma the son of R. Assi said to R. Ashi, and some say \[that\] R. Samma the son of R. Ashi \[said\] to R. Ashi: Do you not make a distinction between a beating that has a limit and a beating that has no limit?[^fn_33b_16] R. Mari \[also\] demurred:[^fn_33b_17] Whence \[do you know\] that \[one smote the other\] wilfully[^fn_33b_18] and 'he shall be quit' \[means\] from \[the penalty of\] death? Perhaps \[one smote the other\] inadvertently[^fn_33b_19] and 'he shall be quit' \[means\] from exile?[^fn_33b_20] The difficulty remains.

Resh Lakish said:[^fn_33b_21] This[^fn_33b_22] is the opinion of R. Meir,[^fn_33b_23] who says: He receives the lashes and pays \[the money\].[^fn_33b_24] — If it is according to R. Meir, \[then one who violated\] his daughter should also \[pay the fine\]?[^fn_33b_25] And if you will say that R. Meir holds \[that\] one may receive the lashes and pay \[the money\], but does not hold \[that\] one may receive the death penalty[^fn_33b_26] and pay \[the money\][^fn_33b_27] — has it not been taught: If he has stolen and slaughtered \[an animal\] on Sabbath,[^fn_33b_28] or has stolen and slaughtered \[an animal\] for idolatry,[^fn_33b_28] or has stolen an ox that is to be stoned[^fn_33b_29] and slaughtered it, he shall pay fourfold or fivefold.[^fn_33b_30] This is the view of R. Meir,[^fn_33b_31] but the Sages declare him free \[from payment\]? — Has it not been stated regarding this: R. Jacob said in the name of R. Johanan, and some say \[that\] R. Jeremiah said in the name of R. Simeon b. Lakish: R. Abin and R. Elai and the whole company \[of scholars\] said in the name of R. Johanan \[that it speaks of a case when\] he \[who stole the animal\] let it be slaughtered by another person. But is it possible that one sins and another one is punished?[^fn_33b_32] Raba said: The Divine law says: and slaughter it or sell it; \[this teaches that\] as the sale is \[effected\] through \[the participation of\] another person, so \[may\] the slaughtering \[of the animal\] be through another person. In the School of R. Ishmael it was taught: \[the word\] 'or' \[is\] to include the agent. In the School of Hezekiah it was taught: \[the word\] 'instead'[^fn_33b_32] \[is\] to include the agent. Mar Zutra demurred to this: Is it anywhere to be found that if he does \[the deed\] himself he is not liable[^fn_33b_33] and if an agent does it he is liable? He himself \[does not pay\], not because he is not liable, but because he suffers the severer penalty. \[But\] if he \[who stole the animal\] let it be slaughtered by another person, what is the reason of the Rabbis who declare him free \[from paying\]? — Who are the Sages? [pg 34a]

R. Simeon, who says: An unfit slaughtering is not called[^fn_34a_1] slaughtering. This might be right with regard to \[the slaughtering for\] idolatry and \[the slaughtering of\] the ox that is to be stoned, but the slaughtering on Sabbath is a fit slaughtering, for we learnt: If someone has slaughtered \[an animal\] on Sabbath or the Day of Atonement, although he is guilty of \[a transgression for which he forfeits\] his life,[^fn_34a_2] his slaughtering is a fit one?[^fn_34a_3] — He holds the opinion of R. Johanan ha-Sandalar,[^fn_34a_4] for it has been taught: If someone has cooked on Sabbath, \[if\] by mistake, he may eat it, \[and if\] wilfully he may not eat it: This is the view of R. Meir. R. Judah says: \[If\] by mistake, he may eat it after the outgoing[^fn_34a_5] of the Sabbath, \[if\] wilfully, he may never eat it. R. Johanan hasandalar says: \[If\] wilfully, others may eat it after the outgoing of the Sabbath, but not he, \[if\] wilfully, neither he nor others may eat it.[^fn_34a_6] What is the reason of R. Johanan ha-Sandalar? As R. Hiyya expounded at the entrance of the house of the Prince:[^fn_34a_7] \[It is written:\] 'Ye shall keep the Sabbath therefore, for it is holy unto you'.[^fn_34a_8] \[From this we derive:\] As what is holy is forbidden to be eaten, so what has been prepared[^fn_34a_9] on the Sabbath is forbidden to be eaten. If \[so, you might say that\] as what is holy is forbidden to be enjoyed,[^fn_34a_10] so what has been prepared on the Sabbath should be forbidden to be enjoyed? — It says 'unto you'; from this we learn: It shall belong to you.[^fn_34a_11] You might think \[that it is forbidden to eat\] even \[what has been prepared on the Sabbath\] by mistake,[^fn_34a_12] \[therefore\] it is said: every one that profaneth it shall surely be put to death.[^fn_34a_13] \[This teaches that only\] when \[the act was done\] wilfully,[^fn_34a_14] have I told thee \[that it is forbidden as that which is holy\] but not \[if it was done\] by mistake.

R. Aha and Rabina differ concerning this. One says: What has been prepared on Sabbath \[is forbidden\] according to the Bible, and one says: \[only\] according to the Rabbis. He who says: According to the Bible — as we have \[just\] explained.[^fn_34a_15] \[And\] he who says: according to the Rabbis — the verse says: 'It is holy', \[that means\]: 'it'[^fn_34a_16] is holy, but what has been prepared on it is not holy.[^fn_34a_17] According to him who says \[that the prohibition is only\] Rabbinical, what is the reason of the Rabbis who declare him[^fn_34a_18] free?[^fn_34a_19] — The Rabbis declare him free only with regard to other cases.[^fn_34a_20]

But \[with regard to\] one who slaughtered for idolatry \[one can ask:\] as soon as he has cut[^fn_34a_21] a little it[^fn_34a_22] has become forbidden,[^fn_34a_23] so when he continues the slaughtering[^fn_34a_24] he does not slaughter what is the owner's?[^fn_34a_25] — Raba said: \[it speaks of a case\] when he says \[that\] he worships it[^fn_34a_26] with the completion of the slaughtering. \[But with regard to\] the ox that is to he stoned \[one can ask\]: he[^fn_34a_27] does not slaughter what is his?[^fn_34a_28] Here we speak of a case when he[^fn_34a_29] handed it[^fn_34a_30] to a keeper and it caused the damage[^fn_34a_31] in the house of the keeper[^fn_34a_32] and it was sentenced in the house of the keeper and a thief stole it from the house of the keeper. And R. Meir holds the view of R. Jacob and holds the view of R. Simeon. He holds the view of R. Jacob who says: If the keeper returned it even after the sentence had been pronounced, it is regarded as returned.[^fn_34a_33] And he holds the view of R. Simeon who says: that which causes \[the gain or loss of\] money is regarded as money.[^fn_34a_34]

Rabbah said: Indeed \[it speaks of a case\] when he[^fn_34a_35] slaughtered it himself [pg 34b]

and R. Meir holds the view that \[though generally\] one may receive the lashes and pay, one cannot receive the death penalty and pay[^fn_34b_1] but these \[cases\][^fn_34b_2] are different, because the Torah has enacted something novel in \[the matter of\] fine,[^fn_34b_3] and \[therefore\][^fn_34b_4] he has to pay, although he has to suffer the death penalty.[^fn_34b_5] And Rabbah follows his own principle, for Rabba said: If he had a kid which he had stolen and he slaughtered it on Sabbath, he is bound,[^fn_34b_6] for he was already guilty of stealing before he came to the profanation[^fn_34b_7] of the Sabbath; \[but\] if he stole and slaughtered it on Sabbath he is free,[^fn_34b_8] for if there is no stealing[^fn_34b_9] there is no slaughtering and no selling.

Rabbah said further: If he had a kid which he had stolen and had slaughtered it at the place he broke into,[^fn_34b_10] he is bound,[^fn_34b_11] for he was already guilty of stealing before he came to the transgression of breaking in;[^fn_34b_12] \[but\] if he stole and slaughtered it in the place he broke into,[^fn_34b_13] he is free, for if there is no stealing, there is no slaughtering and no selling. And it was necessary \[to state both cases\]. For if he had let us hear \[the case of the\] Sabbath \[I would have said that he is free from payment\] because its prohibition is a perpetual prohibition,[^fn_34b_14] but \[in the case of\] breaking in, which is only a prohibition for the moment,[^fn_34b_15] I might say, \[that it is\] not \[so\].[^fn_34b_16] And if he had let us hear \[the case of\] breaking in \[I would say that he is free from payment\] because his breaking in is his warning,[^fn_34b_17] but \[with regard to the\] Sabbath, \[in\] which \[case\] a warning is required, I might say that \[it is\] not \[so\].[^fn_34b_18] \[Therefore\] it is necessary \[to state both cases\].

R. Papa said: If one had a cow that he had stolen and he slaughtered it on Sabbath, he is liable[^fn_34b_19] for he was already guilty of stealing before he came to the profanation of the Sabbath; if he had a cow that he borrowed and he slaughtered it[^fn_34b_20] on Sabbath, he is free.[^fn_34b_21] R. Aha the son of Raba said to R. Ashi: Does R. Papa mean to tell us[^fn_34b_22] \[that the same rule[^fn_34b_23] applies to\] a cow? — He answered him: R. Papa means to tell us \[that the same rules applies to\] a borrowed \[cow\]. You might possibly think \[that\] because R. Papa said that he[^fn_34b_24] becomes responsible for its food from the time of \[his taking possession of the cow by\] 'pulling'[^fn_34b_25] here also he becomes responsible for any unpreventable accident \[that may befall it\] from the time of borrowing,[^fn_34b_26] so he lets us hear \[that it is not so\].[^fn_34b_27]

Raba said: If their father left them[^fn_34b_28] a borrowed cow,[^fn_34b_29] they[^fn_34b_30] may use it during the whole period for which he borrowed it;[^fn_34b_31] if it died,[^fn_34b_32] they are not responsible for what happened.[^fn_34b_33] If they thought that it belonged to their father and they slaughtered it and ate it, they pay the value of the meat at the lowest price.[^fn_34b_34] If their father left them an obligation of property,[^fn_34b_35] they are bound to pay. Some refer it[^fn_34b_36] to the first case,[^fn_34b_37] and some refer it to the second case.[^fn_34b_38] He who refers it to the first case, so much the more \[does he refer it\] to the second case, and he differs from R. Papa.[^fn_34b_39] And he who refers it to the second case[^fn_34b_40] does not refer it to the first case, and he agrees with R. Papa.[^fn_34b_41]

It is alright \[that\] R. Johanan[^fn_34b_42] does not say according to Resh Lakish,[^fn_34b_43] because he wants to explain[^fn_34b_44] it[^fn_34b_45] according to the Rabbis. But why does not Resh Lakish say according to R. Johanan? — He will answer you: since he is free[^fn_34b_46] if they warned him, he is also free \[even\] if they did not warn him.[^fn_34b_47]

And they[^fn_34b_48] follow their own principles,[^fn_34b_49] for when R. Dimi came \[from Palestine\] he said: He who has committed inadvertently an act which, if he had committed it wilfully, would have been punishable with death or with lashes, and \[which is also punishable\] with something else,[^fn_34b_50] R. Johanan says \[that\] he is bound,[^fn_34b_51] and Resh Lakish says \[that\] he is free.[^fn_34b_52] R. Johanan says \[that\] he is bound, for they did not warn him.[^fn_34b_53] Resh Lakish says \[that\] he is free,[^fn_34b_54] for since he is free if they warned him, so he is free also when they did not warn him.

Resh Lakish raised an objection against R. Johanan: \[It is written\]: If no harm follow, he shall be surely fined.[^fn_34b_55] [pg 35a]

\[Now\] is not real 'harm' meant?[^fn_35a_1] No, the law concerning 'harm' \[is meant\].[^fn_35a_2] Some say: R. Johanan raised an objection against Resh Lakish: \[It is written\] 'And if no harm follow, he shall be surely fined'. Is not the law concerning 'harm' \[meant\]?[^fn_35a_2] No, real 'harm' \[is meant\].[^fn_35a_1]

Raba said: Is there any one who holds that he who committed inadvertently an act which, if he had committed it wilfully, would have been punishable with death \[and which is also punishable with the payment of money\] is bound \[to make the money payment\]? Has not the school of Hezekiah taught: \[It is written\] He that smiteth a man … he that smiteth a beast[^fn_35a_3] \[from which we infer:\] As in \[the case of\] the killing of a beast you have made no distinction between \[it being done\] inadvertently and wilfully, intentionally and unintentionally, by way of going down or by way of going up,[^fn_35a_4] so as to free him \[from the payment\], but \[in any case\] make him liable to pay, so also in \[the case of\] the killing of a man you shall make no distinction between \[it being done\] inadvertently and wilfully, intentionally and unintentionally, by way of going down or by way of going up, so as to make him liable to pay money, but to free him from paying money?[^fn_35a_5] But when Rabin came \[from Palestine\], he said: \[As to\] him who committed inadvertently an act which, if he had committed it wilfully, would have been punishable with death \[and which is also punishable with the payment of money\] — all agree that he is free \[from the payment of money\], they only differ when the act committed inadvertently would, if committed wilfully, have been punishable with lashes and something else.[^fn_35a_6] R. Johanan says \[that\] he is bound \[to make the money payment, because\] only with regard to those who commit an act punishable with death, the analogy is made,[^fn_35a_7] \[but\] with regard to those who commit an act punishable with lashes, the comparison is not made. \[But\] Resh Lakish says \[that\] he is free \[from making the money payment, because\] the Torah has expressly included those who commit an act punishable with lashes to be as those who commit an act punishable with death. Where has the Torah included \[them\]? — Abaye said: \[We infer it from\] the double occurrence of 'wicked man'[^fn_35a_8] Raba said: \[We infer it from\] the double occurrence of 'smiting'.[^fn_35a_9] R. Papa said to Raba: Which 'smiting' \[do you mean\]? If you mean[^fn_35a_10] \[the verse\][^fn_35a_11] 'And he that smiteth a beast shall pay for it, and he that smiteth a man shall be put to death,' this[^fn_35a_12] speaks[^fn_35a_13] of the death penalty?[^fn_35a_14] — Is it this 'smiting'; he that smiteth a beast shall pay for it: life for life and next to it \[comes\] And if a man cause a blemish in his neighbour, as he hath done so shall it be done to him?[^fn_35a_15] But here \[the term\] 'smiting' is not mentioned![^fn_35a_16] — We mean[^fn_35a_17] the effect of 'smiting'.[^fn_35a_18] But this verse refers to one who injures his fellow, and one who injures his fellow has to pay damages?[^fn_35a_19] — It if does not refer to a 'smiting' in which there is the value of a *perutah*,[^fn_35a_20] refer it[^fn_35a_21] to a smiting in which there is not the value of a *perutah*.[^fn_35a_22] [pg 35b]

Anyhow, he is not liable to pay damages?[^fn_35b_1] — It necessarily \[speaks of a case\] where, while he smote him, he tore his silk garment.[^fn_35b_2]

R. Hiyya said to Raba: And according to the Tanna of the school of Hezekiah, who says: \[It is written\] 'He that smiteth a man … He that smiteth a beast' \[etc.,\][^fn_35b_3] — whence does he know that it[^fn_35b_4] refers to a week-day and there is no distinction to be made?[^fn_35b_5] Perhaps it refers to the Sabbath, \[in which case\] there is a distinction to be made with regard to the beast itself?[^fn_35b_6] — This cannot be,[^fn_35b_7] for it is written: 'And he that smiteth a beast shall pay for it, and he that smiteth a man shall be put to death.' How shall we imagine this case? If they did not warn him, why should he, if he killed a man, be put to death? Hence it is clear that they warned him,[^fn_35b_8] and if \[it happened\] on a Sabbath would he, if he smote a beast, pay for it?[^fn_35b_9] Therefore it can only refer to[^fn_35b_10] a week-day.[^fn_35b_11]

R. Papa said to Abaye: According to Rabbah, who says \[that\] the Torah has instituted something novel in the matter of fines and \[therefore\] he pays although he is killed[^fn_35b_12] — according to whom does he put our Mishnah? If according to R. Meir,[^fn_35b_13] \[the law regarding\] his daughter is difficult,[^fn_35b_14] if according to R. Nehunia b. ha-Kana,[^fn_35b_15] \[the law regarding\] his sister is difficult;[^fn_35b_16] \[and\] if according to R. Isaac[^fn_35b_17] \[the law regarding\] a mamzereth is difficult?[^fn_35b_18] It would be alright if he would hold like R. Johanan,[^fn_35b_19] \[for\] he would \[then\] explain it[^fn_35b_20] like R. Johanan.[^fn_35b_19] But if he holds like Resh Lakish[^fn_35b_21] how can he explain it?[^fn_35b_22] — He \[therefore\], of necessity, holds like R. Johanan.

R. Mattena said to Abaye: According to Resh Lakish who says that the Torah has expressly included those who commit an act punishable with lashes to be as those who commit an act punishable with death[^fn_35b_23] — who is the Tanna, who differs from R. Nehunia b. ha'Kana?[^fn_35b_24] It is either R. Meir[^fn_35b_25] or R. Isaac.[^fn_35b_26]

Our Rabbis taught: All forbidden relations and all relations forbidden in the second degree have no claim[^fn_35b_27] to fine \[for outrage\][^fn_35b_28] or to indemnity for seduction.

A woman who refuses \[her husband\] by *mi'un*[^fn_35b_29] has no claim to fine \[for outrage\] or to indemnity for seduction. \[In this case\] a barren woman has no claim to fine for outrage or to indemnity for seduction. And a woman who has gone out[^fn_35b_30] on account of an evil name,[^fn_35b_31] has no claim to fine for outrage or to indemnity for seduction. What are 'forbidden relations' and what are 'relations forbidden in the second degree'? Shall I say \[that\] 'forbidden relations' [pg 36a]

are really forbidden relations[^fn_36a_1] and prohibitions of the second degree \[are those relations which were forbidden\] by the Rabbis?[^fn_36a_2] Why should the latter not receive the fine since they are fit for him Biblically? — But, forbidden relations are those with regard to which one is liable to the penalty of death at the hand of the Court,[^fn_36a_3] prohibitions of the second degree are those with regard to which there is *kareth*;[^fn_36a_4] but in the case of prohibitions with regard to which one trespasses a plain prohibitory law,[^fn_36a_5] they receive the fine. And whose opinion is it? \[It is that of\] Simeon the Temanite.[^fn_36a_5] Some say: 'Forbidden relations' are those with regard to which one is liable to the penalty of death at the hand of the Court or *kareth*, 'prohibitions of the second degree are those with regard to which one transgresses a plain prohibitory law. Whose opinion is this? That of R. Simeon b. Menassia.[^fn_36a_5]

         \[It is said above:\][^fn_36a_6] A woman who refuses her husband by *mi'un* has no claim to fine \[for outrage\] or to indemnity for seduction. But any other minor has a claim \[to the fine\]. Whose opinion would this be? That of the Rabbis, who say: A minor receives the fine.[^fn_36a_7] Read now the other clause: 'A barren woman has no claim to fine \[for outrage\] or to indemnity for seduction'. This is according to R. Meir, who says: The minor does not receive the fine; and this one came from her state as minor into the state of womanhood.[^fn_36a_8] The first clause would then be according to the Rabbis and the last clause according to R. Meir? And if you would say that all of it is according to R. Meir, but in the case of the woman who refuses her husband by *mi'un* he holds like R. Judah[^fn_36a_9] — does he indeed hold the view \[of R. Judah\]? Has it not been taught: Until when can the daughter exercise the right of *mi'un*? Until she grows two hairs[^fn_36a_10] — \[these are\] the words of R. Meir. R. Judah says: Until the black is more than the white?[^fn_36a_11] — But it is according to R. Judah,[^fn_36a_12] and with regard to a minor he holds like R. Meir,[^fn_36a_13] But does he[^fn_36a_14] hold this view?[^fn_36a_15] Did not Rab Judah say \[that\] Rab said: 'These are the words of R. Meir'?[^fn_36a_16] Now if it had been so,[^fn_36a_17] he ought to have said: 'These are the words of R. Meir and R. Judah'? — This Tanna[^fn_36a_18] holds according to R. Meir in one thing[^fn_36a_19] and differs from him in one thing.[^fn_36a_20] Rafram said: What is meant by 'a woman who refuses her husband by mi'un'? One who is entitled to refuse.[^fn_36a_21] Let him then teach[^fn_36a_22] 'a minor'? — This is indeed difficult.

\[It is said above:\] 'A barren woman has no claim to fine \[for outrage\] or to indemnity for seduction. A contradiction was raised against this: A woman who is a deaf-mute, or an idiot, or barren, has a claim to fine \[for outrage\], and a suit can be brought \[by her husband\] against her concerning her virginity. What contradiction is there? The one \[Baraitha\][^fn_36a_23] is according to R. Meir[^fn_36a_24] and the other \[Baraitha\] is according to the Rabbis! But he who raised the questions how could he raise it at all?[^fn_36a_25] — He wanted to raise another contradiction: Against a woman who is a deaf-mute, or an idiot, or has reached maturity,[^fn_36a_26] or lost her virginity through an accident, no suit can be brought concerning her virginity; against a woman who is blind or barren, a suit can be brought concerning her virginity. Symmachus says in the name of R. Meir: Against a blind woman a suit cannot be brought concerning her virginity! — Said R. Shesheth: This is not difficult: the one \[Baraitha\] is according to R. Gamaliel and the other \[Baraitha\] is according to R. Joshua.[^fn_36a_27] \[But\] say when does R. Gamaliel hold this view?[^fn_36a_28] When she pleads;[^fn_36a_29] but does he hold this view when she does not plead — Yes, since R. Gamaliel holds that she is believed, \[we apply\], in a case like this, \[the verse\], Open thy mouth for the dumb.[^fn_36a_30]

'And against a woman who has reached maturity, one cannot bring a suit concerning her virginity.' Did not Rab say: To a woman who has reached maturity one gives the \[whole\] first night?[^fn_36a_31] [pg 36b]

— If he raises the complaint with regard to the bleeding,[^fn_36b_1] it is really so;[^fn_36b_2] here we treat of a case where he raises the complaint of the 'open door'.[^fn_36b_3]

\[It is said above:\] 'Symmachus says in the name of R. Meir: Against a blind woman a suit cannot be brought concerning her virginity'. What is the reason of Symmachus? — R. Zera said: 'because she may have struck against the ground'.[^fn_36b_4] All the others[^fn_36b_5] may also have struck against the ground?[^fn_36b_6] All the others see it[^fn_36b_7] and show it to their mothers,[^fn_36b_8] this one does not see it and does not shew it to her mother.[^fn_36b_9]

\[It is said above\]:[^fn_36b_10] 'And a woman who goes out because of an evil name has no claim to fine \[for outrage\] and to indemnity for seduction'. A woman who goes out because of an evil name is liable to be stoned?[^fn_36b_11] — R. Shesheth said: He[^fn_36b_12] means it thus: if an evil name has gone out concerning her in her childhood[^fn_36b_13] she has no claim to fine \[for outrage\] or to indemnity for seduction. R. Papa said: Infer from this \[that\] one does not collect \[a debt\] with an unsound document. How shall we imagine this case? If to say that a rumour has gone out that the document is forged, and similarly here that a rumour has gone out that she has been unchaste? — Did not Raba say \[that\] if the rumour has gone out in the town \[that\] she is unchaste one does not pay any attention to it?[^fn_36b_14] — But \[the case is that\] two \[persons\] came and said \[that\] she asked them to commit with her a transgression[^fn_36b_15] and similarly here \[that\] two \[persons\] came and said \[that\] he[^fn_36b_16] said to them: Forge me \[the document\]. It is all right there,[^fn_36b_17] since there are many unrestrained men.[^fn_36b_18] But here[^fn_36b_19] — if he[^fn_36b_20] has been established,[^fn_36b_21] have \[therefore\] all Israelites been established?[^fn_36b_22] — Here also, since he[^fn_36b_23] was going round searching for a forgery, I can say \[that\] he \[him. self\] has forged it and written it.[^fn_36b_24]

***MISHNAH***. AND[^fn_36b_25] IN THE FOLLOWING CASES NO FINE[^fn_36b_26] IS INVOLVED: IF A MAN HAD INTERCOURSE WITH A FEMALE PROSELYTE, A FEMALE CAPTIVE OR A BONDWOMAN, WHO WAS RANSOMED, PROSELYTIZED OR MANUMITTED AFTER THE AGE OF[^fn_36b_27] THREE YEARS AND A DAY.[^fn_36b_28] R. JUDAH RULED: IF A FEMALE CAPTIVE WAS RANSOMED SHE IS DEEMED TO BE IN HER VIRGINITY[^fn_36b_29] EVEN IF SHE BE OF AGE. {¶=3.2}

A MAN WHO HAD INTERCOURSE WITH HIS DAUGHTER. HIS DAUGHTER'S DAUGHTER, HIS SON'S DAUGHTER. HIS WIFE'S DAUGHTER. HER SON'S DAUGHTER OR HER DAUGHTER'S DAUGHTER INCURS NO FINE,[^fn_36b_30] BECAUSE HE FORFEITS HIS LIFE, THE DEATH PENALTIES OF SUCH TRANSGRESSORS BEING[^fn_36b_31] IN THE HANDS OF *BETH DIN*, AND HE WHO FORFEITS HIS LIFE PAYS NO MONETARY FINE FOR IT IS SAID IN SCRIPTURE, AND YET NO HARM FOLLOW HE SHALL BE SURELY FINED.[^fn_36b_32]

***GEMARA***. R. Johanan said: Both R. Judah and R. Dosa taught the same thing. As to R. Judah \[we have the ruling\] just mentioned. As to R. Dosa? — It was taught: A female captive[^fn_36b_33] may eat *terumah*;[^fn_36b_34] so R. Dosa. 'What after all is it', said R. Dosa, 'that that Arab[^fn_36b_35] has done to her? Has he rendered her unfit to be a priest's wife merely because he squeezed her between her breasts?'[^fn_36b_36]

Said Raba:[^fn_36b_37] Is it not possible that there is really no \[agreement between them\]?[^fn_36b_38] R. Judah may have laid down his ruling[^fn_36b_39] here[^fn_36b_40] only in order that the sinner may gain no advantage,[^fn_36b_41] but there[^fn_36b_42] he may hold the same opinion as the Rabbis;[^fn_36b_43] or else: \[May not\] R. Dosa have laid down his ruling[^fn_36b_44] only there[^fn_36b_45] \[where it concerns\] *terumah* which \[at the present time is only\] a Rabbinical enactment,[^fn_36b_46] but in the case of a fine which is a Pentateuchal law[^fn_36b_47] he may well hold the same view as the Rabbis?[^fn_36b_48]

Abaye answered him: Is R. Judah's reason here[^fn_36b_49] 'that the sinner may gain no advantage'? Surely it was taught: R. Judah ruled, 'If a female captive was ransomed[^fn_36b_50] she is deemed to be in her virginity,[^fn_36b_51] and even if she is ten years old her *kethubah* is two hundred[^fn_36b_52] zuz'.[^fn_36b_53] Now how[^fn_36b_54] \[could the reason\] 'that the sinner shall gain no advantage' apply[^fn_36b_55] there?[^fn_36b_56] — There also \[a good reason exists for R. Judah's ruling, since otherwise[^fn_36b_57] men\][^fn_36b_58] would abstain from marrying her.[^fn_36b_59]

Could R. Judah, however, maintain the view \[that a female captive\] retains the status of a virgin[^fn_36b_60] when in fact, it was taught: A man who ransoms a female captive may marry her, but he who gives evidence on her behalf[^fn_36b_61] may not marry her,[^fn_36b_62] and R. Judah ruled: In either case he[^fn_36b_62] may not marry her![^fn_36b_63]

Is not this,[^fn_36b_64] however, self-contradictory? You said, 'A man who ransoms a female captive may marry her', and then it is stated, 'He[^fn_36b_65] who gives evidence on her behalf may not marry her'; shall he[^fn_36b_66] not marry her \[it may well be asked\] because he gives also evidence on her behalf? — This is no difficulty. It is this that was meant: A man who ransoms a female captive and gives evidence on her behalf may marry her,[^fn_36b_67] but he who merely gives evidence on her behalf may not marry her.[^fn_36b_68]

In any case, however, does not the contradiction against R. Judah remain?[^fn_36b_69] — R. Papa replied: Read, 'R. Judah ruled: In either case he may marry her'.

R. Huna the son of R. Joshua replied: \[The reading may\] still be as it was originally given,[^fn_36b_70] but R. Judah was speaking to the Rabbis in accordance with their own ruling. 'According to my view[^fn_36b_71] \[he argued\] the man may marry her in either case; but according to your view[^fn_36b_72] it should have been laid down that in either case he may not marry her'.

And the Rabbis?[^fn_36b_73] — 'A man who ransoms a captive and gives evidence on her behalf may marry her' because no one would throw money away for nothing,[^fn_36b_74] but 'he who merely gives evidence on her behalf may not marry her' because he may have fallen in love with her.[^fn_36b_75]

R. Papa b. Samuel pointed out the following contradiction to R. Joseph: [pg 37a]

Could R. Judah hold the view that \[a female captive\] is deemed to have retained her virginity[^fn_37a_1] when it was, in fact, taught. 'If a woman proselyte discovered \[some menstrual\] blood[^fn_37a_2] on \[the day of\] her conversion it is sufficient, R. Judah ruled, \[to reckon her Levitical uncleanness from\] the time she \[discovered it\].[^fn_37a_3] R. Jose ruled: She is subject to the same laws[^fn_37a_4] as all other women[^fn_37a_5] and, therefore, causes uncleanness \[retrospectively\] for twenty-four hours,[^fn_37a_6] or \[for the period\] intervening between[^fn_37a_7] \[her last\] examination and[^fn_37a_7] \[her previous\] examination.[^fn_37a_8] She must also wait[^fn_37a_9] three months;[^fn_37a_10] so R. Judah. but R. Jose permits her to be betrothed and married at once'?[^fn_37a_11] — The other replied: You are pointing out a contradiction between a proselyte and a captive \[who belong to totally different categories, since\] a proselyte does not protect her honour while a captive does protect her honour.

A contradiction, however, was also pointed out between two rulings in relation to a captive.[^fn_37a_12] For it was taught: Proselytes,[^fn_37a_13] captives[^fn_37a_13] or slaves[^fn_37a_13] who were ransomed, or proselytized. or were manumitted, must wait three months[^fn_37a_14] if they were older than three years and one day; so R. Judah. R. Jose permits immediate betrothal and marriage.[^fn_37a_15] \[The other\] remained silent. 'Have you'. he said to him, 'heard anything on the subject?' — 'Thus', the former replied. 'said R. Shesheth: \[This is a case\] where people saw that the captive was seduced'. If so[^fn_37a_16] what could be R. Jose's reason? — Rabbah replied: R. Jose is of the opinion that a woman who plays the harlot makes use of an absorbent in order to prevent conception. This[^fn_37a_17] is intelligible in the case of a proselyte, who, since her intention is to proselytize, is careful.[^fn_37a_18] It[^fn_37a_17] is likewise \[intelligible in the case of\] a captive \[who is also careful\][^fn_37a_18] since she does not know whither they would take her.[^fn_37a_19] It[^fn_37a_17] is similarly \[intelligible in the case of\] a bondwoman \[who might also be careful\][^fn_37a_18] when she hears from her master.[^fn_37a_20] What, however, can be said in the case of one who is liberated on account of the loss of a tooth or an eye?[^fn_37a_21] And were you to suggest that R. Jose did not speak[^fn_37a_22] of an unexpected occurrence,[^fn_37a_23] \[it might be retorted,\] there is the case of a woman who was outraged or seduced[^fn_37a_24] which may happen unexpectedly and yet it was taught: A woman who has been outraged or seduced must wait three months; so R. Judah, but R. Jose permits immediate betrothal and marriage![^fn_37a_25] — The fact, however, is, said Rabbah,[^fn_37a_26] that R. Jose is of the opinion that a woman who plays the harlot turns over in order to prevent conception.[^fn_37a_27] And the other?[^fn_37a_28] — There is the apprehension that she might not have turned over properly.[^fn_37a_29]

FOR IT IS SAID IN SCRIPTURE, AND YET NO HARM FOLLOW HE SHALL BE SURELY FINED etc. Is, however, the deduction[^fn_37a_30] made from this text?[^fn_37a_31] Is it not in fact made from the following text:[^fn_37a_32] According to the measure of his crime,[^fn_37a_33] \[which implies\][^fn_37a_34] you make him liable to a penalty[^fn_37a_35] for one crime, but you cannot make him liable \[at the same time\] for two crimes?[^fn_37a_36] — One \[text[^fn_37a_37] deals\] with \[the penalties of\] death and money and the other[^fn_37a_38] with \[the penalties of\] flogging and money.

And \[both texts[^fn_37a_39] were\] needed. For if we had been told \[only of that which deals with the penalties of\] death and money[^fn_37a_37] it might have been assumed \[that the restriction[^fn_37a_40] applied only to the death penalty\] because it involves loss of life,[^fn_37a_41] but not \[to the penalties of\] flogging and money where no loss of life is involved. And if we had been told only of flogging and money[^fn_37a_38] it might have been assumed \[that the restriction[^fn_37a_40] applied only to flogging\] because the transgression for which flogging is inflicted[^fn_37a_42] is not very grave,[^fn_37a_43] but not \[to the penalties of\] death and money where the transgression for which the death penalty is imposed[^fn_37a_42] is very grave.[^fn_37a_44] \[Hence it was\] necessary \[to have both texts\].

According to R. Meir, however, who ruled: 'A man may be flogged and also ordered to pay'.[^fn_37a_45] what need was there for the two texts?[^fn_37a_46] — One[^fn_37a_47] deals with the penalties of death and money [pg 37b]

and the other[^fn_37b_1] with those of death and flogging. And \[both texts were\] needed. For if we had been told \[only of that which deals with the penalties of\] death and money it might have been assumed \[that the restriction[^fn_37b_2] applied to these two penalties only\] because we must not inflict one penalty upon one's body and another upon one's possessions, but in the case of death and flogging, both of which are inflicted on one's body, it might have been assumed \[that the flogging\] is deemed to be \[but\] one pro tracted death penalty and both may, therefore, be inflicted upon one man.[^fn_37b_3] And if we had been told about death and flogging only \[the restriction[^fn_37b_4] might have been assumed to apply to these penalties only\] because no two corporal punishments may be inflicted on the same person, but in the case of the penalties of death and money one of which is corporal and the other monetary it might have been assumed that both may be inflicted.[^fn_37b_5] \[Both texts were, therefore,\] necessary.

What need was there[^fn_37b_6] for the Scriptural text, Moreover ye shall take no ransom for the life of a murderer?[^fn_37b_7] — The All-Merciful has here stated: You shall take no monetary fine from him and thus exempt him from the death penalty.

What was the need[^fn_37b_8] for the Scriptural text, And ye shall take no ransom for him that is fled to his city of refuge'?[^fn_37b_9] — The All-Merciful has here stated: You shall take no monetary fine from him to exempt him from exile.[^fn_37b_10]

But why two texts?[^fn_37b_11] — One deals with unwitting, and the other with intentional \[murder\]. And \[both texts\] were required. For if we had been told[^fn_37b_12] of intentional murder[^fn_37b_13] only it might have been assumed \[that the restriction[^fn_37b_12] applied to this case only\], because the transgression for which death is inflicted[^fn_37b_14] is grave,[^fn_37b_15] but not to the one of unintentional murder where the transgression is not so grave. And if we had been told[^fn_37b_16] of unintentional murder[^fn_37b_17] is only it might have been assumed \[that the restriction[^fn_37b_16] applied to this case only\] because no loss of life is involved,[^fn_37b_18] but not to intentional murder where a loss of life[^fn_37b_19] is involved.[^fn_37b_20] \[Both texts were consequently\] required.

What was the object[^fn_37b_21] of the Scriptural text, And no expiation can be made for the land for the blood that is shed therein, but by the blood of him that shed it?[^fn_37b_22] — It was required for \[the following deduction\] as it was taught: Whence is it deduced that, if the murderer has been discovered after the heifer's neck had been broken,[^fn_37b_23] he is not to be acquitted?[^fn_37b_24] From the Scriptural text, 'And no expiation can be made for the land for the blood that is shed therein etc.'[^fn_37b_25]

Then what was the need[^fn_37b_26] for the text, So shalt thou put away the innocent blood front the midst of thee?[^fn_37b_27] — It is required for \[the following deduction\] as it was taught: Whence is it deduced that execution by the sword[^fn_37b_28] must be at the neck? It was explicitly stated in Scripture, 'So shalt thou put away the innocent blood from the midst of thee', all who shed blood are compared to the atoning heifer:[^fn_37b_29] As its head is cut[^fn_37b_30] at the neck[^fn_37b_31] so \[is the execution of\] those who shed blood at the neck.[^fn_37b_32] If \[so, should not the comparison be carried further\]: As there[^fn_37b_33] \[its head is cut\] with an axe and at the nape of the neck so here[^fn_37b_34] too? — R. Nahman answered in the name of Rabbah b. Abbuha: Scripture said, But thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself,[^fn_37b_35] choose for him an easy death.[^fn_37b_36]

What need was there[^fn_37b_37] for the Scriptural text, None devoted, that may be devoted of men, shall be ransomed?[^fn_37b_38] — It is required for \[the following\] as it was taught: Whence is it deduced that, when a person was being led to his execution,[^fn_37b_39] and someone said, 'I vow to give his value[^fn_37b_40] \[to the Temple\].' his vow is null and void?[^fn_37b_41] \[From Scripture\] wherein it is said, 'None devoted, that may be devoted of man, shall be redeemed'.[^fn_37b_42] As it might \[have been presumed that the same law applied\] even before his sentence had been pronounced[^fn_37b_43] it was explicitly stated: 'Of men',[^fn_37b_44] but not 'all men'.[^fn_37b_45]

According to R. Hanania b. 'Akabia, however, who ruled that the \[age\] value of such a person[^fn_37b_46] may be vowed[^fn_37b_47] because its price is fixed,[^fn_37b_48] what deduction does he[^fn_37b_49] make from the text of 'None devoted'?[^fn_37b_50] — He requires it for \[the following deduction\] as it was taught: R. Ishmael the son of R. Johanan b. Beroka said, Whereas we find that those who incur the penalty of death at the hand of heaven[^fn_37b_51] may pay a monetary fine and thereby obtain atonement, for it is said in Scripture, If there be laid down on him a sum of money,[^fn_37b_52] it might \[have been assumed that\] the same law applied also \[to those who are sentenced to death\] at the hands of men,[^fn_37b_53] hence it was explicitly stated in the Scriptures. 'None … devoted[^fn_37b_54] of men shall be redeemed'. Thus we know the law only concerning[^fn_37b_55] severe death penalties[^fn_37b_56] since \[they are imposed for offences\] which cannot be atoned for[^fn_37b_57] if committed unwittingly;[^fn_37b_58] whence, \[however. is it inferred that the same law applies also to\] lighter death penalties[^fn_37b_59] seeing that \[they are for offences\] that may be atoned for[^fn_37b_60] if committed unwittingly?[^fn_37b_61] It was explicitly stated in Scripture, 'None devoted'.[^fn_37b_62] But could not this[^fn_37b_63] be inferred independently from Ye shall take no ransom[^fn_37b_64] which implies: You shall take no money from him to exempt him \[from death\]?[^fn_37b_65] What need was there for 'None devoted'? — Rami b. Hama replied: It was required. Since it might have been assumed [pg 38a]

that this applied only where murder had been committed[^fn_38a_1] in the course of an upward movement,[^fn_38a_2] because no atonement[^fn_38a_3] is allowed when such an act[^fn_38a_4] was committed unwittingly.[^fn_38a_5] but that where murder was committed in the course of a downward movement,[^fn_38a_2] which \[is an offence that\] may be atoned for[^fn_38a_3] if committed unwittingly,[^fn_38a_5] a monetary fine may be received from him and thereby he may be exempted \[from the death penalty\]. Hence we were taught[^fn_38a_6] \[that in no circumstances may the death penalty be commuted for a monetary fine\].

Said Raba to him,[^fn_38a_7] Does not this[^fn_38a_8] follow from what a Tanna of the School of Hezekiah \[taught\]; for a Tanna of the School of Hezekiah taught: He that smiteth a man[^fn_38a_9] \[was placed in juxtaposition with\] And he that smiteth a beast[^fn_38a_9] \[to indicate that just\] as in the case of the killing of[^fn_38a_10] a beast no distinction is made whether \[the act was\] unwitting or presumptuous, whether intentional or unintentional, whether it was performed in the course of a down ward movement or in the course of an upward movement, in respect of exempting him from a monetary obligation[^fn_38a_11] but in respect of imposing a monetary obligation[^fn_38a_12] upon him,[^fn_38a_13] so also in the case of the killing of[^fn_38a_14] a man no distinction is to be made whether \[the act was\] unwitting or presumptuous. whether intentional or unintentional, whether it was performed in the course of a downward movement or in the course of an upward movement, in respect of imposing upon him a monetary obligation[^fn_38a_15] but[^fn_38a_16] in respect of exempting him from any monetary obligation?[^fn_38a_17] — But, said Rami b. Hama, \[one of the texts[^fn_38a_18] was\] required \[to obviate the following assumption\]: It might have been presumed that this[^fn_38a_19] applied only where a man blinded another man's eye and thereby killed him, but that where he blinded his eye and killed him[^fn_38a_20] by another act a monetary fine must be exacted from him.[^fn_38a_21]

Said Raba to him:[^fn_38a_22] Is not this[^fn_38a_23] also deduced from \[the statement of\] another Tanna of the School of Hezekiah; for a Tanna of the School of Hezekiah \[taught:\] Eye for eye[^fn_38a_24] \[implies\] but not an eye[^fn_38a_25] and a life for an eye?[^fn_38a_26] — \[This\]. however, \[is the explanation\], said R. Ashi: \[One of the texts[^fn_38a_27] was\] required \[to obviate the following assumption\]: It might have been presumed that since the law of a monetary fine is an anomaly[^fn_38a_28] which the Torah has introduced, a man must pay it even though he also suffers the death penalty. Hence we were told[^fn_38a_29] \[that even a monetary fine may not be imposed in addition to a death penalty\].

But according to Rabbah, who said that it is an anomaly[^fn_38a_28] that the Torah has introduced by the enactment of the law of a monetary fine \[and that therefore an offender\][^fn_38a_30] must pay his fine even though he is also to be killed,[^fn_38a_31] what application can be made of the text 'None devoted…'?[^fn_38a_32] — He[^fn_38a_33] holds the view of the first Tanna who \[is in dispute with\] R. Hanania b. 'Akabia.[^fn_38a_34]

***MISHNAH***. A GIRL[^fn_38a_35] WHO WAS BETROTHED AND THEN DIVORCED[^fn_38a_36] IS NOT ENTITLED, SAID R. JOSE THE GALILEAN, TO RECEIVE A FINE \[FROM HER VIOLATOR\].[^fn_38a_37] R. AKIBA SAID: SHE IS ENTITLED TO RECEIVE THE FINE AND, MOREOVER, THE FINE BELONGS TO HER.[^fn_38a_38] {¶=3.3}

***GEMARA***. What is R. Jose the Galilean's reason?[^fn_38a_39] — Scripture said, That is not betrothed[^fn_38a_40] \[is entitled to a fine\],[^fn_38a_41] one, therefore, who was betrothed is not entitled to a fine. And R. Akiba?[^fn_38a_42] — \[In the case of a girl\] that is not betrothed \[the fine is given\] to her father but if she Was betrothed \[the fine is given\] to herself.

Now then, \[the expression,\] A damsel[^fn_38a_43] \[implies\] but not one who is adolescent;[^fn_38a_44] could it here also[^fn_38a_45] \[be maintained\] that \[the fine is given\] to herself?[^fn_38a_46] \[Likewise the expression\] virgin[^fn_38a_47] \[implies\] but not one who is no longer a virgin; would it here also[^fn_38a_48] \[be maintained\] that \[the fine is given\] to herself?[^fn_38a_46] Must it not consequently be admitted[^fn_38a_48] \[that the exclusion in the last mentioned case\] is complete,[^fn_38a_49] and so here also[^fn_38a_50] it must be complete?[^fn_38a_51] — R. Akiba can answer you: The text of[^fn_38a_52] 'Not betrothed' is required for \[another purpose\].[^fn_38a_53] as it was taught: 'That is not. betrothed' excludes a girl[^fn_38a_54] that was betrothed and then divorced who has no claim to a fine; so R. Jose the Galilean. R. Akiba, however, ruled: She has a claim to a fine and her fine \[is given\] to her father.[^fn_38a_55] This[^fn_38a_56] is arrived at by analogy: Since her father is entitled to have the money of her betrothal[^fn_38a_57] and he is also entitled to have the money of her fine[^fn_38a_58] \[the two payments should be compared to one another\]: As the money of her betrothal[^fn_38a_59] belongs to her father even after she had been betrothed[^fn_38a_60] and divorced,[^fn_38a_61] so also the money of her fine should belong to her father even after she had been betrothed and divorced. If so[^fn_38a_62] what was the object of the Scriptural text, 'That is not betrothed'? It is free for the purpose of a comparison with it and an inference from it by means of a *gezerah shawah*.'[^fn_38a_63] Here[^fn_38a_64] it is said, 'That is not betrothed' and elsewhere[^fn_38a_65] it is said, That is not betrothed,[^fn_38a_66] as here[^fn_38a_67] \[the fine is that of\] fifty \[silver coins\][^fn_38a_68] so is it fifty \[silver coins\] there[^fn_38a_65] also; and as there[^fn_38a_65] \[the coins must be\] *shekels*[^fn_38a_69] so here[^fn_38a_67] also they must be *shekels*.

What, however, moved[^fn_38a_70] R. Akiba \[to apply the text\] of 'That is not betrothed'[^fn_38a_71] for a *gezerah shawah* and that of 'Virgin' for the exclusion[^fn_38a_72] of one who was no longer a virgin? [pg 38b]

Might \[not one equally well\] suggest that 'Virgin' should be applied for the *gezerah shawah*[^fn_38b_1] and 'That is not betrothed' \[should serve the purpose of\] excluding[^fn_38b_2] a girl[^fn_38b_3] that was betrothed and divorced? — It stands to reason \[that the text of\] 'That is not betrothed' should be employed for the *gezerah shawah*,[^fn_38b_4] since such a girl[^fn_38b_3] is still[^fn_38b_5] designated. A damsel that is a virgin.[^fn_38b_6] On the contrary; \[should not the expression of\] 'Virgin' be applied for the *gezerah shawah*, since \[a non-virgin\] may still be described as one 'That is not betrothed'?[^fn_38b_7] — It stands to reason \[that R. Akiba's first view[^fn_38b_8] is to be preferred, since\] the body of the one[^fn_38b_9] had undergone a change while that of the other[^fn_38b_10] had not.[^fn_38b_11]

As to R. Jose the Galilean,[^fn_38b_12] whence does he draw that logical inference?[^fn_38b_13] — He derives it from the following where it was taught: He shall pay money according to the dowry of virgins[^fn_38b_14] \[implies\] that this \[payment\] shall be the same sum as the dowry of the virgins and the dowry[^fn_38b_15] of the virgins shall be the same as this.[^fn_38b_16]

Does not a contradiction arise between the two statements of R. Akiba?[^fn_38b_17] — \[The respective statements represent the opinions of\] two Tannaim who differ as to what was the ruling of R. Akiba.

\[The ruling of\] R. Akiba in our Mishnah presents no difficulty since the *gezerah shawah* does not altogether deprive the Scriptural text of its ordinary meaning.[^fn_38b_18] According to R. Akiba's ruling in the Baraitha, however, does not the *gezerah shawah* completely deprive the Scriptural text of its ordinary meaning?[^fn_38b_19] — R. Nahman b. Isaac replied. Read in the text:[^fn_38b_20] That is not a betrothed maiden.[^fn_38b_21] \[But\] is not a betrothed maiden one \[for the violation of whom\] the penalty of stoning \[but not fine\] is incurred?[^fn_38b_22] — It might have been assumed that, since it is an anomaly[^fn_38b_23] that the Torah had introduced by the enactment of the law of a monetary fine, an offender[^fn_38b_24] must, therefore, pay his fine even if he is also to be executed.[^fn_38b_25]

According to Rabbah, however, who said that it was an anomaly[^fn_38b_23] that the Torah had introduced by the' enactment of the law of a monetary fine and that an offender[^fn_38b_24] must pay his fine even if he is also to be executed,[^fn_38b_26] what can be said \[in reply to the objection raised\]?[^fn_38b_27] — He[^fn_38b_28] adopts the same view as that of R. Akiba in our Mishnah.[^fn_38b_29]

Our Rabbis taught: To whom is the monetary fine \[of an outraged virgin[^fn_38b_30] to be given\]? — To her father. Others say: To herself. But why 'to herself'?[^fn_38b_31] — R. Hisda replied: We are dealing here with the case of a virgin who was once betrothed and is now divorced, and they[^fn_38b_32] differ on the principles underlying the difference between the view of R. Akiba in our Mishnah and his view in the Baraitha.

Abaye stated: If he[^fn_38b_33] had intercourse with her and she died,[^fn_38b_34] he is exempt \[from the fine\], for in Scripture it was stated, Then the man … shall give unto the damsel's father,[^fn_38b_35] but not unto a dead woman's father.[^fn_38b_36]

This ruling which was so obvious to Abaye formed the subject of an enquiry by Raba.[^fn_38b_37] For Raba enquired: Is the state of adolescence legally attainable in the grave[^fn_38b_38] or not? 'Is the state of adolescence attainable in the grave and \[the fine,[^fn_38b_35] therefore,\] belongs to her son,[^fn_38b_39] or is perhaps the age of adolescence not attainable in the grave and \[the fine, therefore,\] belongs to her father? [pg 39a]

But is she,[^fn_39a_1] however, capable of \[normal\]

         conception?[^fn_39a_2] Did not R. Bibi recite in the presence of R. Nahman:[^fn_39a_3] Three \[categories of\] women may use an absorbent[^fn_39a_4] in their marital intercourse:[^fn_39a_5]   a minor, and an expectant and nursing mother. The minor,[^fn_39a_6] because otherwise she might become pregnant and die. An expectant mother,[^fn_39a_6] because otherwise she might cause her foetus to degenerate into a sandal.[^fn_39a_7]   A nursing mother,[^fn_39a_6] because otherwise she might have to wean her child \[prematurely\][^fn_39a_8] and this would result in his death.[^fn_39a_9] And what is \[the age of such\] a minor?[^fn_39a_10] From the age of eleven years and one day to the age of twelve years and one day. One who is under,[^fn_39a_11] or over this age[^fn_39a_12] must carry on her marital intercourse in a normal manner; so R. Meir. But the Sages said: The one as well as the other carries on her marital intercourse in a normal manner, and mercy[^fn_39a_13] will be vouchsafed from Heaven, for it is said in the Scriptures, *The Lord preserveth the simple*.[^fn_39a_14] And should you reply that this is a case where she conceived when she was a na'arah and gave birth to a child when she was still a na'arah \[it could be objected:\] Does one give birth to a child within six months \[after conception\]? Did not Samuel, in fact, state: The period between the age of na'aruth[^fn_39a_15] and that of bagruth[^fn_39a_16] is only six months? And should you suggest \[that he meant to say\] that there were no less but more \[than six months\] surely \[it could be retorted\] he used the expression, only'![^fn_39a_17] It must be this, then, that he[^fn_39a_18] asked: Is the state of adolescence[^fn_39a_19] attainable in the grave[^fn_39a_20] and her father consequently forfeits[^fn_39a_21] \[his right\],[^fn_39a_22] or is perhaps the state of adolescence not attainable in the grave[^fn_39a_23] and the father, therefore, does not forfeit[^fn_39a_24] \[his right\]?

Mar son of R. Ashi raised the question[^fn_39a_25] in the following manner: Does death effect adolescence[^fn_39a_26] or not? — The question stands undecided.[^fn_39a_27]

Raba enquired of Abaye: What \[is the legal position if\] he[^fn_39a_28] had intercourse and became betrothed?[^fn_39a_29] The other replied: Is it written in Scripture. 'Then the man … shall give unto the father of the damsel[^fn_39a_30] who was not a betrothed woman'?[^fn_39a_31] Following, however, your line of reasoning, \[the first retorted, one can argue in respect\] of what was taught: '\[If the offender had\] intercourse with her and she married \[the fine\] belongs to herself', is it written in Scripture. 'Then the man … shall give unto the father of the damsel[^fn_39a_32] who was not a married woman'? — What a comparison![^fn_39a_33] There[^fn_39a_34] \[the following analogy may well be made\]: Since the state of

         adolescence liberates a daughter from her father's authority[^fn_39a_35] and marriage also liberates a daughter from her father's authority[^fn_39a_36] \[the two may be compared to one another\]: As \[in the case of\] adolescence, if she attains adolescence after he had intercourse with her,[^fn_39a_37] \[the fine\] belongs to the girl herself,[^fn_39a_38] so also \[in the case of\] marriage, if she married after he had intercourse with her,[^fn_39a_37] \[the fine\] belongs to the girl herself. But as to betrothal, does it completely liberate a daughter from her father's authority? Surely we learned: \[In the case of\] a betrothed girl[^fn_39a_39] her father and her husband jointly may invalidate her vows.[^fn_39a_40]

***MISHNAH***. THE SEDUCER PAYS THREE FORMS \[OF COMPENSATION\] AND THE VIOLATOR FOUR. THE SEDUCER PAYS COMPENSATION FOR INDIGNITY AND BLEMISH[^fn_39a_41] AND THE \[STATUTORY\] FINE, WHILE THE VIOLATOR PAYS AN ADDITIONAL \[FORM OF COMPENSATION\] IN THAT HE PAYS FOR THE PAIN. {¶=3.4}

WHAT \[IS THE DIFFERENCE\] BETWEEN \[THE PENALTIES OF\] A SEDUCER AND THOSE OF A VIOLATOR? THE VIOLATOR PAYS COMPENSATION FOR THE PAIN BUT THE SEDUCER DOES NOT PAY COMPENSATION FOR THE PAIN. THE VIOLATOR PAYS[^fn_39a_42] FORTHWITH[^fn_39a_43] BUT THE SEDUCER \[PAYS ONLY\] IF HE DISMISSES[^fn_39a_44] HER. THE VIOLATOR MUST DRINK OUT OF HIS POT[^fn_39a_45] BUT THE SEDUCER MAY DISMISS \[THE GIRL\] IF HE WISHES. WHAT IS MEANT BY[^fn_39a_46] 'MUST DRINK OUT OF HIS POT'?
