         — EVEN IF SHE IS LAME, EVEN IF SHE IS BLIND AND EVEN IF SHE IS AFFLICTED WITH BOILS \[HE MAY NOT DISMISS HER\]. IF, HOWEVER, SHE WAS FOUND TO HAVE COMMITTED[^fn_39a_47] AN IMMORAL ACT OR WAS UNFIT TO MARRY AN ISRAELITE[^fn_39a_48] HE MAY NOT CONTINUE TO LIVE WITH HER, FOR IT IS SAID IN SCRIPTURE, AND UNTO HIM SHE SHALL BE FOR A WIFE,[^fn_39a_49] \[IMPLYING\] A WIFE THAT IS FIT 'UNTO HIM.

***GEMARA***. \[For the\] PAIN of what?[^fn_39a_50] — The father of Samuel replied: For the pain \[he has inflicted\] when he thrust her upon the ground.

R. Zera demurred: Now then, if he had thrust her upon silk stuffs[^fn_39a_51] would he for a similar reason[^fn_39a_52] be exempt? And should you say that the law is so indeed,[^fn_39a_52] was it not \[it may be retorted\] taught: 'R. Simeon b. Judah stated in the name of R. Simeon.[^fn_39a_53] A violator does not pay compensation for the pain \[he has inflicted\] because [pg 39b]

the woman would ultimately have suffered the same pain from her husband, but they[^fn_39b_1] said to him: One who is forced to intercourse cannot be compared to one who acts willingly'?[^fn_39b_2]   — \[The reference.\] in fact,[^fn_39b_3] said R. Nahman in the name of Rabbah b. Abbuha \[is to the\] pain of opening the feet, for so it is said in Scripture, And hast opened thy feet to every one that passed by.[^fn_39b_4] But if so, the same applies to one who has been seduced?[^fn_39b_5] R. Nahman replied in the name of Rabbah b. Abbuha: The case of one who has been seduced may be compared to that of a person who said to his friend, 'Tear up my silk garments and you will be free from liability'.[^fn_39b_6]   'My'? Are they[^fn_39b_7]

         not her father's?[^fn_39b_8] — This, however, said R. Nahman in the name of Rabbah b. Abbuha, \[is the explanation\]: The smart women among them declare that one who is seduced experiences no pain. But do we not see that one does experience pain? — Abaye replied: Nurse[^fn_39b_9]   told me: Like hot water on a bald head.[^fn_39b_10] Raba said: R. Hisda's daughter[^fn_39b_11] told me, Like the prick of the blood-letting lancet.[^fn_39b_12] R. Papa said: The daughter of Abba of Sura[^fn_39b_11] told me, Like hard crust in the jaws.[^fn_39b_13]

THE VIOLATOR PAYS FORTHWITH BUT THE SEDUCER \[PAYS ONLY\] IF HE DISMISSES HER etc. WHEN HE DISMISSES HER! Is she then his wife?[^fn_39b_14] Abaye replied: Read, 'If he does not marry her,[^fn_39b_15] So it was also taught: Although it was laid down that the seducer pays \[the statutory fine\] only if he does not marry her, he must pay compensation for indignity and blemish forthwith. And \[in the case of\] the violator as well as \[of\] the seducer, she herself or her father may oppose.[^fn_39b_16]

As regards one who has been seduced, this[^fn_39b_17] may well be granted because it is written in Scripture. If her father will refuse,[^fn_39b_18] \[since from 'refusing'\][^fn_39b_19] I would only \[have known that\] her father \[may refuse\], whence \[could it be deduced that\] she herself \[may also refuse\]?[^fn_39b_20] It was, therefore, explicitly stated 'will refuse', implying either of them.[^fn_39b_21] But as regards a violator, though one may well grant that she \[may refuse him since\] it is written in Scripture. 'and onto him she shall be[^fn_39b_22] \[which implies\][^fn_39b_23] only if she is so minded, whence, however, \[it may be objected\] is it deduced that her father \[may also object to the marriage\]? — Abaye replied: \[Her father was given the right to object\] in order that the sinner[^fn_39b_24] might not gain an advantage.[^fn_39b_25] Raba replied; It[^fn_39b_26] is deduced a minori ad majus: If a seducer who has acted against the wish of her father alone may be rejected either by herself or by her father how much more so the violator who has acted both against the wish of her father and against the wish of herself.

Raba did not give the same reply as Abaye, because, having paid the fine, \[the offender can\] no \[longer be described as a\] sinner gaining an advantage. Abaye does not give the same reply as Raba \[because it may be argued:[^fn_39b_27] In the case of\] a seducer, since he himself may object \[to the marriage\], her father also may object to it; \[but in the case of\] a violator, since he himself may not object \[to the marriage\] her father also may have no right to object to it.

Another Baraitha taught: Although it has been laid down that the violator pays forthwith[^fn_39b_28] she has no claim upon him[^fn_39b_29] when he divorces her.[^fn_39b_30] \['When he divorces her'! Can he divorce her?[^fn_39b_31] — Read: When she demands a divorce[^fn_39b_32] she has no claim upon him\].[^fn_39b_29] If he died, the fine is regarded as a quittance for her *kethubah*.[^fn_39b_33] R. Jose the son of R. Judah ruled: She is entitled[^fn_39b_34] to a *kethubah* for one *maneh*.[^fn_39b_35]

On what principle do they[^fn_39b_36] differ? — The Rabbis hold the view that the only reason why[^fn_39b_37] the Rabbis instituted a *kethubah* \[for a wife was\] in order that the man might not find it easy[^fn_39b_38] to divorce her,[^fn_39b_39] but \[the violator,\] surely, cannot divorce her.[^fn_39b_40] R. Jose the son of R. Judah, however, is of the opinion that this man too might torment her until she says to him, 'I do not want you'.[^fn_39b_41] THE VIOLATOR MUST DRINK OUT OF HIS POT. Said Raba of Parazika[^fn_39b_42] to R. Ashi. Consider! \[The fines of a violator and a seducer\] are deduced from one another.[^fn_39b_43] [pg 40a]

why then should not this law[^fn_40a_1] also be inferred?[^fn_40a_2] — Scripture stated, He shall surely pay a dowry for her to be his wife,[^fn_40a_3] 'her'[^fn_40a_4] \[implies\][^fn_40a_5] only if he is so minded \[need he marry her\].

WHAT IS MEANT BY 'MUST DRINK OUT OF HIS POT' etc.? R. Kahana said, I submitted the following argument before R. Zebid of Nehardea:[^fn_40a_6] Why should not the positive commandment[^fn_40a_7] supersede the negative one?[^fn_40a_8] And he replied to me: 'Where do we say that a positive commandment supersedes a negative one? \[Only in a case\], for instance, like circumcision in leprosy.[^fn_40a_9] since otherwise it would be impossible to fulfil the positive commandment, but here, if she should say that she did not want \[the man for a husband\], would \[the question of the performance of\] the positive commandment[^fn_40a_7] ever have arisen?'[^fn_40a_10]

***MISHNAH***. IF AN ORPHAN WAS BETROTHED AND THEN DIVORCED, ANY MAN WHO VIOLATES HER, SAID R. ELEAZAR, IS LIABLE \[TO PAY THE STATUTORY FINE\][^fn_40a_11] BUT THE MAN WHO SEDUCES HER IS EXEMPT.[^fn_40a_12] {¶=3.5}

***GEMARA***. Rabbah b. Bar Hana stated in the name of R. Johanan: R. Eleazar made his statement[^fn_40a_13] on the lines of the view of his master R. Akiba who ruled: She[^fn_40a_14] is entitled to receive the fine, and, moreover, the fine belongs to her. How is this[^fn_40a_15] inferred?[^fn_40a_16] — As it was stated, IF AN ORPHAN … ANY MAN WHO VIOLATES HER, SAID R. ELEAZAR, IS LIABLE \[TO PAY THE STATUTORY FINE\] BUT THE MAN WHO SEDUCES HER IS EXEMPT, \[the difficulty arises: Is not the case of\] an orphan self-evident?[^fn_40a_17] Consequently it must be this that we were taught: A girl WHO WAS BETROTHED AND THEN DIVORCED has the same status as AN ORPHAN. As \[the fine of\] an orphan belongs to the orphan herself so does that of a girl who was betrothed and then divorced belong to the girl herself.

R. Zera said in the name of Rabbah b. Shila who said it in the name of R. Hamnuna the Elder who had it from R. Adda b. Ahabah who had it from Rab: The *halachah* is in agreement with the ruling of R. Eleazar. Rab \[in fact\] designated R. Eleazar[^fn_40a_18] as the happiest[^fn_40a_19] of the wise men.

***MISHNAH***. WHAT IS \[THE COMPENSATION THAT IS PAID FOR\] INDIGNITY?[^fn_40a_20] ALL DEPENDS ON THE STATUS OF THE OFFENDER AND THE OFFENDED. {¶=3.6}

\[AS TO\] BLEMISH,[^fn_40a_20] SHE IS REGARDED AS IF SHE WERE A BOND WOMAN TO BE SOLD IN THE MARKET PLACE \[AND IT IS ESTIMATED\] HOW MUCH SHE WAS WORTH[^fn_40a_21] AND HOW MUCH SHE IS WORTH NOW.

THE STATUTORY FINE[^fn_40a_22] IS THE SAME FOR ALL, AND ANY SUM THAT IS FIXED PENTATEUCHALLY REMAINS THE SAME FOR ALL.

***GEMARA***, Might it not be suggested that the All-Merciful intended the fifty *sela'*[^fn_40a_23] to cover all the forms of compensation?[^fn_40a_24] — R. Zera replied: \[If that were so\] it would be said, 'Should one who had intercourse with a princess pay fifty and one who had intercourse with the daughter of a commoner also pay only fifty?'[^fn_40a_25] Said Abaye to him: If so, the same might be argued in respect of a slave:[^fn_40a_26] 'Should \[compensation for\] a slave who perforates pearls be thirty \[and that for\] one who does [pg 40b]

needlework also be thirty?'[^fn_40b_1] — This, however, said R. Zera, \[is the proper explanation\]: If two men had intercourse with her, one in a natural, and the other in an unnatural manner, it would be argued,[^fn_40b_2] 'Should one who had intercourse with a sound woman pay fifty and one who had intercourse with a degraded woman also pay fifty?'

Said Abaye to him: If so, the same might be argued in respect of a slave: 'Should \[compensation for\] a healthy slave be thirty \[and that for\] one afflicted with boils also be thirty?'[^fn_40b_1] — This, however, said Abaye, \[is the explanation\]: Scripture said,[^fn_40b_3] Because he hath humbled her[^fn_40b_4] \[as if to say\]: These[^fn_40b_5] \[must be paid\] 'because he hath humbled her',' thus it may be inferred that \[compensation for\] indignity and blemish[^fn_40b_6] must also be paid.[^fn_40b_7]

Raba replied: Scripture said, Then the man that lay with her shall give unto the damsel's father fifty \[*shekels* of\] silver;[^fn_40b_8] for the gratification of 'lying' \[he gives\] fifty. Thus it may be inferred that \[compensation for\] indignity and blemish must also be paid.[^fn_40b_7]

But say \[perhaps\] that \[compensation for indignity and blemish is paid\] to her?[^fn_40b_9] — Scripture said, Being in her youth in her father's house,[^fn_40b_10] \[implying that\] all advantages of 'her youth' belong to her father.

\[Consider,\] however, that which R. Huna said in the name of Rab: 'Whence is it deduced that a daughter's handiwork belongs to her father? \[From Scripture\] where it is said, And if a man sell his daughter to be a maidservant,[^fn_40b_11] as[^fn_40b_12] the handiwork of a maidservant belongs to her master so does the handiwork of a daughter belong to her father'. Now what need is there[^fn_40b_13] \[it may be asked, for this text when\] the law[^fn_40b_14] can be deduced from \[the text of\] 'Being in her youth in her father's house'? Consequently \[it must be admitted, must it not, that\] that text was written in connection only with the annulment of vows?[^fn_40b_15] And should you suggest[^fn_40b_16] that we might infer[^fn_40b_17] from it,[^fn_40b_18] \[it could be retorted that,\] monetary matters[^fn_40b_19] cannot be inferred from ritual matters.[^fn_40b_20] And should you suggest[^fn_40b_16] that we might infer it[^fn_40b_17] from the law of fine, is \[it could be retorted, could it not, that,\] monetary payments cannot be inferred from fines?[^fn_40b_21] — This, however, \[is the explanation\]:[^fn_40b_22] it stands to reason that \[her compensation should\] belong to her father; for if he wished he could have handed her over[^fn_40b_23] to an ugly man or to one afflicted with boils.[^fn_40b_24]

AS TO BLEMISH, SHE IS REGARDED AS IF SHE WERE A BONDWOMAN TO BE SOLD. How is she assessed? The father of Samuel replied: It is estimated how much[^fn_40b_25] more a man would pay for a virgin slave than[^fn_40b_25] for a non-virgin slave to attend upon him. 'A non-virgin slave to attend upon him'! What difference does this[^fn_40b_26] make to him? — \[The meaning\], however, \[is this: How much more a man would pay for\] a virgin slave than[^fn_40b_25] for a non-virgin slave[^fn_40b_25] for the purpose of marrying her to his bondman. But even if 'to his bondman', what difference does this[^fn_40b_27] make to him? — \[We are dealing here\] with a bondman who gives his master satisfaction.[^fn_40b_28]

***MISHNAH***. WHEREVER THE RIGHT OF SALE APPLIES NO FINE IS INCURRED[^fn_40b_29] AND WHEREVER A FINE IS INCURRED NO RIGHT OF SALE APPLIES. IN THE CASE OF A MINOR THE RIGHT OF SALE[^fn_40b_30] APPLIES BUT NO FINE[^fn_40b_31] IS INCURRED;[^fn_40b_32] IN THE CASE OF A DAMSEL[^fn_40b_33] A FINE IS INCURRED[^fn_40b_32] BUT NO RIGHT OF SALE[^fn_40b_30] APPLIES. TO A DAMSEL WHO IS ADOLESCENT[^fn_40b_34] THE RIGHT OF SALE DOES NOT APPLY NOR IS A FINE INCURRED THROUGH HER. {¶=3.7}

***GEMARA***. Rab Judah stated in the name of Rab: This[^fn_40b_35] is the ruling of R. Meir, but the Sages rule: A fine is incurred[^fn_40b_32] even where the right of sale[^fn_40b_36] applies. For it was taught: The right of sale[^fn_40b_36] applies to a minor from the age of one day until the time when she grows two hairs,[^fn_40b_37] but no fine is incurred through her.[^fn_40b_38] From the time she grows two hairs until she comes of age a fine is incurred through her but no right of sales applies; so R. Meir, because R. Meir has laid down: Wherever the right of sale applies no fine is incurred, and wherever a fine is incurred no right of sale applies. The Sages, however, ruled: Through a minor from the age of three years and one day until the time she becomes adolescent a fine is incurred.[^fn_40b_39] Only a fine \[you say\] but not the right of sale?[^fn_40b_40] — Read: A fine also where the right of sale applies.[^fn_40b_41]

R. Hisda said: What is R. Meir's reason?[^fn_40b_42] Scripture said, And unto him[^fn_40b_43] she shall be[^fn_40b_44] for a wife;[^fn_40b_45] the text thus speaks of a girl who may herself contract a marriage.[^fn_40b_46] And the Rabbis?[^fn_40b_47] Resh Lakish replied: Scripture said, na'ar[^fn_40b_48] which[^fn_40b_49] implies even a minor.[^fn_40b_50]

R. Papa the son of R. Hanan of Be Kelohith heard this[^fn_40b_51] and proceeded to report it before R. Shimi b. Ashi \[when the latter\] said to him: You apply it[^fn_40b_52] to that law; we apply it to the following: Resh Lakish ruled; A man who has brought an evil name[^fn_40b_53] upon a minor is exempt,[^fn_40b_54] for it is said in Scripture, And give them unto the father of the damsel,[^fn_40b_53] Scripture expressed the term na'arah[^fn_40b_55] as plenum.[^fn_40b_56]

R. Adda b. Ahabah demurred: Is the reason then[^fn_40b_57] because the All-Merciful has written na'arah, but otherwise it would have been said that even a minor \[was included\], surely \[it may be objected\] it is written in Scripture, But if this thing be true, and the tokens of virginity be not found in the damsel, then they shall bring out the damsel to the door of her father's house, and \[the men of her city\] shall stone her,[^fn_40b_58] while a minor is not, is she, subject to punishment?[^fn_40b_59] — \[The explanation,\] however, \[is that since\] na'arah \[has been written\] here[^fn_40b_60] \[it may be inferred that here only is a minor excluded\] but wherever Scripture uses the expression of na'ar even a minor is included. [pg 41a]

***MISHNAH***. HE WHO DECLARES, 'I HAVE SEDUCED THE DAUGHTER OF SO-AND-SO' MUST PAY COMPENSATION FOR INDIGNITY AND BLEMISH ON HIS OWN EVIDENCE BUT NEED NOT PAY THE STATUTORY FINE.[^fn_41a_1] {¶=3.8}

HE WHO DECLARES, 'I HAVE STOLEN' MUST MAKE RESTITUTION FOR THE PRINCIPAL ON HIS OWN EVIDENCE BUT NEED NOT REPAY DOUBLE,[^fn_41a_2] FOURFOLD[^fn_41a_3] OR FIVEFOLD.[^fn_41a_3]

\[HE WHO STATES,\] 'MY OX HAS KILLED SO-AND-SO' OR 'THE OX OF SO-AND-SO' MUST MAKE RESTITUTION[^fn_41a_4] ON HIS OWN EVIDENCE. \[IF HE, HOWEVER, SAID.\] 'MY OX HAS KILLED THE BONDMAN OF SO-AND-SO'[^fn_41a_5] HE NEED NOT MAKE RESTITUTION ON HIS OWN EVIDENCE.[^fn_41a_6]

THIS IS THE GENERAL RULE: WHOEVER PAYS MORE THAN THE ACTUAL COST OF THE DAMAGE HE HAS DONE[^fn_41a_7] NEED NOT PAY IT ON HIS OWN EVIDENCE.

***GEMARA***. Why did not he[^fn_41a_8] include 'I have violated'?[^fn_41a_9] — He implied that this was unnecessary: It was unnecessary \[to state that if a man declared,\] 'I have violated', in which case he casts no reflection on the girl's character,[^fn_41a_10] that he must pay compensation for indignity and blemish on his own evidence,[^fn_41a_11] but \[if a man declared.\] 'I HAVE SEDUCED', in which case he does cast a reflection on her character,[^fn_41a_12] it might have been assumed that he does not pay \[such compensation\] on his own evidence,[^fn_41a_13] hence he informs us \[that he does\].

Our Mishnah does not agree with the following Tanna. For it was taught: R. Simeon b. Judah stated in the name of R. Simeon, \[Compensation for\] indignity and blemish also a man does not pay on his own evidence[^fn_41a_14] because he[^fn_41a_15] cannot be trusted[^fn_41a_16] to tarnish the character of another man's daughter.

Said R. Papa to Abaye: What \[is the ruling if\] she is satisfied?[^fn_41a_17] — It is possible that her father might not be satisfied. And what if her father also is satisfied? — It is possible that the members of her family might not be satisfied. What if the members of her family are also satisfied? — It is impossible that there should not be one somewhere[^fn_41a_18] who is not satisfied.

HE WHO DECLARES, 'I HAVE STOLEN' MUST MAKE RESTITUTION FOR THE PRINCIPAL etc. It was stated: \[In respect of liability for\] half damages.[^fn_41a_19] R. Papa ruled: It is a civil obligation,[^fn_41a_20] but R. Huna the son of R. Joshua ruled: It is penal.[^fn_41a_21] 'R. Papa ruled: It is a civil obligation', for he is of the opinion that cattle as a rule[^fn_41a_22] cannot be presumed to be safe.[^fn_41a_23] Justice, therefore, demands that the owner should make full restitution,[^fn_41a_24] but the All-Merciful has shown mercy towards him[^fn_41a_25] because his cattle have not yet become *mu'ad*.[^fn_41a_26] 'R. Huna the son of R. Joshua ruled: It is penal', for he is of the opinion that cattle as a rule are presumed to be safe.[^fn_41a_27] Justice. therefore, demands that the owner should make no restitution at all,[^fn_41a_28] but it was Divine Law[^fn_41a_29] that imposed a fine upon him in order that he should exercise special care over his cattle.[^fn_41a_30]

(Mnemonic:[^fn_41a_31] He damaged what, and killed a general rule.)

We have learned: The plaintiff and the defendant[^fn_41a_32] are involved[^fn_41a_33] in the payment.[^fn_41a_34] Now according to him who holds that liability for half damages is a civil obligation[^fn_41a_35] it is perfectly correct \[to say\] that the plaintiff is involved in the payment,[^fn_41a_36] but according to him who maintains that liability for half damages is penal \[it may well be asked:\] If he receives that which \[in strict justice\] is not his due how can he be involved[^fn_41a_37] in the payment?[^fn_41a_38] — It[^fn_41a_39] may apply[^fn_41a_40] only to \[a loss caused by\] a decrease in the value of the carcass.[^fn_41a_41] \[But have we not\] already learned elsewhere \[about\] the decrease in the value of the carcass? 'To compensate for the damage'[^fn_41a_42] means that the owner[^fn_41a_43] must dispose of the carcass?[^fn_41a_44] — One \[of the statements deals\] with a *tam*[^fn_41a_45] and the other with a *mu'ad*.[^fn_41a_45] And \[both statements are\] required. For if \[that relating to\] a *tam* only had been made it might have been presumed \[to apply to that alone\] because the animal has not yet become *mu'ad* but not to a *mu'ad* since \[in the latter case the owner\] has been duly warned. And if \[only the statement relating to\] a *mu'ad* had been made it might have been assumed \[to apply to that case alone\] because the owner pays full compensation[^fn_41a_46] but not \[to that of\] a *tam*.[^fn_41a_47] \[Both rulings were consequently\] required.

Come and hear: What is the difference \[in the case of compensation for damages\] between a *tam*[^fn_41a_45] and a *mu'ad*?[^fn_41a_45] — In the case of a *tam* half damages are paid out of its own body,[^fn_41a_48] while in the case of a *mu'ad* full compensation is paid out of the best of the \[defendant's\] estate.[^fn_41a_49] Now if[^fn_41a_50] it were the case \[that liability for half damage[^fn_41a_51] is penal\] why was it not also stated[^fn_41a_52] that in the case of a *tam* no compensation is paid merely on one's own evidence[^fn_41a_53] whereas in the case of a *mu'ad*[^fn_41a_54] compensation is paid even on one's own[^fn_41a_55] evidence?[^fn_41a_56] — He[^fn_41a_57] recorded \[some distinctions\][^fn_41a_58] and omitted others. What \[else, however\], did he omit \[that should justify the assumption\] that he omitted this distinction also.[^fn_41a_59] — He omitted \[also the payment of\] half *kofer*.[^fn_41a_60] If \[the only point not mentioned\] is that of[^fn_41a_61] half *kofer* it is no omission, [pg 41b]

since that \[Mishnah\] may represent the view of[^fn_41b_1] R. Jose the Galilean who ruled that \[in the case of\] a *tam* half *kofer* is paid.[^fn_41b_2]

Come and hear: \[A MAN WHO SAID.\] 'MY OX KILLED SO-AND-SO' OR 'THE OX OF SO-AND-SO MUST PAY COMPENSATION ON HIS OWN EVIDENCE. Now does not \[this statement deal\] with a *tam*?[^fn_41b_3] — No; with a *mu'ad*. What, however, \[would be the law\] in the case of a *tam*? Would no liability be established by one's own evidence? Then instead of stating in the final clause, '… THE BONDMAN OF SO-AND-SO HE NEED NOT MAKE RESTITUTION ON HIS OWN EVIDENCE, could not a distinction have been drawn in the very same case, thus: 'This[^fn_41b_4] applies only to a *mu'ad* but in respect of a *tam* no liability is incurred by one's own evidence'? — The entire \[Mishnah prefers to\] deal with a *mu'ad*.[^fn_41b_5]

Come and hear: THIS IS THE GENERAL RULE: WHOSOEVER PAYS MORE THAN THE ACTUAL COST OF THE DAMAGE HE HAS DONE NEED NOT PAY ON HIS OWN EVIDENCE, from which it follows,[^fn_41b_6] \[does it not, that if the payment is\] less than the cost of the damage,[^fn_41b_7] one must pay compensation even on one's own evidence?[^fn_41b_8] Do not infer: '\[But if payment is\] less than the cost of the damage \[one must pay … on one's own evidence\]',[^fn_41b_7] but infer: '\[If payment\] corresponds to the actual amount of the damage one must pay compensation even on one's own evidence'. What, however, \[would be the law if payment were\] less than the amount of the damage?[^fn_41b_9] Would no liability be established by one's own evidence? Then[^fn_41b_10] why was it not stated, 'This is the general rule: Whoever does not pay an amount corresponding to the actual cost of the damage he has done pays no compensation on his own evidence', which would imply \[that where compensation is\] less or more[^fn_41b_11] \[it is to be paid on one's own evidence\]?[^fn_41b_12] — This is indeed a refutation.[^fn_41b_13]

The law, however, \[is that the liability for\] half damage is penal. 'A refutation' \[of a ruling\][^fn_41b_14] and \[yet it is\] the law? — Yes; for the sole basis of the refutation[^fn_41b_15] was that[^fn_41b_16] the statement[^fn_41b_17] did not run, '\[whoever does not pay an amount\] corresponding to the actual cost of the damage he has done'; \[but such a principle\][^fn_41b_18] was not regarded by him[^fn_41b_19] as exactly accurate, since there is the liability for half damages \[in the case of the damage done by\] pebbles[^fn_41b_20] Concerning which there is an halachic tradition that the liability is civil.[^fn_41b_21] On account of this consideration he did not adopt \[the form of the expression suggested\].

Now that you have laid down that liability for half damage is penal, the case of a dog that devoured lambs or that of a cat that devoured big hens is one of unusual occurrence[^fn_41b_22] and no distress is executed in Babylon.[^fn_41b_23] If, however, they[^fn_41b_24] were small the occurrence is a usual[^fn_41b_25] one and distress is executed.[^fn_41b_26] Should the plaintiff,[^fn_41b_26] however, seize \[the chattels of the defendant\][^fn_41b_27] they are not to be taken away from him.[^fn_41b_28] Furthermore, if[^fn_41b_29] he pleads. 'Fix for me a date \[by which the defendant must come with me\] to the Land of Israel,'[^fn_41b_30] such date must be fixed for him, and if \[the defendant\] does not go with him he must be placed under the ban. In any case,[^fn_41b_31] however, \[the defendant\] is to be placed under the ban;[^fn_41b_32] for he is told, 'Abate your nuisance', in accordance with a dictum of R. Nathan. For it was taught:[^fn_41b_33] R. Nathan said, Whence is it derived that a man may not breed a bad dog in his house nor place a shaking ladder in his house? \[From Scripture\] where it is said, That thou bring not blood upon thine house.[^fn_41b_34]

## CHAPTER IV

***MISHNAH***. IF A GIRL[^fn_41b_35] WAS SEDUCED \[THE COMPENSATION FOR\] HER INDIGNITY AND BLEMISH AS WELL AS THE STATUTORY FINE BELONG TO HER FATHER[^fn_41b_36] \[TO WHOM BELONGS ALSO THE COMPENSATION FOR\] PAIN IN THE CASE OF ONE WHO WAS VIOLATED. {¶=4.1}

IF THE GIRL'S ACTION WAS TRIED[^fn_41b_37] BEFORE HER FATHER DIED \[ALL THE FORMS OF COMPENSATION\] ARE DUE TO HER FATHER,[^fn_41b_38] IF HER FATHER \[SUBSEQUENTLY\] DIED THEY ARE DUE TO HER BROTHERS.[^fn_41b_39] IF HER FATHER, HOWEVER, DIED BEFORE HER ACTION WAS TRIED THEY[^fn_41b_40] ARE DUE TO HER.[^fn_41b_41] IF HER ACTION WAS TRIED BEFORE SHE BECAME ADOLESCENT[^fn_41b_42] \[ALL FORMS OF COMPENSATION\] ARE DUE TO HER FATHER; IF HER FATHER \[SUBSEQUENTLY\] DIED[^fn_41b_43] THEY ARE DUE TO HER BROTHERS.[^fn_41b_39] IF, HOWEVER, SHE BECAME ADOLESCENT BEFORE HER ACTION COULD BE TRIED THEY ARE DUE TO HER.[^fn_41b_44] R. SIMEON RULED.' IF HER FATHER DIED,[^fn_41b_45] BEFORE SHE COULD COLLECT \[THE DUES\] THEY BELONG TO HER.[^fn_41b_46] [pg 42a]

HER HANDIWORK, HOWEVER, AND ANYTHING SHE FINDS EVEN IF SHE HAD NOT COLLECTED \[THE PROCEEDS\]. BELONG TO HER BROTHERS IF HER FATHER DIED.[^fn_42a_1]

***GEMARA***. What \[new law\] does he teach us?[^fn_42a_2] Have we not \[already\] learned: The seducer pays three forms \[of compensation\] and the violator four. The seducer pays compensation for indignity and blemish as well as the statutory fine, and the violator pays an additional \[form of compensation\] in that he pays for the pain?[^fn_42a_3] — It was necessary \[to teach us[^fn_42a_2] that the compensation is due\] TO HER FATHER.[^fn_42a_4] \[But\] that \[the compensation is due\] to her father is also obvious, since a seducer has to pay for it? For if \[it were to be given\] to herself \[the objection could be raised\], why should the seducer pay \[to her when\] he acted with her consent?[^fn_42a_5] — It was necessary \[to tell us[^fn_42a_2] of the case where\] HER ACTION WAS TRIED \[which is a point in\] dispute between R. Simeon and the Rabbis.[^fn_42a_6]

We have learned elsewhere: \[If a man said to another\] 'You have violated or seduced my daughter', and the other replied. 'I did not violate or seduce her'. 'I adjure you' \[said the first\] and the other responded. 'Amen', but afterwards admitted his guilt, he is liable.[^fn_42a_7] R. Simeon, however, exempts him, for no fine is paid on one's own admission.[^fn_42a_8] They,[^fn_42a_9] however, said to him: Though no man pays a fine on his own admission he nevertheless pays compensation for indignity and blemish[^fn_42a_10] on his own admission.[^fn_42a_11]

Abaye enquired of Rabbah:[^fn_42a_12] What is the law according to R. Simeon[^fn_42a_13] where a man said to another, 'You have violated or seduced my daughter, and I have brought you to law and you were ordered to pay me \[a stipulated sun, of\] money' and the other replied. 'I have neither violated nor seduced her, nor have you brought me to law nor have I been ordered to pay you any money', and after he had taken an oath[^fn_42a_14] he admitted his guilt? Is \[his liability\], since his action had been tried,[^fn_42a_15] civil[^fn_42a_16] and he consequently incurs thereby a sacrifice for \[having taken a false\] oath, or is it possible that, though his action had been tried, his liability[^fn_42a_17] is still regarded as penal?[^fn_42a_18] — The other replied: It is a civil liability and he incurs thereby the obligation to bring a sacrifice for a false oath.[^fn_42a_19]

He[^fn_42a_20] pointed out to him[^fn_42a_21] the following objection: R. Simeon, said, As it might have been presumed that if a man said to another, 'You have violated or seduced my daughter' and the other replied 'I have neither violated nor seduced her', \[or if the first said\]. 'Your ox has killed my bondman' and the other replied, 'He did not kill him', or if a bondman said to his master,[^fn_42a_22] 'You have knocked out my tooth' or 'You have blinded my eye'.[^fn_42a_23] and he replied. 'I have not knocked it out' or 'I have not blinded it' and \[the defendant\] took the oath[^fn_42a_24] but afterwards admitted his liability it might have been presumed that he is liable,[^fn_42a_25] hence It was explicitly stated in Scripture, And he deal falsely with his neighbour[^fn_42a_23] a matter of deposit, or of pledge, or of robbery, or have oppressed his neighbour; or have found that which was lost, and deal falsely therein, and swear to a lie,[^fn_42a_26] as these are distinguished by the characteristics of being civil cases so must all \[other cases where similar liabilities[^fn_42a_27] may be incurred be distinguished by the characteristics\] of being civil. These, therefore, are excluded \[from liability\][^fn_42a_28] since they are penal. [pg 42b]

Does not \[this ruling refer to a man\] whose action had already been tried?[^fn_42b_1] — No, \[it deals\] with one whose action had not yet been tried.[^fn_42b_2] But, surely, since the first clause deals with the case of a man whose action had been tried, would not the final clause also deal with such a case? For in the first clause it was stated: 'I only knew \[that liability[^fn_42b_3] is incurred in\] cases where compensation is paid for the actual value only, whence, however, is it deduced that \[such liability is also incurred in\] cases where the payment is double,[^fn_42b_4] fourfold[^fn_42b_5] or fivefold[^fn_42b_5] and \[in those of\] the violator, the seducer and the calumniator?[^fn_42b_6] From Scripture which explicitly stated, And commit a trespass,[^fn_42b_7] \[implying that all such are\] included'. Now, how is this statement to be understood? If \[it is one referring to\] a man whose action had not yet been tried \[the objection could be raised:\] Is double compensation payable in such circumstances?[^fn_42b_8] It is obvious, therefore, that \[the reference is to one\] whose action had already been tried. And since the first clause deals with one whose action had been tried, the final clause also must deal, must it not, with one whose action had already been tried?[^fn_42b_9] — The other replied: I could have answered you that the first clause deals with one whose action had already been tried, and the final clause with one whose action had not yet been tried and that the entire Baraitha represents the view of R. Simeon, but I would not give you forced interpretations, for, were I to do so, you might retort: Then either the first clause should begin with 'R. Simeon said' or the final clause should conclude with 'these are the words of R. Simeon'.[^fn_42b_10] The fact, however, is that the entire \[Baraitha\] refers to one whose action had already been tried, the first clause being the view of the Rabbis and the final clause that of R. Simeon, and I must agree with you in regard to the sacrifice for \[taking a false\] oath,[^fn_42b_11] for the All-Merciful has exempted him[^fn_42b_12] \[as may be deduced\] from \[the text\] And he deal falsely.[^fn_42b_13] When I, however, said, that 'It is a civil liability' \[I was only implying that a man had the right\] to transmit such a liability as an inheritance to his sons.[^fn_42b_14]

Again he[^fn_42b_15] raised an objection against him:[^fn_42b_16] R. SIMEON RULED, IF HER FATHER DIED BEFORE SHE COULD COLLECT \[HER DUES\] THEY BELONG TO HER. Now if you maintain \[that such compensation\] is a civil liability in respect of being transmitted as an inheritance to one's sons, why should the compensation belong to her? Should it not, in fact, belong to the brothers? — This subject, said Raba, both Rabbah and R. Joseph found difficult for twenty-two years[^fn_42b_17] and no solution was forthcoming. It was only when[^fn_42b_18] R. Joseph assumed the presidency of the academy[^fn_42b_19] that he solved it: There[^fn_42b_20] it is different \[from other penal liabilities\] because Scripture said, Then the man that lay with her shall give unto the damsel's father fifty \[*shekels* of\] silver[^fn_42b_21] \[which implies that\] the Torah has not conferred upon the father the right of possession before the money had actually been handed to him; when Rabbah, however, said, 'It is a civil liability in respect of being transmitted as an inheritance to his sons' he was referring to other penal liabilities.[^fn_42b_22] But then, in the case of a bondman it is written in Scripture, He shall give into their master thirty *shekels* of silver,[^fn_42b_23] would it here[^fn_42b_24] also \[be maintained that\] the Torah has not conferred upon the master the right of possession before the money had actually been handed to him? — The yitten[^fn_42b_25] cannot be compared[^fn_42b_26] with we-nathan.[^fn_42b_27] If so,[^fn_42b_28] \[instead of deducing the exemption from sacrifice\] from the Scriptural text, 'And he deal falsely',[^fn_42b_29] should not the deduction rather be made from 'Then … shall give'?[^fn_42b_30] — Raba replied: The text of 'And he deal falsely' was required in a case, for instance, where the girl's action had been tried and then she became adolescent[^fn_42b_31] and died, in which case[^fn_42b_32] when the father receives[^fn_42b_33] \[the fine\] he inherits \[it\] from her.[^fn_42b_34] If so,[^fn_42b_35] \[however, how could it be said:\] 'These, therefore, are excluded \[from liability\] since they are in fact penal' when they are in fact[^fn_42b_36] civil? — R. Nahman b. Isaac replied: \[The meaning is\], These are excluded since they were originally penal.

He[^fn_42b_37] pointed out to him[^fn_42b_38] another objection: R. Simeon, however. exempts him, for no fine is paid on ones own admission.[^fn_42b_39] The reason then[^fn_42b_40] is because his action had not been tried[^fn_42b_41] but if it had been tried,[^fn_42b_42] in which case he does pay,[^fn_42b_43] even on his own admission,[^fn_42b_44] he would incur. also, would he not, \[the obligation of bringing\] a sacrifice for swearing \[a false oath\]?[^fn_42b_45] — R. Simeon argues with the Rabbis on the lines of their own view. According to my own view \[he argued\] the All-Merciful has exempted the man[^fn_42b_46] even after he had been tried \[as may be deduced\] from the text 'And deal falsely'.[^fn_42b_47] According to your view, however, you must at least admit that \[the man is exempt\] if he has not yet been tried, since the claim advanced against him is penal [pg 43a]

and one who makes a voluntary admission in a penal case is exempt.[^fn_43a_1] But the Rabbis are of the opinion that the claim[^fn_43a_2] is \[mainly\] in respect of compensation for indignity and blemish.[^fn_43a_3] On what principle do they[^fn_43a_4] differ? — R. Papa replied: R. Simeon is of the opinion that a man would not leave that which is fixed[^fn_43a_5] to claim[^fn_43a_6] that which is not fixed,[^fn_43a_7] while the Rabbis hold the view that no man would leave a claim[^fn_43a_6] from which \[the defendant\] could not be exempt even if he made a voluntary admission[^fn_43a_8] and advance a claim[^fn_43a_9] from which he would be exempt[^fn_43a_10] if he made a voluntary admission.

R. Abina enquired of R. Shesheth: To whom belongs the handiwork of a daughter who[^fn_43a_11] is maintained[^fn_43a_12] by her brothers?[^fn_43a_13] Are they[^fn_43a_14] in loco parentis and as in that case her handiwork belongs to her father so here also it belongs to her brothers; or \[is it more reasonable that\] they should not be compared to their father, for in his case she is maintained out of his own estate but here she is not maintained out of their estate?[^fn_43a_15] — He replied: You have learned about such a case: A widow is to be maintained out of the estate of \[her deceased husband's\] orphans, and her handiwork belongs to them.[^fn_43a_16] \[But\] are \[the two cases in every way\] alike? It may not be any satisfaction to a man that his widow should be liberally provided for,[^fn_43a_17] but he might well be pleased, might he not, that his daughter should?[^fn_43a_18]

Does this[^fn_43a_19] imply that a man has preference for his daughter than for his widow? Surely. R. Abba said in the name of R. Jose:[^fn_43a_20] The relationship between[^fn_43a_21] a widow and her daughter, in the case of a small estate,[^fn_43a_22] has been put on the same level as that of the relationship between[^fn_43a_21] a daughter and her brothers. As in the case of the relationship between a daughter and her brothers, the daughter is maintained[^fn_43a_23] while the brothers can go begging at \[people's\] doors, so also in the case of the relationship between a widow and her daughter, the widow is maintained and the daughter can go begging at \[people's\] doors;[^fn_43a_24] \[which shews, does it not, that the widow is given preference\]? — As regards \[provision against\] degradation[^fn_43a_25] a man gives preference to his widow;[^fn_43a_26] as regards liberal provision[^fn_43a_27] he gives preference to his daughter.[^fn_43a_28]

R. Joseph objected: HER HANDIWORK, HOWEVER, AND ANYTHING SHE FINDS, EVEN IF SHE HAS NOT COLLECTED \[THE PROCEEDS\], BELONG TO HER BROTHERS IF HER FATHER DIED. The reason[^fn_43a_29] then is[^fn_43a_30] that \[they originated during\] the lifetime of their father, but \[if they originated\] after his death \[they would belong\] to herself. Does not \[this refer to a daughter\] who is maintained?[^fn_43a_31] — No; \[this is a case of one\] who is not maintained.[^fn_43a_32] If she is not maintained, what need is there to state \[such a case\]?[^fn_43a_33] For even according to him who ruled that a master is entitled to say to his bondman, 'Work for me and I will not maintain you'[^fn_43a_34] the ruling applies only to a Canaanite bondman concerning whom 'With thee' was not written in Scripture, but not to a Hebrew slave concerning whom with thee[^fn_43a_35] was written in Scripture. How much less \[then would such a ruling apply\] to one's daughter? — Rabbah b. 'Ulla replied: It[^fn_43a_36] was only required in the case of a surplus.[^fn_43a_37] 

Said Raba: Did not such a great man as R. Joseph know that \[sometimes there may\] be a surplus when he raised his objection?[^fn_43a_38] The fact however is, Raba explained, that R. Joseph raised his objection from our very Mishnah. For it was stated, HER HANDIWORK, HOWEVER, AND ANYTHING SHE FINDS, EVEN IF SHE HAS NOT COLLECTED \[THE PROCEEDS\]; but from whom \[it may be asked\] is she to collect anything she finds? Consequently it must be conceded that it is this that was meant: HER HANDIWORK is like ANYTHING SHE FINDS; as anything she finds belongs to her father[^fn_43a_39] \[if she finds it\] during his lifetime, and to herself \[if she finds it\] after his death[^fn_43a_40] so also in the case of her handiwork, \[if it was done\] during the lifetime of her father it belongs to her father \[but if it was done\] after his death it belongs to herself. Thus it may be concluded \[that the ruling of R. Shesheth stands refuted\].[^fn_43a_41]

So it was also stated:[^fn_43a_42] Rab Judah ruled in the name of Rab, The handiwork of a daughter who is maintained by her brothers belongs to herself. Said R. Kahana: What is the reason? Because it is written in Scripture And ye make them an inheritance for your children after you,[^fn_43a_43] \[implying\]: 'them'[^fn_43a_44] \[you may make an inheritance\] 'for your children', but not your daughters for your children. This tells us that a man may not transmit his authority[^fn_43a_45] over his daughter to his son.[^fn_43a_46] To this Rabbah demurred: It might be suggested that the Scriptural text[^fn_43a_47] speaks of \[payments in connection with\] the seduction of one's daughter, fines and mayhem![^fn_43a_48] And so did R. Hanina learn: The Scriptural text[^fn_43a_47] speaks of \[payments in connection with\] the seduction of one's daughter, fines and mayhem![^fn_43a_49]

Is not mayhem injury involving bodily pain?[^fn_43a_50] — R. Jose b. Hanina replied: [pg 43b]

The wound \[may be supposed to\] have been made in her face.[^fn_43b_1]

Rab[^fn_43b_2] Zera stated in the name of R. Mattena who had it from Rab: (others assert \[that it was\] Rabbi[^fn_43b_2] Zera who stated in the name of R. Mattena who had it from Rab): The handiwork of a daughter who is maintained by her brothers belongs to herself, for it is written in Scripture, And ye make them an inheritance for your children after you[^fn_43b_3] \[implying\]: 'Them'[^fn_43b_4] \[you may make an inheritance\] 'for your children', but not your daughters for your children. This tells us that a man may not transmit his authority over his daughter to his son.[^fn_43b_5]

Said Abimi b. Papi to him: Shakud[^fn_43b_6] made this statement.[^fn_43b_7] Who is Shakud? — Samuel. But, surely, was it not Rab who made this statement? — Read: Shakud also made this statement.

Mar the son of Amemar said to R. Ashi, Thus the Nehardeans have laid down: The law is in agreement with the ruling of R. Shesheth.[^fn_43b_8]

R. Ashi \[however\] said: The law is in agreement with Rab.[^fn_43b_9] And the law is to be decided in agreement with the view of Rab.

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN GAVE HIS DAUGHTER[^fn_43b_10] IN BETROTHAL AND SHE WAS DIVORCED, \[AND THEN\] HE GAVE HER \[AGAIN\] IN BETROTHAL AND SHE WAS LEFT A WIDOW, HER *KETHUBAH*[^fn_43b_11] BELONGS TO HIM.[^fn_43b_12] IF HE GAVE HER IN MARRIAGE AND SHE WAS DIVORCED \[AND THEN\] HE GAVE HER \[AGAIN\] IN MARRIAGE AND SHE WAS LEFT A WIDOW, HER *KETHUBAH*[^fn_43b_13] BELONGS TO HER.[^fn_43b_14] R. JUDAH SAID: THE FIRST[^fn_43b_15] BELONGS TO HER FATHER.[^fn_43b_16] THEY,[^fn_43b_17] HOWEVER, SAID TO HIM: HER FATHER, AS SOON[^fn_43b_18] AS HE GIVES HER IN MARRIAGE, LOSES ALL CONTROL OVER HER.[^fn_43b_19] {¶=4.2}

***GEMARA***. The[^fn_43b_20] reason[^fn_43b_21] is that when HE GAVE HER IN MARRIAGE \[the first time\] SHE WAS DIVORCED \[and that when\] HE GAVE HER \[AGAIN\] IN MARRIAGE, SHE WAS LEFT A WIDOW \[for the first time\],[^fn_43b_22] but if she had been left a widow twice[^fn_43b_23] she would not have been fit to marry again. The Tanna[^fn_43b_24] has thus indirectly laid down an anonymous ruling in agreement with Rabbi who holds that if \[a thing has happened\] twice presumption is established.[^fn_43b_25]

R. JUDAH SAID: THE FIRST BELONGS TO HER FATHER. What is R. Judah's reason? — Both Rabbah and R. Joseph explained: Since her father has acquired the right to it[^fn_43b_26] at the time of the betrothal.[^fn_43b_27] Raba objected: 'R. Judah ruled that the first[^fn_43b_28] belonged to her father; R. Judah nevertheless admitted that if a father gave his daughter in betrothal while she was still a minor and she married after she had attained adolescence he has no authority over her'.[^fn_43b_29] But why? Might it not here also be argued,[^fn_43b_30] 'Since her father has acquired the right to it at the time of the betrothal'?[^fn_43b_31] The fact, however, is that if any statement \[in the nature mentioned\] has at all been made it must have been made in the following terms:[^fn_43b_32] Both Rabbah and R. Joseph explained: Because it[^fn_43b_33] was written while she was still under his authority.[^fn_43b_34]

As to the recovery \[of a *kethubah*\],[^fn_43b_35] from which date may distraint be effected?[^fn_43b_36] — R. Huna replied: The hundred[^fn_43b_37] or the two hundred[^fn_43b_38] from the date of the betrothal[^fn_43b_39] and the additional jointure[^fn_43b_40] from that of the marriage.[^fn_43b_41] R. Assi, however, replied: The former as well as the latter \[may be distrained upon only\] from the date of the marriage.[^fn_43b_42]

But could R. Huna, however, have given such a ruling?[^fn_43b_43] Has it not been stated: If a wife produced against her husband two *kethuboth*, one for two hundred, and one for three hundred *zuz*, she may, said R. Huna, distrain from the earlier date if she wishes to collect the two hundred *zuz* \[but if she desires to collect the\] three hundred *zuz* she may distrain from the later date only. Now if the ruling were as stated[^fn_43b_44] she should be entitled, should she not, to distrain to the extent of two hundred *zuz* from the earlier date and to that of one hundred from the later date? — But \[even\] according to your conception \[it might equally be objected why\] should she \[not\] distrain for all the five hundred *zuz*, two hundred from the earlier date and three hundred from the later date? What then is the reason why she cannot distrain for all the five hundred? \[Obviously this:\] Since the man did not write in her favour,[^fn_43b_45] 'I willingly added to your credit three hundred *zuz* to the two hundred' he must have meant to imply: 'If you desired to distrain from the earlier date you would recover \[no more than\] two hundred, and if you desired to distrain from the later date you would receive three hundred'. [pg 44a]

Here also[^fn_44a_1] \[it may similarly be said:\] This is the reason why she cannot distrain \[for the additional jointure from the earlier date\]: Since he did not write in her favour, 'I have added a hundred *zuz* to the two hundred'[^fn_44a_2] she \[having accepted the deed\] must have renounced her former lien.[^fn_44a_3]

The Master[^fn_44a_4] has laid down that if she wishes she may distrain with the earlier kethubahs and if she prefers she may distrain with the later one.[^fn_44a_5] Is it then to be assumed \[that this ruling\] differs from that of R. Nahman who laid down that if two deeds[^fn_44a_6] were issued one after the other the latter cancels the former?[^fn_44a_7] — \[No, for\] has it not been stated in connection with this statement that R. Papa said: R. Nahman nevertheless admits that if the man has added[^fn_44a_8] one palm[^fn_44a_9] the insertion was intended as an additional privilege?[^fn_44a_10] And here also, Surely, \[the husband\] has added something.[^fn_44a_11]

\[To turn to\] the original text.[^fn_44a_12] R. Nahman laid down that if two deeds were issued one after the other the latter cancels the former. Said R. Papa: R. Nahman nevertheless admits that if the man has added one palm the insertion was intended as an additional privilege.[^fn_44a_13] It is obvious \[that the reason why both deeds are valid where\] the first \[was a deed\] of sale and the second \[a deed\] of gift[^fn_44a_14] \[is because the action of the owner\] was intended[^fn_44a_15] to improve the other's rights,[^fn_44a_16] as a safeguard against[^fn_44a_17] the law of pre-emption;[^fn_44a_18] and much more \[is this[^fn_44a_19] obvious where\] the first was for a gift and the second for a sale, for it may then be presumed that the latter was written in that manner in order to safeguard the other against a creditor's rights.[^fn_44a_20] \[What\], however, \[is the reason why\] the second cancels the first where both deeds[^fn_44a_21] were for a sale or both for a gift? — Rafram replied: Because it may be presumed that \[the holder of the deeds\] has admitted to the other \[the invalidity of the first deed\].[^fn_44a_22] R. Aha replied: Because it might be presumed that \[the holder of the deeds\] has surrendered his security of tenure.[^fn_44a_23] What is the practical issue between them?[^fn_44a_24] — The disqualification of the witnesses,[^fn_44a_25] payment of compensation for unsufruct[^fn_44a_26] and land tax.[^fn_44a_27]

What is \[the decision\] in respect of the *kethubah*?[^fn_44a_28] — Come and hear what Rab Judah laid down in the name of Samuel who had it from R. Eleazar the son of R. Simeon:[^fn_44a_29] \[The statutory *kethubah* of\] a *maneh*[^fn_44a_30] or two hundred *zuz*[^fn_44a_31] \[may be distrained for\] from \[the date of\] the betrothal but the additional jointure only from the date of the marriage. The Sages, however, ruled: The one as well as the other \[may be distrained for only\] from the date of the marriage. The law is that the one as well as the other \[may be distrained only\] from the date of the marriage.

***MISHNAH***. THE DAUGHTER OF A PROSELYTE WOMAN WHO BECAME A PROSELYTE TOGETHER WITH HER MOTHER[^fn_44a_32] AND THEN[^fn_44a_33] PLAYED THE HARLOT IS SUBJECT TO THE PENALTY[^fn_44a_34] OF STRANGULATION,[^fn_44a_35] BUT NOT TO[^fn_44a_36] \[STONING AT\] THE DOOR OF HER FATHER'S HOUSE[^fn_44a_37] NOR \[DOES HER HUSBAND PAY THE\] HUNDRED *SELA'*.[^fn_44a_38] IF SHE WAS CONCEIVED IN UNHOLINESS[^fn_44a_39] BUT HER BIRTH WAS IN HOLINESS[^fn_44a_40] SHE IS SUBJECT TO THE PENALTY OF STONING BUT NOT TO[^fn_44a_36] \[THAT OF BRINGING HER OUT TO 'THE DOOR OF HER FATHER'S HOUSE', NOR \[DOES HER HUSBAND PAY THE\] HUNDRED *SELA'*. IF SHE WAS BOTH CONCEIVED AND BORN IN HOLINESS[^fn_44a_40] SHE IS REGARDED AS A DAUGHTER OF ISRAEL IN ALL RESPECTS.[^fn_44a_41]  {¶=4.3}

ONE[^fn_44a_42] WHO HAD A FATHER BUT NO DOOR OF HER FATHER'S HOUSE',[^fn_44a_43] OR A 'DOOR OF HER FATHER'S HOUSE' BUT NO FATHER, IS NEVERTHELESS SUBJECT TO THE PENALTY[^fn_44a_44] OF STONING,[^fn_44a_45] \[FOR THE REGULATION, 'TO\] THE DOOR OF HER FATHER'S HOUSE',[^fn_44a_46] WAS ONLY INTENDED AS \[AN INDEPENDENT\] PRECEPT.[^fn_44a_47] [pg 44b]

***GEMARA***. Whence is this[^fn_44b_1] deduced? — Resh Lakish replied: Since Scripture said, That she die[^fn_44b_2] it[^fn_44b_3] included also her who WAS CONCEIVED IN UNHOLINESS BUT HER BIRTH WAS IN HOLINESS: If so, \[should not her wrongful accuser\][^fn_44b_4] also be flogged[^fn_44b_5] and \[condemned\] to pay the hundred *sela'*?[^fn_44b_6] Scripture stated, That she die[^fn_44b_7] \[implying that she\] was included in respect of death but not in respect of the fine.

Might it not be suggested \[that Scripture intended\] to include one who was both conceived and born in holiness? — Such a person is a proper Israelite woman.[^fn_44b_8] But can it not be said that \[Scripture intended\] to include one conceived and born in unholiness? — If this were so what purpose would be served[^fn_44b_9] by the expression,[^fn_44b_10] 'In Israel'?[^fn_44b_11]

R. Jose b. Hanina ruled: A man who brought an evil name upon an orphan girl is exempt, for it is said in Scripture, And give them unto the father of the damsel,[^fn_44b_12] Which excludes this girl who has no 'father'.

R. Jose b. Abin, or it might be said, R. Jose b. Zebida, raised an objection: If her father utterly refuse[^fn_44b_13] \[was meant\][^fn_44b_14] to include an orphan girl in respect of the fine;[^fn_44b_15] so R. Jose the Galilean.[^fn_44b_16] \[Why then should the orphan in this case[^fn_44b_17] be excluded\]? — He raised the objection and he himself supplied the answer: \[This[^fn_44b_18] is a case of a girl\] who became an orphan after the man had intercourse with her.[^fn_44b_19]

Rabbah[^fn_44b_20] ruled: He[^fn_44b_21] is guilty. Whence \[did he infer this\]? — From that which Ammi taught: A virgin of Israel,[^fn_44b_22] but not a proselyte virgin.[^fn_44b_23] Now if you assume that in a case of this nature[^fn_44b_24] in Israel[^fn_44b_25] guilt is incurred, one can well see why it was necessary for a Scriptural text to exclude proselytes. If you, however, assume that in a case of this nature in Israel[^fn_44b_25] \[the offender\] is exempt \[the difficulty would arise:\] Now \[that we know that the offender\] is exempt \[even if he sinned\] against Israelites[^fn_44b_25] was it any longer necessary \[to mention exemption if the offence was\] against proselytes?[^fn_44b_26]

Resh Lakish ruled: A man who has brought an evil name[^fn_44b_27] upon a minor is exempt,[^fn_44b_28] for it is said in Scripture, And give them unto the father of the damsel,[^fn_44b_29] Scripture expressed the term na'arah[^fn_44b_30] as plenum.[^fn_44b_31] To this R. Aha[^fn_44b_32] b. Abba[^fn_44b_33] demurred: Is the reason then[^fn_44b_34] because in this case 'the na'arah'[^fn_44b_35] was written \[in Scripture\], but otherwise it would have been said that even a minor \[was included\], surely, \[it may be objected\] it is written in Scripture, But if the things be true, and the tokens of virginity be not found in the damsel, then they shall bring out the damsel to the door of her father's house and \[the men of the city\] shall stone her,[^fn_44b_36] while a minor is not, is she, subject to punishment?[^fn_44b_37] — \[The explanation,\] however, \[is that, since\] na'arah \[has been written\] here[^fn_44b_38] \[it may be inferred that only where na'arah[^fn_44b_39] is used is a minor excluded\] but wherever Scripture uses the expression na'arah[^fn_44b_40] even a minor is included.[^fn_44b_41]

Shila taught: There are three modes \[of execution\] in the case of a \[betrothed\] damsel[^fn_44b_42] \[who played the harlot\]. If witnesses appeared against her in the house of her father-in-law[^fn_44b_43] \[testifying\] that she had played the harlot in her father's house[^fn_44b_44] [pg 45a]

she is stoned at the door of her father's house,[^fn_45a_1] as if to say,[^fn_45a_2] 'See the plant that you have reared'. If witnesses came \[to testify\] against her in her father's house that she played the harlot in his house she is stoned at the entrance of the gate of the city. If having committed the offence[^fn_45a_3] she eventually[^fn_45a_4] attained adolescence[^fn_45a_5] she is condemned to strangulation.[^fn_45a_6]

This[^fn_45a_7] then implies that wherever there occurred a change in one's person, one's mode of execution also must be changed. But is not this contradicted by the following: 'If a betrothed damsel[^fn_45a_8] played the harlot and \[her husband\] brought upon her an evil name[^fn_45a_9] after she had attained adolescence,[^fn_45a_10] he is neither to be flogged[^fn_45a_11] nor is he to pay the hundred *sela'*,[^fn_45a_12] but she and the witnesses who testified falsely against her[^fn_45a_13] are hurried[^fn_45a_14] to the place of stoning'?[^fn_45a_15] 'She and the witnesses who testified falsely against her'! Can this be imagined?[^fn_45a_16] — But \[this is the meaning:\] 'She[^fn_45a_17] or[^fn_45a_18] her witnesses[^fn_45a_19] are hurried[^fn_45a_14] to the place of stoning'?[^fn_45a_20] — Raba replied: You speak \[of the law relating to a husband\] who brought up an evil name; but this law is different \[from the others\],[^fn_45a_21] because it is an anomaly.[^fn_45a_22] For, elsewhere, if a girl[^fn_45a_23] entered the bridal chamber,[^fn_45a_24] though no intercourse followed, she is condemned to strangulation if she committed adultery, but \[a woman upon whom a husband\] brought an evil name is condemned to Stoning.[^fn_45a_25] Said R. Huna the son of R. Joshua to Raba: Is it not possible that the All-Merciful created the anomaly only where no constitutional change had taken place,[^fn_45a_26] but where a constitutional change had occurred[^fn_45a_27] the All-Merciful has created no anomaly?[^fn_45a_28] — The fact however is, explained R. Nahman b. Isaac, \[that the question whether a change in status\] involves, or does not involve a change \[in the penalty\] is \[a point in dispute between\] Tannaim. For we have learned: If they[^fn_45a_29] committed a sin before they were appointed \[to their respective offices\] and \[then\] were appointed, they are regarded[^fn_45a_30] as laymen. R. Simeon ruled: If their sin came to their knowledge before they were appointed[^fn_45a_31] they are liable,[^fn_45a_32] but if after they were appointed[^fn_45a_33] they are exempt.[^fn_45a_34] [pg 45b]

\[But\] is it not to be maintained that R. Simeon was heard to be guided by \[the time of\] the awareness also,[^fn_45b_1] did you, how ever, hear that he Was guided by \[the time of\] awareness alone and not also by that of the commission of sin? For were that so,[^fn_45b_2] should they[^fn_45b_3] not have brought an offering in accordance with their present status, the High Priest a bullock, and the ruler a he-goat?[^fn_45b_4] — Surely R. Johanan said to the Tanna:[^fn_45b_5] Read, 'She is to be condemned to stoning.'[^fn_45b_6]

But why?[^fn_45b_7] Did not the All-Merciful[^fn_45b_8] speak of a betrothed 'damsel'[^fn_45b_9] and this one is adolescent? — R. Elai replied: Scripture said, the damsel[^fn_45b_10] \[implying\] her who was a damsel[^fn_45b_9] before.[^fn_45b_11] Said R. Hanania to R. Elai: If so,[^fn_45b_12] should not \[the husband\] also be flogged and pay the hundred *sela'*?[^fn_45b_13] — 'May the All-Merciful', the other replied, 'save us from such an opinion'.[^fn_45b_14] 'On the contrary \[the first retorted\], may the All-Merciful save us from such an opinion as yours'. What, however, is the reason?[^fn_45b_15] — R. Isaac b. Abin, or, as some say, R. Isaac b. Abba, replied: In her case it was[^fn_45b_16] her behaviour that brought about her \[punishment\] but in his case it was is the inclination of his lips[^fn_45b_17] that brought about his \[penalties\]. 'In her case it was her behaviour that brought about her \[punishment\]' and when she played the harlot she was still a na'arah.[^fn_45b_18] 'But in his case it was the inclination of his lips that brought about his \[penalty\]'; and when does he incur his guilt? Obviously at that time,[^fn_45b_19] and at that time she Was already adolescent.

Our Rabbis taught: A betrothed damsel[^fn_45b_18] who played the harlot is to be stoned at 'the door of her father's house'.[^fn_45b_20] If she had no 'door of her father's house'[^fn_45b_21] she is stoned at the entrance of the gate of that city. But in a town which is mostly inhabited by idolaters she is stoned at[^fn_45b_22] the door of the court. Similarly you may say: A man who worships idols[^fn_45b_23] is to be stoned at the gate \[of the city\] where he worshipped, and in a city the majority of whose inhabitants are idolaters he is stoned at the door of the court.[^fn_45b_24]

Whence are these rulings derived? — From what our Rabbis have taught: \[By the expression\] thy gates[^fn_45b_25] \[was meant\] the gate \[of the city\] wherein the man has worshipped. You say, 'The gate \[of the city\] wherein the man has worshipped', might it not mean the gate where he is tried?[^fn_45b_26] — \[Since the expression\] 'thy gates' is used below[^fn_45b_27] and also above[^fn_45b_28] \[an analogy is to be made:\] As 'thy gates' mentioned above[^fn_45b_29] refers to the gate \[of the city\] wherein he worshipped[^fn_45b_30] so does 'thy bates' that was mentioned below[^fn_45b_27] refer to the gate \[of the city\] wherein the man had worshipped. Another interpretation: 'Thy gates',[^fn_45b_25] but not the gates of idolaters.[^fn_45b_31] \[As to\] that \[expression of\] 'thy gates', has not a deduction already been drawn from it?[^fn_45b_32] — If \[the purpose of the expression were only\] this deduction[^fn_45b_33] Scripture would have used the expression 'gate'; why thy gates'? Both deductions may, therefore, be made.

Thus we obtain \[rulings in respect of\] idolatry,[^fn_45b_34] whence do we \[derive the law in respect of\] a betrothed girl?[^fn_45b_35] R. Abbahu replied: 'Door'[^fn_45b_36] is inferred from 'door',[^fn_45b_37] and door[^fn_45b_37] from 'gate',[^fn_45b_38] and 'gate'[^fn_45b_37] from 'thy gates'.[^fn_45b_39]

Our Rabbis taught: \[A husband\] who brings up an evil name \[upon his wife\] is flogged[^fn_45b_40] and he must also pay a hundred *sela'*.[^fn_45b_41] R. Judah ruled: As to flogging, \[the husband is\] flogged in all circumstances; as to the hundred *sela'*, however, where he had intercourse with her[^fn_45b_42] he pays them but if he did not have intercourse with her[^fn_45b_43] he does not pay. They[^fn_45b_44] differ on the same principles as those on which R. Eliezer b. Jacob and the Rabbis differed,[^fn_45b_45] and it is this that \[each of the former group\] meant: \[A husband\] who brought an evil name \[upon his wife\] is flogged and he must also pay a hundred *sela'*, whether he had intercourse, or did not have intercourse with her, \[this being\] in agreement with the Rabbis.[^fn_45b_46] R. Judah ruled: As to flogging \[the husband is\] flogged in all circumstances;[^fn_45b_47] as to the hundred *sela'*, however, where he had intercourse with her he pays them but if he did not have intercourse with her he does not pay; in agreement with R. Eliezer b. Jacob.[^fn_45b_48]

Another reading.[^fn_45b_49] All the statement[^fn_45b_50] is in agreement with the opinion of R. Eliezer b. Jacob[^fn_45b_48] and it is this that \[each of the former group\][^fn_45b_51] meant: \[A husband\] who brought an evil name \[upon his wife\] is flogged and he must also pay the hundred *sela'* only where he had intercourse with her.[^fn_45b_52] R. Judah ruled: As to flogging, \[the husband is\] flogged in all circumstances.[^fn_45b_53]

Can R. Judah, however, maintain that 'as to flogging, \[the husband\] is flogged in all circumstances' when it was taught: R. Judah ruled, If he had intercourse he is flogged but if he did not have intercourse he is not flogged? — R. Nahman b. Isaac replied: \[By the ruling of R. Judah that the husband\] 'is flogged'[^fn_45b_54] \[was meant\] chastisement[^fn_45b_55] which is a Rabbinical penalty.[^fn_45b_56] [pg 46a]

R. Papa replied: By the expression[^fn_46a_1] If he had intercourse he is flogged',[^fn_46a_2] which was used there,[^fn_46a_3] the monetary fine[^fn_46a_4] \[was meant\].[^fn_46a_5] But could one describe a monetary fine as 'flogging'? — Yes, and so indeed we have learned:[^fn_46a_6] If a man said, 'I vow to pay half of my valuation'[^fn_46a_7] he most pay half of his valuation. R. Jose the son of R. Judah ruled: He is flogged[^fn_46a_8] and must pay his full valuation. \[And in reply to the question,\] why should he be flogged? R. Papa explained: He is 'flogged'[^fn_46a_8] by \[having to pay his\] full valuation.[^fn_46a_9] What is the reason?[^fn_46a_10] — \[The ruling[^fn_46a_10] in the case of a vow for\] a half of one's valuation[^fn_46a_11] is a preventive measure against the possibility \[of a vow for\] the value of half of one's body,[^fn_46a_12] such a half[^fn_46a_13] being an organic part[^fn_46a_14] on which one's life depends.[^fn_46a_15]

Our Rabbis taught: *And they shall fine him*[^fn_46a_16] refers to[^fn_46a_17] a monetary fine; *And chastise him*[^fn_46a_18] refers to[^fn_46a_17] flogging. One can readily understand why *'And they shall fine'* refers to a monetary payment since it is written, *'And they shall fine him a hundred *shekels* of silver and give them unto the father of the damsel'*;[^fn_46a_19] whence, however, is it deduced that *'And chastise him'* refers to flogging? — R. Abbahu replied: We deduce *'Shall chastise'*[^fn_46a_18] from *'Shall chastise'*,[^fn_46a_20] and *'Shall chastise'*[^fn_46a_20] from *'Son'*,[^fn_46a_21] and '*Son*'[^fn_46a_21] from '*Son*'[^fn_46a_22] \[occurring in the Scriptural text:\] *Then it shall be, if the wicked man deserve[^fn_46a_23] to be beaten*.[^fn_46a_24]

Whence is the warning[^fn_46a_25] against bringing up an evil name \[upon one's wife\] deduced? R. Eleazar replied: From *Thou shalt not go up and dawn as a talebearer*.[^fn_46a_26] R. Nathan replied: From Then thou shalt keep thee[^fn_46a_27] from every evil thing.[^fn_46a_28] What is the reason that R. Eleazar does not make his deduction[^fn_46a_29] from the latter[^fn_46a_30] text?[^fn_46a_28] — That text[^fn_46a_28] he requires for \[the same deduction\] as \[that made by\] R. Phinehas b. Jair: From the text,[^fn_46a_31] Then thou shalt keep thee from every evil thing;[^fn_46a_28] R. Phinehas b. Jair deduced[^fn_46a_29] that a man should not indulge in \[morbid\] thoughts by day that might lead him to uncleanness by night.[^fn_46a_32] What then is the reason why R. Nathan does not make his deduction from the former[^fn_46a_33] text?[^fn_46a_34] — That text[^fn_46a_34] is a warning to the court that it must not be lenient with one[^fn_46a_35] \[of the litigants\] and harsh to the other.

If \[a husband\] did not tell the witnesses,[^fn_46a_36] 'Come and give evidence for me' and they volunteered to give it, he[^fn_46a_37] is not to be flogged nor is he to pay the hundred *sela'*.[^fn_46a_38] She, however, and the witnesses who testified falsely against her are hurried[^fn_46a_39] to the place of stoning. 'She and the witnesses who testified against her'! Can this be imagined? — But \[this is the meaning\]: 'She or her witnesses are hurried to the place of stoning.[^fn_46a_39] Now the reason then[^fn_46a_40] is because he did not even tell them \[to give their evidence\].[^fn_46a_41] Had he, however, told them \[he would have been subject to the prescribed penalties\][^fn_46a_42] even though he did not hire them. \[This ruling thus serves the purpose\] of excluding the view of R. Judah concerning whom it was taught: R. Judah ruled, \[a husband\] incurs no penalties[^fn_46a_42] unless he has hired the witnesses.[^fn_46a_43]

What is R. Judah's reason? R. Abbahu replied: An analogy is drawn between the two forms of the root 'to lay'.[^fn_46a_44] Here[^fn_46a_45] it is written, And lay[^fn_46a_46] wanton charges against her,[^fn_46a_47] and elsewhere it is written, Neither shall ye lay[^fn_46a_48] upon him interest,'[^fn_46a_49] as there[^fn_46a_49] \[the offence is committed through the giving of\] money[^fn_46a_50] so here \[also it can be committed only by the giving of\] money.[^fn_46a_51] R. Nahman b. Isaac said, and so did R. Joseph the Zidonian recite at the school[^fn_46a_52] of R. Simeon b. Yohai: An analogy is drawn between the two forms of the root 'to lay'.[^fn_46a_53]

R. Jeremiah raised the question: What is the ruling[^fn_46a_54] where \[the husband\] hired them[^fn_46a_55] with a piece of land?[^fn_46a_56] What \[if he hired them\] for a sum less than a *perutah*?[^fn_46a_57] What \[if both witnesses were hired\] for one *perutah*?

R. Ashi enquired: What \[is the ruling where a husband\][^fn_46a_58] brought an evil name \[upon his wife\] in respect of their first marriage? What \[if a levir[^fn_46a_59] brought up an evil name\] in respect of his brother's marriage? — You may at all events solve one \[of these questions\].[^fn_46a_60] For R. Jonah taught: I gave my daughter unto this man[^fn_46a_61] only unto this man[^fn_46a_62] but not to a levir.[^fn_46a_63]

What \[is the ruling of\] the Rabbis and what \[is that of\] R. Eliezer b. Jacob?[^fn_46a_64] — It was taught: What constitutes[^fn_46a_65] the bringing up of an evil name \[against one's wife\]?[^fn_46a_66] If \[a husband\] came to the *Beth din* and said, 'I, So-and-so, found not in thy daughter the tokens of virginity'. If there are witnesses that she committed adultery while living with hint she is entitled to a *kethubah* for a *maneh*.[^fn_46a_67] 'If there are witnesses that she committed adultery while living with him \[you say,\] she is entitled to a *kethubah* for a maneh'! But is she not in that case subject to the penalty of stoning?[^fn_46a_68] — It is this that was meant: If there are witnesses that she committed adultery while she was living with him she is to be stoned; if, however, she committed adultery before \[her marriage\] she is entitled to a *kethubah* for a *maneh*.[^fn_46a_69] If it was ascertained that the evil name had no foundation in fact[^fn_46a_70] the husband is flogged and he must also pay a hundred *sela'* irrespective of whether he had intercourse \[with her\] or whether he did not have intercourse \[with her\]. R. Eliezer b. Jacob said: These penalties[^fn_46a_71] apply only where he had intercourse \[with her\].

According to R. Eliezer b. Jacob[^fn_46a_72] one can well understand why Scripture used the expressions, 'And go in unto her'[^fn_46a_73] and 'When I came nigh to her',[^fn_46a_74] but according to the Rabbis[^fn_46a_75] what \[could be the meaning of\] 'And go in unto her'[^fn_46a_73] and' When I came nigh unto her'?[^fn_46a_74] 'And go in unto her'[^fn_46a_73] with wanton charges, and 'When I come nigh to her'[^fn_46a_74] with words.

According to R. Eliezer b. Jacob[^fn_46a_72] one can well see why Scripture used the expression, 'I found not in thy daughter the tokens of virginity',[^fn_46a_76] but according to the Rabbis[^fn_46a_75] what \[could be the sense of the expression\], 'I found not in thy daughter the tokens of virginity'? — I found not far[^fn_46a_77] thy daughter witnesses to establish her claim to tokens of virginity.[^fn_46a_78]

It was quite correct for Scripture, according to R. Eliezer b. Jacob,[^fn_46a_79] to state, And yet these are the tokens of my daughter's virginity;[^fn_46a_80] but according to the Rabbis[^fn_46a_81] what could be the sense of \[the expression,\] 'And yet these are the tokens of my daughter's virginity'?[^fn_46a_80] — And yet these are the witnesses who establish[^fn_46a_78] the tokens of my daughter's virginity.

One can well understand, according to R. Eliezer b. Jacob,[^fn_46a_79] why Scripture wrote, And they shall spread the garment,'[^fn_46a_80] but according to the Rabbis[^fn_46a_81] what \[could be the sense of the instruction,\] And they shall spread the garment? — R. Abbahu replied: They explain[^fn_46a_82] \[the charge\] which he submitted against her;[^fn_46a_83] as it was taught: 'And they shall spread the garment' teaches that the witnesses of the one party and those of the other party come, and the matter is made as clear as a new garment. R. Eliezer b. Jacob said: The words are to be taken in their literal sense: \[They must produce\] the actual garment.[^fn_46a_84]

R. Isaac son of R. Jacob b. Giyori sent this message in the name of R. Johanan: Although we do not find anywhere in the Torah that Scripture draws a distinction between natural and unnatural intercourse In respect of flogging or other punishments, such a distinction was made in the case of a man who brought an evil name \[upon his wife\];[^fn_46a_85] for he is not held guilty unless, having had intercourse with her, \[even\][^fn_46a_86] in an unnatural manner, he brought up an evil name upon her in respect of a natural intercourse.

In accordance with whose view?[^fn_46a_87] If \[it be said to be\] in accordance with the view of the Rabbis \[the husband, it could be retorted, should have been held guilty\] even if he had no intercourse with her. If \[it be said to be\] in agreement with the view of R. Eliezer b. Jacob [pg 46b]

must not the intercourse in both cases be in a natural manner?[^fn_46b_1] — The fact, however, is, said R. Kahana in the name of R. Johanan, that the husband is not held guilty unless he had intercourse In a natural manner and he brought up an evil name upon her in respect of a natural intercourse.

***MISHNAH***. A FATHER HAS AUTHORITY OVER HIS DAUGHTER[^fn_46b_2] IN RESPECT OF HER BETROTHAL \[WHETHER IT WAS EFFECTED\] BY MONEY,[^fn_46b_3] DEED[^fn_46b_4] OR INTERCOURSE;[^fn_46b_5] HE IS ENTITLED TO ANYTHING SHE FINDS AND TO HER HANDIWORK; \[HE HAS THE RIGHT\] OF ANNULLING HER VOWS[^fn_46b_6] AND HE RECEIVES HER BILL OF DIVORCE;[^fn_46b_7] BUT HE HAS NO USUFRUCT[^fn_46b_8] DURING HER LIFETIME.[^fn_46b_9] WHEN SHE MARRIES, THE HUSBAND SURPASSES HIM \[IN HIS RIGHTS\] IN THAT HE HAS[^fn_46b_10] USUFRUCT DURING HER LIFETIME,[^fn_46b_11] BUT HE IS ALSO UNDER THE OBLIGATION OF MAINTAINING AND RANSOMING HER[^fn_46b_12] AND TO PROVIDE FOR HER BURIAL. R. JUDAH RULED: EVEN THE POOREST MAN IN ISRAEL MUST PROVIDE[^fn_46b_13] NO LESS THAN TWO FLUTES AND ONE LAMENTING WOMAN. {¶=4.4}

***GEMARA***. 'BY MONEY'. Whence is this[^fn_46b_14] deduced? — Rab Judah replied: Scripture said, Then shall she go ant for nothing without money,[^fn_46b_15] \[which implies that\] this master[^fn_46b_16] receives no money[^fn_46b_17] but that another master does receive money;[^fn_46b_18] and who is he? Her father.[^fn_46b_19] But might it not be suggested that it[^fn_46b_20] belongs to her?[^fn_46b_21] — Since[^fn_46b_22] it is her father who contracts[^fn_46b_23] her betrothal, as it is written in Scripture, I gave my daughter unto this man,[^fn_46b_24] would she take the money![^fn_46b_25] But can it not be suggested that this[^fn_46b_26] applies only to a minor[^fn_46b_27] who has no legal right[^fn_46b_28] \[to act on her own behalf\], but that a na'arah[^fn_46b_29] who has such rights[^fn_46b_30] may herself contract her betrothal, and she herself receives the money? — Scripture stated, Being in her youth in her father's house,[^fn_46b_31] \[implying that\] all the advantages of her youth belong to her father.

\[Consider\], however, that which R. Huna said in the name of Rab: 'Whence is it deduced that a daughte handiwork belongs to her father? \[From Scripture\] where it is said, And if a van sell his daughter to be a maidservant,[^fn_46b_32] as[^fn_46b_33] the handiwork of a maidservant belongs to her master so does the handiwork of a daughter belong to her father'.[^fn_46b_34] Now what need was there,[^fn_46b_35] \[it may be asked, for this text when\] deduction[^fn_46b_36] could have been made from \[the text of\] 'Being in her youth in her father's house'?[^fn_46b_31] Consequently \[it must be admitted, must it not, that\] that text was written in connection only with the annulment of vows?[^fn_46b_37] And should you suggest that we might infer this[^fn_46b_38] from it,[^fn_46b_39] \[it could be retorted that\] monetary matters cannot be inferred from ritual matters.[^fn_46b_39] And should you suggest that we might infer it is from \[the law of\] fine,[^fn_46b_40] \[it could be retorted, could it not, that\] monetary payments cannot be inferred from fines? And should you suggest that it is might be inferred from \[the law of compensation for\] indignity and blemish,[^fn_46b_41] \[it could be retorted\] that indignity and blemish are different,[^fn_46b_42] since \[the rights\] of her father \[are also, are they not\], involved[^fn_46b_43] in it?[^fn_46b_44] — \[This\], however, \[is the explanation\]:[^fn_46b_45] It is logical to conclude that when the All-Merciful excluded[^fn_46b_46] \[another\] going out,[^fn_46b_47] the exclusion Was meant to be \[understood in a manner\] similar to the original.[^fn_46b_48] But[^fn_46b_49] one 'going out', surely, is not like that of the other: For[^fn_46b_50] in the case of the master \[the maidservant\] goes entirely out of his control while in the 'going out' from the control of her father \[the daughter's\] transfer to the bridal chamber is still lacking?[^fn_46b_51] — In respect of the annulment of vows, at any rate, she passes out of his control; for we have learned: In the case of a betrothed damsel[^fn_46b_52] it is her father and her husband who jointly annul her vows.[^fn_46b_53]

DEED OR INTERCOURSE. Whence do we \[deduce this\]?[^fn_46b_54] — Scripture said, And becometh another man's wife[^fn_46b_55] is \[from which it may be inferred that\] the various forms of betrothal[^fn_46b_56] are to be compared to one another.[^fn_46b_57]

HE IS ENTITLED TO ANYTHING SHE FINDS, [pg 47a]

in order \[to avert\] ill feeling.[^fn_47a_1]

TO HER HANDIWORK. Whence do we deduce this? — \[From that\] which R. Huna quoted in the name of Rab: Whence is it deduced that a daughter's handiwork belongs to her father? — \[From Scripture\] where it is stated, And if a man sell his daughter to be a maidservant,[^fn_47a_2] as the handiwork of a maidservant belongs to her master so does the handiwork of a daughter belong to her father.[^fn_47a_3] But may it not be suggested that this[^fn_47a_4] \[applies only to\] a minor whom he may sell, but the handiwork of a na'arah[^fn_47a_5] whom he cannot sell belongs to herself? — It is but logical to assume that it should belong to her father; for should it be imagined that her handiwork does not belong to him \[the objection could well be advanced against\] the right[^fn_47a_6] which the All-Merciful has conferred upon a father to consign his daughter to the bridal chamber: How could he consign her when he thereby[^fn_47a_7] prevents her from doing her work?[^fn_47a_8] R. Ahai demurred: Might it not be suggested that he[^fn_47a_9] pays her compensation \[for the time\] she is taken away \[from her work\] or else, that he consigns her during the night,[^fn_47a_10] or else that he might consign her on Sabbaths[^fn_47a_11] or festivals?[^fn_47a_11] — \[The fact\], however, \[is that in the case of\] a minor no Scriptural text was necessary.[^fn_47a_12] For since[^fn_47a_13] is he may even sell her was it at all necessary \[to state that her handiwork belongs to him\]?[^fn_47a_14] If a Scriptural text[^fn_47a_15] then was at all necessary \[it must have been\] in respect of a na'arah.

TO ANNUL HER VOWS. Whence do we \[deduce this\]? \[From Scripture\] where it is written,[^fn_47a_16] Being in her youth in her father's house.[^fn_47a_17]

AND HE RECEIVES HER BILL OF DIVORCE. Whence is this deduced? — From Scripture where it is written, And she departeth and And becometh,[^fn_47a_18] 'departure'[^fn_47a_19] being compared to 'becoming'.[^fn_47a_20]

BUT HE HAS NO USUFRUCT DURING HER LIFETIME. Our Rabbis taught: A father has no usufruct[^fn_47a_21] during the lifetime of his daughter.[^fn_47a_22] R. Jose the son of R. Judah ruled: A father is entitled to usufruct[^fn_47a_21] in the lifetime of his daughter. On what principle do they differ? — The first Tanna is of the opinion that the Rabbis were well justified in allowing usufruct to a husband, since otherwise he might refrain from ransoming \[his wife\].[^fn_47a_23] What, however, can be said[^fn_47a_24] in respect of a father? That he would refrain from ransoming her? \[It is certain that\] he would ransom her in any case. R. Jose the son of R. Judah, however, is of the opinion that a father also might refrain from ransoming \[his daughter\], for he might think: She is carrying a purse[^fn_47a_25] about her, let her proceed to ransom herself.[^fn_47a_26]

WHEN SHE MARRIES, THE HUSBAND SURPASSES HIM \[IN HIS RIGHTS\] IN THAT HE HAS USUFRUCT etc. Our Rabbis taught: If \[a father\] promised his daughter in writing[^fn_47a_27] fruit,[^fn_47a_28] clothes or other movable objects[^fn_47a_29] that she might take[^fn_47a_30] with her[^fn_47a_31] from her father's house to that of her husband, and she died,[^fn_47a_32] her husband does not acquire these objects. In the name of R. Nathan it was stated: The husband does acquire them. Must it be assumed that they[^fn_47a_33] differ on the same principles as those on which R. Eleazar b. Azariah and the Rabbis differed? For we learned: A woman who was widowed or divorced, either after betrothal or after marriage, is entitled to collect all[^fn_47a_34] \[that is due to her\]. R. Eleazar b. Azariah ruled: \[Only a woman widowed or divorced\] after her marriage recovers all \[that is due to her\], but if after a betrothal a virgin recovers only two hundred *zuz*[^fn_47a_35] and a widow only one *maneh*[^fn_47a_35] [pg 47b]

for the man wrote \[the additional jointure\] for her with the sole object of marrying her.[^fn_47b_1] \[Must it then be assumed\] that he who ruled that 'her husband does not acquire' \[upholds the same principle\] as R. Eleazar b.
