Azariah[^fn_47b_2] while he[^fn_47b_3] who ruled that 'the husband does acquire' \[upholds the same principle\] as the Rabbis?[^fn_47b_4] — No; all[^fn_47b_5] \[may, in fact, hold the same view\] as R. Eleazar b. Azariah.[^fn_47b_6] \[For\] he who ruled, 'her husband does not acquire', \[is obviously\] in agreement with R. Eleazar b. Azariah.[^fn_47b_7] And as to him[^fn_47b_3] who ruled, 'the husband does acquire' \[it may be explained that\] only \[in respect of undertakings\] from him[^fn_47b_8] towards her[^fn_47b_9] did R. Eleazar b. Azariah maintain his view,[^fn_47b_10] \[for the reason that\] 'the man wrote \[the additional jointure\] for her with the sole object of marrying her',[^fn_47b_11] but \[in respect of undertakings\] from her[^fn_47b_12] towards him[^fn_47b_13] even R. Eleazar b. Azariah may admit \[that betrothal has the same force as marriage\] since \[undertakings of such a nature\][^fn_47b_14] are due to \[a desire for\] matrimonial association, and such association, surely, had taken place.[^fn_47b_15]

HE IS ALSO UNDER THE OBLIGATION OF MAINTAINING HER etc. Our Rabbis taught: Maintenance was provided for a wife in return for her handiwork, and her burial[^fn_47b_16] in return for her *kethubah*.[^fn_47b_17] A husband is, therefore, entitled to usufruct. 'Usufruct'! Who mentioned it?[^fn_47b_18] — A clause is missing, and this is the proper reading: Maintenance was provided for a wife in return for her handiwork, her ransom In return for usufruct,[^fn_47b_19] and her burial in return for her *kethubah*;[^fn_47b_20] a husband, therefore, is entitled to usufruct.[^fn_47b_19]

What \[was the need for\] 'therefore'?[^fn_47b_21] — It might have been presumed \[that a husband\] must not consume the fruits[^fn_47b_19] but should rather leave them,[^fn_47b_22] since, otherwise,[^fn_47b_23] he might refrain from ransoming her, hence we were informed that that \[course\][^fn_47b_24] was preferable, for sometimes \[the proceeds of the fruit\] might not suffice[^fn_47b_25] and he[^fn_47b_26] would have to ransom her at his own expense.

Might I not transpose \[the sequence\]?[^fn_47b_27] — Abaye replied: They[^fn_47b_28] ordained the common for the common[^fn_47b_29] and the uncommon for the uncommon.[^fn_47b_30]

Said Raba: The following Tanna is of the opinion that maintenance[^fn_47b_31] is a Pentateuchal duty. For it was taught: She'erah[^fn_47b_32] refers to[^fn_47b_33] maintenance, for so it is said in Scripture, Who also eat the she'er[^fn_47b_34] of my peaple;[^fn_47b_35] Her raiment[^fn_47b_36] \[is to be understood\] according to its ordinary meaning; 'Onatha[^fn_47b_37] refers to the time for conjugal duty[^fn_47b_38] prescribed in the Torah,[^fn_47b_39] for so it is said in Scripture, If than shalt afflict[^fn_47b_40] my daughters.[^fn_47b_41] R. Eleazar said: 'She'erah' refers to the prescribed time for conjugal duty,[^fn_47b_39] for so it is said in Scripture, None of you shall approach to any that is near of kin[^fn_47b_42] to him to uncover their nakedness;[^fn_47b_43] 'Her raiment' \[is to be taken\] according to its literal meaning; 'Onatha refers to maintenance, for so it is said in Scripture, And he afflicted thee,[^fn_47b_44] and suffered thee to hunger.[^fn_47b_45] [pg 48a]

R. Eliezer b. Jacob interpreted: \[The expressions\] She'erah kesutha,[^fn_48a_1] \[imply\]: Provide her with raiment according to her age, viz. that a man shall not provide his old wife[^fn_48a_2] \[with the raiment\] of a young one nor his young wife with that of an old one. \[The expressions\], Kesutha we- 'Onatha[^fn_48a_3] \[imply.\] Provide her with raiment according to the season of the year,[^fn_48a_4] viz. that he shall not give her new raiment[^fn_48a_5] in the summer nor worn out raiment[^fn_48a_6] in the winter.[^fn_48a_7] R. Joseph learnt: Her flesh[^fn_48a_8] implies close bodily contact,[^fn_48a_9] viz, that he must not treat her in the manner of the Persians who perform their conjugal duties in their clothes. This provides support for \[a ruling of\] R. Huna who laid down that a husband who said, 'I will not \[perform conjugal duties\] unless she wears her clothes and I mine', must divorce her and give her also her *kethubah*.

R. JUDAH RULED: EVEN THE POOREST MAN IN ISRAEL etc. This[^fn_48a_10] then implies that the first Tanna is of the opinion that these[^fn_48a_11] are not \[necessary\]. But how is one to imagine \[the case\]? If these[^fn_48a_11] were required by the woman's status,[^fn_48a_12] what \[it may be objected could be\] the reason of the first Tanna who ruled \[that these[^fn_48a_11] were\] not \[required\]? And if these[^fn_48a_11] were not required by the woman's status,[^fn_48a_13] what \[it may be objected could be\] the reason of R. Judah? — \[The ruling was\] necessary only \[in a case\], for instance, where these were demanded by his status but not by hers. The first Tanna is of the opinion that the principle that she[^fn_48a_14] rises with him[^fn_48a_15] but does not go down with him[^fn_48a_16] is applied only during her lifetime[^fn_48a_17] but not after her death, while R. Judah maintains \[that the principle applies\] even after her death. R. Hisda laid down in the name of Mar 'Ukba that the *halachah* is in agreement with R. Judah.

R. Hisda further stated in the name of Mar 'Ukba: If a man became insane *Beth din* take possession[^fn_48a_18] of his estate and provide food and clothing for his wife, sons and daughters, and for anything else.[^fn_48a_19] Said Rabina to R. Ashi: Why should this[^fn_48a_20] be different from that concerning which it was taught: If a man went to a country beyond the sea and his wife claimed maintenance, *Beth din* take possession of[^fn_48a_21] his estate and provide food and clothing for his wife, but not for his sons and daughters or for anything else?[^fn_48a_22] The other replied: Do you not draw a distinction between one who departs[^fn_48a_23] deliberately and one who departs[^fn_48a_24] without knowing it?[^fn_48a_25]

What \[is meant by\] 'anything else'? — R. Hisda replied: Cosmetics were meant,[^fn_48a_26] R. Joseph explained: Charity. According to him who replied, 'Cosmetics', the ruling[^fn_48a_27] would apply with even greater force to charity.[^fn_48a_28] He, however, who explained, 'charity' \[restricts his ruling[^fn_48a_27] to this alone\] but cosmetics \[he maintains\] must he given to her, for \[her husband\] would not be pleased that she shall lose her comeliness.

R. Hiyya b. Abin stated in the name of R. Huna: If a man went to a country beyond the sea, and his wife died, *Beth din* take possession[^fn_48a_29] of his estate and bury her in a manner befitting the dignity of his status. \[You say\] 'In a manner befitting the dignity of his status', and not that of her status![^fn_48a_30] — Read, In a manner befitting his status also; and it is this that he[^fn_48a_31] informs us: She rises with him \[in his dignity\] but does not go down with him \[to a lower status\] even after her death.

R. Mattena ruled: A man[^fn_48a_32] who gave instructions that when \[his wife\] died she shall not be buried at the expense of his estate must be obeyed.[^fn_48a_33] What, however, is the reason \[for obeying the man\] when he has left instructions? Obviously because the estate falls to the orphans;[^fn_48a_34] but the estate falls to the orphans, does it not, even if he left no instructions?[^fn_48a_35] — \[The proper reading\], however, is: A man[^fn_48a_32] who gave instructions that when he dies be shall not be buried at the expense of his estate[^fn_48a_36] is not to be obeyed, for it is not within his power[^fn_48a_37] to enrich his sons and throw himself upon the public.

***MISHNAH***. SHE[^fn_48a_38] REMAINS[^fn_48a_39] UNDER THE AUTHORITY OF HER FATHER[^fn_48a_40] UNTIL SHE ENTERS [pg 48b] {¶=4.5}

UNDER THE AUTHORITY OF HER HUSBAND[^fn_48b_1] \[BY GOING INTO THE BRIDAL CHAMBER\][^fn_48b_2] AT MARRIAGE. IF HER FATHER DELIVERED HER TO THE AGENTS OF THE HUSBAND[^fn_48b_3] SHE PASSES[^fn_48b_4] UNDER THE AUTHORITY OF HER HUSBAND. IF HER FATHER WENT WITH HER HUSBAND'S AGENTS[^fn_48b_5] OR IF THE FATHER'S AGENTS WENT WITH THE HUSBAND'S AGENTS[^fn_48b_5] SHE REMAINS[^fn_48b_4] UNDER THE AUTHORITY OF HER FATHER. IF HER FATHER'S AGENTS DELIVERED HER TO HER HUSBAND'S AGENTS[^fn_48b_6] SHE PASSES[^fn_48b_4] UNDER THE AUTHORITY OF HER HUSBAND.

***GEMARA***. What \[is the purport of\] REMAINS?[^fn_48b_7] — To exclude \[the ruling\] of an earlier[^fn_48b_8] Mishnah where we learned: If the respective periods[^fn_48b_9] expired[^fn_48b_10] and they were not married[^fn_48b_11] they are entitled to maintenance out of the man's estate[^fn_48b_12] and \[if he is a priest\][^fn_48b_13] may also eat *terumah*.[^fn_48b_14] Therefore 'REMAINS'[^fn_48b_15] was used.[^fn_48b_16]

IF HER FATHER DELIVERED HER TO THE AGENTS OF THE HUSBAND SHE PASSES UNDER THE AUTHORITY OF HER HUSBAND etc. Rab ruled: Her delivery \[is regarded as entry into the bridal chamber\] in all respects[^fn_48b_17] except that of *terumah*;[^fn_48b_18] but R. Assi ruled in respect of *terumah* also.

R. Huna, (or as some Say, Hiyya b. Rab,) raised an objection against R. Assi: She remains[^fn_48b_15] under the authority of her father until she enters the bridal chamber.[^fn_48b_19] 'Did I not tell you', said Rab to them,[^fn_48b_20] 'that you should not be guided by an ambiguous statement?[^fn_48b_21] He[^fn_48b_22] can answer you that "her delivery" is regarded as her entry into the bridal chamber'.

Samuel, however, ruled: \[Her delivery has the force of entry into the bridal chamber only in respect\] of her inheritance.[^fn_48b_23] Resh Lakish ruled: \[Only in respect\] of her *kethubah*.[^fn_48b_24] What is meant by 'her kethubah'? \[If it means\] that should \[the woman\] die he inherits it,[^fn_48b_25] \[then this ruling is, is it not,\] the same as that of Samuel?[^fn_48b_26] Rabina replied: The meaning is[^fn_48b_27] that her \[statutory\] *kethubah* from a second husband[^fn_48b_28] is only a *maneh*.[^fn_48b_29]

Both R. Johanan and R. Hanina ruled: Her delivery \[is regarded as entry into the bridal chamber\] in all respects. even that of *terumah*.[^fn_48b_30]

An objection was raised: If the father went with the agents of the husband, or if the agents of the father went with the agents of the husband, or if she had a court-yard on the way, and she entered it with him[^fn_48b_31] to rest there for the night,[^fn_48b_32] her father inherits from her if she died, although her *kethubah*[^fn_48b_33] is already in the house of her husband. If, however, her father delivered her to her husband's agents, or if her father's agents delivered her to her husband's agents, or he[^fn_48b_34] had a court-yard on the way, and she entered it with him with an intention to matrimony, her husband is her heir if she died, although her *kethubah*[^fn_48b_33] was still in her father's house.[^fn_48b_35] This ruling[^fn_48b_36] applies only in respect of her inheritance[^fn_48b_37] but in respect of *terumah* \[the law is that\] no woman is allowed to eat *terumah* until she enters the bridal chamber.[^fn_48b_38] \[Does not this represent\] a refutation of all?[^fn_48b_39] This is indeed a refutation.

\[But\] is not this,[^fn_48b_40] however, self-contradictory? You said. 'She entered it with him to rest for the night'. The reason \[why such an act is not regarded as entry into the bridal chamber is\] because \[the entrance was made specifically for the purpose of\] resting for the night. Had it, however, been made with no specified intention \[it would be deemed to have been made\] with an intention to matrimony. Read, however, the final clause: 'She entered it with him with an intention to matrimony', from which it follows, does it not, that if the entrance was made with no specified intention \[it would be deemed to have been made just\] in order to rest there for the night? — R. Ashi replied: Both entrances mentioned[^fn_48b_41] are such as were made with no specified intention, but any unspecified \[entrance into\] a court-yard of hers \[is presumed to have been made\] in order to rest there for the night while any unspecified \[entrance into\] a court-yard of his[^fn_48b_42] \[is presumed to have been made\] with an intention to matrimony.

A Tanna taught: If a father delivered \[his daughter\][^fn_48b_43] to the agents of her husband and she played the harlot[^fn_48b_44] her penalty is that[^fn_48b_45] of strangulation.[^fn_48b_46] Whence is this ruling deduced? — R. Ammi b. Hama replied: Scripture stated,[^fn_48b_47] To play the harlot in her father's house,[^fn_48b_48] thus excluding one whom the father had delivered to the agents of the husband.

Might it not be suggested that this[^fn_48b_48] excludes one who entered her bridal chamber but with whom no cohabitation had taken place?[^fn_48b_49] — Raba replied: Ammi told me \[that a woman[^fn_48b_50] who entered her\] bridal chamber was explicitly[^fn_48b_51] mentioned in Scripture: If there be a damsel that is a virgin betrothed unto a man;[^fn_48b_52] 'a damsel' but not a woman who is adolescent, 'a virgin' 'but not a woman with whom intercourse took place, 'betrathed' but not one married.[^fn_48b_53] Now what \[is meant by\] 'one married'? If it be suggested: One actually married, \[it can be objected that such a deduction\][^fn_48b_54] would be practically the same as that of 'a virgin but not one with whom intercourse took place'. Consequently it must be concluded[^fn_48b_55] \[that by 'married' was meant one\] who entered into the bridal chamber but with whom no intercourse took place.[^fn_48b_56] [pg 49a]

But might not one suggest that if she[^fn_49a_1] returned[^fn_49a_2] to her parental home she resumes her former status?[^fn_49a_3] — Raba replied: A Tanna of the school of R. Ishmael has long ago settled this difficulty. For a Tanna of the school of R. Ishmael taught: What need was there for Scripture to state, But the vow of a widow, or of her that is divorced, even everything wherewith she bath bound her soul, shall stand against her?[^fn_49a_4] Is she not free from the authority of her father[^fn_49a_5] and also from that of her husband?[^fn_49a_6] \[The fact\], however, is that where[^fn_49a_7] her father had delivered her to the agents of her husband, or where the agents of her father had delivered her to the agents of her husband and, on the way,[^fn_49a_8] she became a widow or was divorced[^fn_49a_9] \[one would not know\] whether she was to be described as of[^fn_49a_10] the house of her father[^fn_49a_11] or as of the house of her husband;[^fn_49a_12] hence the need for the text[^fn_49a_13] to tell you that as soon as she has left her father's authority,[^fn_49a_14] even if only for a short while, he may no longer annul her vows.[^fn_49a_15]

Said R. Papa: We also learned \[a similar ruling\]:[^fn_49a_16] A man who has intercourse with a betrothed girl incurs no penalties[^fn_49a_17] unless she is a na'arah,[^fn_49a_18] a virgin, betrothed, and in her father's house.[^fn_49a_19] Now one can well see that 'na'arah' excludes[^fn_49a_20] one who is adolescent, 'virgin' excludes[^fn_49a_20] one with whom a man has had intercourse, and 'betrothed' excludes one who married \[by entry into the bridal chamber\].[^fn_49a_21] What, \[however, could the expression\] 'in her father's house' exclude? Obviously this:[^fn_49a_22] \[The case where\] her father delivered her to the agents of the husband.[^fn_49a_23]

R. Nahman b. Isaac said: We also learned \[a similar ruling\]:[^fn_49a_24] Should one have intercourse with a 'married woman'[^fn_49a_25] the latter,[^fn_49a_26] provided she entered under the authority of her husband,[^fn_49a_27] although no intercourse had taken place, is to he punished by strangulation.[^fn_49a_28] 'She entered under the authority of her husband' \[implies\][^fn_49a_29] in any form whatever.[^fn_49a_30] This is conclusive proof.

***MISHNAH***. A FATHER[^fn_49a_31] IS UNDER NO OBLIGATION TO MAINTAIN HIS DAUGHTER. THIS EXPOSITION[^fn_49a_32] WAS MADE BY R. ELEAZAR B. AZARIAH[^fn_49a_33] IN THE PRESENCE OF THE SAGES IN THE VINEYARD OF JABNEH:[^fn_49a_34] \[SINCE IT WAS ENACTED THAT\] THE SONS SHALL BE HEIRS \[TO THEIR MOTHER'S KETHUBAH\][^fn_49a_35] AND THE DAUGHTERS SHALL BE MAINTAINED \[OUT OF THEIR FATHER'S ESTATE,[^fn_49a_35] THE TWO CASES MAY BE COMPARED:\] AS THE SONS CANNOT BE HEIRS EXCEPT AFTER THE DEATH OF THEIR FATHER, SO THE DAUGHTERS CANNOT CLAIM MAINTENANCE EXCEPT AFTER THE DEATH OF THEIR FATHER. {¶=4.6}

***GEMARA***. \[Since it has been said that\] he is UNDER NO OBLIGATION TO MAINTAIN HIS DAUGHTER Only, it follows[^fn_49a_36] that he is under an obligation to maintain his son, \[and in the case of\] his daughter also, since he is only exempt from[^fn_49a_37] legal OBLIGATION he is, obviously, still subject[^fn_49a_38] to a moral duty; who, \[then, it may be asked, is the author\] of our Mishnah? \[Is it\] neither R. Meir nor R. Judah nor R. Johanan b. Beroka? For it was taught: It is a moral duty[^fn_49a_39] to feed one's daughters, and much more so ones sons, (since the latter are engaged in the study of the Torah);[^fn_49a_40] so R. Meir. R. Judah ruled: It is a moral duty to feed ones sons, and much more so one's daughters, (in order \[to prevent their\] degradation).[^fn_49a_41] R. Johanan b. Beroka ruled: It is a legal obligation to feed one's daughters[^fn_49a_42] after their father's death; but during the lifetime of their father neither sons nor daughters need be[^fn_49a_43] fed.[^fn_49a_44] Now who \[could be the author of\] our Mishnah? If R. Meir, he, surely, \[it may be objected\] ruled that \[the maintenance of\] sons \[was only\] a moral duty.[^fn_49a_45] If R. Judah, he, surely ruled that also[^fn_49a_46] \[the maintenance of\] sons \[was only\] a moral duty.[^fn_49a_45] And if R. Johanan b. Beroka \[should be suggested, the objection would be: Is not his opinion that\] one is not even subject to[^fn_49a_47] a moral duty?[^fn_49a_45] — If you wish I might say \[that the author is\] R. Meir; If you wish I might Say: R. Judah; and if you prefer I might Say: R. Johanan b. Beroka. 'If you wish I might say \[that the author is\] R. Meir', and it is this that he meant:[^fn_49a_48] A FATHER IS UNDER NO OBLIGATION TO MAINTAIN HIS DAUGHTER, and the same law applies to his son. \[Maintenance\], however, is a moral duty in the case of his daughter and, much more so, in the case of his sons; and the reason why[^fn_49a_49] HIS DAUGHTER was mentioned[^fn_49a_50] was to teach us this: [pg 49b]

That even in the case of his daughter[^fn_49b_1] he is only exempt from a legal obligation but is nevertheless subject to a moral duty.[^fn_49b_2] 'If you wish I might say: R. Judah'; and it is this that he meant: A FATHER is UNDER NO OBLIGATION TO MAINTAIN HIS DAUGHTER, and much more so[^fn_49b_3] his son.[^fn_49b_4] It is, however, a moral duty \[to maintain\] one's son and, much more so, ones daughters; and the only reason why HIS DAUGHTER was mentioned Was to teach us this: That even \[the maintenance of\] one's daughter is no[^fn_49b_5] legal obligation. 'And if you prefer I might say: R. Johanan b. Beroka', and what Was meant is this: HE IS UNDER NO OBLIGATION TO MAINTAIN HIS DAUGHTER, and the same law applies to his son; and this, furthermore, means[^fn_49b_6] that \[such maintenance\] is not even[^fn_49b_5] a moral duty; only because \[the maintenance of daughters\] after their father's death is a legal obligation, the expression, HE IS UNDER NO OBLIGATION, was used here also.[^fn_49b_7]

R. Elai stated in the name of Resh Lakish who had it from R. Judah[^fn_49b_8] b. Hanina: At Usha[^fn_49b_9] it was ordained that a man must maintain his sons and daughters while they are young.[^fn_49b_10] The question was raised: Is the law in agreement with his statement or not? — Come and hear: When people came before Rab Judah,[^fn_49b_11] he used to tell them, 'A Yarod[^fn_49b_12] bears progeny and[^fn_49b_13] throws them upon \[the tender mercies of\] the townspeople'.[^fn_49b_14]

When people came before R. Hisda,[^fn_49b_10] he used to tell them, 'Turn a mortar[^fn_49b_15] for him upside down,[^fn_49b_16] in public and let one[^fn_49b_17] stand \[on it\] and say: The raven cares[^fn_49b_18] for its young but that man[^fn_49b_19] does not care for his children'.[^fn_49b_20] But does a raven care[^fn_49b_18] for its young? Is it not written in Scripture,[^fn_49b_21] To the young ravens which cry?[^fn_49b_22] — This is no difficulty. The latter[^fn_49b_23] applies to white ravens[^fn_49b_24] and the former[^fn_49b_25] to black ones.[^fn_49b_26] 

When a man[^fn_49b_27] came before Raba he used to tell him, 'Will it please you that your children should be maintained from the charity funds?'[^fn_49b_28] 

This ruling,[^fn_49b_29] however, has been laid down only for one who is not a wealthy man, but if the man is wealthy he may be compelled[^fn_49b_30] even against his wish; as was the case with[^fn_49b_31] Raba who used compulsion against R. Nathan b. Ammi[^fn_49b_32] and extracted front him four hundred *zuz*[^fn_49b_33] for charity.[^fn_49b_34] 

R. Elai stated in the name of Resh Lakish: It was enacted at Usha[^fn_49b_35] that if a man assigned all his estate to his sons in writing, he and his wife[^fn_49b_36] may nevertheless[^fn_49b_37] be maintained out of it. R. Zera, or as some say, R. Samuel b. Nahmani, demurred: Since the Rabbis went so far as to rule[^fn_49b_38] that \[in the case that follows\] a widow is maintained out of her husband's estate, was there any necessity \[to state that such maintenance is allowed to\] the man himself and his wife? For Rabin had sent in his letter:[^fn_49b_39] If a man died and left a widow and a daughter, his widow is to receive her maintenance from his estate?[^fn_49b_40] If the daughter married,[^fn_49b_41] his widow is still to receive her maintenance from his estate. If the daughter died?[^fn_49b_42] Rab[^fn_49b_43] Judah the son of the sister of R. Jose b. Hanina said: I had such a case, and it was decided[^fn_49b_44] that his widow was to receive her maintenance from his estate.[^fn_49b_45] \[In view of this ruling we ask: Was it\] necessary \[to give a similar ruling[^fn_49b_46] in respect of\] the man himself[^fn_49b_47] and his wife? — It might have been assumed \[that the law applies only\] there,[^fn_49b_48] because there is no one else to provide for her,[^fn_49b_49] but here \[it might well be argued:\] Let him provide for himself and for her;[^fn_49b_50] hence we were taught \[that here also the same ruling applies\].

The question was raised: Is the law in agreement with his view[^fn_49b_51] or not? — Come and hear: R. Hanina and R. Jonathan were once standing together when a man approached them and bending down kissed R. Jonathan upon his foot. 'What \[is the meaning of\] this?' said R. Hanina to him.[^fn_49b_52] 'This man', the other[^fn_49b_52] replied, 'assigned his estate to his sons in writing [pg 50a]

and I compelled them to maintain him'. Now if it be conceded that this[^fn_50a_1] was not \[in accordance with the strict\] law one can well understand why he had to compel them,[^fn_50a_2] but if it be contended that this[^fn_50a_3] is the law, would it have been necessary for him \[it may be objected\] to compel them?[^fn_50a_4]

R. Elai stated: It was ordained at Usha[^fn_50a_5] that if a man wishes to spend liberally[^fn_50a_6] he should not spend more than a fifth.[^fn_50a_7] So it was also taught: If a man desires to spend liberally[^fn_50a_6] he should not spend more than a fifth,[^fn_50a_7] \[since by spending more\] he might himself come to be in need \[of the help\] of people.[^fn_50a_8] It once happened that a man wished to spend[^fn_50a_6] more than a fifth[^fn_50a_7] but his friend did not allow him. Who was it?[^fn_50a_9] — R. Yeshebab. Others say \[that the man who wished to spend was\] R. Yeshebab, but his friend did not allow him. And who was it?[^fn_50a_9] R. Akiba. R. Nahman, or as some say, R. Aha b. Jacob, said: What \[is the proof from\] Scripture?[^fn_50a_10] — And of all that Thou shalt give me I will surely give the tenth[^fn_50a_11] into thee.[^fn_50a_12]

But the second tenth,[^fn_50a_13] surely, is not like the first one? — R. Ashi replied: I will … give a tenth of it[^fn_50a_14] \[implies 'I will make\] the second like the first'.

Said R. Shimi b. Ashi: \[The number of those who report\] these traditions[^fn_50a_15] steadily diminishes,[^fn_50a_16] and your mnemonic[^fn_50a_17] is 'The young[^fn_50a_18] assigned in writing[^fn_50a_19] and spend liberally'.[^fn_50a_20]

R. Isaac stated: It was ordained at Usha[^fn_50a_21] that a man must bear[^fn_50a_22] with his son until \[he is\] twelve years \[of age\]. From that age[^fn_50a_23] onwards he may threaten[^fn_50a_24] his life.[^fn_50a_25] But could this be correct?[^fn_50a_26] Did not Rab, in fact, say to R. Samuel b. Shilath,[^fn_50a_27] 'Do not accept \[a pupil\] under the age of six; a pupil of the age of six you shall accept and stuff him like an ox'?[^fn_50a_28] — Yes, 'stuff him like an ox', but he may not 'threaten him'[^fn_50a_24] until after \[he has reached the age of\] twelve years. And if you prefer I may say: This[^fn_50a_29] is no difficulty, since one may have referred[^fn_50a_30] to Scripture[^fn_50a_31] and the other to Mishnah; for Abaye stated: Nurse[^fn_50a_32] told me that a child of six \[is ripe\] for Scripture; one of ten, for Mishnah; one of thirteen,[^fn_50a_33] for a full twenty-four hours'[^fn_50a_34] fast,[^fn_50a_35] and, in the case of a girl,[^fn_50a_36] \[one who is of\] the age of twelve.[^fn_50a_37]

Abaye stated, Nurse[^fn_50a_32] told me: A child of the age of six whom a scorpion has bitten on the day on which he has completed his sixth year does not survive \[as a rule\].[^fn_50a_38] What is his remedy? — The gall of a white stork[^fn_50a_39] in beer. This should be rubbed into the wound \[and the patient\] be made to drink it. A child of the age of one year whom a bee has stung on the day he has completed his first year does not survive \[as a rule\].[^fn_50a_38] What is his remedy? — The creepers of a palm-tree in water. This should be rubbed in and \[the patient\] be made to drink it.

Said R. Kattina: Whosoever brings his son \[to school\] under the age of six will run after hint but never overtake him.[^fn_50a_40] Others say: His fellows will run after him but will never overtake him.[^fn_50a_41] Both statements, however, are correct:[^fn_50a_42] He is feeble but learned. If you prefer I might say: The former[^fn_50a_43] applies to one[^fn_50a_44] who is emaciated; the latter, to one[^fn_50a_44] who is in good health.

R. Jose b. Hanina stated:[^fn_50a_45] At Usha[^fn_50a_46] it was ordained that if a woman had sold usufruct property[^fn_50a_47] during the lifetime of her husband and then died, the husband[^fn_50a_48] may seize it from the buyers.[^fn_50a_49] 

R. Isaac b. Joseph found R. Abbahu standing among a crowd of people.[^fn_50a_50] 'Who', he said to hint, 'is the author of the traditions of Usha?' — 'R. Jose b. Hanina', the other informed him. He learned this from him forty times and then it appeared to him as if he had it safely in his bag.[^fn_50a_51] 

Happy are they that keep justice, that do righteousness at all times.[^fn_50a_52] Is it possible to do righteousness at all times? — This, explained our Rabbis of Jabneh[^fn_50a_53] (or, as others say. R. Eliezer), refers to a man who maintains his sons and daughters[^fn_50a_54] while they are young.[^fn_50a_55] R. Samuel b. Nahmani said: This[^fn_50a_52] refers to a man who brings up an orphan boy or orphan girl in his house and enables them to marry.

Wealth and riches are in his house; and his merit endureth for ever.[^fn_50a_56] R. Huna and R. Hisda \[expounded the text in different ways\]. One said: It applies to a man who studies the Torah[^fn_50a_57] and teaches it to others;[^fn_50a_58] and the other said: It applies to a man who writes the Pentateuch, the Prophets and the Hagiographa and lends them to others.[^fn_50a_59] And see thy children's children,' peace be upon Israel.[^fn_50a_60] R. Joshua b. Levy said: As soon as your children have children there will be peace upon Israel; for they will not be subject to *halizah*[^fn_50a_61] or levirate marriage.[^fn_50a_62] R. Samuel b. Nahmani said: As soon as your children have children[^fn_50a_63] there will be peace for the judges of Israel, for \[doubtful claimants\] will not come to quarrels.[^fn_50a_64]

THIS EXPOSITION WAS MADE BY R. ELEAZAR B. AZARIAH[^fn_50a_65] IN THE PRESENCE OF THE SAGES etc. [pg 50b]

R. Joseph sat before R. Hamnuna while R. Hamnuna was sitting and discoursing: As sons may obtain their inheritance only from landed property so may one's daughters obtain their maintenance only from landed property. All shouted at him: 'Is it only from a man who leaves land that sons inherit while from him who leaves no land his sons do not inherit?'[^fn_50b_1] Said R. Joseph to him:[^fn_50b_2] Might not the Master have been speaking of the *kethubah* \[that is due to\] male children?[^fn_50b_3] The other[^fn_50b_2] replied: The Master who is a great man understood precisely what I meant.[^fn_50b_4]

R. Hiyya b. Joseph stated: Rab allowed maintenance \[to daughters\][^fn_50b_5] from wheat[^fn_50b_6] of 'aliyyah.[^fn_50b_7]

The question was raised: Was \[Rab's allowance made for\] a marriage outfit,[^fn_50b_8] and by 'aliyyah is meant,[^fn_50b_9] 'in accordance with her father's generans[^fn_50b_10] disposition', \[his ruling being\] in agreement with that of Samuel who laid down that in respect of marriage outfit the assessment[^fn_50b_11] is determined by \[the disposition of\] the father;[^fn_50b_12] or was it rather for actual maintenance,[^fn_50b_13] and by 'aliyyah was meant[^fn_50b_9] 'in accordance with the chivalrous[^fn_50b_14] enactments made[^fn_50b_15] in an upper chamber',[^fn_50b_16] for R. Isaac b. Joseph stated: In an upper chamber it was enacted that daughters shall be maintained even out of movable property?[^fn_50b_17] — Come and hear: R. Benai the brother of R. Hiyya b. Abba had in his possession orphans' movable property, and when \[he and the daughters of the deceased\] came before Samuel, the latter said to him, 'Go and provide maintenance \[for them\]'. Does not \[maintenance refer\] to actual maintenance, he being of the same opinion as R. Isaac b. Joseph?[^fn_50b_18] — No; there[^fn_50b_19] \[the claim\] was in respect of marriage outfit, and Samuel \[acted\] in accordance with his own view, since he laid down that in respect of marriage outfit the assessment[^fn_50b_20] is determined by \[the disposition of\] the father.[^fn_50b_21]

\[Such\] a case[^fn_50b_22] occurred at Nehardea,[^fn_50b_23] and the Nehardean judges issued an order[^fn_50b_24] \[in favour of the daughters\]. At Pumbeditha also[^fn_50b_25] R. Hana b. Bizna allowed \[daughters\] to collect \[for their maintenance\].[^fn_50b_26] R. Nahman, however, said to them: Proceed to withdraw \[your orders\], otherwise[^fn_50b_27] I shall order the seizure of your mansions.

R. Ammi and R. Assi intended to allow maintenance[^fn_50b_28] out of movable property.[^fn_50b_29] Said R. Jacob b. Idi to them: In a matter concerning which R. Johanan and Resh Lakish hesitated to act[^fn_50b_30] would you \[venture to\] act?

R. Eleazar intended to allow maintenance[^fn_50b_28] out of movable property.[^fn_50b_29] Said R. Simeon b. Eliakim to him: 'Master, I know that in your decision[^fn_50b_31] you are not acting on the line[^fn_50b_32] of justice but on the line of mercy, but \[the possibility ought to be considered that\] the students might observe this ruling and fix it as an *halachah* for future generations'.

A similar case[^fn_50b_33] was once submitted to[^fn_50b_34] R. Joseph. 'Give her', he ordered, 'of the dates that \[are spread\] on the reed-mat'.[^fn_50b_35] Said Abaye to him, 'Even if she were a creditor[^fn_50b_36] would the Master have allowed her \[a privilege\] of such a nature?'[^fn_50b_37] — 'What I mean is', the other said to him, '\[dates\] that are suitable[^fn_50b_38] for \[spreading on\] the reed-mat'.[^fn_50b_39] [pg 51a]

'After all, however, \[it may be objected\] is not all that is ripe[^fn_51a_1] for cutting[^fn_51a_2] regarded as already cut?'[^fn_51a_3] — 'I mean \[dates\] that are still dependent[^fn_51a_4] on the palm-tree'.[^fn_51a_5]

A boy orphan and girl orphan[^fn_51a_6] once came before Raba.[^fn_51a_7] 'Grant a bigger \[maintenance allowance\] to the boy', said Raba, 'for the sake of the girl'.[^fn_51a_8] Said the Rabbis to Raba: Did not the Master himself lay down \[that payment may be exacted\] from landed property but not from movable property whether in respect of \[a daughter's\] maintenance, \[a wife's\] *kethubah* or \[a daughter's\] marriage outfit?[^fn_51a_9] — He answered them: Had he desired to have a handmaid to attend on him would we not have granted him \[an Increased allowance for the purpose\]?[^fn_51a_10] How much more then \[should the allowance be increased\] here[^fn_51a_11] where it serves[^fn_51a_12] two \[purposes\].[^fn_51a_13]

Our Rabbis taught: Both landed property[^fn_51a_14] and movable property may be seized[^fn_51a_15] for the maintenance of a wife[^fn_51a_16] or daughters;[^fn_51a_16] so Rabbi.[^fn_51a_17] R. Simeon b. Eleazar ruled: Landed property may be seized for daughters[^fn_51a_18] from sons, for daughters from daughters,[^fn_51a_19] and for sons from Sons;[^fn_51a_19] for sons from daughters where the estate is large[^fn_51a_20] but not where it is small.[^fn_51a_21] Movable property[^fn_51a_22] may be seized for sons from sons,[^fn_51a_23] for daughters from daughters[^fn_51a_23] and for sons from daughters, but not for daughters from sons.[^fn_51a_24] Although we have an established rule that the *halachah* is in agreement with Rabbi \[where he differs\] from his colleague, the *halachah* here is in agreement with R. Simeon b. Eleazar; for Raba stated: The law is \[that payment may be exacted\] from landed property but not from movable property whether in respect of a *kethubah*, maintenance or marriage outfit.[^fn_51a_25]

***MISHNAH***. \[IF A HUSBAND\] DID NOT WRITE A *KETHUBAH* FOR HIS WIFE[^fn_51a_26] SHE MAY RECOVER TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ*[^fn_51a_27] \[IF AT MARRIAGE SHE WAS\] A VIRGIN, AND ONE *MANEH*[^fn_51a_27] \[IF SHE WAS THEN\] A WIDOW, BECAUSE \[THE STATUTORY *KETHUBAH*\] IS A CONDITION LAID DOWN BY *BETH DIN*. {¶=4.7}

IF HE ASSIGNED TO HER IN WRITING A FIELD THAT WAS WORTH ONE MANEH INSTEAD OF THE TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ*,[^fn_51a_28] AND DID NOT WRITE IN HER FAVOUR,[^fn_51a_26] 'ALL PROPERTY THAT I POSSESS IS SURETY FOR YOUR KETHUBAH',[^fn_51a_29] HE IS NEVERTHELESS LIABLE \[FOR THE FULL AMOUNT\][^fn_51a_30] BECAUSE \[THE CLAUSE MENTIONED\] IS A CONDITION LAID DOWN BY *BETH DIN*. IF HE DID NOT WRITE IN HER FAVOUR[^fn_51a_31] \[THE CLAUSE\], IF YOU ARE TAKEN CAPTIVE I WILL RANSOM YOU AND TAKE YOU AGAIN AS MY WIFE,'[^fn_51a_29] OR, IN THE CASE OF A PRIEST'S WIFE,[^fn_51a_32] '[^fn_51a_29] WILL RESTORE YOU TO YOUR PARENTAL HOME',[^fn_51a_33] HE IS NEVERTHELESS LIABLE \[TO CARRY OUT THESE OBLIGATIONS\], BECAUSE \[THE CLAUSE\] IS A CONDITION LAID DOWN BY *BETH DIN*.

IF SHE IS TAKEN CAPTIVE IT IS HIS DUTY TO RANSOM HER; AND IF HE SAID, 'HERE[^fn_51a_34] IS HER LETTER OF DIVORCE AND HER *KETHUBAH* LET HER RANSOM HERSELF', HE IS NOT ALLOWED \[TO ACT ACCORDLNGLY\].[^fn_51a_35] IF SHE SUSTAINED AN INJURY IT IS HIS DUTY TO PROVIDE FOR HER MEDICAL TREATMENT,[^fn_51a_36] BUT IF HE SAID, HERE[^fn_51a_34] IS HER LETTER OF DIVORCE AND HER *KETHUBAH*, LET HER HEAL HERSELF', HE IS ALLOWED \[TO ACT IN ACCORDANCE WITH HIS DESIRE\].

***GEMARA***. Whose \[view is represented in our Mishnah\]? It is \[obviously that of\] R. Meir who ruled \[that the intercourse of\] any man who undertakes to give a virgin less than two hundred *zuz*[^fn_51a_37] or a widow less than 'a *Maneh*[^fn_51a_37] is[^fn_51a_38] an act of prostitution;[^fn_51a_39] for if \[it be suggested that it is the view of\] R. Judah, he surely, \[it can be objected\] ruled, \[that if a husband\] wished he may write out for a virgin[^fn_51a_40] a deed for two hundred *zuz* and she writes \[a quittance\][^fn_51a_41] 'I have received from you a *maneh*,' and for a widow \[he may write out a deed for\] a *maneh* and she writes \[a quittance\], 'I received from you fifty zuz'.[^fn_51a_42] Read, however, the final clause: IF HE ASSIGNED TO HER IN WRITING A FIELD THAT WAS WORTH ONE *MANEH* INSTEAD OF THE TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ*, AND DID NOT WRITE IN HER FAVOUR, ALL PROPERTY THAT I POSSESS[^fn_51a_43] IS SURETY FOR YOUR KETHUBAH' HE IS NEVERTHELESS LIABLE \[FOR THE FULL AMOUNT\], BECAUSE \[THE CLAUSE MENTIONED\] IS A CONDITION LAID DOWN BY *BETH DIN*. Does not this obviously represent the view[^fn_51a_44] of R. Judah who laid down that \[the omission from a bond of the clause\] pledging property[^fn_51a_45] \[is regarded as\] the scribe's error?[^fn_51a_46] for if \[It be suggested that it represents the view of\] R. Meir, he, surely, \[it can be objected\] ruled that \[the omission of the clause\] pledging property is not \[regarded as\] the scribe's error. For we have learned: If a man found notes of indebtedness [pg 51b]

he must not restore them[^fn_51b_1] if they contain a clause pledging property, because the court would exact payment from such property,[^fn_51b_2] but if they do not contain the clause pledging property, he must return them, because the court will not exact payment from the property;[^fn_51b_3] so R. Meir. The Sages,[^fn_51b_4] however, ruled: In either case he must not return them, because the court will exact payment from the property[^fn_51b_5] \[in any case\].[^fn_51b_6] Would then the first clause \[represent the view of\] R. Meir and the final clause that of R. Judah? And should you suggest that both clauses[^fn_51b_7] \[represent the view of\] R. Meir and that he draws a distinction between a *kethubah* and notes of indebtedness,[^fn_51b_8] \[it could be retorted\] does he, indeed, draw such a distinction? Has it not been taught: For five \[classes of claims\] may distraint be made only on free assets;[^fn_51b_9] they are as follows. \[A claim for\] produce,[^fn_51b_10] for amelioration shewing profits,[^fn_51b_11] for an undertaking[^fn_51b_12] to maintain the wife's son or the wife's daughter, for a note of indebtedness wherein no lien on property had been entered, and for a woman's *kethubah* from which the clause pledging security was omitted.[^fn_51b_13] Now what authority have you heard laying down that \[the omission from a deed of a record of\] a lien on property is not regarded as the scribe's error?[^fn_51b_14] \[Obviously it is\] R. Meir;[^fn_51b_15] and yet it was stated, was it not, 'a woman's kethubah'?[^fn_51b_16] — If you wish, I might reply: \[Our Mishnah represents the view of\] R. Meir; and if you prefer I might reply: \[It represents the View of\] R. Judah. 'If you prefer I might reply: \[It represents the view of\] R. Judah', for there[^fn_51b_17] she specifically

         wrote in the man's favour[^fn_51b_18] \[in a quittance\]: 'I received'[^fn_51b_19] but here[^fn_51b_20] she did not write in his favour,[^fn_51b_18] 'I received'.[^fn_51b_21] 'If you wish I might reply: \[Our Mishnah represents the view of\] R. Meir', for by the expression[^fn_51b_22] 'HE IS NEVERTHELESS LIABLE' \[was meant liability to pay\] out of his free assets.[^fn_51b_23]

IF HE DID NOT WRITE IN HER FAVOUR etc. Samuel's father ruled: The wife of an Israelite who had been outraged is forbidden to her husband, since it may be apprehended that the act begun[^fn_51b_24] under compulsion may have terminated[^fn_51b_25] with her consent.[^fn_51b_26]

Rab raised an objection against Samuel's father: \[Have we not learned,\] IF YOU ARE TAKEN CAPTIVE I WILL RANSOM YOU AND TAKE YOU AGAIN AS MY WIFE?[^fn_51b_27] The other remained silent. Rab thereupon applied to Samuel's father the Scriptural text, The princes refrained talking and laid their hand on their mouth.[^fn_51b_28] What, however, could he have replied?[^fn_51b_29] — \[That the law\][^fn_51b_30] was relaxed in the case of a captive.[^fn_51b_31]

According to Samuel's father's ruling how is it possible to conceive a case of outrage which the All-Merciful deemed to be genuine?[^fn_51b_32] — Where, for instance, witnesses testified that she cried from the commencement to the end.

\[This ruling\],[^fn_51b_33] however, differs from that of Raba; for Raba laid down: Any woman, the outrage against whom began[^fn_51b_34] under

         compulsion, though it terminated with her consent, and even if she said, 'Leave him alone', and that if he had not made the attack upon her she would have hired him to do it, is permitted \[to her husband\]. What is the reason? — He plunged[^fn_51b_35] her into an uncontrollable passion.[^fn_51b_36]

It was taught in agreement with Raba: And she be not seized[^fn_51b_37] \[only then\][^fn_51b_38] is she forbidden,[^fn_51b_39] \[from which it follows\] that if she was seized[^fn_51b_40] she is permitted.[^fn_51b_39] But there is another class of woman who is permitted[^fn_51b_39] even if she was not seized.[^fn_51b_41] And who is that? Any woman who began[^fn_51b_42] under compulsion and ended[^fn_51b_43] with her consent.

Another Baraitha taught: 'And she be not seized' \[only then\] is she forbidden[^fn_51b_44] \[from which it follows\] that if she was seized[^fn_51b_45] she is permitted.[^fn_51b_44] But there is another class of woman who is forbidden[^fn_51b_44] even though she was seized. And who is that? The wife of a priest.[^fn_51b_46]

Rab Judah stated in the name of Samuel who had it from R. Ishmael: 'And she be not seized', \[then only\][^fn_51b_47] is she forbidden,[^fn_51b_44] but if she was seized she is permitted. There is, however, another class of woman who is permitted even if she was not seized. And who is that? A woman whose betrothal was a mistaken one,[^fn_51b_48] and who may, even if her son sits riding on her shoulder, make a declaration of refusal[^fn_51b_49] \[against her husband\] and go away.

Rab Judah ruled: Women who are kidnapped[^fn_51b_50] are permitted to their husbands.[^fn_51b_51] 'But', said the Rabbis to Rab Judah, 'do they[^fn_51b_52] not bring bread to them?'[^fn_51b_53] — \[They do this\] out of fear. 'Do they[^fn_51b_52] not, however, hand them[^fn_51b_53] their arrows?'[^fn_51b_54] — \[They do this also\] out of fear. It is certain, however, that they[^fn_51b_52] are forbidden if \[the kidnappers\] release then, and they go to them of their own free will.

Our Rabbis taught: Royal captives[^fn_51b_55] have the status of ordinary captives[^fn_51b_56] but those that are kidnapped by highwaymen are not regarded as ordinary captives. Was not, the reverse, however, taught? — There is no contradiction between the rulings concerning royal captives[^fn_51b_57] since the former refers[^fn_51b_58] \[for example\] to the kingdom of Ahasuerus[^fn_51b_59] while the latter refers[^fn_51b_60] to the kingdom of \[one like\] Ben Nezer.[^fn_51b_61] There is also no contradiction between the two rulings concerning captives of highwaymen[^fn_51b_62] since the former refers[^fn_51b_60] to \[a highwayman like\] Ben Nezer[^fn_51b_61] while the latter refers[^fn_51b_60] to an ordinary highwayman.[^fn_51b_63]

As to Ben Nezer, could he be called there[^fn_51b_64] 'king' and here[^fn_51b_65] 'highwayman'? — Yes; in comparison with Ahasuerus he was a highwayman but in comparison with an ordinary robber he was a king.

OR, IN THE CASE OF A PRIEST'S WIFE, 'I WILL RESTORE YOU TO YOUR PARENTAL HOME' etc. Abaye ruled: If a widow was married to a High Priest[^fn_51b_66] it is the latter's duty to ransom[^fn_51b_67] her, since one may apply to her: OR IN THE CASE OF A PRIEST'S WIFE, I WILL RESTORE YOU TO YOUR PARENTAL HOME',[^fn_51b_68] [pg 52a]

but if a bastard or a nethinah[^fn_52a_1] was married to an Israelite the latter is under no obligation to ransom her, since one cannot apply to her:[^fn_52a_2] AND TAKE YOU AGAIN AS MY WIFE.[^fn_52a_3] Raba ruled: Wherever the captivity causes the woman to be forbidden[^fn_52a_4] \[to her husband\] it is his duty to ransom her[^fn_52a_5] but where some other circumstance causes her to be forbidden to him[^fn_52a_6] it is not his duty to ransom her.[^fn_52a_7]

Must it be assumed \[that they[^fn_52a_8] differ on the same principles\] as the following Tannaim? \[For it was taught:\] If a man forbade his wife by a vow \[from deriving any benefit from him\] and she was taken captive, he must, said R. Eliezer, ransom her[^fn_52a_9] and give her also her *kethubah*. R. Joshua said: He must give her her *kethubah* but need not ransom her. Said R. Nathan: I asked Symmachus, 'When R. Joshua said, "He must give her her *kethubah* but need not ransom her" \[did he refer to a case\] where her husband first made his vow against her and she was then taken captive or even to a case where she was first taken captive and he made his vow against her subsequently?'[^fn_52a_10] And he told me, 'I did not hear \[what he exactly said\] but it seems \[that he referred to\] a case where \[the husband\] made the vow against her first and the woman was taken captive afterwards; for, should you suggest \[that the ruling applied also to a woman who\] was taken captive first and the man made his vow against her afterwards \[the objection could be raised that in such a case\] he might make use of a trick'.[^fn_52a_11] Do not they[^fn_52a_12] then differ[^fn_52a_13] in \[the case of one\] who made a vow against the wife of a priest,[^fn_52a_14] Abaye upholding the view of R. Eliezer[^fn_52a_15] while Raba IS maintaining that of R. Joshua?[^fn_52a_16] — No;[^fn_52a_17] here[^fn_52a_18] we are dealing \[with the case of a woman\] who, for instance, made the vow herself and her husband[^fn_52a_19] confirmed it,[^fn_52a_20] R. Eliezer being of the opinion that it was he[^fn_52a_21] who put his finger between her teeth[^fn_52a_22] while R. Joshua maintains that it was she herself who put her finger between her teeth.[^fn_52a_23]

\[But\] If she herself put her finger between her teeth what claim can she have to her[^fn_52a_24] *kethubah*? And, furthermore, \[it was stated\]: Said R. Nathan: I asked Symmachus, 'When R. Joshua said, "He must give her her *kethubah* but need not ransom her" \[did he refer to a case\] where her husband first made his vow against her and she was then taken captive or even to a case where she was first taken captive and he made his vow against her subsequently?' and he told me: 'I did not hear \[what he exactly said\]'. Now if \[this is a case\] where she herself had made the vow, what difference is there \[it may be asked\] whether he made the vow first against her[^fn_52a_25] and she was taken captive afterwards or whether she was first taken captive and he then made the vow?[^fn_52a_26] — The fact is that \[here[^fn_52a_27] it is a case where\] the husband made the vow against her, but Abaye explains \[the dispute\][^fn_52a_28] on the lines of his view while Raba explains it on the lines of his view. 'Abaye explains the dispute on the lines of his view', thus: If a widow \[was married\] to a High Priest no one[^fn_52a_29] disputes \[the ruling\] that it is the husband's duty to ransom her;[^fn_52a_30] if a bastard or a nethinah \[was married\] to an Israelite no one[^fn_52a_29] disputes the ruling that it is not his duty to ransom her,[^fn_52a_31] if also one made a vow against the wife of a priest[^fn_52a_32] no one[^fn_52a_29] disputes the ruling that it is his duty to ransom her, since \[the principle in this case\] is identical with that of a widow \[who was married\] to a High Priest.[^fn_52a_33] They[^fn_52a_34] differ only in \[respect of him who\] made a vow against the wife of an Israelite,[^fn_52a_35] R. Eliezer being guided by the woman's original status[^fn_52a_36] while R. Joshua is guided by her subsequent status.[^fn_52a_37] 'Raba explains it on the lines of his view', thus: If a widow \[was married\] to a High Priest, or a bastard or a nethinah to an Israelite no one[^fn_52a_38] disputes the ruling that it is not the husband's duty to ransom her.[^fn_52a_39] They[^fn_52a_40] differ only in \[the case where one\] made a vow against either the wife of a priest or the wife of an Israelite,[^fn_52a_41] R. Eliezer being guided by the woman's original status[^fn_52a_36] while R. Joshua is guided by her subsequent status.[^fn_52a_37]

IF SHE IS TAKEN CAPTIVE IT IS HIS DUTY TO RANSOM HER etc. Our Rabbis taught: If she was taken captive during the lifetime of her husband, and he died afterwards, and her husband was aware of her \[captivity\],[^fn_52a_42] it is the duty of his heirs to ransom her, but if her husband was not aware of her captivity it is not the duty of his heirs to ransom her.

Levi proposed to give a practical decision[^fn_52a_43] in agreement with this Baraitha. Said Rab to him, Thus said my uncle:[^fn_52a_44] The law is not in agreement with that Baraitha but with the following[^fn_52a_45] wherein it was taught: \[If a woman\] was taken captive after the death of her husband it is not the duty of his orphans to ransom her, and, furthermore,[^fn_52a_46] even if she was taken captive during the lifetime of her husband, but he died subsequently, the orphans are under no obligation to ransom her, since one cannot apply to her \[the clause in her *kethubah*:\] AND I WILL TAKE YOU AGAIN AS MY WIFE.[^fn_52a_47]

Our Rabbis taught: \[If a woman\] was taken captive and a demand was made upon her husband for as much as ten times her value, he must ransom her the first time. Subsequently, however, he ransoms her only if he desired to do so but need not ransom her[^fn_52a_48] if he does not wish to do so. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel ruled: [pg 52b]

Captives must not be ransomed for more than their value, in the interests of the public.[^fn_52b_1] \[This then implies\] that they must be ransomed for their actual value even though the cost of a captive's ransom[^fn_52b_2] exceeds the amount of her *kethubah*. Has not, however, the contrary been taught: \[If a woman\] was taken captive, and a demand was made upon her husband for as much as ten times the amount of her *kethubah*[^fn_52b_3] he must ransom her the first time. Subsequently, however, he ransoms her only if he desires to do so but need not ransom her if he does not wish to do so. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel ruled: If the price of her ransom corresponded to the amount of her *kethubah*, he must ransom her; if not, he[^fn_52b_4] need not ransom her?[^fn_52b_5] — R. Simeon b. Gamaliel upholds two lenient rules.[^fn_52b_6] IF SHE SUSTAINED AN INJURY IT IS HIS DUTY TO PROVIDE FOR HER MEDICAL TREATMENT. Our Rabbis taught: A widow is to be maintained from \[her husband's\] orphans' estate; and if she requires medical treatment, it is regarded[^fn_52b_7] as maintenance. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel ruled: Medical treatment of a limited liability may be deducted[^fn_52b_8] from her *kethubah* but one which has no limited liability[^fn_52b_9] is regarded[^fn_52b_10] as maintenance. Said R. Johanan: Blood letting in the Land of Israel[^fn_52b_11] was regarded as medical treatment of no limited liability.[^fn_52b_12] R. Johanan's relatives had \[to maintain\] their father's wife who required daily medical treatment. When they came to R. Johanan[^fn_52b_13] he told them: Proceed to arrange with a medical man an inclusive fee.[^fn_52b_14] \[Later, however\], R. Johanan remarked: 'We have put ourselves \[in the unenviable position\] of[^fn_52b_15] legal advisers'.[^fn_52b_16] What, however, was his opinion at first,[^fn_52b_17] and why did he change it in the end![^fn_52b_18] At first he thought \[of the Scriptural text,\] And that thou hide not thyself from thine own flesh,[^fn_52b_19] but ultimately he realized \[that the position of\] a noted personality is different \[from that of the general public\].[^fn_52b_20]

***MISHNAH***. \[A HUSBAND WHO\] DID NOT GIVE HIS WIFE IN WRITING[^fn_52b_21] \[THE FOLLOWING UNDERTAKING:\] 'THE MALE CHILDREN THAT WILL BE BORN FROM OUR MARRIAGE[^fn_52b_22] SHALL INHERIT THE MONEY OF THY *KETHUBAH* IN ADDITION TO THEIR SHARES WITH THEIR BROTHERS',[^fn_52b_23] IS NEVERTHELESS LIABLE, BECAUSE \[THIS CLAUSE\] IS A CONDITION LAID DOWN BY *BETH DIN*. \[THOUGH HE DID NOT GIVE HIS WIFE IN WRITING[^fn_52b_24] THE UNDERTAKING:\] 'THE FEMALE CHILDREN THAT WILL BE BORN FROM OUR MARRIAGE[^fn_52b_25] SHALL DWELL IN MY HOUSE AND BE MAINTAINED OUT OF MY ESTATE UNTIL THEY SHALL BE TAKEN IN MAKRIAGE'[^fn_52b_26] HE IS NEVERTHELESS LIABLE, BECAUSE \[THIS CLAUSE\] IS A CONDITION LAID DOWN BY *BETH DIN*. \[SIMILARLY IF HE DID NOT GIVE HIS WIFE THE WRITTEN UNDERTAKING:\][^fn_52b_27] 'YOU SHALL DWELL IN MY HOUSE AND BE MAINTAINED THEREIN OUT OF MY ESTATE THROUGHOUT THE DURATION OF YOUR WIDOWHOOD', HE IS NEVERTHELESS LIABLE, BECAUSE \[THIS CLAUSE ALSO\] IS A CONDITION LAID DOWN BY *BETH DIN*. SO DID THE MEN OF JERUSALEM WRITE. THE MEN OF GALILEE WROTE IN THE SAME MANNER AS THE MEN OF JERUSALEM. THE MEN OF JUDAEA, HOWEVER, USED TO WRITE:[^fn_52b_28] 'UNTIL THE HEIRS MAY CONSENT TO PAY YOU YOUR KETHUBAH'. THE HEIRS, CONSEQUENTLY, MAY, IF THEY WISH TO DO IT, PAY HER HER *KETHUBAH* AND DISMISS HER. {¶=4.8}

***GEMARA***. R. Johanan stated in the name of R. Simeon b. Yohai: Why was the *kethubah* for MALE CHILDREN[^fn_52b_29] instituted?[^fn_52b_30] In order that any man might thereby[^fn_52b_31] be encouraged[^fn_52b_32] to give[^fn_52b_33] to his daughter as much as to his son. But is such a regulation found anywhere else?[^fn_52b_34] Seeing that the All-Merciful ordained that a son shall be heir; a daughter shall not',[^fn_52b_35] would the Rabbis proceed to make a provision[^fn_52b_36] whereby a daughter shall be the heir? — This[^fn_52b_37] also has Scriptural sanction, for it is written, Take ye wives, and beget sons and daughters,' and take wives far your sans, and give your daughters to husbands;[^fn_52b_38] \[now the advice to take wives for one's\] sons is quite intelligible \[since such marriages are\] within a father's power[^fn_52b_39] but \[as to the giving of\] one's daughters \[the difficulty arises:\] Is \[such giving\] within his power?[^fn_52b_39] \[Consequently[^fn_52b_40] it must be\] this that we were taught: That a father must provide for his daughter clothing and covering and must also give her a dowry[^fn_52b_41] so that people may be anxious to woo[^fn_52b_42] her and so proceed to marry her. And to what extent?[^fn_52b_43] Both Abaye and Raba ruled: Up to a tenth of his wealth. But might it not be suggested[^fn_52b_44] \[that the sons\] should inherit \[what their mother received\] from her father[^fn_52b_45] but not \[that which was due to her\] from her husband?[^fn_52b_46] — If that were so, a father also would abstain from assigning[^fn_52b_47] \[a liberal dowry for his daughter\].[^fn_52b_48] May it then be suggested[^fn_52b_44] that where her father had assigned a dowry[^fn_52b_49] her husband must also enter the clause[^fn_52b_50] but where her father did not assign any dowry[^fn_52b_51] her husband also need not enter the clause?[^fn_52b_52] — The Rabbis drew no distinction.[^fn_52b_53] But should not then[^fn_52b_54] a daughter[^fn_52b_55] among sons[^fn_52b_56] also be heir?[^fn_52b_57] — The Rabbis have treated \[the *kethubah*\][^fn_52b_58] like an inheritance.[^fn_52b_59] But should not then a daughter[^fn_52b_55] among the other daughters[^fn_52b_56] be heir?[^fn_52b_60] — The Rabbis made no distinction.[^fn_52b_61] Why then[^fn_52b_62] is not \[the *kethubah*\] recoverable[^fn_52b_63] from movables also?[^fn_52b_64] — The Rabbis treated it like the \[statutory\] *kethubah*.[^fn_52b_65] Why then should not distraint be made on sold or mortgaged property?[^fn_52b_66] — \[The expression\] we learned \[was\] SHALL INHERIT.[^fn_52b_67] May it then[^fn_52b_62] be suggested \[that It Is recoverable\] even if there was no surplus[^fn_52b_68] of a *denar*?[^fn_52b_69] — The Rabbis have made no enactment where the Pentateuchal law of inheritance would thereby be uprooted. R. Papa was making arrangements for his son to be married into the house of Abba of Sura.[^fn_52b_70] He went there to write the *kethubah* for the bride.[^fn_52b_71] When Judah b. Meremar heard \[of his arrival\] he went out to welcome him.[^fn_52b_72] When, however, they reached the door \[of the bride's father's house\] he asked leave to depart, when \[R. Papa\] said to him, 'Will the Master come in with me?' [pg 53a]

Observing, however, that it was distasteful to him \[to enter\], he addressed him thus: 'What is it that you have on your mind? \[Are you reluctant to enter\] because Samuel said to Rab Judah, "Shinena,[^fn_53a_1] keep away from[^fn_53a_2] transfers of inheritance[^fn_53a_3] even though they be from a bad son to a good son, because one never knows what issue will come forth from him,[^fn_53a_4] and much more so \[when the transfer is\] from a son to a daughter",[^fn_53a_5] this[^fn_53a_6] also \[I may point out\] is an enactment of the Rabbis; as R. Johanan stated in the name of R. Simeon b. Yohai',[^fn_53a_7] The other replied, 'This enactment applies only \[to one who acts\] willingly;[^fn_53a_8] does it also imply that one should be compelled so to act?' — 'Did I tell you' said \[R. Papa\] to him, 'to come in and coerce him? What I meant was: Come in but exercise no pressure upon him'. 'My entrance', the other replied, 'would amount to compulsion'.[^fn_53a_9] \[As R. Papa, however,\] urged him, he entered but, having sat down, remained silent.[^fn_53a_10] \[Abba\] thought that he[^fn_53a_11] was vexed[^fn_53a_12] and consequently assigned[^fn_53a_13] \[to his daughter as dowry\] all that he possessed. Finally, however, he said to him,[^fn_53a_11] 'Will not the Master speak even now? By the life of the Master, I have left nothing for myself!' — 'As far as I am concerned',[^fn_53a_14] the other replied, 'even the amount you have assigned[^fn_53a_15] has given me no pleasure'. 'This being the case',[^fn_53a_16] the first said, 'I will withdraw'. 'l did not suggest', the other said, 'that you should make a rogue[^fn_53a_17] of yourself'.

R. Yemar the Elder enquired of R. Nahman: Does a woman who sold her *kethubah* to her husband retain the right to the *kethubah* for her male children[^fn_53a_18] or not?[^fn_53a_19] — Said Raba to him: Why do you not raise the same question in the case of a woman who surrendered her claim \[to her *kethubah*\]?[^fn_53a_20] 'Now', the other replied, 'that I \[found it necessary to\] enquire \[concerning a woman\] who sold \[her *kethubah*\],[^fn_53a_21] though \[in that case\] it might well be assumed \[that her need for\] money compelled her \[to the sale; and, furthermore,\] it might be said \[that she is\] like a person who was struck a hundred blows with a hammer,[^fn_53a_22] was it then necessary \[to raise the same question in respect of\] a woman who \[voluntarily\] surrendered her claim \[to her *kethubah*\]?[^fn_53a_23]

Raba stated: I have no doubt[^fn_53a_24] that a woman who sells[^fn_53a_25] her *kethubah* to strangers[^fn_53a_26] retains the right to the male children's *kethubah*.' What is the reason? \[It is her need for\] money that has compelled her \[to sell\].[^fn_53a_27] A woman \[on the other hand\] who surrenders her claim \[to her *kethubah*\] in favour of her husband does not retain the right to the male children's *kethubah*. What is the reason? She has lightheartedly surrendered her claims.[^fn_53a_28] \[Is, however, a woman,\] Raba enquired, who sells her *kethubah* to her husband treated as one who sells it to strangers,[^fn_53a_29] or as one who renounces it in favour of her husband?[^fn_53a_30] After he raised the question he himself solved it: \[The law concerning\] a Woman who sells her *kethubah* to her husband is the same as that of one who sells it to strangers.[^fn_53a_29]

R. Idi b. Abin raised an objection: \[We learned\]: If she[^fn_53a_31] died, neither the heirs of the one husband nor the heirs of the other are entitled to inherit her *kethubah*.[^fn_53a_32] And in considering the difficulty, 'How does the question of a *kethubah* at all arise?'[^fn_53a_33] R. Papa replied, 'The *kethubah* of the male children \[was meant\]'.[^fn_53a_34] But why?[^fn_53a_35] Could not one[^fn_53a_36] argue here also:[^fn_53a_37] 'Her passion has overpowered her'?[^fn_53a_38] — There[^fn_53a_39] \[the loss of her *kethubah*\] is a penalty that the Rabbis have imposed upon her.[^fn_53a_40]

Rabin b. Hanina once sat \[at his studies\] before R. Hisda and in the course of the session he laid down in the name of R. Eleazar: A woman who surrenders her *kethubah* to her husband is not entitled to maintenance.[^fn_53a_41] The other[^fn_53a_42] said to him: Had you not spoken to me in the name of a great man I would have told you: Whoso rewardeth evil for good, evil shall not depart from his house.[^fn_53a_43]

R. Nahman and 'Ulla and Abimi son of R. Papi once sat at their studies, and R. Hiyya b. Ammi was sitting with them when there came before them a man whose betrothed wife had died.[^fn_53a_44] 'Go and bury her', they said to him, 'or pay her *kethubah* on her account',[^fn_53a_45] Said R. Hiyya to them, We have a teaching:[^fn_53a_46] In the case of a betrothed wife[^fn_53a_47] \[the husband\] is subject neither to the laws of onan,[^fn_53a_48] nor may he defile himself for her;[^fn_53a_49] and she likewise[^fn_53a_50] is not subject to the laws of onan,[^fn_53a_51] nor may she defile herself for him;[^fn_53a_52] if she dies he is not her heir,[^fn_53a_53] but if he dies she collects her *kethubah*.[^fn_53a_54] Now the reason \[why she collects her *kethubah* is\] because it was he who died; had she, however, died she would not have been entitled to any *kethubah*.[^fn_53a_55] What is the reason?[^fn_53a_56] — R. Hoshaia replied: Because one cannot apply to her: 'If you will be married to another man you will receive what is prescribed for you'.[^fn_53a_57] 

When Rabin came[^fn_53a_58] he stated in the name of Resh Lakish: If a betrothed woman died, she is not entitled to a *kethubah*. Said Abaye to them:[^fn_53a_59] Go and tell him: [pg 53b]

'You are deprived of your benefaction;[^fn_53b_1] it is cast upon the thorns',[^fn_53b_2] for R. Hoshaia has already expounded his traditional teachings[^fn_53b_3] in Babylon.[^fn_53b_4]

THE FEMALE CHILDREN THAT WILL BE BORN FROM OUR MARRIAGE etc. Rab[^fn_53b_5] taught: Until they shall be taken in marriage;[^fn_53b_6] but Levi taught: Until they shall attain adolescence.[^fn_53b_7] \[Would daughters then be maintained\] according to Rab although they attained adolescence, and according[^fn_53b_8] to Levi even though they married?[^fn_53b_9] — The fact, however, \[is that where a daughter\] attained adolescence though she was not married or where she was married though she did not attain adolescence no one[^fn_53b_10] disputes \[the ruling that she is not entitled to maintenance\]. They[^fn_53b_11] differ only on the question of a \[daughter who was\] betrothed but did not attain adolescence.[^fn_53b_12]

So also did Levi teach in his Baraitha:[^fn_53b_13] Until they shall attain adolescence and the time for their marriages arrives. Both?[^fn_53b_14] — What was meant is this:[^fn_53b_15] Either they shall attain adolescence or[^fn_53b_16] the time for their marriage[^fn_53b_17] shall arrive.

\[They[^fn_53b_18] differ on the same principles\] as the following Tannaim: How long is a daughter to be maintained? Until she is betrothed. In the name of R. Eleazar it was stated: Until she attains adolescence.

R. Joseph learnt: \[Daughters must be maintained\] until they become \[wives\]. The question was raised: Does this[^fn_53b_19] mean becoming \[wives\] at marriage or becoming \[wives\] at betrothal? — The question must stand unanswered.[^fn_53b_20]

Said R. Hisda to R. Joseph: Did you ever hear from Rab Judah whether a betrothed \[orphan\] is entitled to maintenance[^fn_53b_21] or not?[^fn_53b_22] The other replied: I have not actually heard it, but it may logically be concluded that she is not entitled, because \[her future husband\], having betrothed her, would not allow[^fn_53b_23] her to be degraded.[^fn_53b_24] 'If you have not actually heard this', \[R. Hisda\] retorted 'it may logically be concluded that she is entitled, for \[her intended husband\], not being sure of her,[^fn_53b_25] would not throw his money away for nothing'.[^fn_53b_26] 

Another reading:[^fn_53b_27] He[^fn_53b_28] replied: I have not actually heard it, but it may logically be concluded that she is entitled \[to maintenance\]; for \[her intended husband\], not being sure of her, would not throw his money away for nothing. The other[^fn_53b_29] retorted: If you have not actually heard this it may logically be concluded that she is not entitled to maintenance; because \[her future husband\], having betrothed her, would not allow her to be degraded. (Mnemonic of the men:[^fn_53b_30] SHaK ZaRaP.[^fn_53b_31] \[Subjects:\] She refused and a sister-in-law of the second degree is betrothed and he outraged her.)

R. Shesheth was asked: Is a minor who exercised her right of refusal[^fn_53b_32] entitled to maintenance[^fn_53b_33] or not?[^fn_53b_34] — You, replied R. Shesheth, have learned this: A widow[^fn_53b_35] in her father's house, a divorced woman[^fn_53b_35] in her father's house or a woman[^fn_53b_35] who was awaiting the decision of a levir[^fn_53b_36] in her father's house is entitled to maintenance. R. Judah ruled: \[Only a woman who\] is still in her father's house is entitled to maintenance but \[a woman who\] is no longer in her father's house is not entitled to maintenance. \[Now is not\] R. Judah's ruling exactly the same as that of the first Tanna?[^fn_53b_37] Consequently it may be concluded that[^fn_53b_38] the difference between them is the case of a minor who had exercised her right of refusal,[^fn_53b_39] the first Tanna being of the opinion that she is entitled \[to maintenance\][^fn_53b_40] while R. Judah upholds the view that she is not entitled to it.[^fn_53b_41]

Resh Lakish enquired: Is the daughter of a sister-in-law[^fn_53b_42] entitled to maintenance[^fn_53b_43] or not? Has she no claim to it, since the Master said,[^fn_53b_44] Her *kethubah* is a charge on the estate of her first husband[^fn_53b_45] or is it possible that she is entitled to it since the Rabbis have enacted that whenever she[^fn_53b_46] is unable to collect her *kethubah* from \[the estate of\] the first, she may recover it from that of the second?[^fn_53b_47] — The question must remain unanswered.[^fn_53b_48]

R. Eleazar enquired: Is the daughter of a forbidden relative of the second degree of incest[^fn_53b_49] entitled to maintenance[^fn_53b_50] or not? [pg 54a]

Has she no claim to maintenance[^fn_54a_1] since \[her mother\] is not entitled to a *kethubah*, or is it likely that the Rabbis have imposed a penalty only upon her mother who had committed a transgression but not upon her who had committed no transgression? — This remains unanswered.

Raba asked: Is the daughter of a betrothed wife entitled to maintenance[^fn_54a_2] or not? Is she entitled to maintenance[^fn_54a_3] since \[her mother\] is entitled to a *kethubah*[^fn_54a_4] or is it possible that she is not entitled \[to maintenance\],[^fn_54a_3] since the Rabbis have not ordained \[the writing of\] the *kethubah* until the time of the marriage?[^fn_54a_5] — The question must stand unanswered.

R. Papa asked: Is the daughter of an outraged woman[^fn_54a_6] entitled to maintenance[^fn_54a_2] or not? According to the ruling of R. Jose the son of R. Judah, who has laid down[^fn_54a_7] that \[her mother\] is entitled to recover[^fn_54a_8] a *kethubah* for one *maneh*,[^fn_54a_9] the question does not arise.[^fn_54a_10] It arises only according to the ruling of the Rabbis who have laid down that the fine[^fn_54a_11] is regarded as a quittance for her *kethubah*. What, \[it may be asked, is the decision\]?[^fn_54a_12] Has she no claim to maintenance[^fn_54a_13] since \[her mother\] is not entitled to a *kethubah*,[^fn_54a_14] or might it possibly \[be argued thus:\] What is the reason why a *kethubah* \[has been instituted for a wife\]? In order that the man might not find it easy[^fn_54a_15] to divorce her;[^fn_54a_16] but \[this man\],[^fn_54a_17] surely, cannot[^fn_54a_18] divorce her?[^fn_54a_19] — This must stand unanswered.

YOU SHALL DWELL IN MY HOUSE etc. R. Joseph learnt: IN MY HOUSE[^fn_54a_20] but not in my hovel.[^fn_54a_21] She is entitled, however, to maintenance.[^fn_54a_22] Mar son of R. Ashi ruled: She is not entitled even to maintenance.[^fn_54a_23] The law, however, is not in agreement with Mar son of R. Ashi.

R. Nahman stated in the name of Samuel: If marriage was proposed to her[^fn_54a_24] and she accepted, she is no longer entitled to maintenance.[^fn_54a_25] \[This is to imply that\] if she did not accept,[^fn_54a_26] she would not be entitled to maintenance! — R. Anan replied: This was explained to me by Mar Samuel: If she said, '\[l cannot accept the proposal\] out of respect for the memory of[^fn_54a_27] So-and-so, my husband', she is entitled to maintenance; \[but if she said\], 'Because the men are not suitable for me,' she is not entitled to maintenance.[^fn_54a_28]

R. Hisda ruled: If she[^fn_54a_29] played the harlot she is not entitled to maintenance. R. Joseph ruled: If she painted her eyes[^fn_54a_30] or dyed her hair[^fn_54a_31] she is not entitled to maintenance.[^fn_54a_32] He who ruled: 'If she played the harlot'[^fn_54a_33] would even more so deprive her of maintenance if she paints her eyes or dyes her hair. He, however, who ruled: 'If she painted her eyes or dyed her hair'[^fn_54a_33] would allow her maintenance[^fn_54a_34] if she played the harlot. What is the reason? — Her passions have overpowered her.

The law, however, is not in agreement with any of these reported rulings but with that which Rab Judah laid down in the name of Samuel: She[^fn_54a_35] who claims her *kethubah* at court is not entitled to maintenance. But is she not entitled? Surely it was taught: If she sold her *kethubah*, pledged it, or mortgaged \[the land that was pledged[^fn_54a_36] for\] her *kethubah* to a stranger, she is not entitled to maintenance. \[Does not this imply\] that only such[^fn_54a_37] \[acts deprive a widow of her maintenance\] but not \[the act of\] claiming \[her *kethubah* at court\]? — These \[acts[^fn_54a_38] deprive her of her maintenance\] whether she appeared at court or not, but the act of claiming \[her *kethubah* deprives her of maintenance\] only if she appeared[^fn_54a_39] in court but does not \[deprive her of it\] if she did not appear at court.

SO DID THE MEN OF JERUSALEM etc. It was stated: Rab ruled, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with \[the practice of\] the MEN OF JUDAEA', but Samuel ruled, 'The *halachah* agrees with \[the practice of\] the MEN OF GALILEE'.

Babylon[^fn_54a_40] and all its neighbouring towns[^fn_54a_41] followed a usage in agreement with the ruling of Rab; Nehardea[^fn_54a_42] and all its neighbouring towns[^fn_54a_41] followed a usage agreeing with the ruling of Samuel.

A woman of Mahuza[^fn_54a_43] was once married to \[a man of\] Nehardea. When they came to R. Nahman,[^fn_54a_44] and he observed from her voice that she was a native of Mahuza, he said to them, '\[The decision must be in agreement with Rab, for\] Babylon and all its neighbouring towns have adopted a usage in agreement with the ruling of Rab'. When, however, they pointed out to him, 'But, surely, she is married to \[a man of\] Nehardea,' he said to them, 'If that is the case, \[the decision will be in agreement with Samuel for\] Nehardea and all its neighbouring towns followed a usage agreeing with the ruling of Samuel. How far does \[the usage of\] Nehardea extend? — As far afield as the Nehardean *kab*[^fn_54a_45] is in use.[^fn_54a_46]

It was stated: \[When a *kethubah* is being paid to\] a widow, said Rab, assessment is made of what she wears,[^fn_54a_47] but Samuel said: That which she wears is not assessed. Said R. Hiyya b. Abin: \[Their opinions[^fn_54a_48] are\] reversed[^fn_54a_49] in the case off retainer.[^fn_54a_50] R. Kahana taught: And so[^fn_54a_51] \[are their opinions\][^fn_54a_48] in the case of a retainer;[^fn_54a_50] and \[Rab\] had laid down this mnemonic, 'Strip the widow and the orphan[^fn_54a_52] and go out'.

R. Nahman said: Although we have learned in a Mishnah in agreement with the view of Samuel[^fn_54a_53] the law is in agreement with that of Rab. For we learned: Whether a man has consecrated his estate, or whether he has consecrated the valuation of himself[^fn_54a_54] \[the Temple treasurer\][^fn_54a_55] has no claim either upon the clothes of that man's wife,[^fn_54a_56] or upon the clothes of his children, or the coloured articles that were dyed for them,[^fn_54a_57] or any new sandals that \[their father\] may have bought[^fn_54a_57] for them.[^fn_54a_58]

Said Raba to R. Nahman: Since, however, we have learned in a Mishnah in agreement with the view of Samuel, why does the law agree with that of Rab? The other replied: At first sight it might appear[^fn_54a_59] to run parallel to the principle of Samuel, but if you examine it carefully \[you will find that\] the law, in fact, must be in agreement with \[the view of\] Rab. For this[^fn_54a_60] is the reason:[^fn_54a_61] When he[^fn_54a_62] bought[^fn_54a_63] \[the clothes\] for her \[he did so\] on the assumption that she would live with him.[^fn_54a_64] He did not, however, buy[^fn_54a_63] them for her on the assumption that she should take them[^fn_54a_65] and depart.[^fn_54a_66]

A daughter-in-law of the house of Bar Eliashib was claiming her *kethubah* from orphans. When she summoned them to court and they said, 'It is degrading for us that you should come with us in such \[clothes\]', she went home and dressed and wrapped herself in all her garments. When they came before Rabina he told them: The law is in agreement with the ruling of Rab who laid down \[that when a *kethubah* is being paid to\] a widow, assessment is made of what she wears.

A man[^fn_54a_67] once said, 'Let a bride's outfit[^fn_54a_68] be provided for my daughter', and the price of an outfit was subsequently reduced. 'The benefit',[^fn_54a_69] ruled R. Idi b. Abin, 'belongs to the orphans'.[^fn_54a_70]

A man[^fn_54a_67] once said, [pg 54b]

'Four hundred *zuz*[^fn_54b_1] \[of the value of this\] wine shall be given to my daughter', and the price of wine rose. 'The profit', ruled R. Joseph, 'belongs to the orphans'.[^fn_54b_2]

Relatives of R. Johanan had \[the responsibility of maintaining their\] father's wife who was in the habit of consuming much[^fn_54b_3] food. When[^fn_54b_4] they came to R. Johanan[^fn_54b_5] she told them, 'Go and ask your father that he should assign a plot of land for her maintenance'.[^fn_54b_6] When they subsequently came before Resh Lakish, he said to them, '\[By such an assignment\] he has increased all the more \[the allowance for\] her maintenance'.[^fn_54b_7] 'But', they said to him, 'R. Johanan did not say so?' — 'Go', he told them, 'and give her \[proper maintenance\], otherwise[^fn_54b_8] I shall pull R. Johanan out of your ears'. R. Johanan, when they came to him again, said to them, 'What can I do when one of equal standing[^fn_54b_9] differs from me?' R. Abbahu stated: This was explained to me by R. Johanan: \[If the husband\] said,[^fn_54b_10] 'towards maintenance' he has thereby increased \[the allowance for\] her maintenance;[^fn_54b_11] but if he said,[^fn_54b_10] 'for maintenance' he has thereby limited the allowance for her maintenance.[^fn_54b_12]

## CHAPTER V

***MISHNAH***. ALTHOUGH \[THE SAGES\] HAVE ENACTED THAT A VIRGIN COLLECTS[^fn_54b_13] TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ*[^fn_54b_14] AND A WIDOW ONE *MANEH*,[^fn_54b_14] IF HE \[THE HUSBAND\] WISHES TO ADD, EVEN A HUNDRED *MANEH*, HE MAY DO SO. {¶=5.1}

\[A WOMAN\] WHO WAS WIDOWED OR DIVORCED, EITHER AFTER BETROTHAL OR AFTER MARRIAGE, IS ENTITLED TO COLLECT ALL \[THAT IS DUE TO HER\].[^fn_54b_15] R. ELEAZAR B. AZARIAH RULED: \[ONLY A WOMAN WIDOWED\] AFTER HER MARRIAGE RECEIVES ALL \[THAT IS DUE TO HER\], BUT IF AFTER A BETROTHAL, A VIRGIN RECOVERS ONLY TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ*[^fn_54b_14] AND A WIDOW ONLY ONE *MANEH*,[^fn_54b_14] FOR THE MAN PROMISED[^fn_54b_16] HER \[THE ADDITIONAL JOINTURE\] WITH THE SOLE OBJECT OF MARRYING HER.[^fn_54b_17]

R. JUDAH RULED: IF \[A HUSBAND\] WISHES HE MAY WRITE OUT FOR A VIRGIN[^fn_54b_13] A DEED FOR TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ* AND SHE WRITES \[A QUITTANCE\],[^fn_54b_18] 'I HAVE RECEIVED FROM YOU A MANEH', AND FOR A WIDOW \[HE MAY WRITE OUT A DEED FOR\] A *MANEH* AND SHE WRITES \[A QUITTANCE\]. 'I HAVE RECEIVED FROM YOU FIFTY ZUZ'. R. MEIR RULED: \[THE INTERCOURSE OF\] ANY MAN WHO UNDERTAKES TO GIVE A VIRGIN LESS THAN TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ*[^fn_54b_14] OR A WIDOW LESS THAN A *MANEH*[^fn_54b_14] IS[^fn_54b_19] AN ACT OF PROSTITUTION.

***GEMARA***. \[Is not this\][^fn_54b_20] obvious? — It might have been presumed that the Rabbis have fixed a limit in order that the man who has no means might not be put to shame; hence we were taught \[that there was no limit\].

IF HE WISHES TO ADD etc. It was not stated, 'If he wishes to write',[^fn_54b_21] but 'WISHES TO ADD'.[^fn_54b_22] This then provides support for \[a ruling which\] R. Aibu stated in the name of R. Jannai. For R. Aibu stated in the name of R. Jannai: The supplementary provisions[^fn_54b_23] \[that are included\] in a *kethubah* are subject to the same regulations as the statutory *kethubah*.[^fn_54b_24] \[In what respect\] can this[^fn_54b_25] matter?[^fn_54b_26] — In respect of a woman who sells or surrenders \[her *kethubah*\],[^fn_54b_27] or one who rebels,[^fn_54b_28] one who impairs,[^fn_54b_29] or claims \[her *kethubah*\],[^fn_54b_30] or one who transgresses the Law;[^fn_54b_31] [pg 55a]

in respect of amelioration,[^fn_55a_1] an oath,[^fn_55a_2] and the Sabbatical year,[^fn_55a_3] in respect of him who assigned all his property to his sons,[^fn_55a_4] or the recovery of payment out of real estate and from the worst part of it,[^fn_55a_5] also in respect of \[the law of a widow\] while in her father's house,[^fn_55a_6] and of the *kethubah* for male children.[^fn_55a_7]

It was stated: The *kethubah* for the male children,[^fn_55a_8] \[the scholars of\] Pumbeditha[^fn_55a_9] ruled, may not be collected from sold or mortgaged property,[^fn_55a_10] for we have learned,[^fn_55a_8] 'They shall inherit';[^fn_55a_11] and the scholars of[^fn_55a_12] Matha Mehasia[^fn_55a_13] ruled: It may be collected from sold or mortgaged property, for we have learned,[^fn_55a_8] 'They shall take'.[^fn_55a_14] The law, however, is that it may not be collected from sold or mortgaged property, since we have learned,[^fn_55a_8] 'They shall inherit'.[^fn_55a_11]

Movables[^fn_55a_15] which are available[^fn_55a_16] \[may be collected\][^fn_55a_17] without an oath;[^fn_55a_18] but if they are not available,[^fn_55a_19] \[the *kethubah* may, the scholars of\] Pumbeditha ruled, \[be collected\][^fn_55a_20] without an oath[^fn_55a_18] and the scholars[^fn_55a_21] of Matha Mehasia ruled: Only with an oath. The law \[is that they may be collected\] without an oath.
