If \[her husband\] has set aside for her a plot of land \[defining it\] by its four boundaries[^fn_55a_22] \[she[^fn_55a_23] may collect from it\] without an oath;[^fn_55a_24] but if \[he only defined it\] by one boundary, \[the scholars of\] Pumbeditha ruled \[that collection[^fn_55a_25] may be made from it\] without an oath,[^fn_55a_24] but the scholars of Matha Mehasia ruled: Only with an oath.[^fn_55a_26] The law, however, is that collection[^fn_55a_25] may be effected without an oath.[^fn_55a_22] If a man said to witnesses, 'Write out \[a deed\],[^fn_55a_27] sign it and give it to a certain person',[^fn_55a_28] and they took from him symbolic possession there is no need[^fn_55a_29] to consult him.[^fn_55a_30] \[If, however,\] no symbolic possession was taken, \[the scholars of\] Pumbeditha ruled, there is no need[^fn_55a_29] to consult him,[^fn_55a_30] but the scholars of Matha Mehasia ruled: It is necessary to consult him. The law is that it is necessary to consult him.

R. ELEAZAR B. AZARIAH etc. It was stated: Rab and R. Nathan \[differed\]. One maintained that the *halachah* was in agreement with R. Eleazar b. Azariah and the other maintained that the *halachah* was not in agreement with R. Eleazar b. Azariah. You may conclude that it was R. Nathan who maintained that the *halachah* was in agreement with R. Eleazar b. Azariah[^fn_55a_31] since R. Nathan was heard \[elsewhere\] to follow \[the rule of\] assumption,[^fn_55a_32] he[^fn_55a_33] having stated that the *halachah* was in agreement with R. Simeon Shezuri in the case of a man dangerously ill[^fn_55a_34] [pg 55b]

and in that of *terumah*[^fn_55b_1] of the tithe of *demai*[^fn_55b_2] produce.[^fn_55b_3] But does not Rab, however, follow \[the rule of\] assumption? Surely it was stated: As to the gift of a dying man[^fn_55b_4] \[in the deed of\] which was recorded \[symbolic\] acquisition, the school of Rab in the name of Rab reported \[that the testator\] has \[thereby\] made him[^fn_55b_5] ride on two harnessed horses;[^fn_55b_6] but Samuel said: I do not know what decision to give on the matter. 'The school of Rab in the name of Rab reported \[that the testator\] has \[thereby\] made him ride on two harnessed horses', for it is like the gift of a man in good health,[^fn_55b_7] and it is also like the gift of a dying man.[^fn_55b_8] 'It is like the gift of a man in good health', in that, if he recovered, he cannot retract,[^fn_55b_7] and 'it is like the gift of a dying man' in that, if he said that his loan[^fn_55b_9] \[shall be given\] to X, his loan \[is to he given\] to X.[^fn_55b_10] 'But Samuel said: I do not know what decision to give on the matter', since it is possible that he[^fn_55b_11] decided not to transfer possession to him[^fn_55b_12] except through the deed,[^fn_55b_13] and no \[possession by means of a\] deed \[may be acquired\] after \[the testator's\] death![^fn_55b_14] [pg 56a]

— The fact, however, is that both[^fn_56a_1] follow \[the rule of\] assumption; and he who stated that the *halachah* \[was so\][^fn_56a_2] was well justified, \[while in respect of\] him who stated that the *halachah* was not \[so\],[^fn_56a_3] \[it may be explained that\] here[^fn_56a_4] also \[the ruling is based on\] an assumption, that the man's object[^fn_56a_5] \[it is assumed\] was the formation of a mutual attachment,[^fn_56a_6] and such attachment has indeed been formed.[^fn_56a_7]

R. Hanina[^fn_56a_8] once sat in the presence of R. Jannai when he stated: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eleazar b. Azariah. \[The Master\] said to him, 'Go Out' read your Biblical verses outside;[^fn_56a_9] the *halachah* is not in agreement with R. Eleazar b. Azariah'.

R. Isaac b. Abdimi stated in the name of our Master:[^fn_56a_10] The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eleazar b. Azariah. R. Nahman stated in the name of Samuel: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eleazar b. Azariah.

R. Nahman in his own name, however, stated that the *halachah* was not in agreement with R. Eleazar b. Azariah, while the Nehardeans stated in the name of R. Nahman that the *halachah* was in agreement with R. Eleazar b. Azariah. And though R. Nahman uttered a curse, proclaiming, 'Such and such a fate shall befall every judge who gives a ruling in agreement with the opinion of R. Eleazar b. Azariah', the *halachah* is nevertheless in agreement with R. Eleazar b. Azariah.

And the *halachah* in practice is in accordance with the Opinion of R. Eleazar b. Azariah.

Rabin enquired: What is the law[^fn_56a_11] where the bride only entered the bridal chamber but there was no intercourse? Is the *kinyan*[^fn_56a_12]

         effected by the affectionate attachment in the bridal chamber[^fn_56a_13] or is the *kinyan* effected by the affectionate attachment of the intercourse?[^fn_56a_14] — Come and hear what R. Joseph learnt: 'Because he assigned[^fn_56a_15] it to her only on account of the affectionate attachment of the first night'. Now, if you grant that it is the affectionate attachment in the bridal chamber that effects the *kinyan* it was correct for him to state 'the first night'. If, however, you contend that it is the affectionate attachment of the intercourse that effects the *kinyan*, does this \[it may be objected, first\] take place on the first night only and not subsequently? — What then \[do you suggest\]? The \[affectionate attachment in the\] bridal chamber? Is the bridal chamber \[it may be retorted\] entered[^fn_56a_16] in the night only and not in the day time![^fn_56a_17] — But according to your argument does intercourse take place at night and not in the day time? Surely Raba stated: If one was in a dark room \[intercourse\] is permitted![^fn_56a_18] — This is no difficulty. He[^fn_56a_19] may have taught us that it is proper conduct[^fn_56a_20] that intercourse should be at night; but \[if it is maintained that it is the affectionate attachment in the\] bridal chamber \[that effects the *kinyan*\] the difficulty arises![^fn_56a_21] — \[The assumption that *kinyan* is effected in the\] bridal chamber also presents no difficulty. Since, usually, the bridal chamber is a prelude to[^fn_56a_22] intercourse he taught us that it was proper that \[it should be entered\] at night.

R. Ashi enquired: What is the law[^fn_56a_23] where \[a bride\] entering the bridal chamber became menstruous?[^fn_56a_24] If you should find \[some reason\] for saying that it is the affectionate attachment in the bridal chamber that effects the *kinyan*[^fn_56a_25] \[the question still remains whether this applies only to\] a bridal chamber that is a prelude[^fn_56a_26] to intercourse but not to a bridal chamber that is no prelude to intercourse,[^fn_56a_27] or is there perhaps no difference?[^fn_56a_28] — This remains unanswered.

R. JUDAH SAID: IF \[A HUSBAND\] WISHES HE MAY WRITE OUT FOR A VIRGIN etc. Does R. Judah hold the opinion that a quittance is written?[^fn_56a_29] Surely we learned: If a person repaid part of his debt, R. Judah said, he[^fn_56a_30] must exchange \[the bond for another\].[^fn_56a_31] R. Jose said: He[^fn_56a_32] must write a quittance for him![^fn_56a_33] — R. Jeremiah replied: \[Here it is a case\] where the quittance is \[written\] within.[^fn_56a_34] Abaye replied: You may even say \[that here it is a case\] where the quittance is not written within.[^fn_56a_35] There[^fn_56a_36] it is quite correct[^fn_56a_37] \[to disallow the use of a quittance, since the debtor\] had undoubtedly repaid him[^fn_56a_38] and it is possible that the quittance might be lost and that he[^fn_56a_38] would produce the bond and thus collect \[the paid portion of the debt\] a second time. Here,[^fn_56a_39] however, did he indeed give her anything?[^fn_56a_40] It is a mere statement that she addressed to him.[^fn_56a_41] If, then, he preserved \[the quittance\] well and good;[^fn_56a_42] and if he did not preserve it, well, it is he himself who is the cause of his own loss. One can well understand why Abaye did not give the explanation as R. Jeremiah, since it was not stated[^fn_56a_43] that the quittance was entered within,[^fn_56a_44] but why did not R. Jeremiah give the same explanation as Abaye? — The quittance here[^fn_56a_45] is forbidden as a preventive measure against the \[erroneous permitting of\] a quittance elsewhere.[^fn_56a_46]

The reason \[for the husband's exemption[^fn_56a_47] is apparently\] because she gave him a quittance in writing.[^fn_56a_48] If, however, \[she had surrendered a portion of her *kethubah*\] by word of mouth only \[he would\] not \[have been exempt\];[^fn_56a_49] but why? This,[^fn_56a_45] surely, is a monetary matter, and R. Judah was heard to rule that in a monetary matter one's stipulation[^fn_56a_50] is valid. For was it not taught: If a man said to a woman, 'Behold thou art consecrated unto me[^fn_56a_51] on condition that thou shalt have no \[claim\] upon me \[for\] food, raiment or conjugal rights', she is consecrated,[^fn_56a_52] but the stipulation is null;[^fn_56a_53] so R. Meir. R. Judah, however, said: In respect of monetary matters his stipulation is valid?[^fn_56a_54] — R. Judah is of the opinion that the *kethubah* is a Rabbinical enactment,[^fn_56a_55] and the Sages[^fn_56a_56] have applied to their enactments[^fn_56a_57] higher restrictions than to those of the Torah.[^fn_56a_58] But what of the case of usufruct[^fn_56a_59] which is a Rabbinical law and the Rabbis nevertheless did not apply any restriction to it;[^fn_56a_60] for we learned: R. Judah said, He[^fn_56a_61] may for all time eat the fruit of the fruit[^fn_56a_62] unless he wrote out for her \[the undertaking\], 'I have no claim whatsoever[^fn_56a_63] upon your estates and their produce and the produce of their produce for ever';[^fn_56a_64] [pg 56b]

and it had been established that by 'writing'[^fn_56b_1] only saying was meant![^fn_56b_2] — Abaye replied: All \[married women\] have a *kethubah*; not all, however, have fruit. In respect of what is usual the Rabbis have applied restrictions. In respect of what is not usual, however, the Rabbis have made no restrictions.

But what of the case of ass-drivers[^fn_56b_3] which is a common occurrence and the Rabbis have nevertheless applied no restrictions to it; for we learned: Where ass-drivers entered a town and one of them declared, 'My \[produce\] is new and that of my fellow is old' or 'Mine is not fit for use[^fn_56b_4] but that of my fellow is fit', they are not believed; but R. Judah said, They are believed![^fn_56b_5] — Abaye replied: To any Rabbinical enactment of an absolute character[^fn_56b_6] the Rabbis have applied further restrictions, but to any Rabbinical enactment of uncertain origin[^fn_56b_7] the Rabbis have added no further restrictions. Raba replied: They[^fn_56b_8] relaxed the law in respect of *demai*.[^fn_56b_9]

R. MEIR RULED … ANY MAN WHO … GIVE … LESS etc. The expression, 'WHO … GIVE … LESS' \[implies\][^fn_56b_10] even \[if the assignment remained a mere\] stipulation.[^fn_56b_11] Thus it follows that he[^fn_56b_12] is of the opinion that the man's stipulation is void and that the woman receives \[her full *kethubah*\];[^fn_56b_13] yet since[^fn_56b_14] the man had said to her[^fn_56b_15] 'You will have but a maneh',[^fn_56b_16] her mind is not at ease[^fn_56b_17] and his intercourse is regarded as an act of prostitution.[^fn_56b_18] But, surely, R. Meir was heard to rule that any stipulation[^fn_56b_19] which is contrary to what is written in the Torah is[^fn_56b_20] null and void, \[from which it may be inferred,[^fn_56b_21] may it not, that if it is\] but against a law of the Rabbis it is[^fn_56b_20] valid?[^fn_56b_22] — R. Meir holds the view that the *kethubah* is a Pentateuchal institution.

It was taught: R. Meir ruled, If any man assigns to a virgin[^fn_56b_23] a sum less than two hundred *zuz* or to a widow less than a *maneh* his marriage is regarded as[^fn_56b_24] an act of prostitution. R. Jose ruled: One is permitted \[to contract such a marriage\].[^fn_56b_25] R. Judah ruled: If the man wished he may write out for a virgin a bond for two hundred *zuz* while she writes[^fn_56b_26] for him, 'I have received from you a maneh'; and \[he may write a bond\] for a widow for a *maneh* while she writes[^fn_56b_26] for him, 'I have received from you fifty zuz'.[^fn_56b_27]

Is R. Jose then of the opinion that 'one is permitted \[to contract such a marriage\]'?[^fn_56b_28] This surely is contrary \[to the following:\] A woman's *kethubah* may not be made \[a charge on\] movable property as a social measure.[^fn_56b_29] Said R. Jose: What social measure is this?[^fn_56b_30] Their[^fn_56b_31] price, surely, is not fixed and they deteriorate in value.[^fn_56b_32] Now, did not the first Tanna also say that \[a *kethubah*\] may not be made \[a charge on movable property\]?[^fn_56b_33] Must he[^fn_56b_34] not, consequently, have meant to say: This[^fn_56b_35] applies only where he[^fn_56b_36] accepted no responsibility;[^fn_56b_37] but where he accepted responsibility[^fn_56b_37] \[the *kethubah*\] may be made \[a charge upon them\].[^fn_56b_38] Thereupon came R. Jose to question: Even If he[^fn_56b_36] did accept responsibility how \[could the *kethubah* be\] made \[a charge upon them\][^fn_56b_39] when their price, surely, is not fixed and they deteriorate in value.[^fn_56b_40] Now, if there,[^fn_56b_41] where the diminution in value \[of the movables\] is only a possibility,[^fn_56b_42] R. Jose provides against it, would he not even more so \[adopt a similar course\] here[^fn_56b_43] where the diminution \[of the *kethubah*\] is a certainty? — How now! There[^fn_56b_44] she did not know it[^fn_56b_45] to think of surrendering her rights;[^fn_56b_46] but here she was well aware \[of the fact\][^fn_56b_47] and has definitely surrendered her rights.

The sister of Rami b. Hama was married to R. Iwia [pg 57a]

and her *kethubah*[^fn_57a_1] was lost. When they came before R. Joseph[^fn_57a_2] he said to them, Thus said Rab Judah in the name of Samuel: This[^fn_57a_3] is the opinion of R. Meir,[^fn_57a_4] but the Sages ruled that a man may live with his wife without a *kethubah* for two or three years.[^fn_57a_5] Said Abaye to him:[^fn_57a_6] But did not R. Nahman state in the name of Samuel that the *halachah* is in agreement with R. Meir in his preventive measures?[^fn_57a_7] — If so, \[the other replied\] go and write one[^fn_57a_8] for her.

When R. Dimi came[^fn_57a_9] he stated in the name of R. Simeon b. Pazzi in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi who had it from Bar Kappara: The dispute[^fn_57a_10] refers to the beginning,[^fn_57a_11] but at the end[^fn_57a_11] she cannot, according to the opinion of all, surrender[^fn_57a_12] \[any portion of her *kethubah*\].[^fn_57a_13] R. Johanan, however stated that their dispute extended to both cases.[^fn_57a_14] Said R. Abbahu: \[The following\] was explained to me by R. Johanan: 'I and R. Joshua b. Levi do not dispute with one another. The "beginning" of which R. Joshua b. Levi spoke means[^fn_57a_15] the beginning of \[the meeting in\] the bridal chamber, and by the "end" was meant[^fn_57a_15] the termination of the intercourse;[^fn_57a_16] and when I stated that the dispute extended to both cases \[I meant\] the beginning \[of the meeting in\] the bridal chamber and the end of that meeting which is the beginning of the intercourse.'[^fn_57a_17]

When Rabin came[^fn_57a_18] he stated in the name of R. Simeon b. Pazzi in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi who had it from Bar Kappara. The dispute refers only to the end, but at the beginning she may, so is the opinion of all, renounce[^fn_57a_19] \[any portion of her *kethubah*\].[^fn_57a_20] R. Johanan, however, stated that their dispute extended to both cases. Said R. Abbahu: This was explained to me by R. Johanan: 'I and R. Joshua b. Levi do not dispute with one another. The "end" of which R. Joshua b. Levi spoke meant the end of \[the meeting in\] the bridal chamber, and by the "beginning" was meant the beginning of \[the meeting in\] the bridal chamber; and when I stated that the dispute extended to both cases \[I meant\] the beginning,[^fn_57a_21] and the termination of the intercourse.'

Said R. Papa: Had not R. Abbahu stated, 'This was explained to me by R. Johanan: "I and R. Joshua b. Levi do not dispute with one another"' I would have submitted that R. Johanan and R. Joshua b. Levi were in dispute while R. Dimi and Rabin[^fn_57a_22] were not in dispute. The 'end' of which Rabin spoke might mean[^fn_57a_23] the end of \[the meeting in\] the bridal chamber, and the 'beginning' of which R. Dimi spoke might mean[^fn_57a_23] the beginning of the intercourse.[^fn_57a_21] What does he[^fn_57a_24] teach us thereby?[^fn_57a_25] — It is this that he teaches us: \[It is preferable to assume\][^fn_57a_26] that two Amoraim differ in their own opinions[^fn_57a_27] rather than that two Amoraim should differ as to what was the view of another Amora.[^fn_57a_28]

***MISHNAH***. A VIRGIN IS ALLOWED TWELVE MONTHS FROM THE \[TIME HER INTENDED\] HUSBAND CLAIMED HER,[^fn_57a_29] \[IN WHICH\] TO PREPARE HER MARRIAGE OUTFIT.[^fn_57a_30] AND, AS \[SUCH A PERIOD\] IS ALLOWED FOR THE WOMAN, SO IS IT ALLOWED FOR THE MAN FOR HIS OUTFIT.[^fn_57a_31] FOR A WIDOW[^fn_57a_32] THIRTY DAYS \[ARE ALLOWED\]. IF THE RESPECTIVE PERIODS EXPIRED[^fn_57a_33] AND THEY WERE NOT MARRIED[^fn_57a_34] THEY[^fn_57a_35] ARE ENTITLED TO MAINTENANCE OUT OF THE MAN'S ESTATE[^fn_57a_36] AND \[IF HE IS A PRIEST\] MAY ALSO EAT *TERUMAH*. R. TARFON SAID: ALL \[THE SUSTENANCE\] FOR SUCH A WOMAN MAY BE GIVEN OF *TERUMAH*.[^fn_57a_37] R. AKIBA SAID: ONE HALF OF UNCONSECRATED FOOD[^fn_57a_38] AND ONE HALF OF *TERUMAH*.[^fn_57a_39] {¶=5.2}

A LEVIR[^fn_57a_40] \[WHO IS A PRIEST\] DOES NOT CONFER \[UPON HIS SISTER-IN-LAW\][^fn_57a_41] THE RIGHT OF EATING *TERUMAH*.[^fn_57a_42] IF SHE[^fn_57a_43] HAD SPENT SIX MONTHS[^fn_57a_44] WITH[^fn_57a_45] HER HUSBAND AND SIX MONTHS WITH[^fn_57a_45] THE LEVIR,[^fn_57a_46] OR EVEN \[IF SHE SPENT\] ALL OF THEM[^fn_57a_47] WITH HER HUSBAND LESS ONE DAY WITH[^fn_57a_45] THE LEVIR,[^fn_57a_46] OR ALL OF THEM[^fn_57a_47] WITH[^fn_57a_45] THE LEVIR[^fn_57a_46] LESS ONE DAY WITH HER HUSBAND,[^fn_57a_48] SHE IS NOT PERMITTED TO EAT *TERUMAH*.[^fn_57a_49] THIS[^fn_57a_50] \[WAS THE RULING ACCORDING TO\] AN EARLIER[^fn_57a_51]

***MISHNAH***.[^fn_57a_52] THE COURT, HOWEVER, THAT SUCCEEDED[^fn_57a_53] RULED: [pg 57b] {¶=5.3}

A WOMAN[^fn_57b_1] MAY NOT EAT *TERUMAH* UNTIL SHE HAS ENTERED THE BRIDAL CHAMBER.[^fn_57b_2]

***GEMARA***. Whence is this[^fn_57b_3] derived? — R. Hisda replied: From Scripture which states, And her brother and her mother said: 'Let the damsel abide with us yamim,[^fn_57b_4] at the least ten.[^fn_57b_5] Now, what could be meant by yamim? If it be suggested 'two days',[^fn_57b_6] do people, \[it might be retorted,\] speak in such a manner? \[If when\] they suggested to him[^fn_57b_7] two days he said no, would they then suggest ten days? Yamim must consequently mean[^fn_57b_8] a year, for it is written, yamim[^fn_57b_9] shall he have the right of redemption.[^fn_57b_10] But might it not be said \[that yamim means\] a month,[^fn_57b_11] for it is written, But a month of yamim?[^fn_57b_12] — I will tell you: \[The meaning of\] an undefined \[expression of\] yamim may well be inferred from another undefined expression of yamim, but no undefined expression of yamim may be inferred from one in connection with which month was specifically mentioned.

R. Zera stated that a Tanna taught: In the case of a minor,[^fn_57b_13] either she herself or her father is empowered to postpone[^fn_57b_14] \[her marriage\].[^fn_57b_15] One can well understand why she is empowered to postpone \[the marriage\], but \[why also her\] father? If she is satisfied, what matters it to her father? — He might think this: Now she does not realize \[what marriage implies\] but to-morrow[^fn_57b_16] she will rebel \[against her husband\], leave him and come back to, and fall \[a burden\] upon me.[^fn_57b_17]

R. Abba b. Levi stated: No arrangements may be made for marrying a minor while she is still in her minority. Arrangements[^fn_57b_18] may, however, be made while she is a minor for marrying her when she becomes of age. Is not this obvious? — It might have been suggested that \[this should not be allowed\] as a precaution against the possibility of her beginning to feel anxiety at once[^fn_57b_19] and so becoming ill. Hence we were taught \[that no such possibility need be considered\].

R. Huna stated: If on the day she became adolescent[^fn_57b_20] she was betrothed, she is allowed thirty days[^fn_57b_21] like a widow.[^fn_57b_22] An objection was raised: One who has attained adolescence is like one who has been claimed \[by her intended husband in marriage\]. Does not this imply, 'Like a Virgin who was claimed'?[^fn_57b_23] — No, like a widow who was claimed.

Come and hear: If a woman who is adolescent had waited for twelve months[^fn_57b_24] her husband, said R. Eliezer, since he is liable for her maintenance, may also annul \[her vows\]![^fn_57b_25] — Read: A woman who is adolescent[^fn_57b_26] or one[^fn_57b_27] who waited twelve months.[^fn_57b_28]

Come and hear: If a man betrothed a virgin, whether he[^fn_57b_29] claimed her and she held back or whether she claimed him and he[^fn_57b_29] held back, she is allowed twelve months[^fn_57b_30] from the time of the claim but not from the time of the betrothal; and one who is adolescent is like one who has been claimed. How \[is this to be understood\]? If she was betrothed on the day she became adolescent,[^fn_57b_31] she is allowed twelve months; while one betrothed \[is sometimes allowed\] thirty days.[^fn_57b_32] Is not this a refutation against R. Huna? — It is a refutation.

What \[was meant by\] 'while one betrothed \[is sometimes allowed\] thirty days'? — R. Papa replied, It is this that was meant: If an adolescent woman was betrothed after twelve months of her adolescence have elapsed, she is allowed[^fn_57b_30] thirty days like a widow. IF THE RESPECTIVE PERIODS EXPIRED AND THEY WERE NOT MARRIED. 'Ulla stated: The daughter of an Israelite who is betrothed \[to a priest\] is, according to Pentateuchal law, permitted to eat *terumah*, for it is written In Scripture, But if a priest buy any soul, the purchase of his money,[^fn_57b_33] and that \[woman\] also is the purchase of his money.[^fn_57b_34] What then is the reason why \[the Rabbis\] ruled that she is not permitted to eat \[*terumah*\]? Because it might happen that when a cup \[of *terumah*\] will be offered[^fn_57b_35] to her in the house of her father she might give her brother or sister[^fn_57b_36] to drink \[from it\]. If so, \[the same reason should apply\] also where THE RESPECTIVE PERIODS EXPIRED AND THEY WERE NOT MARRIED! — In that case[^fn_57b_37] he appoints for her a special place.[^fn_57b_38] Now then, no \[hired harvest\] gleaner[^fn_57b_39] \[working\] for an Israelite should be allowed to eat *terumah*, since it is possible that \[the household of the Israelite\] would come to eat with him! If[^fn_57b_40] they feed him from their own \[victuals\], Would they eat of his?[^fn_57b_41]

R. Samuel son of Rab[^fn_57b_42] Judah explained:[^fn_57b_43] Owing to a bodily defect[^fn_57b_44] \[that might subsequently be detected\].[^fn_57b_45] lf so, \[should not the same reason\] also \[be applicable to a woman who\] had entered the bridal chamber, but intercourse with whom did not take place?[^fn_57b_46] — In that case[^fn_57b_47] he arranges for her to be first examined and only then takes her in.[^fn_57b_48] Now then, the slave of a priest,[^fn_57b_49] bought from an Israelite, should not be allowed to eat *terumah* on account of a bodily defect[^fn_57b_44] \[that might be discovered\]![^fn_57b_50] — \[The law of cancellation of a sale owing to a subsequent detection of a\] bodily defect[^fn_57b_44] does not apply to slaves. For if the defect is external \[the buyer\] has presumably seen it;[^fn_57b_51] and if it is internal, since \[the buyer\] requires \[the slave\] for work only he does not mind a private defect.[^fn_57b_52] Were \[the slave\] to be found to have been a thief or [pg 58a]

a gambler[^fn_58a_1] the sale is still valid.[^fn_58a_2] What else is there?[^fn_58a_3] \[Only that the slave might be found to have been\] an armed robber or one proscribed by the government;[^fn_58a_4] but such characters are generally known.[^fn_58a_5]

Consider! Whether according to the \[explanation of the one\] Master[^fn_58a_6] or according to that of the other Master[^fn_58a_7] she[^fn_58a_8] is not permitted to eat \[*terumah*\], what then is the practical difference between them? — The difference between them \[is the case where her intended husband\] accepted \[her defects,[^fn_58a_9] or where her father\] delivered \[her to the intended husband's agents\][^fn_58a_10] or went[^fn_58a_11] \[with them\].[^fn_58a_10]

R. TARFON SAID: ALL \[THE SUSTENANCE\] FOR SUCH A WOMAN MAY BE GIVEN OF *TERUMAH* etc. Abaye stated: The dispute[^fn_58a_12] applies only to the daughter of a priest[^fn_58a_13] who was betrothed to a priest but with respect to the daughter of an Israelite[^fn_58a_14] who was betrothed to a priest all[^fn_58a_15] agree \[that she is supplied with\] one half of unconsecrated food[^fn_58a_16] and one half of *terumah*.

Abaye further stated: Their dispute[^fn_58a_12] relates to one who[^fn_58a_17] was only betrothed,[^fn_58a_18] but in respect of a married woman[^fn_58a_19] all[^fn_58a_15] agree \[that she is supplied with\] one half of unconsecrated food[^fn_58a_20] and one half of *terumah*.[^fn_58a_20] So it was also taught: R. Tarfon said, All \[the sustenance\] for such a woman is given of *terumah*. R. Akiba said, One half of consecrated food and one half of *terumah* — This[^fn_58a_21] applies only to the daughter of a priest who was betrothed to a priest, but with respect to the daughter of an Israelite who was betrothed to a priest all[^fn_58a_22] agree \[that she is supplied with\] one half of unconsecrated food and one half of *terumah*. This,[^fn_58a_21] furthermore, applies only to one who[^fn_58a_23] was only betrothed but in respect of a married woman[^fn_58a_24] all[^fn_58a_22] agree \[that she is supplied with\] one half of unconsecrated food[^fn_58a_25] and one half of *terumah*.[^fn_58a_25] R. Judah b. Bathyra said, She is supplied with two thirds[^fn_58a_26] of *terumah* and one third of unconsecrated food. R. Judah said, All \[her sustenance\] is given to her in *terumah*[^fn_58a_27] and she sells it and purchases unconsecrated food out of the proceeds.[^fn_58a_28] R. Simeon b. Gamaliel said, Wherever *terumah* was mentioned[^fn_58a_29] \[the woman\] is to be given \[a supply equal to\] twice the quantity of unconsecrated victuals.[^fn_58a_30] What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_58a_31] — The difference between them \[is the question of the woman's\] trouble.[^fn_58a_32]

A LEVIR \[WHO IS A PRIEST\] DOES NOT CONFER \[UPON HIS SISTER-IN-LAW\] THE RIGHT OF EATING *TERUMAH*. What is the reason? — The All-Merciful said, The purchase of his money[^fn_58a_33] while she is the purchase of his brother.[^fn_58a_34]

IF SHE HAD SPENT SIX MONTHS WITH HER HUSBAND. Now that you stated \[that even if she spent the full twelve months less one day\] WITH THE HUSBAND \[she is\] not \[permitted to eat *terumah*\] is there any need \[to mention also\] WITH THE LEVIR?[^fn_58a_35] — This is a case[^fn_58a_36] \[of anti-climax:\]

'This, and there is no need to say that'.[^fn_58a_37] THIS \[WAS THE RULING ACCORDING TO\] AN EARLIER MISHNAH etc. What is the reason?[^fn_58a_38] — 'Ulla, or some say R. Samuel b. Judah, replied: Owing to a bodily defect \[that might subsequently be detected\].[^fn_58a_39] According to 'Ulla[^fn_58a_40] one can well understand \[the respective rulings of the earlier,[^fn_58a_41] and the later rulings\],[^fn_58a_42] the former[^fn_58a_41] being due to the possibility that a cup \[of *terumah*\] might be offered[^fn_58a_43] to her in the house of her father,[^fn_58a_44] and the latter to \[the possibility of\] the detection of a bodily defect.[^fn_58a_45] [pg 58b]

According to R. Samuel b. Judah, however, the earlier \[ruling of the\] Mishnah is due to \[the possible detection of\] a bodily defect and the later is also due to \[the possible detection of\] a bodily defect, what then is \[the reason for\] their difference? — \[The principle underlying\] the difference is the \[efficacy of an\] examination by outsiders. One Master[^fn_58b_1] is of the opinion that an examination by others[^fn_58b_2] is regarded as effective,[^fn_58b_3] while the other Master[^fn_58b_4] holds the opinion that an examination by others is not regarded as effective.[^fn_58b_5]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN CONSECRATED HIS WIFE'S HANDIWORK,[^fn_58b_6] SHE MAY NEVERTHELESS CONTINUE TO WORK AND TO CONSUME \[THE PROCEEDS HERSELF\].[^fn_58b_7] \[IF, HOWEVER, HE CONSECRATED\] THE SURPLUS[^fn_58b_8] \[ONLY\]. R. MEIR RULED: IT IS DULY CONSECRATED.[^fn_58b_9] R. JOHANAN HA-SANDELAR RULED: IT REMAINS UNCONSECRATED.[^fn_58b_9] {¶=5.4}

***GEMARA***. R. Huna stated in the name of Rab:[^fn_58b_10] A woman is entitled to say to her husband, 'I do not wish either to be maintained by you or to work for you'. He holds the opinion that when the Rabbis regulated \[the relations of husband and wife\] her maintenance was fundamental[^fn_58b_11] while \[the assignment of the proceeds of\] her handiwork \[to her husband\] was due \[only to their desire for preventing\] ill-feeling.[^fn_58b_12] If, therefore, she said, 'I do not wish either to be maintained by you or to work for you', she is entitled to do so.[^fn_58b_13]

An objection was raised: Maintenance \[for a wife\] was provided in return for her handiwork![^fn_58b_14] — Read: Her handiwork was assigned \[to her husband\] in return for her maintenance.

May it be suggested that \[our Mishnah\] provides support for his[^fn_58b_15] view? \[It stated,\] IF A MAN CONSECRATED HIS WIFE'S HANDIWORK SHE MAY NEVERTHELESS CONTINUE TO WORK AND TO CONSUME \[THE PROCEEDS HERSELF\]. Does not \[this refer to a wife for whom her husband is able[^fn_58b_16] to\] provide maintenance?[^fn_58b_17] — No; \[it is a case where the husband is unable to\] provide her maintenance. If, however, \[her husband is unable to\] provide her maintenance, what need was there to state \[such an obvious case\]?[^fn_58b_18] Even according to him who holds that a master has the right to say to his slave, 'Work for me but I will not maintain you,'[^fn_58b_19] such a rule applies only to a Canaanite slave concerning whom Scripture has not written 'with thee', but not to a Hebrew slave concerning whom it is written in Scripture. With thee,[^fn_58b_20] how much less then \[would this apply to\] his wife?[^fn_58b_21] — It[^fn_58b_22] was necessary \[as an introduction to\] the final clause: \[IF, HOWEVER, HE CONSECRATED\] THE SURPLUS \[ONLY\]. R. MEIR RULED: IT IS DULY CONSECRATED.[^fn_58b_23] R. JOHANAN HA-SANDELAR RULED: IT REMAINS UNCONSECRATED.

Now \[R. Huna's ruling\] is in disagreement with that of Resh Lakish. For Resh Lakish stated: You must not assume that R. Meir's reason[^fn_58b_24] is because he is of the opinion that a man may consecrate that which has not yet come into existence[^fn_58b_25] but this is R. Meir's reason: Since \[a husband\] has the right to compel her to work, his consecration is regarded as if he had said to her, 'May your hands[^fn_58b_26] be consecrated to Him who created them'. But, surely, he[^fn_58b_27] did not use such an expression![^fn_58b_28] — Since R. Meir was heard to state that a man does not utter his words to no purpose,[^fn_58b_29] \[the expression the husband used here\][^fn_58b_30] may be regarded as if he had actually said to her, 'May your hands be consecrated to Him who created them'. But is R. Meir of the opinion that a man cannot consecrate anything that is not yet in existence? Surely it was taught: If a man said to a woman, 'Be thou betrothed unto me after I shall have become a proselyte' or 'After thou shalt have become a proselyte'. 'After I shall have been set free', 'After thou shalt have been set free', 'After thy husband will have died', 'After thy sister will have died', or 'After thy brother-in-law shall have submitted to *halizah*[^fn_58b_31] from thee', she, R. Meir ruled, is legally betrothed![^fn_58b_32] — From that \[Baraitha\] the inference[^fn_58b_33] may indeed be drawn;[^fn_58b_34] from this, \[our Mishnah\], however, it cannot be inferred.[^fn_58b_35]

\[IF, HOWEVER, HE CONSECRATED\] THE SURPLUS \[ONLY\]. R. MEIR RULED: IT IS DULY CONSECRATED. When does it become consecrated? — Both Rab and Samuel stated: The surplus becomes consecrated only after \[the wife's\] death.[^fn_58b_36] R. Adda b. Ahabah stated: The surplus is consecrated while she is still alive.[^fn_58b_37] \[In considering this statement\] R. Papa argued: In what circumstances?[^fn_58b_38] If it be suggested: Where \[the husband\] allows her maintenance[^fn_58b_39] and also allows her[^fn_58b_40] a silver *ma'ah*[^fn_58b_41] for her other requirements,[^fn_58b_42] what \[it may be retorted\] is the reason of those who stated that it 'becomes consecrated only after \[the wife's\] death'?[^fn_58b_43] If, however, it is a case where \[the husband\] does not allow her maintenance and does not allow her a silver *ma'ah* for her other requirements, what \[it may be objected\] is the reason of him who stated that 'it is consecrated while she is still alive'? — This is a case indeed[^fn_58b_44] where he does allow her maintenance; but does not allow her a silver *ma'ah* for her other requirements. Rab and Samuel are of the opinion that \[the Rabbis\] have ordained [pg 59a]

maintenance \[for a wife\] in return for her handiwork,[^fn_59a_1] and a silver *ma'ah*[^fn_59a_2] in return for the surplus;[^fn_59a_3] and since the husband does not give her the silver *ma'ah*, the surplus remains hers.[^fn_59a_4] R. Adda b. Ahabah, however, is of the opinion that maintenance was ordained in return for the surplus,[^fn_59a_3] and the silver *ma'ah* in return for her handiwork; and since \[the husband\] supplies her maintenance, the surplus is his. On what principle do they[^fn_59a_5] differ? — The Masters hold that the usual[^fn_59a_6] is for the usual,[^fn_59a_7] and the Master holds that the fixed \[sum\][^fn_59a_8] is for the fixed \[quantity\].[^fn_59a_9]

An objection was raised: Maintenance \[for a wife\] was provided in return for her handiwork![^fn_59a_10] — Read: In return for the surplus of her handiwork.

Come and hear: If he does not give her a silver *ma'ah* for her other requirements, her handiwork belongs to her![^fn_59a_11] — Read: The surplus of her handiwork belongs to her. But, surely, in connection with this statement it was taught: What \[is the quantity of work that\] she[^fn_59a_12] must do for him?[^fn_59a_13] The weight of five sela's[^fn_59a_14] of warp in Judaea \[etc.\]![^fn_59a_15] — It is this that was meant: What is the quantity of work \[that she must do\] in order that we might determine how much is her surplus? The weight of five sela's of warp in Judaea which is ten sela's[^fn_59a_16] in Galilee.

Samuel stated: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Johanan ha-Sandelar.[^fn_59a_17] But could Samuel have made such a statement? Have we not learned: \[If a woman said to her husband\],[^fn_59a_18] if I do aught for your mouth',[^fn_59a_19] he[^fn_59a_20] need not annul her vow.[^fn_59a_21] R. Akiba, however, said: He[^fn_59a_20] must annul it, since she might do more work than is due to him.[^fn_59a_22] R. Johanan b. Nuri said: He[^fn_59a_20] must annul her vow[^fn_59a_23] since he might happen to divorce her[^fn_59a_24] and she would \[owing to her vow\] be forbidden to return[^fn_59a_25] to him.[^fn_59a_26] And Samuel stated: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Johanan b. Nuri?[^fn_59a_27] — When Samuel stated, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Johanan b. Nuri' \[he referred only\] to the surplus.[^fn_59a_28] Then let him[^fn_59a_29] specifically state, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Johanan b. Nuri in respect of the surplus', or else 'The *halachah* is not in agreement with the first Tanna',[^fn_59a_30] or else, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Akiba![^fn_59a_31] — But, replied R. Joseph, you speak of konamoth?[^fn_59a_32] Konamoth are different. For, as a man may[^fn_59a_33] forbid to himself the fruit of his fellow[^fn_59a_34] so may he also consecrate[^fn_59a_35] that which is not yet in existence.[^fn_59a_36] Said Abaye to him:[^fn_59a_37] It is quite logical that a man should be entitled to forbid the use of the fruit of his fellows to himself,[^fn_59a_38] since he may also forbid his own fruit[^fn_59a_39] to his fellow;[^fn_59a_40] should he, however, have the right to forbid something that is not yet in existence,[^fn_59a_41] seeing that no man has the right[^fn_59a_42] to forbid the fruit of his fellow to his fellow?[^fn_59a_43] — But, replied R. Huna son of R. Joshua, \[that[^fn_59a_44] is a case\] where the woman said, 'My hands shall be consecrated to Him who created them', \[such consecration being valid\] since her hands are in existence.[^fn_59a_45] But even if she had said so, could she consecrate them? Are they not mortgaged to him?[^fn_59a_46] — \[This is a case\] where she said,[^fn_59a_47] 'When I shall have been divorced'.[^fn_59a_48] But is there a consecration that could not take effect now[^fn_59a_49] and would nevertheless become effective later?[^fn_59a_50] — And why not? retorted R. Elai. Were a man to say to his friend, 'This field that I am selling you shall be consecrated as soon as I shall have re-purchased it from you', would it not[^fn_59a_51] become consecrated?[^fn_59a_52] R. Jeremiah demurred: What a comparison? There[^fn_59a_53] \[the seller\] has the right to consecrate \[his field\];[^fn_59a_54] here,[^fn_59a_55] however, \[the woman\] has no power to divorce herself![^fn_59a_56] This[^fn_59a_55] is rather similar[^fn_59a_57] to the case of a man who said to another, 'This field which I have sold to you shall become consecrated after I shall have re-purchased it from you', where it does not become consecrated.[^fn_59a_58] R. Papa demurred: Are the two cases at all similar? There[^fn_59a_59] both the field itself and its produce are in the possession of the buyer, but here[^fn_59a_60] the wife's person is in her own possession. This[^fn_59a_60] is rather similar[^fn_59a_61] to the case of a man who said to another, [pg 59b]

'This field which I have mortgaged to you shall be consecrated after I have redeemed it,' where it is consecrated. R. Shisha son of R. Idi demurred: Are these cases similar? There it[^fn_59b_1] is in his[^fn_59b_2] power to redeem it; but here she has no power to divorce herself. This is rather similar to the case of a man who said to his fellow, 'This field which I have mortgaged to you for ten years[^fn_59b_3] shall be consecrated when I shall have redeemed it', where it becomes consecrated. R. Ashi demurred: Are these cases similar? There[^fn_59b_4] he[^fn_59b_2] has the power to redeem it at least after ten years, but here she has never the power to divorce herself![^fn_59b_5] — But, replied R. Ashi, you speak of konamoth! Konamoth are different \[from ordinary vows\] since they effect the consecration of the body[^fn_59b_6] itself;[^fn_59b_7] and \[the reason here[^fn_59b_8] is the same\] as that of Raba, for Raba stated: Consecration,[^fn_59b_9] leavened food[^fn_59b_10] and manumission[^fn_59b_11] cancel a mortgage.[^fn_59b_12] They[^fn_59b_13] should then[^fn_59b_14] become consecrated forthwith![^fn_59b_15] — The Rabbis have imparted force to a husband's rights[^fn_59b_16] \[over his wife\] so that they[^fn_59b_13] shall not become consecrated forthwith.[^fn_59b_17]

***MISHNAH***. THE FOLLOWING ARE THE KINDS OF WORK WHICH A WOMAN MUST PERFORM FOR HER HUSBAND: GRINDING CORN, BAKING BREAD, WASHING CLOTHES, COOKING, SUCKLING HER CHILD, MAKING READY HIS BED AND WORKING IN WOOL. IF SHE BROUGHT HIM ONE BONDWOMAN[^fn_59b_18] SHE NEED NOT DO ANY GRINDING OR BAKING OR WASHING. \[IF SHE BROUGHT\] TWO BONDWOMEN,[^fn_59b_19] SHE NEED NOT EVEN COOK OR SUCKLE HER CHILD. IF THREE, SHE NEED NEITHER MAKE READY HIS BED NOR WORK IN WOOL. IF FOUR, SHE MAY LOUNGE[^fn_59b_20] IN AN EASY CHAIR.[^fn_59b_21] R. ELIEZER SAID: EVEN IF SHE BROUGHT HIM[^fn_59b_22] A HUNDRED BONDWOMEN HE MAY[^fn_59b_23] COMPEL HER TO WORK IN WOOL; FOR IDLENESS LEADS TO UNCHASTITY. R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL SAID: EVEN[^fn_59b_24] IF A MAN FORBADE HIS WIFE UNDER A VOW TO DO ANY WORK HE MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER *KETHUBAH*[^fn_59b_25] TO HER FOR IDLENESS LEADS TO IDIOCY.[^fn_59b_26] {¶=5.5}

***GEMARA***. GRINDING CORN! How could you imagine this?[^fn_59b_27] — Read: Attending to[^fn_59b_28] the grinding.[^fn_59b_29] And if you prefer I might say: With a hand mill.

Our Mishnah[^fn_59b_30] does not agree with the view of R. Hiyya. For R. Hiyya taught: A wife \[should be taken\] mainly for the sake[^fn_59b_31] of her beauty; mainly for the sake[^fn_59b_32] of children.[^fn_59b_33] And R. Hiyya further taught: A wife is mainly for the wearing[^fn_59b_32] of a woman's finery. And R. Hiyya further taught: He who wishes his wife to look graceful[^fn_59b_34] should clothe her in linen garments. He who wishes his daughter to have a bright complexion,[^fn_59b_35] let him, on the approach of her maturity, feed her with young fowls and give her milk to drink.

SUCKLING HER CHILD. Must it be assumed that our Mishnah[^fn_59b_36] does not agree with the View of Beth Shammai? For was it not taught: If a woman vowed not to sickle her child she must, said Beth Shammai, pull the breast out of its mouth,[^fn_59b_37] and Beth Hillel said: \[Her husband\] may compel her to suckle it.[^fn_59b_38] If she was divorced he cannot compel her; but if \[the child\] knows her[^fn_59b_39] \[her husband\] pays her the fee and may compel her to suckle it in order \[to avert\] danger?[^fn_59b_40] — It may be said to be in agreement even with the view of Beth Shammai, but here[^fn_59b_41] we are dealing with such a case, for instance, where the woman made a vow and her husband confirmed it; Beth Shammai being of the opinion that he has thereby put his finger between her teeth,[^fn_59b_42] while Beth Hillel hold that it is she that has put her finger between her teeth.[^fn_59b_43] Then[^fn_59b_44] let them[^fn_59b_45] express their disagreement as regards a *kethubah* generally.[^fn_59b_46] Furthermore, it was taught:[^fn_59b_47] Beth Shammai said: She need not suckle \[her child\]![^fn_59b_48] — But, clearly, our Mishnah is not in agreement with the view of Beth Shammai.

'If \[the child\] knows her'. [pg 60a]

At what age?[^fn_60a_1] — Raba in the name of R. Jeremiah b. Abba who had it from Rab replied: Three months. Samuel, however, said: Thirty days; while R. Isaac stated in the name of R. Johanan: Fifty days. R. Shimi b. Abaye stated: The *halachah* is in agreement with the statement of R. Isaac which was made in the name of R. Johanan. One can well understand \[the respective views of\] Rab and R. Johanan since they are guided by the child's keenness of perception.[^fn_60a_2] According to Samuel, however, is such \[precocity\][^fn_60a_3] at all possible? — When Rami b. Ezekiel came[^fn_60a_4] he said, 'Pay no regard to those rules which my brother Judah laid down in the name of Samuel; for this said Samuel: As soon as \[the child\][^fn_60a_5] knows her'.[^fn_60a_6]

A \[divorced woman\] once came to Samuel \[declaring her refusal to suckle her son\]. 'Go', he said to R. Dimi b. Joseph, 'and test her case'.[^fn_60a_7] He went and placed her among a row of women and, taking hold of her child, carried him in front of them. When he came up to her \[the child\][^fn_60a_8] looked at her face with joy,[^fn_60a_9] but she turned her eye away from him. 'Lift up your eyes'. he called to her, 'come, take away your son'. How does a blind child know \[its mother\]? R. Ashi said: By the smell and the taste.[^fn_60a_10]

Our Rabbis taught: A child must be breast fed for[^fn_60a_11] twenty-four months. From that age onwards[^fn_60a_12] he is to be regarded as one who sucks an abominable thing; these are the words of R. Eliezer. R. Joshua said: \[He may be breast fed\] even for four or five years. If, however, he ceased[^fn_60a_13] after the twenty-four months and started again[^fn_60a_14] he is to be regarded as sucking an abominable thing.[^fn_60a_15]

The Master said, 'From that age onwards he is to be regarded as one who sucks an abominable thing'. But I could point out a contradiction: As it might have been presumed that human[^fn_60a_16] milk is forbidden[^fn_60a_17] since such \[prohibition may be deduced from the following\] logical argument: If in the case of a beast[^fn_60a_18] in respect of which the law of contact[^fn_60a_19] has been relaxed[^fn_60a_20] \[the use of\] its milk has nevertheless been restricted,[^fn_60a_21] how much more should the use of his milk be restricted in the case of a human being in respect of whom the law of contact has been restricted;[^fn_60a_22] hence it was specifically stated, The camel because it[^fn_60a_23] cheweth the cud \[… it is unclean unto you\],[^fn_60a_24] only 'it' is unclean; human milk, however, is not unclean but clean. As it might also have been presumed that only \[human\] milk is excluded[^fn_60a_25] because \[the use of milk\] is not equally \[forbidden\] in all cases[^fn_60a_26] but that \[human\] blood is not excluded[^fn_60a_27] since \[the prohibition of eating blood\] is equally applicable in all cases,[^fn_60a_28] hence it was specifically stated, it,[^fn_60a_29] only 'it' is forbidden; human blood, however, is not forbidden but permitted.[^fn_60a_30] And \[in connection with this teaching\] R. Shesheth has stated: Even \[a Rabbinical\] ordinance of abstinence is not applicable to it![^fn_60a_31] — This is no difficulty. The latter[^fn_60a_32] \[refers to milk\] that has left \[the breast\][^fn_60a_33] whereas the former[^fn_60a_34] \[refers to milk\] which has not left \[the breast\]. \[This law, however\], is reversed in the case of blood,[^fn_60a_35] as it was taught: \[Human\] blood which \[is found\] upon a loaf of bread must be scraped off and \[the bread\] may only then be eaten; but that which is between the teeth[^fn_60a_36] may be sucked without any scruple.[^fn_60a_37]

The Master stated, 'R. Joshua said: \[He may be breast fed\] even for four or five years'. But was it not taught that R. Joshua said: Even when \[he carries\] his bundle on his shoulders?[^fn_60a_38] — Both represent the same age.[^fn_60a_39] R. Joseph stated: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Joshua.

It was taught: R. Marinus said, A man suffering from an attack on the chest[^fn_60a_40] may suck milk[^fn_60a_41] \[from a beast\] on the Sabbath.[^fn_60a_42] What is the reason? — Sucking is an act of unusual[^fn_60a_43] unloading[^fn_60a_44] against which, where pain[^fn_60a_45] is involved, no preventive measure has been enacted by the Rabbis. R. Joseph stated: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Marinus.

It was taught: Nahum the Galatian[^fn_60a_46] stated, If rubbish[^fn_60a_47] was collected[^fn_60a_48] in a gutter[^fn_60a_49] it is permissible to crush it with one's foot quietly[^fn_60a_50] on the Sabbath, and one need have no scruples about the matter. What is the reason? — Such repair is carried out in an unusual manner[^fn_60a_51] against which, when loss is involved,[^fn_60a_52] the Rabbis enacted no preventive measure. R. Joseph stated: The *halachah* is in agreement with the ruling of Nahum the Galatian.

'If he ceased, however, after the twenty-four months and started again he is to be regarded as one who sucks an abominable thing'. And for how long?[^fn_60a_53] — R. Judah b. Habiba replied in the name of Samuel: For three days. Others read: R. Judah b. Habiba recited[^fn_60a_54] before Samuel: 'For three days'.

Our Rabbis taught: A nursing mother whose husband died within twenty-four months \[of the birth of their child\] shall neither be betrothed nor married again [pg 60b]

until \[the completion of the\] twenty-four months;[^fn_60b_1] so R. Meir. R. Judah however, permits \[remarriage\] after eighteen months.[^fn_60b_2] Said R. Nathan[^fn_60b_3] b. Joseph: Those[^fn_60b_4] surely, are the very words of Beth Shammai and these[^fn_60b_5] are the very words of Beth Hillel; for Beth Shammai ruled: Twentyfour months,[^fn_60b_6] while Beth Hillel ruled: Eighteen months![^fn_60b_6] R. Simeon b. Gamaliel replied, I will explain:[^fn_60b_7] According to the view[^fn_60b_8] \[that a child must be breast fed for\] twenty-four months[^fn_60b_9] \[a nursing mother\] is permitted to marry again after twenty-one months,[^fn_60b_10] and according to the view[^fn_60b_11] \[that it is to be breast fed for\] eighteen months[^fn_60b_12] she may marry again after fifteen months;[^fn_60b_13] because a \[nursing mother's\] milk deteriorates only three months after \[her conception\].[^fn_60b_14]

'Ulla stated: The *halachah* is in agreement with the ruling of R. Judah;[^fn_60b_15] and Mar 'Ukba stated: R. Hanina permitted me to marry \[a nursing woman\] fifteen months after \[the birth of her child\].[^fn_60b_16]

Abaye's metayer once came to Abaye and asked him: Is it permissible to betroth \[a nursing woman\] fifteen months after \[her child's birth\]? — The other answered him: In the first place[^fn_60b_17] \[whenever there is disagreement\] between R. Meir and R. Judah the *halachah* is in agreement with the view of R. Judah;[^fn_60b_15] and, furthermore, \[in a dispute between\] Beth Shammai and Beth Hillel the *halachah* is in agreement with the view of Beth Hillel;[^fn_60b_18] and while 'Ulla said, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Judah',[^fn_60b_15] Mar 'Ukba stated, 'R. Hanina permitted me to marry \[a nursing woman\] fifteen months after \[the birth of her child\]', how much more then \[is there no need for you to wait the longer period\] since you only intend betrothal. When he[^fn_60b_19] came to R. Joseph[^fn_60b_20] the latter told him, 'Both Rab and Samuel ruled that \[a nursing woman\] must wait twenty-four months exclusive of the day on which her child was born and exclusive of the day on which she is betrothed'.[^fn_60b_21] Thereupon he[^fn_60b_22] ran[^fn_60b_23] three parasangs[^fn_60b_24] after him, (some say, one *parasang* along sand mounds), but failed to overtake him.

Said Abaye: The statement made by the Rabbis that 'Even \[a question about the permissibility of eating\] an egg[^fn_60b_25] with kutha[^fn_60b_26] a man shall not[^fn_60b_27] decide[^fn_60b_28] in a district \[which is under the jurisdiction\] of his Master' was not due \[to the view that this might\] appear as an act of irreverence[^fn_60b_29] but to the reason that \[a disciple\] would have no success in dealing with the matter. For I have in fact learned the tradition of Rab and Samuel and yet I did not get the opportunity of applying it.[^fn_60b_30]

Our Rabbis taught: \[If a nursing mother\] gave her child to a wet nurse or weaned him, or if he died, she is permitted to marry again forthwith.[^fn_60b_31] R. Papa and R. Huna son of R. Joshua intended to give a practical decision in accordance with this Baraitha, but an aged woman said to them, 'I have been in such a position[^fn_60b_32] and R. Nahman forbade me \[to marry again\].[^fn_60b_33] Surely, this could not have been so;[^fn_60b_34] for has not R. Nahman in fact permitted \[such remarriage\][^fn_60b_35] in the Exilarch's family?[^fn_60b_36] — The family of the Exilarch was different \[from ordinary people\] because no nurse would break her agreement[^fn_60b_37] with them.[^fn_60b_38]

Said R. Papi to them:[^fn_60b_39] Could you not have inferred it[^fn_60b_40] from the following? It has been taught: \[A married woman\] who was always anxious[^fn_60b_41] to spend her time[^fn_60b_42] at her paternal home,[^fn_60b_43] or who has some angry quarrel at her husband's home,[^fn_60b_44] or whose husband was in prison,[^fn_60b_44] or had gone to a country beyond the sea,[^fn_60b_45] or was old or infirm,[^fn_60b_44] or if she herself was barren, old,[^fn_60b_46] incapable of procreation or a minor,[^fn_60b_46] or if she miscarried after the death of her husband, or was in any other way incapacitated for propagation, must[^fn_60b_47] wait three months.[^fn_60b_48] These are the words of R. Meir. R. Jose,[^fn_60b_49] however, permits betrothal or marriage forthwith.[^fn_60b_50] And \[in connection with this\] R. Nahman stated in the name of Samuel: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Meir in respect of his restrictive measures![^fn_60b_51] — 'This', they[^fn_60b_52] answered him, 'did not occur to us'. The law is \[that if the child\] died \[remarriage by his mother\] is permitted \[forthwith\], but if she has weaned him \[her remarriage\] is[^fn_60b_53] forbidden. Mar son of R. Ashi ruled: Even if the child died \[the remarriage of the mother\] is forbidden, it being possible that she has killed it so as to be in a position[^fn_60b_54] to marry. It once actually happened that a mother strangled her child. This incident, however, is no proof.[^fn_60b_55] That woman[^fn_60b_56] was an imbecile, for it is not likely that \[sane\] women would strangle their children.

Our Rabbis taught: If a woman was given a child to suckle[^fn_60b_57] she must not suckle together with it either her own child or the child of any friend of hers. If she agreed to a small allowance for board she must nevertheless eat much.[^fn_60b_58] Whilst in charge of the child[^fn_60b_59] she must not eat things which are injurious for the milk. Now that you said \[that she must\] not \[suckle\] 'her own child' was there any need \[to state\] 'nor the child of any friend of hers'? — It might have been assumed that only her own child \[must not be suckled\] because owing to her affection for it she might supply it with more \[than the other child\] but that the child of a friend of hers \[may well be suckled\] because if she had no surplus \[of milk\] she would not have given any at all. Hence we were taught \[that even the child of a friend must not be suckled\].

'If she agreed to a small allowance for board she must nevertheless eat much'. Wherefrom? — R. Shesheth replied: From her own.[^fn_60b_60]

'Whilst in charge of the child she must not eat things which are injurious'. What are these? — R. Kahana replied: For instance, cuscuta,[^fn_60b_61] lichen, small fishes and earth.[^fn_60b_62] Abaye said: Even pumpkins and quinces. R. Papa said: Even a palm's heart[^fn_60b_63] and unripe dates.[^fn_60b_64] R. Ashi said: Even kamak[^fn_60b_65] and fish-hash. Some of these cause the flow of the milk to stop while others cause the milk to become turbid.

A woman who couples in a mill will have epileptic children. One who couples on the ground will have children with long necks. \[A woman\] who treads[^fn_60b_66] on the blood[^fn_60b_67] of an ass will have scabby[^fn_60b_68] children. One who eats[^fn_60b_66] mustard will have intemperate children.[^fn_60b_69] One who eats[^fn_60b_66] cress will have blear-eyed children. One who eats[^fn_60b_66] fish brine[^fn_60b_70] will have children with blinking eyes.[^fn_60b_71] One who eats[^fn_60b_72] clay[^fn_60b_73] will have ugly children. One who drinks[^fn_60b_72] intoxicating liquor will have ungainly[^fn_60b_74] children. One who eats[^fn_60b_72] meat and drinks wine will have children [pg 61a]

of a robust constitution. One who eats eggs will have children with big eyes. One who eats fish will have graceful children. One who eats parsley[^fn_61a_1] will have beautiful children. One who eats coriander will have stout[^fn_61a_2] children. One who eats ethrog[^fn_61a_3] will have fragrant children. The daughter of King Shapur, whose mother had eaten ethrog[^fn_61a_3] \[while she was pregnant\] with her, used to be presented before her father as his principal perfume.

R. Huna[^fn_61a_4] related: R. Huna b. Hinena tested us \[with the following question:\] If she[^fn_61a_5] says that she wishes to suckle her child and he[^fn_61a_6] says that she shall not suckle it her wish is to be granted,[^fn_61a_7] for she would be the sufferer.[^fn_61a_8] What, \[however, is the law\] where he says that she shall suckle the child and she says that she will not suckle it? Whenever this[^fn_61a_9] is not the practice in her family we, of course, comply with her wish; what, \[however, is the law\] where this is the practice in her family but not in his? Do we follow the practice of his family or that of hers? And we solved his problem from this: She[^fn_61a_10] rises with him[^fn_61a_11] but does not go down with him.[^fn_61a_12] What, said R. Huna, is the Scriptural proof?[^fn_61a_13] — For she is a man's wife,[^fn_61a_14] \[she is to participate\] in the rise of her husband but not in his descent. R. Eleazar said, \[The proof is\] from here: Because she[^fn_61a_15] was the mother of all living[^fn_61a_16] she was given \[to her husband\][^fn_61a_17] to live but not to suffer pain.

IF SHE BROUGHT HIM ONE BONDWOMAN etc. Her other duties, however, she must obviously perform; \[but why?\] Let her say to him, 'I brought you a wife in my place'![^fn_61a_18] — Because he might reply, 'That bondwoman works for me and for herself, who will work for you!'

\[IF SHE BROUGHT\] TWO BONDWOMEN, SHE NEED NOT EVEN COOK OR SUCKLE etc. Her other duties, however, she must obviously perform; \[but why\]? Let her say to him, 'I brought you another wife who will work for me and for her, while the first one \[will work\] for you and for herself!' — Because he might reply, 'Who will do the work for our guests[^fn_61a_19] and occasional visitors!'[^fn_61a_20]

IF THREE, SHE NEED NEITHER MAKE READY HIS BED. Her other duties, however, she must perform; \[but why\]? Let her say to him, 'I brought you a third one[^fn_61a_21] to attend upon our guests and occasional visitors!' — Because he might reply, 'The more the number of the household the more the number of guests and occasional visitors'. If so,[^fn_61a_22] \[the same plea could also be advanced\] even \[when the number of bondwomen was\] four! — \[In the case of\] four bondwomen, since their number is considerable they assist one another.

R. Hana, or some say R. Samuel b. Nahmani, stated: \[SHE BROUGHT\] does not mean that she had actually brought; but: Wherever she is in a position to bring,[^fn_61a_23] even though she has not brought any. A Tanna taught: \[A wife is entitled to the same privileges\] whether she brought \[a bondwoman\] to him[^fn_61a_24] or whether she saved up for one out of her income.

IF FOUR, SHE MAY LOUNGE IN AN EASY CHAIR. R. Isaac b. Hanania[^fn_61a_25] stated in the name of R. Huna: Although it has been said, SHE MAY LOUNGE IN AN EASY CHAIR she should[^fn_61a_26] nevertheless fill[^fn_61a_27] for him his cup, make ready his bed and wash his face, hands and feet.[^fn_61a_28]

R. Isaac b. Hanania[^fn_61a_29] further[^fn_61a_30] stated in the name of R. Huna: All kinds of work which a wife performs for her husband a menstruant also may perform for her husband, with the exception of filling[^fn_61a_31] his cup, making ready his bed and washing his face, hands and feet.[^fn_61a_32] As to 'the making ready of his bed' Raba explained that \[the prohibition\] applies only in his presence but \[if it is done\] in his absence it does not matter.[^fn_61a_33] With regard to 'the filling of his cup'. Samuel's wife made a change[^fn_61a_34] \[by serving\] him with her left hand. \[The wife of\] Abaye placed it[^fn_61a_35] on the edge[^fn_61a_36] of the wine cask. Raba's \[wife placed it\] at the head-side of his couch, and R. Papa's \[wife put it\] on his foot-stool.[^fn_61a_37]

R. Isaac b. Hanania[^fn_61a_38] further[^fn_61a_39] stated: All \[foodstuffs\] may be held back from the waiter[^fn_61a_40] except meat and wine.[^fn_61a_41] Said R. Hisda: \[This applies only to\] fat meat and old wine. Raba said: Fat meat[^fn_61a_42] throughout the year but old wine only in the Tammuz[^fn_61a_43] season.[^fn_61a_44] 

R. Anan b. Tahlifa related: I was once standing in the presence of Samuel when they brought him a dish of mushrooms, and, had he not given me \[some of it\], I would have been exposed to danger.[^fn_61a_45] I, related R. Ashi, was once standing before R. Kahana when they brought him slices[^fn_61a_46] of turnips in vinegar, and had he not given me some, I would have been exposed to danger.

R. Papa said: Even a fragrant date \[if not tasted may expose one to danger\].[^fn_61a_45] This is the rule: Any foodstuff that has a strong flavour or an acrid taste \[will expose a man to danger[^fn_61a_45] if he is not allowed to taste of it\].

Both Abbuha[^fn_61a_47] b. Ihi and Minjamin b. Ihi \[shewed consideration for their waiter\] the one giving \[him a portion\] of every kind of dish[^fn_61a_48] while the other gave \[him a portion\][^fn_61a_49] of one kind only.[^fn_61a_50] With the former Elijah[^fn_61a_51] conversed, with the latter he did not.

\[It was related of\] two pious men, and others say of R. Mari and R. Phinehas the sons of R. Hisda, that one of them[^fn_61a_52] gave \[a share to his waiter\][^fn_61a_53] first[^fn_61a_54] while the other gave him last.[^fn_61a_55] With the one who gave \[the waiter his share\] first, Elijah[^fn_61a_56] conversed; with the one, however, who gave his waiter last, Elijah did not converse.[^fn_61a_57] 

Amemar, Mar Zutra and R. Ashi were once sitting at the gate of King Yezdegerd[^fn_61a_58] when the King's table-steward[^fn_61a_59] passed them by. R. Ashi, observing that Mar Zutra [pg 61b]

turned pale in the face, took up with his finger \[some food from the dish and\] put it to his mouth. 'You have spoilt the King's meal' \[the table-steward\][^fn_61b_1] cried. 'Why did you do such a thing?' he was asked \[by the King's officers\].[^fn_61b_1] 'The man who prepared that dish',[^fn_61b_2] he[^fn_61b_3] replied, 'has rendered the King's food objectionable'. 'Why?' they asked him. 'I noticed', he replied, 'a piece of leprous swine[^fn_61b_4] flesh in it'. They examined \[the dish\] but did not find \[such a thing\]. Thereupon he took hold of his finger and put it on it,[^fn_61b_5] saying, 'Did you examine this part?' They examined it and found it \[to be as R. Ashi had said\]. 'Why did you rely upon a miracle?' the Rabbis asked him. 'I saw', he replied, 'the demon of leprosy hovering over him'.[^fn_61b_6]

A Roman once said to a woman, 'Will you marry me?' — 'No,' she replied. Thereupon[^fn_61b_7] he brought some pomegranates, split them open and ate them in her presence. She kept on swallowing all the saliva[^fn_61b_8] that irritated her, but he did not give her \[any of the fruit\] until \[her body\] became swollen.[^fn_61b_9] Ultimately he said to her, 'If I cure you, will you marry me?' — 'Yes', she replied. Again[^fn_61b_7] he brought some pomegranates, split them and ate them in her presence. 'Spit out at once, and again and again',[^fn_61b_10] he said to her, all saliva that irritated you'. \[She did so\] until \[the matter\] issued forth from her body in the shape of a green palm-branch; and she recovered.

AND WORKING IN WOOL. Only IN WOOL but not in flax. Whose \[view then is represented in\] our Mishnah? — It is that of R. Judah. For it was taught: \[Her husband\] may not compel her to wait[^fn_61b_11] upon his father or upon his son, or to put straw before his beast;[^fn_61b_12] but he may compel her to put straw before his herd.[^fn_61b_13] R. Judah said: Nor may he compel her to work in flax because flax causes one's mouth to be sore[^fn_61b_14] and makes one's lips stiff.[^fn_61b_15] This refers, however, only to Roman flax.

R. ELIEZER SAID: EVEN IF SHE BROUGHT HIM A HUNDRED BONDWOMEN. R. Malkio stated in the name of R. Adda b. Ahabah: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer. Said R. Hanina the son of R. Ika: \[The rulings concerning\] a spit,[^fn_61b_16] bondwomen[^fn_61b_17] and follicles[^fn_61b_18] \[were laid down by\] R. Malkio; \[but those concerning\] a forelock,[^fn_61b_19] wood-ash[^fn_61b_20] and cheese[^fn_61b_21] \[were laid down by\] R. Malkia. R. Papa, however, said: \[If the statement is made on\] a Mishnah or a Baraitha \[the author is\] R. Malkia \[but if on\] a reported statement[^fn_61b_22] \[the author is\] R. Malkio. And your mnemonic[^fn_61b_23] is, 'The Mishnah[^fn_61b_24] is queen'.[^fn_61b_25] What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_61b_26] — \[The statement on\] Bondwomen.[^fn_61b_27] R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL SAID etc. Is not this the same view as that of the first Tanna?[^fn_61b_28] — The practical difference between them \[is the case of a woman\] who plays with little cubs[^fn_61b_29] or \[is addicted to\] checkers.[^fn_61b_30]

         ***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN FORBADE HIMSELF BY VOW TO HAVE INTERCOURSE WITH HIS WIFE[^fn_61b_31] BETH SHAMMAI RULED: \[SHE MUST CONSENT TO THE DEPRIVATION FOR\] TWO WEEKS;[^fn_61b_32] BETH HILLEL RULED: \[ONLY FOR\] ONE WEEK.[^fn_61b_32]

STUDENTS MAY GO AWAY[^fn_61b_33] TO STUDY THE TORAH, WITHOUT THE PERMISSION \[OF THEIR WIVES FOR A PERIOD OF\] THIRTY DAYS; LABOURERS \[ONLY FOR\] ONE WEEK.

THE TIMES FOR CONJUGAL DUTY PRESCRIBED IN THE TORAH[^fn_61b_34] ARE: FOR MEN OF INDEPENDENCE,[^fn_61b_35] EVERY DAY; FOR LABOURERS, TWICE A WEEK; FOR ASS-DRIVERS,[^fn_61b_36] ONCE A WEEK; FOR CAMEL-DRIVERS,[^fn_61b_37] ONCE IN THIRTY DAYS; FOR SAILORS,[^fn_61b_38] ONCE IN SIX MONTHS. THESE ARE THE RULINGS OF R. ELIEZER.

***GEMARA***. What is the reason of Beth Shammai?[^fn_61b_39] — They derive their ruling from \[the law relating to\] a woman who bears a female child.[^fn_61b_40] And Beth Hillel? — They derive their ruling from \[the law relating to\] one who bears a male child.[^fn_61b_41] Why should not Beth Hillel also derive their ruling from \[the law relating to\] a woman who bears a female child?[^fn_61b_42] — If they had derived their ruling from \[the law relating to\] a woman who bears a child they should indeed have ruled thus, but \[the fact is that\] Beth Hillel derive their ruling from \[the law of\] the menstruant.[^fn_61b_43] On what principle do they[^fn_61b_44] differ? — One[^fn_61b_45] is of the opinion that the usual[^fn_61b_46] \[is to be inferred\] from the usual,[^fn_61b_47] and the other[^fn_61b_48] is of the opinion that what a husband has caused[^fn_61b_49] should be derived from that which he has caused.[^fn_61b_50]

Rab stated: They[^fn_61b_44] differ only in the case of one who specified \[the period of abstention\] but where he did not specify the period it is the opinion of both that he must divorce her forthwith and give her the *kethubah*. Samuel, however, stated: Even where the period had not been specified the husband may delay \[his divorce\],[^fn_61b_51] since it might be possible for him to discover some reason[^fn_61b_52] for \[the remission of\] his vow.[^fn_61b_53] But surely, they[^fn_61b_54] once disputed this question; for have we not learned: If a man forbade his wife by vow to have any benefit from him he may, for thirty days, appoint a steward,[^fn_61b_55] but if for a longer period he must divorce her and give her the *kethubah*. And \[in connection with this\] Rab stated: This ruling applies only where he specified \[the period\] but where he did not specify it he must divorce her forthwith and give her the *kethubah*, while Samuel stated: Even where the period had not been specified the husband may also postpone \[his divorce\],[^fn_61b_51] since it might be possible for him, to discover some grounds[^fn_61b_52] for \[the annulment of his vow\]?[^fn_61b_56] — \[Both disputes are\] required. For if \[their views\] had been stated in the former[^fn_61b_57] only it might have been assumed that only in that case did Rab maintain his view, since \[the appointment\] of a steward is not possible but that in the second case[^fn_61b_58] where \[the appointment\] of a steward is possible he agrees with Samuel. And If the second case[^fn_61b_58] only had been stated it might have been assumed that only in that case did Samuel maintain his view[^fn_61b_59] but that in the former case[^fn_61b_60] he agrees with Rab. \[Hence both statements were\] necessary.

STUDENTS MAY GO AWAY TO STUDY etc. For how long \[may they go away\] with the permission \[of their wives\]? — For as long as they desire. [pg 62a]

What should be the usual periods?[^fn_62a_1] — Rab said: One month at the college[^fn_62a_2] and one month at home; for it is said in the Scriptures, In any matter of the courses which came in and went out month by month throughout all the months of the year.[^fn_62a_3] R. Johanan, however, said: One month at the college and two months at home; for it is said in the Scriptures, A month they were in Lebanon and two months at home.[^fn_62a_4] Why does not Rab also derive his opinion from this text?[^fn_62a_4] — The building of the holy Temple is different \[from the study of the Torah\] since it could be carried on by others.[^fn_62a_5] Then why does not R. Johanan derive his opinion from the former text?[^fn_62a_3] — There \[the conditions were\] different because every man was in receipt of relief.[^fn_62a_6]

Rab said:[^fn_62a_7] A sigh breaks down half of the human constitution,[^fn_62a_8] for it is said in Scripture, Sigh, therefore, thou son of man; with the breaking of thy loins[^fn_62a_9] and with bitterness shalt thou sigh.[^fn_62a_10] R. Johanan, however, said: Even all the human constitution, for it is said in Scripture, And it shall be when they say unto thee: Wherefore sighest thou? that thou shalt say: Because of the tidings, for it cometh; and every heart shall melt, and all hands shall be slack, and every spirit shall faint, and all knees shall drip with water.[^fn_62a_11] As to R. Johanan, is it not also written, 'With the breaking of thy loins'? — \[The meaning of\] this is that when \[the breaking\] begins it does so from the loins. And as to Rab, is it not also written, 'And every heart shall melt, and all hands shall be slack, and every spirit shall be faint'? — The report of the holy Temple is different since \[the calamity\] was very severe.

An Israelite and an idolater were once walking together on the same road and the idolater could not keep pace with the Israelite. Reminding him of the destruction of the holy Temple \[the latter\] grew faint and sighed; but still the idolater was unable to keep pace with him. 'Do you not say', the idolater asked him, 'that a sigh breaks half of the human body'? — 'This applies only', the other replied, 'to a fresh calamity but not to this one with which we are familiar. As people say: A woman who is accustomed to bereavements is not alarmed \[when another occurs\]'.

MEN OF INDEPENDENCE EVERY DAY. What is meant by tayyalin?[^fn_62a_12] — Raba replied: Day students.[^fn_62a_13] Said Abaye to him: \[These are the men\] of whom it is written in Scripture, It is vain for you[^fn_62a_14] that ye rise early, and sit up late, ye that eat of the bread of toil; so He giveth[^fn_62a_15] unto those who chase their sleep away;[^fn_62a_16] and 'these',[^fn_62a_17] R. Isaac explained, 'are the wives of the scholars,[^fn_62a_18] who chase the sleep from their eyes[^fn_62a_19] in this world and achieve thereby the life of the world to come',[^fn_62a_20] and yet you Say. Day students'![^fn_62a_21] — \[The explanation\]. however, said Abaye, is in agreement \[with a statement\] of Rab who said \[a man of independence is one.\] for instance, like R. Samuel b. Shilath[^fn_62a_22] who eats of his own, drinks of his own and sleeps in the shadow of his mansion[^fn_62a_23] and a king's officer[^fn_62a_24] never passes his door.[^fn_62a_25] When Rabin came[^fn_62a_26] he stated: \[A man of independence is one\]. for instance, like the pampered men of the West,[^fn_62a_27]

R. Abbahu[^fn_62a_28] was once standing in a bath house, two slaves supporting him, when \[the floor of\] the bath house collapsed under him.[^fn_62a_29] By chance he was near a column \[upon which\] he climbed[^fn_62a_30] taking up the slaves with him.[^fn_62a_31] R. Johanan was once ascending a staircase, R. Ammi and R. Assi supporting him, when the staircase collapsed under him. He himself climbed up and brought them up with him. Said the Rabbis to him, 'Since \[your strength is\] such, why do you require support?[^fn_62a_32] — 'Otherwise', he replied. what \[strength\] will I reserve for the time of my old age?'

FOR LABOURERS TWICE A WEEK. Was it not, however, taught: Labourers, once a week? — R. Jose the son of R. Hanina replied: This is no difficulty; the former[^fn_62a_33] \[speaks of labourers\] who do their work in their own town while the latter \[speaks of those\] who do their work in another town — So it was also taught: Labourers \[perform their marital duties\] twice a week. This applies only \[to those\] who do their work in their own town, but for those who do their work in another town \[the time is only\] once a week

FOR ASS-DRIVERS ONCE A WEEK. Rabhah son of R. Hanan[^fn_62a_34] said to Abaye: Did the Tanna[^fn_62a_35] go to all this trouble[^fn_62a_36] to teach us \[merely the law relating to\] the man of independence[^fn_62a_37] and the labourer?[^fn_62a_38] — The other replied: No; [pg 62b]

to all.[^fn_62b_1] But was it not stated ONCE IN SIX MONTHS?[^fn_62b_2] — One who has bread in his basket is not like one who has no bread in his basket.[^fn_62b_3]

Said Rabbah[^fn_62b_4] son of R. Hanan to Abaye: What \[is the law where\] an ass-driver becomes a camel-driver?[^fn_62b_5] — The other replied: A woman prefers one *kab*[^fn_62b_6] with frivolity to ten *kab*[^fn_62b_6] with abstinence.[^fn_62b_7]

FOR SAILORS, ONCE IN SIX MONTHS. THESE ARE THE WORDS OF R. ELIEZER. R. Beruna[^fn_62b_8] stated in the name of Rab:[^fn_62b_9] The *halachah* follows R. Eliezer. R. Adda b. Ahabah, however, stated in the name of Rab: This is the view of R. Eliezer only. but the Sages ruled: Students may go away to study Torah without the permission \[of their wives even for\] two or three years.[^fn_62b_10]

Raba stated: The Rabbis[^fn_62b_11] relied on R. Adda b. Ahabah[^fn_62b_12] and act accordingly at the risk of \[losing\] their lives.[^fn_62b_13] Thus R. Rehumi who was frequenting \[the school\] of Raba at Mahuza[^fn_62b_14] used to return home on the Eve of every Day of Atonement. On one occasion[^fn_62b_15] he was so attracted by his subject \[that he forgot to return home\]. His wife was expecting \[him every moment, saying.\] 'He is coming soon,[^fn_62b_16] he is coming soon'[^fn_62b_16] As he did not arrive she became so depressed that tears began to flow from her eyes. He was \[at that moment\] sitting on a roof. The roof collapsed under him and he was killed.[^fn_62b_17]

How often[^fn_62b_18] are scholars to perform their marital duties? — Rab Judah in the name of Samuel replied: Every Friday night.[^fn_62b_19]

That bringeth forth its fruit in its season,[^fn_62b_20] Rab Judah, and some say R. Huna, or again. as others say. R. Nahman, stated: This \[refers to the man\] who performs his marital duty every Friday night.[^fn_62b_21]

Judah[^fn_62b_22] the son of R. Hiyya and son-in-law of R. Jannai was always spending his time[^fn_62b_23] in the school house but every Sabbath eve[^fn_62b_24] he came home. Whenever he arrived the people saw[^fn_62b_25] a pillar of light moving before him. Once he was so attracted by his subject of study \[that he forgot to return home\]. Not Seeing[^fn_62b_26] that Sign. R. Jannai said to those \[around him\], 'Lower[^fn_62b_27] his bed,[^fn_62b_28] for had Judah been alive he would not have neglected the performance of his marital duties'. This \[remark\] was like an error that proceedeth from the ruler,[^fn_62b_29] for \[in consequence\] Judah's[^fn_62b_30] soul returned to its eternal rest.

Rabbi was engaged in the arrangements for the marriage of his son into the family of R. Hiyya,[^fn_62b_31] but when the *kethubah*[^fn_62b_32] was about to be written the bride passed away.[^fn_62b_33] 'Is there, God forbid', said Rabbi, 'any taint \[in the proposed union\]?'[^fn_62b_34] An enquiry was instituted[^fn_62b_35] into \[the genealogy of the two\] families \[and it was discovered that\] Rabbi descended from Shephatiah[^fn_62b_36] the son of Abital[^fn_62b_37] while R. Hiyya descended from Shimei a brother of David.[^fn_62b_38]

Later[^fn_62b_39] he[^fn_62b_40] was engaged in preparations for the marriage of his son into the family of R. Jose b. Zimra. It was agreed that he[^fn_62b_41] should spend twelve years at the academy.[^fn_62b_42] When the girl was led before him[^fn_62b_41] he said to them, 'Let it[^fn_62b_43] be six years'. When they made her pass before him \[a second time\] he said,'I would rather marry \[her first\] and then proceed \[to the academy\]'. He felt abashed[^fn_62b_44] before his father, but the latter said to him.'My son, you[^fn_62b_45] have the mind of your creator;[^fn_62b_46] for in Scripture it is written first, Thou bringest them in and plantest them[^fn_62b_47] and later it is written, And let them make Me a sanctuary. that I may dwell among them.[^fn_62b_48] \[After the marriage\] he departed and spent twelve years at the academy. By the time he returned his wife[^fn_62b_49] had lost the power of procreation. 'What shall we do?', said Rabbi. 'Should we order him to divorce her, it would be said: This poor soul waited in vain! Were he to marry another woman, it would be said: The latter is his wife and the other his mistress.' He prayed for mercy to be vouchsafed to her, and she recovered.

R. Hanania b. Hakinai was about to go away to the academy towards the conclusion of R. Simeon b. Yohai's wedding. 'Wait for me', the latter said to him, 'until I am able to join you'.[^fn_62b_50] He, however, did not wait for him but went away alone and spent twelve years at the academy. By the time he returned the streets of the town were altered and he was unable to find the way[^fn_62b_51] to his home. Going down to the river bank and sitting down there he heard a girl being addressed thus: 'Daughter of Hakinai, O, daughter of Hakinai, fill up your pitcher and let us go!' 'It is obvious',[^fn_62b_52] he thought, 'that the girl is ours', and he followed her. \[When they reached the house\] his wife was sitting and sifting flour. She[^fn_62b_53] lifted up her eyes and seeing him, was so overcome with joy[^fn_62b_54] that she fainted.[^fn_62b_55] 'O, Lord of the universe', \[the husband\] prayed to Him, 'this poor soul; is this her reward?'[^fn_62b_56] And so he prayed for mercy to be vouchsafed to her and she revived.

R. Hama b. Bisa went away \[from home and\] spent twelve years at the house of study. When he returned he said, 'I will not act as did b. Hakina'.[^fn_62b_57] He therefore entered the \[local\] house of study and sent word to his house. Meanwhile his son, R. Oshaia[^fn_62b_58] entered, sat down before him and addressed to him a question on \[one of the\] subjects of study. \[R. Hama\]. seeing how well versed he was in his studies, became very depressed. 'Had I been here,'[^fn_62b_59] he said, 'l also could have had such a child'.- \[When\] he entered his house his son came in, whereupon \[the father\] rose before him, believing that he wished to ask him some \[further\] legal questions. 'What[^fn_62b_60] father', his wife chuckled,[^fn_62b_61] 'stands up before a son!' Rami b. Hama applied to him \[the following Scriptural text:\] And a threefold cord is not quickly broken[^fn_62b_62] is a reference to R. Oshaia, son of R. Hania. son of Bisa.[^fn_62b_63]

R.
