Akiba was a shepherd of Ben Kalba Sabua.[^fn_62b_64] The latter's daughter. seeing how modest and noble \[the shepherd\] was, said to him, 'Were I to be betrothed to you. would you go away to \[study at\] an academy?' 'Yes', he replied. She was then secretly betrothed to him and sent him away. When her father heard \[what she had done\] he drove her from his house and forbade her by a vow to have any benefit from his estate. \[R. Akiba\] departed. and spent twelve years at the academy. When he returned home he brought with him twelve thousand disciples. \[While in his home town\] he heard an old man saying to her, 'How long [pg 63a]

will you lead the life of a living widowhood?' 'If he would listen to me,' she replied. 'he would spend \[in study\] another twelve years'. Said \[R. Akiba\]: 'It is then with her consent that I am acting'. and he departed again and spent another twelve years at the academy. When he finally returned he brought with him twenty-four thousand disciples. His wife heard \[of his arrival\] and went out to meet him, when her neighbours said to her, 'Borrow some respectable clothes and put them on', but she replied: A righteous man regardeth the life of his beast.[^fn_63a_1] On approaching him she fell upon her face and kissed his feet. His attendants were about to thrust her aside, when \[R. Akiba\] cried to them, 'Leave her alone, mine and yours are hers'.[^fn_63a_2] Her father, on hearing that a great man had come to the town, said, 'I shall go to him; perchance he will invalidate my vow',[^fn_63a_3] When he came to him \[R. Akiba\] asked, 'Would you have made your vow if you had known that he was a great man?' '\[Had he known\]' the other replied. 'even one chapter or even one Single *halachah* \[I would not have made the vow\]'. He then said to him, 'I am the man'.[^fn_63a_4] The other fell upon his face and kissed his feet and also gave him half of his wealth.[^fn_63a_5]

The daughter of R. Akiba acted in a similar way[^fn_63a_6] towards Ben Azzai. This is indeed an illustration of the proverb:[^fn_63a_7] 'Ewe follows ewe; a daughter's acts are like those of her mother.'

R. Joseph the son of Raba \[was\] sent \[by\] his father to the academy under[^fn_63a_8] R. Joseph. and they arranged for him \[to stay there for\] six years. Having been there three years and the eve of the Day of Atonement approaching. he said, 'I would go and see my family'. When his father heard \[of his premature arrival\] he took up a weapon and went out to meet him. 'You have remembered', he said to him, 'your mistress!'[^fn_63a_9] Another version: He said to him, 'You have remembered your dove!'[^fn_63a_10] They got involved in a quarrel and neither the one nor the other ate of the last meal before the fast.[^fn_63a_11]

***MISHNAH***. IF A WIFE REBELS[^fn_63a_12] AGAINST HER HUSBAND. HER *KETHUBAH*[^fn_63a_13] MAY BE REDUCED BY SEVEN *DENARII*[^fn_63a_14] A WEEK.[^fn_63a_15] R. JUDAH SAID: SEVEN TROPAICS.[^fn_63a_16] FOR HOW LONG MAY THE REDUCTION CONTINUE TO BE MADE? UNTIL \[A SUM\] CORRESPONDING TO HER *KETHUBAH* \[HAS ACCUMULATED\].[^fn_63a_17] R. JOSE SAID: REDUCTIONS MAY BE MADE CONTINUALLY UNTIL \[SUCH TIME\] WHEN, SHOULD AN INHERITANCE FALL TO HER FROM ELSEWHERE, \[HER HUSBAND\] WILL BE IN A POSITION TO COLLECT FROM HER THE \[FULL AMOUNT DUE\]. SIMILARLY, IF A HUSBAND REBELS AGAINST HIS WIFE, AN ADDITION OF THREE[^fn_63a_18] *DENARII* A WEEK IS MADE TO HER *KETHUBAH*. R. JUDAH SAID: THREE TROPAICS. {¶=5.6}

***GEMARA***. REBELS in what \[respect\]? — R. Huna replied: \[In respect\] of conjugal union. R. Jose the son of R. Hanina replied: \[In respect\] of work.

We learned, SIMILARLY, IF A HUSBAND REBELS AGAINST HIS WIFE. Now according to him who said, '\[In respect\] of conjugal union \[this ruling\] is quite logical and intelligible;[^fn_63a_19] but according to him who said, '\[In respect\] of work', is he[^fn_63a_20] \[it may be objected\] under any obligation \[at all to work\] for her?[^fn_63a_21] — Yes,[^fn_63a_22] \[rebellion being possible\] when he declares 'I will neither sustain nor support \[my wife\]' — But did not Rab state: If a man says. 'I will neither sustain nor support \[my wife\]', he must divorce her and give her the *kethubah*?[^fn_63a_23] — Is it not necessary to consult him \[before ordering him to divorce her\]?[^fn_63a_24] 

An objection was raised: The same[^fn_63a_25] \[law[^fn_63a_26] is applicable to a woman\] betrothed[^fn_63a_27] or married, even to a menstruant, even to a sick woman and even to one who was awaiting the decision of the levir.[^fn_63a_28] Now,[^fn_63a_29] according to him who said, '\[In respect\] of conjugal union' it is quite correct to mention the sick, [pg 63b]

but according to him who said, '\[In respect\] of work', is a sick woman \[it may be objected\] fit to do work?[^fn_63b_1] — The fact, however, is that[^fn_63b_2] \[in respect\] of conjugal union all[^fn_63b_3] agree that \[a wife who refuses\] is regarded as a rebellious woman.[^fn_63b_4] They[^fn_63b_3] differ only in respect of work. One Master is of the opinion that \[for a refusal\] of work \[a wife\] is not to be regarded as rebellious and the other Master holds the opinion \[that for a refusal\] of work also \[a wife\] is regarded as rebellious.

\[To turn to\] the main text,[^fn_63b_5] If a wife rebels against her husband, her *kethubah* may be reduced by seven *denarii* a week. R. Judah said: Seven tropaics. Our Masters, however, took a second vote[^fn_63b_6] \[and ordained\] that an announcement regarding her shall be made on four consecutive Sabbaths and that then the court shall send her \[the following warning\]: 'Be it known to you that even if your *kethubah* is for a hundred *maneh*[^fn_63b_7] you have forfeited it'.[^fn_63b_8] The same \[law is applicable to a woman\] betrothed or married, even to a menstruant, even to a sick woman, and even to one who was awaiting the decision of the levir.[^fn_63b_9] Said R. Hiyya b. Joseph to Samuel: Is a menstruant capable of conjugal union?[^fn_63b_10] — The other replied: One who has bread in his basket is not like one who has no bread in his basket[^fn_63b_11]

Rami b. Hama stated: The announcement concerning her[^fn_63b_12] is made only in the Synagogues and the houses of study. Said Raba: This may be proved by a deduction,[^fn_63b_13] it having been taught,'Four Sabbaths consecutively'.[^fn_63b_14] This is decisive.[^fn_63b_15]

Rami b. Hania further stated: \[The warning\] is sent to her[^fn_63b_16] from the court twice, once before the announcement and once after the announcement.

R. Nahman b. R. Hisda stated in his discourse: The *halachah* is in agreement with our Masters.[^fn_63b_17] Raba remarked: This is senseless.[^fn_63b_18] Said R. Nahman b. Isaac to him, 'Wherein lies[^fn_63b_19] its senselessness? I, in fact, told it to him, and it was in the name of a great man that I told it to him. And who is it? R. Jose the son of R. Hanina!' Whose view then is he[^fn_63b_20] following? — The first of the undermentioned.[^fn_63b_21] For it was stated: Raba said in the name of R. Shesheth, 'The *halachah* is that she[^fn_63b_16] is to be consulted',[^fn_63b_22] while R. Huna b. Judah stated in the name of R. Shesheth, 'The *halachah* is that she is not to be consulted'.[^fn_63b_23]

What is to be understood by 'a rebellious woman'?[^fn_63b_24] — Amemar said: \[One\] who says. 'I like him[^fn_63b_25] but wish to torment him'.[^fn_63b_26] If she said, however, 'He is repulsive to me', no pressure is to be brought to bear upon her.[^fn_63b_27] Mar Zutra ruled: Pressure is to be brought to bear upon her.[^fn_63b_28] Such a case once occurred, and Mar Zutra exercised pressure upon the woman and \[as a result of the reconciliation that ensued\] R. Hanina of Sura[^fn_63b_29] was born from the re-union. This, however,[^fn_63b_30] was not \[the right thing to do\]. \[The successful\] result\] was due to the help of providence.[^fn_63b_31]

R. Zebid's daughter-in-law rebelled \[against her husband\][^fn_63b_32] and took possession of her silk \[cloak\].[^fn_63b_33] Amemar, Mar Zutra and R. Ashi were sitting together[^fn_63b_34] and R. Gamda sat beside them; and in the course of the session they laid down the law: \[If a wife\] rebels she forfeits her worn-out[^fn_63b_35] clothing that may still be in existence. Said R. Gamda to them, 'Is it because R. Zebid is a great man that you would flatter him? Surely R. Kahana stated that Raba had only raised this question[^fn_63b_36] but had not solved it'. Another version:[^fn_63b_37] In the course of their session they decided: \[If a wife\] rebels she does not forfeit her worn-out clothing[^fn_63b_38] that may still be in existence. Said R. Gamda to them, [pg 64a]

'Is it because R. Zebid is a great man[^fn_64a_1] that you turn the law against him? Surely R. Kahana stated that Raba had only raised the question but had not solved it'. Now that it has not been stated what the law is,[^fn_64a_2] \[such clothing\] is not to be taken away from her if she has already seized them, but if she has not yet seized them they are not to be given to her. We also make her wait twelve months, a \[full\] year. for her divorce,[^fn_64a_3] and during these twelve months she receives no maintenance from her husband.[^fn_64a_4]

R. Tobi b. Kisna stated in the name of Samuel: A certificate of rebellion may be written against a betrothed woman but no such certificate may be written against one who is awaiting the decision of the levir.[^fn_64a_5] An objection was raised: The same \[law[^fn_64a_6] is applicable to a woman\] betrothed or married, even to a menstruant, even to a sick woman and even to one who was awaiting the decision of the levir![^fn_64a_7] — This is no contradiction. The one[^fn_64a_8] refers to the case where the man claimed her;[^fn_64a_9] the other[^fn_64a_10] to that where she claimed him.[^fn_64a_11] For R. Tahlifa b. Abimi stated in the name of Samuel: If he claimed her[^fn_64a_9] he is attended to;[^fn_64a_12] if she claimed him she is not attended to.[^fn_64a_13] To what case did you explain the statement of Samuel[^fn_64a_14] as referring? To the one where she claimed him?[^fn_64a_15] \[But if so\] instead of Saying[^fn_64a_16] 'A certificate of rebellion may be written against a betrothed woman' it should have been said, 'On behalf of a betrothed woman'![^fn_64a_17] — This is no difficulty. Read, 'On behalf of a betrothed woman'.[^fn_64a_18]

Wherein does a woman awaiting the decision of the levir differ \[from the man\] that no \[certificate of rebellion should be issued on her behalf\]? Obviously because we tell her, 'Go, you are not commanded \[to marry\]';[^fn_64a_19] \[but. then.\] a betrothed woman also should be told, 'Go, you are not commanded \[to marry\]'![^fn_64a_19] Again should \[it be explained to be one\] where she comes with the plea Saying. 'I wish to have a staff in my hand and a spade for my burial',[^fn_64a_20] \[this then should\] also apply to a woman awaiting the decision of the levir if she comes with such a plea! — \[The proper explanation\] then \[must be this\]: Both statements[^fn_64a_21] \[refer to the case\] where the man claimed,[^fn_64a_22] and yet there is no difficulty. since one[^fn_64a_23] may refer[^fn_64a_24] to the performance of *halizah* and the other[^fn_64a_25] to that of the levirate marriage. For R. Pedath stated in the name of R. Johanan: \[If the levir\] claimed her for the performance of *halizah* his request is to be attended to,[^fn_64a_26] but if he claimed her for the levirate marriage his request is disregarded.[^fn_64a_27] Why \[is he\] not \[attended to when he claims her\] for the levirate marriage? Naturally because we tell him, 'Go and marry another woman'; \[but then even when he claims her\] for the performance of *halizah* could we not also tell him, 'Go and marry another woman'? Again should the answer be: \[Because\] he can plead. 'As she is bound to me[^fn_64a_28] no other wife will be given me'. Here also[^fn_64a_29] \[could he not plead\] 'As she is bound to me no other wife will be given to me'? — \[The proper explanation\] then \[is this\]: Both statements[^fn_64a_30] \[deal with one\] who claimed her for the levirate marriage. but there is really no difficulty. one[^fn_64a_31] being[^fn_64a_32] in agreement with the earlier Mishnah while the other is[^fn_64a_32] in agreement with the latter Mishnah. For we have learned: The commandment of the levirate marriage must take precedence over that of *halizah*.[^fn_64a_33] \[This was the case\] in earlier days when \[levirs\] had the intention of observing the commandment — Now, however, when their intention is not the fulfilment of the commandment, it has been ruled that the commandment of *halizah* takes precedence over that of the levirate marriage.[^fn_64a_34]

FOR HOW LONG MAY THE REDUCTION CONTINUE TO BE MADE? etc. What \[is meant by\] TROPAICS? R. Shesheth replied: \[one tropaic is\] an istira. And how much is an istira? — Half a *zuz*.[^fn_64a_35] So it was also taught: R. Judah said: Three tropaics which \[amount to\] nine *ma'ah*[^fn_64a_35] \[the reduction being at the rate of\] one *ma'ah* and a half per day.[^fn_64a_36]

R. Hiyya b. Joseph asked Of Samuel: In what respect is he[^fn_64a_37] different \[from his wife\] that he is allowed \[a reduction\] for the Sabbath,[^fn_64a_38] and in what respect is she different \[from him\] that she is not allowed \[an addition\] for the Sabbath?[^fn_64a_39] — In her case,[^fn_64a_40] since it is a reduction that is made, \[the seventh tropaic the husband gains\] does not have the appearance of Sabbath pay. In his case, however,[^fn_64a_41] since it is additions that are made, [pg 64b]

\[another addition for the seventh day\] would have the appearance of Sabbath pay. R. Hiyya b. Joseph \[further\] asked of Samuel: What \[is the reason for the distinction\] between a man who rebels \[against his wife\] and a woman who rebels \[against her husband\]?[^fn_64b_1] — The other replied. 'Go and learn it from the market of the harlots; who hires whom?'[^fn_64b_2] Another explanation: \[The manifestation of\] his passions is external; hers is internal.

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN[^fn_64b_3] MAINTAINS HIS WIFE THROUGH A TRUSTEE, HE MUST GIVE HER \[EVERY WEEK\] NOT LESS THAN TWO *KABS*[^fn_64b_4] OF WHEAT OR FOUR *KABS* OF BARLEY. SAID R. JOSE: ONLY R. ISHMAEL WHO LIVED NEAR EDOM[^fn_64b_5] GRANTED HER A SUPPLY OF BARLEY.[^fn_64b_6] HE MUST ALSO GIVE HER HALF A KAB OF PULSE AND HALF A LOG[^fn_64b_4] OF OIL; AND A KAB OF DRIED FIGS OR A *MANEH*[^fn_64b_4] OF PRESSED FIGS,[^fn_64b_7] AND IF HE HAS NO \[SUCH FRUIT\] HE MUST SUPPLY HER WITH A CORRESPONDING QUANTITY OF OTHER[^fn_64b_8] FRUIT. HE MUST ALSO PROVIDE HER WITH A BED, A MATTRESS[^fn_64b_9] AND[^fn_64b_10] A RUSH MAT. HE MUST ALSO GIVE HER \[ONCE A YEAR\] A CAP FOR HER HEAD AND A GIRDLE FOR HER LOINS; SHOES \[HE MUST GIVE HER\] EACH MAJOR FESTIVAL;[^fn_64b_11] AND CLOTHING \[OF THE VALUE\] OF FIFTY *ZUZ* EVERY YEAR. SHE IS NOT TO BE GIVEN NEW \[CLOTHES\][^fn_64b_12] IN THE SUMMER OR WORN-OUT CLOTHES IN THE WINTER, BUT MUST BE GIVEN THE CLOTHING \[OF THE VALUE\] OF FIFTY *ZUZ* DURING THE WINTER, AND SHE CLOTHES HERSELF WITH THEM WHEN THEY ARE WORN-OUT DURING THE SUMMER; AND THE WORN-OUT CLOTHES REMAIN HER PROPERTY.[^fn_64b_13] HE MUST ALSO GIVE HER \[EVERY WEEK\] A SILVER *MA'AH* FOR HER \[OTHER\] REQUIREMENTS[^fn_64b_14] AND SHE IS TO EAT WITH HIM ON THE NIGHT OF EVERY SABBATH.[^fn_64b_15] IF HE DOES NOT GIVE HER A SILVER *MA'AH* FOR HER OTHER REQUIREMENTS, HER HANDIWORK BELONGS TO HER.[^fn_64b_16] AND WHAT \[IS THE QUANTITY OF WORK THAT\] SHE MUST DO FOR HIM?[^fn_64b_17] THE WEIGHT OF FIVE SELA'S OF WARP IN JUDAEA, WHICH AMOUNTS TO TEN SELA'S IN GALILEE,[^fn_64b_18] OR THE WEIGHT OF TEN SELA'S OF WOOF[^fn_64b_19] IN JUDAEA, WHICH AMOUNTS TO TWENTY SELA'S IN GALILEE.[^fn_64b_18] IF SHE WAS NURSING \[HER CHILD\] HER HANDIWORK IS REDUCED AND HER MAINTENANCE IS INCREASED. ALL THIS APPLIES TO THE POOREST IN ISRAEL, BUT IN THE CASE OF A MEMBER OF THE BETTER CLASSES[^fn_64b_20] ALL IS FIXED ACCORDING TO THE DIGNITY OF HIS POSITION. {¶=5.7}

***GEMARA***. Whose \[view is represented in\] our Mishnah?[^fn_64b_21] \[It seems to be\] neither that of R. Johanan b. Beroka nor that of R. Simeon. For we learned: And what must be its[^fn_64b_22] size? Food for two meals for each, \[the quantity being\] the food one eats on weekdays and not On the Sabbath; so R. Meir. R. Judah said: As on the Sabbath and not as on weekdays. And both intended to give the lenient ruling.[^fn_64b_23] R. Johanan b. Beroka said:[^fn_64b_24] A loaf that is purchased for a dupondiom[^fn_64b_25] \[when the cost of wheat is at the rate of\] four *se'ah*[^fn_64b_25] for a *sela'*.[^fn_64b_25] R. Simeon said:[^fn_64b_26] Two thirds of a loaf, three of which are made from a *Kab*.[^fn_64b_27] Half of this \[loaf is the size prescribed\] for a leprous house,[^fn_64b_28] and half of its half[^fn_64b_29] renders one's body[^fn_64b_30] unfit;[^fn_64b_31] and half of the half of its half to be susceptible to Levitical uncleanness,[^fn_64b_32] Now, whose \[view is that expressed in our Mishnah\]?[^fn_64b_33] If \[it be suggested that it is that of\] R. Johanan b. Beroka \[the prescribed TWO *KABS* would only\] be \[sufficient for\] eight \[meals\].[^fn_64b_34] and if \[the suggestion is that it is that of\] R. Simeon \[the TWO *KABS* would\] be \[sufficient even for\] eighteen \[meals\].[^fn_64b_35] — \[Our Mishnah may\] in fact \[represent the view of\] R. Johanan b. Beroka but, as R. Hisda said elsewhere,[^fn_64b_36] 'Deduct a third of them for the \[profit of the\] shopkeeper',[^fn_64b_37] so here[^fn_64b_38] also take a third[^fn_64b_39] and add to them.[^fn_64b_40] But \[do not the meals\] still amount only to twelve?[^fn_64b_41] — She eats with him on Friday nights — 42 This is satisfactory according to him who explained[^fn_64b_43] \[TO EAT In our Mishnah as\] actual eating. What, however, can be said according to him who explained 'eating' \[to mean\] intercourse? Furthermore, \[would not her total number of meals still\] be only thirteen?[^fn_64b_44] — The proper answer is really this:[^fn_64b_45] As R. Hisda said elsewhere,[^fn_64b_46] 'Deduct a half for the \[profit of the\] shopkeeper.[^fn_64b_47] so here[^fn_64b_48] also take a half[^fn_64b_49] and add to them.[^fn_64b_50] (Does not a contradiction arise between the two statements of R. Hisda?[^fn_64b_51] — There is no contradiction. One statement refers[^fn_64b_52] to a place where \[the sellers of the wheat\] supply also wood[^fn_64b_53] while the other refers[^fn_64b_52] to a place where they do not supply the wood.)[^fn_64b_54] If so[^fn_64b_55] \[the number of meals\] is sixteen.[^fn_64b_56] With whose \[view then would our Mishnah agree\]? With R. Hidka who ruled: A man must eat on the Sabbath four meals?[^fn_64b_57] — It may be said to represent even the view of the Rabbis, for one meal is to be reserved for guests and occasional visitors.[^fn_64b_58] Now that you have arrived at this position \[our Mishnah\] may be said to represent even the view of R. Simeon,[^fn_64b_59] for according to the Rabbis[^fn_64b_60] three meals should be deducted[^fn_64b_61] for guests and occasional visitors[^fn_64b_62] and according to R. Hidka[^fn_64b_63] two Only are to be deducted for guests and occasional visitors.[^fn_64b_64] 

SAID R. JOSE: ONLY … GRANTED A SUPPLY OF BARLEY etc. Do they eat barley at Edom only and throughout the world none IS eaten? — It is this that he meant: ONLY R. ISHMAEL WHO LIVED NEAR EDOM GRANTED A SUPPLY OF BARLEY equal to twice the quantity of wheat, because the Idumean barley was of an inferior quality.

THE MAN MUST ALSO GIVE HER HALF A *KAB* OF PULSE. Wine, however, is not mentioned. This provides support for a view of R. Eleazar. For R. Eleazar stated: [pg 65a]

No allowance for wine is made for a woman.[^fn_65a_1] And should you point out the Scriptural text, I will go after my lovers, that give me my bread and my water, my wool and my flax. mine oil and my drink,[^fn_65a_2] \[it may be replied that the reference is to\] things which a woman desires.[^fn_65a_3] And what are they? Jewellery.

R. Judah of Kefar Nabirya[^fn_65a_4] (others say: of Kefar Napor[^fn_65a_5] Hayil) made the following exposition: Whence is it derived that no allowance for wines is made for a woman? — \[From Scripture in\] which it is said, So Hannah rose up after she had eaten[^fn_65a_6] in Shiloh, and after drinking.[^fn_65a_7] only 'he had drunk' but she did not drink. Now, then, would you also \[interpret:\] 'She had eaten'[^fn_65a_8] that he[^fn_65a_6] did not eat? — What we say is \[that the deduction may be made\] because the text has deliberately been changed. For consider: It was dealing with her, why did it change \[the form\]?[^fn_65a_9] Consequently it may be deduced that it was 'he who drank' and that she did not drink.

An objection was raised: If \[a woman\] is accustomed \[to drink\] she is given \[an allowance of drink\]! — Where she is accustomed to drink the case is different. For R. Hinena b. Kahana stated in the name of Samuel, 'If she was accustomed \[to drink\] she is given an allowance of one cup; if she was not accustomed \[to it\] she is given an allowance of two cups'. What does he mean? — Abaye replied: It is this that he means: If she was in the habit \[of drinking\] two cups in the presence of her husband she is given one cup in his absence; if she is used \[to drink\] in the presence of her husband only one cup, she is given none at all in his absence. And if you prefer I might say: If she is used \[to drink\] she is allowed some wine for her puddings[^fn_65a_10] only. For R. Abbahu stated in the name of R. Johanan: It happened that when the Sages granted the daughterin-law of Nakdimon[^fn_65a_11] b. Gorion a weekly[^fn_65a_12] allowance of two se'ahs of wine for her puddings she[^fn_65a_13] said to them, 'May you grant such allowances to your daughters'. A Tanna taught: She was a woman awaiting the decision of the levir.[^fn_65a_14] Hence they did not reply Amen after her.[^fn_65a_15]

A Tanna taught: One cup[^fn_65a_16] is becoming to a woman; two are degrading. \[and if she has\] three she solicits publicly.[^fn_65a_17] \[but if she has\] four she solicits even an ass in the street and cares not. Raba said: This was taught only \[in respect of a woman\] whose husband is not with her; but if her husband is with her \[the objection to her drinks\] does not arise.[^fn_65a_18] But, Surely. \[there is the case of\] Hannah whose husband was with her![^fn_65a_19] — With a guest[^fn_65a_20] it is different,[^fn_65a_21] for R. Huna stated Whence is it inferred that a guest is forbidden marital union? \[From Scripture in\] which it is said, And they rose up in the morning early and worshipped before the Lord, and returned, and came to their house to Ramah; and Elkanah knew Hannah his wife; and the Lord remembered her,[^fn_65a_22] only[^fn_65a_23] then[^fn_65a_24] but not before.

Homa, Abaye's wife, came to Raba[^fn_65a_25] and asked him, 'Grant me an allowance of board', and he granted her the allowance. 'Grant me \[she again demanded\] an allowance of wine'. 'I know', he said to her, 'that Nahmani[^fn_65a_26] did not drink wine'. 'By the life of the Master \[I swear\]'. she replied. 'that he gave me to drink[^fn_65a_27] from horns[^fn_65a_28] like this'.[^fn_65a_29] As she was showing it to him her arm was uncovered and a light shone[^fn_65a_30] upon the court. Raba rose, went home and solicited R. Hisda's daughter.[^fn_65a_31] 'Who has been to-day at the court?' enquired R. Hisda's daughter. 'Homa the wife of Abaye'. he replied. Thereupon she followed her, striking her with the straps[^fn_65a_32] of a chest[^fn_65a_33] until she chased her out of all Mahuza.[^fn_65a_34] 'You have', she said to her, 'already killed three \[men\].[^fn_65a_35] and now you come to kill another \[man\]!'

The wife of R. Joseph the son of Raba came before R. Nehemiah the son of R. Joseph and said to him, 'Grant me an allowance of board', and he granted her. 'Grant me also an allowance of wine' \[she demanded\], and he granted her. 'I know', he said to her, 'that the people of Mahuza drink wine'. The wife of R. Joseph the son of R. Menashya of Dewil[^fn_65a_36] came before R. Joseph and said to him, 'Grant me an allowance of board', and he granted her. 'Grant me', she said, 'an allowance of wine', and he granted her. 'Grant me', she said again. 'an allowance of silks'. 'Why silks?' he asked. 'For your sake', she replied. 'and for the sake of your friend and for the sake of your associates'.[^fn_65a_37]

HE MUST ALSO PROVIDE HER WITH A BED, A MATTRESS etc. Why[^fn_65a_38] should he give her A MATTRESS AND A RUSH MAT?[^fn_65a_39] — R. Papa replied: \[This is done only\] in a place where it is the practice to girth the bed with ropes.[^fn_65a_40] which would hurt[^fn_65a_41] her.

Our Rabbis taught: She[^fn_65a_42] is not given[^fn_65a_43] a cushion and a bolster. In the name of R. Nathan it was stated: She is given a cushion and a bolster. How is this to be understood? If it is a case where she is used to it,[^fn_65a_44] what \[it may be objected\] is the reason of the first Tanna?[^fn_65a_45] And if it is a case where she is not used to it,[^fn_65a_44] what \[it may be asked\] is the reason of R. Nathan?[^fn_65a_46] — \[The statement was\] necessary only in the case where it[^fn_65a_47] was his habit but not her habit.[^fn_65a_48] The first Tanna[^fn_65a_49] is of the opinion that \[her husband\] may say to her, 'When I go away[^fn_65a_50] I take them and when I return I bring them back with me',[^fn_65a_51] while R. Nathan holds the opinion that she can tell him, 'It might sometimes happen \[that you will return\] at twilight[^fn_65a_52] when you will be unable to bring them[^fn_65a_53] and so you will take mine[^fn_65a_54] and make me sleep on the ground'.[^fn_65a_55] 

HE MUST ALSO GIVE HER \[ONCE A YEAR\] A CAP. Said R. Papa to Abaye: [pg 65b]

This Tanna[^fn_65b_1] \[expects a person to be\] 'stripped naked and to wear shoes'![^fn_65b_2] 'The Tanna,' the other replied. 'was dealing[^fn_65b_3] with a mountainous region where one cannot possibly manage with less than three pairs of shoes \[a year\].[^fn_65b_4] and indirectly he informed us that these should be given to her on the occasion of a major festival so that she might derive joy from them.

AND CLOTHING \[OF THE VALUE\] OF FIFTY *ZUZ*. Abaye said: Fifty small *zuz*.[^fn_65b_5] Whence is this deduced? — From the statement:[^fn_65b_6] ALL THIS APPLIES TO THE POOREST IN ISRAEL, BUT IN THE CASE OF A MEMBER OF THE BETTER CLASSES ALL IS FIXED ACCORDING TO THE DIGNITY OF HIS POSITION. Now, should one imagine \[that the reference is to\] fifty real *zuz*,[^fn_65b_7] whence \[it could be objected\] would a poor man obtain fifty *zuz*? Consequently it must be concluded \[that the meaning is\] fifty small *zuz*.

SHE IS NOT TO BE GIVEN NEW etc. Our Rabbis taught: Any surplus of food[^fn_65b_8] belongs to the husband, while any Surplus of worn out clothes belongs to the woman. \[You said:\] 'Any surplus of worn out clothes belongs to the woman'; of what use are they to her? — Rehaba replied: For putting on during the days of her menstruation so that she may not \[by the constant wearing[^fn_65b_9] of the same clothes\] become repulsive to her husband. Abaye stated: We have a tradition that the surplus of the worn out clothes of a widow[^fn_65b_10] belongs to her husband's heirs. For the reason in the former case[^fn_65b_11] is that she shall not become repulsive to her husband[^fn_65b_12] but in this case[^fn_65b_13] let her be ever so repulsive.

HE MUST ALSO GIVE HER \[EVERY WEEK\] A SILVER *MA'AH* etc. What \[is meant by\] SHE IS TO EAT? — R. Nahman replied: Actual eating. R. Ashi replied: Intercourse. We have learned: SHE IS TO EAT WITH HIM ON THE NIGHT OF EVERY SABBATH. Now, according to him[^fn_65b_14] who said, '\[actual\] eating' it is quite correct to use the expression SHE IS TO EAT. According to him,[^fn_65b_15] however, who said, 'intercourse', why \[it may be asked\] was the expression SHE IS TO EAT used?[^fn_65b_16] — It is a euphemism.[^fn_65b_17] as it is written in Scripture. She[^fn_65b_18] eateth, and wipeth her mouth, and saith: 'I have done no wickedness'.[^fn_65b_19] 

An objection was raised: R. Simeon b. Gamaliel said, 'She is to eat with him on the night of the Sabbath and on the Sabbath \[day\]'. Now, according to him[^fn_65b_20] who said, '\[actual\] eating', it is correct to state, 'and on the Sabbath \[day\]'.[^fn_65b_21] According to him,[^fn_65b_22] however, who said, 'intercourse', is there any intercourse on the Sabbath day? Did not R. Huna state, The Israelites are holy and do not have intercourse in the day-time'?[^fn_65b_23] — But, Surely, Raba stated: It is permitted in a dark room.[^fn_65b_24]

IF SHE WAS NURSING \[HER CHILD\]. R. 'Ulla the Great made at the Prince's[^fn_65b_25] door the following exposition: Although it was said:[^fn_65b_26] 'A man is under no obligation to maintain his sons and daughters when they are minors', he must maintain them while they are very young.[^fn_65b_27] How long?[^fn_65b_28] — Until the age of six; in accordance \[with the view of\] R. Assi, for R. Assi stated: A child of the age of six is exempt[^fn_65b_29] by the 'erub[^fn_65b_30] of his mother. Whence \[is this[^fn_65b_31] derived\]? — From the Statement: IF SHE WAS NURSING \[HER CHILD\] HER HANDIWORK IS REDUCED AND HER MAINTENANCE IS INCREASED. What can be the reason?[^fn_65b_32] Surely because he[^fn_65b_33] must eat together with her. But is it not possible \[that the reason[^fn_65b_32] is\] because she[^fn_65b_34] ailing? — If that were the case it should have been stated, 'If she was ailing', why then \[was it stated\]. IF SHE WAS NURSING?[^fn_65b_35] But is it not possible that it was this that we were taught:[^fn_65b_36] That nursing mothers are commonly ailing?[^fn_65b_37] 

It was stated: What is the addition[^fn_65b_38] that he makes for her?[^fn_65b_39] R. Joshua b. Levi said: She is given an additional allowance for wine, because wine is beneficial for lactation.

## CHAPTER VI

***MISHNAH***. A WIFE'S FIND AND HER HANDIWORK BELONG TO HER HUSBAND. AND \[OF\] HER INHERITANCE[^fn_65b_40] HE HAS THE USUFRUCT DURING HER LIFETIME.[^fn_65b_41] \[ANY COMPENSATION FOR\] AN INDIGNITY OR BLEMISH \[THAT MAY HAVE BEEN INFLICTED UPON\] HER BELONGS TO HER. R. JUDAH B. BATHYRA RULED: WHEN IN PRIVACY[^fn_65b_42] SHE RECEIVES TWO-THIRDS \[OF THE COMPENSATION\] WHILE HE[^fn_65b_43] RECEIVES ONE-THIRD, BUT WHEN IN PUBLIC[^fn_65b_44] HE RECEIVES TWO-THIRDS[^fn_65b_45] AND SHE RECEIVES ONE-THIRD. HIS SHARE IS TO BE GIVEN TO HIM FORTHWITH, BUT WITH HERS LAND IS TO BE BOUGHT AND HE[^fn_65b_43] ENJOYS THE USUFRUCT.[^fn_65b_46] {¶=6.1}

***GEMARA***. What does he[^fn_65b_47] teach us? This surely was already learnt: A father has authority over his daughter in respect of her betrothal \[whether it was effected\] by money, by deed or by intercourse; he is entitled to anything she finds and to her handiwork; \[he has the right\] of invalidating her vows, and he receives her letter of divorce; but he has no usufruct during her lifetime. When she marries, the husband surpasses him \[in his rights\] in that he has usufruct during her lifetime![^fn_65b_48] — He[^fn_65b_49] regarded this[^fn_65b_50] as necessary \[on account of the law relating to\] INDIGNITY OR BLEMISH \[THAT MAY HAVE BEEN INFLICTED UPON\] HER, \[which is the subject of\] a dispute between R. Judah b. Bathyra and the Rabbis.[^fn_65b_51]

A tanna recited in the presence of Raba: A wife's find belongs to herself; but R. Akiba ruled: \[It belongs\] to her husband. The other[^fn_65b_52] said to him: Now that \[in respect of the\] surplus[^fn_65b_53] [pg 66a]

which is her handiwork[^fn_66a_1] R. Akiba ruled \[that it belongs\] to herself, how much more so her find? For we learned: \[If a woman said to her husband,\] 'Konam, if I do aught for your mouth', he need not invalidate her vow;[^fn_66a_2] R. Akiba, however, said: He must invalidate it, since she might do more work than is due to him![^fn_66a_3] — Reverse then: A wife's find belongs to her husband, but R. Akiba ruled \[that it belonged\] to herself. But surely, when Rabin came[^fn_66a_4] he stated in the name of R. Johanan: In respect of a surplus[^fn_66a_5] obtained through no undue exertion all[^fn_66a_6] agree that \[it belongs to the\] husband, and they only differ in respect of a surplus[^fn_66a_5] obtained through undue exertion; the first Tanna being of the opinion \[that even this belongs\] to her husband while R. Akiba maintains \[that it belongs\] to herself![^fn_66a_7] — R. Papa replied: A find is like a surplus gained through undue exertion,[^fn_66a_8] \[concerning which there is\] a difference of opinion between R. Akiba and the Rabbis.

R. Papa raised the question: What is the law where she performed for him two \[kinds of work\] simultaneously?[^fn_66a_9] Rabina raised the question: What is the ruling where she did three or four \[kinds of work\][^fn_66a_10] simultaneously? — These must remain undecided.[^fn_66a_11]

\[ANY COMPENSATION FOR\] INDIGNITY OR BLEMISH \[THAT MAY HAVE BEEN INFLICTED UPON\] HER. Raba son of R. Hanan demurred:[^fn_66a_12] Now then,[^fn_66a_13] if a man insulted his fellow's mare would he also have to pay him \[compensation for the\] indignity? But is a horse then susceptible to insult?[^fn_66a_14] — This, however, \[is the objection:\] If a man spat on his fellow's garment would he[^fn_66a_15] also have to pay him \[compensation for this\] indignity? And should you say that \[the ruling\] is really so,[^fn_66a_16] surely \[it can be retorted\] we have learned: If a man spat so that the spittle fell upon another person, or uncovered the head of a woman, or removed a cloak from a person he must pay four hundred *zuz*;[^fn_66a_17] and R. Papa explained: This has been taught \[to apply\] only \[where it touched\] him[^fn_66a_18] but if it touched his garment only \[the offender\] is exempt![^fn_66a_19] — \[An insult\] to his garment involves no indignity to him, \[but an insult to\] his wife does involve an indignity to him.[^fn_66a_20]

Said Rabina to R. Ashi: Now then,[^fn_66a_21] If a man insulted a poor man of a good family where all the members of the family are involved in the indignity, must he also pay \[compensation for\] indignity to all the members of the family?[^fn_66a_22] — The other replied: There[^fn_66a_23] it is not their own persons \[that are insulted\]. Here, however, one's wife is \[like\] one's own body.

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN UNDERTOOK TO GIVE A FIXED SUM OF MONEY TO HIS SON-IN-LAW AND HIS SON-IN-LAW DIED,[^fn_66a_24] HE[^fn_66a_25] MAY, THE SAGES RULED, SAY[^fn_66a_26] 'I WAS WILLING TO GIVE \[THE MENTIONED SUM\] TO YOUR BROTHER BUT I AM UNWILLING TO GIVE IT TO YOU'.[^fn_66a_27] {¶=6.2}

IF A WOMAN UNDERTOOK TO BRING HER HUSBAND[^fn_66a_28] ONE THOUSAND *DENARII* HE MUST ASSIGN TO HER[^fn_66a_29] A CORRESPONDING SUM OF FIFTEEN *MANEH*.[^fn_66a_30] AS A CORRESPONDING SUM FOR APPRAISED GOODS,[^fn_66a_31] HOWEVER, HE ASSIGNS[^fn_66a_29] ONE FIFTH LESS.[^fn_66a_32] \[IF A HUSBAND IS REQUESTED TO ENTER IN HIS WIFE'S *KETHUBAH*:\] 'GOODS ASSESSED AT ONE MANEH', AND THESE ARE IN FACT WORTH A *MANEH*,[^fn_66a_33] HE CAN HAVE \[A CLAIM FOR\] ONE *MANEH* ONLY.[^fn_66a_34] \[OTHERWISE,[^fn_66a_35] IF HE IS REQUESTED TO ENTER IN THE *KETHUBAH*:\] 'GOODS ASSESSED AT A MANEH', HIS WIFE MUST GIVE HIM \[GOODS OF THE ASSESSED VALUE[^fn_66a_35] OF\] THIRTY-ONE SELA'S AND A *DENAR*,[^fn_66a_36] AND IF 'AT FOUR HUNDRED \[*ZUZ*\]', SHE MUST GIVE \[HIM GOODS VALUED[^fn_66a_35] AT\] FIVE HUNDRED \[ZUZ.\][^fn_66a_37] WHATEVER [pg 66b]

A BRIDEGROOM ASSIGNS \[TO HIS WIFE IN HER *KETHUBAH*\] HE ASSIGNS AT ONE FIFTH LESS \[THAN THE APPRAISED VALUE\].

***GEMARA***. Our Rabbis taught: There was no need to state that where the first[^fn_66b_1] was a scholar and the second an 'am ha-'arez \[the father-in-law\] can say, 'I WAS WILLING TO GIVE \[THE MENTIONED SUM\] TO YOUR BROTHER BUT I AM UNWILLING TO GIVE IT TO YOU, but even where the first was 'am ha-'arez and the second a scholar he may also say so.

IF A WOMAN UNDERTOOK TO BRING TO HER HUSBAND ONE THOUSAND *DENARII* etc. Are not these[^fn_66b_2] the same as the case in the first clause?[^fn_66b_3] — He taught \[first concerning a\] large assessment[^fn_66b_4] and then he taught also about a smaller assessment;[^fn_66b_5] he taught about his assessment[^fn_66b_6] and he also taught about her assessment.[^fn_66b_7]

M I S H N A H. IF A WOMAN UNDERTOOK TO BRING TO HER HUSBAND[^fn_66b_8] READY MONEY, EVERY *SELA'*[^fn_66b_9] OF HERS COUNTS[^fn_66b_10] AS SIX *DENARII*.[^fn_66b_11] THE BRIDEGROOM MUST UNDERTAKE \[TO GIVE HIS WIFE\][^fn_66b_12] TEN *DENARII* FOR HER \[PERFUME\][^fn_66b_13] BASKET IN RESPECT OF EACH *MANEH*.[^fn_66b_14] R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL SAID: IN ALL MATTERS THE LOCAL USAGE SHALL BE FOLLOWED.

***GEMARA***. This,[^fn_66b_15] surely, is exactly \[the same ruling as\] 'He must assign to her a corresponding sum of fifteen maneh'.[^fn_66b_16] — He taught first about a major transaction[^fn_66b_17] and then taught about a minor transaction.[^fn_66b_18] And \[both rulings were\] necessary. For had that of the major transaction only been taught it might have been assumed \[that it applied to this only\] because the profit \[it brings in\] is large but not to a minor transaction the profit from which is small; \[hence it was\] necessary \[to state the latter\]. And had we been informed of that of the minor transaction only it might have been said \[to apply to this only\] because the expenses and responsibility[^fn_66b_19] are small but not to a large transaction where the expenses and responsibility are great; \[hence it was\] necessary \[to state the former\].

THE BRIDEGROOM MUST UNDERTAKE \[TO GIVE HIS WIFE\] TEN *DENARII* FOR HER BASKET. What is meant by BASKET?

r. Ashi replied: The perfume basket. R. Ashi further stated: This ruling applies to Jerusalem[^fn_66b_20] only.

R. Ashi enquired: \[Is the prescribed perfume allowance[^fn_66b_21] made\] in respect of each *maneh* valued or each *maneh* for which \[obligation has been\] accepted?[^fn_66b_22] \[And even\][^fn_66b_23] if you could find \[some reason\] for stating: \['In respect of each\] *maneh* for which \[obligation has been\] accepted'[^fn_66b_22] \[the question arises: Is the allowance to be made only on\] the first day or every day? Should you find \[some ground\] for deciding: Every day, \[the question still remains whether this applies only to the\] first week or to every week. Should you find \[some authority\] for stating: Every week, \[it may be asked whether this applies only to the\] first month or to every month — And should you find \[some argument\] for saying: Every month, \[It may still be questioned whether this is applicable only to the\] first year or to every year. — All this remains undecided.[^fn_66b_24]

Rab Judah related in the name of Rab: It once happened that the daughter of Nakdimon b. Gorion[^fn_66b_25] was granted by the Sages[^fn_66b_26] an allowance of four hundred gold coins in respect of her perfume basket for that particular day, and she[^fn_66b_27] said to them, 'May you grant such allowances for your own daughters!' and they answered after her: Amen.[^fn_66b_28] Our Rabbis taught: It once happened that R. Johanan b. Zakkai left Jerusalem riding upon an ass, while his disciples followed him, and he saw a girl picking barley grains in the dung of Arab cattle. As soon as she saw him she wrapped herself with her hair and stood before him. 'Master', she said to him, 'feed me'. 'My daughter', he asked her, 'who are you?' 'I am', she replied, 'the daughter of Nakdimon b. Gorion'. 'My daughter', he said to her, 'what has become[^fn_66b_29] of the wealth of your father's house?' 'Master', she answered him, 'is there not a proverb current in Jerusalem: "The salt[^fn_66b_30] of money is diminution?"'[^fn_66b_31] (Others read: Benevolence).[^fn_66b_32] 'And where \[the Master asked\] is the wealth of your father-in-law's house?' 'The one', she replied, 'came and destroyed the other'.[^fn_66b_33] 'Do you remember, Master', she said to him, 'when you signed my *kethubah*?' 'I remember', he said to his disciples, 'that when I signed the *kethubah* of this \[unfortunate woman\], I read therein "A million gold *denarii* from her father's house" besides \[the amount\] from her father-in-law's house'.[^fn_66b_34] Thereupon R. Johanan b. Zakkai wept and said: 'How happy are Israel;[^fn_66b_35] when they do the will of the Omnipresent no nation nor any language-speaking group has any power over them; but when they do not do the will of the Omnipresent he delivers them into the hands of a low people, and not only in the hands of a low people but into the power of the beasts of a low people'.

Did not Nakdimon b. Gorion, however, practice charity? Surely it was taught: It was said of Nakdimon b. Gorion that, when he walked from his house to the house of study, woollen clothes were [pg 67a]

spread beneath his feet and the poor followed behind him and rolled them up![^fn_67a_1] — If you wish I might reply: He did it for his own glorification — 2 And if you prefer I might reply: He did not act as he should have done,[^fn_67a_3] as people say, 'In accordance with the camel is the burden'.[^fn_67a_4]

It was taught: R. Eleazar the son of R. Zadok said, 'May I \[not\] behold the consolation \[of Zion\] if I have not seen her[^fn_67a_5] picking barley grains among the horses' hoofs at Acco. \[On seeing her plight\] I applied to her this Scriptural text: If thou know not, O thou fairest among women, go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock and feed thy kids;[^fn_67a_6] read not thy kids[^fn_67a_7] but thy 'bodies'.[^fn_67a_8]

R. Shaman b. Abba stated in the name of R. Johanan: If a wife brought to her husband[^fn_67a_9] \[a bar of\] gold, it is to be assessed and \[entered in her *kethubah*\] according to its actual value.[^fn_67a_10]

An objection was raised: '\[Broken pieces of\] gold are like vessels'.[^fn_67a_11] Does not this imply[^fn_67a_12] 'like silver vessels' which wear out?[^fn_67a_13] — No, 'like gold vessels' which do not wear out. If so, \[the expression\] should have been 'like vessels \[made\] thereof'! And, furthermore, it was taught: \[A bar of\] gold is like vessels; gold *denarii* are like ready money.[^fn_67a_14] R. Simeon b. Gamaliel said: Where the usage is not to change them[^fn_67a_15] they are valued and are \[to be entered in the *kethubah*\] at the rate of their actual value.[^fn_67a_16] Now, to what is R. Simeon b. Gamaliel referring? If it be suggested \[that he refers\] to the final clause,[^fn_67a_17] the inference \[it may be pointed out would be\] that the first Tanna maintains his opinion[^fn_67a_18] even when the usage is not to change them, but, surely, \[it may be objected\] they can not be used as currency![^fn_67a_19] It must consequently be assumed[^fn_67a_20] \[that he[^fn_67a_21] referred\] to the first clause and that it is this that was meant: \[A bar of\] gold is like vessels; and what \[is meant by\] vessels? silver vessels;[^fn_67a_22] and R. Simeon b. Gamaliel said: It is like gold *denarii* where the usage is not to change them![^fn_67a_23] — No;[^fn_67a_24] he[^fn_67a_21] may still refer to the final clause but \[it is a case where\] with difficulty they can be used as currency; and the principles on which they differ is this: One Master[^fn_67a_25] holds the view that since they can be used as currency we allow her the increase[^fn_67a_26] and the other Master[^fn_67a_21] is of the opinion that since they can be used as currency only with difficulty, she is not to have the increase.[^fn_67a_27]

If you prefer I might reply: All the statement[^fn_67a_28] is that of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel, but a clause therein is missing, and the proper reading is as follows: \[A bar of\] gold is like vessels,[^fn_67a_29] gold *denarii* are like ready money. This is the case only where it is the usage to change them,[^fn_67a_30] but where it is the usage not to change them[^fn_67a_31] they are to be valued and entered in the *kethubah* at the rate of their actual value; so R. Simeon b. Gamaliel for R. Simeon b. Gamaliel holds the view that where it is the usage not to change them they are to be valued and \[entered in the *kethubah*\] at the rate of their actual value. But \[the difficulty\] nevertheless \[remains that the expression\] should have been, 'like vessels \[made\] thereof'! — This is indeed a difficulty. And if you prefer I might reply: We are here[^fn_67a_28] dealing with a case of broken pieces of gold.[^fn_67a_32] R. Ashi said: \[We deal here[^fn_67a_28] with\] gold leaf.[^fn_67a_33] R. Jannai stated: The spices of Antioch[^fn_67a_34] are[^fn_67a_35] like ready money.[^fn_67a_36] R. Samuel b. Nahmani stated in the name of R. Johanan:[^fn_67a_37] A woman[^fn_67a_38] is entitled to seize Arabian camels in settlement of her *kethubah*.[^fn_67a_39]

R. Papi stated: A woman[^fn_67a_38] may seize clothes[^fn_67a_40] manufactured at Be Mikse[^fn_67a_41] for her *kethubah*.[^fn_67a_42]

R. Papi further stated: A woman[^fn_67a_38] may seize sacks made at Rodya[^fn_67a_43] and the ropes of Kamhunya[^fn_67a_44] for her *kethubah*.

Raba stated: At first I said: A woman[^fn_67a_38] is entitled to seize money bags[^fn_67a_45] of Mahuza[^fn_67a_46] for her *kethubah*.[^fn_67a_42] What was \[my\] reason? Because \[women\] relied upon them.[^fn_67a_42] When I observed, however, that they[^fn_67a_47] took them and went out with them into the market[^fn_67a_48] and as soon as a plot of land came their way they purchased it with this money I formed the opinion that they rely[^fn_67a_49] only upon land.[^fn_67a_50]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN GAVE HIS DAUGHTER IN MARRIAGE WITHOUT SPECIFYING ANY CONDITIONS, HE MUST GIVE HER NOT LESS THAN FIFTY *ZUZ*. IF THE \[BRIDEGROOM\] AGREED TO TAKE HER IN NAKED HE[^fn_67a_51] MAY NOT SAY, 'WHEN I HAVE TAKEN HER INTO MY HOUSE I SHALL CLOTHE HER WITH CLOTHES OF MY OWN', BUT HE MUST PROVIDE HER WITH CLOTHING WHILE SHE IS STILL IN HER FATHER'S HOUSE. SIMILARLY IF AN ORPHAN IS GIVEN IN MARRIAGE[^fn_67a_52] SHE MUST BE GIVEN NOT LESS THAN FIFTY *ZUZ*. IF \[CHARITY\] FUNDS ARE AVAILABLE[^fn_67a_53] SHE IS TO BE FITTED OUT IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE DIGNITY OF HER POSITION. {¶=6.3}

***GEMARA***. Abaye stated: By FIFTY *ZUZ* small coins[^fn_67a_54] \[were meant\]. Whence is this statement inferred? — From the statement in the final clause: IF \[CHARITY\] FUNDS ARE AVAILABLE SHE IS FITTED OUT IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE DIGNITY OF HER POSITION \[concerning which\], when it was asked, 'What was meant by FUNDS'.[^fn_67a_55] Rehaba explained: Charity funds.[^fn_67a_56] Now if we should imagine that by FIFTY *ZUZ* the actual[^fn_67a_57] \[coins were meant\], how much \[it may be asked\] ought we to give her even IF CHARITY FUNDS ARE AVAILABLE! Consequently it must be inferred that by FIFTY *ZUZ* small coins \[were meant\].

Our Rabbis taught: If an orphan boy and an orphan girl applied for maintenance,[^fn_67a_58] the girl orphan is to be maintained first and the boy orphan afterwards,[^fn_67a_59] because it is not unusual for a man to go begging[^fn_67a_60] but it is unusual for a woman to do so.[^fn_67a_61] If an orphan boy and an orphan girl [pg 67b]

applied for a marriage grant[^fn_67b_1] the girl orphan is to be enabled to marry first and the boy orphan is married afterwards, because the shame of a woman is greater than that of a man.[^fn_67b_2]

Our Rabbis taught: If an orphan applied for assistance to marry,[^fn_67b_3] a house must be rented for him, a bed must be prepared for him and \[he must also be supplied with\] all \[household\] objects \[required for\] his use, and then he is given a wife in marriage, for it is said in Scriptures, Sufficient for his need in that which he wanteth:[^fn_67b_4] 'sufficient for his need', refers to the house; 'in that which wanteth', refers to a bed and a table; 'he'[^fn_67b_5] refers to a wife, for so it is said in Scripture, I will make him[^fn_67b_5] a help meet unto him.[^fn_67b_6]

Our Rabbis taught: 'Sufficient for his need' \[implies\] you are commanded to maintain him, but you are not commanded to make him rich; 'in that which he wanteth' \[includes\] even a horse to ride upon and a slave to run before him. It was related about Hillel the Elder that he bought[^fn_67b_7] for a certain poor man who was of a good family a horse to ride upon and a slave to run before him. On one occasion he could not find a slave to run before him, so he himself ran before him for three miles.

Our Rabbis taught: It once happened that the people of Upper Galilee bought for a poor member of a good family of Sepphoris[^fn_67b_8] a pound of meat every day.[^fn_67b_9] 'A pound of meat'! What is the greatness in this? — R. Huna replied: \[It was\] a pound of fowl's meat.[^fn_67b_10] And if you prefer I might say: \[They purchased\] ordinary meat for a pound[^fn_67b_11] \[of money\].[^fn_67b_12] R. Ashi replied: The place was[^fn_67b_13] a small village[^fn_67b_14] and everyday a beast had to be spoiled for his sake.[^fn_67b_15]

A certain man once applied to[^fn_67b_16] R. Nehemiah \[for maintenance\]. 'What do your meals consist of', \[the Rabbi\] asked him. 'Of fat meat and old wine', the other replied — 'Will you consent \[the Rabbi asked him\] to live[^fn_67b_17] with me on lentils?' \[The other consented,\] lived with him on lentils and died. 'Alas', \[the Rabbi\] said, 'for this man whom Nehemiah has killed.' On the contrary, he should \[have said\] 'Alas for Nehemiah who killed this man'! — \[The fact\], however, \[is that the man himself was to blame, for\] he should not have cultivated his luxurious habits to such an extent.

A man once applied to[^fn_67b_18] Raba \[for maintenance\]. 'What do your meals consist of?' he asked him. 'Of fat chicken and old wine', the other replied. 'Did you not consider', \[the Rabbi\] asked him, 'the burden of the community?' 'Do I', the other replied, 'eat of theirs? I eat \[the food\] of the All-Merciful; for we learned: The eyes of all wait for Thee, and Thou givest them their food in due season,[^fn_67b_19] this, since it is not said, 'in their season' but 'in his[^fn_67b_20] season', teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, provides for every individual his food In accordance with his own habits'.[^fn_67b_21] Meanwhile there arrived Raba's sister, who had not seen him for thirteen years, and brought him a fat chicken and old wine. 'What a remarkable incident!'[^fn_67b_22] \[Raba\][^fn_67b_23] exclaimed; \[and then\] he said to him, 'I apologize[^fn_67b_24] to you, come and eat'.

Our Rabbis taught: If a man has no means and does not wish to be maintained \[out of the poor funds\] he should be granted \[the sum he requires\] as a loan and then it can be presented to him as a gift; so R. Meir. The Sages, however, said: It is given to him as a gift and then it is granted to him as a loan. ('As a gift'? He, surely, refuses to[^fn_67b_25] take \[gifts\]! Raba replied: It is offered to him in the first instance[^fn_67b_26] as a gift.)

If he has the means but does not want to maintain himself, \[at his own expense\],[^fn_67b_27] he is given \[what he needs\] as a gift, and then he is made to repay it. (If 'he is made to repay it' he would, surely, not take again! — R. Papa replied: \[Repayment is claimed\] after his death.) R. Simeon said: If he has the means and does not want to maintain himself \[at his own expense\], no one need feel any concern about him. If he has no means and does not wish to be maintained \[out of the poor funds\] he is told, 'Bring a pledge and you will receive \[a loan\]' in order to raise thereby his \[drooping\] spirit.[^fn_67b_28]

Our Rabbis taught: To lend[^fn_67b_29] refers to a man who has no means and is unwilling to receive his maintenance \[from the poor funds\] to whom \[the allowance\] must be given as a loan and then presented to him as a gift. Thou shalt lend him[^fn_67b_30] refers to a man who has the means and does not wish to maintain himself \[at his own expense\] to whom \[the allowance\] is given as a gift and repayment is claimed from his \[estate\] after his death, so R. Judah. The Sages, however, said: If he has the means and does not wish to maintain himself \[at his own expense\] no one need feel any concern about him. To what, however, is the text Thou shalt lend him[^fn_67b_31] to be applied? The Torah employs ordinary phraseology.[^fn_67b_32]

Mar 'Ukba had a poor man in his neighbourhood into whose door-socket he used to throw four *zuz* every day. Once[^fn_67b_33] \[the poor man\] thought: 'I will go and see who does me this kindness'. On that day \[it happened\] that Mar 'Ukba was late at[^fn_67b_34] the house of study and his wife[^fn_67b_35] was coming home with him. As soon as \[the poor man\] saw them moving the door he went out after them, but they fled from him and ran into a furnace from which the fire had just been swept. Mar 'Ukba's feet were burning and his wife said to him: Raise your feet and put them on mine. As he was upset,[^fn_67b_36] she said to him, 'I am usually at home[^fn_67b_37] and my benefactions are direct'.[^fn_67b_38] And what \[was the reason for\] all that?[^fn_67b_39] — Because Mar Zutra b. Tobiah said in the name of Rab (others state: R. Huna[^fn_67b_40] b. Bizna said in the name of R. Simeon the Pious; and others again state: R. Johanan said in the name of R. Simeon b. Yohai): Better had a man thrown himself into a fiery furnace than publicly put his neighbour to shame. Whence do we derive this? From \[the action of\] Tamar; for it is written in Scripture, When she was brought forth,[^fn_67b_41] \[she sent to her father-in-law\].[^fn_67b_42]

Mar 'Ukba had a poor man in his neighbourhood to whom he regularly sent four hundred *zuz* on the Eve of every Day of Atonement. On one occasion[^fn_67b_43] he sent them through his son who came back and said to him, 'He does not need \[your help\]'. 'What have you seen?' \[his father\] asked. 'I saw \[the son replied\] that they were spraying old wine before him'.[^fn_67b_44] 'Is he so delicate?' \[the father\] said, and, doubling the amount, he sent it back to him.

When he[^fn_67b_45] was about to die[^fn_67b_46] he requested, 'Bring me my charity accounts'. Finding that seven thousand of Sijan[^fn_67b_47] \[gold\] *denarii* were entered therein he exclaimed, 'The provisions are scanty and the road is long', and he forthwith[^fn_67b_48] distributed half of his wealth. But how could he do such a thing?[^fn_67b_49] Has not R. Elai stated: It was ordained at Usha that if a man wishes to spend liberally he should not spend more than a filth?[^fn_67b_50] — This applies only during a man's lifetime, since he might thereby be impoverished[^fn_67b_51] but after death[^fn_67b_52] this does not matter.

R. Abba used to bind money in his scarf,[^fn_67b_53] sling it on his back, and place himself at the disposal of the poor.[^fn_67b_54] He cast his eye, however, sideways \[as a precaution\] against rogues.[^fn_67b_55]

R. Hanina had a poor man to whom he regularly sent four *zuz* on the Eve of every Sabbath. One day he sent that sum through his wile who came back and told him \[that the man was in\] no need of it. 'What \[R. Hanina asked her\] did you see?' \[She replied:\] I heard that he was asked, 'On what will you dine; [pg 68a]

on the silver \[coloured\] cloths[^fn_68a_1] or on the gold \[coloured\] ones?'[^fn_68a_2] 'It is in view of such cases' \[R. Hanina\] remarked, 'that R. Eleazar said: Come let us be grateful to the rogues for were it not for then, we[^fn_68a_3] would have been sinning every day, for it is said in Scripture, And he cry unto to the Lord against thee, and it be sill unto thee.[^fn_68a_4] Furthermore, R. Hiyya b. Rab of Difti[^fn_68a_5] taught: R. Joshua b. Korha said, Any one who shuts his eye against charity is like one who worships idols, for here[^fn_68a_6] it is written, Beware that there be not a base[^fn_68a_7] thought in thy heart etc. \[and thine eye will be evil against thy poor brother\][^fn_68a_8] and there[^fn_68a_9] it is written, Certain base[^fn_68a_7] fellows are gone out,[^fn_68a_10] as there[^fn_68a_9] \[the crime is that of\] idolatry, so here also \[the crime is like that of\] idolatry'.[^fn_68a_11]

Our Rabbis taught: If a man pretends to have a blind eye, a swollen belly or a shrunken leg,[^fn_68a_12] he will not pass out from this world before actually coming into such a condition. If a man accepts charity and is not in need of it his end \[will be that\] he will not pass out of the world before he comes to such a condition.

We learned elsewhere: He[^fn_68a_13] may not be compelled to sell his house or his articles of service'.[^fn_68a_14] May he not indeed?[^fn_68a_15] Was it not taught: If he was in the habit of using gold articles he shall now use copper ones?[^fn_68a_16] — R. Zebid replied. This is no difficulty. The one[^fn_68a_17] refers to the bed and table: the other to cups and dishes. What difference is there in the case of the cups and dishes that they are not \[to be sold\]? Obviously because he can say, '\[The inferior quality\] is repulsive to me', \[but then, in respect of\] a bed and table also, he might say \[the cheaper article\] is unacceptable to me! — Raba the son of Rabbah replied: \[This[^fn_68a_17] refers\] to a silver strigil.[^fn_68a_18] R. Papa replied: There is no difficulty: one[^fn_68a_19] \[refers to a man\] before he came under the obligation of repayment,[^fn_68a_20] and the other refers to a man[^fn_68a_21] after he had come under the obligation of repayment.[^fn_68a_22]

***MISHNAH***. IF AN ORPHAN WAS GIVEN IN MARRIAGE BY HER MOTHER OR HER BROTHERS \[EVEN IF\] WITH HER CONSENT[^fn_68a_23] AND THEY ASSIGNED[^fn_68a_24] TO HER A HUNDRED, OR FIFTY *ZUZ*,[^fn_68a_25] SHE MAY, WHEN SHE ATTAINS HER MAJORITY,[^fn_68a_26] RECOVER FROM THEM THE AMOUNT THAT WAS DUE TO HER.[^fn_68a_27] R. JUDAH RULED: IF A MAN HAD GIVEN HIS FIRST DAUGHTER IN MARRIAGE, THE SECOND[^fn_68a_28] MUST RECEIVE AS MUCH AS THE \[FATHER\] HAD GIVEN TO THE FIRST. THE SAGES, HOWEVER, SAID: SOMETIMES A MAN IS POOR AND BECOMES RICH OR RICH AND BECOMES POOR.[^fn_68a_29] THE ESTATE SHOULD RATHER BE VALUED AND SHE[^fn_68a_30] BE GIVEN \[THE SHARE THAT IS HER DUE\]. {¶=6.4}

***GEMARA***. Samuel stated: In respect of the marriage outfit[^fn_68a_31] the assessment[^fn_68a_32] is to be determined by \[the disposition of\] the father.[^fn_68a_33]

All objection was raised: 'The daughters are to be maintained and provided for[^fn_68a_34] out of the estate of their father. In what manner? It is not to be said, "Had her father been alive he would have given her such and such a sum" but the estate is valued and she is given \[her due share\]'. Does not \['provided for' refer to\] the marriage[^fn_68a_35] outfit?[^fn_68a_36] — R. Nahman b. Isaac replied: No; \[it refers to\] her own maintenance.[^fn_68a_37] But, surely, it was stated: 'Are to be maintained and provided for'; does not one \[of the expressions\][^fn_68a_38] refer to the marriage[^fn_68a_39] outfit and the other to her own maintenance?[^fn_68a_40] — No; the one as well as the other refers to her own maintenance,[^fn_68a_40] and yet there is no real difficulty, for one of the expressions[^fn_68a_38] refers[^fn_68a_41] to food and drink and the other[^fn_68a_41] to clothing and bedding.

We learned: THE SAGES, HOWEVER, SAID, SOMETIMES A MAN IS POOR AND BECOMES RICH OR RICH AND BECOMES POOR. THE ESTATE SHOULD RATHER BE VALUED AND SHE BE GIVEN \[THE SHARE THAT IS HER DUE\]. Now what is meant by POOR and RICH? If it be suggested that POOR means poor in material possessions, and RICH means rich in such possessions, the inference \[should consequently be\] that the first Tanna holds the opinion that even when a man was rich and became poor she is given as much as before; but, surely, \[it may be objected\] he has none \[to give\]. Must it not then \[be concluded that\] POOR means poor in mind[^fn_68a_42] and RICH means rich in mind,[^fn_68a_43] and yet it was stated, THE ESTATE SHOULD RATHER BE VALUED AND SHE BE GIVEN \[THE SHARE THAT IS HER DUE\]. from which it clearly follows that we are not guided by the assumed disposition \[of her father\], and this presents an objection against Samuel![^fn_68a_44] He[^fn_68a_45] holds the same view as R. Judah. For we learned, R. JUDAH RULED: IF A MAN HAD GIVEN HIS FIRST DAUGHTER IN MARRIAGE, THE SECOND SHOULD RECEIVE AS MUCH AS THE \[FATHER\] HAD GIVEN TO THE FIRST. \[Why\], then, \[did he not\] say, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Judah'?[^fn_68a_46] — If he had said, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Judah', it might have been assumed \[to apply\] only \[where her father had actually\] given her[^fn_68a_47] in marriage, since \[in that case\] he has revealed his disposition, but not \[to a case where\] he had not given her[^fn_68a_47] in marriage,[^fn_68a_48] hence he[^fn_68a_45] taught us[^fn_68a_49] that R. Judah's reason is that we are guided by our assumption \[as to whit was her father's disposition\], there being no difference whether he had already given her[^fn_68a_50] in marriage or whether he had not given her in marriage; the only object he[^fn_68a_51] had[^fn_68a_52] in mentioning \[the case where a father\] gave her[^fn_68a_50] in marriage was to let you know the extent of the ruling[^fn_68a_53] of the Rabbis[^fn_68a_54] \[who maintain\] that although he had already given her[^fn_68a_50] in marriage and had thereby revealed his disposition, we are nevertheless not to be guided by the assumption \[as to what may have been the father's disposition\].

Said Raba to R. Hisda: In our discourse we stated[^fn_68a_55] in your name, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Judah. The other replied: May it be the will \[of Providence\] that you may report in your discourses all such beautiful sayings in my name. But could Raba, however, have made such a statement?[^fn_68a_56] Surely, it was taught: Rabbi said, A daughter who is maintained by her brothers is to receive[^fn_68a_57] a tenth of \[her father's\] estate;[^fn_68a_58] and Raba stated that the law is in agreement with Rabbi![^fn_68a_59] — This is no difficulty. The former[^fn_68a_60] \[is a case\] where we have formed some opinion about him;[^fn_68a_61] the latter[^fn_68a_62] is one where we have not formed any opinion about him.[^fn_68a_63] This explanation may also be supported by a process of reasoning. For R. Adda b. Ahaba stated: It once happened that Rabbi gave her[^fn_68a_64] a twelfth of \[her father's\] estate. Are not the two statements contradictory?[^fn_68a_65] Consequently[^fn_68a_66] it must be inferred that the one[^fn_68a_67] \[refers to a father of whom\] some opinion had been formed while the other[^fn_68a_68] \[refers to one of whom\] we have formed no opinion. This is conclusive proof.

\[To turn to\] the main text.[^fn_68a_69] Rabbi said, A daughter who is maintained by her brothers is to receive a tenth of \[her father's\] estate. They[^fn_68a_70] said to Rabbi: According to your statement, if a man had ten daughters and one son the sons should receive no share at all on account of[^fn_68a_71] the daughters? He replied: What I mean is this: The first[^fn_68a_72] \[daughter\] receives a tenth of the estate, the second \[receives a tenth\] of what \[the first\] had left, and the third \[gets a tenth\] of what \[the second\] had left, and then they divide again \[all that they had received\] into equal shares. [pg 68b]

But did not each one receive what was hers?[^fn_68b_1] — It is this that was meant: If all of theme wish[^fn_68b_2] to marry at the same time they are to receive equal shares.[^fn_68b_3] This provides support for \[the opinion\] of R. Mattena; for R. Mattena has said: If all of them wish to marry at the same time they are to receive one tenth. 'One tenth'! Can you imagine \[such a ruling\]?[^fn_68b_4] The meaning must consequently be that[^fn_68b_5] they are to receive their tenths at the same time.[^fn_68b_6]

Our Rabbis taught: The daughters,[^fn_68b_7] whether they had attained their adolescence before they married or whether they married before they had attained their adolescence, lose their right to maintenance[^fn_68b_8] but not to their allowance for marriage outfit; so Rabbi. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said: If they also attained their adolescence, they lose the right to their marriage outfit.[^fn_68b_9] How should they proceed?[^fn_68b_10] — They hire for themselves husbands[^fn_68b_11] and exact their outfit allowance. R. Nahman stated: Huna told me, The law is in agreement with Rabbi.

Raba raised an objection against R. Nahman: IF AN ORPHAN WAS GIVEN IN MARRIAGE BY HER MOTHER OR HER BROTHERS \[EVEN IF\] WITH HER CONSENT, AND THEY ASSIGNED TO HER A HUNDRED, OR FIFTY *ZUZ*, SHE MAY, WHEN SHE ATTAINS HER MAJORITY, RECOVER FROM THEM THE AMOUNT THAT WAS DUE TO HER. The reason then[^fn_68b_12] is because she was a minor;[^fn_68b_13] had she, however, been older[^fn_68b_14] her right[^fn_68b_15] would have been surrendered![^fn_68b_16] — This is no difficulty; the one[^fn_68b_17] is a case where she protested;[^fn_68b_18] the other,[^fn_68b_19] where she did not protest.[^fn_68b_20] This expla nation may also be supported by a process of reasoning. For otherwise[^fn_68b_21] there would arise a contradiction between two statements of Rabbi.[^fn_68b_22] For it was taught, 'Rabbi said, A daughter who is maintained by her brothers is to receive a tenth of \[her father's\] estate', \[which implies\] only when[^fn_68b_23] she is maintained[^fn_68b_24] but not[^fn_68b_25] when she is not maintained.[^fn_68b_26] Must it not in consequence be concluded that one \[statement deals with one\] who protested and the other \[with one\] who did not protest. This proves it.

Rabina said to Raba: R. Adda b. Ahaba told us in your name, If she attained her adolescence she need not lodge a protest;[^fn_68b_27] if she married she need not lodge a protest;[^fn_68b_27] but if she attained her adolescence and was also married it is necessary for her to lodge a protest.[^fn_68b_28] But could Raba have made such a statement? Surely, Raba pointed out an objection against R. Nahman \[from the Mishnah of\] AN ORPHAN, and the other replied that 'the one is a case where she protested, the other where she did not protest'![^fn_68b_29] — This is no difficulty. One[^fn_68b_30] is a case where she is maintained[^fn_68b_31] by them;[^fn_68b_32] the other,[^fn_68b_33] where she is not maintained by them.[^fn_68b_34]

R. Huna stated in the name of Rabbi: \[The right[^fn_68b_35] to\] marriage outfit is not the same as that[^fn_68b_36] conferred by a condition in a *kethubah*.[^fn_68b_37] What is meant by 'is not the same as that conferred by a condition in a kethubah'? Should it be suggested[^fn_68b_38] that whereas for the allowance for a marriage outfit even property pledged[^fn_68b_39] may be seized,[^fn_68b_40] \[for the fulfilment of an obligation[^fn_68b_36] under\] the terms of a *kethubah* no pledged property[^fn_68b_41] may be seized,[^fn_68b_42] what \[new point, it may be objected,\] does this teach us? Surely it is a daily occurrence \[that pledged property\] is seized for marriage outfit but not for maintenance! \[Should it\], however, \[be suggested that\] whereas for a marriage outfit movable objects also may be seized, \[for the fulfilment of an obligation under\] a condition in a *kethubah* only real estate. but not movable objects, may be seized, \[it may be objected that,\] according to Rabbi, for the one as well as the other[^fn_68b_43] \[movable objects\] may be seized. For it was taught: Both landed property and movable property may be seized for the maintenance of a wile or daughters;[^fn_68b_44] so Rabbi! What, then, is meant by '\[The right to\] marriage outfit is not the same as that conferred by a condition in a kethubah'? — As it was taught: If a man[^fn_68b_45] said that his daughters must not be maintained out of his estate he is not to be obeyed.[^fn_68b_46] \[If, however, he said, that\] his daughters shall not receive their marriage outfit out of his estate he is obeyed, because \[the right to\] marriage outfit is not the same as that conferred by a condition in a *kethubah*.[^fn_68b_47] [pg 69a]

Rah inserted[^fn_69a_1] \[the following enquiry\] between the lines[^fn_69a_2] \[of a communication[^fn_69a_3] he sent\] to Rabbi: What \[is the law\] where the brothers have encumbered \[the estate they inherited from their father\]?[^fn_69a_4] \[When the enquiry reached him\] R. Hiyya \[who\] was sitting before him asked, '\[does he mean:\] They sold it or pledged it?' — 'What difference call this make?'[^fn_69a_5] the other retorted. Whether they sold it \[he continued\] or pledged it, \[the estate\] may he seized \[to meet the obligation\] of marriage outfit but may not be seized for that of maintenance

As to Rab, however, if his enquiry \[related to brothers\] who sold \[the estate\], he should have written to him, 'sold'; and if his enquiry \[related to brothers\] who pledged it, he should have written to him, 'pledged'! — Rab wished to ascertain the law concerning both cases and he thought: If I write to him 'sold' \[I shall get\] satisfaction If he were to send \[in reply\] that 'the estate may be seized', since the same ruling would apply with even greater force to the case where they pledged \[the estate\]. If, however, he were to send me in reply that 'it may not be seized', the question \[in respect of brothers\] who pledged \[the estate\] would still remain. If, \[again\]. I were to write to him, 'pledged' then if he sent in reply that 'the estate may not be seized' this ruling would apply with even greater force \[to the case where\] they sold it. Should he, however, send a reply that 'it may be seized', the question \[in respect of brothers\] who sold It would still remain. I will, therefore, write to him, 'encumbered' which might mean the one[^fn_69a_6] as well as the other[^fn_69a_7]

R. Johanan, however, ruled: \[An estate\][^fn_69a_8] may not be seized either \[to meet the obligation of the\] one or of the other.[^fn_69a_9]

The question was raised: Did not R. Johanan hear the ruling of Rabbi, but if he had heard it he would have accepted it? Or is it possible that he heard it and did not accept it? — Come and hear what has been stated: If a man died and left two daughters and one son, and the first forestalled \[the others\] and took a tenth of the estate while the other did not manage to collect \[her share\] before the son died,[^fn_69a_10] R. Johanan ruled: The second[^fn_69a_11] has surrendered her right.[^fn_69a_12] Said R. Hanina: Something that is even more striking than this has been said, \[viz.. that an estate\] may be seized[^fn_69a_13] \[to meet the obligation\] of a marriage outfit though it may not be seized for that of maintenance, and you nevertheless state, 'The second has surrendered her right'?[^fn_69a_14] Now, if that were the case,[^fn_69a_15] he[^fn_69a_16] should have asked him 'who said it?'[^fn_69a_17]

— But is it not possible that he in fact did not hear it \[at first\][^fn_69a_18] and when he \[finally\] heard he accepted it, but there[^fn_69a_19] \[the circumstances are\] different, since the house \[of the second daughter\] has now ample provisions?[^fn_69a_20] Said R. Yemar to R. Ashi: Now then,[^fn_69a_21] if she[^fn_69a_22] found anything at all, so that her house is amply provided for, would we in such a case also not give her a tenth of the estate? — The other replied: I said, A house amply provided for from the same estate.[^fn_69a_23]

Amemar ruled: A daughter[^fn_69a_24] has \[the legal status of\] an heiress. Said R. Ashi to Amemar: Should it be desired to settle her claim[^fn_69a_25] by means of a money payment such a settlement cannot be effected for the same reason?[^fn_69a_26] — 'Yes', the other replied. 'Should it be desired \[the first asked\] to settle her claim by \[giving her\] one plot of land, such a settlement cannot be effected for the same reason?'[^fn_69a_26] — 'Yes', the other replied.[^fn_69a_27] R. Ashi, however, ruled: A daughter[^fn_69a_28] has \[the legal status of\] a creditor.[^fn_69a_29] And Amemar also withdrew his former opinion. For R. Minyomi son of R. Nihumi stated: I was once standing before Amemar and a woman who claimed a tenth of \[her deceased father's\] estate appeared before him, and I observed \[that it was his\] opinion that if \[her brothers\] desired to settle with her by means of a money payment he would have agreed to the settlement.[^fn_69a_30] For he heard the brothers say to her, 'If we had the money we would settle with you[^fn_69a_31] by a cash payment', and he remained silent and told them nothing to the contrary.

Now that it has been said that \[a daughter in her claim to her tenth\][^fn_69a_28] has the legal status of a creditor \[the question arises whether she is the creditor\] of the father or of the brothers. In what respect can this matter? — In respect \[of allowing her\] to collect \[her tenth\] either from their medium[^fn_69a_32] land and without an oath,[^fn_69a_33] or of their worst land with an oath.[^fn_69a_34] Now what \[is the law\]? — Come and hear \[of the decision\] of Rabina: He allowed the daughter of R. Ashi to collect \[her tenth\] from Mar[^fn_69a_35] the son of R. Ashi out Of his medium land, without an oath, but from the son of R. Sama[^fn_69a_36] the son of R. Ashi out of his worst land with an oath.[^fn_69a_37]

R. Nehemiah the son of R. Joseph sent the following message to Rabbah the son of R. Huna Zuta[^fn_69a_38] of Nehardea:[^fn_69a_39] When this woman[^fn_69a_40] presents herself to you, authorize her to collect a tenth part of \[her deceased father's\] estate even from the casing of handmills.[^fn_69a_41]

R. Ashi stated: When we were at the college of R. Kahana we authorized the collection \[of a daughter's tenth\] from the rent[^fn_69a_42] of houses also.

R. Anan sent \[this communication\] to R. Huna, '\[To\] our colleague Huna, greetings.[^fn_69a_43] When this woman[^fn_69a_40] presents herself before you, authorize her to collect a tenth part of \[her father's\] estate'. \[When the communication arrived,\] R. Shesheth was sitting before him. 'Go', \[R. Huna\] said to him,[^fn_69a_44] 'and convey[^fn_69a_45] to him[^fn_69a_46] \[the following message\]-and he[^fn_69a_47] who does not deliver the message[^fn_69a_48] to him shall fall under the ban — "Anan, Anan, \[is the collection to be made\] from landed, or from movable property? And who presides at the meal in a house of mourning?"'[^fn_69a_49] R. Shesheth went to R. Anan and said to him: The Master[^fn_69a_50] is a teacher,[^fn_69a_51] and R. Huna is a teacher of the teacher,[^fn_69a_52] and he pronounced the ban against anyone who would not convey[^fn_69a_53] \[his message\] to you;[^fn_69a_54] and had he not pronounced the ban I would not have said, 'Anan, Anan, \[is the collection to be made\] from landed, or movable property, and who presides at the meal in a house of mourning?'[^fn_69a_55] Thereupon, R. Anan went to Mar 'Ukba and said to him: See, Master, how R. Huna addressed[^fn_69a_56] me as 'Anan, Anan';[^fn_69a_57] and, furthermore, I do not know what he meant by the message he sent me on marziha.[^fn_69a_58] The other said to him: Tell me now [pg 69b]

how the incident actually occurred. 'The incident', the first replied, 'happened in such and such a way'. 'A man', the other exclaimed, 'who does not know the meaning of marziha should \[scarcely\] presume to address[^fn_69b_1] R. Huna as, "our colleague Huna".'

What \[is the meaning of\] marziha. — Mourning; for it is written in Scripture, Thus saith the Lord: Enter not into the house of mourning[^fn_69b_2] etc.[^fn_69b_3]

R. Abbahu stated: Whence is it deduced that a mourner sits at the head \[of the table\]?[^fn_69b_4] \[From Scripture\] wherein it is said, I chose out their way, and sat at the head,[^fn_69b_5] and dwelt as a king in the army, as one that comforteth[^fn_69b_6] the mourners.[^fn_69b_7] But does not yenahem[^fn_69b_8] mean \[one who comforts\] others?[^fn_69b_9] R. Nahman b. Isaac replied: The written form is YNHM.[^fn_69b_10] Mar Zutra said: \[The deduction[^fn_69b_11] is made\] from here: We-sar marzeah seruhim,[^fn_69b_12] he who is in bitterness and distracted[^fn_69b_13] becomes the chief[^fn_69b_14] of those that stretched themselves.[^fn_69b_15]

Raba stated: The law \[is that payment may be exacted\] from landed property, but not from movable property, whether in respect of maintenance, *kethubah* or marriage outfit.[^fn_69b_16]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN DEPOSITED[^fn_69b_17] A SUM OF MONEY FOR HIS \[UNMARRIED\] DAUGHTER WITH A TRUSTEE,[^fn_69b_18] AND \[AFTER SHE WAS BETROTHED\][^fn_69b_19] SHE SAYS, 'I TRUST MY HUSBAND',[^fn_69b_20] THE TRUSTEE MUST ACT IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE CONDITION OF HIS TRUST;[^fn_69b_21] SO R. MEIR. R. JOSE, HOWEVER, SAID: WERE \[THE TRUST\] ACTUALLY[^fn_69b_22] A FIELD[^fn_69b_23] AND SHE WISHED TO SELL IT, WOULD IT NOT BE DEEMED[^fn_69b_24] SOLD FORTHWITH![^fn_69b_25] THIS APPLIES TO ONE WHO IS OF AGE.[^fn_69b_26] IN THE CASE OF A MINOR, HOWEVER, THERE IS NO VALIDITY AT ALL IN THE ACT OF A MINOR. {¶=6.5}

***GEMARA***. Our Rabbis taught: If a man deposited for his son-in-law with a trustee a sum of money wherewith to buy a field for his daughter, and she says, 'Let it be given to my husband', she is entitled \[to have her wish fulfilled, if it was expressed\] after her marriage[^fn_69b_27] but if only after her betrothal the trustee must act according to the conditions of his trust;[^fn_69b_28] so R. Meir. R. Jose, however, said: A woman who is of age has a right \[to obtain her desire\] whether \[it was expressed\] after her marriage or only after betrothal, but \[in the case of\] a minor \[whether her wish was expressed\] after marriage or after betrothal, the trustee must act in accordance with the conditions of his trust.[^fn_69b_29] What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_69b_30] If it be suggested that the practical difference between them is the case of a minor after her marriage, R. Meir holding the opinion that \[even\] she is entitled \[to have her wish\] and R. Jose comes to state that even after marriage \[It is only\] a woman who is of age that is entitled to have her wish[^fn_69b_31] but not a minor, \[in that case\] what of[^fn_69b_32] the final clause,[^fn_69b_33] IN THE CASE OF A MINOR, HOWEVER, THERE IS NO VALIDITY AT ALL IN THE ACT OF A MINOR. Who \[it might be asked\] could have taught this? If it be suggested \[that the author was\] R. Jose, \[it could be objected:\] This, surely, could be inferred from the first clause; for, since R. Jose said, WERE \[THE TRUST\] ACTUALLY A FIELD AND SHE WISHED TO SELL IT, WOULD IT NOT BE DEEMED SOLD FORTHWITH! \[it follows[^fn_69b_34] that only\] one that is of age, who is eligible to effect a sale, was meant,[^fn_69b_35] but not a minor who is ineligible to effect a sale.[^fn_69b_36] Consequently it must be R. Meir \[who was the author of\] it, and a clause is in fact missing \[from our Mishnah\], the proper reading being as follows:[^fn_69b_37] 'THE TRUSTEE MUST ACT IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE CONDITIONS OF HIS TRUST. This applies only \[to a woman whose desire was expressed\] after her betrothal, but if after her marriage she is entitled \[to have her wish\]. THIS \[furthermore\] APPLIES TO ONE WHO IS OF AGE.
