IN THE CASE OF A MINOR, HOWEVER, THERE IS NO VALIDITY AT ALL IN THE ACT OF A MINOR.'[^fn_69b_38] — \[The fact\]. however, is that the practical difference between them is the case of one who is of age \[whose wish was expressed\] after her betrothal.[^fn_69b_39]

It was stated: Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel. The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Jose. Raba ion the name of R. Nahman said, The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Meir. Ilfa[^fn_69b_40] reclined[^fn_69b_41] upon a sail mast[^fn_69b_42] and[^fn_69b_43] said: 'Should any one come and submit to me any statement \[in the Baraithoth\] of R. Hiyya and R. Oshaia[^fn_69b_44] which I cannot make clear to him \[with the aid\] of our Mishnah I will drop from the mast[^fn_69b_45] and drown myself'. An aged man came and recited to him \[the following Baraitha:\][^fn_69b_46] If a man[^fn_69b_47] said, 'Give my children[^fn_69b_48] a *shekel* a week',[^fn_69b_49] and they require a *sela'*,[^fn_69b_50] a *sela'* is to he given to them.[^fn_69b_51] But if he said, 'Give them no more than a shekel', only a *shekel* is to he given to them.[^fn_69b_52] If, however, he gave Instructions that if these died others[^fn_69b_53] shall be his heirs in their stead, only one *shekel* \[a week\] is to be given to them, irrespective of whether he used the expression of 'give' or 'give no \[more\]',[^fn_69b_54] \[Ilfa\] said to him: \[Do you wish to know\] whose ruling this[^fn_69b_55] is? [pg 70a]

It is that of R. Meir[^fn_70a_1] who laid down that it is a religious obligation to carry out the instructions of a dying man.[^fn_70a_2]

R. Hisda stated in the name of Mar 'Ukba: The law is that whether \[the dying man\] said, 'Give' or 'give no more',[^fn_70a_3] his children are to he given all that they require. But have we not, however, an established principle that the *halachah* is in agreement with R. Meir who laid down that it is a religious obligation to carry out the instructions of a dying man? — This applies to other matters, but in this case \[the father\] is quite satisfied \[that his children should be provided with all they need\]; and in limiting their allowance,[^fn_70a_4] his object was[^fn_70a_5] to encourage them.[^fn_70a_6]

We learned elsewhere: With regard to little children,[^fn_70a_7] their purchase is a valid purchase and their sale is a valid sale in the case of movable objects.[^fn_70a_8] Rafram explained: This has been taught in the case only where no guardian had been appointed,[^fn_70a_9] but where a guardian had been appointed neither their purchase nor their sale has any legal validity. Whence is this inferred? From the expression, THERE IS NO VALIDITY AT ALL IN THE ACT OF A MINOR. But might not the case where a trustee[^fn_70a_10] had been appointed be different?[^fn_70a_11] — If so,[^fn_70a_12] it should have been stated, 'IN THE CASE OF A MINOR, HOWEVER, a trustee must act in accordance with the conditions of his trust' what \[then was the purpose of the expression,\] THERE IS NO VALIDITY AT ALL IN THE ACT OF A MINOR? Hence it may be inferred \[that the same law is applicable\] in all cases.[^fn_70a_13]

## CHAPTER VII

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN FORBADE HIS WIFE BY VOW TO HAVE ANY BENEFIT FROM HIM HE MAY, \[IF THE PROHIBITION IS TO LAST\] NOT MORE[^fn_70a_14] THAN THIRTY DAYS, APPOINT A STEWARD,[^fn_70a_15] BUT IF FOR A LONGER PERIOD HE MUST DIVORCE HER[^fn_70a_16] AND GIVE HER THE *KETHUBAH*. R. JUDAH RULED: IF HE WAS AN ISRAELITE[^fn_70a_17] HE MAY KEEP HER \[AS HIS WIFE IF THE PROHIBITION WAS FOR\] ONE MONTH, BUT MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER THE *KETHUBAH* \[IF IT WAS FOR\] TWO MONTHS. IF HE WAS A PRIEST[^fn_70a_18] HE MAY KEEP HER \[AS HIS WIFE, IF THE PROHIBITION WAS FOR\] TWO MONTHS,[^fn_70a_19] BUT MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER THE *KETHUBAH* \[IF IT WAS FOR\] THREE. {¶=7.1}

IF A MAN FORBADE HIS WIFE BY VOW THAT SHE SHOULD NOT TASTE A CERTAIN FRUIT[^fn_70a_20] HE MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER THE *KETHUBAH*. R. JUDAH RULED: IF HE WAS AN ISRAELITE[^fn_70a_17] HE MAY KEEP HER \[AS HIS WIFE, IF THE VOW WAS FOR\] ONE DAY, \[BUT IF FOR\] TWO DAYS HE MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER THE *KETHUBAH*. IF, HOWEVER, HE WAS A PRIEST[^fn_70a_18] HE MAY KEEP HER \[AS HIS WIFE, IF THE VOW WAS FOR\] TWO DAYS \[BUT IF FOR\] THREE HE MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER THE *KETHUBAH*.

IF A MAN FORBADE HIS WIFE BY VOW THAT SHE SHOULD NOT MAKE USE OF A CERTAIN ADORNMENT[^fn_70a_21] HE MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER THE *KETHUBAH*. R. JOSE RULED: \[THIS[^fn_70a_22] APPLIES\] TO POOR WOMEN IF NO TIME LIMIT[^fn_70a_23] IS GIVEN, AND TO RICH WOMEN \[IF THE TIME LIMIT[^fn_70a_23] IS\] THIRTY DAYS.

***GEMARA***. Since, however, he[^fn_70a_24] is under an obligation to \[maintain\] her[^fn_70a_25] how can he forbid her by a vow \[to have any benefit from him\]? Has he then the power[^fn_70a_26] to cancel his obligation? Surely we have learned: \[If a woman said to her husband\] 'Konam, if I do aught for your mouth' he need not annul her vow;[^fn_70a_27] from which[^fn_70a_28] it is evident that, as she is under an obligation to him,[^fn_70a_29] she has no right to cancel her obligation,[^fn_70a_30] similarly here, since he is under an obligation to \[maintain\] her he should have no right to cancel his obligation![^fn_70a_31] — \[This,\] however, \[is the right explanation:\] As he[^fn_70a_32] is entitled to say to her,[^fn_70a_33] 'Deduct \[the proceeds of\] your handiwork for your maintenance'[^fn_70a_34] [pg 70b]

he \[in making his vow\] is regarded[^fn_70b_1] as having said to her, 'Deduct \[the proceeds of\] your handiwork for your maintenance'.

If, however, one is to adopt the ruling R. Huna gave in the name of Rab, for R. Huna stated in the name of Rab: A wife may say to her husband, 'I would neither be maintained by, nor work \[for you\]', why should there be no need to annul \[her vow\] when she said 'Konam, if I do aught for your mouth'? Let it rather be said that as she is entitled to say, 'I would neither be maintained by nor work \[for you\]' she \[in making her vow\] might be regarded[^fn_70b_1] as having said, 'I would neither be maintained by, nor work \[for you\]'?[^fn_70b_2] — \[The fact,\] however, \[is that\] the explanation is not that 'he is regarded'[^fn_70b_3] but that he actually said to her, 'Deduct your handiwork for your maintenance.' If so,[^fn_70b_4] what need has she of a steward?[^fn_70b_5] — \[She needs one\] where \[the proceeds of her handiwork\] do not suffice.[^fn_70b_6] If, \[however, her handiwork\] does not suffice,[^fn_70b_7] our original question arises again![^fn_70b_8] R. Ashi replied: \[This is a case\] where \[her handiwork\] suffices for major requirements but does not suffice for minor requirements.

How is one to understand these 'minor requirements'? If the woman is in the habit of having them, they are, surely, a part of her regular requirements,[^fn_70b_9] and if she is not used to them[^fn_70b_10] what need has she for a steward?[^fn_70b_11] — \[The law concerning a steward\] is required only where she was used \[to them\] in her father's house but consented to dispense with them when with her husband.[^fn_70b_12] In such a case she can say to him, 'Hitherto, before you forbade me by a vow \[to have any benefit from you\], I was willing to put up with your \[mode of living\], but now that you have forbidden me \[to enjoy any benefit from you\] I am not able to put up \[any longer\] with your \[mode of living\]'. And wherein lies the difference \[between a vow for more, and one for\] NOT MORE THAN THIRTY DAYS? — \[Within a period of\] NOT MORE THAN THIRTY DAYS people would not become aware of it, and the matter would be no degradation to her; but after a longer period[^fn_70b_13] people would hear of it, and the matter would be degrading to her.

If you prefer I might reply: \[His vow[^fn_70b_14] is valid\] only if he vowed while she was merely betrothed to him.[^fn_70b_15] But has a betrothed woman, however, any claim to maintenance?[^fn_70b_16] — \[Yes\], if the time \[for the celebration of the marriage\] arrived and she was[^fn_70b_17] not married. For we have learned: If the respective periods expired[^fn_70b_18] and they were not married,[^fn_70b_19] they[^fn_70b_20] are entitled to maintenance[^fn_70b_21] out of the man's estate, and \[if he is a priest\] may also eat *terumah*.[^fn_70b_22] Wherein then lies the difference \[between a vow for more, and one for\] NOT MORE THAN THIRTY DAYS? — \[During a period of\] NOT MORE THAN THIRTY DAYS an agent[^fn_70b_23] performs his mission; for a longer period no agent performs his mission.

And if you prefer I might reply: \[The husband's vow[^fn_70b_24] is valid\] when he made it while she was betrothed to him and she was \[afterwards\] married.

But if she was married \[afterwards\] she must obviously have understood her position and accepted it![^fn_70b_25] — \[It is a case\] where she pleaded, 'I thought I shall be able to bear it but now I cannot bear it'.

But granted that such a plea[^fn_70b_26] is properly admissible[^fn_70b_27] in respect of bodily defects;[^fn_70b_28] is it admissible, however, in respect of maintenance?[^fn_70b_29] — Clearly, then, we can only explain as we explained at first.

HE MAY, \[IF THE PROHIBITION IS TO LAST\] NOT MORE THAN THIRTY DAYS, APPOINT A STEWARD. Does not the steward, however, act on his[^fn_70b_30] behalf?[^fn_70b_31] — R. Huna replied: \[Our Mishnah refers\] to one who declared, 'Whoever will maintain \[my wife\] will not suffer any loss'.[^fn_70b_32] But, even if be spoke in such a manner, is not the steward acting on his behalf? Have we not learned: If a man who was thrown into a pit cried that whosoever should hear his voice should write a letter of divorce for his wife, \[the hearers\][^fn_70b_33] may lawfully[^fn_70b_34] write, and deliver \[it to his wife\]?[^fn_70b_35] — How now! there[^fn_70b_36] the man said, 'should write';[^fn_70b_37] but did the man here[^fn_70b_38] say, 'should maintain'? All he said was, 'whoever will maintain'.[^fn_70b_39]

But surely R. Ammi said: In \[the case of\] a fire \[breaking\] out on the Sabbath\][^fn_70b_40] permission was given to make the announcement 'Whosoever shall extinguish it will suffer no loss'.[^fn_70b_41] Now what does \[the expression\] 'In a fire'[^fn_70b_42] exclude? Does it not exclude a case of this kind?[^fn_70b_43] — No; \[it was meant\] to exclude other acts that are forbidden on the Sabbath.[^fn_70b_44]

Rabbah raised an objection: If a man is forbidden by a vow to have any benefit from another man, and he has nothing to eat \[the other\] may go to a shopkeeper with whom he is familiar and say to him, 'So-and-so is forbidden by a vow to have any benefit from me, and I do not know what to do for him'. \[The shopkeeper\] may then give to the one and recover the cost from the other.[^fn_70b_45] Only such \[a suggestion\][^fn_70b_46] is permitted but not that of 'whoever will maintain \[my wife\] will not suffer any loss'?[^fn_70b_47] — \[The formula,\] 'There is no question' is here implied:[^fn_70b_48] There is no question \[that a man may announce,\] 'whoever will maintain \[my wife\] will not suffer any loss', since he is speaking to no one in particular;[^fn_70b_49] but even in this case where, since he is familiar with him[^fn_70b_50] and goes and speaks to him directly, \[it might have been thought that his mere suggestion is\] the same as if he had expressly told him,[^fn_70b_50] 'You go and give him',[^fn_70b_51] hence we were taught \[that this also is permitted\].

\[To revert to\] the main text.[^fn_70b_52] If a man is forbidden by a vow to have any benefit from another man, and he has nothing to eat, \[the other\] may go to a shopkeeper with whom he is familiar and say to him, 'So-and-so is forbidden by a vow to have any benefit from me, and I do not know what to do for him'. \[The shopkeeper\] may then give to the one and recover the cost from the other.[^fn_70b_53] If his[^fn_70b_54] house is to be built, his wall to be put up or his field to be harvested \[the other\] may go to labourers with whom he is familiar and say to them, 'So-and-so is forbidden by a vow to have any benefit from me, and I do not know what to do for him'. They may then work for him and recover[^fn_70b_55] their wages from the other. If they were going on the same journey and the one had with him nothing to eat, \[the other\][^fn_70b_56] may give \[some food\] to a third[^fn_70b_57] person as a gift and the first may take it \[from that person\] and eat it.[^fn_70b_58] If no third person[^fn_70b_57] is available, he[^fn_70b_56] may put the food upon a stone or a wall, and say, 'Behold this is free[^fn_70b_59] for all who desire \[to take it\]', and the other[^fn_70b_60] may take it and eat it.[^fn_70b_61] R. Jose, however, forbids this.[^fn_70b_62] Raba said: What is R. Jose's reason? — \[It is forbidden as\] a preventive measure against [pg 71a]

\[a repetition of\] the incident of Beth Horon.[^fn_71a_1]

R. JUDAH SAID: IF HE WAS AN ISRAELITE HE MAY KEEP HER \[AS HIS WIFE, IF THE PROHIBITION WAS FOR\] ONE MONTH etc. Is not this the same ruling as that of the first Tanna?[^fn_71a_2] — Abaye replied: He[^fn_71a_3] came to teach us \[the law concerning\] a priest's wife.[^fn_71a_4] Raba replied: The difference between them is a full month[^fn_71a_5] and a defective month.[^fn_71a_6]

Rab stated: This[^fn_71a_7] was taught only in the case of a man who specified \[the period of the prohibition\], but where he did not specify, he[^fn_71a_8] must divorce her immediately and give her the *kethubah*. Samuel, however, stated: Even where the period was not specified \[the husband\] need not divorce her, since it is possible that he might discover some reason[^fn_71a_9] for \[the remission of\] his vow.[^fn_71a_10] But surely they[^fn_71a_11] had once been in dispute upon this principle; for have we not learned, 'If a man forbade his wife by vow to have intercourse, Beth Shammai ruled: \[She must consent to the deprivation for\] two weeks; Beth Hillel ruled: \[Only for\] one week';[^fn_71a_12] and Rab stated, 'They[^fn_71a_13] differ only in the case of a man who specified \[the period of abstention\] but where he did not specify the period he[^fn_71a_14] must divorce her forthwith and give her the kethubah', and Samuel stated, 'Even where the period had not been specified the husband need not divorce her, since it might be possible for him to discover some reason[^fn_71a_15] for \[the annulment of\] his[^fn_71a_16] vow'?[^fn_71a_17] — \[Both disputes were\] necessary. For if \[their views\] had been expressed in the former case[^fn_71a_18] it might have been assumed that only in that case did Rab maintain his view, since \[the appointment\] of a steward is not possible, but that in the latter case[^fn_71a_19] where \[the appointment\] of a steward is possible, he agrees with Samuel. And if \[their views\] had been stated in the latter case[^fn_71a_19] it might have been assumed that only in that case did Samuel maintain his view, since the appointment of a steward is possible. but that in the former case[^fn_71a_18] he agrees with Rab. \[Hence both statements were\] necessary.

We learned: IF A MAN FORBADE HIS WIFE BY VOW THAT SHE SHOULD NOT TASTE A CERTAIN FRUIT, HE MUST DIVORCE HER[^fn_71a_20] AND GIVE HER THE *KETHUBAH*. Now according to Rab[^fn_71a_21] \[there is no contradiction[^fn_71a_22] since\] the latter[^fn_71a_23] may apply to a man who did not specify \[the period of the prohibition\] and the former[^fn_71a_23] to a man who did specify \[the period\]. According to Samuel,[^fn_71a_24] however, a contradiction arises![^fn_71a_22] — Here we are dealing with a case, for instance, where the woman made the vow and he confirmed it;[^fn_71a_25] R. Meir[^fn_71a_26] holding the opinion that \[the husband\][^fn_71a_27] had himself put his finger between her teeth. But does R. Meir hold the principle, 'He has himself put his finger between her teeth'? Surely it was taught: If a woman made the vow of a nazirite[^fn_71a_28] and her husband heard of it and did not annul it, she, said R. Meir and R. Judah, has thereby put her own finger between her teeth. Therefore, if the husband wishes to annul her vow, he may do so. But if he[^fn_71a_29] said, 'I do not want a wife who is in the habit of vowing'. she may be divorced without \[receiving\] her *kethubah*. R. Jose and R. Eleazar said: He[^fn_71a_30] has put his finger between her teeth. Therefore, if the husband wishes to annul her vow, he may do so. But if he[^fn_71a_31] said, 'I do not want a wife who is in the habit of vowing', he may divorce her but must give her the *kethubah*![^fn_71a_32] — Reverse \[the views\]: R. Meir and R. Judah said: 'He has put'[^fn_71a_33] and R. Jose and R. Eleazar said: 'She has put'.[^fn_71a_34] But is R. Jose of the opinion that it is she who put?[^fn_71a_34] Have we not learned: R. Jose ruled: \[THIS[^fn_71a_35] APPLIES\] TO POOR WOMEN IF NO TIME LIMIT IS GIVEN?[^fn_71a_36] — Read: R. Meir and R. Jose said, 'He has put';[^fn_71a_33] R. Judah and R. Eleazar said, 'She has put'.[^fn_71a_34] But does R. Judah uphold the principle of 'She put'?[^fn_71a_34] Have we not learned: R. JUDAH RULED: IF HE WAS AN ISRAELITE HE MAY KEEP HER \[AS HIS WIFE, IF THE VOW WAS FOR\] ONE DAY?[^fn_71a_37] — Read: R. Meir and R. Judah and R. Jose said, 'He put'.[^fn_71a_33] and R. Eleazar said, 'She put'.[^fn_71a_34] And should you find \[some ground\] for insisting that the names must appear in pairs,[^fn_71a_38] then read: R. Meir and R. Eleazar said, 'She put',[^fn_71a_39] and R. Judah and R. Jose said, 'He put';[^fn_71a_40] and this anonymous Mishnah[^fn_71a_41] is not in agreement with R. Meir.

Is R. Jose, however, of the opinion that \[THIS[^fn_71a_42] APPLIES\] TO POOR WOMEN IF NO TIME LIMIT IS GIVEN; from which[^fn_71a_43] it is evident that a husband has the right to annul[^fn_71a_43] \[such vows\]?[^fn_71a_44] This, surely, is incongruous \[with the following\]. These are the vows[^fn_71a_45] which a husband may annul: Vows which involve an affliction of soul[^fn_71a_46] \[as, for instance, if a woman said, 'I vow not to enjoy the pleasure of bathing\] should I bathe'[^fn_71a_47] \[or\] 'I swear that[^fn_71a_48] I shall not bathe', \[or again, 'I vow not to make use of adornments\] should I make use of an adornment',[^fn_71a_47] \[or\] 'I swear that[^fn_71a_48] I shall not make use of any adornments'. R. Jose said: These are not regarded as vows involving an affliction of soul;[^fn_71a_49] and the following are vows that involve an affliction of soul: '\[I swear\] that I shall not eat meat' or 'that I shall not drink wine' or 'that I shall not adorn myself [pg 71b]

with coloured garments'![^fn_71b_1] — Here[^fn_71b_2] we are dealing with matters affecting their intimate relations.[^fn_71b_3] This explanation is satisfactory according to him who maintains that a husband may annul \[vows on\] matters affecting their intimate relations. — What, however, can be said \[in explanation\] according to him who maintains that a husband may not annul \[such vows\]? For it was stated:[^fn_71b_4] \[As to vows on\] matters affecting their intimate relations, R. Huna ruled: A husband may annul them; R. Adda b. Ahabah ruled: A husband may not annul them, for we do not find that a fox should die of the dust of his den![^fn_71b_5] — The fact, however, is that we are here[^fn_71b_2] dealing with a case, for instance, where she made her marital intercourse dependent upon her use of adornments, by saying. 'The enjoyment of your intercourse shall be forbidden to me should I ever make use of any adornment.'[^fn_71b_6] \[This explanation\] is in agreement with a ruling of R. Kahana. For R. Kahana ruled, \[If a woman said to her husband\]. 'The enjoyment of my intercourse \[shall be forbidden\][^fn_71b_7] to you', he may compel her to such intercourse;[^fn_71b_8] \[if, however, she vowed,\] 'The enjoyment of your intercourse \[shall be forbidden\][^fn_71b_9] to me'[^fn_71b_10] he must annul \[her vow\][^fn_71b_11] because no person is to be fed with a thing that is forbidden to him.[^fn_71b_12] But let her[^fn_71b_13] not adorn herself and consequently not be forbidden to him![^fn_71b_14] — If so,[^fn_71b_15] she would be called, 'The ugly woman'.[^fn_71b_16] But then let her adorn herself and be forbidden \[intercourse\] either for two weeks, according to Beth Shammai[^fn_71b_17] or for one week according to Beth Hillel!'[^fn_71b_18] — These[^fn_71b_19] apply only to a case where he \[the husband\] has forbidden her by a vow \[to have intercourse with him\], because \[in such circumstances\] she thinks 'He may have been angry with me[^fn_71b_20] and will later[^fn_71b_21] calm down'.[^fn_71b_22] Here, however, since she has made the vow and he remained silent,[^fn_71b_23] she comes to the conclusion: 'Since he remained silent[^fn_71b_23] he must indeed hate me'.[^fn_71b_24]

R. JOSE RULED: \[THIS APPLIES\] TO POOR WOMEN IF NO TIME LIMIT IS GIVEN. What is the TIME LIMIT?[^fn_71b_25] — Rab Judah citing Samuel replied: Twelve months.[^fn_71b_26] Rabbah b. Bar Hana citing R. Johanan replied: Ten years.[^fn_71b_26] R. Hisda citing Abimi replied: A festival;[^fn_71b_27] for[^fn_71b_28] the daughters of Israel adorn themselves on a festival.

AND TO RICH WOMEN \[IF THE TIME LIMIT IS\] THIRTY DAYS. Why just[^fn_71b_29] THIRTY DAYS? — Abaye replied: Because[^fn_71b_28] a prominent woman enjoys the scent of her cosmetics for thirty days.[^fn_71b_30]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN FORBADE HIS WIFE[^fn_71b_31] BY VOW THAT SHE SHALL NOT GO TO HER FATHER'S HOUSE, AND HE[^fn_71b_32] LIVES WITH HER IN THE SAME TOWN, HE MAY KEEP \[HER AS HIS WIFE, IF THE PROHIBITION WAS FOR\] ONE MONTH; BUT IF FOR TWO MONTHS HE MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER ALSO THE *KETHUBAH*. WHERE HE, HOWEVER, LIVES IN ANOTHER TOWN, HE MAY KEEP \[HER AS HIS WIFE, IF THE PROHIBITION WAS FOR\] ONE FESTIVAL,[^fn_71b_33] \[BUT IF FOR\] THREE[^fn_71b_34] FESTIVALS, HE MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER ALSO HER *KETHUBAH*. IF A MAN FORBADE HIS WIFE BY VOW[^fn_71b_35] THAT SHE SHALL NOT VISIT A HOUSE OF MOURNING OR A HOUSE OF FEASTING, HE MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER ALSO HER *KETHUBAH*, BECAUSE THEREBY HE HAS CLOSED \[PEOPLE'S DOORS\] AGAINST HER. IF HE PLEADS, HOWEVER, \[THAT HIS ACTION\] WAS DUE TO SOME OTHER CAUSE[^fn_71b_36] HE IS PERMITTED \[TO FORBID HER\]. IF HE SAID TO HER: '\[THERE SHALL BE NO VOW\] PROVIDED THAT YOU TELL[^fn_71b_36] SO-AND-SO WHAT YOU HAVE TOLD ME' OR 'WHAT I HAVE TOLD YOU' OR 'THAT YOU SHALL FILL[^fn_71b_36] AND POUR OUT ON THE RUBBISH HEAP', HE MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER ALSO HER *KETHUBAH*. {¶=7.2}

***GEMARA***. This, surely, is self-contradictory. You said, HE MAY KEEP \[HER AS HIS WIFE, IF THE PROHIBITION WAS FOR\] ONE FESTIVAL, which implies that if it was for two festivals he must divorce her and give her also her *kethubah*. But read the concluding clause, \[IF FOR\] THREE FESTIVALS HE MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER ALSO HER *KETHUBAH*, from which it follows, does it not, that if it was for two only he may keep \[her as his wife\]?[^fn_71b_37] Abaye replied: The concluding clause refers to a priest's wife, and it represents the view of R. Judah.[^fn_71b_38] Rabbah b. 'Ulla said: There is no contradiction, for one[^fn_71b_39] refers to a woman who was anxious \[to visit her parents home\][^fn_71b_40] and the other applies to one who was not anxious.[^fn_71b_41]

Then[^fn_71b_42] was I in his eyes as one that found peace,[^fn_71b_43] R.[^fn_71b_44] Johanan[^fn_71b_45] interpreted: like a bride[^fn_71b_46] who was found faultless[^fn_71b_47] in the house of her father-in-law[^fn_71b_48] and she is anxious to go and tell of her success[^fn_71b_49] at her paternal home.[^fn_71b_50]

And it shall be at that day, saith the Lord, that thou shalt call me Ishi,[^fn_71b_51] and shalt not call me Ba'ali,[^fn_71b_52] R. Johanan interpreted: Like a bride in the house of her father-in-law[^fn_71b_53] and not like a bride in her paternal home.[^fn_71b_54]

IF A MAN FORBADE HIS WIFE BY VOW etc. One can well understand that in respect \[of her prohibition to enter\] A HOUSE OF FEASTING [pg 72a]

the reason, HE HAS CLOSED \[PEOPLE'S DOORS\] AGAINST HER, is applicable;[^fn_72a_1] what \[point, however,\] is there \[in the reason,\] HE HAS CLOSED \[PEOPLE'S DOORS\] AGAINST HER, in the case of A HOUSE OF MOURNING? — A Tanna taught: To-morrow she might die and no creature would mourn for her.[^fn_72a_2] Others read: And no creature would bury her.[^fn_72a_3]

It was taught: R. Meir used to say: What is meant by the Scriptural text, it is better to go to the house of mourning than to go to the house of feasting. for that is the end of all men, and the living will lay it to his heart,[^fn_72a_4] what, \[I say, is meant by\] And the living will lay it[^fn_72a_5] to his heart? The matters relating to death. \[Let him realize\] that if a man mourns for other people others will also mourn for him; if he buries other people others will also bury him; if he lifts up \[his voice to lament\] for others, others will \[lift up their voices to lament\] for him; if he escorts others \[to the grave\] others will also escort him; if he carries others \[to their last resting place\] others will also carry him.

IF, HOWEVER, HE PLEADS \[THAT HIS ACTION\] WAS DUE TO SOME OTHER CAUSE HE IS PERMITTED. What is meant by SOME OTHER CAUSE? — Rab Judah citing Samuel replied: On account of dissolute men who frequent that place. Said R. Ashi: This applies only where \[the place\] has gained such a reputation; where, however, it has not gained such reputation it is not within the power of the husband \[to veto it\].[^fn_72a_6]

IF HE SAID TO HER: '\[THERE SHALL BE NO VOW\] PROVIDED THAT YOU TELL \[etc.\].' \[Why indeed\] should she \[not\] tell it? — Rab Judah citing Samuel replied: \[This refers to\] abusive language.[^fn_72a_7]

OR 'THAT YOU SHALL FILL AND POUR OUT ON THE RUBBISH HEAP'. \[Why indeed\] should she \[not\] do it? — Rab Judah citing Samuel replied: \[Because the meaning of his request is\] that she shall allow herself to be filled and then scatter it.[^fn_72a_8] In a Baraitha it was taught: \[The man's request is\] that she shall fill ten jars of water and empty them on to the rubbish heap. Now according to \[the explanation\] of Samuel one can well see the reason why HE MUST DIVORCE HER AND GIVE HER ALSO HER *KETHUBAH*; according to the Baraitha, however, \[the difficulty arises\] what matters it to her if she does it?[^fn_72a_9] — Rabbah b. Bar Hana citing R. Johanan replied: \[She cannot be expected to do it\] because she would appear like an imbecile.

R. Kahana stated: If a man placed his wife under a vow that she shall neither borrow nor lend a winnow, a sieve, a mill or an oven, he must divorce her and give her also her *kethubah*, because \[should she fulfil the vow\] he would give her a bad name among her neighbours. So it was also taught in a Baraitha: If a man placed his wife under a vow that she shall neither borrow nor lend a winnow, a sieve, a mill or an oven, he must divorce her and give her also her *kethubah*, because \[should she comply with his desire\] he would give her a bad name among her neighbours. Similarly if she vowed that she shall neither borrow nor lend a winnow, a sieve, a mill or an oven, or that she shall not weave beautiful garments for his children, she may be divorced without a *kethubah*, because \[by acting on her wishes\] she gives him a bad name among his neighbours.

***MISHNAH***. THESE ARE TO BE DIVORCED WITHOUT RECEIVING THEIR KETHUBAH: A WIFE WHO TRANSGRESSES THE LAW OF MOSES OR \[ONE WHO TRANSGRESSES\] JEWISH PRACTICE. AND WHAT IS \[REGARDED AS A WIFE'S TRANSGRESSION AGAINST\] THE LAW OF MOSES? FEEDING HER HUSBAND WITH UNTITHED FOOD,[^fn_72a_10] HAVING INTERCOURSE WITH HIM DURING THE PERIOD OF HER MENSTRUATION,[^fn_72a_11] NOT SETTING APART HER DOUGH OFFERING,[^fn_72a_12] OR MAKING VOWS AND NOT FULFILLING THEM.[^fn_72a_13] AND WHAT \[IS DEEMED TO BE A WIFE'S TRANSGRESSION AGAINST\] JEWISH PRACTICE? GOING OUT WITH UNCOVERED HEAD,[^fn_72a_14] SPINNING IN THE STREET[^fn_72a_15] OR CONVERSING WITH EVERY MAN. ABBA SAUL SAID: \[SUCH TRANSGRESSIONS INCLUDE\] ALSO THAT OF A WIFE WHO CURSES HER HUSBAND'S PARENTS IN HIS PRESENCE. R. TARFON SAID: ALSO ONE WHO SCREAMS. AND WHO IS REGARDED A SCREAMER? A WOMAN WHOSE VOICE CAN BE HEARD BY HER NEIGHBOURS WHEN SHE SPEAKS INSIDE HER HOUSE.[^fn_72a_16] {¶=7.3}

***GEMARA***. FEEDING HER HUSBAND WITH UNTITHED FOOD. How are we to understand this? If the husband knows \[the fact\],[^fn_72a_17] let him abstain; if he does not know \[it\],[^fn_72a_17] how did he discover it? — \[This ruling was\] required in the case only where she told him, 'So-and-so the priest has ritually prepared for me the pile of grain',[^fn_72a_18] and he went and asked him and her statement was found to be untrue.

HAVING INTERCOURSE WITH HIM DURING THE PERIOD OF HER MENSTRUATION. How are we to understand this? If he was aware of her \[condition\] he could have abstained, if he was not aware \[of it\][^fn_72a_19] he should still rely upon her, for R. Hinena b. Kahana stated in the name of Samuel: Whence is it deduced that the menstruant herself may \[be relied upon to\] count \[correctly\]?[^fn_72a_20] From the Scriptural statement, Then she shall number to herself[^fn_72a_21] seven days,[^fn_72a_22] 'Lah means to herself.'[^fn_72a_23] — It was required in the case only where she said to her husband, 'So-and-so the sage told me that the blood was clean',[^fn_72a_24] and when her husband went and asked him it was found that her statement was untrue. If you prefer I might reply on the lines of a ruling of Rab Judah who said: If a woman was known[^fn_72a_25] among her neighbours to be a menstruant her husband[^fn_72a_26] is flogged on her account for \[having intercourse with\] a menstruant.[^fn_72a_27]

NOT SETTING APART THE DOUGH OFFERING. How is this to be understood? If the husband was aware \[of the fact\] he should have abstained \[from the food\]; if he was not aware \[of it at the time\] how does he know it now? — \[The ruling is to be understood as\] required in the case only where she said to him. 'So-and-so the baker[^fn_72a_28] has ritually prepared the dough[^fn_72a_29] for me' and when the husband went and asked him her statement was found to be untrue.

OR MAKING VOWS AND NOT FULFILLING THEM; for the Master stated: One's children die on account of the sin of making vows,[^fn_72a_30] as it is said in Scripture. Suffer not thy mouth to cause thy flesh to sin etc. \[wherefore should God be angry at thy voice, and destroy the work of thine hands\];[^fn_72a_31] and what is the work of a man's hands? You must say: His sons and his daughters. R. Nahman[^fn_72a_32] said, \[It[^fn_72a_33] may be inferred\] from the following: In vain have I smitten your children;'[^fn_72a_34] 'In vain' implies, on account of vain utterances.[^fn_72a_35]

It was taught: R. Meir said, Any man who knows that his wife makes vows and does not fulfil them should impose vows upon her again. \[You say\] 'Should impose vows upon her \[again\]'? Whereby would he reform her?[^fn_72a_36] — But \[say\] he should provoke her again in order that she should make her vow in his presence[^fn_72a_37] and he would \[thus be able to\] annul it.[^fn_72a_38] They, however, said to him: No one can live with a serpent in the same basket.[^fn_72a_39]

It was taught: R. Judah said. Any husband who knows that his wife does not \[properly\] set apart for him the dough offering should set it apart again after her. They, however, said to him: No one can live with a serpent in the same basket.[^fn_72a_40] He who taught it[^fn_72a_41] in connection with this case[^fn_72a_42] \[would apply it\] with even greater force to the other case;[^fn_72a_43] he, however, who taught it in connection with the other case \[applies it to that case only\][^fn_72a_44] but \[not to this one,[^fn_72a_42] because\][^fn_72a_45] it might sometimes happen that he would eat.[^fn_72a_46]

AND WHAT \[IS DEEMED TO BE A WIFE'S TRANSGRESSION AGAINST\] JEWISH PRACTICE? GOING OUT WITH UNCOVERED HEAD. \[Is not the prohibition against going out with\] an uncovered head Pentateuchal;[^fn_72a_47] for it is written, And he shall uncover the woman's head,[^fn_72a_48] and this, it was taught at the school of R. Ishmael, was a warning to the daughters of Israel that they should not go out with uncovered[^fn_72a_49] head?[^fn_72a_50] — Pentateuchally [pg 72b]

it is quite satisfactory \[if her head is covered by\] her work-basket;[^fn_72b_1] according to traditional Jewish practice, however, she is forbidden \[to go out uncovered\] even with her basket \[on her head\].

R. Assi stated in the name of R. Johanan: With a basket \[on her head a woman\] is not guilty of[^fn_72b_2] \[going about with\] an uncovered head. In considering this statement, R. Zera pointed out this difficulty: Where \[is the woman assumed to be\]?[^fn_72b_3] If it be suggested, 'In the street', \[it may be objected that this is already forbidden by\] Jewish practice;[^fn_72b_4] but \[if she is\] in a court-yard[^fn_72b_3] \[the objection may be made that\] if that were so[^fn_72b_5] you will not leave our father Abraham a \[single\] daughter who could remain with her husband![^fn_72b_6] — Abaye, or it might be said, R. Kahana, replied: \[The statement refers to one who walks\] from one courtyard into another by way of an alley.[^fn_72b_7]

SPINNING IN THE STREET. Rab Judah stated in the name of Samuel: \[The prohibition applies only\] where she exposed her arms to the public. R. Hisda stated in the name of Abimi: \[This applies only\] where she spins rose \[coloured materials, and holds them up\] to her face.[^fn_72b_8]

CONVERSING WITH EVERY MAN. Rab Judah stated in the name of Samuel: \[This refers only to one\] who jests with young men.

Rabbah b. Bar Hana related: I was once walking behind R. 'Ukba when I observed an Arab woman who was sitting, casting her spindle and spinning a rose \[coloured material which she held up\] to her face.[^fn_72b_9] When she saw us she detached the spindle \[from the thread\], threw it down and said to me, 'Young man, hand me my[^fn_72b_10] spindle'. Referring to her[^fn_72b_11] R. 'Ukba made a statement. What was that statement? — Rabina replied: He spoke of her as a woman SPINNING IN THE STREET. The Rabbis said: He spoke of her as one CONVERSING WITH EVERY MAN.

ABBA SAUL SAID: \[SUCH TRANSGRESSIONS INCLUDE\] ALSO THAT OF A WIFE WHO CURSES HER HUSBAND'S PARENTS IN HIS PRESENCE. Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel: \[This[^fn_72b_12] includes also\] one who curses his parents in the presence of his offspring;[^fn_72b_13] and your mnemonic sign[^fn_72b_14] is, *Ephraim and Manasseh,[^fn_72b_15] even as Reuben and Simeon,[^fn_72b_16] shall be mine*.[^fn_72b_17] Rabbah[^fn_72b_18] explained:[^fn_72b_19] When she said[^fn_72b_20] in the presence of her husband's son, 'May a lion devour your grandfather'.[^fn_72b_21]

R. TARFON SAID: ALSO ONE WHO SCREAMS. What is meant by a screamer? — Rab Judah replied in the name of Samuel: One who speaks aloud[^fn_72b_22] on marital matters. In a Baraitha it was taught: \[By screams was meant a wife\] whose voice[^fn_72b_23] during her intercourse in one court can be heard in another court. But should not this, then,[^fn_72b_24] have been taught in the Mishnah[^fn_72b_25] among defects?[^fn_72b_26] — Clearly we must revert to the original explanation.[^fn_72b_27]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN BETROTHED A WOMAN ON CONDITION THAT SHE WAS NOT SUBJECT TO ANY VOWS AND SHE WAS FOUND TO BE UNDER A VOW,[^fn_72b_28] HER BETROTHAL IS INVALID. IF HE MARRIED HER[^fn_72b_29] WITHOUT MAKING ANY CONDITIONS AND SHE WAS FOUND TO BE UNDER A VOW,[^fn_72b_28] SHE MAY BE DIVORCED WITHOUT RECEIVING HER *KETHUBAH*. {¶=7.4}

\[IF A WOMAN WAS BETROTHED\] ON CONDITION THAT SHE HAS NO BODILY DEFECTS, AND SHE WAS FOUND TO HAVE SUCH DEFECTS, HER BETROTHAL IS INVALID. IF HE MARRIED HER WITHOUT MAKING ANY CONDITIONS AND SHE WAS FOUND TO HAVE BODILY DEFECTS, SHE MAY BE DIVORCED WITHOUT A KETHUBAH. ALL DEFECTS WHICH DISQUALIFY PRIESTS[^fn_72b_30] DISQUALIFY WOMEN ALSO.[^fn_72b_31]

***GEMARA***. We have \[in fact\] learned \[the same Mishnah\] also in \[the Tractate\] *Kiddushin*.[^fn_72b_32] \[But\] here[^fn_72b_33] \[the laws\][^fn_72b_34] were required \[in respect of\] *kethuboth*,[^fn_72b_35] and the laws concerning betrothal[^fn_72b_36] were stated on account of those of the *kethubah*; there[^fn_72b_37] the laws in respect of betrothal were required, and those concerning *kethuboth*[^fn_72b_34] were stated on account of those of betrothal.

R. Johanan said in the name of R. Simeon b. Jehozadak: They[^fn_72b_38] spoke only of the following vows. That she would not eat meat, that she would not drink wine or that she would not adorn herself with coloured garments. So it was also taught elsewhere: They spoke of such vows as involve an affliction of the soul, \[namely,\] that she would not eat meat, that she would not drink wine or that she would not adorn herself with coloured garments.

In dealing with this subject R. Papa raised this difficulty: What does it[^fn_72b_39] refer to? If it be suggested \[that it refers\] to the first clause[^fn_72b_40] \[it might be retorted that\] since the husband objects \[to vows\] even other kinds of vows[^fn_72b_41] Should also be included! — \[It refers\] only to the final clause.[^fn_72b_42] R. Ashi said: It may in fact refer to the first clause,[^fn_72b_40] but in respect of the vows to which people usually take exception[^fn_72b_43] his objection is valid;[^fn_72b_44] respect of vows to which people do not as a rule take exception his objection has no validity.

It was stated: If a man betrothed a woman on condition \[that she was under no vow\] and married her without attaching any conditions, it is necessary, Rab ruled, that she[^fn_72b_45] shall obtain from him a letter of divorce; and Samuel ruled: It is not necessary for her to obtain a letter of divorce from him.[^fn_72b_46] Said Abaye: [pg 73a]

It must not be suggested that Rab's reason[^fn_73a_1] is that, because the man has married her without attaching any conditions, he has entirely dispensed with his former condition.[^fn_73a_2] Rab's reason rather is that no man treats his intercourse as a mere act of prostitution.[^fn_73a_3]

Surely they[^fn_73a_4] once disputed on such a principle.[^fn_73a_5] For it was stated: Where \[an orphan\] minor[^fn_73a_6] who did not[^fn_73a_7] exercise her right of *mi'un*[^fn_73a_8] and who, when she came of age, left[^fn_73a_9] \[her husband\][^fn_73a_10] and married \[another man\], Rab ruled: She requires no letter of divorce from her second husband,[^fn_73a_11] and Samuel ruled: She requires a letter of divorce from her second husband![^fn_73a_12] — \[Both disputes were\] necessary. For if the latter[^fn_73a_13] only had been stated, it might have been assumed that Rab adhered to his opinion[^fn_73a_14] in that case only because no condition was attached \[to the betrothal\],[^fn_73a_15] but that in the former case,[^fn_73a_16] where a condition was attached \[to the betrothal\],[^fn_73a_17] he agrees with Samuel.[^fn_73a_18] And if the former case[^fn_73a_16] only had been stated, it might have been assumed that in that case only[^fn_73a_19] did Samuel maintain his view[^fn_73a_20] but that in the latter[^fn_73a_13] he agrees with Rab.[^fn_73a_21] \[Hence both were\] required.

We have learned: IF HE MARRIED HER WITHOUT MAKING ANY CONDITION AND SHE WAS FOUND TO BE UNDER A VOW, SHE MAY BE DIVORCED WITHOUT RECEIVING HER *KETHUBAH* \[which[^fn_73a_22] implies that\] it is only her *kethubah* that she cannot claim but that she nevertheless requires a letter of divorce. Now does not this[^fn_73a_23] refer to one who has betrothed a woman on condition \[that she was under no vow\][^fn_73a_24] and married her without making any condition?[^fn_73a_25] This then[^fn_73a_26] represents an objection against Samuel![^fn_73a_27] [pg 73b]

— No; \[this[^fn_73b_1] refers to one who\] betrothed her without attaching a condition and also married her without attaching a condition.[^fn_73b_2] If, however, one betrothed a woman on a certain condition and subsequently married her without attaching a condition would she, \[according to our Mishnah\], indeed[^fn_73b_3] require no divorce?[^fn_73b_4] If so, then, instead of stating, IF A MAN BETROTHED A WOMAN ON THE CONDITION THAT SHE WAS NOT SUBJECT TO ANY VOWS AND SHE WAS FOUND TO BE UNDER A VOW, HER BETROTHAL IS INVALID,[^fn_73b_5] it should rather have been stated: If a man married a woman without attaching a condition and she was found to be under a vow, her betrothal is invalid, and \[it would be evident, would it not, that this[^fn_73b_6] applies\] even more so to the former?[^fn_73b_7] — It is really this reading that was meant:[^fn_73b_8] IF A MAN BETROTHED A WOMAN ON THE CONDITION THAT SHE WAS NOT SUBJECT TO ANY VOWS, and then he married her without making any conditions, AND SHE WAS FOUND TO BE UNDER A VOW, HER BETROTHAL IS INVALID; if, however, he betrothed her without making any conditions and also MARRIED HER WITHOUT MAKING ANY CONDITIONS, SHE MAY BE DIVORCED WITHOUT RECEIVING HER *KETHUBAH*; it is only her *kethubah* that she cannot claim but it is necessary for her to obtain a divorce. But why has she no claim to her *kethubah*? Because, \[apparently\], he[^fn_73b_9] could plead, 'I do not want a wife that is in the habit of making vows',[^fn_73b_10] but if that is the case there should be no need for her to obtain a divorce either![^fn_73b_11] — Rabbah replied: It is only according to Rabbinical law that she requires a divorce. So also said R. Hisda: It is only in accordance with the Rabbinical law that she requires a divorce. Raba replied: The Tanna[^fn_73b_12] was really in doubt.[^fn_73b_13] \[Hence he adopted\] the lenient view in monetary matters[^fn_73b_14] and the stricter one[^fn_73b_15] in the case of prohibitions.[^fn_73b_16]

Rabbah stated: They[^fn_73b_17] differ only in the case of an error[^fn_73b_18] \[affecting\] two women,[^fn_73b_19] but where an error \[affects\] one woman[^fn_73b_20] all agree[^fn_73b_21] that she requires no divorce from him.[^fn_73b_22] Said Abaye:[^fn_73b_23] But our Mishnah, surely, is one which \[has been assumed[^fn_73b_24] to refer to\] an error \[affecting\] one woman but was nevertheless adduced as an objection![^fn_73b_25] If, however, such a statement was made at all it must have been made in this form: Rabbah stated: They[^fn_73b_26] differ only in the case of an error \[affecting\] a woman \[who is in a position\] similar \[to that of one of\] two women,[^fn_73b_27] but in the case of an error \[affecting\] merely one woman[^fn_73b_28] all agree[^fn_73b_29] that she requires no divorce from him.[^fn_73b_30]

Abaye raised an objection against him:[^fn_73b_31] If a man betrothed a woman in error[^fn_73b_32] or \[with something worth\] less than a *perutah*,[^fn_73b_33] and, similarly, if a minor betrothed a woman, even if any \[of them\] has subsequently sent presents[^fn_73b_34] \[to the woman\], her betrothal is invalid,[^fn_73b_35] because he has sent these gifts on account of the original betrothal.[^fn_73b_36] If, however, they[^fn_73b_37] had intercourse they have thereby effected legal *kinyan*. R. Simeon b. Judah in the name of R. Ishmael said: Even if they had intercourse they effect no *kinyan*.[^fn_73b_38] Now here, surely, it is an error \[affecting\] only one woman and they[^fn_73b_39] nevertheless differ. Would you not \[admit that by 'error' is meant\] an error in respect of vows?[^fn_73b_40] — No; \[what was meant is\] an error in respect of that which was worth less than a *perutah*.[^fn_73b_41] — But was not 'less than than a perutah' explicitly mentioned: 'If a man betrothed a woman in error or \[with something worth\] less than a perutah'?[^fn_73b_42] — \[The latter part is\] really an explanation \[of the former:\] What is meant by 'If a man betrothed a woman in error'? If, for instance, he betrothed her with 'something worth less than 'a perutah'.

On what principle do they[^fn_73b_43] differ?[^fn_73b_44] — One Master[^fn_73b_45] holds the view that everyone is aware that with less than the value of a *perutah* no betrothal can be effected, and consequently any man having intercourse \[after such an invalid act\] determines \[to do so\] for the purpose of betrothal. The other Master,[^fn_73b_46] however, holds the view that not everyone is aware that with less than the value of a *perutah* no betrothal can be effected, and when a man has intercourse \[after such an act[^fn_73b_47] he does so\] in reliance on his first betrothal.[^fn_73b_48]

He raised \[another\] objection against him:[^fn_73b_49] \[If a man said to a woman,\] 'I am having intercourse with you on the condition that my father will consent',[^fn_73b_50] she is betrothed to him even if his father did not consent. R. Simeon b. Judah, however, stated in the name of R. Simeon, If his father consented she is betrothed but if his father did not consent she is not betrothed.[^fn_73b_51] Now here, surely, it is a case similar to that of an error affecting one woman[^fn_73b_52] and they[^fn_73b_53] nevertheless differ![^fn_73b_54] — They differ in this case[^fn_73b_55] on the following points.[^fn_73b_56] One Master[^fn_73b_57] holds the opinion that \[the expression\] 'On the condition that my father consents' implies, 'On condition that my father will remain silent', and \[the betrothal is valid\] because, surely, his father remained silent. And the other Master[^fn_73b_58] holds the opinion \[that the meaning of the expression is\] that his father will say, 'yes', and \[the betrothal is invalid\] because his father in fact did not say, 'yes'.

He raised \[a further\] objection against him.[^fn_73b_59] The Sages agree with R. Eliezer[^fn_73b_60] in respect of a minor whom her father had given in marriage and who was divorced,[^fn_73b_61] \[in consequence of which\] she is regarded as an 'orphan' in her father's lifetime,[^fn_73b_62] and who was then remarried,[^fn_73b_63] that she must perform *halizah*[^fn_73b_64] but may not[^fn_73b_65] contract the levirate marriage because her divorce was a perfectly legal divorce,[^fn_73b_66] but her remarriage was not a perfectly legal remarriage.[^fn_73b_67] This,[^fn_73b_68] however, applies only where he[^fn_73b_69] divorced her while she was a minor[^fn_73b_70] and remarried her while she was still a minor;[^fn_73b_71] but if he[^fn_73b_72] divorced her while she was a minor[^fn_73b_73] and remarried her while she was still a minor and she became of age while she was still with him, and then he died,[^fn_73b_74] she must either perform *halizah* or contract the levirate marriage.[^fn_73b_75] [pg 74a]

In the name of R. Eliezer,[^fn_74a_1] however, it was stated: She[^fn_74a_2] must perform *halizah* but may not contract the levirate marriage.[^fn_74a_3] Now, here,[^fn_74a_4] surely, it is a case similar to that of an error[^fn_74a_5] affecting merely one woman and they[^fn_74a_6] nevertheless differ![^fn_74a_7] — In that case[^fn_74a_8] also \[it may be said that\][^fn_74a_9] they[^fn_74a_6] differ on the following principles.[^fn_74a_10] One Master[^fn_74a_11] maintains that everyone is aware that there is no validity in the betrothal of a minor and, consequently, any man having intercourse \[after such an invalid act\] determines that his intercourse shall serve the purpose of a betrothal.[^fn_74a_12] The other Master,[^fn_74a_13] however, maintains that not everyone is aware that there is no validity in the betrothal of a minor, and when a man has intercourse \[after such an act[^fn_74a_14] he does so\] in reliance on his original betrothal.[^fn_74a_15]

\[So\][^fn_74a_16] it was also stated: R. Aha b. Jacob stated in the name of R. Johanan. If a man betrothed a woman on a certain condition and then had intercourse with her, she,[^fn_74a_17] it is the opinion of all, requires no letter of divorce from him.

R. Aha the son of R. Ika, his[^fn_74a_18] sister's son[^fn_74a_19] raised an objection against him: A *halizah* under a false pretext[^fn_74a_20] is valid; and what is 'a *halizah* under a false pretext'? Resh Lakish explained: Where a levir is told, 'Submit to her *halizah* and you will thereby wed her'. Said R. Johanan to him:[^fn_74a_21] I am in the habit of repeating \[a Baraitha,\] 'Whether he[^fn_74a_22] had the intention[^fn_74a_23] \[of performing the commandment of *halizah*\] and she had no such intention, or whether she had such intention and he had not, her *halizah* is invalid, it being necessary[^fn_74a_24] that both shall \[at the same time\] have such intention', and you say that her *halizah* is valid?[^fn_74a_25] But, said R. Johanan, \[this is the meaning:\][^fn_74a_26] When a levir is told, 'Submit to her *halizah* on the con dition that she gives you two hundred zuz'.[^fn_74a_27] Thus[^fn_74a_28] it clearly follows that as soon as a man has performed an act[^fn_74a_29] he has thereby dispensed with his condition, \[why then should it not be said\] here also that as soon as the man has intercourse he has thereby dispensed with his condition?[^fn_74a_30] — The other replied: Young hopeful,[^fn_74a_31] do you speak sensibly?[^fn_74a_32] Consider: Whence do we derive \[the law of the validity of\] any condition? \[Obviously\] from the condition in respect of the sons of Gad and the sons of Reuben;[^fn_74a_33] \[hence it is only\] a condition that may be carried out through an agent, as was the case there,[^fn_74a_34] that is regarded as a valid condition; but one which cannot be carried out through an agent,[^fn_74a_35] as was the case there, is not regarded as a valid condition.[^fn_74a_36] But is not intercourse[^fn_74a_37] an act which cannot be performed through an agent as was the case there[^fn_74a_34] and yet a condition in connection with it is valid?[^fn_74a_38] — The reason[^fn_74a_39] there is because the various forms of betrothal[^fn_74a_40] were compared to one another.[^fn_74a_41]

R. 'Ulla b. Abba in the name of 'Ulla in the name of R. Eleazar stated: If a man betrothed a woman by a loan[^fn_74a_42] and then had intercourse with her, or on a certain condition[^fn_74a_43] and then had intercourse with her, or with less than the value of a *perutah*[^fn_74a_44] and then had intercourse with her, she,[^fn_74a_45] it is the opinion of all, requires from him a letter of divorce.[^fn_74a_46]

R. Joseph b. Abba, in the name of R. Menahem in the name of R. Ammi stated: If a man betrothed a woman with something worth less than a *perutah* and then had intercourse with her, she[^fn_74a_45] requires a letter of divorce from him.[^fn_74a_46] It is only in this case[^fn_74a_47] that no one could be mistaken,[^fn_74a_48] but in the case of the others[^fn_74a_49] a man may be mistaken.[^fn_74a_50]

R. Kahana stated in the name of 'Ulla: If a man betrothed a woman on a certain condition[^fn_74a_43] and then had intercourse with her, she[^fn_74a_45] requires a divorce from him.[^fn_74a_46] Such a case once occurred and the Sages could find no legal ground[^fn_74a_51] for releasing the woman without a letter of divorce. \[This is meant\] to exclude \[the ruling\] of the following Tanna. For Rab Judah stated in the name of Samuel in the name of R. Ishmael: And she be not seized[^fn_74a_52] \[only then[^fn_74a_53] is she\] forbidden;[^fn_74a_54] if, however, she was seized[^fn_74a_55] she is permitted.[^fn_74a_54] There is, however, another \[kind of woman\] who is permitted[^fn_74a_54] even though she was not seized.[^fn_74a_56] And who is she? A woman whose betrothal was a mistaken one[^fn_74a_57] and who may, even if her son sits riding on her shoulder, [pg 74b]

make a declaration of refusal[^fn_74b_1] \[against her husband\] and go away.[^fn_74b_2]

Our Rabbis taught: If she[^fn_74b_3] went to a Sage \[after her betrothal\] and he disallowed her vow her betrothal is valid. \[If one[^fn_74b_4] went\] to a physician who cured her, her betrothal is invalid. What is the difference between the act of the Sage and that of the physician?[^fn_74b_5] — A Sage annuls[^fn_74b_6] the vow retrospectively[^fn_74b_7] while a physician effects the cure only from that moment onwards.[^fn_74b_8] But was it not, however, taught, \[that if she[^fn_74b_9] went\] to a Sage and he disallowed her vow or to a physician and he cured her, her betrothal is invalid?[^fn_74b_10] — Rabbah[^fn_74b_11] replied: There is no contradiction. The former[^fn_74b_12] represents the view of R. Meir; the latter[^fn_74b_13] represents that of R. Eleazar. 'The former represents the view of R. Meir', who holds that a man does not mind[^fn_74b_14] his wife's being exposed to the publicity[^fn_74b_15] of a court of law.[^fn_74b_16] 'The latter represents that of R. Eleazar' who holds that no man wants his wife to be exposed to the publicity[^fn_74b_17] of a court of law.[^fn_74b_18] What is the source[^fn_74b_19] \[of these statements\]?[^fn_74b_20] — \[The following\] where we learned: If a man divorced his wife on account of a vow \[she had made\] he may not remarry her,[^fn_74b_21] nor may he remarry his wife \[if he divorced her\] on account of a had name.[^fn_74b_22] R. Judah ruled: In the case of a vow that was made in the presence of many people[^fn_74b_23] he may not remarry her,[^fn_74b_24] but if it was not made in the presence of many people he may remarry her.[^fn_74b_25] R. Meir ruled: In the case of a vow \[the disallowance of which\] necessitates the investigation of a Sage[^fn_74b_26] her husband may not remarry her,[^fn_74b_27] but if it does not require the investigation of a Sage[^fn_74b_28] he may remarry her.[^fn_74b_29] R. Eleazar said:[^fn_74b_30] The prohibition against \[remarriage where the disallowance of the vow\] required \[the investigation of a Sage\][^fn_74b_31] was ordained only on account \[of a vow\] which requires \[no such investigation\].[^fn_74b_32] (What is R. Judah's reason?[^fn_74b_33] Because it is written in Scripture, [pg 75a]

And the children of Israel smote them not, because the princes of the congregation had sworn unto them.[^fn_75a_1] And what is considered 'many'? R. Nahman b. Isaac said: Three \[men\]; \[for the expression of\] 'days'[^fn_75a_2] implies two \[days\] and 'many'[^fn_75a_2] three. R. Isaac replied: Ten; \[for the term\] congregation[^fn_75a_3] was applied to them.)[^fn_75a_4] \[Now\] 'R. Meir ruled: In the case of a vow \[the disallowance of which\] necessitates the investigation of a Sage he may not remarry her' \[and\] 'R. Eleazar said: The prohibition \[against remarriage where the disallowance of the vow\] required \[the investigation of a Sage\] was ordained only on account \[of a vow\] which required \[no such investigation\]'.[^fn_75a_5] on what principles do they[^fn_75a_6] differ? — R. Meir holds the view that 'a man does not mind his wife's being exposed to the publicity of a court of law' and R. Eleazar holds the view that 'no man wants his wife to be exposed to the publicity of a court of law'.[^fn_75a_7]

Raba replied:[^fn_75a_8] Here[^fn_75a_9] we are dealing with the case of a woman from a noted family in which case the man[^fn_75a_10] could say,[^fn_75a_11] 'I have no wish to be forbidden to marry her relatives'.[^fn_75a_12] If so,[^fn_75a_13] \[consider\] the final clause where it is stated, 'But if he[^fn_75a_14] went[^fn_75a_15] to a Sage who disallowed his vow or to a physician who cured him, his betrothal of the woman is valid', \[why, it may be asked, was it not\] stated, 'the betrothal is invalid' and[^fn_75a_16] explained,[^fn_75a_17] 'Here we are dealing with the case of a man from a noted family concerning whom the woman[^fn_75a_18] might plead. 'I have no wish to be forbidden to marry his relatives'?[^fn_75a_19] — A woman is satisfied with any sort \[of husband\] as Resh Lakish said. For Resh Lakish stated: 'It is preferable to live in grief[^fn_75a_20] than to dwell in widowhood'.[^fn_75a_21] Abaye said: With a husband \[of the size of an\] ant her seat is placed among the great.[^fn_75a_22] R. Papa said: Though her husband be a carder[^fn_75a_23] she calls him to the threshold and sits down \[at his side\].[^fn_75a_24] R. Ashi said: Even if her husband is only a cabbage-head[^fn_75a_25] she requires no lentils[^fn_75a_26] for her pot.[^fn_75a_27]

A Tanna taught: But all such women[^fn_75a_28] play the harlot and attribute the consequences[^fn_75a_29] to their husbands.

ALL DEFECTS WHICH DISQUALIFY etc. A Tanna taught: To these[^fn_75a_30] were added[^fn_75a_31] \[excessive\] perspiration, a mole and offensive breath.[^fn_75a_32] Do these, then, not cause a disqualification in respect of priests? Surely we have learned,[^fn_75a_33] 'The old, the sick and the filthy'[^fn_75a_34] and we have also learned, 'These defects whether permanent or transitory, render human beings[^fn_75a_35] unfit \[for the Temple service\]![^fn_75a_36] — R. Jose b. Hanina replied: This is no contradiction. The former refers to perspiration that can be removed;[^fn_75a_37] the latter, to perspiration that cannot be removed.[^fn_75a_38]

R. Ashi said \[in reply\]: You are pointing out a contradiction between 'perspiration' and 'one who is filthy' \[which in fact are not alike, for\] there, in the case of priests,[^fn_75a_39] it is possible to remove the perspiration[^fn_75a_40] by the aid of sour wine, and it is also possible \[to remove\] an offensive breath by holding pepper in one's mouth and thus performing the Temple service, but in the case of a wife[^fn_75a_41] \[such devices are for all practical purposes\] impossible.[^fn_75a_42]

What kind of a mole is here meant? If one overgrown with hair, it would cause disqualification in both cases; if one with no hair, \[then, again\], if it is a large one it causes disqualification in both cases[^fn_75a_43] and if it is a small one it causes no disqualification in either; for it was taught: A mole which is overgrown with hair is regarded as a bodily defect; if with no hair it is only deemed to be a bodily defect when large but when small it is no defect; and what is meant by large? R. Simeon b. Gamaliel explained: The size of an Italian issar![^fn_75a_44] — R. Jose the son of R. Hanina said: One which is situated on her forehead.[^fn_75a_45] \[If it was on\] her forehead he[^fn_75a_46] must have seen it and acquiesced![^fn_75a_47] — R. Papa replied: It is one that was situated under her bonnet and is sometimes exposed and sometimes not.

R. Hisda said: I heard the following statement from a great man (And who is he? R. Shila). If a dog bit her[^fn_75a_48] and the spot of the bite turned into a scar \[such a scar\] is considered a bodily defect.

R. Hisda further stated: A harsh voice in a woman is a bodily defect; since it is said in Scripture, For sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely.[^fn_75a_49]

R. Nathan of Bira learnt: \[The space\] of one handbreadth between a woman's breasts.[^fn_75a_50] R. Aha the son of Raba intended to explain in the presence of R. Ashi \[that this statement meant that '\[the space of\] a handbreadth' is to \[a woman's\] advantage,[^fn_75a_51] but R. Ashi said to him: This[^fn_75a_52] was taught in connection with bodily defects. And what space \[is deemed normal\]? Abaye replied: \[A space of\] three fingers.

It was taught: R. Nathan said, It is a bodily defect if a woman's breasts are bigger than those of others. By how much? — R. Meyasha the grandson of R. Joshua b. Levi replied in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi: By one handbreadth. Is such a deformity, however, possible?[^fn_75a_53] — Yes; for Rabbah b. Bar Hana related, I saw an Arab woman who flung her breasts over her back and nursed her child.

But[^fn_75a_54] of Zion it shall be said: 'This man and that[^fn_75a_55] was born in her; and the Most High Himself doth establish her;[^fn_75a_56] R. Meyasha, grandson of R. Joshua b. Levi, explained: Both[^fn_75a_57] he who was born therein and he who looks forward to seeing it.[^fn_75a_58]

Said Abaye: And one of them[^fn_75a_59] is as good as two of us.[^fn_75a_60] Said Raba: When one of us, however, goes up there[^fn_75a_61] he is as good as two of them. For \[you have the case of\] R. Jeremiah who, while here,[^fn_75a_62] did not understand what the Rabbis were saying, but when he went up there he was able to refer to us as 'The stupid Babylonians'.[^fn_75a_63]

***MISHNAH***. IF SHE[^fn_75a_64] WAS AFFLICTED WITH BODILY DEFECTS WHILE SHE WAS STILL IN HER FATHER'S HOUSE,[^fn_75a_65] HER FATHER[^fn_75a_66] MUST PRODUCE PROOF THAT THESE DEFECTS AROSE AFTER SHE HAD BEEN BETROTHED AND \[THAT, CONSEQUENTLY, IT WAS THE\] HUSBAND'S FIELD THAT WAS INUNDATED.[^fn_75a_67] IF SHE CAME UNDER THE AUTHORITY OF HER HUSBAND,[^fn_75a_68] THE HUSBAND[^fn_75a_69] MUST PRODUCE PROOF THAT THESE DEFECTS WERE UPON HER BEFORE SHE HAD BEEN BETROTHED AND \[THAT CONSEQUENTLY\] HIS BARGAIN WAS MADE IN ERROR. THIS IS THE RULING OF R. MEIR. THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: THIS[^fn_75a_70] APPLIES ONLY TO CONCEALED BODILY DEFECTS; [pg 75b] {¶=7.5}

BUT IN RESPECT OF DEFECTS THAT ARE EXPOSED HE[^fn_75b_1] CANNOT ADVANCE ANY VALID PLEA.[^fn_75b_2] AND IF THERE WAS A BATH-HOUSE IN THE TOWN HE CANNOT ADVANCE ANY VALID PLEA[^fn_75b_2] EVEN AGAINST CONCEALED BODILY DEFECTS, BECAUSE HE \[IS ASSUMED TO HAVE HAD HER\] EXAMINED BY HIS WOMEN RELATIVES.[^fn_75b_3]

***GEMARA***. The reason then[^fn_75b_4] is because the father produced proof, but if he produced no proof,[^fn_75b_5] the husband is believed.[^fn_75b_6] Whose \[view consequently is here[^fn_75b_7] expressed\]? \[Obviously\] that of R. Joshua who stated, 'Our life is not dependent on her statement'.[^fn_75b_8] Now read the final clause: IF SHE CAME UNDER THE AUTHORITY OF THE HUSBAND, THE HUSBAND MUST PRODUCE PROOF, the reason then[^fn_75b_9] is because the husband produced proof, but if he produced no proof,[^fn_75b_10] the father is believed,[^fn_75b_11] a ruling which expresses the view of R. Gamaliel who stated that the woman is believed![^fn_75b_12] — R. Eleazar replied: The contradiction[^fn_75b_13] \[is evident\]; he who taught the one did not teach the other.[^fn_75b_14]

Raba said: It must not be assumed that R. Joshua[^fn_75b_15] is never guided by the principle of the presumptive soundness of the body, for the fact is[^fn_75b_16] that R. Joshua is not guided by that principle only where it is opposed by the principle of possession.[^fn_75b_17] Where, however, the principle of possession is not applicable R. Joshua is guided by that of the soundness of the body; for it was taught: If the bright spot[^fn_75b_18] preceded the white hair, he[^fn_75b_19] is unclean; if the reverse, he is clean. \[If the order is in\] doubt, he is unclean; but R. Joshua said: It darkened.[^fn_75b_20] What is meant by 'It darkened'? Rabbah replied: \[It is as though the spot\] darkened[^fn_75b_21] \[and, therefore,\] he is clean.[^fn_75b_22]

Raba explained:[^fn_75b_23] The first clause \[is a case of\] 'Here[^fn_75b_24] they[^fn_75b_25] were found and here they must have arisen'[^fn_75b_26] and so is the final clause: Here[^fn_75b_27] they[^fn_75b_28] were found and here they must have arisen.[^fn_75b_29] Abaye raised an objection against him:[^fn_75b_30] IF SHE CAME UNDER THE AUTHORITY OF THE HUSBAND, THE HUSBAND MUST PRODUCE PROOF THAT THESE DEFECTS WERE UPON HER BEFORE SHE HAD BEEN BETROTHED[^fn_75b_31] AND \[THAT, CONSEQUENTLY,\] HIS BARGAIN WAS MADE IN ERROR; \[Thus only if she had the defects\] BEFORE SHE HAD BEEN BETROTHED \[is the husband's plea\] accepted,[^fn_75b_32] \[but if they were seen upon her\] only after she had been betrothed[^fn_75b_33] \[his plea would\] not \[be accepted\]. But why? Let it be said,[^fn_75b_34] 'Here they were found and here they must have arisen'![^fn_75b_35] — The other[^fn_75b_30] replied: \[The principle[^fn_75b_36] cannot be applied if the defects were discovered\] after she had been betrothed because it may be taken for granted that no man drinks out of a cup[^fn_75b_37] unless he has first examined it; and this man[^fn_75b_38] must consequently have seen \[the defects\] and acquiesced.[^fn_75b_39] If so,[^fn_75b_40] \[the same principle should apply\] also to one \[who had defects\] prior to her betrothal. \[Since,\] however, \[it is not applied\], the presumption must be that no man is reconciled to bodily defects, \[why then is it not presumed\] here[^fn_75b_41] also that no man is reconciled to bodily defects? — This, however, is the explanation: \[The principle[^fn_75b_36] cannot be applied to defects discovered\] after she had been betrothed because two \[principles\] are \[opposed to it:\] The presumptive soundness of the woman's body[^fn_75b_42] and the presumption that no man drinks out of a cup unless he has first examined it and that this man must, consequently, have seen \[the defects\] and acquiesced. What possible objection can you raise?[^fn_75b_43] Is it the presumption that no man is reconciled to bodily defects? \[But this\] is only [pg 76a]

one principle[^fn_76a_1] against two principles,[^fn_76a_2] and one against two cannot be upheld.[^fn_76a_3] \[But where the defects were discovered\] before betrothal, the principle of the presumptive soundness of her body cannot be applied,[^fn_76a_4] and all that remains is[^fn_76a_5] the presumption that no man drinks out of a cup unless he has first examined it and that this man must consequently have seen \[the defects\] and acquiesced, \[but to this it can be retorted:\] On the contrary, the presumption is that no man is reconciled to bodily defects, and consequently the money is to remain in the possession of its holder.[^fn_76a_6]

R. Ashi explained:[^fn_76a_7] The \[claim in the\] first clause[^fn_76a_8] \[is analogous to the claim\] 'You owe my father a maneh',[^fn_76a_9] but that in the final clause[^fn_76a_10] \[is analogous to the claim\] 'You owe me a maneh'.[^fn_76a_11]

R. Aha the son of R. Awya raised an objection against R. Ashi: R. Meir[^fn_76a_12] admits that in respect of bodily defects[^fn_76a_13] likely to have come[^fn_76a_14] with her from her father's house it is the father who must produce the proof.[^fn_76a_15] But why?[^fn_76a_16] Is \[not this[^fn_76a_17] analogous to the claim,\] 'You owe me a maneh'?[^fn_76a_18] — Here[^fn_76a_15] we are dealing with the case of a woman who had a superfluous limb.[^fn_76a_19] \[But if\] she had a superfluous limb[^fn_76a_20] what proof could be brought?[^fn_76a_21] — Proof that the man has seen it[^fn_76a_22] and acquiesced.

Rab Judah stated in the name of Samuel: If a man exchanged a cow for \[another man's\] ass, and the owner of the ass pulled[^fn_76a_23] the cow[^fn_76a_24] but the owner of the cow did not manage to pull[^fn_76a_25] the ass before the ass died, it is for the owner of the ass to produce proof that his ass was alive at the time the cow was pulled.[^fn_76a_26] And the Tanna \[of our Mishnah who taught about\] a bride[^fn_76a_27] supports this ruling. Which \[ruling concerning the\] bride?[^fn_76a_28] If it be suggested: [pg 76b]

The one concerning a bride IN HER FATHER'S HOUSE,[^fn_76b_1] are the two cases \[it may be objected\] alike? There it is the father[^fn_76b_2] who produces the proof and receives[^fn_76b_3] \[the *kethubah* from the husband\][^fn_76b_4] while here it is the owner of the ass[^fn_76b_5] who produces the proof and retains \[the cow\],[^fn_76b_6] — R. Abba replied: \[The ruling concerning a\] bride in her father-in-law's house.[^fn_76b_7] But \[the two cases\] are still unlike, for there it is the husband who produces the proof[^fn_76b_8] and thereby impairs the presumptive right of the father,[^fn_76b_9] while here it is the owner of the ass who produces the proof[^fn_76b_10] and thereby confirms his presumptive right![^fn_76b_11] — R. Nahman b. Isaac replied: \[The support is derived from the case of the\] bride IN HER FATHER'S HOUSE in respect of her token of betrothal.[^fn_76b_12] And, furthermore, it need not be said \[that this[^fn_76b_13] applies only\] in accordance with him who holds \[that a token of\] betrothal is not unreturnable[^fn_76b_14] but \[it holds good\] even according to him who maintains \[that a token of\] betrothal is unreturnable, since his ruling relates only to certain betrothal, but \[not\] to doubtful betrothal \[where the father may retain the token\] only[^fn_76b_15] if he produces proof but not otherwise.[^fn_76b_16]

An objection was raised: If a needle was found in the thick walls of the second stomach \[of a ritually killed beast, and it protrudes only\] from one of its sides,[^fn_76b_17] the beast is fit \[for human consumption,[^fn_76b_18] but if it protruded\] from both sides, the beast is unfit for human consumption.[^fn_76b_19] If a drop of blood was found on \[the needle\] it is certain that \[the wound was inflicted\] before the ritual killing;[^fn_76b_20] if no drop of blood was found on it, it is certain that \[the wound was made\] after the killing.[^fn_76b_21] If the top[^fn_76b_22] of the wound was covered with a crust, it is certain that \[the wounding occurred\] three days prior to the killing;[^fn_76b_23] if the top[^fn_76b_22] of the wound was not covered with a crust,[^fn_76b_24] it is for the claimant to produce the proof.[^fn_76b_25] Now if the butcher[^fn_76b_26] had already paid the price he[^fn_76b_27] would have to produce the required proof and so obtain the refund \[of his money\]; but why? Let the owner of the beast rather produce the proof and retain \[the purchase money\]![^fn_76b_28] — \[This is a case\] where the butcher[^fn_76b_26] has not yet paid the price.[^fn_76b_29] But how can such an absolute assertion[^fn_76b_30] be made?[^fn_76b_31] — \[This\] however, \[will dispose of the difficulty:\] For when Rami b. Ezekiel came he said, 'Pay no regard to those rules which my brother Judah laid down in the name of Samuel; for thus said Samuel: He in whose domain the doubt first arose[^fn_76b_32] must produce the proof; and the Tanna \[of our Mishnah who taught about\] the bride[^fn_76b_33] provides support for this ruling.[^fn_76b_34]

An objection was raised: If a needle was found in the thick walls of the second stomach etc.[^fn_76b_35] Now,[^fn_76b_36] if the butcher[^fn_76b_26] has not yet paid the purchase price it would be the owner of the beast[^fn_76b_36] who would have to produce the proof and so obtain \[its price\] from \[the butcher\]; but why? \[Has not\] the doubt arisen \[when the beast was already\] in the possession of the butcher?[^fn_76b_37] — \[This is a case\] where the butcher has already paid the price.[^fn_76b_38] But how can such a categorical statement[^fn_76b_39] be made?[^fn_76b_40] — It is the usual practice that so long as one man does not pay the price the other does not give his beast.

THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: THIS APPLIES ONLY TO CONCEALED BODILY DEFECTS. R. Nahman stated: [pg 78a]

## CHAPTER VIII

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN CAME INTO THE POSSESSION[^fn_78a_1] OF PROPERTY BEFORE SHE WAS BETROTHED, BETH SHAMMAI AND BETH HILLEL AGREE THAT SHE MAY[^fn_78a_2] SELL IT OR GIVE IT AWAY AND HER ACT IS LEGALLY VALID. IF SHE CAME INTO THE POSSESSION OF THE PROPERTY AFTER SHE WAS BETROTHED, BETH SHAMMAI SAID: SHE MAY SELL IT,[^fn_78a_2] AND BETH HILLEL SAID: SHE MAY NOT SELL IT;[^fn_78a_2] BUT BOTH AGREE THAT IF SHE HAD SOLD IT OR GIVEN IT AWAY HER ACT IS LEGALLY VALID. R. JUDAH STATED: THE SAGES ARGUED BEFORE R. GAMALIEL, 'SINCE THE MAN[^fn_78a_3] GAINS POSSESSION OF THE WOMAN DOES HE NOT ALSO GAIN POSSESSION OF HER PROPERTY?'[^fn_78a_4] HE REPLIED, 'WE ARE EMBARRASSED[^fn_78a_5] WITH REGARD TO \[THE PROBLEM OF\] HER NEW POSSESSIONS[^fn_78a_6] AND DO YOU WISH TO INVOLVE US \[IN THE PROBLEM OF\] HER OLD ONES[^fn_78a_7] ALSO?' IF SHE CAME INTO THE POSSESSION OF PROPERTY AFTER SHE WAS MARRIED, BOTH[^fn_78a_8] AGREE THAT, EVEN IF SHE HAD SOLD IT OR GIVEN IT AWAY, THE HUSBAND MAY SEIZE IT FROM THE BUYERS. \[IF SHE CAME INTO POSSESSION\] BEFORE SHE MARRIED.[^fn_78a_9] AND SUBSEQUENTLY MARRIED, R. GAMALIEL SAID: IF SHE[^fn_78a_10] HAD SOLD IT OR GIVEN IT AWAY HER ACT IS LEGALLY VALID. R. HANINA B. AKABIA STATED: THEY ARGUED BEFORE R. GAMALIEL, SINCE THE MAN[^fn_78a_11] GAINED POSSESSION OF THE WOMAN SHOULD HE NOT ALSO GAIN POSSESSION OF HER PROPERTY?' HE REPLIED, 'WE ARE EMBARRASSED WITH REGARD TO \[THE PROBLEM OF\] HER NEW POSSESSIONS AND DO YOU WISH TO INVOLVE US \[IN THE PROBLEM OF\] HER OLD ONES ALSO?[^fn_78a_12] R. SIMEON DRAWS A DISTINCTION BETWEEN ONE KIND OF PROPERTY AND ANOTHER: PROPERTY THAT IS KNOWN[^fn_78a_13] TO THE HUSBAND \[THE WIFE\] MAY NOT SELL, AND IF SHE HAS SOLD IT OR GIVEN IT AWAY HER ACT IS VOID; \[PROPERTY, HOWEVER,\] WHICH IS UNKNOWN TO THE HUSBAND SHE MAY NOT SELL, BUT IF SHE HAS SOLD IT OR GIVEN IT AWAY HER ACT IS LEGALLY VALID. {¶=8.1}

***GEMARA***. What is the essential difference between the first clause[^fn_78a_14] in which they[^fn_78a_15] do not differ and the succeeding clause[^fn_78a_16] in which they differ?[^fn_78a_17] — The school of R. Jannai replied: In the first clause it was into her possession that the property had come;[^fn_78a_18] in the succeeding clause[^fn_78a_16] the property came into his possession.[^fn_78a_19] If, however, \[it is maintained\] that the property 'came into his possession' why is HER ACT LEGALLY VALID when SHE HAD SOLD \[THE PROPERTY\] OR GIVEN IT AWAY? — This then \[is the explanation:\] In the first clause the property has beyond all doubt come into her possession.[^fn_78a_18] In the succeeding clause, \[however, the property\] might be said \[to have come either\] into her, or into his possession;[^fn_78a_20] \[hence,\][^fn_78a_21] she may not properly sell \[the property, but\] IF SHE HAD SOLD IT OR GIVEN IT AWAY HER ACT IS LEGALLY VALID.

R. JUDAH STATED: \[THE SAGES\] ARGUED BEFORE R. GAMALIEL. The question was raised: Does R. Judah[^fn_78a_22] refer to the case of direct permissibility[^fn_78a_23] or also to one of ex post facto?[^fn_78a_24] [pg 78b]

Come and hear what was taught in the following. R. Judah stated: They argued before R. Gamaliel, 'Since the one woman[^fn_78b_1] is his wife and the other[^fn_78b_2] is his wife, just as a sale by the former[^fn_78b_3] is invalid so also should a sale by the latter[^fn_78b_4] be invalid'. He replied, 'We are in an embarrassed condition with regard to \[the problem of\] her new possessions and you wish to involve us \[in the problem of\] her old ones also?'[^fn_78b_5] Thus[^fn_78b_6] it may be inferred that he referred to a case of ex post facto also. This is conclusive.[^fn_78b_7]

It was taught: R. Hanina b. Akabia said, It was not such a reply[^fn_78b_8] that R. Gamaliel gave to the Sages,[^fn_78b_9] but it was this that he replied, '\[There is\] no \[comparison\]; if you say \[the ruling\][^fn_78b_10] is to apply to a married woman whose husband is entitled to her finds, to her handiwork and to the annulment of her vows, will you say it also applies to a betrothed woman whose husband is not entitled either to her finds or to her handiwork or to the annulment of her vows?'[^fn_78b_11] 'Master', they said to him, '\[this is quite feasible if\] she effected a sale before she married;[^fn_78b_12] what, \[however, will be your ruling where\] she was married and effected the sale[^fn_78b_13] subsequently?' — 'This woman also', he replied, 'may sell or give away, and her act is valid'. 'Since, however', they argued, 'he[^fn_78b_14] gained possession of the woman[^fn_78b_15] should he not also gain possession of her property?'[^fn_78b_16] — 'We are quite embarrassed', he replied, 'about \[the problem of\] her new possessions and you wish to involve us \[in the problem of\] her old ones[^fn_78b_17] also!' But, surely, we learned, \[IF SHE CAME INTO POSSESSION\] BEFORE SHE MARRIED, AND SUBSEQUENTLY MARRIED, R. GAMALIEL SAID: IF SHE HAD SOLD IT OR GAVE IT AWAY[^fn_78b_18] HER ACT IS LEGALLY VALID![^fn_78b_19] — R. Zebid replied, Read: She may sell or give away, and her act is valid.[^fn_78b_20] R. Papa replied: There is no difficulty,[^fn_78b_21] for one[^fn_78b_22] is the view of R. Judah on R. Gamaliel's opinion[^fn_78b_23] whilst the other[^fn_78b_24] is the view of R. Hanina b. Akabia on R. Gamaliel's opinion.[^fn_78b_25]

Is R. Hanina b. Akabia then in agreement with Beth Shammai?[^fn_78b_26] — It is this that he meant: Beth Shammai and Beth Hillel did not differ at all on this point.[^fn_78b_27]

Both Rab and Samuel stated: Whether a woman came into the possession of property before she was betrothed or whether she came into possession after she was betrothed her husband may, \[if she sold it\] after she married, take it away from the buyers. In agreement with whose view \[is this ruling\], which is neither in agreement with that of R. Judah nor with that of R. Hanina b. Akabia? — They adopted the ruling of our Masters; for it was taught: Our Masters took a recount \[of votes, and decided that\] whether a woman came into the possession \[of property\] before she was betrothed or whether she came into its possession after she was betrothed, her husband may, \[if she sold it\] after she married, take it away from the buyers.[^fn_78b_28]

AFTER SHE WAS MARRIED, BOTH AGREE. May it be suggested that here we are learning Of the enactment of Usha,[^fn_78b_29] for R. Jose the son of R. Hanina stated: It was enacted at Usha that if a woman sold during the lifetime of her husband *melog*[^fn_78b_30] property,[^fn_78b_31] and died, the husband[^fn_78b_32] may seize it from the buyers![^fn_78b_33] — Our Mishnah \[deals with the seizure\] during the woman's lifetime for the purposes of usufruct \[only\];[^fn_78b_34] the enactment of Usha \[refers to the seizure\] of the capital after her death.[^fn_78b_35]

R. SIMEON DRAWS A DISTINCTION BETWEEN ONE KIND OF PROPERTY \[etc.\]. Which kind is regarded as KNOWN, and which as UNKNOWN? — R. Jose the son of R. Hanina replied: KNOWN means landed property;[^fn_78b_36] UNKNOWN, movable property. But R. Johanan said: Both are regarded as KNOWN, but the following is classed as UNKNOWN. Whenever a woman lives in a certain place and comes into the possession of property in a country beyond the sea. So it was also taught elsewhere: The following is classed as unknown. Wherever a woman lives in a certain place and comes into the possession of property in a country beyond the sea.

A certain woman[^fn_78b_37] wishing to deprive her \[intended\] husband of her estate assigned it in writing to her daughter.[^fn_78b_38] After she married and was divorced[^fn_78b_39] [pg 79a]

she came before R. Nahman \[to claim the return of her estate\]. R. Nahman tore up the deed.[^fn_79a_1] R. Anan, thereupon, went to Mar 'Ukba[^fn_79a_2] and said to him, 'See, Master, how Nahman the boor[^fn_79a_3] tears up people's deeds'. 'Tell me', the other said to him, 'how exactly the incident occurred'. 'It occurred', he replied,' in such and such a manner'. 'Do you speak', the other exclaimed, 'of a deed a woman intended as a means of evasion?[^fn_79a_4] Thus said R. Hanilai b. Idi in the name of Samuel: I am an officially recognized judge,[^fn_79a_5] and should a deed which a woman intended as a means of evasion[^fn_79a_4] come into my hand I would tear it up.

Said Raba to R. Nahman:[^fn_79a_6] What in fact is the reason?[^fn_79a_7] \[Obviously\] because no man would neglect himself and give his property away to others. But this would apply to strangers only, whilst to a daughter one might well give![^fn_79a_8] — Even in the case of a daughter a woman gives preference to her own person.[^fn_79a_9]
