An objection was raised: If a woman desires to keep her property from her husband, how is she to proceed? She writes out[^fn_79a_10] a deed of trust[^fn_79a_11] to a stranger;[^fn_79a_12] so R. Simeon b. Gamaliel.[^fn_79a_13] But the Sages said: If he[^fn_79a_14] wishes he may laugh at her[^fn_79a_15] unless she wrote out for him: '\[You shall acquire possession\] from this day whenever I shall express[^fn_79a_16] my consent',[^fn_79a_17] The reason then[^fn_79a_18] is because she wrote out for him in the manner prescribed;[^fn_79a_19] but had she not done so, the \[fictitious\] buyer would have acquired \[would he not\] possession of it?[^fn_79a_20] — R. Zera replied: There is no difficulty. One ruling[^fn_79a_21] refers to \[a woman who has assigned to the stranger\] all her property;[^fn_79a_22] the other,[^fn_79a_23] to \[a woman who assigned to a stranger\] a part of her property. But if the buyer does not[^fn_79a_24] acquire her property[^fn_79a_25] the husband[^fn_79a_26] should acquire it![^fn_79a_27] — Abaye replied: It[^fn_79a_28] was treated as property WHICH IS UNKNOWN TO THE HUSBAND[^fn_79a_29] in accordance with the view of R. Simeon.[^fn_79a_30]

***MISHNAH***. \[IF A MARRIED WOMAN\] CAME INTO THE POSSESSION OF MONEY, LAND SHOULD BE BOUGHT THEREWITH AND THE HUSBAND IS ENTITLED TO THE USUFRUCT.[^fn_79a_31] \[IF SHE CAME INTO THE POSSESSION OF\] PRODUCE THAT WAS DETACHED FROM THE GROUND,[^fn_79a_32] LAND SHOULD BE BOUGHT THEREWITH AND THE HUSBAND IS ENTITLED TO THE USUFRUCT. \[IF IT WAS\] PRODUCE ATTACHED TO THE GROUND, THE LAND,[^fn_79a_33] R. MEIR RULED, IS TO BE VALUED AS TO HOW MUCH IT IS WORTH WITH THE PRODUCE[^fn_79a_34] AND HOW MUCH WITHOUT THE PRODUCE, AND WITH THE DIFFERENCE[^fn_79a_35] LAND SHOULD BE BOUGHT[^fn_79a_36] AND THE HUSBAND IS ENTITLED TO ITS USUFRUCT.[^fn_79a_37] THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: ALL PRODUCE ATTACHED TO THE GROUND BELONGS TO THE HUSBAND[^fn_79a_38] AND ONLY THAT WHICH IS DETACHED FROM IT[^fn_79a_39] BE LONGS TO THE WIFE; \[WITH THE PROCEEDS OF THE LATTER\] LAND IS TO BE BOUGHT AND THE HUSBAND IS ENTITLED TO THE USUFRUCT.[^fn_79a_40] {¶=8.2}

R. SIMEON SAID: IN RESPECT OF THAT[^fn_79a_41] WHEREIN THE HUSBAND IS AT AN ADVANTAGE WHEN HE MARRIES HIS WIFE[^fn_79a_42] HE IS AT A DISADVANTAGE WHEN HE DIVORCES HER[^fn_79a_43] AND IN RESPECT OF THAT WHEREIN HE IS AT A DISADVANTAGE WHEN HE MARRIES HER HE IS AT AN ADVANTAGE WHEN HE DIVORCES HER. HOW SO? PRODUCE WHICH IS ATTACHED TO THE GROUND IS THE HUSBAND'S WHEN HE MARRIES HIS WIFE[^fn_79a_44] AND HERS WHEN HE DIVORCES HER,[^fn_79a_45] WHILST PRODUCE THAT IS DETACHED FROM THE GROUND IS HERS WHEN SHE MARRIES[^fn_79a_46] BUT THE HUSBAND'S WHEN SHE IS DIVORCED.[^fn_79a_47]

***GEMARA***. It is obvious[^fn_79a_48] \[that if husband and wife differ on the choice of purchase between\] land and houses,[^fn_79a_49] land \[is to receive preference\].[^fn_79a_50] \[If they differ on the choice between\] houses and date-trees, houses \[are to receive preference\].[^fn_79a_51] \[If they insist respectively on\] date-trees and other fruit trees, date-trees \[are to receive preference\].[^fn_79a_51] \[If their dispute is on\] fruit trees and vines, fruit trees \[are to receive preference\].[^fn_79a_51] \[What, however, is the ruling if the husband desires to purchase\][^fn_79a_52] a thicket of sorb[^fn_79a_53] or a fish pond?[^fn_79a_54] — Some maintain that it is regarded as[^fn_79a_55] produce;[^fn_79a_56] and others maintain that it is regarded as[^fn_79a_57] capital.[^fn_79a_58] This is the general rule:[^fn_79a_59] If the stump grows new shoots[^fn_79a_60] it is regarded as capital,[^fn_79a_61] but if the stump grows no new shoots it is regarded as produce.[^fn_79a_62]

R. Zera stated in the name of R. Oshaia in the name of R. Jannai (others say, R. Abba stated in the name of R. Oshaia in the name of R. Jannai), If a man steals [pg 79b]

the young of a *melog*[^fn_79b_1] beast he must pay double[^fn_79b_2] its value to the woman.[^fn_79b_3] In accordance with whose \[view has this ruling[^fn_79b_4] been laid down\]? Is it in agreement with neither that of the Rabbis nor with that of Hananiah? For it was taught: The young of a *melog* beast belongs to the husband; the child of a *melog* bondwoman belongs to the wife; but Hananiah the son of Josiah's brother ruled, The child of a *melog* bondwoman has been given the same legal status as the young of a *melog* beast![^fn_79b_5] — It may be said to agree even with the opinion of all,[^fn_79b_6] for it is the produce alone that the Rabbis in their enactment have assigned to the husband but not the produce that accrues from this produce.[^fn_79b_7]

\[The view\] of Hananiah is quite logical on the assumption[^fn_79b_8] that death[^fn_79b_9] is not to be taken into consideration,[^fn_79b_10] but \[what principle is followed by\] the Rabbis? If they do take into consideration the possibility of death,[^fn_79b_11] even the young of a *melog* beast also should not \[belong to the husband\], and if they do not take the possibility of death into consideration,[^fn_79b_12] then even the child of a bondwoman also \[should belong to the husband\]![^fn_79b_13] — They do in fact take the possibility of death into consideration,[^fn_79b_11] but the case of the beast is different \[from that of a bondwoman\] since its skin remains.[^fn_79b_14]

R. Huna b. Hiyya stated in the name of Samuel: The *halachah* is in agreement with Hananiah. Said Raba in the name of R. Nahman: Although Samuel said, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with Hananiah', Hananiah admits that if the woman is divorced she may pay the price \[of the bondwoman's children\] and take them because \[they constitute\] the pride of her paternal house \[which she is entitled to retain\].[^fn_79b_15]

Raba stated in the name of R. Nahman: If a woman brought to her husband[^fn_79b_16] a goat for milking, a ewe for shearing, a hen for laying eggs, or a date-tree for producing fruit, he may go on eating \[the yield of any of these\][^fn_79b_17] until the capital is consumed.

R. Nahman stated: If a woman[^fn_79b_16] brought to her husband a cloak[^fn_79b_18] \[its use\] is \[to be regarded as\] produce and he may continue to use it as a covering until it is worn out.[^fn_79b_19]

In accordance with whose view \[has this statement[^fn_79b_20] been made\]? — In agreement with the following Tanna,[^fn_79b_21] for it has been taught: Salt or sand[^fn_79b_22] is regarded as produce;[^fn_79b_23] a sulphur quarry or an alum-mine[^fn_79b_24] is regarded, R. Meir said, as capital,[^fn_79b_25] but the Rabbis said, As produce.[^fn_79b_26]

R. SIMEON SAID: IN RESPECT OF THAT WHEREIN THE HUSBAND IS AT AN ADVANTAGE. \[Is not this view of\] R. Simeon identical \[with that of\] the first Tanna?[^fn_79b_27] — Raba replied: The difference between them is \[the case of produce that was\] attached at the time of the divorce.[^fn_79b_28]

***MISHNAH***. IF AGED BONDMEN OR BONDWOMEN FELL TO HER[^fn_79b_29] \[AS AN INHERITANCE\] THEY MUST BE SOLD, AND LAND PURCHASED WITH THE PROCEEDS, AND THE HUSBAND CAN ENJOY THE USUFRUCT THEREOF. R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL SAID; SHE NEED NOT SELL THEM,[^fn_79b_30] BECAUSE THEY ARE THE PRIDE OF HER PATERNAL HOUSE.[^fn_79b_31] IF SHE CAME INTO THE POSSESSION OF OLD OLIVE-TREES OR VINES THEY MUST BE SOLD,[^fn_79b_32] AND LAND PURCHASED WITH THE PROCEEDS, AND THE HUSBAND CAN ENJOY THE USUFRUCT THEREOF. R. JUDAH SAID: SHE NEED NOT SELL THEM, BECAUSE THEY ARE THE PRIDE OF HER PATERNAL HOUSE.[^fn_79b_31] {¶=8.3}

***GEMARA***. R. Kahana stated in the name of Rab: They[^fn_79b_33] differ only where \[the olive-trees or vines\] fell \[to the woman\] in her own field,[^fn_79b_34] but \[if they were\] in a field that did not belong to her[^fn_79b_35] she must, according to the opinion of all, sell them;[^fn_79b_36] because \[otherwise\] the capital[^fn_79b_37] would be destroyed.[^fn_79b_38] To this R. Joseph demurred: Are not BONDMEN OR BONDWOMEN[^fn_79b_39] the same as \[trees in\] a field that does not belong to her[^fn_79b_40] and there is nevertheless a dispute?[^fn_79b_41] — The fact is, if the statement[^fn_79b_42] has at all been made it must have been made in the following terms: R. Kahana stated in the name of Rab, They[^fn_79b_43] differ only where \[the olive-trees and vines\] fell \[to the woman\] in a field that did not belong to her[^fn_79b_44] but \[if they were\] in her own field[^fn_79b_45] it is the opinion of all that she need not sell them because \[she is entitled to retain\] the pride of her paternal house.

***MISHNAH***. HE WHO INCURRED EXPENDITURE IN CONNECTION WITH HIS WIFE'S \[*MELOG*\][^fn_79b_46] PROPERTY, WHETHER HE SPENT MUCH AND CONSUMED[^fn_79b_47] LITTLE, \[OR SPENT\] LITTLE AND CONSUMED MUCH, WHAT HE HAS SPENT HE HAS SPENT, AND WHAT HE HAS CONSUMED HE HAS CONSUMED.[^fn_79b_48] IF HE SPENT BUT DID NOT CONSUME HE MAY TAKE AN OATH AS TO HOW MUCH HE HAS SPENT AND RECEIVE COMPENSATION. {¶=8.4}

***GEMARA***. How much is considered LITTLE? — R. Assi replied: Even one dried fig; but this applies only where he ate it in a dignified manner.[^fn_79b_49] Said [pg 80a]

R. Abba: At the school of Rab it was stated, Even the refuse[^fn_80a_1] of dates.[^fn_80a_2]

R. Bibi enquired: What \[is the ruling in respect of\] a mash of pressed dates?[^fn_80a_3] — This stands undecided.[^fn_80a_4]

What \[is the ruling if\] he did not eat it[^fn_80a_5] in a dignified manner?[^fn_80a_6] 'Ulla replied: On this there is a difference of opinion between two Amoraim in the West.[^fn_80a_7] One says, The value of an issar;[^fn_80a_8] and the other says, The value of a *denar*.[^fn_80a_8]

The judges of Pumbeditha[^fn_80a_9] stated: Rab Judah gave a practical decision[^fn_80a_10] in \[a case where the husband used up some\] bundles of vine-shoots,[^fn_80a_11] Rab Judah acting here in accordance with his own principle; for Rab Judah ruled: If he[^fn_80a_12] ate thereof \[during one of the three years\] only 'uncircumcised'[^fn_80a_13] produce,[^fn_80a_14] \[the produce of\] the Sabbatical year,[^fn_80a_15] or the produce of mingled seed,[^fn_80a_16] this counts \[towards the three years of\] *hazakah*.[^fn_80a_17]

R. Jacob stated in the name of R. Hisda: If a man has incurred expenses on the *melog* property of his wife who was a minor[^fn_80a_18] \[he is in the same legal position\] as one who incurred expenses on the property of a stranger.[^fn_80a_19] What is the reason? — The Rabbis have enacted this measure[^fn_80a_20] in order that he should not allow her property to deteriorate.[^fn_80a_21]

A woman once came into the possession of four hundred *zuz*[^fn_80a_22] at Be-Hozae.[^fn_80a_23] Her husband went thither, spent six hundred \[on his journey\] and brought with him the four hundred. While he was on his way back he required one *zuz* and took it out of these. When he came before R. Ammi[^fn_80a_24] the latter ruled: What he has spent he has spent and what he used he has used.[^fn_80a_25] Said the Rabbis to R. Ammi: Does not this[^fn_80a_26] apply only where he consumes the produce, whilst here he used up the capital which \[constituted a part of\] the expenditure? — If so, he replied,[^fn_80a_27] he is one who SPENT BUT DID NOT CONSUME, then HE MAY TAKE AN OATH AS TO HOW MUCH HE HAS SPENT AND RECEIVE HIS COMPENSATION.

HE MAY TAKE AN OATH AS TO HOW MUCH HE HAS SPENT AND RECEIVE COMPENSATION. Said R. Assi: This applies only where the appreciation corresponds to the expenditure. What exactly is the object of this[^fn_80a_28] law?[^fn_80a_29] — Abaye replied: That if the appreciation exceeded the expenditure be receives the sum of his outlay without an oath. Said Raba to him: If so,[^fn_80a_30] one might be induced to act cunningly![^fn_80a_31] — \[The object of the law\] however, said Raba, was that if the outlay exceeded the appreciation he is only entitled to receive that amount of his outlay which corresponds to the appreciations and \[even this can be obtained only\] by an oath.[^fn_80a_32]

The question was raised: What is the legal position where a husband has sent down[^fn_80a_33] arisin[^fn_80a_34] in his place?[^fn_80a_35] Does \[an *aris*\] go down \[into *melog* fields\] in his reliance on the rights of the husband, \[and, consequently,\] when the husband forfeits his claim[^fn_80a_36] they also[^fn_80a_37] lose theirs, or does an *aris* possibly go down \[into the *melog* fields\] in his reliance on the \[yield of\] the land, and land, surely is usually entrusted to arisin?[^fn_80a_38] To this Raba son of R. Hanan demurred: Wherein does this case essentially differ from that of a man who went down into a neighbour's field and planted it without the owner's authority where an assessment[^fn_80a_39] is made and he is at a disadvantage?[^fn_80a_40] — In that case[^fn_80a_41] there was no other person to take the trouble;[^fn_80a_42] but here there is the husband who should have taken the trouble.[^fn_80a_43] What then is the decision on the matter? — R. Huna the son of R. Joshua replied: We must observe \[the conditions of each case\]: If the husband is an *aris*,[^fn_80a_44] the arisin lose all claim to compensation wherever the husband loses his claim;[^fn_80a_45] if the husband is not an *aris* \[they are entitled to compensation, since\] all land is usually entrusted to arisin.[^fn_80a_46]

The question was raised: What is the ruling where a husband sold \[his wife's *melog*\] land for usufruct?[^fn_80a_47] Do we say that whatever he possesses[^fn_80a_48] he may transfer to others, or is it possible that the Rabbis have by their enactment granted the usufruct to the husband only [pg 80b]

in order to provide for the comfort of his home but not so that he should sell it? — Judah Mar b. Meremar replied in the name of Raba: Whatever he has done is done. R. Papi[^fn_80b_1] in the name of Raba replied: His act has no validity. Said R. Papa: The ruling reported[^fn_80b_2] by Judah Mar b. Meremar was not explicitly stated[^fn_80b_3] but was arrived at by inference. For a woman once brought to her husband[^fn_80b_4] two bondwomen,[^fn_80b_5] and the man went and married another wife and assigned to her one of them. \[When the first wife\] came before Raba and cried, he disregarded her. One who observed \[the incident\] formed the opinion \[that Raba's inaction\] was due to his view that whatever the husband did[^fn_80b_6] is valid;[^fn_80b_7] but in fact, it is not so.[^fn_80b_8] \[Usufruct has been allowed to a husband\] in order to provide for the comfort of his house and here, Surely, comfort was provided.[^fn_80b_9]

And the law is that if a husband sold \[his wife's *melog*\] field for its usufruct[^fn_80b_10] his act has no legal validity. What is the reason? Abaye replied: Provision must be made against the possible deterioration of the land.[^fn_80b_11] Raba explained: In order \[to safeguard\] the comfort of his house.[^fn_80b_12] What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_80b_13] — The practical difference between them is the case of land that was adjoining a town;[^fn_80b_14] or else where the husband \[himself\] was \[acting as\] *aris*,[^fn_80b_15] or else where \[the husband\] receives money[^fn_80b_16] and trades therewith.[^fn_80b_17]

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN AWAITING THE DECISION OF THE LEVIR[^fn_80b_18] CAME[^fn_80b_19] INTO THE POSSESSION OF PROPERTY, BETH SHAMMAI AND BETH HILLEL AGREE THAT SHE MAY SELL IT OR GIVE IT AWAY, AND THAT HER ACT IS LEGALLY VALID.[^fn_80b_20] IF SHE DIED, WHAT SHALL BE DONE WITH HER *KETHUBAH*[^fn_80b_21] AND WITH THE PROPERTY THAT COMES IN AND GOES OUT WITH HER?[^fn_80b_22] BETH SHAMMAI RULED: THE HEIRS OF HER HUSBAND[^fn_80b_23] ARE TO SHARE IT[^fn_80b_24] WITH THE HEIRS OF HER FATHER;[^fn_80b_25] AND BETH HILLEL RULED: THE \[ZON BARZEL\][^fn_80b_26] PROPERTY IS TO REMAIN WITH THOSE IN WHOSE POSSESSION IT IS,[^fn_80b_27] THE *KETHUBAH*[^fn_80b_28] IS TO REMAIN IN THE POSSESSION OF THE HEIRS OF THE HUSBAND, AND THE PROPERTY WHICH GOES IN AND COMES OUT WITH HER[^fn_80b_29] REMAINS IN THE POSSESSION OF THE HEIRS OF HER FATHER. {¶=8.5}

IF HIS[^fn_80b_30] BROTHER[^fn_80b_31] LEFT MONEY, LAND SHALL BE BOUGHT THEREWITH AND HE[^fn_80b_32] SHALL ENJOY ITS USUFRUCT.[^fn_80b_33] \[IF THE DECEASED LEFT\] PRODUCE THAT WAS DETACHED FROM THE GROUND, LAND SHALL BE BOUGHT \[OUT OF THE PROCEEDS\] AND HE[^fn_80b_32] SHALL ENJOY ITS USUFRUCT. \[IF IT WAS STILL\] ATTACHED TO THE GROUND, THE LAND[^fn_80b_34] IS TO BE ASSESSED, SAID R. MEIR, AS TO HOW MUCH IT IS WORTH[^fn_80b_35] TOGETHER WITH THE PRODUCE AND HOW MUCH IT IS WORTH WITHOUT THE PRODUCE, AND WITH THE DIFFERENCE LAND SHALL BE BOUGHT,[^fn_80b_36] AND HE[^fn_80b_37] SHALL ENJOY ITS USUFRUCT. THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: PRODUCE WHICH IS \[STILL\] ATTACHED TO THE GROUND BELONGS TO HIM,[^fn_80b_38] BUT THAT WHICH IS DETACHED FROM THE GROUND PASSES INTO THE OWNERSHIP OF HIM WHO SEIZES IT FIRST.[^fn_80b_39] IF HE \[SEIZED IT\] FIRST HE ACQUIRES OWNERSHIP; AND IF SHE \[SEIZED IT\] FIRST LAND SHALL BE BOUGHT THEREWITH AND HE[^fn_80b_37] SHALL ENJOY ITS USUFRUCT. IF \[THE LEVIR\] MARRIED HER SHE IS REGARDED AS HIS WIFE IN ALL RESPECTS[^fn_80b_38] SAVE THAT HER *KETHUBAH* REMAINS A CHARGE ON HER FIRST HUSBAND'S ESTATE. HE CANNOT SAY TO HER, 'BEHOLD YOUR *KETHUBAH* LIES ON THE TABLE', BUT ALL HIS PROPERTY[^fn_80b_40] IS PLEDGED TO HER *KETHUBAH*.[^fn_80b_41] SO, TOO, A MAN MAY NOT SAY TO HIS WIFE, BEHOLD YOUR *KETHUBAH* LIES ON THE TABLE, BUT ALL HIS PROPERTY IS PLEDGED TO HER *KETHUBAH*. IF HE DIVORCED HER[^fn_80b_42] SHE IS ENTITLED ONLY TO HER *KETHUBAH*.[^fn_80b_43] IF HE SUBSEQUENTLY REMARRIED HER SHE IS \[TO ENJOY THE SAME RIGHTS AS\] ALL OTHER WIVES, AND IS ENTITLED ONLY TO HER *KETHUBAH*.[^fn_80b_38]

***GEMARA***. The question was raised: If a woman awaiting the decision of a levir[^fn_80b_44] died, who is to bury her? Are her husband's heirs to bury her because they inherit her *kethubah*[^fn_80b_45] or is it possibly the heirs of her father who must bury her because they inherit the property that comes in and goes out with her? — R. Amram replied, Come and hear what was taught: If a woman awaiting the decision of a levir died, [pg 81a]

it is the duty of her heirs, even those who inherit her *kethubah*, to bury her. Said Abaye, We also have learned a \[similar Mishnah\]: A widow is to be maintained out of the estate of \[her deceased husband's\] orphans, and her handiwork belongs to them. It is not their duty, however, to bury her; it is the duty of her heirs, even those who inherit her *kethubah*, to bury her.[^fn_81a_1] Now, what widow is it that has two kinds of heirs?[^fn_81a_2] Obviously[^fn_81a_3] she who is awaiting the decision of a levir.[^fn_81a_4]

Said Raba: But could[^fn_81a_5] he not plead, 'I am only heir to my brother; it is not my duty to bury his wife'![^fn_81a_6] — Abaye replied: \[Such a plea would be untenable\] because he is approached by two alternative demands:[^fn_81a_7] If he is heir to his brother he should bury his wife;[^fn_81a_8] if he does not bury his wife he should return her *kethubah*.[^fn_81a_9] \[Raba\] retorted, it is this that I mean: \[Might he not plead\], 'I am only heir to my brother; it is not my duty to bury his wife; and if \[I am expected to bury her\] on account of the *kethubah*[^fn_81a_10] \[I may point out that\] a *kethubah* is not payable during \[the husband's\] lifetime'?[^fn_81a_11] — Who is it that was heard to admit the *kethubah* as a text for legal exposition?[^fn_81a_12] Beth Shammai, of course.[^fn_81a_13] But Beth Shammai have also been heard to lay down the rule that a note of indebtedness which is due for payment is regarded as repaid.[^fn_81a_14] For we have learned: If their husbands[^fn_81a_15] died before they drank,[^fn_81a_16] Beth Shammai rule that they are to receive their *kethubah* and that they need not drink,[^fn_81a_16] and Beth Hillel rule that they either drinks or they do not receive their *kethubah*.[^fn_81a_17] \[Now how could it be said,\] 'They either drink', when the All-Merciful said, Then shall the man bring his wife to the priest,[^fn_81a_18] and he is not there? \[The meaning must\] consequently be: As they do not drink[^fn_81a_19] they are not to receive their *kethubah*. Again 'Beth Shammai rule that they are to receive their *kethubah* and that they need not drink', but why \[should they receive their *kethubah*\]? Is not their claim of a doubtful nature,[^fn_81a_20] it being uncertain whether she had committed adultery or not;[^fn_81a_21] then how could an uncertainty[^fn_81a_22] override a certainty?[^fn_81a_23] Beth Shammai \[must consequently\] hold the view that 'a note of indebtedness that is due for payment is regarded as repaid'.[^fn_81a_24] But is it not required \[that the proviso\], 'When thou wilt be married to another man thou wilt receive what is prescribed for thee' \[be complied with\], which is not the case here?[^fn_81a_25] — R. Ashi replied: A levir is also regarded as 'another man'.[^fn_81a_26]

Raba addressed \[the following message\] to Abaye[^fn_81a_27] through R. Shemaya b. Zera: Is a *kethubah*[^fn_81a_28] indeed payable during \[the levir's\] lifetime? Has it not, in fact, been taught: R. Abba[^fn_81a_29] stated, 'I asked Symmachus, "How is a man[^fn_81a_30] who desires to sell his brother s property to proceed" \[and he replied,\] "If he is a priest,[^fn_81a_31] he should prepare a banquet[^fn_81a_32] and use persuasive means;[^fn_81a_33] if he is an Israelite[^fn_81a_34] he may divorce her and then marry her again".'[^fn_81a_35] [pg 81b]

Now if it could be assumed that a *kethubah* is payable during the lifetime \[of the levir\] why should he not set aside exclusively for her some property equal in value to the amount of the *kethubah*, and then sell the rest?[^fn_81b_1] 'But according to your argument[^fn_81b_2] \[it might be asked\] why should not the same objection[^fn_81b_3] be raised from our Mishnah \[where it was stated,\] HE CANNOT SAY TO HER, "BEHOLD YOUR *KETHUBAH* LIES ON THE TABLE", BUT ALL HIS PROPERTY IS PLEDGED FOR HER *KETHUBAH*?' — 'There[^fn_81b_4] we might merely have been given a piece of good advice;[^fn_81b_5] for, were you not to admit this, \[how would you\] read the final clause where it is stated, So, TOO, A MAN MUST NOT SAY TO HIS WIFE, "BEHOLD YOUR *KETHUBAH* LIES ON THE TABLE", BUT ALL HIS PROPERTY IS PLEDGED FOR HER *KETHUBAH*, would he here also \[it may be asked\] not be able to sell if he wished to do so?[^fn_81b_6] Consequently \[it must be agreed that\] he was there merely giving a piece of good advice;[^fn_81b_7] and similarly here also we might merely be given a piece of good advice;[^fn_81b_5] the statement of R. Abba, however, does present an objection!'[^fn_81b_8] — 'R. Abba's statement also does not give rise to any objection \[because the restrictions on the man's liberty to sell\] are due to \[the desire of avoiding\] hatred.'[^fn_81b_9]

A sister-in-law once fell to the lot of a man[^fn_81b_10] at Pumbeditha, and his \[younger\] brother wanted to cause her to be forbidden to marry him[^fn_81b_11] by \[forcing upon her\] a letter of divorce.[^fn_81b_12] 'What is it', \[the eldest brother\] said to him, 'that you have in your mind? \[Are you troubled\] because of the property[^fn_81b_13] \[that I all, to inherit\]?[^fn_81b_14] I will share the property with you'. R. Joseph \[in considering this case\] said: Since the Rabbis have laid down that he[^fn_81b_15] may not sell,[^fn_81b_16] his sale is invalid even if he had already sold it.[^fn_81b_17] For it was taught:[^fn_81b_18] If a man died[^fn_81b_19] and left a widow who was awaiting the decision of a levir[^fn_81b_20] and also left a bequest of property of the value of a hundred *maneh*,[^fn_81b_21] \[the levir\] must not sell the property although the widow's *kethubah* amounts only to one *maneh*, because all his property is pledged to her *kethubah*.[^fn_81b_22] Said Abaye to him:[^fn_81b_23] Is it so that wherever the Rabbis ruled that one must not sell, the sale is invalid, even after it had taken place? Did we not, in fact, learn: Beth Shammai said, She[^fn_81b_24] may sell it, and Beth Hillel said, She may not sell it; but both agree that if she had sold it or given it away her act is legally valid?[^fn_81b_25] The case was sent to R. Hanina b. Papi who sent \[the same reply\] as that of R. Joseph. On this Abaye remarked: Has R. Hanina b. Papi, forsooth, hung jewels[^fn_81b_26] upon it?[^fn_81b_27] It was then sent to R. Minyomi the son of R. Nihumai who sent \[the same reply\] as Abaye[^fn_81b_28] \[and added:\][^fn_81b_29] 'Should R. Joseph give a new reason report it to me. R. Joseph thereupon went out, investigated, and discovered that it was taught: If a man who had a monetary claim against his brother died,[^fn_81b_30] and left a widow who had to await the decision of a levir, \[the latter\][^fn_81b_31] is not entitled to plead, 'Since I am the heir I have acquired \[the amount of the debt\]', but it must be taken from the levir and spent on the purchase of land and he is only entitled to its usufruct.[^fn_81b_32] But 'is it not possible', said Abaye to him, 'that provision was made in his own interests?'[^fn_81b_33] — 'The Tanna stated', the other replied, 'that it must be "taken" from him,[^fn_81b_34] and you say that "provision was made in his own interests"'! The case was again sent to R. Minyomi the son of R. Nihumai who said to then: Thus said R. Joseph b. Minyomi in the name of R. Nahman, 'This[^fn_81b_35] is not an authentic teaching'.[^fn_81b_36] What is the reason?[^fn_81b_37] If it be Suggested, 'Because money is a movable thing and movables are not pledged to a kethubah',[^fn_81b_38] is it not possible \[it might be retorted\] that the statement represents the view of R. Meir who holds that movables are pledged to a *kethubah*?[^fn_81b_39] \[Should it be suggested,\] however,[^fn_81b_40] 'Because he[^fn_81b_41] could say to her: You are not the party I have to deal with',[^fn_81b_42] [pg 82a]

is it not possible \[it might be retorted\] that the statement represents the view of R. Nathan, since it was taught: R. Nathan stated, 'Whence is it deduced that if a man claims a *maneh*[^fn_82a_1] from another, and this one \[claims a similar sum\] from a third, the sum is to be collected from the last \[named\] and handed over to the first? From Scripture, which stated,[^fn_82a_2] And give unto him against whom he hath trespassed'?[^fn_82a_3] \[This\], however, \[is the reason:\][^fn_82a_4] We find nowhere a Tanna who imposes two restrictions[^fn_82a_5] in the matter of a *kethuboth*;[^fn_82a_6] we only find agreement either with R. Meir or with R. Nathan.[^fn_82a_7] Raba remarked: If so, I can well understand[^fn_82a_8] what Abaye meant when I heard him say, 'This is not an authentic teaching' and \[at the time\] I did not understand what \[his reason\] was.

A sister-in-law at Matha Mehasia[^fn_82a_9] once fell to the lot of a man[^fn_82a_10] whose \[younger\] brother wanted to cause her to be forbidden to marry him[^fn_82a_11] by \[forcing upon her\] a letter of divorce.[^fn_82a_12] 'What is it', \[the eldest brother\] said to him, 'that you have in your mind? If it is on account of the property[^fn_82a_13] \[that you are troubled\][^fn_82a_14] will share the estate with you'. 'I am afraid', the other replied, 'that you will treat me as the Pumbedithan rogue \[has treated his brother\]'.[^fn_82a_15] 'If you wish', the first said to him, 'take your half at once'.[^fn_82a_16] Said Mar son of R. Ashi: Although when R. Dimi came[^fn_82a_17] he stated in the name of R. Johanan, If a man said to another, 'Go and pull[^fn_82a_18] this cow, but it shall pass into your legal possession only after thirty days', he legally acquires it after thirty days,[^fn_82a_19] even if it stands at the time in the meadow,[^fn_82a_20] \[in this case the younger brother cannot acquire possession of the promised share\]; for there[^fn_82a_21] it was in his power \[to transfer possession at once\][^fn_82a_22] but here[^fn_82a_23] it is not in his power \[to transfer immediate possession\]. But, surely, when Rabin came[^fn_82a_24] he stated in the name of R. Johanan[^fn_82a_25] that 'he does not acquire possession'![^fn_82a_26] — This is no difficulty: One[^fn_82a_27] refers to a case where the seller said, 'Acquire possession[^fn_82a_28] from now';[^fn_82a_29] the other, where he did not say, 'Acquire from now'.

'Ulla was asked: What is the ruling where levirate marriage was consummated first and the division of the property[^fn_82a_30] took place afterwards?[^fn_82a_31] — The act[^fn_82a_32] is null and void[^fn_82a_33] \[he replied\]. What is the ruling \[he was asked\] if the division[^fn_82a_30] took place first and the levirate marriage afterwards?[^fn_82a_31] — The act[^fn_82a_32] \[he replied\] is null and void.[^fn_82a_33] R. Shesheth demurred: Now \[that it has been said that where\] levirate marriage took place first and the division[^fn_82a_30] afterwards the act[^fn_82a_32] is null and void, was it at all necessary \[to ask the question where\] the division took place first and the levirate marriage afterwards?[^fn_82a_34] — \[The respective enquiries related to\] two independent incidents that occurred \[at different times\].[^fn_82a_35]

When Rabin came[^fn_82a_24] he stated in the name of Resh Lakish: Whether levirate marriage was consummated first and the division took place afterwards, or whether the division took place first and the levirate marriage afterwards, the act is null and void. And \[in fact\] the law is that the act is null and void.

THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: WHAT IS STILL ATTACHED TO THE GROUND BELONGS TO HIM. But why? Is not all his[^fn_82a_36] landed estate[^fn_82a_37] a pledge and a guarantee for her *kethubah*? — Resh Lakish replied: Read, 'Belongs to her'.[^fn_82a_38]

IF \[THE LEVIR\] MARRIED HER SHE IS REGARDED AS HIS WIFE. In what respect? — R. Jose the son of R. Hanina replied: By this is meant that her separation from him is effected by a letter of divorce[^fn_82a_39] and that he may marry her again.[^fn_82a_40] \[You say,\] 'Her separation from him is effected By a letter of divorce'; \[but\] is not this obvious? — It might have been assumed that since the All-Merciful said, And perform the duty of a husband's brother unto her,[^fn_82a_41] she[^fn_82a_42] is still subject to the original levirate obligations[^fn_82a_43] and a letter of divorce should not be enough unless \[the separation had been effected\] by *halizah*, hence we were taught \[that only a letter of divorce is required\].

\[You say,\] 'He may marry her again'; \[but\] is not this obvious? [pg 82b]

— It might have been assumed that since he has already performed the commandment that the All-Merciful has imposed upon him she shall again resume towards him the prohibition of \[marrying\] a brother's wife,[^fn_82b_1] hence we were informed \[that he may remarry her\]. But might it not be suggested that the law is so[^fn_82b_2] indeed?[^fn_82b_3] — Scripture stated, And take her to him to wife,[^fn_82b_4] as soon as he has taken her she becomes his wife \[in all respects\].

SAVE THAT HER *KETHUBAH* REMAINS A CHARGE ON HER FIRST HUSBAND'S ESTATE. What is the reason?[^fn_82b_5] — A wife has been given[^fn_82b_6] to him from heaven.[^fn_82b_7] If, however, she is unable to obtain her *kethubah* from her first husband \[provision was made by the Rabbis that\] she receives it from the second[^fn_82b_8] in order that It may not be easy for bin, to divorce her.[^fn_82b_9]

HE CANNOT SAY TO HER, BEHOLD YOUR *KETHUBAH* \[etc.\]'. What \[need was there for stating\] SO, TOO?[^fn_82b_10] — It might have been suggested \[that the restriction mentioned applies only\] in the former case[^fn_82b_11] because the levir does not insert \[in her *kethubah* the clause\] 'That which I possess and that which I will acquire',[^fn_82b_12] but that in the latter case, where he does insert \[the pledge clause,\] 'That which I possess and that which I will acquire',[^fn_82b_13] she relies upon this guarantee,[^fn_82b_14] hence we were told \[that the ruling applies in both cases\].

IF HE DIVORCED HER SHE IS ENTITLED ONLY TO HER *KETHUBAH*. Only[^fn_82b_15] IF HE DIVORCED HER \[may he sell the property\],[^fn_82b_16] but if he did not divorce her he may not. Thus we were informed in agreement with the ruling of R. Abba.[^fn_82b_17]

IF HE SUBSEQUENTLY REMARRIED HER SHE IS \[TO ENJOY THE SAME RIGHTS AS\] ALL OTHER WIVES, AND IS ENTITLED ONLY TO HER *KETHUBAH*. IF HE SUBSEQUENTLY REMARRIED HER'! What does he thereby[^fn_82b_18] teach us? Have we not learned: If a man divorced his wife and then remarried her, his second marriage is contracted on the terms of her first *kethubah*?[^fn_82b_19] — It might have been assumed that the law applied only to his wife since it was he himself who wrote the *kethubah*; in the case of his sister-in-law, however, since it was not he[^fn_82b_20] who wrote the *kethubah* for her, it might well have been assumed that where he divorced, and then remarried her the *kethubah* must come from himself, hence we were taught \[that in this case also she is entitled only to the first *kethubah*\].

Rab Judah stated: At first they used to give merely a written undertaking[^fn_82b_21] in respect of \[the *kethubah* of\] a virgin for two hundred *zuz*[^fn_82b_22] and in respect of that of a widow for a *maneh*,[^fn_82b_22] and consequently[^fn_82b_23] they grew old and could not take any wives, when Simeon b. Shetah took the initiative[^fn_82b_24] and ordained that all the property of a husband is pledged for the *kethubah* of his wife. So it was also taught elsewhere: At first they used to give merely a written undertaking[^fn_82b_25] in respect of \[the *kethubah* of\] a virgin for two hundred *zuz*[^fn_82b_22] and in respect of that of a widow for a *maneh*,[^fn_82b_22] and consequently[^fn_82b_23] they grew old and could not take any wives. It was then ordained that the amount of the *kethubah*[^fn_82b_26] was to be deposited in the wife's father's house. At any time, however, when the husband was angry with her he used to tell her, 'Go to your kethubah'.[^fn_82b_27] It was ordained, therefore, that the amount of the *kethubah*[^fn_82b_26] was to be deposited in the house of her father-in-law.[^fn_82b_28] Wealthy women[^fn_82b_29] converted it into silver, or gold baskets, while poor women converted it into brass[^fn_82b_30] tubs. Still, whenever the husband had occasion to be angry with his wife he would say to her, 'Take your *kethubah* and go'.[^fn_82b_31] It was then that[^fn_82b_32] Simeon b. Shetah ordained that the husband must insert the pledging clause, 'All my property is mortgaged to your kethubah'.[^fn_82b_33] [pg 83a]

## CHAPTER IX

***MISHNAH***. IF A HUSBAND GIVES TO HIS WIFE A WRITTEN UNDERTAKING, 'I HAVE NO CLAIM WHATSOEVER[^fn_83a_1] UPON YOUR ESTATES', HE MAY NEVERTHELESS ENJOY ITS USUFRUCT DURING HER LIFETIME AND, WHEN SHE DIES, HE IS HER HEIR. IF SO, WHAT WAS HIS OBJECT IN GIVING HER THE WRITTEN UNDERTAKING, 'I HAVE NO CLAIM WHATSOEVER UPON YOUR ESTATES'? THAT IF SHE SOLD THEM OR GAVE THEM AWAY HER ACT MIGHT BE VALID. IF HE WROTE, 'I HAVE NO CLAIM WHATSOEVER UPON YOUR ESTATES AND UPON THEIR PRODUCE, HE MAY NOT ENJOY THEIR USUFRUCT DURING HER LIFETIME BUT, WHEN SHE DIES, HE IS HER HEIR. R. JUDAH RULED: HE MAY IN ALL CASES ENJOY THE YIELD OF THE PRODUCE UNLESS HE WROTE OUT FOR HER \[THE FOLLOWING UNDERTAKING\]: 'I HAVE NO CLAIM WHATSOEVER UPON YOUR ESTATES AND UPON THEIR PRODUCE AND THE PRODUCE OF THEIR PRODUCE AND SO ON WITHOUT END. {¶=9.1}

IF HE WROTE, 'I HAVE NO CLAIM UPON YOUR ESTATES, THEIR PRODUCE AND THE PRODUCE OF THEIR PRODUCE DURING YOUR LIFETIME AND AFTER YOUR DEATH', HE MAY NEITHER ENJOY THEIR PRODUCE DURING HER LIFETIME NOR CAN HE BE HER HEIR WHEN SHE DIES. R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL RULED: WHEN SHE DIES HE IS HER HEIR BECAUSE \[BY HIS DECLARATION\] HE IS MAKING A CONDITION WHICH IS CONTRARY TO WHAT IS ENJOINED IN THE TORAH[^fn_83a_2] AND WHENEVER A MAN MAKES A CONDITION WHICH IS CONTRARY TO WHAT IS WRITTEN IN THE TORAH, HIS CONDITION IS NULL AND VOID.[^fn_83a_3]

***GEMARA***. R. Hiyya taught:[^fn_83a_4] If a husband said[^fn_83a_5] to his wife.[^fn_83a_6]

And if he gave her such an undertaking in writing,[^fn_83a_7] what does It matter? Was it not taught: If a man says[^fn_83a_8] to another,[^fn_83a_9] 'I have no claim whatsoever on this field, I have no concern in it and I entirely dissociate myself from it',[^fn_83a_10] his statement is of no effect?[^fn_83a_11] — At the school of R. Jannai it was explained, \[we are dealing here with the case\] of a man who gave the undertaking to his wife[^fn_83a_12] while she was still only betrothed to him,[^fn_83a_13] \[the ruling[^fn_83a_14] being\] in agreement with that of R. Kahana, that a man is at liberty to renounce beforehand an inheritance[^fn_83a_15] which is likely to accrue to him from another source;[^fn_83a_16] and \[this ruling, furthermore, is\] in agreement with a dictum of Raba, that if anyone says. 'I do not desire \[to avail myself\] of a regulation of the Rabbis of this kind', his desire is granted.[^fn_83a_17] What \[is meant by the expression\] 'of this kind'? As \[that referred to in the statement made by\] R. Huna in the name of Rab: A woman is entitled to say to her husband, 'I do not wish either to be maintained by you or to work for you'.[^fn_83a_18] If so,[^fn_83a_19] should not \[the same ruling apply to\] a married woman also?[^fn_83a_20] Abaye replied: In the case of a married woman the husband's rights have the same force as the wife's.[^fn_83a_21] Raba said: His rights are superior to hers. This[^fn_83a_22] is of practical significance in the case of a woman who was awaiting the decision of the levir.[^fn_83a_23]

The question was raised: What is the ruling if symbolic *kinyan* was executed[^fn_83a_24] \[at the time of the renunciation\]?[^fn_83a_25] — R. Joseph replied: \[The *kinyan* is invalid since\] it related to an abstract renunciation.[^fn_83a_26] R. Nahman replied: \[The *kinyan* is valid because\] it related to land itself.[^fn_83a_27] Said Abaye: R. Joseph's statement is reasonable [pg 83b]

where \[the partner\][^fn_83b_1] lodged his protest forthwith,[^fn_83b_2] but if he delayed,[^fn_83b_3] the *kinyan* must be regarded as relating to the land itself,[^fn_83b_4] Amemar said, the law is that the *kinyan* is taken to refer to the land itself.[^fn_83b_5] Said R. Ashi to Amemar: \[Do you speak\] of one who lodged his protest forthwith or of one who delayed it? 'In what respect \[the other asked\] does this matter?' — In respect of \[determining whether the law is\] in agreement with the view of R. Joseph.[^fn_83b_6] 'I did not hear this',[^fn_83b_7] the other replied. 'by which I mean that I do not accept it.'

IF SO, WHAT WAS HIS OBJECT IN GIVING HER THE WRITTEN UNDERTAKING etc. But[^fn_83b_8] why should she not be able to say to him, 'You have renounced all your claims'?[^fn_83b_9] — Abaye replied: The holder of a deed is always at a disadvantage.[^fn_83b_10] But might it not be suggested \[that he renounced his claim\] upon the usufruct?[^fn_83b_11] — Abaye replied: A young pumpkin \[in hand\] is better than a full-grown one \[in the field\].[^fn_83b_12] But may it be suggested \[that his renunciation related\] to his heirship?[^fn_83b_13] Abaye replied: Death is a common occurrence but the sale \[of property by a wife\] is not common;[^fn_83b_14] and whenever a person renounces his claims \[he does so\] in respect of what is not a common occurrence but he does not do it in respect Of that which is a common occurrence. R. Ashi replied:[^fn_83b_15] \[The husband's renunciation was\] 'UPON YOUR ESTATES',[^fn_83b_16] but not upon their produce; 'UPON YOUR[^fn_83b_17] ESTATES', but not after your death.[^fn_83b_18]

R. JUDAH RULED: HE MAY IN ALL CASES ENJOY THE YIELD OF THE PRODUCE \[etc.\]. Our Rabbis taught: The following are regarded as produce and the following as the yield of the produce respectively. If a woman brought to her husband[^fn_83b_19] a plot of land and it yielded produce, such yield is regarded as produce. If he sold the produce and purchased land with the proceeds and that land yielded produce, such yield is regarded as the yield of the produce.

The question was raised: According to R. Judah, \[is the expression\] THE PRODUCE OF THEIR PRODUCE[^fn_83b_20] the essential element,[^fn_83b_21] or is rather WITHOUT END[^fn_83b_22] the essential element,[^fn_83b_23] or is it possible that both expressions are essential?[^fn_83b_24] But should you find \[some ground\] for deciding \[that the expression\] THE PRODUCE OF THEIR PRODUCE is the essential element,[^fn_83b_25] what need was there \[it might be asked, for the mention[^fn_83b_26] of\] 'WITHOUT END'? — It is this that we were taught: So long as he renounced in her favour, in writing, the yield of the produce it is as if he had expressly written in her favour, 'without end'. But should you find \[some reason\] for deciding that WITHOUT END is the essential element,[^fn_83b_27] what need was there \[it might be asked, for the mention[^fn_83b_26] of\] THE PRODUCE OF THEIR PRODUCE? — It is this that we were taught; Although he renounced in her favour, in writing, the yield of the produce \[the renunciation\] is valid only[^fn_83b_28] if he also wrote 'without end' but is invalid[^fn_83b_29] if he did not \[write it\]. But if you should find some argument for giving the decision that both expressions are essential \[it could he asked\]. what need is there for the specification[^fn_83b_30] of both? Both are necessary. For if only the 'yield of the produce' had been written in her favour and 'without end' had been omitted, it might have been assumed that he loses thereby his right to the enjoyment of the yield of the produce only but that he is still entitled to enjoy the produce of the yield of that produce, hence it is necessary for the expression 'without end' \[to be included in the renunciation\]. And if only 'without end' had been written in her favour and the 'yield of the produce' had not been specified,[^fn_83b_30] it might have been assumed that 'without end' referred to the first produce only,[^fn_83b_31] hence it is necessary to specify also the 'yield of the produce'.[^fn_83b_32]

The question was raised: May a husband who wrote, in favour of his wife, the renunciation 'I have no claim whatsoever upon your estates and upon the yield of their produce', enjoy the produce itself? Has he renounced the yield of their produce only but not the produce \[itself\] or is it possible that he renounced all his claim? But it is quite obvious that he has renounced all his claims. For should you suggest that he only renounced his claim upon the yield of the produce but not upon the produce itself, whence \[it might be objected\] would arise a yield of the produce if the man had consumed the produce itself?[^fn_83b_33]

\[No, for even\] according to your view, \[how will you explain\] the statement in our Mishnah, R. JUDAH RULED: HE MAY IN ALL CASES ENJOY THE YIELD OF THE PRODUCE etc. \[Where it may equally be objected,\] whence would there be a yield of the produce if she[^fn_83b_34] has consumed the produce itself? \[Your explanation,\] however, \[would be that the reference is to a case\] where the woman had allowed \[the produce\] to remain;[^fn_83b_35] here also \[it may be a case\] where the husband has allowed the produce to remain.[^fn_83b_35]

R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL RULED etc. Rab said: The *halachah* is in agreement with the ruling of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel but not because of the reason he gave. What is meant by 'the *halachah* is In agreement with the ruling of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel but not because of the reason he gave'? If it be suggested: 'The *halachah* is in agreement with the ruling of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel' in respect of his statement that WHEN SHE DIES HE IS HER HEIR, 'but not because of the reason he gave'.for whereas R. Simeon b. Gamaliel is of the opinion that if A MAN MAKES A CONDITION WHICH IS CONTRARY TO WHAT IS WRITTEN IN THE TORAH, HIS CONDITION IS NULL AND VOID, Rab holds that such a condition[^fn_83b_36] is valid[^fn_83b_37] and \[his acceptance of the ruling[^fn_83b_38] is solely due to\] his opinion that a husband's right of inheritance is a Rabbinical enactment and that the Sages have imposed upon their enactments greater restrictions than upon those of the Torah;[^fn_83b_39] [pg 84a]

could Rab, however, \[it may be retorted,\] hold the opinion that one's condition \[though contrary to what is written in the Torah\] is valid? Has it not in fact been stated: If a man says to another, '\[I sell you this object\] on condition that you have no claim for overreaching against me' \[the buyer\]. Rab ruled, has nevertheless a claim for overreaching against him,[^fn_84a_1] and Samuel ruled, He has no claim for overreaching against him?[^fn_84a_2] — \[It is this\] then \[that was meant;\] 'The *halachah* is in agreement with the ruling of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel' who laid down that IF A MAN MAKES A CONDITION WHICH IS CONTRARY TO WHAT IS WRITTEN IN THE TORAH, HIS CONDITION IS NULL AND VOID, 'but not because of the reason he gave', for whereas R. Simeon b. Gamaliel is of the opinion that WHEN SHE DIES HE IS HER HEIR, Rab maintains that when she dies he is not her heir.[^fn_84a_3] But is not this in agreement with his reason[^fn_84a_4] and not with his ruling?[^fn_84a_5] — This then \[it is that was meant:\] 'The *halachah* is in agreement with the ruling of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel' who laid down that WHEN SHE DIES HE IS HER HEIR, but not 'because of the reason he gave' for, whereas R. Simeon b. Gamaliel is of the opinion that only a condition that is contrary to a Pentateuchal law is null but one that is contrary only to a Rabbinic law[^fn_84a_6] is valid, Rab maintains that even a condition contrary to a Rabbinic law[^fn_84a_6] is also null.[^fn_84a_7]

But this would be in agreement, would it not, with both his reason[^fn_84a_8] and his ruling.[^fn_84a_9] Rab only adding \[greater force to it\]?[^fn_84a_10] This then \[it is that was meant:\] 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Simeon b. Gamaliel' who laid down that WHEN SHE DIES HE IS HER HEIR, but not 'because of the reason he gave', for, whereas R. Simeon b. Gamaliel holds that a husband's right of heirship is Pentateuchal and that \[it is invalid because\] WHEREVER A MAN MAKES A CONDITION WHICH IS CONTRARY TO WHAT IS WRITTEN IN THE TORAH, HIS CONDITION IS NULL AND VOID, Rab maintains that a husband's right of heirship is only a Rabbinic enactment and \[that the condition is nevertheless null because\] the Sages have imparted to their enactments the same force as that of Pentateuchal laws.

But \[could it be said,\] that Rab is of the opinion that a husband's right of heirship is only Rabbinical when in fact we have learned:[^fn_84a_11] R. Johanan b. Beroka ruled, 'If a husband is the heir of his wife he must \[when the Jubilee year[^fn_84a_12] arrives\] return \[the inheritance\] to the members of her family and allow them a reduction of price';[^fn_84a_13] and, in considering this statement, the objection was raised: What is really his[^fn_84a_14] opinion? If he holds that a husband's right of heirship is Pentateuchal, why \[it may be asked\] should he return \[the inheritance at all\]?[^fn_84a_15] And if \[he[^fn_84a_16] holds it to be only\] Rabbinical, why \[it may be objected\] should \[even a part of\] its price be paid?[^fn_84a_17] And Rab explained: He[^fn_84a_16] holds in fact the opinion that a husband's right of heirship is Pentateuchal but[^fn_84a_18] \[here it is a case of a man\], for instance, whose wife bequeathed to him a \[family\] graveyard, \[and it is\] in order \[to avoid\] a family taint[^fn_84a_19] that the Rabbis have ruled, Let him take the price and return it; and by[^fn_84a_20] 'allow them a reduction in price' \[was meant a deduction of\] the cost of his wife's grave;[^fn_84a_21] \[the return of a family graveyard being\] in agreement with what was taught: If a person has sold his \[family\] grave, the path to this grave, his halting place.[^fn_84a_22] or his place of mourning, the members of his family may come and bury him perforce,[^fn_84a_23] in order \[to avert\] a slight upon the family![^fn_84a_24] — Rab spoke here in accordance with R. Johanan b. Beroka's point of view but he himself does not uphold it.

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN DIED AND LEFT A WIFE,[^fn_84a_25] A CREDITOR,[^fn_84a_26] AND HEIRS[^fn_84a_27] AND HE ALSO HAD A DEPOSIT OR A LOAN IN THE POSSESSION OF OTHERS, THIS, R. TARFON RULED, SHALL BE GIVEN TO THE ONE WHO IS UNDER THE GREATEST DISADVANTAGE.[^fn_84a_28] R. AKIBA SAID: NO PITY IS TO BE SHEWN IN A MATTER OF LAW; AND IT[^fn_84a_29] SHALL RATHER BE GIVEN TO THE HEIRS, FOR WHEREAS ALL THE OTHERS[^fn_84a_30] MUST TAKE AN OATH[^fn_84a_31] THE HEIRS NEED NOT TAKE ANY OATH.[^fn_84a_32] IF HE LEFT PRODUCE THAT WAS DETACHED FROM THE GROUND, THEN WHOEVER[^fn_84a_33] SEIZES IT FIRST ACQUIRES POSSESSION. IF THE WIFE TOOK POSSESSION OF MORE THAN THE AMOUNT OF HER *KETHUBAH*, OR A CREDIT OR OF MORE THAN THE VALUE OF HIS DEBT, THE BALANCE, R. TARFON RULED, SHALL. BE GIVEN TO THE ONE WHO IS UNDER THE GREATEST DISADVANTAGE.[^fn_84a_34] R. AKIBA SAID: NO PITY IS TO BE SHEWN IN A MATTER OF LAW; AND IT SHALL RATHER BE GIVEN TO THE HEIRS, FOR WHEREAS ALL THE OTHERS[^fn_84a_30] MUST TAKE AN OATH[^fn_84a_31] THE HEIRS NEED NOT TAKE ANY OATH.[^fn_84a_32] {¶=9.2}

***GEMARA***. What was the object of specifying both A LOAN and a DEPOSIT?[^fn_84a_35] \[Both were\] required. For if A LOAN only had been mentioned it might have been presumed that only in that case did R. Tarfon maintain his view, because a loan is intended to be spent,[^fn_84a_36] but that in the case of a deposit which is in existence[^fn_84a_37] he agrees with R. Akiba.[^fn_84a_38] And if the former[^fn_84a_39] only had been mentioned it might have been assumed that only in that case did R. Akiba maintain his view[^fn_84a_40] but that in the other case[^fn_84a_41] he agrees with R. Tarfon.[^fn_84a_42] \[Hence both were\] necessary.

What is meant by TO THE ONE WHO IS UNDER THE GREATEST DISADVANTAGE? — R. Jose the son of R. Hanina replied: To the one who is under the greatest disadvantage in respect of proof.[^fn_84a_43] R. Johanan replied: \[The reference is\] to the *kethubah* of the wife[^fn_84a_44] \[who was given this privilege\] in order to maintain pleasantness[^fn_84a_45] \[between her and her husband\].[^fn_84a_46] \[This dispute is the same\] as that between the following Tannaim: R. Benjamin said, To the one who is under the greatest disadvantage in respect of proof.[^fn_84a_43] and this is the proper \[course to take\]; R. Eleazar said.\[The reference is\] to the *kethubah* of the wife[^fn_84a_44] \[who was given this privilege\] in order to maintain pleasantness[^fn_84a_45] \[between her and her husband\].[^fn_84a_46] IF HE LEFT PRODUCE THAT WAS DETACHED. As to R. Akiba,[^fn_84a_47] what was the point in discussing the BALANCE when[^fn_84a_48] the entire estate belongs to the heirs?[^fn_84a_49] — The law is so indeed,[^fn_84a_50] but since R. Tarfon spoke of the BALANCE, he also mentioned the BALANCE. [pg 84b]

But would R. Akiba[^fn_84b_1] maintain that seizure[^fn_84b_2] is never legally valid?[^fn_84b_3] Raba replied in the name of R. Nahman: Seizure[^fn_84b_4] is valid where it took place during the lifetime \[of the deceased\].[^fn_84b_5]

Now according to R. Tarfon,[^fn_84b_6] where \[must the produce\] be kept?[^fn_84b_7] — Both Rab and Samuel replied: It must be heaped up and lie in a public domain, but \[if it was kept\] in an alley[^fn_84b_8] no \[seizure is valid\]. Both R. Johanan and Resh Lakish, however, said: Even \[if the produce lay\] in an alley \[seizure is valid\].

Certain judges once gave their decision in agreement with R. Tarfon, and Resh Lakish[^fn_84b_9] reversed their verdict. Said R. Johanan to him, 'You have acted as \[if R. Akiba's ruling were a law\] of the Torah'![^fn_84b_10] May it be assumed that they[^fn_84b_11] differ on this principle; One Master upholds the view that if \[in giving a decision\] a law cited in a Mishnah had been overlooked the decision must be reversed[^fn_84b_12] and the other Master upholds the view that if a law cited in a Mishnah had been overlooked the decision need not be reversed?[^fn_84b_13] — No; all agree that if \[in giving a decision\] a law cited in a Mishnah had been overlooked the decision must be reversed, but this is the point at issue between them:[^fn_84b_14] One Master holds that the *halachah* is in agreement with the opinion of R. Akiba \[only when he differs\] from a colleague of his but not from his master,[^fn_84b_15] while the other Master holds that the *halachah* \[is in agreement with him\] even \[if he differs\] from his master. If you prefer[^fn_84b_16] I might say; All agree that the *halachah* agrees with R. Akiba \[only when he differs\] from a colleague of his but not from his master. Here, however. the point at issue is this: One Master holds R. Tarfon to have been his[^fn_84b_17] master and the other Master holds him to have been his colleague. Alternatively it might be said: All agree that he[^fn_84b_18] was his[^fn_84b_19] colleague; but the point at issue between them[^fn_84b_20] is this: One Master maintains that the statement[^fn_84b_21] was that 'The *halachah* \[agrees with R. Akiba\]'[^fn_84b_22] and the other Master maintains that the statement[^fn_84b_21] was that 'one should be inclined \[in favour of a ruling of R. Akiba\]'.[^fn_84b_23]

R. Johanan's relatives seized in an alley a cow that belonged to orphans. When they appeared before R. Johanan, he said to them, 'Your seizure is quite lawful'. R. Simeon b. Lakish, however, before whom they subsequently appeared, said to them. 'Go and return it'.[^fn_84b_24] 'What can I do', said R. Johanan to whom they came again, 'when one of equal authority[^fn_84b_25] differs from me?'

\[A creditor\] once seized an ox from the herdsman of \[his debtor's\] orphans. The creditor said, 'I seized it during the lifetime \[of the debtor\]'[^fn_84b_26] and the herdsman said, 'He seized it after the debtor's death'.[^fn_84b_27] They appeared before R. Nahman who asked the herdsman, 'Have you witnesses that \[the creditor\] has seized it?' — 'No', the other replied. \[R. Nahman thereupon\] said to him: Since he could have said, 'It came into my possession through purchase'[^fn_84b_28] he is also entitled to say. 'I seized it during the lifetime \[of the debtor\]'. But did not Resh Lakish state; The law of presumptive possession is inapplicable to living creatures?[^fn_84b_29] — The case of an ox that was entrusted to a herdsman is different \[from that of other living creatures\].[^fn_84b_30]

The people of the Nasi's[^fn_84b_31] household once seized in an alley a bondwoman belonging to orphans. At a session held by R. Abbahu, R. Hanina b. Papi and R. Isaac Nappaha in whose presence sat also R. Abba they[^fn_84b_32] were told, 'Your seizure is quite lawful'. 'Is it', said R. Abba to them,[^fn_84b_33] 'because these people are of the Nasi's household that you are favouring them? Surely, when certain judges once gave a decision in agreement with R. Tarfon Resh Lakish reversed their decision'.[^fn_84b_34]

Yemar b. Hashu had a money claim against a certain person who died and left a boat. 'Go', he said to his agent, 'and seize it'. \[The latter\] went and seized it, but R. Papa and R. Huna the son of R. Joshua met him and told him, 'You are seizing \[the ship\] on behalf of a creditor and thereby you are causing loss to others,[^fn_84b_35] and R. Johanan ruled: He who seizes \[a debtor's property\] on behalf of a creditor and thereby causes loss to others[^fn_84b_35] [pg 85a]

does not legally acquire it'.[^fn_85a_1] Thereupon they[^fn_85a_2] seized it themselves, R. Papa rowing[^fn_85a_3] the boat while R. Huna the son of R. Joshua pulled it by the rope. One Master then declared, 'I have acquired all the ship'[^fn_85a_4] and the other similarly declared, 'I have acquired all of it'.[^fn_85a_5] They were met by R. Phinehas b. Ammi who said to them: Both Rab and Samuel ruled that '\[Seizure is valid\] only if \[the produce\] was piled up and lay in a public domain'.[^fn_85a_6] 'We too', they replied, 'have seized it at the main current of the river'.[^fn_85a_7] When they appeared before Raba he said to them, 'Ye white geese[^fn_85a_8] that strip the people of their cloaks;[^fn_85a_9] thus ruled R. Nahman; \[The seizure is valid\] only if it took place during the lifetime \[of the original owner\].

The men of Be-Hozae[^fn_85a_10] once claimed a sum of money from Abimi the son of R. Abbahu, who sent it to them by the hand of Hama the son of Rabbah b. Abbahu. He duly went there and paid them, but when he asked them, 'Return to me the bond', they replied. 'This payment was made in settlement of some other claims'.[^fn_85a_11] He came before R. Abbahu \[to complain\] and the latter asked him, 'Have you witnesses that you have paid them?' — 'No', he replied. 'Since', the former said to him, 'they could plead[^fn_85a_12] that the payment was never made,[^fn_85a_13] they are also entitled to plead that the payment was made in settlement of some other claims'.[^fn_85a_14]

What is the law in respect of the agent's liability to refund? — R. Ashi replied; We have to consider the facts. If he[^fn_85a_15] said to him. 'Secure the bond and pay the money' he[^fn_85a_16] must refund it; \[but if he[^fn_85a_15] said.\] 'Pay the money and secure the bond', he is under no obligation to refund it. The law, however, is not so. He[^fn_85a_16] must refund it in either case, because the other[^fn_85a_15] may well say. 'I deputed you to improve my position, not to make it worse

There was a certain woman with whom a case[^fn_85a_17] of bonds was once deposited and when the heirs \[of the depositor\] came to claim it from her she said, 'I seized them[^fn_85a_18] during \[the depositor's\] lifetime'.[^fn_85a_19] R. Nahman to whom she came said to her, 'Have you witnesses that it[^fn_85a_20] was claimed from you during \[the depositor's\] lifetime and that you refused to return it?' — 'No', she replied. 'If so', he said to her, 'your seizure is one that took place after \[the owner's\] death,[^fn_85a_21] and such a seizure is invalid.[^fn_85a_22]

A woman was once ordered[^fn_85a_23] to take an oath[^fn_85a_24] at the court of Raba, but when R. Hisda's daughter[^fn_85a_25] said to him, 'I know that she is suspected of \[taking false\] oaths', Raba transferred the oath to her opponent.[^fn_85a_26]

On another occasion R. Papa and R. Adda b. Mattena sat in his presence when a bond was brought to him. Said R. Papa to him. 'I know that this bond is paid up'. 'Is there, \[Raba\] asked him, 'any other man with the Master \[to confirm the statement\]?' 'No', he replied. 'Although', the other said to him, 'the Master is present \[to give evidence\] there is no validity \[in the testimony of\] one witness'.[^fn_85a_27] Said R. Adda b. Mattena to him, 'Should not R. Papa be \[deemed as reliable\] as the daughter of R. Hisda?'[^fn_85a_28] — 'As to the daughter of R. Hisda \[he replied\] I am certain of her;[^fn_85a_29] I am not sure, however, about the Master'.[^fn_85a_30] Said R. Papa: Now that the Master has stated \[that a judge who can assert,\] 'I am certain of a person', may rely upon that person's evidence,[^fn_85a_31] I would tear up a bond on the evidence of my son Abba Mar of whose reliability I am certain. 'I would tear up'! Is such an act conceivable?[^fn_85a_32] — He rather \[meant to say,\] 'I would impair a bond[^fn_85a_33] on his evidence'.

A woman was once ordered to take[^fn_85a_34] an oath at the court of R. Bibi b. Abaye, when her opponent suggested to them, 'Let her rather come and take the oath in our town,[^fn_85a_35] where she might possibly feel ashamed \[of her action\] and confess'. 'Write out said she to them, 'the verdict in my favour[^fn_85a_36] so that after I shall have taken the oath it may be given to me'. 'Write it out for her', ordered R. Bibi b. Abaye. 'Because', said R. Papi. 'you are descendants of short-lived people you speak frail words;[^fn_85a_37] surely Raba stated, 'An attestation[^fn_85a_38] by judges that was written before the witnesses have identified their signatures is invalid',[^fn_85a_39] from which it is evident \[that such an attestation\] has the appearance of a false declaration, and so here also \[the verdict\][^fn_85a_40] would appear to contain a false statement'. This conclusion,[^fn_85a_41] however, is futile[^fn_85a_42] \[as may be inferred\] from a statement of R. Nahman, who said; R. Meir ruled that even if \[a husband\] found it[^fn_85a_43] on a rubbish heap, and then signed and gave it to her, it is valid; and even the Rabbis[^fn_85a_44] differ from R. Meir only in respect of letters of divorce where it is necessary that the writing shall be done specifically in her name, but in respect of other legal documents they agree with him,[^fn_85a_45] for R. Assi stated in the name of R. Johanan, 'A man may not borrow again on a bond on which he has once borrowed and which he has repaid.[^fn_85a_46] because the obligation \[incurred by the first loan\][^fn_85a_47] was cancelled;[^fn_85a_48] the reason then is because 'the obligation was cancelled', but that \[the contents of the document\] have the appearance [pg 85b]

of a false statement[^fn_85b_1] is a matter which need not be taken into consideration.

A certain man once deposited seven pearls, wrapped in a sheet, with R. Miasha the son of the son of R. Joshua h. Levi. As R. Miasha died intestate[^fn_85b_2] they came to R. Ammi.[^fn_85b_3] 'In the first instance', he said to them, 'I know that R. Miasha the son of the son of R. Joshua b. Levi was not a wealthy man,[^fn_85b_4] and secondly. does not the man[^fn_85b_5] indicate the marks?'[^fn_85b_6] This ruling, however, applies only to a man who was not a frequent visitor at the bailee's house,[^fn_85b_7] but if he was a frequent visitor there \[the marks he indicates are no evidence of ownership since\] it might well be assumed that another person has made the deposit and he happened to see it. A certain man once deposited a silver cup with Nasa; and Hasa died intestate.[^fn_85b_8] R. Nahman before whom \[the heirs\] appeared said to them, 'I know that Hasa was not a wealthy man? and, furthermore, does he[^fn_85b_5] not indicate the mark?'[^fn_85b_9] This, however, applies only to a man who was not an habitual visitor at the bailee's house,[^fn_85b_7] but if he was a frequent visitor there \[the mark he indicates is no valid proof since\] it might be said that another person had deposited \[the cup\] and he happened to see it.

A certain man once deposited a silk cloth[^fn_85b_10] with R. Dimi the brother of R. Safra, and R. Dimi died intestate.[^fn_85b_2] R. Abba, to whom \[the depositor\] came \[to submit his claim.\] said to them,[^fn_85b_11] 'In the first place I know that R. Dimi was not a wealthy man[^fn_85b_4] and, secondly, the man is here indicating the distinguishing mark.' This, however, applies only to a man who was not a frequent visitor[^fn_85b_7] at the bailee's house, but if he was a frequent visitor there \[the indication of the mark is no valid proof since\] it might well be suggested that another man deposited the object and he happened to see it.

A man once said[^fn_85b_12] to those around him,[^fn_85b_13] 'Let my estate be given to Tobiah', and then he died. \[A man named\] Tobiah came \[to claim the estate\]. 'Behold', said R. Johanan. 'Tobiah has come'.[^fn_85b_14] Now if he said, 'Tobiah'[^fn_85b_15] and 'R. Tobiah'[^fn_85b_16] came, \[the latter is not entitled to the estate, since\] he said 'To Tobiah' but not 'To R. Tobiah'. If he,[^fn_85b_16] however, was on familiar terms with him[^fn_85b_17] \[the estate must be given to him, since the omission of title might have been due to\] the fact that he was on intimate terms with him. If two Tobiahs appeared,[^fn_85b_18] one of whom was a neighbour[^fn_85b_19] and the other a scholar, the scholar is to be given precedence.[^fn_85b_20] If one \[of the Tobiahs\] is a relative and the other a scholar, the scholar is given precedence.[^fn_85b_20] The question was asked: What is the position where one is a neighbour[^fn_85b_19] and the other a relative? — Come and hear; Better is a neighbour that is near than a brother far off[^fn_85b_21] if both[^fn_85b_22] are relatives, or both are neighbours. or both are scholars the decision is left to the discretion[^fn_85b_23] of the judges.

Come, said Raba to the son of R. Hiyya b. Abin, I will tell you a fine saying of your father's:[^fn_85b_24] Although[^fn_85b_25] Samuel said, 'If a man sold a bond of indebtedness to another person and then he[^fn_85b_26] released the debtor, the latter is legally released;[^fn_85b_27] and, moreover, even \[a creditor's\] heir may[^fn_85b_28] release \[the debtor\]' Samuel, nevertheless, admits that, where a wife brought in to her husband[^fn_85b_29] a bond of indebtedness and then remitted it, the debt is not to be considered remitted, because her husband's rights are equal to hers.[^fn_85b_30]

A relative of R. Nahman once sold her *kethubah* for the goodwill.[^fn_85b_31] She was divorced and then died. Thereupon \[the buyers\] came to claim \[the amount of the *kethubah*\] from her daughter.[^fn_85b_32] 'Is there no one', said R. Nahman to those around him,[^fn_85b_33] 'who can tender her advice? [pg 86a]

She might remit[^fn_86a_1] her mother's *kethubah* in favour of her father,[^fn_86a_2] and then she may inherit it frons him'.[^fn_86a_3] When she heard this she went and remitted it \[in her father's favour\]. Thereupon R. Nahman said: 'We have put ourselves in the \[unenviable\] position of legal advisers'.[^fn_86a_4] What was the opinion that he held at first[^fn_86a_5] and what made him change it afterwards?[^fn_86a_6] — At first he thought \[of the Scriptural text.\] And that thou hide not thyself from thine own flesh,[^fn_86a_7] but ultimately he realized that \[the position of\] a noted personality is different \[from that of the general public\].[^fn_86a_8]

\[Reverting to\] the main text; Samuel said, 'If a man sold a bond of indebtedness to another person, and then he released the debtor, the latter is released; and, moreover, even \[a creditor's\] heir may release \[the debtor\].'[^fn_86a_9] Said R. Huna the son of R. Joshua; But if he[^fn_86a_10] is clever he[^fn_86a_11] rattles some coins in his[^fn_86a_12] face and \[the latter\][^fn_86a_13] writes the bond[^fn_86a_14] in his[^fn_86a_15] name.

Amemar said; He[^fn_86a_16] who adjudicates \[liability\] in an action \[for damage\] caused indirectly would here also[^fn_86a_17] adjudge damages[^fn_86a_18] to the amount \[recoverable\] on a valid bond,[^fn_86a_19] but he who does not adjudicate \[liability\] in an action for damage caused indirectly[^fn_86a_20] would here adjudge damages only to the extent of the value of the mere scrap of paper.[^fn_86a_21] Such[^fn_86a_22] an action was \[once tried\] when through Rafram's insistence[^fn_86a_23] R. Ashi[^fn_86a_24] was compelled to order the collection \[of damages\][^fn_86a_25] in the manner of a beam that is fit for decorative mouldings.[^fn_86a_26]

Amemar stated in the name of R. Hama; If a man has against him, the claim of his wife's *kethubah* and that of a creditor, and he owns a plot of land and has also ready money, the creditor's claim is settled by means of the ready money while the woman's claim is settled by means of the land, the creditor being treated in accordance with his rights,[^fn_86a_27] and the wife in accordance with her rights.[^fn_86a_28] If, however, he owns only one plot of land and it suffices to meet the claim of one only, it is to be given to the creditor;[^fn_86a_29] it is not to be given to the wife. What is the reason?[^fn_86a_30] — More than the man's desire to marry is the woman's desire to be married.[^fn_86a_31]

Said R. Papa to R. Hama, Is it a fact that you have stated in the name of Raba; If a man, against whom there was a monetary claim owned a plot of land, and who, when his creditor approached hini with the claim for repayment, replied, 'Collect your loan from the land', he is to be ordered \[by the court,\] 'You must yourself go and sell it, bring \[the net proceeds\] and deliver it to him'?[^fn_86a_32]

'No', the other replied. 'Tell me then', \[the first said to him,\] 'how the incident[^fn_86a_33] had actually occurred'. '\[The debtor\]' the other replied, 'alleged that his money belonged to[^fn_86a_34] an idolater; and since he acted in an improper manner[^fn_86a_35] he was similarly treated in an improper manner'.[^fn_86a_36]

Said K. Kahana to R. Papa; According to the statement you made that the repayment of \[a debt to\] a creditor is a religious act,[^fn_86a_37] what is the ruling where \[a debtor\] said, 'I am not disposed to perform a religious act'?[^fn_86a_38] — 'We', the other replied. 'have learned: This[^fn_86a_39] applies only to negative precepts, but in the case of positive precepts, as for instance, when a man is told, 'Make a sukkah'[^fn_86a_40] and he does not make it \[or, 'Perform the commandment of the\] lulab'[^fn_86a_41] and he does not perform it [pg 86b]

he is flogged[^fn_86b_1] until his soul departeth.[^fn_86b_2]

Rami b. Hama enquired of R. Hisda: What is the ruling where \[a husband said to his wife,\] 'Here is your letter of divorce but you shall be divorced thereby only after \[the lapse of\] thirty days'. and she went and laid it down at the side of a public domain?[^fn_86b_3] — 'She', the other replied, 'is not divorced, by reason of the ruling of Rab and Samuel, both of whom have stated, 'It must be heaped up and lie in a public domain'[^fn_86b_4] and the sides of a public domain are regarded as the public domain itself.[^fn_86b_5] On the contrary! She should be deemed divorced by reason of a ruling of R. Nahman, who stated in the name of Rabbah b. Abbuha, 'If a man said to another, "Pull this cow, but it shall pass into your possession Only after thirty days", he legally acquires it even if it stands at the time in the meadow';[^fn_86b_6] and a meadow presumably has, has it not, the same status as the sides of a public domain?[^fn_86b_7] — No; a meadow has a status of its own[^fn_86b_8] and the sides of a public domain, too, have a status of their own.[^fn_86b_9] Another version: He[^fn_86b_10] said to him,[^fn_86b_11] 'She[^fn_86b_12] is divorced by reason of a ruling of R. Nahman,[^fn_86b_13] the sides of a public domain having the same status as a meadow'. — 'On the contrary! She should not be regarded as divorced by reason of a ruling of Rab and Samuel.[^fn_86b_13] for have not the sides of a public domain the same status as a public domain?' — 'No; a public domain has a status of its own[^fn_86b_8] and the sides of a public domain, too, have a status of their own'.[^fn_86b_9]

***MISHNAH***. IF A HUSBAND SET UP HIS WIFE AS A SHOPKEEPER[^fn_86b_14] OR APPOINTED HER AS HIS ADMINISTRATRIX HE MAY IMPOSE UPON HER AN OATH[^fn_86b_15] WHENEVER HE DESIRES TO DO SO. R. ELIEZER SAID; \[SUCH AN OATH[^fn_86b_15] MAY BE IMPOSED UPON HER\] EVEN IN RESPECT OF HER SPINDLE AND HER DOUGH.[^fn_86b_16] {¶=9.3}

***GEMARA***. The question was asked; Does R. Eliezer mean \[that the oath[^fn_86b_17] is to be imposed\] by implication[^fn_86b_18] or does he mean that it may be imposed directly?[^fn_86b_19] Come and hear: They[^fn_86b_20] said to R. Eliezer, 'No one can live with a serpent in the same basket'.[^fn_86b_21] Now if you will assume that R. Eliezer meant the imposition of a direct oath[^fn_86b_19] one can well understand the argument;[^fn_86b_22] but if you were to suggest \[that he meant the oath to be imposed\] by implication only, what \[it may be objected\] could this[^fn_86b_23] matter to her?[^fn_86b_24] — She might tell him, 'Since you are so particular with me I am unable to live with you'.[^fn_86b_25]

Come and hear:[^fn_86b_26] If a man did not exempt his wife[^fn_86b_27] from a vow[^fn_86b_28] and from an oath[^fn_86b_29] and set her up as his saleswoman or appointed her as his administratrix, he may impose upon her an oath[^fn_86b_29] whenever he desires to do so. If, however, he did not set her up as his saleswoman and did not appoint her as his administratrix, he may not impose any oath upon her. R. Eliezer said: Although he did not set her up as his saleswoman and did not appoint her as his administratrix, he may nevertheless impose upon her an oath wherever he desires to do so, because there is no woman who was not administratrix for a short time, at least, during the lifetime of her husband, in respect of her spindle and her dough. Thereupon they said to him: No one can live with a serpent in the same basket. Thus you may infer that \[R. Eliezer meant that the oath[^fn_86b_29] may he imposed\] directly. This is conclusive.

***MISHNAH***. \[IF A HUSBAND\] GAVE TO HIS WIFE AN UNDERTAKING IN WRITING, 'I HAVE NO CLAIM UPON YOU FOR EITHER VOW[^fn_86b_30] OR OATH',[^fn_86b_31] HE CANNOT IMPOSE AN OATH[^fn_86b_32] UPON HER. HE MAY, HOWEVER, IMPOSE AN OATH UPON HER HEIRS[^fn_86b_33] AND UPON HER LAWFUL SUCCESSORS.[^fn_86b_34] \[IF HE WROTE,\] I HAVE NO CLAIM FOR EITHER VOW[^fn_86b_30] OR OATH[^fn_86b_31] EITHER UPON YOU, OR UPON YOUR HEIRS OR UPON YOUR LAWFUL SUCCESSORS', HE MAY NOT IMPOSE AN OATH EITHER UPON HER OR UPON HER HEIRS OR UPON HER LAWFUL SUCCESSORS. HIS HEIRS, HOWEVER, MAY[^fn_86b_35] IMPOSE AN OATH UPON HER, UPON HER HEIRS OR UPON HER LAWFUL SUCCESSORS. \[IF THE WRITTEN UNDERTAKING READ.\] 'NEITHER I NOR MY HEIRS NOR MY LAWFUL SUCCESSORS[^fn_86b_36] SHALL HAVE ANY CLAIM UPON YOU OR UPON YOUR HEIRS OR UPON YOUR LAWFUL SUCCESSORS FOR EITHER VOW OR OATH', NEITHER HE NOR HIS HEIRS NOR HIS LAWFUL SUCCESSORS MAY IMPOSE AN OATH EITHER UPON HER OR UPON HER HEIRS OR UPON HER LAWFUL SUCCESSORS. {¶=9.4}

IF SHE[^fn_86b_37] WENT FROM HER HUSBAND'S GRAVE TO HER FATHER'S HOUSE,[^fn_86b_38] OR RETURNED TO HER FATHER-IN-LAW'S HOUSE BUT WAS NOT MADE ADMINISTRATRIX, THE HEIRS ARE NOT ENTITLED TO IMPOSE AN OATH UPON HER;[^fn_86b_39] BUT IF SHE WAS MADE ADMINISTRATRIX THE HEIRS MAY IMPOSE AN OATH UPON HER IN RESPECT OF \[HER ADMINISTRATION\] DURING THE SUBSEQUENT PERIOD[^fn_86b_40] BUT NOT IN RESPECT OF THE PAST.[^fn_86b_41]

***GEMARA***. What is the nature of the oath?[^fn_86b_42] — Rab Judah replied in the name of Rab: [pg 87a]

\[It is one that is incumbent\] upon a woman who during the lifetime of her husband was made administratrix \[of his affairs\].[^fn_87a_1] R. Nahman replied in the name of Rabbah b. Abbuha: \[It is one that is incumbent\] upon a woman who impairs her *kethubah*.[^fn_87a_2] R. Mordecai went to R. Ashi and submitted to him this argument: One can well imagine \[the origin of the exemption\], according to him who holds \[that the oath is one incumbent\] upon a woman who impairs her *kethubah* \[by assuming that\] it occurred to the woman that she might sometime be in need of money and would draw it from her *kethubah* and would, therefore, tell her husband, 'Give me an undertaking in writing that you will impose no oath upon me'.[^fn_87a_3] According to him, however, who holds \[that the oath is one incumbent\] upon a woman who during the lifetime of her husband was made administratrix \[of his affairs\],[^fn_87a_4] did she know \[it may be objected\] that he would set her up as administratrix that she should say to him, 'Give me a written undertaking that you will impose no oath upon me'?[^fn_87a_5] — The other replied: You taught this statement[^fn_87a_6] in connection with that clause;[^fn_87a_7] we teach it[^fn_87a_8] in connection with this:[^fn_87a_9] IF SHE WENT FROM HER HUSBAND'S GRAVE TO HER FATHER'S HOUSE, OR RETURNED TO HER FATHER-IN-LAW'S HOUSE BUT WAS NOT MADE ADMINISTRATRIX, THE HEIRS ARE NOT ENTITLED TO IMPOSE AN OATH UPON HER, BUT IF SHE WAS MADE ADMINISTRATRIX THE HEIRS MAY IMPOSE AN OATH UPON HER IN RESPECT OF \[HER ADMINISTRATION\] DURING THE SUBSEQUENT PERIOD BUT NOT IN CONNECTION WITH THE PAST, \[and, in reply to the question as to\] what exactly was meant by THE PAST, Rab Judah stated in the name of Rab: \[The period\] during the lifetime of her husband for which she was made administratrix \[of his affairs\], but in respect of \[the period intervening\] between death and burial an oath may be imposed upon her.[^fn_87a_10] R. Mattena, however,[^fn_87a_11] maintained that no oath may be imposed upon her[^fn_87a_12] even in respect of \[the period between\] death and burial;[^fn_87a_13] for the Nehardeans laid down: For poll-tax,[^fn_87a_14] maintenance[^fn_87a_15] and funeral expenses. an estate[^fn_87a_16] is sold without public announcement.[^fn_87a_17]

Said Rabbah in the name of R. Hiyya: \[If in giving exemption to his wife a husband wrote,\] 'Neither vow nor oath' it is only he who cannot impose an oath upon her, but his heirs may impose an oath upon her. \[If he wrote, however,\] 'Free from vow, free from oath', neither he nor his heirs may exact an oath from her, \[since by this expression\] he meant to say to her: 'Be free from the obligation of an oath'.

R. Joseph. however, stated in the name of R. Hiyya: \[If in giving exemption to his wife a husband writes,\] 'Neither vow nor oath' it is only he who cannot impose an oath upon her but his heirs may; \[but if he wrote,\] 'Free from vow, free from oath', both he and his heirs may exact an oath from her \[since by such an expression\] he thus meant to say to her: 'Clear yourself by means of an oath'.

R. Zakkai sent to Mar 'Ukba the following message: Whether \[the husband wrote,\] 'Neither oath' or 'Free from oath', or whether \[he wrote.\] 'Neither vow', or 'Free from vow', \[and he used the expression\] 'In respect of my estates',[^fn_87a_18] he cannot impose an oath upon her, but his heirs may. \[If he wrote, however,\] 'In respect of these estates', neither he nor his heirs may exact an oath from her.

R. Nahman stated in the name of Samuel in the name of Abba Saul the son of Imma Miriam: Whether \[the husband wrote,\] 'Neither oath' or 'Free from oath'' whether \[he wrote,\] 'Neither vow' or 'Free from vow, or whether \[he used the expression,\] 'In respect of my[^fn_87a_18] estates' or 'In respect of these estates', neither he nor his heirs may exact an oath from her; but what can I do in view of a ruling of the Sages that anyone who comes to exact payment out of the property of orphans is not to be paid unless he first takes an oath.[^fn_87a_19]

Others read this[^fn_87a_20] as a Baraitha: Abba Saul the son of Imma Miriam stated; Whether \[the husband wrote.\] 'Neither oath' or 'Free from oath', whether \[he wrote,\] 'Neither vow' or 'Free from vow, or whether \[he used the expression,\] 'In respect of my[^fn_87a_18] estates, or 'In respect of these estates'. neither he nor his heirs may impose, an oath upon her; but what can I do in view of a ruling of the Sages that anyone who comes to exact payment out of the property of orphans need not be paid unless he first takes an oath. \[It was in connection with this Baraitha[^fn_87a_21] that\] R. Nahman said in the name of Samuel: The *halachah* is in agreement with the ruling of the son of Imma Miriam.

***MISHNAH***. A WOMAN WHO IMPAIRS[^fn_87a_22] HER *KETHUBAH* IS NOT PAID[^fn_87a_23] UNLESS SHE FIRST TAKES AN OATH.[^fn_87a_24] IF ONE WITNESS TESTIFIES AGAINST HER THAT \[HER *KETHUBAH*\] HAS BEEN PAID,[^fn_87a_25] SHE IS NOT BE PAID UNLESS SHE FIRST TAKES THE OATH.
