FROM THE PROPERTY OF ORPHANS, FROM ASSIGNED PROPERTY[^fn_87a_26] AND \[FROM THE PROPERTY OF\] AN ABSENT HUSBAND[^fn_87a_27] SHE MAY NOT RECOVER \[THE PAYMENT OF HER *KETHUBAH*\] UNLESS SHE FIRST TAKES AN OATH.[^fn_87a_28] {¶=9.5}

HOW \[ARE WE TO UNDERSTAND THE STATEMENT,\] 'A WOMAN WHO IMPAIRS HER KETHUBAH'? IF HER *KETHUBAH* WAS FOR A THOUSAND *ZUZ*[^fn_87a_29] AND \[HER HUSBAND\] SAID TO HER, 'YOU HAVE ALREADY RECEIVED \[THE FULL AMOUNT OF\] YOUR KETHUBAH', AND SHE SAYS, 'I RECEIVED ONLY A MANEH',[^fn_87a_29] SHE IS NOT PAID \[THE BALANCE\] UNLESS SHE TAKES AN OATH. WHAT IS MEANT BY[^fn_87a_30] 'IF ONE WITNESS TESTIFIES AGAINST HER THAT \[HER *KETHUBAH*\] HAS BEEN PAID'? IF HER *KETHUBAH* WAS FOR A THOUSAND *ZUZ*[^fn_87a_29] AND WHEN \[HER HUSBAND\] SAID TO HER, 'YOU HAVE RECEIVED \[THE FULL AMOUNT OF\] YOUR KETHUBAH', SHE REPLIED, 'I HAVE NOT RECEIVED IT WHILE ONE WITNESS TESTIFIES AGAINST HER THAT \[THE *KETHUBAH*\] HAS BEEN PAID[^fn_87a_25] SHE IS NOT PAID UNLESS SHE FIRST TAKES AN OATH. WHAT IS MEANT BY THE EXPRESSION,[^fn_87a_30] 'FROM ASSIGNED PROPERTY'? IF \[HER HUSBAND\] HAD SOLD HIS PROPERTY TO OTHERS AND SHE SEEKS TO RECOVER PAYMENT FROM THE BUYERS, SHE IS NOT PAID UNLESS SHE FIRST TAKES AN OATH. WHAT IS THE EXPLANATION OF THE EXPRESSION,[^fn_87a_30] FROM THE PROPERTY OF ORPHANS'? IF \[HER HUSBAND\] DIED AND LEFT HIS ESTATE TO HIS ORPHANS AND SHE SEEKS TO RECOVER PAYMENT FROM THE ORPHANS, SHE IS NOT PAID UNLESS SHE FIRST TAKES AN OATH. WHAT IS TO BE UNDERSTOOD BY[^fn_87a_31] 'AN ABSENT HUSBAND'? IF HER HUSBAND WENT TO A COUNTRY BEYOND THE SEA AND SHE SEEKS TO RECOVER PAYMENT IN HIS ABSENCE,[^fn_87a_32] SHE IS NOT PAID UNLESS SHE FIRST TAKES AN OATH. [pg 87b]

R. SIMEON RULED: WHENEVER[^fn_87b_1] SHE[^fn_87b_2] CLAIMS HER *KETHUBAH* THE HEIRS MAY IMPOSE AN OATH UPON HER BUT WHERE SHE DOES NOT CLAIM HER *KETHUBAH* THE HEIRS CAN NOT IMPOSE AN OATH UPON HER.

***GEMARA***. Rami b. Hama wished to assume that the OATH[^fn_87b_3] was Pentateuchal,[^fn_87b_4] since \[it is a case where\] one \[of two persons\] claims two hundred \[*zuz*\] and the other admits one hundred \[the defence\] being an admission of a part of the claim,[^fn_87b_5] and whoever admits part of a claim must[^fn_87b_6] take an oath.[^fn_87b_7] Said Raba: There are two objections to this assumption: In the first place, all who take an oath in accordance with Pentateuchal law take the oath and do not pay,[^fn_87b_8] while she[^fn_87b_9] takes the oath and receives payment. And, secondly, no oath may be imposed[^fn_87b_6] in respect of the denial of \[a claim that is\] secured[^fn_87b_10] on landed property.[^fn_87b_11] \[The fact,\] however, is, said Raba, \[that the oath is only\] Rabbinical. As it is the person who pays that is careful to remember the details while he who receives payment is not, the Rabbis have imposed an oath upon her[^fn_87b_12] that she might be careful to recollect the details.

The question was raised; What if a woman impaired her *kethubah* by \[admitting that she received part payment in the presence of\] witnesses? \[Is it assumed that\] were \[her husband\] to pay her \[the balance\] he would do it in the presence of witnesses,[^fn_87b_13] or \[is it rather assumed that\] it was a mere coincidence \[that witnesses were present when the first payment was made\]?[^fn_87b_14] — Come and hear;[^fn_87b_15] All who take an oath in accordance with Pentateuchal law, take the oath and do not pay,[^fn_87b_16] but the following take an oath and receive payment; A hired labourer,[^fn_87b_17] a man who was robbed[^fn_87b_18] or wounded,[^fn_87b_19] \[any claimant\] whose opponent is suspected of \[taking a false\] oath[^fn_87b_20] and a shopkeeper[^fn_87b_21] with his \[accounts\] book,[^fn_87b_22] and also \[a creditor\] who impaired his bond \[the first instalment of which had been paid\] in the absence of witnesses.[^fn_87b_23] Thus only[^fn_87b_24] \[where the first instalment was paid\] 'in the absence of witnesses'[^fn_87b_25] but not where it was paid in the presence of witnesses![^fn_87b_26] — This is a case of 'there is no question …'[^fn_87b_27] There is no question[^fn_87b_28] that \[when the first instalment was paid\] in the presence of witnesses she must take an oath; when, however, \[it was paid\] in the absence of witnesses, it might be assumed that she has \[the same privilege\] as one who restores a lost object \[to its owner\][^fn_87b_29] and should, therefore, receive payment without taking an oath. It was, therefore, taught \[that the oath is nevertheless not to be dispensed with\].

The question was raised: What if a woman impaired her *kethubah* \[by including in the amount she admitted\] sums amounting to[^fn_87b_30] less than the value of a *perutah*?[^fn_87b_31] Is it assumed that since she[^fn_87b_32] is so careful in her statements she must be speaking the truth[^fn_87b_33] or is it possible that she[^fn_87b_34] is merely acting cunningly?[^fn_87b_35] — This remains unsolved.[^fn_87b_36]

The question was raised: What if a woman declares her \[original\] *kethubah* to have been less \[than the amount recorded in the written document\]?[^fn_87b_37] Is it assumed that such a woman is in the same position as the woman who impaired \[her *kethubah*\] or is it possible \[that the two cases are unlike, since\] the woman who impairs \[her *kethubah*\] admits a part \[of the sum involved\][^fn_87b_38] while this one does not admit a part \[of the sum involved\]?[^fn_87b_39] — Come and hear: A woman who declares that her \[original\] *kethubah* was less \[than the amount recorded in the document\] receives payment without an oath. How \[is this to be understood\]? If her *kethubah* was for a thousand *zuz*[^fn_87b_40] and when her husband said to her, 'You have already received your *kethubah*,'[^fn_87b_41] she replies. 'I have not received it,[^fn_87b_41] but \[the original *kethubah*\] was only for one *maneh*,'[^fn_87b_42] she is to receive payment without an oath.[^fn_87b_43]

Wherewith, however, does she collect \[the amount she claims\]? Obviously with that document.[^fn_87b_44] But is not that document a mere potsherd?[^fn_87b_45] — Raba the son of Rabbah replied: \[This is a case\] where she states, 'There was an arrangement of mutual trust between me and him'.[^fn_87b_46]

IF ONE WITNESS TESTIFIES AGAINST HER THAT \[HER *KETHUBAH*\] HAS BEEN PAID \[etc.\]. Rami b. Hama wished to assume that the OATH was Pentateuchal, for it is written In Scripture, One witness shall not rise up against a man for any iniquity, or for any sin;[^fn_87b_47] it is only for ally iniquity or for any sin that he may not rise up, but he may rise up \[to cause the imposition upon one of the obligation\] of an oath. And, furthermore, a Master has laid down: In all cases where two witnesses render a man liable to pay money, one witness renders him liable to take an oath.[^fn_87b_48] Said Raba: There are two objections to this assumption. In the first place, all who take an oath in accordance with Pentateuchal law, do so and do not pay,[^fn_87b_49] while she takes an oath and receives payment; and, secondly, no oath may be imposed in respect of the denial of \[a claim that is\] secured on landed property. \[The fact\], however, is, said Raba \[that the oath is only\] Rabbinical, \[having been enacted\] to appease the mind of the husband.

R. Papa said: [pg 88a]

If he[^fn_88a_1] is clever he may bring her under the obligation[^fn_88a_2] of a Pentateuchal oath:[^fn_88a_3] He pays her[^fn_88a_4] the amount of her *kethubah* in the presence of one witness, associates the first witness[^fn_88a_5] with the second[^fn_88a_6] and then treats his first payments[^fn_88a_7] as a loan.[^fn_88a_8] R. Shisha son of R. Idi demurred: How can one associate the first witness with the second one?[^fn_88a_9] — But, said R. Shisha the son of R. Idi, \[he might proceed in this manner:\][^fn_88a_10] He pays her the amount of her *kethubah* in the presence of the first witness and a second one, and then treats his first payments as a loan. R. Ashi demurred: Might she not still assert that there were two kethubahs?[^fn_88a_11] — But, said R. Ashi: He might inform them[^fn_88a_12] \[of the facts\].[^fn_88a_13]

FROM ASSIGNED PROPERTY. Elsewhere we have learned; And so also orphans cannot exact payment unless they first take an oath.[^fn_88a_14] From whom?[^fn_88a_15] If it be suggested. From a borrower[^fn_88a_16] \[it may be objected;\] Since[^fn_88a_17] their father would have received payment without an oath[^fn_88a_18] should they require an oath?[^fn_88a_19] — It is this, however, that was meant: And so also orphans cannot exact payment from orphans unless they first take an oath.[^fn_88a_20]

R. Zerika stated in the name of Rab Judah: This[^fn_88a_21] has been taught only \[in the case\] where the orphans[^fn_88a_22] stated, 'Father told us; I have borrowed and paid up'. If, however, they said, 'Father told us: I have never borrowed' \[the others\] cannot exact payment even if they take an oath. Raba demurred: On the contrary. wherever a man says. 'I have not borrowed', it is as if he had said, 'I have not paid'![^fn_88a_23] — \[The fact,\] however, \[is that\] if such a statement[^fn_88a_24] was at all made it was made in these terms: R. Zerika stated in the name of Rab Judah. This[^fn_88a_25] has been taught only \[in a case\] where the orphans[^fn_88a_22] stated, 'Father told us: I have borrowed and paid up'. If, however, they said — 'Father told us: I have never borrowed', \[the orphans of the creditor\] may exact payment from them without an oath, because to say, 'I have not borrowed' is equivalent to saying, 'I have not paid'.

AND[^fn_88a_26] \[FROM THE PROPERTY OF\] AN ABSENT HUSBAND \[A WOMAN\] MAY NOT RECOVER \[THE PAYMENT OF HER *KETHUBAH*\] UNLESS SHE FIRST TAKES AN OATH. R. Aha, the governor of the castle,[^fn_88a_27] stated: A case[^fn_88a_28] was once brought before R. Isaac Nappaha[^fn_88a_29] at Antioch[^fn_88a_30] and he made this statement, 'This[^fn_88a_31] has been taught only in respect of the *kethubah* of a woman \[who receives preferential treatment\] in order to maintain pleasant relations[^fn_88a_32] \[between her and her husband\] but not \[in respect of\] a creditor. Raba, however, stated in the name of R. Nahman; Even a creditor \[has been given the same privilege\],[^fn_88a_33] in order that every person shall not take his friend's money and abscond and settle in a country beyond the sea and thus \[cause the creditor's\] door to be shut in the face of intending borrowers.[^fn_88a_34]

R. SIMEON RULED: WHENEVER SHE CLAIMS HER *KETHUBAH* etc. What is R. Simeon referring to? — R. Jeremiah replied. To this; AND[^fn_88a_35] \[FROM THE PROPERTY OF\] AN ABSENT HUSBAND \[A WOMAN\] MAY NOT RECOVER \[THE PAYMENT OF HER *KETHUBAH*\] UNLESS SHE FIRST TAKES AN OATH \[which implies that\] there is no difference between \[a claim\] for maintenance and one for a *kethubah*,'[^fn_88a_36] and \[in opposition to this ruling\] R. Simeon came to lay down the rule that WHENEVER SHE CLAIMS HER *KETHUBAH* THE HEIRS MAY IMPOSE AN OATH UPON HER [pg 88b]

BUT WHERE SHE DOES NOT CLAIM HER *KETHUBAH* THE HEIRS CANNOT IMPOSE AN OATH UPON HER. And they[^fn_88b_1] \[in fact\] differ on the same principles as those on which Hanan and the sons of the High Priests differed; for we learned: If a man went to a country beyond the sea and his wife claimed maintenance, she must, Hanan ruled, take an oath at the end[^fn_88b_2] but not at the beginning.[^fn_88b_3] The sons of the High Priests, however, differed from him and said that she must take an oath both at the beginning[^fn_88b_3] and at the end.[^fn_88b_4] R. Simeon \[is thus of the same opinion\] as Hanan while the Rabbis[^fn_88b_5] \[hold the same view\] as the sons of the High Priests.

R. Shesheth demurred; Then[^fn_88b_6] \[instead of saying,\] THE HEIRS MAY IMPOSE AN OATH UPON HER, It should have said, 'Beth din[^fn_88b_7] may impose an oath upon her'! — The fact, however, is, said R. Shesheth.\[that R. Simeon referred\] to this:[^fn_88b_8] If she went from her husband's grave to her father's house, or returned to her father-in-law's house but was not made administratrix, the heirs are not entitled to impose an oath upon her; but if she was made administratrix the heirs may exact an oath from her in respect of \[her administration\] during the subsequent period but may not exact one concerning the past;[^fn_88b_9] and \[in reference to this ruling\] R. Simeon came to lay down the rule that WHENEVER SHE CLAIMS HER *KETHUBAH* THE HEIRS MAY ENACT AN OATH FROM HER BUT WHERE SHE DOES NOT CLAIM HER *KETHUBAH* THE HEIRS CANNOT IMPOSE AN OATH[^fn_88b_10] UPON HER. And they[^fn_88b_11] differ on the same principles as those on which Abba Saul and the Rabbis differed; for we have learned: An administrator whom the father of the orphans had appointed must take an oath,[^fn_88b_10] but one whom the *Beth din* have appointed need not take an oath. Abba Saul, however, said, The rule is to be reversed: If *Beth din* appointed him he must take an oath but if the father of the orphans appointed him he need not take an oath.[^fn_88b_12] R. Simeon \[thus holds the same view\] as Abba Saul[^fn_88b_13] and the Rabbis \[in our Mishnah hold the same view\] as the Rabbis.[^fn_88b_14] Abaye demurred: Then[^fn_88b_15] \[rather than say,\] WHEREVER SHE CLAIMS HER *KETHUBAH*[^fn_88b_16] it should have said,[^fn_88b_15] 'If[^fn_88b_17] she claims'.[^fn_88b_18] The fact, however, is, said Abaye, \[that R. Simeon referred\] to this: \[If a husband\] gave to his wife an undertaking in writing, 'I renounce my claim upon you for either vow or oath', he cannot impose an oath upon her etc. \[If the written undertaking read,\] 'Neither I nor my heirs nor my lawful successors will have any claim upon you. or your heirs or your lawful successors for either vow or oath', neither he nor his heirs nor his lawful successors may impose an oath either upon her or upon her heirs or upon her lawful successors;[^fn_88b_19] and \[in reference to this ruling\][^fn_88b_20] R. Simeon came to lay down the rule[^fn_88b_21] that[^fn_88b_22] WHENEVER SHE CLAIMS HER *KETHUBAH* THE HEIRS MAY ENACT AN OATH FROM HER.[^fn_88b_22]

And they[^fn_88b_23] \[consequently\] differ on the same principles as those on which Abba Saul the son of Imma Miriam, and the Rabbis differed.[^fn_88b_24] R. Simeon agreeing with Abba Saul and the Rabbis \[of our Mishnah\] with the Rabbis.[^fn_88b_25] R. Papa demurred: This would satisfactorily explain \[the expression\] WHENEVER SHE CLAIMS HER *KETHUBAH*.[^fn_88b_26] What, however, can be said \[in justification of\] BUT WHERE SHE DOES NOT CLAIM HER *KETHUBAH*?[^fn_88b_27] The fact, however, is, said R. Papa, \[R. Simeon's ruling was intended\] to oppose the views of both R. Eliezer and those who differed from him.[^fn_88b_28]

***MISHNAH***. IF SHE[^fn_88b_29] PRODUCED A LETTER OF DIVORCE WITHOUT A *KETHUBAH*[^fn_88b_30] [pg 89a] {¶=9.6}

SHE IS ENTITLED TO COLLECT THE AMOUNT OF HER *KETHUBAH*.[^fn_89a_1] \[IF SHE, HOWEVER, PRODUCED HER\] *KETHUBAH* WITHOUT A LETTER OF DIVORCE AND, WHILE SHE PLEADS, MY LETTER OF DIVORCE WAS LOST',[^fn_89a_2] HE[^fn_89a_3] PLEADS, 'MY QUITTANCE[^fn_89a_4] WAS LOST', AND SO ALSO A CREDITOR WHO PRODUCED[^fn_89a_5] A BOND OF INDEBTEDNESS THAT WAS UNACCOMPANIED BY A *PROSBUL*,[^fn_89a_6] THESE[^fn_89a_7] ARE NOT PAID. R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL RULED; SINCE THE TIME OF DANGER[^fn_89a_8] A WOMAN IS ENTITLED TO COLLECT HER *KETHUBAH* WITH OUT A LETTER OF DIVORCE AND A CREDITOR IS ENTITLED TO COLLECT \[HIS DEBT\] WITHOUT A *PROSBUL*.

***GEMARA***. This[^fn_89a_9] implies \[does it not\] that a quittance[^fn_89a_10] may be written;[^fn_89a_11] for if a quittance may not be written would not the possibility have been taken into consideration that the woman might produce her *kethubah* \[after her husband's death\] and[^fn_89a_12] collect therewith \[a second time\]?[^fn_89a_13] — Rab replied: We are dealing[^fn_89a_14] with a place where no *kethubah* is written.[^fn_89a_15] Samuel, however, said: \[Our Mishnah refers\] also to a place where a *kethubah* is written.

May then[^fn_89a_16] a quittance be written according to Samuel?[^fn_89a_17] R. Anan replied, This was explained to me by Mar Samuel;[^fn_89a_18] Where it is the custom not to write \[a *kethubah*\] and \[the husband\] asserted, 'I have written one' it is he who must produce the proof, where it is the usage to write one and she pleads. 'He did not write one for me' it is she that must produce the proof.[^fn_89a_19]

Rab[^fn_89a_20] also withdrew from \[his previously expressed opinion\]. For Rab had stated: Both in a place where \[a *kethubah*\] is written and in one where it is not written, a letter of divorce \[enables a woman to\] collect her statutory[^fn_89a_21] *kethubah* \[while the written document of the\] *kethubah* \[enables her to\] collect the additional jointure;[^fn_89a_22] and whosoever wishes to raise any objection may come and do so.[^fn_89a_23]

We have learned: \[A WOMAN, HOWEVER, WHO PRODUCED HER\] *KETHUBAH* WITHOUT A LETTER OF DIVORCE AND, WHILE SHE PLEADS, 'MY LETTER OF DIVORCE WAS LOST HE PLEADS, 'MY QUITTANCE WAS LOST'. AND SO ALSO A CREDITOR WHO PRODUCED A BOND OF INDEBTEDNESS WITHOUT A *PROSBUL*, THESE ARE NOT PAID. Now, according to Samuel[^fn_89a_24] this statement is quite intelligible since one might interpret it as applying to a locality where it is the practice to write \[no *kethubah*\] and the husband pleaded. 'I did write one'. In such a case \[the man\] might justly be told, 'Produce your evidence', and should he fail to do so he might well be told, 'Go and pay up'.[^fn_89a_25] According to Rab,[^fn_89a_26] however, \[the question arises,\] granted that she[^fn_89a_27] is not to collect her statutory *kethubah*,[^fn_89a_28] let her at least collect the additional jointure![^fn_89a_29] — R. Joseph replied: Here[^fn_89a_30] we are dealing with a case where no witnesses to the divorce were present. Since \[the husband\] could have pleaded. 'I have not divorced her',[^fn_89a_31] [pg 89b]

he is also entitled to plead, 'I have divorced her but I have already paid her the kethubah'.[^fn_89b_1]

But since it was stated in the final clause, R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL RULED: SINCE THE TIME OF DANGER A WOMAN IS ENTITLED TO COLLECT HER *KETHUBAH* WITHOUT A LETTER OF DIVORCE AND A CREDITOR IS ENTITLED TO COLLECT \[HIS DEBT\] WITHOUT A *PROSBUL*, \[it follows that\] we are dealing with a case where witnesses to the divorce are present; for had no such witnesses been present whereby could she have collected \[her *kethubah*\]?[^fn_89b_2] — \[The fact\], however, is that the entire Mishnah represents the view of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel, but some clauses are missing, the correct reading being the following: NEED NOT BE PAID'. This applies only where no witnesses to the divorce are present, but if such witnesses are present she is entitled to collect her additional jointure. As to the statutory *kethubah*, if she produces her letter of divorce she may collect it, but if she does not produce her letter of divorce she may not collect it.[^fn_89b_3] Since the time of danger, however, a woman may collect her *kethubah* even if she does not produce her letter of divorce, for R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL RULED; SINCE THE TIME OF DANGER A WOMAN IS ENTITLED TO COLLECT HER *KETHUBAH* WITHOUT A LETTER OF DIVORCE AND A CREDIT OR \[IS ENTITLED TO COLLECT HIS DEBT\] WITHOUT A PROSBUL'.

R. Kahana and R. Assi said to Rab; According to the ruling you have laid down that the statutory *kethubah* is collected by the letter of divorce, \[the question arises,\] whereby does a woman who was widowed after her marriage collect her *kethubah*? \[Obviously\] through the witnesses \[who testify to the\] death \[of her husband\]. Should we not, however, take into consideration the possibility that her husband might have divorced her and that she might subsequently[^fn_89b_4] produce the letter of divorce[^fn_89b_5] and collect[^fn_89b_6] with it also? — \[A widow may collect her *kethubah* only\] if she lived with her husband.[^fn_89b_7] But is it not possible that he might have divorced her near the time of his death?[^fn_89b_8] — \[In such a case\] it is he[^fn_89b_9] who has brought the loss upon himself.

Whereby does a woman who was widowed after her betrothal collect her *kethubah*? \[Obviously\] by the witnesses \[who testify to the man's\] death. Should we not, however, take into consideration the possibility that the man might have divorced her and that she would subsequently produce her letter of divorce and collect with it also?[^fn_89b_10] — \[This\],[^fn_89b_11] however, \[is the explanation:\][^fn_89b_12] Where no other course is possible a quittance may be written.[^fn_89b_13] For were you not to admit this \[the objection might be raised even in respect of\] the very witnesses \[who testify to her husband's\] death:[^fn_89b_14] The possibility should be considered that the woman might present \[one pair of\] witnesses to \[her husband's\] death before one court and so collect \[her *kethubah*\] and then present \[another pair\] before another court and collect it \[again\]. It must he obvious, therefore,[^fn_89b_15] that where no other course is possible a quittance may be written.

Said Mar Kashisha the son of R. Hisda to R. Ashi: Whence is it derived that a woman who was widowed after her betrothal is entitled to a *kethubah*.[^fn_89b_16] If it be suggested \[that it may he derived\] from this passage: 'A woman who was widowed or divorced either after her betrothal or after her marriage is entitled to collect all[^fn_89b_17] \[that is due to her\]',[^fn_89b_18] is it not possible \[it may be retorted that this applies to a case\] where the man had written a *kethubah* for her? And were you to argue. 'If he has written one for her, what need was there to tell \[such an obvious rule?' It could be retorted that it serves the purpose\] of rejecting the view of R. Eleazar b. Azariah who maintained that 'the man wrote the \[additional jointure\] for her with the sole object of marrying her'.[^fn_89b_19] The inference too \[from the Mishnah cited leads to the same conclusion\].[^fn_89b_20] For it has been stated, '\[She\] is entitled to collect all \[that is due to her\]'. Now if you agree that \[this is a case where\] the man had written \[a *kethubah*\] for her one can well understand why she 'is entitled to collect all \[that is due to her\]'.[^fn_89b_21] If you submit, however, that the man did not write a *kethubah* for her, what \[it may be objected is the justification for the expression.\] 'is entitled to collect all', seeing that she is only entitled to one hundred or two hundred[^fn_89b_22] *zuz*?[^fn_89b_23] \[Should it,\] however, \[be suggested that the law[^fn_89b_24] may be derived\] from that which R. Hiyya b. Abin[^fn_89b_25] taught: 'In the case of a betrothed wife[^fn_89b_26] \[a husband\] is neither \[subject to the laws of\] onan[^fn_89b_27] nor may he[^fn_89b_28] defile himself for her,[^fn_89b_29] and she likewise is not subject to the laws of the onan[^fn_89b_30] nor is she[^fn_89b_31] obliged[^fn_89b_32] to defile herself for him;[^fn_89b_33] if she died he[^fn_89b_34] does not inherit from her though if he died she is entitled to collect the amount of her kethubah',[^fn_89b_35] is it not possible \[it might be retorted that this refers only to a case\] where the man had written a *kethubah* for her? And should you argue. 'If he had written one for her what need was there to state \[such an obvious ruling?' It might be replied that\] 'it was necessary \[in order to inform us that if\] she died he does not inherit from her'.[^fn_89b_36]

R. Nahman said to R. Huna: According to Rab who laid down that a letter of divorce \[enables a woman to\] collect her statutory *kethubah*, is there no cause to apprehend that she might produce the letter of divorce at one court of law and collect her *kethubah* therewith and then again produce it at another court of law and collect therewith \[a second time\]? And should you reply that it might be torn up,[^fn_89b_37] could she not \[it may be retorted\] demand, 'I need \[it to be enabled\] thereby[^fn_89b_38] to marry again? — \[What we do is,\] we tear it up and endorse on the back of it: 'This letter of divorce has been torn by us, not because it is an invalid document but in order to prevent the woman from collecting therewith a second payments.

***MISHNAH***. \[A WOMAN WHO PRODUCED\] TWO LETTERS OF DIVORCE AND TWO KETHUBAHS MAY[^fn_89b_39] COLLECT PAYMENT OF THE TWO KETHUBAHS.[^fn_89b_40] \[IF SHE PRODUCES, HOWEVER.\] TWO KETHUBAHS AND ONE LETTER OF DIVORCE[^fn_89b_41] OR ONE *KETHUBAH* AND TWO LETTERS OF DIVORCE,[^fn_89b_42] OR A *KETHUBAH*, A LETTER OF DIVORCE AND \[EVIDENCE OF HER HUSBAND'S\] DEATH,[^fn_89b_43] SHE MAY COLLECT PAYMENT FOR ONE *KETHUBAH* ONLY, FOR ANY MAN WHO DIVORCES HIS WIFE AND THEN REMARRIES HER CONTRACTS HIS SECOND MARRIAGE ON THE CONDITION OF THE FIRST *KETHUBAH*.[^fn_89b_44] {¶=9.7}

***GEMARA***. If she desired it, she[^fn_89b_45] could \[evidently\][^fn_89b_46] collect \[payment of her *kethubah*\] either with the one *kethubah* or with the other.[^fn_89b_47] May it not then be argued that this ruling presents an objection against the ruling which R. Nahman stated in the name of Samuel? For R. Nahman stated in the name of Samuel: Where two bills[^fn_89b_48] are issued one after the other[^fn_89b_49] the latter annuls the former![^fn_89b_50] — Has it not been stated in connection with this ruling that R. Papa said: 'R. Nahman in fact admits that if one[^fn_89b_51] has added in the \[second\] bill one palm-tree[^fn_89b_52] \[it is assumed that\] he has written it[^fn_89b_53] for the sake of that addition',[^fn_89b_54] so also here \[it is a case\] where the husband has added something for her \[in the second *kethubah*\].[^fn_89b_55]

Our Rabbis taught: If \[a woman\] produced a letter of divorce, a *kethubah* and \[evidence of her husband's\] death[^fn_89b_56] [pg 90a]

she may. if the letter of divorce bears an earlier date than the *kethubah*, collect payment for two kethubahs,[^fn_90a_1] but if the *kethubah* bears an earlier date than the letter of divorce she may collect payment of one *kethubah* only, for any man who divorces his wife and then remarries her contracts his second marriage on the condition of the first *kethubah*.

***MISHNAH***. \[IN THE CASE OF\] A MINOR WHOM HIS FATHER HAD GIVEN IN MARRIAGE, THE *KETHUBAH* OF HIS WIFE[^fn_90a_2] REMAINS VALID,[^fn_90a_3] SINCE IT IS ON THIS CONDITION THAT HE KEPT HER AS HIS WIFE. \[IN THE CASE OF ONE WHO BECAME\] A PROSELYTE AND HIS WIFE WITH HIM, THE *KETHUBAH* REMAINS VALID,[^fn_90a_4] SINCE IT IS ON THIS CONDITION THAT HE KEPT HER AS HIS WIFE. {¶=9.8}

***GEMARA***. R. Huna stated: \[The ruling of our Mishnah\][^fn_90a_5] was given only in respect of the *maneh*[^fn_90a_6] or the two hundred *zuz*;[^fn_90a_7] to the additional jointure, however, she[^fn_90a_8] is not entitled.[^fn_90a_9] Rab Judah, however, stated: She[^fn_90a_10] is entitled \[to receive payment for\] her additional jointure also.

An objection was raised: If an additional monetary obligation was undertaken[^fn_90a_11] the woman receives that which was added.[^fn_90a_12] \[Thus it follows, does it not, that\] only if an additional monetary obligation was undertaken[^fn_90a_13] is the woman to receive any addition[^fn_90a_14] but if no such addition was made[^fn_90a_15] \[she does\] not \[receive any addition at all\]?[^fn_90a_16] — Read: 'Also that which had been added'.[^fn_90a_17] But surely, \[in the following Baraitha\] it was not taught so: 'If an additional monetary obligation was undertaken[^fn_90a_13] the woman receives that which was added, and if no additional monetary obligation was undertaken a virgin receives two hundred *zuz* and a widow receives a maneh'. Is not this then an objection against Rab Judah?[^fn_90a_18] — Rab Judah was misled by the wording of our Mishnah. He thought that the rule, 'THE *KETHUBAH* OF HIS WIFE REMAINS VALID', applied to the full amount;[^fn_90a_19] but in fact it is not so. It applies to the statutory *kethubah* alone.

## CHAPTER X

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN WAS MARRIED TO TWO WIVES AND DIED, THE FIRST \[WIFE\] TAXES PRECEDENCE[^fn_90a_20] OVER THE SECOND, AND THE HEIRS[^fn_90a_21] OF THE FIRST WIFE TAKE PRECEDENCE[^fn_90a_22] OVER THE HEIRS OF THE SECOND. IF HE MARRIED A FIRST WIFE AND SHE DIED AND THEN HE MARRIED A SECOND WIFE AND HE HIMSELF DIED,[^fn_90a_23] THE SECOND WIFE[^fn_90a_24] AND HER HEIRS[^fn_90a_25] TAKE PRECEDENCE OVER THE HEIRS OF THE FIRST WIFE.[^fn_90a_26] {¶=10.1}

***GEMARA***. Since it was stated THE FIRST \[WIFE\] TAKES PRECEDENCE OVER THE SECOND but not 'The first wife receives payment[^fn_90a_27] and the second does not',[^fn_90a_28] it may be implied that if the second wife forestalled \[the first\] and seized \[the payment of her *kethubah*\] it cannot be taken away from her.[^fn_90a_29] May it then be inferred from this ruling that if a creditor of a later date has forestalled \[one of an earlier date\] and 'distrained \[on the property of the debtor\], his distraint is of legal Validity?[^fn_90a_30] In fact it may be maintained that his distraint is of no legal validity, and as to \[the phrase\] TAKES PRECEDENCE, It means complete \[right of seizure\];[^fn_90a_31] as we have learned: A son takes precedence over a daughter.[^fn_90a_32]

Some there are who say: Since it was not stated, 'If the second wife forestalled \[the first\] and seized \[the payment of her *kethubah*\] it is not to he taken away from her', it may be implied that even if she has seized payment it may be taken away from her. May it then be concluded that if a creditor of a later date has forestalled \[one of an earlier date\] and distrained \[on the property of a debtor\] his distraint is of no legal Validity?[^fn_90a_33] — In fact it may be maintained that his distraint is of legal validity, only because the Tanna stated, THE SECOND WIFE AND HER HEIRS TAKE PRECEDENCE OVER THE HEIRS OF THE FIRST WIFE,[^fn_90a_34] [pg 90b]

he also taught. THE FIRST WIFE TAKES PRECEDENCE OVER THE SECOND.[^fn_90b_1]

IF A MAN MARRIED A FIRST WIFE. Three rulings may be inferred from this statement. It may be inferred that if one \[wife died\] during her husband's lifetime and the other after his death, \[the sons of the former\] are entitled to the *kethubah* of 'male children'[^fn_90b_2] and we do not apprehend any quarrelling.[^fn_90b_3] Whence is this inferred? Since it was stated, THE SECOND WIFE AND HER HEIRS TAKE PRECEDENCE OVER THE HEIRS OF THE FIRST WIFE \[it follows that\] they are only entitled to precedence but that if there is \[a balance, the others also\] take \[their share\]. It may also be inferred that the *kethubah* \[of the second wife\][^fn_90b_4] may be regarded as the surplus[^fn_90b_5] over the other.[^fn_90b_6] Whence is this inferred? Since it was not stated \[that payment[^fn_90b_7] is made only\] if a surplus of a *denar* remained there. Furthermore It may be inferred that a *kethubah* \[claimed by virtue\] of the 'male children' \[clause\] may not be distrained on mortgaged property;[^fn_90b_8] for if it could be imagined that it may be distrained on mortgaged property, the sons of the first wife[^fn_90b_9] should \[be entitled to\] come and distrain on \[the property\] of the sons of the second.[^fn_90b_10]

To this R. Ashi demurred: Whence \[these conclusions\]? Might I not in fact maintain that if one \[wife died\] while her husband was alive, and the other after his death, \[the sons of the former\] are not entitled to the *kethubah* \[that they claim by virtue\] of the 'male children' clause, whilst the expression of[^fn_90b_11] TAKE PRECEDENCE[^fn_90b_12] might refer[^fn_90b_13] to the inheritance?[^fn_90b_14] And were you to retort: What was the object[^fn_90b_15] \[of the description\] THE HEIRS OF THE FIRST WIFE?[^fn_90b_16] \[I might reply that\] as the Tanna used the expression, THE SECOND WIFE AND HER HEIRS[^fn_90b_17] he also spoke of THE HEIRS OF THE FIRST WIFE![^fn_90b_18] And with reference to your conclusion that 'the *kethubah* \[of the second wife\] may be regarded as a surplus over the other', might I not in fact still maintain that no *kethubah* may be regarded as a surplus over the other, but here[^fn_90b_19] it is a case where there was a surplus of a *denar*![^fn_90b_20] 

\[As to the case where\] one \[wife died\] during her husband's lifetime and the other after his death, this is \[a matter in dispute[^fn_90b_21] between\] Tannaim. For it was taught: \[If a man's wives\] died, one during his lifetime and the other after his death, the sons of the first wife, Ben Nannus ruled, can say to the sons of the second,[^fn_90b_22] 'You are the sons of a creditor;[^fn_90b_23] take your mother's *kethubah*[^fn_90b_24] and go'.[^fn_90b_25] R. Akiba said: The inheritance[^fn_90b_26] has already been transferred[^fn_90b_27] from \[the sole right of inheritance by\] the sons of the first wife[^fn_90b_28] \[the joint right of inheritance by these and\] the sons of the second.[^fn_90b_29] Do they[^fn_90b_30] not differ on the following principle: One Master[^fn_90b_31] holds the Opinion that where one \[wife died\] during her husband's lifetime and the other after his death \[the sons of the former\] are entitled to the *kethubah* \[of their mother by Virtue of the\] 'male children' clause, and the other Master holds that where one \[wife died\] during a husband's lifetime and the other after his death \[the sons of the former\] are not entitled to the 'male children' *kethubah*?[^fn_90b_32] Said Rabbah: I found the young scholars of the academy while they were sitting \[at their studies\] and arguing: All[^fn_90b_33] \[may hold the view that where\] one \[wife died\] during her husband's lifetime and the other after his death \[the sons of the former\] are entitled to \[their mother's\] 'male children' *kethubah*, but here they[^fn_90b_34] differ \[on the principle whether the second wife's\][^fn_90b_35] *kethubah* may be regarded[^fn_90b_36] as a surplus over the other; and the same dispute applies to \[the debt\] of a creditor.[^fn_90b_37] One Master[^fn_90b_31] holds that the \[second wife's\][^fn_90b_35] *kethubah* is regarded as a surplus over the other,[^fn_90b_36] and the same law applies to \[the debt\] of a creditor, and the other Master holds that no one *kethubah* may be regarded as a surplus over the other, and the same law applies to \[the debt\] of a creditor. Thereupon I said to them: In respect of \[a claim of\] a creditor no ones disputes \[the view\] that \[the debt\] is regarded as a surplus;[^fn_90b_38] they[^fn_90b_30] only differ in respect of a *kethubah*.[^fn_90b_39]

To this R. Joseph demurred: If so[^fn_90b_40] \[instead of saying.\] 'R. Akiba said: The inheritance has already been transferred' it should \[have said.\] 'If there is a surplus of a *denar* \[the sons of the first wife receive their mother's *kethubah*\].'[^fn_90b_41] \[The fact\]. however, is, said R. Joseph. that they[^fn_90b_42] differ \[on the question whether the 'male children' *kethubah* is payable where\] one \[wife died\] during her husband's lifetime and the other after his death.[^fn_90b_43]

These Tannaim[^fn_90b_44] \[differ on the same principle\] as the following Tannaim. For it was taught: If a man married his first wife and she died and then he married his second wife and he himself died, the sons of this wife[^fn_90b_44] may come after \[her\][^fn_90b_45] death and exact their mother's *kethubah*.[^fn_90b_46] R. Simeon ruled: If there is a surplus of one *denar*[^fn_90b_47] both[^fn_90b_48] receive the kethubahs of their mothers but if no \[such surplus remains\] they[^fn_90b_48] divide \[the residue\][^fn_90b_49] in equal portions. Do they[^fn_90b_50] not differ on this principle: Whereas one Master[^fn_90b_51] holds that where one \[wife died\] during her husband's lifetime and the other after his death \[the sons of the former\] are entitled to the 'male children' *kethubah*, the other Master holds that where one \[wife died\] during her husband's lifetime and the other after his death \[the children of the former\] are not entitled to the 'male children' *kethubah*?[^fn_90b_52] No; all[^fn_90b_53] may agree that where one \[wife died\] during her husband's lifetime and the other after his death \[the sons of the former\] are to receive the 'male children' *kethubah*, [pg 91a]

but they differ here on \[the question whether it is necessary for the surplus\] *denar* to consist of real estate. The one Master[^fn_91a_1] holds that only real estate is regarded as a surplus[^fn_91a_2] but not movables[^fn_91a_3] and the other Master[^fn_91a_4] holds that even movables \[are regarded as surplus\].[^fn_91a_5] But can you say so?[^fn_91a_6] Have we not learned, R. Simeon ruled: Even if there was movable property[^fn_91a_7] it is of no avail[^fn_91a_8] unless there was landed property \[of the Value of\] one *denar* more than \[the total amount of\] the two kethubahs?[^fn_91a_9] — \[The fact,\] however, is that they[^fn_91a_10] differ here on \[the question whether\] a *denar* of mortgaged property \[is regarded as a surplus\]. One Master[^fn_91a_11] holds that only free property constitutes a surplus[^fn_91a_12] but not mortgaged property, and the other Master[^fn_91a_13] holds that mortgaged property also \[constitutes a surplus\]. If so,[^fn_91a_14] \[instead of stating,\] 'R. Simeon ruled: If there is a surplus of one denar', should it not have been stated, 'Since there is a surplus of one denar'? — The fact, however, is that they[^fn_91a_10] differ on \[the question whether a sum\] less than a *denar* \[constitutes a surplus\]. One Master[^fn_91a_15] is of the opinion that only a *denar* constitutes a surplus[^fn_91a_16] but not a sum less than a *denar*, and the other Master[^fn_91a_17] holds that even less than a *denar* \[constitutes a surplus\]. But did not R. Simeon, however, say 'a denar'? And were you to reply. 'Reverse \[their views\]',[^fn_91a_18] does not the first Tanna of the Mishnah[^fn_91a_19] \[it may be retorted\] also speak of a *denar*?[^fn_91a_20] — The fact, however, \[is that we must follow\] on the lines of the first two explanations. and reverse \[the views\].[^fn_91a_21]

Mar Zutra stated in the name of R. Papa: The law \[is that where\] one \[wife died\] during her husband's lifetime and the other after his death \[the sons of the former\] are entitled to the 'male children' *kethubah*, and that one *kethubah*[^fn_91a_22] is regarded as the surplus over the other. \[Now\] granted that if we had been told that '\[where\] one \[wife died\] during her husband's lifetime and the other after his death \[the sons of the former\] are entitled to the "male children" kethubah', but had not been told that 'one *kethubah* is regarded as the surplus over the other' it might have been presumed \[that the former law applied\] Only where the surplus amounted to a *denar* but not otherwise.[^fn_91a_23] \[Why,\] however, could we \[not have\] been informed \[of the second law only, viz., that\] 'one *kethubah* is regarded as the surplus over the other', and it would have been self-evident,[^fn_91a_24] \[would it not, that this ruling was\] due to \[the law that 'where\] one \[wife died\] during her husband's lifetime and the other after his death \[the sons of the former\] are entitled to the "male children" kethubah'?[^fn_91a_25] — If we were given the information in such a manner, \[the law\] might have been presumed \[to apply to a case,\] for instance, where a man had married three wives of whom two died during his lifetime and one after his death, and the last mentioned had given birth to a daughter who is not entitled to heirship.[^fn_91a_26] but \[not to the case where\] one \[wife died\] during her husband's lifetime and the other after his death and the latter had given birth to a son, \[since in this case\] the possibility of a quarrel[^fn_91a_27] might have to be taken into consideration,[^fn_91a_28] hence we were taught \[that even in this case one *kethubah*[^fn_91a_29] is regarded as surplus over the other\].[^fn_91a_30]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN WAS MARRIED TO TWO WIVES AND THEY DIED, AND SUBSEQUENTLY HE HIMSELF DIED, AND THE ORPHANS \[OF ONE OF THE WIVES\][^fn_91a_31] CLAIM THEIR MOTHER'S KETHUBAH[^fn_91a_32] \[BUT THE ESTATE OF THE DECEASED HUSBAND\] IS ONLY ENOUGH[^fn_91a_33] \[FOR THE SETTLEMENT OF THE\] TWO KETHUBAHS[^fn_91a_34] \[ALL THE ORPHANS\] RECEIVE EQUAL SHARES.[^fn_91a_35] IF THERE WAS A SURPLUS[^fn_91a_36] OF \[A MINIMUM OF\] ONE DEN A R,[^fn_91a_37] EACH GROUP OF SONS[^fn_91a_38] RECEIVE THE *KETHUBAH* OF THEIR MOTHER.[^fn_91a_39] IF THE ORPHANS \[OF ONE OF THE WIVES\][^fn_91a_40] SAID, 'WE ARE OFFERING FOR OUR FATHER'S ESTATE ONE DEN AR MORE \[THAN THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF THE KETHUBAHS\]', IN ORDER THAT THEY \[MIGHT THEREBY BE ENABLED TO\] TAKE THEIR MOTHER'S *KETHUBAH*[^fn_91a_41] THEIR REQUEST IS DISREGARDED[^fn_91a_42] AND[^fn_91a_43] THE ESTATE IS \[PROPERLY\] VALUED AT THE *BETH DIN*. IF THE ESTATE INCLUDED[^fn_91a_44] PROSPECTIVE PROPERTY,[^fn_91a_45] IT IS NOT \[REGARDED\] AS \[PROPERTY HELD\] IN ACTUAL POSSESSION.[^fn_91a_46] R. SIMEON RULED: EVEN IF THERE WAS MOVABLE PROPERTY[^fn_91a_47] IT IS OF NO AVAIL[^fn_91a_48] UNLESS THERE WAS LANDED PROPERTY \[WORTH\] ONE *DENAR* MORE THAN \[ THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF\] THE TWO KETHUBAHS. {¶=10.2}

***GEMARA***. Our Rabbis taught: If one wife had[^fn_91a_49] \[a *kethubah* for\] a thousand \[*zuz*\] and the other for five hundred, each group of sons[^fn_91a_50] receive the *kethubah* of their mother provided a surplus of one *denar* was available; otherwise, they must divide the estate in equal proportions.

It is obvious \[that if[^fn_91a_51] the estate was\] large[^fn_91a_52] and[^fn_91a_53] it depreciated,[^fn_91a_54] the heirs have already[^fn_91a_55] acquired ownership thereof.[^fn_91a_56] What, \[however, is the ruling where the estate was\] small and it appreciated?[^fn_91a_57] — Come and hear the case of the estate of the house of Bar Zarzur which was small and it appreciated, and when \[the heirs\] came \[with their suit\] before R. Amram he said to them, 'It is your duty[^fn_91a_58] to satisfy them'.[^fn_91a_59] As they disregarded \[his ruling\] he said to them, 'If you will not satisfy them I will chastise you with a thorn that causes no blood to flow'.[^fn_91a_60] Thereupon he sent them to R. Nahman, who said to them 'Just as \[in the case where an estate was\] large and it depreciated [pg 91b]

the heirs have already acquired ownership thereof, so \[also where the estate was\] small and it appreciated the other heirs[^fn_91b_1] have already[^fn_91b_2] acquired ownership thereof.[^fn_91b_3]

(Mnemonic:[^fn_91b_4] A thousand and a hundred duty in a *kethubah*, Jacob put up his fields by words \[of\] claimants.) A man against whom there was a claim of a thousand *zuz* had two mansions each of which he sold[^fn_91b_5] for five hundred *zuz*. The creditor thereupon came and distrained on one of them and then he was going to distrain on the other. \[Whereupon the purchaser\] took one thousand *zuz*, and went to \[the creditor\] and said to him, 'If \[the one mansion\] is worth to you one thousand *zuz*, well and good; but if not, take your thousand[^fn_91b_6] *zuz* and go'.[^fn_91b_7] Rami b. Hama \[in dealing with the question\] proposed that this case was exactly analogous to that in our Mishnah: IF THE ORPHANS \[OF ONE OF THE WIVES\] SAID, 'WE ARE OFFERING FOR OUR FATHER'S ESTATE ONE *DENAR* MORE'.[^fn_91b_8] But Raba said to him, 'Are the two cases at all alike? There[^fn_91b_9] the orphans[^fn_91b_10] would be suffering a loss, but here, does the creditor suffer any loss? He only advanced a thousand *zuz* and a thousand *zuz* he receives

And for what amount is the tirpa[^fn_91b_11] made out?[^fn_91b_12] — Rabina said: For a thousand *zuz*. R. 'Awira said: For five hundred. And the law is \[that the tirpa is made out\] for five hundred.

A certain man against whom someone had a claim for a hundred *zuz* had two small plots of land each of which he sold[^fn_91b_5] for fifty *zuz*. His creditor came and distrained on one of them and then he came again to distrain on the other. \[The purchaser. thereupon.\] took a hundred *zuz* and went to him and said, 'If \[one of the plots\] is worth a hundred *zuz*[^fn_91b_13] to you. well and good; but if not, take the one hundred *zuz* and go'.[^fn_91b_14] R. Joseph \[in considering the question\] proposed to say that this was a case exactly analogous to that in our Mishnah: IF THE ORPHANS \[OF ONE OF THE WIVES\] SAID[^fn_91b_15] etc. But Abaye said to him, 'Are the two cases at all alike? There the orphans would have suffered a loss, but here, what loss would \[the creditor\] have? He lent a hundred and receives a hundred'.

For what amount is the tirpa made out? — Rabina said: For a hundred. R. 'Awira said: For fifty. And the law is \[that it is made out\] for fifty.

A certain man against whom there was a claim for a hundred *zuz* died and left a small plot of land that was worth fifty *zuz*. As his creditor came and distrained on it the orphans went to him and handed to him fifty *zuz*. Thereupon he distrained on it again. When they came \[with this action\] before Abaye. he said to them, 'It is a moral duty incumbent upon orphans[^fn_91b_16] to pay the debt of their father.[^fn_91b_17] With the first payment you have performed a moral duty. and now that he has seized \[the land again\] his action is perfectly lawful',[^fn_91b_18] This ruling. however, applies only in the case where \[the orphans\] did not tell him,[^fn_91b_19] 'These fifty *zuz* are for the price of the small plot of land', but if they did tell him, 'these fifty *zuz* are for the price of the small plot of land',[^fn_91b_20] they have thereby entirely dismissed him,[^fn_91b_21]

A certain man[^fn_91b_22] once sold the *kethubah* of his mother[^fn_91b_23] for a goodwill \[price\][^fn_91b_24] and said to \[the buyer\], 'If mother comes and raises objections I shall not pay you any compensation'.[^fn_91b_25] His mother then died having raised no objections. but he himself[^fn_91b_26] came and objected.[^fn_91b_27] Rami b. Hama \[in discussing the case\] proposed to decide that he[^fn_91b_28] takes the place of his mother. Raba, however, said to him: Granted that he did not accept any responsibility for her action, did he not accept responsibility for his own action either?[^fn_91b_29]

Rami b. Hama stated: If Reuben[^fn_91b_30] sold a field to Simeon[^fn_91b_30] without a guarantee[^fn_91b_31] and Simeon then re-sold it to Reuben with a guarantee [pg 92a]

and Reuben's creditor[^fn_92a_1] came and seized it from him, the law is that Simeon must proceed to offer him[^fn_92a_2] compensation.[^fn_92a_3] Raba, however, said to him: Granted that \[Simeon\] had accepted responsibility for general claims,[^fn_92a_4] did he also accept responsibility for \[claims against Reuben\] himself?[^fn_92a_5] Raba admits, however, that where Reuben inherited a field from Jacob[^fn_92a_6] and sold it to Simeon[^fn_92a_7] without a guarantee and Simeon then re-sold It to Reuben with a guarantee. whereupon Jacob's creditor came and seized it from him, the law is that Simeon must proceed to offer him[^fn_92a_8] compensation.[^fn_92a_9] What is the reason? — Jacob's creditor is regarded as any other creditor.[^fn_92a_10]

Rami b. Hama \[further\] stated: If Reuben sold a field to Simeon with a guarantee and allowed \[the price of the field\] to stand[^fn_92a_11] as a loan,[^fn_92a_12] and when Reuben died, and his creditor came to seize it from Simeon, \[the latter\] satisfied him by \[refunding to him the\] amount,[^fn_92a_13] the law is that Reuben's children can tell him, '\[As far as\] we \[are concerned,\] our father has left movables[^fn_92a_14] with you. and the movables of orphans are not pledged to a creditor.'[^fn_92a_15]

Raba remarked: If the other[^fn_92a_16] is clever he gives them[^fn_92a_17] a plot of land in settlement of the debt and then he collects it from them,[^fn_92a_18] in accordance \[with a ruling of\] R. Nahman who stated in the name of Rabbah b. Abbahu: If orphans collected a plot of land for their father's debt,[^fn_92a_19] a creditor[^fn_92a_20] may in turn collect it from them.[^fn_92a_21]

Rabbah[^fn_92a_22] stated: If Reuben sold all his fields[^fn_92a_23] to Simeon who In turn sold one field \[of these\] to Levi, and then Reuben's creditor appeared,[^fn_92a_24] \[the latter\] may collect either from the one or from the other.[^fn_92a_25] This law, however, applies only where \[Levi\] had bought \[land of\] medium quality, but if he bought either the best or the worst he may tell him,[^fn_92a_26] 'It is for this reason[^fn_92a_27] that I have taken the trouble \[to buy the best or the worst because either is\] land which is not available for you'.[^fn_92a_28] And even \[when he bought\] medium quality the law is applicable only where \[Levi\] did not leave[^fn_92a_29] medium quality of a similar nature [pg 92b]

but if he did leave medium quality of a similar nature he may lawfully tell him,[^fn_92b_1] 'I have left for you ample land[^fn_92b_2] from which to collect \[your debt\]'.

Abaye stated: If Reuben sold a field to Simeon with a guarantee and a creditor of Reuben's came to distrain on it the law is that Reuben may proceed to litigate[^fn_92b_3] with that creditor and \[the latter\] cannot say to him, 'You are no party to me'[^fn_92b_4] for \[the other can\] retort, 'For whatever you will take away from him he will turn to me \[to claim compensation\]'[^fn_92b_5] Others say: Even where no guarantee was given[^fn_92b_6] the same law[^fn_92b_7] applies, since \[Reuben\] may say to him,[^fn_92b_8] 'I do not like Simeon to have any grievance against me

Abaye \[further\] stated: If Reuben sold a field to Simeon without a guarantee and there appeared against him[^fn_92b_9] [pg 93a]

claimants[^fn_93a_1] \[disputing his title to the field\][^fn_93a_2] he[^fn_93a_3] may withdraw before he has taken possession of it,[^fn_93a_4] but after he had taken possession of it[^fn_93a_5] he may no longer withdraw,[^fn_93a_6] because \[Reuben\] can say to him,[^fn_93a_3] 'You have agreed to a bag sealed with knots[^fn_93a_7] and you got it'.[^fn_93a_8] And from what moment is possession considered to have been effected? — As soon as he[^fn_93a_9] sets his foot upon the landmarks.[^fn_93a_10] Others say: Even \[If the sale was made\] with a guarantee the same law[^fn_93a_11] applies. since \[the seller\] might say to him, 'Produce the tirpa[^fn_93a_12] \[that was issued against\] you and I shall pay you'.[^fn_93a_13]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN WHO WAS MARRIED TO THREE WIVES DIED, AND THE *KETHUBAH* OF ONE[^fn_93a_14] WAS A *MANEH*,[^fn_93a_15] OF THE OTHER[^fn_93a_14] TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ*, AND OF THE THIRD[^fn_93a_14] THREE HUNDRED *ZUZ*[^fn_93a_16] AND THE ESTATE[^fn_93a_17] \[WAS WORTH\] ONLY ONE *MANEH*[^fn_93a_18] \[THE SUM\] IS DIVIDED EQUALLY.[^fn_93a_19] IF THE ESTATE[^fn_93a_20] \[WAS WORTH\] TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ* \[THE CLAIMANT\] OF THE *MANEH* RECEIVES FIFTY *ZUZ*[^fn_93a_21] \[AND THE CLAIMANTS RESPECTIVELY\] OF THE TWO HUNDRED AND THE THREE HUNDRED *ZUZ* \[RECEIVE EACH\] THREE GOLD *DENARII*.[^fn_93a_22] IF THE ESTATE[^fn_93a_23] \[WAS WORTH\] THREE HUNDRED *ZUZ*,[^fn_93a_24] \[THE CLAIMANT\] OF THE *MANEH* RECEIVES FIFTY *ZUZ*[^fn_93a_25] AND \[THE CLAIMANT\] OF THE TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ* \[RECEIVES\] A *MANEH*[^fn_93a_25] WHILE \[THE CLAIMANT\] OF THE THREE HUNDRED *ZUZ* \[RECEIVES\] SIX GOLD *DENARII*.[^fn_93a_26] SIMILARLY, IF THREE PERSONS CONTRIBUTED TO A JOINT FUND[^fn_93a_27] AND THEY HAD MADE A LOSS OR A PROFIT THEY SHARE IN THE SAME MANNER.[^fn_93a_28] {¶=10.3}

***GEMARA***. \[THE CLAIMANT\] OF THE *MANEH* RECEIVES FIFTY *ZUZ*. Should she not be entitled to thirty-three and a third *zuz* only?[^fn_93a_29] — Samuel replied: \[Here it is a case\] where the one who is entitled to the two hundred *zuz* gave a written undertaking to the woman who was entitled to one *maneh*, 'I have no claim whatsoever upon the maneh'.[^fn_93a_30] But if so,[^fn_93a_31] read the next clause: \[THE CLAIMANTS RESPECTIVELY\] OF THE TWO HUNDRED, AND THE THREE HUNDRED *ZUZ* \[RECEIVE EACH\] THREE GOLD *DENARII*, \[why, it may be objected, could she[^fn_93a_32] not\] tell her,[^fn_93a_33] 'You have already renounced your claim upon[^fn_93a_34] it'? — Because she can reply. 'I have only renounced my claim'.[^fn_93a_35]

IF THE ESTATE \[WAS WORTH\] THREE HUNDRED etc. \[Why should THE CLAIMANT\] OF THE TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ*[^fn_93a_36] RECEIVE A *MANEH* \[when in fact\] she should be entitled to seventy-five *zuz* only?[^fn_93a_37] — Samuel replied: \[Our Mishnah refers to a case\] where the woman who was entitled to the three hundred *zuz* gave a written undertaking to the one who was entitled to the two hundred *zuz* and the other who was entitled to a *maneh*, 'I have no claim whatsoever upon you in respect of one maneh'.[^fn_93a_38] R. Jacob of Nehar Pekod[^fn_93a_39] replied in the name of Rabina: The first clause deals with two acts of seizure[^fn_93a_40] and the final clause deals with two acts of seizure.[^fn_93a_40] 'The first clause deals with two acts of seizure' viz. seventy-five *zuz* came into their hands[^fn_93a_41] the first[^fn_93a_42] time[^fn_93a_43] and one hundred and twenty-five the second[^fn_93a_42] time.[^fn_93a_44] 'The final clause deals with two acts of seizure, viz., seventy-five came into their hands[^fn_93a_41] the first[^fn_93a_42] time[^fn_93a_43] and two hundred and twenty-five the second[^fn_93a_42] time.[^fn_93a_45]

It was taught: This[^fn_93a_46] is the teaching of R. Nathan. Rabbi,[^fn_93a_47] however, said, 'I do not approve[^fn_93a_48] of R. Nathan's views in these \[cases\][^fn_93a_46] for[^fn_93a_49] \[the three wives\][^fn_93a_50] take equal shares'.[^fn_93a_51]

SIMILARLY IF THREE PERSONS CONTRIBUTED. Samuel ruled: If two persons contributed to a joint fund,[^fn_93a_52] one of them a *maneh*, and the other two hundred *zuz*, [pg 93b]

the profit is to be equally divided.[^fn_93b_1]

Rabbah said: It stands to reason \[that Samuel's ruling applies\] where an ox \[was purchased\][^fn_93b_2] for ploughing and Was used[^fn_93b_3] for ploughing.[^fn_93b_4] Where, however, an ox \[was purchased\] for ploughing[^fn_93b_5] and was used[^fn_93b_3] for slaughter[^fn_93b_6] each of the Partners[^fn_93b_7] receives a share in proportion to his capital.[^fn_93b_8] R. Hamnuna, however, ruled: Where an ox \[was bought\] for ploughing,[^fn_93b_9] even if it was used[^fn_93b_3] for slaughter[^fn_93b_10] the profit must be equally divided.[^fn_93b_11]

An objection was raised: If two persons contributed to a joint fund,[^fn_93b_12] one of them a *maneh*, and the other, two hundred *zuz*, the profit is to be equally divided.[^fn_93b_13] Does not this refer to an ox \[bought\] for ploughing and used[^fn_93b_3] for slaughter, and \[thus presenting\] an objection against Rabbah? — No, it refers to an ox that was bought for ploughing and was used for ploughing.[^fn_93b_9] What, however, \[is the law where\] an ox \[was bought\] for ploughing and used[^fn_93b_3] for killing? Does each partner[^fn_93b_7] \[in such a case\] receive a share in proportion to his capital? Then instead of stating in the final clause, 'If one man had bought \[some oxen\] out of his own money and the other \[had bought some\] out of his own money[^fn_93b_14] and the animals were mixed up, each partner[^fn_93b_7] receives a share in proportion to his capital',[^fn_93b_15] could not a distinction have been made in the very same case,[^fn_93b_16] \[thus:\] 'This[^fn_93b_17] applies only where an ox was bought for ploughing and was used for ploughing, but where an ox was bought for ploughing and was used for slaughter each partner receives a share in proportion to his capital'? — It is this, in fact, that[^fn_93b_18] was implied: 'This[^fn_93b_19] applies only where an ox was bought for ploughing and was used for ploughing. but where an ox was bought for ploughing and was used for slaughter' the law is the same as 'if one man had bought \[some oxen\] out of his own money and the other \[had bought some\] out of his own money, and the animals were mixed up \[in which case\] each party receives a share in proportion to his capital'.

We learned: SIMILARLY IF THREE PERSONS CONTRIBUTED TO A JOINT FUND AND THEY MADE A LOSS OR A PROFIT THEY SHARE IN THE SAME MANNER. Does not 'THEY MADE A LOSS mean that they made a loss on their actual transaction, and A PROFIT' that they made a profit on their actual transaction?[^fn_93b_20] — R. Nahman replied in the name of Rabbah b. Abbuha: No; they made 'A PROFIT' \[owing to the issue of\] new coins[^fn_93b_21] and THEY MADE A LOSS' \[by the deterioration of a coin into\] an istira[^fn_93b_22] that was only suitable for application to a bunion.[^fn_93b_23]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN WHO WAS MARRIED TO FOUR WIVES DIED, HIS FIRST WIFE[^fn_93b_24] TAKES PRECEDENCE[^fn_93b_25] OVER THE SECOND, THE SECOND TAKES PRECEDENCE OVER THE THIRD AND THE THIRD OVER THE FOURTH. THE FIRST MUST TAKE AN OATH[^fn_93b_26] \[IN ORDER TO GIVE SATISFACTION\] TO THE SECOND,[^fn_93b_27] THE SECOND TO THE THIRD,[^fn_93b_28] AND THE THIRD TO THE FOURTH,[^fn_93b_28] WHILE THE FOURTH RECOVERS PAYMENT WITHOUT AN OATH.[^fn_93b_29] BEN NANNUS SAID: SHOULD SHE[^fn_93b_30] HAVE THE ADVANTAGE BECAUSE SHE IS THE LAST? SHE ALSO MAY NOT EXACT PAYMENT EXCEPT ON OATH, IF ALL \[KETHUBAHS\] WERE ISSUED ON THE SAME DAY THEN THE WOMAN \[WHOSE *KETHUBAH*\] PRECEDED THAT OF THE OTHER, EVEN IF ONLY BY ONE HOUR,[^fn_93b_31] GAINS \[THE FIRST RIGHT\]. AND SO IT WAS THE CUSTOM IN JERUSALEM TO INSERT THE HOURS \[IN SUCH DOCUMENTS\]. IF ALL KETHUBAHS WERE ISSUED AT THE SAME HOUR AND THE ESTATE IS WORTH NO MORE[^fn_93b_32] THAN A *MANEH* \[THE WOMEN\] RECEIVE EQUAL. SHARES. {¶=10.4}

***GEMARA***. On what principle do they[^fn_93b_33] differ? — Samuel replied: [pg 94a]

\[Their dispute relates to a case,\] for instance, where It was found that one of the fields[^fn_94a_1] did not belong to him,[^fn_94a_2] their point of difference[^fn_94a_3] being the question \[of the legality of the action\] of a creditor of a later date who forestalled \[one of an earlier date\] and distrained \[on the debtor's property\]. The first Tanna holds that such distraint has no legal validity,[^fn_94a_4] and Ben Nannus holds that whatever he distrained on is legally his,[^fn_94a_5] R. Nahman in the name of Rabbah b. Abbuha replied: Both[^fn_94a_6] agree that the distraint \[of a creditor of a later date\] has no legal validity,[^fn_94a_7] but here they differ on the question whether provision is to be made against the possibility that \[the fourth woman might\] allow the ground to deteriorate. One Master[^fn_94a_8] is of the opinion that provision is to be made against the possibility that she[^fn_94a_9] might allow the ground[^fn_94a_10] to deteriorate,[^fn_94a_11] and the other Master is of the opinion that no provision need be made against such a possibility. Abaye replied: The difference between them[^fn_94a_6] is the ruling of Abaye the Elder who stated: The 'orphans' spoken of[^fn_94a_12] are grown-ups and there is no need to say that minors[^fn_94a_13] \[are included\].[^fn_94a_14] The first Tanna[^fn_94a_15] does not hold the view of Abaye the Elder while Ben Nannus upholds it.[^fn_94a_16]

R. Huna stated: If two brothers or two partners had a lawsuit[^fn_94a_17] against a third party[^fn_94a_18] and one of them went with that person to law,[^fn_94a_19] the other[^fn_94a_20] cannot say to him,[^fn_94a_21] 'You are not my party'[^fn_94a_22] because[^fn_94a_23] \[the one who went to law\] acted on his behalf also.[^fn_94a_24]

R. Nahman once visited Sura[^fn_94a_25] and was asked what the law was in such a case.[^fn_94a_26] He replied: This is \[a case that has been stated in\] our Mishnah: THE FIRST MUST TAKE AN OATH \[IN ORDER TO GIVE SATISFACTION\] TO THE SECOND, THE SECOND TO THE THIRD AND THE THIRD TO THE FOURTH, but it was not stated, 'the first to the third'. Now, what could be the reason?[^fn_94a_27] Obviously[^fn_94a_28] because \[the second\] has acted on her behalf also.

But are \[the two cases\] alike? In the latter,[^fn_94a_29] an oath for one person is the same as an oath for a hundred,[^fn_94a_30] but in this case[^fn_94a_31] he[^fn_94a_32] might well plead, 'Had I been present I would have submitted more convincing arguments'.[^fn_94a_33] This,[^fn_94a_34] however, applies only when he[^fn_94a_32] was not In town \[when the action was tried\] but if he was in town \[his plea is disregarded, since if he had any valid arguments\] he ought to have come.[^fn_94a_35]

It was stated: If two deeds[^fn_94a_36] bearing the same date[^fn_94a_37] \[are presented in court,[^fn_94a_38] the property in question\],[^fn_94a_39] Rab ruled, should be divided \[between the two claimants\], and Samuel ruled: \[The case is to be decided at\] the discretion of the judges.[^fn_94a_40] Must it be assumed that Rab follows the view Of R. Meir who holds that the signatures of the witnesses make \[a Get\] effective,[^fn_94a_41] [pg 94b]

and that Samuel follows the view of R. Eleazar who holds that the witnesses to the delivery \[Of a Get\] make it effective?[^fn_94b_1] — No, all[^fn_94b_2] follow the view of R. Eleazar,[^fn_94b_3] but it is the following Principle on which they differ here. Rab is of the opinion that a division \[between the claimants\] is preferable and Samuel holds that \[leaving the decision to\] the discretion Of the judges is prefer. able. But can you maintain that Rab follows the view Of R. Eleazar? Surely, Rab Judah stated in the name of Rab, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eleazar in matters Of divorce' \[and he added.\] 'When I mentioned this in Samuel's presence he said: "Also in the case of other deeds". Does not this then imply that Rab is of the opinion that in the case Of deeds \[the *halachah* is\] not \[in agreement with R. Eleazar\]?' Clearly. Rab follows the view Of R. Meir and Samuel that of R. Eleazar.

An objection was raised: 'If two deeds[^fn_94b_4] bearing the same date \[are produced in court, the property In question\] is to be divided. Is not this an objection against Samuel?[^fn_94b_5] — Samuel can answer you: This represents the view of[^fn_94b_6] R. Meir but I follow the view of R. Eleazar.[^fn_94b_7]

But if this[^fn_94b_8] represents the view of R. Meir, read the final clause: 'If he[^fn_94b_9] wrote \[a deed\] for one man[^fn_94b_10] \[and then he wrote a deed for,\] and delivered it to another man, the one to whom he delivered \[the deed\] acquires legal possession'. Now if \[this[^fn_94b_8] represents the view of\] R. Meir why does he acquire possession? Did he not, in fact, lay down that the signatures of the witnesses[^fn_94b_11] make \[a Get\] effective?[^fn_94b_12] — This[^fn_94b_13] \[is a question which is also in dispute between\] Tannaim.[^fn_94b_14] For it was taught: And the Sages say \[that the money\][^fn_94b_15] must[^fn_94b_16] be divided,[^fn_94b_17] while here[^fn_94b_18] it was ruled that the trustee[^fn_94b_19] shall use his own discretion.[^fn_94b_20]

The mother of Rami b. Hama[^fn_94b_21] gave her property in writing to Rami b. Hama in the morning, but in the evening she gave it in writing to Mar 'Ukba b. Hama.[^fn_94b_22] Rami b. Hama came before R. Shesheth who confirmed him in the possession of the property. Mar 'Ukba then appeared before R. Nahman who Similarly confirmed him in the possession of the property. R. Shesheth, thereupon, came to R. Nahman and said to him, 'What is the reason that the Master has acted in this way?' 'And what is the reason', the other retorted, 'that the Master has acted in that way?' 'Because', the former replied, '\[Rami's deed was written\] first',[^fn_94b_23] 'Are we then', the other retorted, 'living in Jerusalem where the hours are inserted \[in deeds\]?'[^fn_94b_24] 'Then why \[the former asked\] did the Master act in this way?'[^fn_94b_25] '\[I treated it,\] the other retorted, \[as a case to be decided\] at the discretion of the judges'.[^fn_94b_26] 'I too'' the first said, '\[treated the case as one to be decided at\] the discretion of the judges',[^fn_94b_27] 'In the first place' the other retorted, 'I am a judge[^fn_94b_28] and the Master is no judge, and furthermore, you did not at first come with this argument',[^fn_94b_29]

Two deeds \[of sale\][^fn_94b_30] were once presented before R. Joseph, one being dated,[^fn_94b_31] 'On the fifth of Nisan',[^fn_94b_32] and the other was vaguely dated, 'In Nisan'. R. Joseph confirmed the \[holder of the deed which had the entry,\] 'fifth of Nisan' in the possession of the property. 'And I', said the other, 'must lose?' 'You', he replied, 'are at a disadvantage, since it may be suggested that your deed was one that was written[^fn_94b_33] on the twenty-ninth of Nisan'[^fn_94b_34] 'Will, then, the Master', the other asked, 'write for me [pg 95a]

a *tirpa*[^fn_95a_1] \[authorizing distraint on property sold\][^fn_95a_2] after the first of Iyar?'[^fn_95a_3] 'They',[^fn_95a_4] he replied, 'might tell you: You \[are holding a deed\] that was written on the first of Nisan'.[^fn_95a_5] What means of redress \[can he[^fn_95a_6] have recourse to\]?[^fn_95a_7] — They[^fn_95a_8] write out authorizations[^fn_95a_9] to one another.[^fn_95a_10]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN WHO WAS MARRIED TO TWO WIVES SOLD HIS FIELD,[^fn_95a_11] AND THE FIRST WIFE[^fn_95a_12] HAD GIVEN A WRITTEN DECLARATION TO THE BUYER, 'I HAVE NO CLAIM WHATSOEVER UPON YOU', THE SECOND WIFE[^fn_95a_13] MAY[^fn_95a_14] DISTRAIN ON THE BUYER, AND THE FIRST WIFE[^fn_95a_12] ON THE SECOND, AND THE BUYER ON THE FIRST WIFE,[^fn_95a_15] AND SO THEY GO ON IN TURN UNTIL THEY ARRANGE SOME COMPROMISE BETWEEN THEM, THE SAME LAW APPLIES ALSO TO[^fn_95a_16] A CREDITOR[^fn_95a_17] AND TO[^fn_95a_16] A WOMAN CREDITOR,[^fn_95a_17] {¶=10.5}

***GEMARA***. What matters it even if she HAD GIVEN him A WRITTEN DECLARATION? Has it not been a man says to another, 'I have no claim whatsoever on this field, I have no concern in it and I entirely dissociate myself from it', his statement is of no effect?[^fn_95a_18] — Here we are dealing with a case where a *kinyan* was executed.[^fn_95a_19] But even if *kinyan* had been executed, what is the use? Could she not say, 'I merely wished to oblige my husband'?[^fn_95a_20] Have we not, in fact, learned: If a man bought \[a married woman's property\][^fn_95a_21] from her husband and then bought it also from the wife, his purchase is legally invalid.[^fn_95a_22] Does not this[^fn_95a_123] show clearly that the woman can plead, 'I merely wished to oblige my husband'?[^fn_95a_21] R. Zera replied in the name of R. Hisda: This is no difficulty. One ruling[^fn_95a_24] is that of R. Meir and the other[^fn_95a_25] is that of R. Judah. For it was taught: \[If a husband\] drew up a deed[^fn_95a_26] for the buyer[^fn_95a_27] \[of a field of his wife\],[^fn_95a_28] and she did not endorse it, \[and then he drew up a deed\] for another buyer \[of a field of hers\][^fn_95a_28] and that she did endorse, she loses thereby \[her claim to\] her *kethubah*,'[^fn_95a_29] so R. Meir.[^fn_95a_30] R. Judah, however, said: She may plead, 'I[^fn_95a_31] merely meant to oblige my husband;[^fn_95a_32] what \[claim\] can you have against me?'[^fn_95a_33]

As to Rabbi,[^fn_95a_34] however, would he allow the anonymous Mishnah here to represent the view of R. Meir and the anonymous Mishnah there[^fn_95a_35] to represent the view of R. Judah?[^fn_95a_36] R. Papa replied: \[Our Mishnah deals\] with the case of a divorced woman,[^fn_95a_37] and it represents the opinion of all. R. Ashi replied: Both Mishnahs[^fn_95a_38] represent the views of R. Meir,[^fn_95a_39] for R. Meir maintains his view[^fn_95a_40] only there where two buyers are concerned,[^fn_95a_41] since in such a case she may well be told, 'If you wished to oblige. you should have done so in the case of the first buyer',[^fn_95a_42] but where Only one buyer \[is concerned\]. even R. Meir admits \[that the sale is invalid\].[^fn_95a_43] while our Mishnah[^fn_95a_44] \[refers to a case\] where \[the husband had first\] written out a deed for another buyer.[^fn_95a_45]

Elsewhere we learned: Payment cannot be recovered from mortgaged property where free assets are available, even if they are only of the poorest quality.[^fn_95a_46] The question was raised: If the free assets were blasted[^fn_95a_47] may the mortgaged property be distrained on? — Come and hear: \[If a husband\] drew up a deed for the buyer \[of a field of his wife\] and she did not endorse it \[and then he drew up a deed\] for another buyer \[of a field of hers\] and that she did endorse, she loses thereby \[her claim to\] her *kethubah*,' so R. Meir.[^fn_95a_48] Now, if it could be imagined that where the free assets were blasted the mortgaged property may be distrained on \[the difficulty would arise:\] Granted that she lost \[her right to recover\] her *kethubah* from the second buyer,[^fn_95a_49] why[^fn_95a_50] should she not be entitled[^fn_95a_51] to recover it, at any rate, from the first buyer?[^fn_95a_52] — Said R. Nahman b. Isaac:[^fn_95a_53] The meaning of 'she loses' is that she loses \[her right to recover her due\] from the second buyer.[^fn_95a_54] Said Raba: Two objections may be raised against this explanation:[^fn_95a_55] In the first place \[it may be pointed out\] that \[the expression of\] 'she loses' implies total loss. And, furthermore, it was taught: If a man borrowed from one person and sold his property to two others, and the creditor gave a written declaration to the second buyer, 'I have no claim whatever upon you', \[this creditor\] has no claim whatever upon the first buyer, since the latter can tell him, 'I have left you[^fn_95a_56] a source[^fn_95a_57] from which to recover your debt'![^fn_95a_58] — There,[^fn_95a_59] \[it may be argued[^fn_95a_60] that\] it was he[^fn_95a_61] who had deliberately caused the loss to himself.[^fn_95a_62]

Said R. Yemar to R. Ashi: [pg 95b]

This,[^fn_95b_1] Surely, is the regular practice[^fn_95b_2] \[of the courts of law\]? For did not a man once pledge a vineyard to his friend for ten years[^fn_95b_3] but it aged after five years,[^fn_95b_4] and \[when the creditor\] came to the Rabbis[^fn_95b_5] they wrote out a tirpa[^fn_95b_6] for him?[^fn_95b_7] — There[^fn_95b_8] also it was they[^fn_95b_9] who caused the loss to themselves. For, having been aware that it may happen that a Vineyard should age,[^fn_95b_10] they should not have bought \[any of the debtor's pledged land\].[^fn_95b_11] The law, however, is that where free assets are blasted, mortgaged property may be distrained on.

Abaye ruled: \[If a man said to a woman\][^fn_95b_12] 'My estate shall be yours and after you \[it shall be given\] to So-and-so', and then the woman[^fn_95b_13] married, her husband has the Status of a vendee and her successor[^fn_95b_14] has no legal claim[^fn_95b_15] in face[^fn_95b_16] of her husband. In agreement with whose view \[was Abaye's ruling laid down\]? In agreement with the following Tanna.[^fn_95b_17] For it has been taught: \[If one man said to another,\] 'My estate shall be yours and after you \[it shall be given\] to So-and-so' and the first recipient went down \[into the estate\] and sold it, the second may reclaim the estate[^fn_95b_18] from those who bought it; so Rabbi. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel ruled: The second may receive only that which the first has left.[^fn_95b_19] But could Abaye have laid down such a ruling? Did not Abaye in fact, Say, 'Who is a cunning rogue? He who counsels[^fn_95b_20] to sell[^fn_95b_21] an estate[^fn_95b_22] in accordance with the ruling of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel?[^fn_95b_23] — Did he Say, 'She may marry'?[^fn_95b_24] All he said was, 'The woman married'.[^fn_95b_25]

Abaye further stated: \[If a man said to a woman.\][^fn_95b_26] 'My estate shall be yours and after you \[it shall be given\] to So-and-so' and the woman sold \[the estate\] and died, her husband[^fn_95b_27] may seize It from the buyer, the woman's successor[^fn_95b_28] \[may seize it\] from the husband,[^fn_95b_29] and the buyer from the successor,[^fn_95b_30] and all the estate is confirmed in the possession of the buyer.[^fn_95b_31] But why should this case be different from the following where we learned: AND SO THEY GO ON IN TURN UNTIL THEY ARRANGE SOME COMPROMISE BETWEEN THEM? — There they are all suffering some loss[^fn_95b_32] but here it is only the buyer who suffers the loss.[^fn_95b_33]

Rafram went to R. Ashi and recited this argument to him: Could Abaye have laid down such a ruling?[^fn_95b_34] Did he not, in fact, lay down: \[If a man said to a woman.\] 'My estate shall be yours and after you \[it shall be given\] to So-and-so', and then the woman married, her husband has the status of a vendee, and her successor has no legal claim in face of her husband?[^fn_95b_35] — The other replied: There \[it is a woman\] to whom he[^fn_95b_36] spoke while she was feme sole,[^fn_95b_37] but here \[we are dealing with one\] to whom he[^fn_95b_36] spoke when she was married.[^fn_95b_38] For it is this that he meant to tell[^fn_95b_39] her? 'Your successor only shall acquire Possession; your husband shall not'.[^fn_95b_40]

THE SAME LAW APPLIES ALSO TO A CREDITOR. A Tanna taught:[^fn_95b_41] The same law applies to[^fn_95b_42] a creditor and two buyers[^fn_95b_43] and also to a woman, who was a creditor,[^fn_95b_44] and two buyers.[^fn_95b_45]

## CHAPTER XI

***MISHNAH***. A WIDOW IS TO BE MAINTAINED OUT OF THE ESTATE OF \[HER DECEASED HUSBAND'S\] ORPHANS \[AND\] HER HANDIWORK BELONGS TO THEM. IT IS NOT THEIR DUTY, HOWEVER, TO BURY HER; IT IS THE DUTY OF HER HEIRS, EVEN THOSE WHO INHERIT HER *KETHUBAH*, TO BURY HER. {¶=11.1}

***GEMARA***. The question was asked: Have we learnt,[^fn_95b_46] 'is to be maintained'[^fn_95b_47] or 'one who is maintained'?[^fn_95b_48] Have we learned, 'is to be maintained', in agreement with the men of Galilee,[^fn_95b_49] so that there is no way[^fn_95b_50] \[by which the orphans\] can avoid[^fn_95b_51] maintaining her; or have we rather learned 'one who is maintained',[^fn_95b_48] in agreement with the men of Judaea,[^fn_95b_52] so that \[the orphans,\] if they wish it, need not[^fn_95b_53] maintain her? [pg 96a]

— Come and hear what[^fn_96a_1] R. Zera stated in the name of Samuel:[^fn_96a_2] 'The find of a widow belongs to herself'. Now if you grant that what we learnt was, one who is maintained' \[this ruling is\] quite justified,[^fn_96a_3] but if you insist that what we learnt was 'is to be maintained'[^fn_96a_4] \[why,[^fn_96a_5] it might be objected, should they not\] have the same rights as a husband, and just as in the latter case[^fn_96a_6] a wife's find belongs to her husband, so it, the former case[^fn_96a_7] also the find of the woman[^fn_96a_8] should belong to the heirs?[^fn_96a_9] — I may still insist that what we have learnt[^fn_96a_10] was 'is to be maintained'; for the reason why[^fn_96a_11] the Rabbis have ordained that the find of a wife belonged to her husband is in order that he shall bear no grudge[^fn_96a_12] against her, but as regards these[^fn_96a_13] let them bear the grudge.[^fn_96a_14]

R. Jose b. Hanina ruled: All manner of work which a wife must render to her husband[^fn_96a_15] a widow must render to the orphans, with the exception of serving one's drinks,[^fn_96a_16] making ready one's bed and washing one's face, hands or feet.[^fn_96a_17]

R. Joshua b. Levi ruled: All manner of service that a slave must render to his master a student must render to his teacher, except that of taking off his[^fn_96a_18] shoe.[^fn_96a_19] Raba explained: This ruling[^fn_96a_20] applies only to a place where he[^fn_96a_21] is not known, but where he is known there can be no objection.[^fn_96a_22] R. Ashi said: Even where he[^fn_96a_21] is not known the ruling[^fn_96a_20] applies only where he does not put on tefillin[^fn_96a_23] but where he puts on tefillin, he may well perform such a service.[^fn_96a_22]

R. Hiyya b. Abba stated in the name of R. Johanan. A man who deprives his student of \[the privilege of\] attending on him acts as if he had deprived him of \[an act of\] kindness, for it is said in Scripture, To him that deprives[^fn_96a_24] his friend[^fn_96a_25] of kindness.[^fn_96a_26] R. Nahman b. Isaac said: He also deprives[^fn_96a_27] him of the fear of heaven, for it is said in Scripture, And he forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.[^fn_96a_28]

R. Eleazar ruled: If a widow[^fn_96a_29] seized movables \[to provide\] for her maintenance, her act is[^fn_96a_30] valid.[^fn_96a_31] So it was also taught: If a widow seized movables \[to provide\] for her maintenance, her act is[^fn_96a_30] valid.[^fn_96a_31] And so R. Dimi, when he came,[^fn_96a_32] related: It once happened that the daughter-in-law of R. Shabbethai seized[^fn_96a_33] a saddle bag[^fn_96a_34] that was full of money,[^fn_96a_35] and the Sages had no power to take it out of her possession.

Rabina ruled: This[^fn_96a_36] applies only to maintenance but \[movables seized\] in payment of a *kethubah* may be taken away from her. Mar son of R. Ashi demurred: Wherein \[is the case of seizure\] for a *kethubah* different \[from the other\]? Is it because \[the former may be distrained for\] on landed property and not on movables, may not maintenance also, \[it may be objected, be distrained\] on landed property and not on movables? The fact, however, is that as in respect of maintenance seizure[^fn_96a_30] is valid,[^fn_96a_31] so it is also valid in respect of a *kethubah*.

Said R. Isaac b. Naphtali to Rabina: Thus, in agreement with your view, it has also been stated in the name of Raba. R. Johanan stated in the name of R. Jose b. Zimra: A widow who allowed two or three years to pass[^fn_96a_37] before[^fn_96a_38] she claimed maintenance loses her maintenance. Now \[that it has been said that\] she loses \[her maintenance after\] two years, was it necessary \[to mention also\] three? — This is no difficulty; the lesser number[^fn_96a_39] refers to a poor woman while the bigger one[^fn_96a_39] refers to a rich woman;[^fn_96a_40] or else: The former[^fn_96a_39] refers to a bold woman and the latter[^fn_96a_39] to a modest woman.[^fn_96a_41] Raba ruled: This[^fn_96a_42] applies only to a retrospective claim,[^fn_96a_43] but in respect of the future she is entitled \[to maintenance\].

R. Johanan enquired: If the orphans plead, 'We have already paid[^fn_96a_44] \[the cost of maintenance[^fn_96a_45] in advance\]', and she retorts, 'I did not receive it', who must produce the proof? [pg 96b]

Is the estate \[of the deceased man\] in the presumptive possession of the orphans[^fn_96b_1] and consequently it is the widow who must produce the proof, or is the estate rather in the presumptive possession of the widow[^fn_96b_2] and the proof must be produced by the orphans? Come and hear what Levi taught: \[In a dispute on the maintenance of\] a widow, the orphans must produce the proof[^fn_96b_3] so long as she is unmarried,[^fn_96b_4] but if she was married[^fn_96b_5] the proof must be produced by her.[^fn_96b_6]

R. Shimi b. Ashi said: \[This point[^fn_96b_7] is a matter in dispute between\] the following[^fn_96b_8] Tannaim: She[^fn_96b_9] may sell \[portions of her deceased husband's estate\] but should specify in writing,[^fn_96b_10] 'These I have sold for maintenance,' and 'These I have sold for the kethubah' \[as the case may be\]; so R. Judah. R.
