Jose, however, ruled: She[^fn_96b_11] may sell \[such portions\] and need not specify the purpose[^fn_96b_12] in writing, for in this manner she gains an advantage.[^fn_96b_13] They[^fn_96b_14] thus apparently[^fn_96b_15] differ on the following point: R. Judah, who ruled that it is necessary to specify[^fn_96b_16] the purpose,[^fn_96b_17] holds that the \[deceased man's\] estate is in the presumptive possession of the orphans and that it is the widow who must produce the proof,[^fn_96b_18] whilst R. Jose, who ruled that it was not necessary to specify the purpose, upholds the view that the estate is in the presumptive possession of the widow and that it is the orphans who must produce the proof.[^fn_96b_19] Whence \[is this[^fn_96b_20] made so obvious\]? It is quite possible that all[^fn_96b_14] agree that the \[deceased man's\] estate is in the presumptive possession of his widow and that the orphans must produce the proof,[^fn_96b_21] but R. Judah[^fn_96b_22] is merely tendering good advice \[by following which the widow\] would prevent people from calling[^fn_96b_23] her a glutton.[^fn_96b_24] For were you not to admit this,[^fn_96b_25] could not the question[^fn_96b_26] raised by R. Johanan[^fn_96b_27] be answered from the Mishnah:[^fn_96b_28] She may sell \[her deceased husband's estate\] for her maintenance out of court but should enter \[in the deed of sale,\] 'I have sold these for maintenance'?[^fn_96b_29] Consequently[^fn_96b_30] It must be concluded[^fn_96b_31] that no deduction may be made from the Mishnah[^fn_96b_28] because therein only good advice was tendered;[^fn_96b_32] and so also here[^fn_96b_33] \[it may similarly be submitted that R. Judah\] was only tendering good advice.[^fn_96b_32] Or else: All[^fn_96b_34] may agree that the estate \[of the deceased\] is in the presumptive possession of the orphans, but R. Jose's reason[^fn_96b_35] is exactly the same as \[that given by\] Abaye the Elder who stated: To what may the ruling[^fn_96b_36] of R. Jose be compared? To \[the instructions of\] a dying man who said, 'Give two hundred *zuz*[^fn_96b_37] to So-and-so, my creditor,[^fn_96b_38] who may take them, if he wishes, in settlement of his debt or, if he prefers, he may take then, as a gift', [pg 97a]

who, if he takes them as a gift, has not the same advantage \[as if he had taken them for his debt\].[^fn_97a_1]

In what manner does \[a widow\] sell \[her deceased husband's property\] for her maintenance?[^fn_97a_2] — R. Daniel son of R. Kattina replied in the name of R. Huna: She sells \[portions of it\] once in twelve months[^fn_97a_3] and the buyer supplies her maintenance \[in instalments\][^fn_97a_4] once every thirty days. Rab Judah, however, stated: She sells once in six months and the buyer provides her maintenance \[in instalments\] once every thirty days.

It was taught in agreement with R. Huna: \[A widow\] sells[^fn_97a_5] once in twelve months and the buyer supplies her maintenance \[in instalments\] once every thirty days. It was also taught in agreement with Rab Judah: \[A widow\] sells once in six months and the buyer provides her maintenance \[in instalments\] once every thirty days.

Amemar said: The law is that \[a widow\] sells \[sufficient land to suffice her\] for six months and the buyer provides her maintenance \[in instalments\] once every thirty days. Said R. Ashi to Amemar: What \[about the ruling\] of R. Huna? — 'I', the other replied, 'have not heard of it', by which he meant,[^fn_97a_6] 'I do not approve of it'.

R. Shesheth was asked: May \[a widow\] who sold \[land\] for her maintenance subsequently distrain on it[^fn_97a_7] for her *kethubah*? This question was raised on \[the basis of a ruling of\] R. Joseph who stated, 'If a widow has sold \[any of her deceased husband's estate\][^fn_97a_8] the responsibility for the indemnity falls upon the orphans,[^fn_97a_9] and if the court sold \[any such property\] the responsibility for the indemnity again falls upon the orphans'[^fn_97a_10] What \[then, it was asked, is the ruling\]? May she, since the responsibility for the indemnity falls upon the orphans, distrain \[on the land\],[^fn_97a_11] or is it possible that \[the buyers\] may tell her,[^fn_97a_12] 'Granted that you have not accepted general[^fn_97a_13] responsibility for indemnity, did you not indeed accept responsibility \[against distraint\] by yourself either?'[^fn_97a_14] — You, he replied, have learned it: '\[A widow\][^fn_97a_15] may continue to sell[^fn_97a_16] until \[only the estate of\] the value of her *kethubah* \[remains\], and this is a support to her since she might thus collect her *kethubah* from the residue'. Thus[^fn_97a_17] it may be inferred that only if she left \[estate corresponding to the value of her *kethubah*\] may[^fn_97a_18] \[she collect her *kethubah*\]. but if she did not leave \[so much of the estate,[^fn_97a_19] she may\] not.[^fn_97a_20] But is it not possible that he[^fn_97a_21] was merely tendering good advice, in order that people might not call her a swindler?[^fn_97a_22] — If so,[^fn_97a_23] he[^fn_97a_21] should have stated, 'She collects her *kethubah* from the remainder', why \[then did he also add,\] 'A support to her'? Consequently it must be inferred that only if she left \[estate corresponding to the value of her *kethubah*\] may[^fn_97a_18] \[the widow collect her *kethubah*\], but if she did not leave \[so much[^fn_97a_19] she may\] not.[^fn_97a_20]

The question was raised: If a man sold \[a plot of land\][^fn_97a_24] but \[on concluding the sale\] he was no longer in need of money, may his sale[^fn_97a_25] be withdrawn[^fn_97a_26] or not?[^fn_97a_27] Come and hear: There was a certain man who sold a plot of land to R. Papa because he was in need of money to buy some oxen, and, as eventually he did not need it, R. Papa actually returned the land to him! — \[This is no proof since\] R. Papa may have acted beyond the strict requirements of the law.[^fn_97a_28]

Come and hear: There was once a dearth at Nehardea[^fn_97a_29] when all the people sold their mansions,[^fn_97a_30] but when eventually wheat arrived[^fn_97a_31] R. Nahman told them: The law is that the mansions must be returned to their original owners! — There also the sales were made in error since it eventually became known that the ship[^fn_97a_32] was[^fn_97a_33] waiting in the bays.[^fn_97a_34] If that is so,[^fn_97a_35] how \[explain\] what Rami b. Samuel said to R. Nahman, 'If \[you rule\] thus you will cause them[^fn_97a_36] trouble in the future',[^fn_97a_37] \[whereupon\] he replied, 'Is dearth a daily occurrence?' and to which the former retorted, 'Yes, a dearth at Nehardea is indeed a common occurrence'?[^fn_97a_38]

And the law is that if a man sold \[a plot of land\][^fn_97a_39] and \[on concluding the sale\] was no longer in need of money the sale may be withdrawn.

***MISHNAH***. A WIDOW, WHETHER \[HER HUSBAND DIED\] AFTER \[HER\] BETROTHAL[^fn_97a_40] OR AFTER \[HER\] MARRIAGE[^fn_97a_41] MAY SELL \[OF HER DECEASED HUSBAND'S ESTATE\] WITHOUT \[THE SANCTION OF\] *BETH DIN*. R. SIMEON RULED: \[IF HER HUSBAND DIED\] AFTER MARRIAGE[^fn_97a_41] SHE MAY SELL[^fn_97a_42] \[OF HIS ESTATE\] WITHOUT \[THE SANCTION OF\] *BETH DIN*,[^fn_97a_43] \[BUT IF ONLY\] AFTER \[HER\] BETROTHAL, SHE MAY NOT SELL \[ANY OF THE ESTATE\] EXCEPT WITH \[THE SANCTION OF\] *BETH DIN*, SINCE SHE IS NOT ENTITLED TO MAINTENANCE, AND ONE WHO IS NOT ENTITLED TO MAINTENANCE MAY NOT SELL \[SUCH PROPERTY\] EXCEPT WITH \[THE SANCTION OF\] *BETH DIN*. {¶=11.2}

***GEMARA***. One can readily see \[that the privilege[^fn_97a_44] of a woman who was widowed\] AFTER MARRIAGE is due to \[her immediate need for\] maintenance;[^fn_97a_45] [pg 97b]

what, however, is the reason[^fn_97b_1] \[for conferring this privilege[^fn_97b_2] upon one widowed\] after betrothal?[^fn_97b_3] — 'Ulla replied: In order to \[enhance the\] attractions[^fn_97b_4] \[of matrimony\].[^fn_97b_5] R. Johanan replied: Because no man wants his wife to suffer the indignity \[of appearing\] in court. What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_97b_6] — The practical difference between them is the case of a divorced woman. For according to him who replied, 'In order to \[enhance the\] attractiveness \[of matrimony\]' a divorced woman also may[^fn_97b_7] claim \[the privilege[^fn_97b_8] of the provision for matrimonial\] attractiveness; but according to him who replied, 'Because no man wants his wife to suffer the indignity \[of appearing\] in court' a divorced woman \[is not entitled to the privilege since\] the man does not care \[for her dignity\].

We learned: And a divorced woman may not sell \[of her former husband's estate\][^fn_97b_9] except with the sanction of *Beth din*.[^fn_97b_10] Now, according to him who replied, 'Because no man wants his wife to suffer the indignity \[of appearing\] in court' the ruling is well justified since for a divorced wife one does not care; but according to him who replied, 'In order to \[enhance the\] attractions \[of matrimony'. why should not\] a divorced woman[^fn_97b_11] also be entitled to claim \[the privilege of the provision for matrimonial\] attractiveness? — This represents the view of R. Simeon.[^fn_97b_12] If \[this represents the view of\] R. Simeon \[the objection arises: Was not this principle\] already laid down in the earlier clause, AFTER HER BETROTHAL SHE MAY NOT SELL etc.?[^fn_97b_13] — It might have been presumed \[that his ruling applied\] Only to a woman widowed after \[her\] betrothal, since in her case there was not much affection,[^fn_97b_14] but that a divorced woman, in whose case there was much affection,[^fn_97b_15] may[^fn_97b_16] demand \[the privilege of the provision for matrimonial\] attraction.[^fn_97b_17] But have we not learned this[^fn_97b_18] also: WHO IS NOT ENTITLED TO MAINTENANCE which includes,[^fn_97b_19] does it not, a divorced woman?[^fn_97b_20] — No, \[it includes one who is both\] divorced[^fn_97b_21] and' not divorced,[^fn_97b_22] as \[the one spoken of by\] R. Zera who stated: Wherever the Sages described a woman as both divorced and not divorced[^fn_97b_22] her husband is responsible for her maintenance.[^fn_97b_23]

Come and hear: As she[^fn_97b_24] may sell \[of her deceased husband's estate\] without \[the sanction of\] *Beth din* so may her heirs, those who inherit her *kethubah*, sell \[such property\] without \[the sanction of\] *Beth din*. Now, according to him who replied, 'Because no man wants his wife to suffer the indignity \[of appearing\] in court' one can well see the reason for this ruling;[^fn_97b_25] for as it is disagreeable to him[^fn_97b_26] that she should suffer indignity so it is also disagreeable to him that her heirs should suffer indignity. According to him, however, who replied, 'In order to \[enhance the\] attractiveness \[of matrimony\]', what \[consideration for\] attractiveness \[it may be objected\] could there be in respect of her heirs?[^fn_97b_27] — 'Ulla interpreted this \[to be a case where\] her daughter, for instance, or her sister, Was her heir.[^fn_97b_28]

***MISHNAH***. \[A WIDOW WHO\] SOLD HER *KETHUBAH* OR PART OF IT, OR PLEDGED IT OR PART OF IT, OR PRESENTED IT OR PART OF IT, TO A STRANGER, MAY NOT SELL THE RESIDUE \[OF HER DECEASED HUSBAND'S ESTATE\][^fn_97b_29] EXCEPT WITH (THE SANCTION OF\] *BETH DIN*.[^fn_97b_30] THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: SHE MAY SELL \[THE LAND PLEDGED FOR HER *KETHUBAH*\] EVEN IN FOUR OR FIVE INSTALMENTS[^fn_97b_31] AND \[IN THE MEANTIME\][^fn_97b_32] SHE MAY SELL \[OF HER HUSBAND'S ESTATE TO PROVIDE\] FOR HER MAINTENANCE WITHOUT \[THE SANCTION OF\] *BETH DIN*, ENTERING, \[HOWEVER, IN THE DEED OF SALE,\] 'I SOLD \[THE LAND TO PROVIDE\] FOR MY MAINTENANCE'.[^fn_97b_33] A DIVORCED WOMAN, HOWEVER, MUST NOT SELL \[SUCH PROPERTY\] EXCEPT WITH \[THE SANCTION OF\] *BETH DIN*. {¶=11.3}

***GEMARA***. Who \[is the author of the first ruling in\] our Mishnah?[^fn_97b_34] — It is R. Simeon. For it was taught: If a woman sold \[all\] her *kethubah* or pledged it, or mortgaged \[the land that was pledged for\] her *kethubah* to a stranger, she is not entitled to maintenance.[^fn_97b_35] R. Simeon ruled: Even if she did not sell or pledge \[all\] her *kethubah*, but half of it only, she loses her maintenance.[^fn_97b_36] Does this[^fn_97b_37] then imply that R. Simeon holds the view that we do not regard part of the amount[^fn_97b_38] as being legally equal to the full amount, while the Rabbis maintain that part of the amount is legally regarded as the full amount? But, \[it may be objected\], have we not in fact heard the reverse? For was It not taught: And he[^fn_97b_39] shall take a wife its her virginity[^fn_97b_40] excludes one who is adolescent[^fn_97b_41] \[some of whose\] virginity is ended; so R. Meir. R. Eleazar and R. Simeon permit[^fn_97b_42] \[the marriage\] of one who is adolescent?[^fn_97b_43] — There[^fn_97b_44] they differ \[on the interpretation\] of Scriptural texts,[^fn_97b_45] R. Meir being of the opinion that 'virgin'[^fn_97b_46] implies even \[one who retains\] some of her virginity; 'her virginity'[^fn_97b_47] implies only one who retains all her virginity;[^fn_97b_48] 'in her virginity'[^fn_97b_49] implies only[^fn_97b_50] \[when previous intercourse with her took place\] in a natural manner,[^fn_97b_51] but not when in an unnatural manner.[^fn_97b_52] R. Eleazar and R. Simeon, however, are of the opinion that 'virgin' would have implied a perfect virgin; 'her virginity' implies even \[one who retains\] only part of her virginity; [pg 98a]

'in her virginity'[^fn_98a_1] implies only one[^fn_98a_2] whose entire virginity is intact,[^fn_98a_3] irrespective of whether \[previous intercourse with her was\] of a natural or unnatural character.[^fn_98a_4] A certain woman[^fn_98a_5] once seized a silver cup on account of her *kethubah*[^fn_98a_6] and then claimed her maintenance. She appeared before Raba. He \[thereupon\] told the orphans, 'Proceed to provide for her maintenance; no one cares for the ruling of R. Simeon who laid down that we do not regard part of the amount as legally equal to the full amount.

Rabbah the son of Raba sent to R. Joseph \[the following enquiry:\] Is a woman[^fn_98a_7] who sells \[of her deceased husband's estate\] without \[an authorization of\] *Beth din* required to take an oath[^fn_98a_8] or is she not required to take an oath? — And \[why, the other replied, do you not\] enquire \[as to whether\] a public announcement[^fn_98a_9] \[is required\]? I have no need, the first retorted, to enquire concerning a public announcement because R. Zera has stated in the name of R. Nahman, 'If a widow assessed \[her husband's estate\] on her own behalf[^fn_98a_10] her act is invalid';[^fn_98a_11] now, how \[is this statement\] to be understood? If a public announcement[^fn_98a_9] has been made \[the difficulty arises,\] why is her act invalid? Must we not consequently assume that there was no public announcement, and \[since it was stated that\] Only \[if the assessment was made\] 'on her own behalf' is 'her act invalid' it follows, does it not, \[that if she made it\] on behalf of another[^fn_98a_12] her act is valid?[^fn_98a_13] — \[No,\] a public announcement may in fact have been made but \[her act is nevertheless invalid\] because she can be told, 'Who \[authorized\] you to make the assessment?'[^fn_98a_14] as was the case with a certain man with whom corals[^fn_98a_15] belonging to orphans had been deposited and he proceeded to assess them on his own behalf for four hundred *ZUZ*, and when later its price rose to six hundred *zuz*, he appeared before R. Ammi, who said to him, 'Who \[authorized\] you to make the assessment?'[^fn_98a_16] And the law is that she[^fn_98a_17] is required to take an oath,[^fn_98a_18] but there is no need to make a public announcement.[^fn_98a_19] 

***MISHNAH***.IF A WIDOW WHOSE *KETHUBAH* WAS FOR TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ* SOLD[^fn_98a_20] \[A PLOT OF LAND THAT WAS\] WORTH A *MANEH*[^fn_98a_21] FOR TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ* OR ONE THAT WAS WORTH TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ* FOR ONE *MANEH*, HER *KETHUBAH* IS DEEMED TO HAVE BEEN THEREBY SETTLED.[^fn_98a_22] IF HER *KETHUBAH*, HOWEVER, WAS FOR ONE *MANEH*, AND SHE SOLD \[LAND THAT WAS\] WORTH A *MANEH* AND A DENAR' FOR ONE *MANEH*, HER SALE IS VOID. EVEN THOUGH SHE DECLARED, I WILL RETURN THE *DENAR* TO THE HEIRS' HER SALE IS VOID.[^fn_98a_23] R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL RULED: HER SALE[^fn_98a_22] IS ALWAYS VALID[^fn_98a_24] UNLESS THERE WAS[^fn_98a_25] \[SO MUCH LAND\] THERE AS WOULD HAVE ENABLED HER[^fn_98a_26] TO LEAVE[^fn_98a_27] FROM A FIELD AN AREA OF NINE *KAB*,[^fn_98a_28] AND FROM A GARDEN THAT OF HALF A *KAB*[^fn_98a_29] OR, ACCORDING TO R. AKIBA, A QUARTER OF A *KAB*.[^fn_98a_29] IF HER *KETHUBAH* WAS FOR FOUR HUNDRED *ZUZ* AND SHE SOLD \[PLOTS OF LAND\][^fn_98a_30] TO \[THREE\] PERSONS, TO EACH FOR ONE *MANEH*,[^fn_98a_31] AND TO A FOURTH[^fn_98a_32] \[SHE SOLD\] WHAT WAS WORTH A MANE HAND A *DENAR* FOR ONE *MANEH*,[^fn_98a_33] \[THE SALE\] TO THE LAST PERSON IS VOID BUT \[THE SALES\] OF ALL THE OTHERS ARE VALID. {¶=11.4}

***GEMARA***. Wherein does \[the sale of a plot of land\] THAT WAS WORTH TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ* FOR ONE *MANEH* differ \[from the previous case? Is it\] because she[^fn_98a_34] might be told, 'You yourself have caused the loss'? \[But, then, why should she not, where she SOLD A PLOT OF LAND THAT WAS\] WORTH A *MANEH* FOR TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ*, also \[be entitled to\] say, 'It is I who have made the profit'?[^fn_98a_35] — R. Nahman replied in the name of Rabbah b. Abbuha: [pg 98b]

Rabbi[^fn_98b_1] has taught here[^fn_98b_2] that all \[profits[^fn_98b_3] belong\] to the owner of the money.[^fn_98b_4] As it was taught,[^fn_98b_5] 'If one unit[^fn_98b_6] was added to \[the purchases made by an agent\] all \[the profit belongs\] to the agent'; so R. Judah, but R. Jose ruled, '\[The profit\] is to be divided',[^fn_98b_7] \[and, in reply to the objection,\] But, surely, it was taught that R. Jose ruled, All \[profit belongs\] to the owner of the money! Rami b. Hama replied: This is no difficulty for the former refers to an object that has a fixed value[^fn_98b_8] while the latter refers to one that has no fixed[^fn_98b_9] value.[^fn_98b_10]

R. Papa stated: The law is that[^fn_98b_11] \[the profit made by the agent on\] an object that had a fixed value must be divided,[^fn_98b_7] but if on an object that had no fixed value all \[profit belongs\] to the owner of the money. What does he[^fn_98b_12] teach us?[^fn_98b_13] — That the reply that was given[^fn_98b_14] is the proper one.[^fn_98b_15]

The question was raised: What \[is the law where a man\] said to his agent,[^fn_98b_16] 'Sell for me a lethek'[^fn_98b_17] and the latter presumed[^fn_98b_18] to sell a *kor*.[^fn_98b_19] \[Is the agent deemed to be merely\] adding to the owner's instructions and \[the buyer, therefore,\] acquires possession of a lethek, at all events, or is he rather transgressing his instructions and \[the buyer, therefore,\] acquires no possession of a lethek either? — Said R. Jacob of Nehar Pekod[^fn_98b_20] in the name of Rabina, Come and hear: If a householder said to his agent, 'Serve a piece \[of meat\][^fn_98b_21] to the guests', and the latter said to them, 'Take two',[^fn_98b_22] and they took three,[^fn_98b_22] all of them are guilty[^fn_98b_23] of trespass.[^fn_98b_24] Now if you agree \[that the agent\][^fn_98b_25] was merely adding to the host's instruction one can well understand the reason why the householder is guilty of trespass. If you should maintain, however, \[that the agent\][^fn_98b_25] was transgressing his instruction \[the objection could well be advanced:\] Why should the householder be guilty of trespass? Have we not In fact learned: If an agent performed his mission it is the householder who is guilty of trespass but if he did not perform his mission it is the agent who is guilty of trespass?[^fn_98b_26] — Here we may be dealing with a case where the agent said to the guests, 'Take one at the desire[^fn_98b_27] of the householder[^fn_98b_28] and one at my own request's[^fn_98b_27] and they took three.

Come and hear: IF HER *KETHUBAH*, HOWEVER, WAS FOR A *MANEH*, AND SHE SOLD \[LAND THAT WAS\] WORTH A *MANEH* AND A *DENAR* FOR A *MANEH*, HER SALE IS VOID. Does[^fn_98b_29] not \[this mean\] that SHE SOLD \[LAND THAT WAS\] WORTH A *MANEH* AND A *DENAR* FOR A MANEH and a *denar*,[^fn_98b_30] and that by[^fn_98b_29] \[the expression,\] 'FOR A MANEH' the *maneh* that was due to her \[is meant\], and by[^fn_98b_29] EVEN[^fn_98b_31] \[one is to understand\] EVEN THOUGH SHE DECLARED, I WILL RETURN THE *DENAR* TO THE HEIRS \[by repurchasing for them\] land of the value of a denar'? And was it not nevertheless stated, HER SALE IS VOID?[^fn_98b_32] — No,[^fn_98b_33] retorted R. Huna the son of R. Nathan, \[this is a case\] where \[she sold\] at the lower price.[^fn_98b_34] [pg 99a]

But since the final clause[^fn_99a_1] \[deals with a case\] where \[she sold\] at a lower price, \[would not\] the earlier clause[^fn_99a_2] \[naturally[^fn_99a_3] refer to one\] where \[she did\] not \[sell\] at a lower price; for has \[it not\] been stated in the final clause, IF HER *KETHUBAH* WAS FOR FOUR HUNDRED *ZUZ* AND SHE SOLD \[PLOTS OF LAND\] TO \[THREE\] PERSONS[^fn_99a_4] TO EACH FOR ONE *MANEH*, AND TO A FOURTH[^fn_99a_4] \[SHE SOLD\] WHAT WAS WORTH A MANE HAND A *DENAR* FOR ONE *MANEH*, \[THE SALE\] TO THE LAST PERSON IS VOID BUT \[THE SALES\] OF ALL THE OTHERS ARE VALID?[^fn_99a_5] — No, both the earlier and the final clause \[refer to a sale\] at a lower price, but[^fn_99a_6] it is this that we were informed in the final clause: The reason \[why her sale is void is\] because \[she sold\][^fn_99a_7] at a lower price \[the property\] that belonged to the orphans,[^fn_99a_8] but \[if that[^fn_99a_9] had been done\] with her own,[^fn_99a_10] her sale is valid.[^fn_99a_11] But is not this already inferred from the first clause: WHOSE *KETHUBAH* WAS FOR TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ* SOLD \[A PLOT OF LAND THAT WAS\] WORTH A *MANEH* FOR TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ* OR ONE THAT WAS WORTH TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ* FOR ONE *MANEH*, HER *KETHUBAH* IS DEEMED TO HAVE BEEN THEREBY SETTLED?[^fn_99a_12] — It might have been assumed \[that the ruling[^fn_99a_13] was applicable\] there Only because \[by her one act\] she completely severed her connection with that house,[^fn_99a_14] but that here[^fn_99a_15] \[the sale for\] the first *maneh* \[should be deemed invalid\] as a preventive measure against \[the assumption of the validity of the sale for the\] last *maneh*,' hence we were informed \[that the law was not so\].

Some there are who say: You have no need to ask \[for a ruling\] where \[a man said to his agent,\] 'Go and sell for me a lethek'[^fn_99a_16] and \[the latter\] sold for him a *kor*, since \[in this case the agent\] was undoubtedly adding to his instructions.[^fn_99a_17] The question, however, arises as to what is the ruling where the man said to the agent, 'Go and sell for me a kor' and he sold for him only one lethek.[^fn_99a_16] Do we \[in such a case\] lay down that \[the agent\] might tell the man, 'I have done for you that which is more advantageous to you, for \[had I sold the full *kor*, and\] you were no longer in need of money you could not have retracted',[^fn_99a_18] or is it rather \[held that the owner\] might retort to him, 'It is no satisfaction to me that many deeds \[should be held\] against me'? — R. Hanina of Sura[^fn_99a_19] replied, Come and hear: If one man gave to another a gold *denar*[^fn_99a_20] and told him, 'Bring me a shirt', and the other brought him a shirt for three sela's and a cloak for three sela's, both are guilty of trespass.[^fn_99a_21] Now if you admit that an agent in similar circumstances[^fn_99a_22] has performed his mission and was only adding to his instructions, one can well see why the owner[^fn_99a_23] is guilty of trespass.[^fn_99a_24] If, however, you should maintain that \[the agent in such circumstances\] was transgressing his instructions, why should \[the owner\] be guilty of trespass?[^fn_99a_25] — Here we are dealing with a case where \[the agent\] brought him \[a shirt that was\] worth six sela's for three.[^fn_99a_26] If so[^fn_99a_27] why should the agent be guilty of trespass? — On account of the cloak.[^fn_99a_28] But if that were so,[^fn_99a_29] read the final clause: R. Judah ruled, Even in this case[^fn_99a_29] the owner is not guilty of trespass because he might say \[to the agent,\] 'I wanted a big shirt and you brought me one that is small and bad'![^fn_99a_30] — 'Bad' means[^fn_99a_31] 'bad in respect of the price', for[^fn_99a_32] \[the owner can\] tell him, 'Had you brought me one for six sela's \[my gain would have been\] even greater since it would have been worth twelve sela's.'[^fn_99a_33] This[^fn_99a_34] may also be proved by an inference. For it was stated:[^fn_99a_35] R. Judah admits \[that if the transaction was\] in pulse both[^fn_99a_36] are guilty of trespass [pg 99b]

because \[the quantity of\] pulse for a *sela'* \[is in exactly the same proportion as\] that for one *perutah*.[^fn_99b_1] This is conclusive. How is this[^fn_99b_2] to be understood? If it be suggested \[that it refers\] to a place where \[pulse\] is sold by conjectural estimate, does not one \[it may be objected\] who pays a *sela'* obtain the commodity at a much cheaper rate?[^fn_99b_3] — R. Papa replied: \[It refers\] to a place where each kanna[^fn_99b_4] is sold[^fn_99b_5] for one *perutah*.[^fn_99b_6]

Come and hear: IF HER *KETHUBAH* WAS FOR FOUR HUNDRED *ZUZ* AND SHE SOLD \[PLOTS OF LAND\] TO \[THREE\] PERSONS[^fn_99b_7] TO EACH FOR ONE *MANEH*, AND TO A FOURTH[^fn_99b_7] \[SHE SOLD\] WHAT WAS WORTH A *MANEH* AND A DENAR FOR ONE *MANEH* \[THE SALE\] TO THE LAST PERSON IS VOID BUT \[THE SALES\] OF ALL THE OTHERS ARE VALID![^fn_99b_8] — \[This[^fn_99b_9] is no proof, for\] as R. Shisha the son of R. Idi replied[^fn_99b_10] \[that the final clause of our Mishnah deals\] with small plots of land,[^fn_99b_11] \[so it may\] in this discussion[^fn_99b_12] also \[be argued that the clause cited deals\] with small plots of land.[^fn_99b_13]

It is obvious \[that if a man\] instructed \[his agent to sell a plot of land\] to one person but not to two persons \[and he sold it to two' the sale is invalid[^fn_99b_14] for\] he distinctly told him, 'To one person but not to two persons'.[^fn_99b_15] What, \[however, is the ruling where\] he gave instructions \[that the sale shall be made\] to one person without mentioning any further limitation?[^fn_99b_16] R. Huna ruled: 'To one person' implies 'but not to two'.[^fn_99b_17] Both R. Hisda and Rabbah son of R. Huna, however, ruled: 'To one person'[^fn_99b_18] may mean even to two;[^fn_99b_19] 'to one', may mean[^fn_99b_16] even to a hundred.[^fn_99b_19] R. Nahman once happened to be at Sura[^fn_99b_20] when R. Hisda and Rabbah b. R. Huna came to visit him. 'What \[is the ruling\], they asked him, in such a case?'[^fn_99b_21] — To one', he replied, \[may mean\] even to two, 'to one' may mean even to a hundred. '\[Are the sales valid,\]' they asked him, 'even where the agent made an error?'[^fn_99b_22] — 'I do not speak', he replied, 'of a case where the agent had made an error'. 'But did not a Master', they asked again, 'say \[that the law of\] overreaching does not apply to landed property'?[^fn_99b_23] This[^fn_99b_24] applies only where the owner made the error; but where the agent has made the error \[the owner\] might tell him, 'I sent you to improve my position but not to impair it'.[^fn_99b_25] Whence, however, is it inferred that a distinction may be drawn between the agent and the owner? — \[From\] what we have learned, 'If a man tells his agent, "Go and give *terumah*", the latter must give the *terumah* in accordance with the disposition of the owner,[^fn_99b_26] and if he does not know the owner's disposition, he should give the *terumah* in a moderate manner, viz., one fiftieth.[^fn_99b_27] If he reduced \[the denominator by\] ten[^fn_99b_28] or added ten to it[^fn_99b_29] his *terumah* is nevertheless valid',[^fn_99b_30] while in respect of an owner[^fn_99b_26] it was taught: If, when setting apart *terumah*, there came up in his hand even so much as one twentieth[^fn_99b_27] his *terumah* is valid.[^fn_99b_31]

Come and hear: IF HER KETHUBAH WAS FOR FOUR HUNDRED ZUZ AND SHE SOLD \[PLOTS OF LAND\] TO \[THREE\] PERSONS[^fn_99b_32] TO EACH FOR ONE MANEH, AND TO A FOURTH[^fn_99b_32] \[SHE SOLD\] WHAT WAS WORTH A MANEH AND A DENAR FOR ONE MANEH, \[THE SALE\] TO THE LAST PERSON IS VOID BUT \[THE SALES\] OF ALL OTHERS ARE VALID.[^fn_99b_33] R. Shisha the son of R. Ishi replied: \[This clause deals\] with small plots of land.[^fn_99b_34]

***MISHNAH***. IF AN ASSESSMENT OF THE JUDGES[^fn_99b_35] WAS BY ONE SIXTH LESS, OR BY ONE SIXTH MORE \[THAN THE ACTUAL VALUE OF THE PROPERTY\]. THEIR SALE IS VOID. R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL RULED: THEIR SALE IS VALID FOR, OTHERWISE,[^fn_99b_36] OF WHAT ADVANTAGE WOULD THE POWER OF A COURT BE? IF A BILL FOR INSPECTION,[^fn_99b_37] HOWEVER, HAS BEEN DRAWN UP, THEIR SALE IS VALID EVEN IF THEY SOLD FOR TWO HUNDRED ZUZ[^fn_99b_38] WHAT WAS WORTH ONE MANEH,[^fn_99b_38] OR FOR ONE MANEH WHAT WAS WORTH TWO HUNDRED ZUZ. {¶=11.5}

***GEMARA***. The question was asked: What is the legal status of[^fn_99b_39] an agent?[^fn_99b_40] — [pg 100a]

Raba in the name of R. Nahman replied: An agent \[has the same status\] as judges,[^fn_100a_1] but R. Samuel b. Bisna replied in the name of R. Nahman: As a widow.[^fn_100a_2] 'Raba in the name of R. Nahman replied: An agent \[has the same status\] as judges', for as judges do not act in their \[personal interests\] so does an agent not act in his \[personal interests\], thus excluding a widow who acts in her \[own personal interests\]. 'R. Samuel b. Bisna replied in the name of R. Nahman: As a widow', for as the widow is a single individual so is an agent a single individual; thus excluding members of a court, who are many. — And the law is that an agent \[has the same legal status\] as a widow. But why \[should this case be\] different from that concerning which we learned: If a man tells his agent, 'Go and give terumah' the latter must give the *terumah* in accordance with the disposition of the owner, and if he does not know the owner's disposition, he should separate *terumah* in a moderate manner, viz. one fiftieth. If he reduced \[the denominator by\] ten or added ten to it his *terumah* is, nevertheless, valid?[^fn_100a_3] — There[^fn_100a_4] \[the circumstances are different\], for, since someone might give his *terumah* in a niggardly manner while some other might give it liberally, \[the agent\][^fn_100a_5] might tell the owner, 'I deemed[^fn_100a_6] you to be of such \[a disposition\]';[^fn_100a_7] but here, since it was clearly an error, \[the owner\] might well say, 'You should have made no error'.[^fn_100a_8]

R. Huna b. Hanina stated in the name of R. Nahman: The *halachah* is in agreement with the ruling of the Sages.[^fn_100a_9] \[Can it be said,\] however, that R. Nahman does not hold \[that the act of a court is invariably valid since, otherwise,\] of what advantage would the power of a court be,[^fn_100a_10] when R. Nahman, in fact, ruled in the name of Samuel:[^fn_100a_11] If orphans came to take their shares in their father's estate, the court must appoint for \[each of\] them a guardian and \[these guardians\] choose for \[each of\] them a proper share, and when \[the orphans\] grow up they may enter a protest \[against the settlement\]; but R. Nahman in his own name, laid down: Even when they grow up they may enter no protest since, otherwise, of what advantage would the power of a court be? — This is no difficulty, the former[^fn_100a_12] \[referring to a case\] where the guardians made a mistake while the latter[^fn_100a_13] \[deals with one\] where no error was made. If no error was made, on what grounds could \[the orphans\] enter their protest? — On that of the adjacent fields.[^fn_100a_14]

When R. Dimi came[^fn_100a_15] he stated: It once happened that Rabbi[^fn_100a_16] acted in agreement with the ruling of the Sages[^fn_100a_9] when Perata, the son of R. Eleazar b. Perata, grandson of R. Perata the Great, asked him, 'If so, of what advantage would the power of a court be?'[^fn_100a_10] And \[as a result\] Rabbi reversed his decision. Thus it was taught by R. Dimi. R. Safra, however, taught as follows: It once happened that Rabbi[^fn_100a_16] desired to act in agreement with the ruling of the Sages,[^fn_100a_9] when Perata, the son of R. Eleazar b. Perata, grandson of R. Perata the Great, said to him, 'If so, of what advantage is the power of a court?' And[^fn_100a_17] \[as a result\] Rabbi did not act as he intended.[^fn_100a_18] Must it be assumed that they[^fn_100a_19] differ on this principle: One master[^fn_100a_20] holds the view that if \[in giving a decision\] a law cited in a Mishnah[^fn_100a_21] has been overlooked the decision must be reversed, and the other Master[^fn_100a_22] upholds the view[^fn_100a_23] that it cannot be reversed?[^fn_100a_24] — No; all[^fn_100a_19] agree that if \[in giving a decision\] a law cited in a Mishnah has been overlooked the decision must be reversed, but one Master holds that the incident occurred in one way[^fn_100a_25] while the other holds that it occurred in the other way.[^fn_100a_25]

R. Joseph stated: If a widow sold \[any of her deceased husband's estate\][^fn_100a_26] the responsibility for the indemnity falls upon the orphans,[^fn_100a_27] and if the court sold \[any such property\][^fn_100a_28] the responsibility for the indemnity again falls upon the orphans.[^fn_100a_29] \[Is not this ruling\] obvious?[^fn_100a_30] — It was not necessary \[indeed in respect of\] the widow,[^fn_100a_30] but was required \[in respect of\] the court; for it might have been assumed [pg 100b]

that whoever buys from the court does so in order that he may have the benefit of a public announcement,[^fn_100b_1] hence we were informed \[that the responsibility for the indemnity still remains upon the orphans\].

R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL RULED etc. To what limit \[of error\]?[^fn_100b_2] — R. Huna b. Judah replied in the name of R. Shesheth: To a half.[^fn_100b_3] So it was also taught: R. Simeon b. Gamaliel ruled, If the court sold for one *maneh* what was worth two hundred *zuz*, or for two hundred *zuz* what was worth one *maneh*, their sale is valid.

Amemar laid down in the name of R. Joseph: A court that sold \[one's estate\] without a \[previous\] public announcement are deemed[^fn_100b_4] to have overlooked a law cited in a Mishnah and \[their decision\][^fn_100b_5] must be reversed. \[You say\] 'Are deemed'?[^fn_100b_4] Have they not in actual fact overlooked one,' we learned:[^fn_100b_6] The assessment \[of the property\] of the orphans[^fn_100b_7] \[must be accompanied by a public announcement for a period of\] thirty days, and the assessment of consecrated land[^fn_100b_8] \[for a period of\] sixty days; and the announcement must be made both in the morning and in the evening?[^fn_100b_9] — If \[the ruling[^fn_100b_10] were to be derived\] from that \[Mishnah alone\] it might be presumed that it applied only to an agent[^fn_100b_11] but not to a court; hence we were taught[^fn_100b_10] \[that the law applied to a court also\].

R. Ashi raised an objection against Amemar: IF AN ASSESSMENT OF JUDGES WAS BY ONE SIXTH LESS, OR ONE SIXTH MORE \[THAN THE ACTUAL VALUE OF THE PROPERTY\], THEIR SALE IS VOID, but \[it follows\] if it corresponded to the actual worth of the land[^fn_100b_12] their sale is valid. Does not this[^fn_100b_13] \[apply even to a case\] where no public announcement was made?[^fn_100b_14] — No; \[it applies only to one\] where an announcement was made. But since the final clause \[refers to a case\] where an announcement was made \[must not\] the first clause[^fn_100b_15] \[refer to one\] where no announcement was made; for in the final clause it was taught: IF A BILL FOR INSPECTION,[^fn_100b_16] HOWEVER, HAS BEEN DRAWN UP, THEIR SALE IS VALID EVEN IF THEY SOLD FOR TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ* WHAT WAS WORTH ONE *MANEH*, OR FOR ONE *MANEH* WHAT WAS WORTH TWO HUNDRED *ZUZ*?[^fn_100b_17] — The fact indeed is \[that the first clause refers to a case\] where no announcement was made, and \[yet[^fn_100b_18] there is\] no difficulty, for one ruling[^fn_100b_19] refers to objects concerning which public announcements must be made, while the other[^fn_100b_20] refers to objects concerning which no public announcements are made, such as[^fn_100b_21] slaves, movables and deeds. (What is the reason \[why no announcement is made in the case of\] slaves? — \[Because if one were made\] they might hear It and escape. Movables and deeds? — Because they might be stolen.) If you wish I might reply:[^fn_100b_22] One ruling[^fn_100b_23] refers to a time when an announcement is made while the others refers to a time when no announcement is made, the Nehardeans having laid down that for poll-tax,[^fn_100b_24] maintenance[^fn_100b_25] and funeral expenses \[an estate\][^fn_100b_26] is sold without a public announcement.[^fn_100b_27] And if you prefer I might reply:[^fn_100b_22] One ruling[^fn_100b_23] applies to a place where announcements are made while the other[^fn_100b_20] applies to one where no announcements are made, R. Nahman having stated: Never was a bill for inspection[^fn_100b_28] drawn up at Nehardea.[^fn_100b_29] From this \[statement\][^fn_100b_30] one implied that \[the reason[^fn_100b_31] was\] because they[^fn_100b_32] were experts in assessments; but R. Joseph b. Minyomi stated: It was explained to me by R. Nahman \[that the reason is\] because they[^fn_100b_33] were nicknamed 'consumers of publicly auctioned estates',[^fn_100b_34]

Rab Judah ruled in the name of Samuel: Orphans' movables must be assessed[^fn_100b_35] and sold forthwith.[^fn_100b_36] R. Hisda ruled in the name of Abimi: They are to be sold[^fn_100b_37] in the markets.[^fn_100b_38] There is, however, no difference of opinion between them.[^fn_100b_39] One speaks of a place[^fn_100b_40] in the proximity of a market,[^fn_100b_41] while the other deals with one[^fn_100b_40] from which the market is far.[^fn_100b_42]

R. Kahana had in his possession some beer that belonged to the orphan R. Mesharsheya b. Hilkai. He kept it until the festival,[^fn_100b_43] saying, 'Though it might deteriorate,[^fn_100b_44] it will have a quick sale.'[^fn_100b_45]

Rabina had In his possession some wine belonging to the orphan Rabina the Little, his sister's son, and he had also some wine of his own which he was about to take up to Sikara.[^fn_100b_46] When he came to R. Ashi and asked him, 'May I carry \[the orphan's wine\] with my own'[^fn_100b_47] the other told him, 'You may go; it is not superior to your own.

***MISHNAH***. \[A MINOR\] WHO EXERCISED THE RIGHT OF *MI'UN*,[^fn_100b_48] A FORBIDDEN RELATIVE OF THE SECOND DEGREE,[^fn_100b_49] OR A WOMAN WHO IS INCAPABLE OF PROCREATION IS NOT ENTITLED EITHER TO A *KETHUBAH*[^fn_100b_50] OR TO THE BENEFITS[^fn_100b_51] \[OF HER *MELOG*[^fn_100b_48] PROPERTY\][^fn_100b_52] OR TO MAINTENANCE,[^fn_100b_53] OR TO HER WORN OUT ARTICLES.[^fn_100b_54] IF THE MAN, HOWEVER, HAD MARRIED HER AT THE OUTSET ON THE UNDERSTANDING THAT SHE WAS INCAPABLE OF PROCREATION SHE IS ENTITLED TO A *KETHUBAH*. A WIDOW WHO WAS MARRIED TO A HIGH PRIEST,[^fn_100b_55] A DIVORCED WOMAN OR A *HALUZAH*[^fn_100b_48] WHO WAS MARRIED TO A COMMON PRIEST,[^fn_100b_56] A BASTARD OR A NETHINAH[^fn_100b_48] WHO WAS MARRIED TO AN ISRAELITE. OR THE DAUGHTER OF AN ISRAELITE WHO WAS MARRIED TO A NATHIN,[^fn_100b_48] OR A BASTARD IS ENTITLED TO A *KETHUBAH*.[^fn_100b_57] {¶=11.6}

***GEMARA***. Rab taught: A minor who is released by means of a letter of divorce is not entitled to a *kethubah*[^fn_100b_58] and, much less so, \[a minor\] who exercises the right of *mi'un*[^fn_100b_48] Samuel taught: \[A minor\] who exercises the right of *mi'un*[^fn_100b_48] is not entitled to a *kethubah*,[^fn_100b_59] but a minor who is released by a letter of divorce is entitled to her *kethubah*.[^fn_100b_60] Samuel[^fn_100b_61] follows his \[previously expressed\] principle; for he laid down: \[A minor\] who exercises the right of *mi'un*[^fn_100b_62] is not entitled to a *kethubah*[^fn_100b_63] but a minor who is released by a letter of divorce is entitled to her *kethubah*,'[^fn_100b_64] \[a minor\] who exercises the right of *mi'un*[^fn_100b_62] is not \[through this act\] disqualified from marrying the brothers \[of her husband\],[^fn_100b_65] nor is she thereby disqualified from marrying a priest,[^fn_100b_66] but \[a minor who\] is released by a letter of divorce is \[through this act\] disqualified from marrying the brothers \[of her husband\][^fn_100b_67] and also from marrying a priest;[^fn_100b_68] \[a minor\] who exercises the right of *mi'un* need not wait three months[^fn_100b_69] [pg 101a]

but \[a minor who\] was released by a letter of divorce must wait three months.[^fn_101a_1] What does he[^fn_101a_2] teach us when all these cases have already been taught:[^fn_101a_3] If \[a minor\] has exercised the right of *mi'un* against her husband he is permitted to marry her relatives[^fn_101a_4] and she is permitted to marry his relatives,[^fn_101a_4] and he does not disqualify her from marrying a priest;[^fn_101a_5] but if he gave her a letter of divorce he is forbidden to marry her relatives and she is forbidden to marry his relatives and he also disqualifies her from marrying a priest?[^fn_101a_6] — He found it necessary \[to restate these rulings in order to mention:\] 'She must wait three months' which we did not learn.[^fn_101a_7]

Must one assume \[that they[^fn_101a_8] differ on the same principles\] as the following Tannaim: R. Eliezer stated, There is no validity whatsoever in the act of a minor, and her husband is entitled neither to anything she finds,[^fn_101a_9] nor to the work of her hands,[^fn_101a_9] nor may he invalidate her vows;[^fn_101a_10] he is not her heir[^fn_101a_9] and he may not defile himself for her;[^fn_101a_11] this being the general rule: She is in no respect regarded as his wife, except that it is necessary for her to make a declaration of refusal;[^fn_101a_12] and R. Joshua stated, The act of a minor is valid, and her husband has the right to anything she finds[^fn_101a_13] and to the work of her hands,[^fn_101a_13] to invalidate her vows,[^fn_101a_14] to be her heir,[^fn_101a_13] and to defile himself for her;[^fn_101a_15] the general principle being that she is regarded as his wife in every respect, except that she may leave him[^fn_101a_12] by declaring her refusal against him?[^fn_101a_16] Must one then assume that Rab[^fn_101a_17] has laid down the same principle as that of R. Eliezer[^fn_101a_18] and that Samuel[^fn_101a_19] has laid down the same principle as that of R. Joshua?[^fn_101a_20] — There is no difference of opinion between them[^fn_101a_21] as to what was the view[^fn_101a_22] of R. Eliezer;[^fn_101a_23] they differ only in respect of the view[^fn_101a_22] of R. Joshua. Samuel \[ruled\] In agreement with R. Joshua; but Rab argued that[^fn_101a_24] R. Joshua maintained his view only there[^fn_101a_25] \[where the benefits[^fn_101a_26] are transferred\] from her to him[^fn_101a_27] but not \[where the benefits[^fn_101a_28] are to be transferred\] from him to her.[^fn_101a_29]

OR TO HER WORN OUT ARTICLES. Said R. Huna b. Hiyya to R. Kahana: You have told us in the name of Samuel that this[^fn_101a_30] was taught only in respect of *melog*,[^fn_101a_31] but that to zon barzel[^fn_101a_31] property she is entitled. R. Papa, in considering this statement, raised the point: To which \[class of women did Samuel refer\]? If it be suggested: To \[A MINOR\] WHO EXERCISED THE RIGHT OF *MI'UN* \[the difficulty would arise:\] If \[the articles\] are still in existence she would be entitled to receive them in either case,[^fn_101a_32] and if they were no longer in existence she would in neither case[^fn_101a_32] be entitled to receive them.[^fn_101a_33] \[Is the reference\], then, to A WOMAN WHO IS INCAPABLE OF PROCREATION? \[But here again, it may be objected:\] If \[the articles\] were still in existence she would receive them in either case,[^fn_101a_32] and if they no longer existed \[the ruling\] should be reversed: She should receive *melog* property since \[the capital\] always remains in her legal possession[^fn_101a_34] but should not receive zon barzel property since \[the capital\] does not remain in her possession.[^fn_101a_35] \[The fact,\] however, \[is that the reference is\] to A FORBIDDEN RELATIVE OF THE SECOND DEGREE, in whose case[^fn_101a_36] the Rabbis have penalized the woman in respect of \[what is due to her\] from the man,[^fn_101a_37] and the man in respect of \[what is due to him\] from the woman.[^fn_101a_38] R. Shimi b. Ashi remarked: From R. Kahana's statement[^fn_101a_39] it may be inferred \[that if a lawful wife\] brought to her husband[^fn_101a_40] a cloak,[^fn_101a_41] the article is \[to be treated as\] capital and the man may not continue to wear it until it is worn out.[^fn_101a_42] But did not R. Nahman, however, rule that \[a cloak must be treated as\] produce?[^fn_101a_43] — He[^fn_101a_44] differs from R. Nahman.

IS NOT ENTITLED \[…\] TO A *KETHUBAH*. Samuel stated: This was taught only in respect of the *maneh*[^fn_101a_45] and the two hundred *zuz*,'[^fn_101a_46] to the additional jointure,[^fn_101a_47] however, she[^fn_101a_48] is entitled. So it was also taught: The women concerning whom the Sages have ruled, 'They are not entitled to a kethubah' as, for instance, a minor who exercised the right of *mi'un*[^fn_101a_39] and the others enumerated in the same context,[^fn_101a_49] are not entitled to the *maneh*[^fn_101a_50] or to the two hundred *zuz*,[^fn_101a_51] but are entitled to their additional jointures; women, however, concerning whom the Sages have ruled, 'They may be divorced without \[receiving their\] kethubah' as, for instance, \[a wife who\] transgresses the \[Mosaic\] law, and others enumerated in the same context,[^fn_101a_52] are not entitled to their additional jointures[^fn_101a_47] and much less to \[their statutory kethubahs of\] a *maneh*[^fn_101a_50] or two hundred *zuz*;[^fn_101a_51] whilst a woman who is divorced on the ground of in repute[^fn_101a_53] takes only[^fn_101a_54] what is hers[^fn_101a_55] and departs. This[^fn_101a_56] provides support to R. Hunah who laid down: If she played the harlot \[a wife\] does not in consequence forfeit [pg 101b]

her worn out articles that are still in existence.

A tanna recited in the presence of R. Nahman: \[A wife who\] played the harlot forfeits in consequence her worn out articles \[though they are still\] in existence. 'If she', the other said to him, 'has played the harlot, have her chattels also played the harlot?[^fn_101b_1] Recite rather: She does not forfeit her worn out articles \[that are still\] in existence' — Rabbah b. Bar Hana stated in the name of R. Johanan: This[^fn_101b_2] is the view of the unnamed R. Menahem,[^fn_101b_3] but the Sages ruled: \[A wife who\] played the harlot does not thereby forfeit her worn out articles that are still in existence.

IF THE MAN, HOWEVER, HAD MARRIED HER etc. Said R. Huna: A woman incapable of procreation \[has sometimes the status of\] a wife and \[sometimes she has\] no such status;[^fn_101b_4] a widow[^fn_101b_5] \[has always the status of\] a proper wife. 'A woman incapable of procreation \[has sometimes the status of\] a wife and \[sometimes she\] has no such status'; if the husband knew of her \[defect\][^fn_101b_6] she is entitled to a *kethubah*[^fn_101b_7] and if he did not know of her \[defect\] she is not entitled to a *kethubah*. 'A widows \[has always the status of\] a proper wife', for, whether her husband was aware of her \[widowhood\] or whether he was not aware of it, she is always entitled to a *kethubah*. Rab Judah, however, said: The one[^fn_101b_8] as well as the other[^fn_101b_9] \[has sometimes the status of\] a wife and \[sometimes she has\] no such status,[^fn_101b_4] for \[in either case\] if her husband was aware of her \[condition or status\] she is entitled to a *kethubah* and if he was not aware of it she is not entitled to a *kethubah*. An objection was raised: If \[a High Priest\] married on the presumption that \[the woman\] was in her widowhood[^fn_101b_10] and it was found that she had been in such a condition,[^fn_101b_10] she is entitled to her *kethubah*. Does not this imply that if[^fn_101b_11] there was no presumption[^fn_101b_12] she is not entitled to a *kethubah*?[^fn_101b_13] — Do not infer 'that[^fn_101b_11] if there was no such presumption' but infer \[this:\] If he married her on the presumption that she was not in her widowhood[^fn_101b_14] and it was found that she had been in such a condition,[^fn_101b_14] she is not entitled to a *kethubah*. What, however, \[is the ruling where he married her\] with no assumption? Is she entitled \[to a *kethubah*\]? Then instead of stating, 'On the presumption that \[the woman\] was in her widowhood[^fn_101b_14] and it was found that she had been in such a condition,[^fn_101b_14] she is entitled to her kethubah', should it not rather have been stated, 'With no assumption she is entitled to her kethubah'[^fn_101b_15] and \[it would have been obvious that this[^fn_101b_16] applied\] with even greater force to the former?[^fn_101b_17] Furthermore, it was explicitly taught: If he[^fn_101b_18] married her in the belief[^fn_101b_19] \[that she was a widow\] and it was found that his belief was justified,[^fn_101b_19] she is entitled to a *kethubah*, but if he married her with no assumption she is not entitled to a *kethubah*. \[Does not this present\] an 'objection against R. Huna? — It was our Mishnah that caused R. Huna to err. He thought that, since a distinction was drawn in the case of a woman incapable of procreation[^fn_101b_20] and no distinction was drawn in respect of a widow, it must be inferred that a widow is entitled \[to a *kethubah* even if she was married\] with no assumption of her status. \[In fact, however\] this is no \[proper conclusion\], for in stating the case of a widow the author intended to apply to it[^fn_101b_21] the distinction drawn in the case of the woman who was incapable of procreation.[^fn_101b_22]

## CHAPTER XII

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN MARRIED A WIFE AND SHE MADE AN ARRANGEMENT WITH HIM THAT HE SHOULD MAINTAIN HER DAUGHTER[^fn_101b_23] FOR FIVE YEARS, HE MUST MAINTAIN HER FOR FIVE YEARS. IF SHE WAS \[SUBSEQUENTLY\][^fn_101b_24] MARRIED TO ANOTHER MAN AND ARRANGED WITH HIM ALSO THAT HE SHOULD MAINTAIN HER DAUGHTER[^fn_101b_23] FOR FIVE YEARS, HE, TOO, MUST MAINTAIN HER FOR FIVE YEARS. THE FIRST HUSBAND IS NOT ENTITLED TO PLEAD, 'IF SHE WILL. COME TO ME I WILL MAINTAIN HER',[^fn_101b_25] BUT HE MUST FORWARD HER MAINTENANCE TO HER AT THE PLACE WHERE HER MOTHER \[LIVES\].[^fn_101b_26] SIMILARLY, THE TWO HUSBANDS CANNOT PLEAD, 'WE WILL MAINTAIN HER JOINTLY', BUT ONE MUST MAINTAIN HER AND THE OTHER ALLOW HER THE COST OF HER MAINTENANCE. IF SHE[^fn_101b_27] MARRIED[^fn_101b_24] HER HUSBAND MUST SUPPLY HER WITH MAINTENANCE AND THEY[^fn_101b_28] ALLOW HER THE COST OF HER MAINTENANCE. SHOULD THEY[^fn_101b_29] DIE, THEIR OWN DAUGHTERS ARE TO BE MAINTAINED OUT OF THEIR FREE ASSETS ONLY[^fn_101b_30] BUT SHE[^fn_101b_27] MUST BE MAINTAINED EVEN OUT OF ASSIGNED PROPERTY, BECAUSE SHE[^fn_101b_31] \[HAS THE SAME LEGAL STATUS\] AS A CREDITOR. PRUDENT MEN USED TO WRITE,[^fn_101b_32] 'ON CONDITION THAT I SHALL MAINTAIN YOUR DAUGHTER FOR FIVE YEARS WHILE YOU \[CONTINUE TO LIVE\] WITH ME'. {¶=12.1}

***GEMARA***. It was stated: A man who said to his fellow, 'I owe you a maneh'[^fn_101b_33] is, R. Johanan ruled, liable; but Resh Lakish ruled: He is free. How is one to understand \[this dispute\]? If \[it refers to a case\] where the man said to them[^fn_101b_34] 'You are my witnesses', what \[it might be objected\] is the reason of Resh Lakish who holds him to be free?[^fn_101b_35] If \[it is a case\] where he did not say to them,[^fn_101b_34] 'You are my witnesses, what \[it might equally be objected\] can be the reason of R. Johanan who holds him liable?[^fn_101b_36] The fact is[^fn_101b_37] that \[the dispute relates to a case\] where he did not tell them, 'You are my witnesses', but here we are[^fn_101b_38] dealing \[with the case of a person\] who said to another, 'I owe you a maneh'[^fn_101b_33] by \[handing to him\][^fn_101b_39] a note of indebtedness.[^fn_101b_40] R. Johanan ruled: He is liable, because the contents[^fn_101b_41] of a bond[^fn_101b_42] has the same force as if the man \[who delivered it\] said, 'You are my witnesses'; but Resh Lakish ruled: He is free, because the contents[^fn_101b_41] of a bond has no binding force.

We learned: IF A MAN MARRIED A WIFE AND SHE MADE AN AGREEMENT WITH HIM THAT HE SHALL MAINTAIN HER DAUGHTER FOR FIVE YEARS, HE MUST MAINTAIN HER FOR FIVE YEARS. Does not this refer to,[^fn_101b_43] a case like this?[^fn_101b_44] [pg 102a]

— No, \[our Mishnah is dealing\] with deeds on verbal agreements,[^fn_102a_1] and \[the ruling[^fn_102a_2] was necessary\] in accordance with \[the view\] of R. Giddal, since R. Giddal has laid down in the name of Rab:[^fn_102a_3] \[if[^fn_102a_4] one man said to another.\] 'How much are you giving to your son?' \[and the other replies.\] 'Such and such a sum', and \[when the other asks.\] 'How much are you giving to your daughter?' \[the first replies.\] 'Such and such a sum', \[and on the basis of this talk\] a betrothal was effected,[^fn_102a_5] *kinyan* is deemed to have been executed, these being matters concerning which *kinyan* is effected by a mere verbal arrangement.[^fn_102a_6]

Come and hear: If a man gave to a priest in writing \[a statement\] that he[^fn_102a_7] owed him five sela's[^fn_102a_8] he must[^fn_102a_9] pay him the five sela's and his son is not redeemed thereby![^fn_102a_10] — There \[the law\] is different because one is under a pentateuchal obligation \[to give them\] to him.[^fn_102a_11] If that be so, why did he write? — In order to choose for himself a priest.[^fn_102a_12] If that is the case[^fn_102a_13] why is not his son redeemed?[^fn_102a_14] — In agreement with a ruling of 'Ulla; For 'Ulla said, pentateuchally \[the son\] is redeemed as soon as \[the father\] gives \[the note of money indebtedness to the priest,\] and the reason why the Rabbis ruled that he was not redeemed is because a preventive measure was enacted against the possibility of the assumption that redemption may be effected by means of bonds \[in general\].[^fn_102a_15]

Raba said: \[Their[^fn_102a_16] dispute seems to follow the same principles\] as \[laid down by\] Tannaim: \[If the guarantee\] of a guarantor appears[^fn_102a_17] below the signatures to bonds of indebtedness,[^fn_102a_18] \[the creditor\] may recover his debt from \[the guarantor's\] free property.[^fn_102a_19] Such a case once came before R. Ishmael who decided that \[the debt\] may be recovered from \[the guarantor's\] free property.[^fn_102a_19] Ben Nannus, however, said to him, '\[The debt may\] be recovered neither from free property nor from assigned property'. 'Why?' the other asked him. 'Behold', he replied, 'this is just as if \[a creditor\] were \[in the act of\] throttling a debtor[^fn_102a_20] in the street,[^fn_102a_21] and his friend found him and said to him, "Leave him alone and I will pay you", \[where he is undoubtedly\] exempt from liability, since the loan was not made through trust in him.'[^fn_102a_22] May it not be suggested that R. Johanan holds the same view as R. Ishmael while Resh Lakish holds that of Ben Nannus? — On the view of Ben Nannus there can be no difference of opinion;[^fn_102a_23] [pg 102b]

their dispute, however, might relate to the view of R. Ishmael. R. Johanan is, \[of course,\] in agreement with R. Ishmael, while Resh Lakish \[might argue:\] R. Ishmael maintains his view there[^fn_102b_1] only[^fn_102b_2] because a pentateuchal responsibility is involved[^fn_102b_3] but \[not\] here where no pentateuchal responsibility is involved.

The \[above\] text \[stated\]: 'R. Giddal has laid down in the name of Rab: \[If one man said to another,\] "How much are you giving to your son?" \[and the other replied,\] "Such and such a sun,", and \[when the other asks,\] "How much are you giving to your daughter?" \[the first replies,\] "Such and such a sum", \[and on the basis of this talk\] betrothal was effected, *kinyan* is deemed to have been executed, these being matters concerning which *kinyan* is effected by a mere verbal arrangement'.[^fn_102b_4] Said Raba: It stands to reason that Rab's ruling should apply \[only\] to the case of a man whose daughter was[^fn_102b_5] a na'arah,[^fn_102b_6] since the benefit \[of her betrothal\][^fn_102b_7] goes to him,[^fn_102b_8] but not to that of a bogereth,[^fn_102b_6] since the benefit \[of the betrothal of the latter\]' does not go to him; but, by God! Rab meant \[his ruling to include\] even one who is a bogereth. For, should you not concede this, \[the objection could be put:\] What benefit does the son's[^fn_102b_9] father derive?[^fn_102b_10] The reason consequently must be that[^fn_102b_11] owing to the pleasure of the formation of a mutual family tie they decide to allow one another the full rights of *kinyan*.

Said Rabina to R. Ashi: Are those verbal arrangements,[^fn_102b_12] allowed to be recorded[^fn_102b_13] or are they not allowed to be recorded?[^fn_102b_14] — They, the other replied, may not be recorded.[^fn_102b_15] He[^fn_102b_16] raised an objection against him:[^fn_102b_17] PRUDENT MEN USED TO WRITE,[^fn_102b_18] ON CONDITION THAT I SHALL MAINTAIN YOUR DAUGHTER FOR FIVE YEARS WHILE YOU \[CONTINUE TO LIVE\] WITH ME'?[^fn_102b_19] — The meaning of[^fn_102b_20] 'WRITE' \[in this context\] is 'say'. Could 'saying', however, be described as 'writing'? — Yes, for so we learned: If a husband gives to his wife a written undertaking,[^fn_102b_21] 'I have no claim whatsoever upon your estates',[^fn_102b_22] and R. Hiyya taught:[^fn_102b_23] If a husband said[^fn_102b_24] to his wife.[^fn_102b_25]

Come and hear: Deeds of betrothal[^fn_102b_26] and marriage[^fn_102b_27] may not be written except with the consent of both parties,[^fn_102b_28] but, \[it follows, that\] with the consent of both parties they may be written. Does not this refer to[^fn_102b_29] deeds based on verbal agreements?[^fn_102b_30] — No; deeds of actual betrothal,[^fn_102b_31] \[the ruling[^fn_102b_32] being\] in agreement with R. papa and R. Sherabya; for it was stated: If a man wrote it[^fn_102b_33] in her name[^fn_102b_34] but without her consent she is, said Rabbah[^fn_102b_35] and Rabina, betrothed, but R. Papa and R. Sherabya aid, She is not betrothed.[^fn_102b_36]

Come and hear: SHOULD THEY DIE, THEIR OWN DAUGHTERS ARE TO BE MAINTAINED OUT OF THEIR FREE PROPERTY ONLY BUT SHE MUST BE MAINTAINED EVEN OUT OF ASSIGNED PROPERTY, BECAUSE SHE \[HAS THE SAME LEGAL STATUS\] AS A CREDITOR![^fn_102b_37] Here we are dealing with a case where the man was made to confirm his obligation[^fn_102b_38] by a *kinyan*.[^fn_102b_39] If so,[^fn_102b_40] \[the same right[^fn_102b_41] should be enjoyed, should it not, by one's own\] daughters also? — \[This is a case\] where *kinyan* was executed in favour of the ones but not in favour of the others.[^fn_102b_42] Whence this certainty?[^fn_102b_43] — Since she was in existence at the time the *kinyan* was executed, the *kinyan* in her favour is effective; the other daughters,[^fn_102b_44] however, since they were not in existence at the time the *kinyan* was executed, the *kinyan* in their favour is not effective. But do we not also deal with the case where they[^fn_102b_45] were in existence at the time of the *kinyan*, this being possible where,[^fn_102b_46] for instance, the man had divorced his wife and then remarried her? — \[This\] however, \[is the explanation:\] Since she is not covered by the provision of *Beth din*[^fn_102b_47] *kinyan* in her case is effective; in the case of the other daughters, however, who are protected by the provision of *Beth din*,[^fn_102b_47] *kinyan* is not effective. Are they, on that account, worse off?[^fn_102b_48] — This, however, is the reason: In the case of his own daughters, since they are protected by the provision of *Beth din*,[^fn_102b_47] it might be assumed that he entrusted them[^fn_102b_49] with some bundles \[of money\].[^fn_102b_50]

THE FIRST HUSBAND IS NOT ENTITLED TO PLEAD \[etc.\] R. Hisda stated: This[^fn_102b_51] implies that \[the place of\] a daughter must be with her mother.[^fn_102b_52] Whence, \[however, the proof\] that we are dealing here[^fn_102b_53] with one who is of age; is it not possible that[^fn_102b_54] we are dealing only with a minor \[whose custody must be entrusted to her mother\] on account of what had once happened? For it was taught: If a man died and left a young son with his mother,[^fn_102b_55] \[and while\] the father's heirs demand, 'Let him be brought up with us' his mother claims, 'My son should be brought up by me', \[the son\] must be left with his mother, but may not be left with anyone who is entitled to be his heir.[^fn_102b_56] Such a case[^fn_102b_57] once occurred and \[the heirs\] killed him on the eve of passover![^fn_102b_58] — If that were so[^fn_102b_59] it should have been stated,[^fn_102b_60] 'To wherever she is,' [pg 103a]

why then was it stated, 'AT THE PLACE WHERE HER MOTHER \[LIVES\]'?[^fn_103a_1] Consequently it must be inferred that \[the place of\] a daughter, whether she be of age or a minor, is with her mother.

THE TWO HUSBANDS CANNOT PLEAD etc. A certain man once leased his mill to another for \[the consideration of the latter's services in\] grinding \[his corn\].[^fn_103a_2] Eventually he became rich and bought another mill and an ass. Thereupon he said to the other, 'Until now I have had my grinding done at your place but now[^fn_103a_3] pay me rent'. — 'I shall', the other replied, 'only grind for you'.[^fn_103a_4] Rabina \[in considering the case\] intended to rule that it involved the very principle that was laid down in our Mishnah: THE TWO HUSBANDS CANNOT PLEAD, 'WE WILL MAINTAIN HER JOINTLY', BUT ONE MUST MAINTAIN HER AND THE OTHER ALLOWS HER THE COST OF HER MAINTENANCE.[^fn_103a_5] R. 'Awira, however, said to him: Are \[the two cases\] alike? There \[the woman\][^fn_103a_6] has Only one stomach, not two;[^fn_103a_7] but here[^fn_103a_8] \[the lessee\] might well tell the owner, 'Grind \[in your own mill\][^fn_103a_9] and sell; grind \[in mine\][^fn_103a_10] and keep'.[^fn_103a_11] This,[^fn_103a_12] however, has been said only in a case where \[the lessee\] has no \[other orders for\] grinding at his mill,[^fn_103a_13] but if he has \[sufficient orders for\] grinding at his mill he may in such circumstances be compelled \[not to act\] in the manner of Sodom.[^fn_103a_14]

***MISHNAH***. SHOULD A WIDOW SAY, 'I HAVE NO DESIRE TO MOVE FROM MY HUSBAND'S HOUSE', THE HEIRS CANNOT TELL HER, GO TO YOUR FATHER'S HOUSE AND WE WILL MAINTAIN YOU', BUT THEY MUST MAINTAIN HER IN HER HUSBAND'S HOUSE[^fn_103a_15] AND GIVE HER A DWELLING BECOMING HER DIGNITY. IF SHE SAID, HOWEVER,[^fn_103a_16] HAVE NO DESIRE TO MOVE FROM MY FATHER'S HOUSE', THE HEIRS ARE ENTITLED TO SAY TO HER, 'IF YOU STAY WITH US YOU WILL HAVE YOUR MAINTENANCE, BUT IF YOU DO NOT STAY WITH US YOU WILL RECEIVE NO MAINTENANCE'. IF SHE BASED HER PLEA[^fn_103a_16] ON THE GROUND THAT SHE WAS YOUNG AND THEY[^fn_103a_17] WERE YOUNG,[^fn_103a_18] THEY MUST MAINTAIN HER WHILE SHE LIVES IN THE HOUSE OF HER FATHER. {¶=12.2}

***GEMARA***. Our Rabbis taught:[^fn_103a_19] \[A widow\] may use \[her deceased husband's\] dwelling as she used it during his[^fn_103a_20] lifetime. \[She may also use\] the bondmen and bondwomen, the cushions and the bolsters, and the silver and gold utensils as she used them during the lifetime of her husband, for such is the written undertaking he gave her: 'And you shall dwell in my house and be maintained therein out of my estate throughout the duration of your widowhood'.[^fn_103a_21]

R. Joseph learnt:[^fn_103a_22] 'In my house' \[implies\] 'but not in my hovel'.[^fn_103a_23]

R. Nahman ruled: If orphans sold a widow's dwelling[^fn_103a_24] their act is legally invalid.[^fn_103a_25] But why \[should this case be\] different from that of which R. Assi spoke in the name of R. Johanan as follows:[^fn_103a_26] If the male orphans forestalled \[the female orphans\] and sold[^fn_103a_27] some property of a small estate[^fn_103a_28] their sale is valid?[^fn_103a_29] — There[^fn_103a_30] \[the property\] Was not pledged to any daughter[^fn_103a_31] during \[her father's\] lifetime,[^fn_103a_32] but here[^fn_103a_33] \[the dwelling\] was pledged to the widow[^fn_103a_34] during \[her husband's\] lifetime.[^fn_103a_35]

Abaye stated: We have a tradition that if a widow's dwelling[^fn_103a_36] collapsed it is not the duty of the heirs to rebuild it.' So it was also taught: If a widow's dwelling[^fn_103a_36] collapsed it is not the duty of the heirs to rebuild it.[^fn_103a_37] Furthermore, even if she says, 'Allow me and I shall rebuild it at my own expense', she is not granted her request.[^fn_103a_38]

Abaye asked: What \[is the legal position if\] she repaired it?[^fn_103a_39] — This is undecided.[^fn_103a_40]

IF SHE SAID, HOWEVER,'I HAVE NO DESIRE' etc. Why should they not give her maintenance while she lives there?[^fn_103a_41] — This supports \[a statement\] of R. Huna who said, 'The blessing of a house \[is proportionate\] to its size'.[^fn_103a_42] Why then can they not give her according to the blessing of the house?[^fn_103a_43] — That is so.[^fn_103a_44]

Said R. Huna: The sayings[^fn_103a_45] of the Sages \[are a source of\] blessing, wealth and healing. \[As to\] 'blessing', \[we have\] the statement just mentioned. 'Wealth'? — Because we learned: If one sold fruits to another[^fn_103a_46] \[and the buyer\] pulled[^fn_103a_47] them, though they have not yet been measured,[^fn_103a_48] ownership is acquired. If, however, they have been measured,[^fn_103a_49] but \[the buyer\] has not pulled them, ownership is not acquired. But if \[the buyer\] is prudent he rents the place where they are kept.[^fn_103a_50] 'Healing'? — For we learned: A man should not chew wheat and put it on his wound during the Passover because it ferments.[^fn_103a_51]

Our Rabbis taught: When Rabbi[^fn_103a_52] was about to depart \[from this life\] he said, 'I require \[the presence\] of my sons'. When his sons entered into his presence he instructed them: 'Take care that you shew due respect to your mother. The light[^fn_103a_53] shall continue to burn in its usual place, the table[^fn_103a_53] shall be laid in its usual place \[and my\] bed shall be spread in its usual place.[^fn_103a_54] Joseph of Haifa and Simeon of Efrath who attended on me in my lifetime shall attend on me when I am dead'.

'Take care that you shew due respect to your mother'. Is \[not this instruction\] Pentateuchal, since it is written, Honour thy father and thy mother?[^fn_103a_55] — She was their stepmother.[^fn_103a_56] \[Is not the commandment to honour\] a stepmother[^fn_103a_56] also Pentateuchal, for it was taught: Honour thy father and thy mother,'[^fn_103a_55] 'thy father'[^fn_103a_57] includes[^fn_103a_58] 'thy stepmother','and thy mother'[^fn_103a_59] includes[^fn_103a_60] 'thy Stepfather',[^fn_103a_61] and the superfluous *waw*[^fn_103a_62] includes 'thy elder brother'? — This exposition[^fn_103a_63] \[was meant to apply\] during \[one's own parents'\] lifetime but not after \[their\] death.

'The light shall continue to burn in its usual place, the table shall be laid in its usual place \[and my\] bed shall be spread in its usual place'.[^fn_103a_64] What is the reason? — He used to come home again at twilight every Sabbath Eve. On a certain Sabbath Eve a neighbour came to the door speaking aloud, when his handmaid whispered, 'Be quiet for Rabbi is sitting there'. As soon as he heard this he came no more, in order that no reflection might be cast[^fn_103a_65] on the earlier saints.[^fn_103a_66]

'Joseph of Haifa and Simeon of Efrath who attended on me in my lifetime shall attend on me when I am dead'. He was understood to mean, 'In this world'.[^fn_103a_67] When it was seen however, that their biers preceded his[^fn_103a_68] \[all\] said that the conclusion must be that he was referring to the other[^fn_103a_69] world, and that the reason why he mentioned it[^fn_103a_70] was that it might not be suspected that they were guilty of some offence[^fn_103a_71] and that it was only the merit of Rabbi that protected[^fn_103a_72] them until that moment.[^fn_103a_73]

'I require'. he said to them, '\[the presence\] of the Sages of Israel', and the Sages of Israel entered into his presence. 'Do not lament for me',[^fn_103a_74] he said to them, 'in the smaller towns, [pg 103b]

and reassemble[^fn_103b_1] the college after thirty days.[^fn_103b_2] My son Simeon is wise[^fn_103b_3] my son Gamaliel Nasi[^fn_103b_4] and Hanina b. Hama shall preside \[at the college\].

'Do not lament for me in the smaller towns'. He was understood to give this instruction In order \[to cause less\] trouble.[^fn_103b_5] As it was observed, however, that when lamentations were held in the large towns everybody[^fn_103b_6] came[^fn_103b_7] they arrived at the conclusion that his instruction was due to \[a desire to enhance\] the honour \[of the people\].[^fn_103b_8]

'Reassemble the college after thirty days', because \[he thought\] 'I am not more important than our teacher Moses concerning whom it is Written in Scripture, *And the children of Israel wept for Moses in the plains of Moab thirty days'*.[^fn_103b_9]

For thirty days they mourned both day and night; subsequently[^fn_103b_10] they mourned in the day-time and studied at night or mourned at night and studied during the day, until a period of twelve months of mourning[^fn_103b_11] \[had passed\].

On the day that Rabbi died a *bath kol*[^fn_103b_12] went forth and announced: Whosoever has been present at the death of Rabbi is destined to enjoy the life of the world to come. A certain fuller,[^fn_103b_13] who used to come to him[^fn_103b_14] every day, failed to call on that day; and, as soon as he heard this, went up upon a roof, fell down to the ground and died. A *bath kol*[^fn_103b_12] came forth and announced: That fuller also is destined to enjoy the life of the world to come.

'My son Simeon is wise. What did he[^fn_103b_14] mean?[^fn_103b_15] — It is this that he meant: Although my son Simeon is wise, my son Gamaliel shall be the Nasi.[^fn_103b_16] Said Levi, 'Was It necessary to state this?'[^fn_103b_17] — It was necessary'. replied R. Simeon b. Rabbi, 'for yourself and for your lameness'.[^fn_103b_18] What was his[^fn_103b_19] difficulty?[^fn_103b_20] Does not Scripture state, But the kingdom gave he to Jehoram, because he was the firstborn?[^fn_103b_21] — The other[^fn_103b_22] was properly representing[^fn_103b_23] his ancestors[^fn_103b_24] but R. Gamaliel was not properly representing[^fn_103b_23] his ancestors.[^fn_103b_25] Then why did Rabbi act in the manner he did?[^fn_103b_26] — Granted that he[^fn_103b_27] was not representing his ancestors In wisdom he was worthily representing them in his fear of sin.[^fn_103b_28]

'Hanina b. Hama shall preside at the college'. R. Hanina, however, did not accept \[the office\] because R. Afes was by two and a half years older than he; and so R. Afes presided. R. Hanina sat \[at his studies\] outside \[the lecture room\],[^fn_103b_29] and Levi came and joined him. When R. Afes went to his eternal rest[^fn_103b_30] and R. Hanina took up the presidency Levi had no one to join him[^fn_103b_31] and came in consequence to Babylon.

This description coincides with the following:[^fn_103b_32] When Rab was told that a great man who was lame made his appearance at Nehardea[^fn_103b_33] and held a discourse \[in the course of which he\] permitted \[the wearing of\] a wreath,[^fn_103b_34] he said,'It is evident[^fn_103b_35] that R. Afes has gone to his eternal rest, and R. Hanina has taken over the presidency; and that Levi having had no one to join him, has come \[down here\].' But might not one have suggested that R. Hanina came to his eternal rest, that R. Afes continued In the presidency as before[^fn_103b_36] and that Levi who had no one to join him came \[therefore, to Babylon\]? If you wish I might reply: Levi would have submitted to the authority of R. Afes. And if you prefer I might reply: Since \[Rabbi\] once said, 'Hanina b. Hama shall preside at the college', there could be no possibility of his not becoming head;[^fn_103b_37] for about the righteous it is written in Scripture. *Thou shalt also decree a thing, and it shall be established unto thee*.[^fn_103b_38]

Was there not R. Hiyya?[^fn_103b_39] — He had already gone to his eternal rest.[^fn_103b_40] But did not R. Hiyya, state, 'I saw Rabbi's sepulchre[^fn_103b_41] and shed tears upon it'? — Reverse \[the names\]. But did not R. Hiyya state, 'On the day on which Rabbi died holiness ceased'? — Reverse \[the names\]. But has it not been taught: When Rabbi fell in R. Hiyya entered into his presence and found him weeping. 'Master', he said to him, 'Why are you weeping? Was it not taught: '\[If a man\] dies smiling it is a good omen for him, if weeping it is a bad omen for him; his face upwards it is a good omen, his face downwards it is a bad omen; his face towards the public it is a good omen, towards the wall it is a bad omen; if his face is greenish it is a bad omen, if bright and ruddy it.is a good omen; dying on Sabbath Eve[^fn_103b_42] is a good omen, on the termination of the Sabbath[^fn_103b_43] is a bad omen; dying on the Eve of the Day of Atonement is a bad omen, on the termination of the Day of Atonement[^fn_103b_44] is a good omen; dying of diarrhoea is a good omen because most righteous men die of diarrhoea?' And the other replied, 'I weep on \[account of my impending separation from\] the Torah and the commandments'?[^fn_103b_45] — If you wish I might reply: Reverse \[the names\]; and if you prefer I might reply: In fact there Is no need to reverse \[the names; but as\] R. Hiyya was engaged in the performance of pious deeds Rabbi thought 'I will not disturb him'.[^fn_103b_46]

This[^fn_103b_47] is in line with the following:[^fn_103b_48] When R. Hanina and R. Hiyya were engaged in a dispute R. Hanina said to R. Hiyya, 'Do you \[venture to\] dispute with me? Were the Torah, God forbid, to be forgotten in Israel, I would restore it by means of my dialectical arguments'. — 'I', replied R. Hiyya, 'make provision that the Torah shall not be forgotten in Israel. For I bring flax seed, sow it, and weave nets \[from the plant\]. \[With these\] I hunt stags with whose flesh I feed orphans and from whose skins I prepare scrolls, and then proceed to a town where there are no teachers of young children, and write out the five Books of the Pentateuch for five children \[respectively\] and teach another six children respectively the six orders of the Mishnah, and then tell each one: "Teach your section to your colleagues"'. It was this that Rabbi \[had in mind when he\] exclaimed, 'How great are the deeds of Hiyya?' Said R. Simeon b. Rabbi to him: '\[Greater\] even than yours?' — 'Yes', he replied. 'Even', asked R. Ishmael the son of R. Jose, 'than my father's?' — 'God forbid', the other replied. 'Let no such thing be \[mentioned\] in Israel!'[^fn_103b_49]

'I desire', he[^fn_103b_50] announced, 'the presence of my younger son R. Simeon entered into his presence and he entrusted him with the orders[^fn_103b_51] of wisdom. 'I desire the presence of my elder son', he announced. When R. Gamaliel entered he entrusted him with the traditions and regulations[^fn_103b_51] of the Patriarchate. 'My son', he said to him, 'conduct your patriarchate with men of high standing,[^fn_103b_52] and cast bile among the students'.[^fn_103b_53]

But surely, this[^fn_103b_54] is not proper[^fn_103b_55] for is it not written in Scripture, *But he honoureth them that fear the Lord*,[^fn_103b_56] and the Master said that this \[text might be applied to\] Jehoshaphat, King of Judah. who, on seeing a scholar, used to rise from his throne, embrace him and kiss him, and call him 'My master, my master; my teacher, my teacher'? — This is no difficulty: The latter attitude[^fn_103b_57] \[is to be adopted\] in private; the former[^fn_103b_57] in public.[^fn_103b_58]

It was taught: Rabbi was lying \[on his sickbed\] at Sepphoris[^fn_103b_59] but a \[burial\] place was reserved for him at Beth She'arim.[^fn_103b_60]

Was it not, however, taught: Justice, justice shalt thou follow.[^fn_103b_61] follow Rabbi to Beth She'arim? — Rabbi was \[indeed\] living at Beth She'arim[^fn_103b_62] but when he fell ill[^fn_103b_63] he was brought to Sepphoris [pg 104a]

because it was situated on higher ground[^fn_104a_1] and its air was salubrious.

On the day when Rabbi died the Rabbis decreed a public fast and offered prayers for heavenly mercy. They. furthermore, announced that whoever said that Rabbi was dead would be stabbed with a sword.

Rabbi's handmaid[^fn_104a_2] ascended the roof and prayed: 'The immortals[^fn_104a_3] desire Rabbi \[to join them\] and the mortals[^fn_104a_4] desire Rabbi \[to remain with them\]; may it be the will \[of God\] that the mortals may overpower the immortals'. When, however, she saw how often he resorted to the privy,[^fn_104a_5] painfully taking off his tefillin[^fn_104a_6] and putting them on again, she prayed: 'May it be the will \[of the Almighty\] that the immortals may overpower the mortals'. As the Rabbis incessantly continued[^fn_104a_7] their prayers for \[heavenly\] mercy she took up a jar and threw it down from the roof to the ground. \[For a moment\] they ceased praying[^fn_104a_8] and the soul of Rabbi departed to its eternal rest.[^fn_104a_9]

'Go', said the Rabbis to Bar Kappara, 'and investigate'.[^fn_104a_10] He went and, finding that \[Rabbi\] was dead, he tore his cloak and turned the tear backwards. \[On returning to the Rabbis\] he began: 'The angels[^fn_104a_11] and the mortals[^fn_104a_12] have taken hold of the holy ark.[^fn_104a_13] The angels overpowered the mortals and the holy ark has been captured'. 'Has he', they asked him, 'gone to his eternal rest?' — 'You', he replied, 'said it; I did not say it'.

Rabbi, at the time of his passing, raised his ten fingers towards heaven[^fn_104a_14] and said: 'Sovereign of the Universe, it is revealed and known to you that I have laboured in the study of the Torah with my ten fingers and that I did not enjoy \[any worldly\] benefits even with my little finger. May it be Thy will that there be peace In my \[Jast\] resting place'. A *bath kol*[^fn_104a_15] echoed, announcing, He shall enter into peace; they shall rest on their beds.[^fn_104a_16]

\[Does not\] the context require \[the singular pronoun:\] 'On thy bed'?[^fn_104a_17] This provides support for R. Hiyya b. Gamda. For he stated in the name of R. Jose b. Saul: When a righteous man departs from this world the ministering angels say to the Holy One, blessed be He, 'Sovereign of the Universe, the righteous man So-and-so is coming', and he answers them, 'Let the righteous men come \[from their resting places\], go forth to meet him, and say to him that he shall enter into peace \[and then\] they[^fn_104a_18] shall rest on their beds'.
