R. Eleazar stated: When a righteous man departs from the world he is welcomed by[^fn_104a_19] three companies of ministering angels. One exclaims, 'Come[^fn_104a_20] into peace'; the other[^fn_104a_21] exclaims, He who walketh in his uprightness,[^fn_104a_22] while the third[^fn_104a_23] exclaims, 'He shall enter into peace; they shall rest on their beds'.[^fn_104a_22] When a wicked man perishes from the world he is met[^fn_104a_24] by three groups of angels of destruction. One announces, 'There is no peace, saith the Lord, unto the wicked';[^fn_104a_25] the other[^fn_104a_23] tells him, 'He[^fn_104a_26] shall lie down in sorrow',[^fn_104a_27] while the third[^fn_104a_23] tells him, 'Go down and be thou laid with the uncircumcised'.[^fn_104a_28]

***MISHNAH***. SO LONG AS SHE LIVES IN HER FATHER'S HOUSE \[A WIDOW\][^fn_104a_29] MAY RECOVER HER *KETHUBAH* AT ANY TIME.[^fn_104a_30] AS LONG, HOWEVER, AS SHE LIVES IN HER HUSBAND'S HOUSE SHE MAY RECOVER HER *KETHUBAH* ONLY WITHIN[^fn_104a_31] TWENTY-FIVE YEARS, BECAUSE IN THE COURSE OF TWENTY-FIVE YEARS SHE HAS SUFFICIENT OPPORTUNITIES[^fn_104a_32] OF RENDERING[^fn_104a_33] FAVOURS[^fn_104a_34] CORRESPONDING \[IN VALUE TO THE AMOUNT OF\] HER *KETHUBAH*; SO R. MEIR WHO LAID DOWN THE RULING IN THE NAME OF R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL. THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: SO LONG AS SHE LIVES IN HER HUSBAND'S HO USE \[A WIDOW\][^fn_104a_35] MAY RECOVER HER *KETHUBAH* AT ANY TIME,[^fn_104a_36] BUT AS LONG AS SHE LIVES IN HER FATHER'S HOUSE SHE MAY RECOVER HER *KETHUBAH* ONLY WITHIN[^fn_104a_31] TWENTY-FIVE YEARS.[^fn_104a_37] IF \[THE WIDOW\] DIED, HER HEIRS MUST MENTION[^fn_104a_38] HER *KETHUBAH* WITHIN[^fn_104a_31] TWENTY-FIVE YEARS.[^fn_104a_39]  {¶=12.3}

***GEMARA***. Said Abaye to R. Joseph. \[Is it logical[^fn_104a_40] that\] the poorest woman in Israel \[should be allowed to recover her *kethubah*\] ONLY WITHIN TWENTY-FIVE YEARS and Martha the daughter of Boethus[^fn_104a_41] also ONLY WITHIN TWENTY-FIVE As?[^fn_104a_42] — The other replied: In accordance with the camel is the burden.[^fn_104a_43]

The question was raised: Must she,[^fn_104a_44] according to R. Meir, lose in proportion?[^fn_104a_45] — This must stand undecided.[^fn_104a_46]

THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: SO LONG. Said Abaye to R. Joseph: \[Is it reasonable that if\] she comes before sunset she may recover her *kethubah* and that \[if she came\] after sunset she may not recover it? \[Is it likely that\] she has surrendered it in that short while? — 'Yes', the other replied. 'all the standards of the Sages are such. In \[a bath of\] forty *se'ah*[^fn_104a_47] \[for instance\] one may perform ritual immersion; In \[a bath of\] forty *se'ah* minus one kortob[^fn_104a_47] one may not perform ritual immersion

Rab Judah reported in the name of Rab: R. Ishmael son of R. Jose testified in the presence of Rabbi to a statement he made[^fn_104a_48] in the name of his father that \[the ruling in our Mishnah\] was taught only \[in respect of a woman\] who produces[^fn_104a_49] no deed of the *kethubah* but if she produces[^fn_104a_49] the deed of the *kethubah* she may recover \[the amount of\] her *kethubah* at any time.[^fn_104a_50] R. Eleazar, however, ruled: Even if she produces[^fn_104a_49] the deed of the *kethubah* she may recover the amount within twenty-five years only.

R. Shesheth raised an objection: 'A creditor may recover his debt \[at any time\]. even if there was no mention of it.'[^fn_104a_51] Now, how is this to be understood? If \[it refers to a creditor\] who holds no bond, whereby \[it might be asked\] could he recover his debt? Consequently \[it must refer to one\] who does hold a bond \[from which it follows, does It not, that\] only a creditor \[may recover his due\]. because he is not likely to have surrendered his claim, but that a widow[^fn_104a_52] \[is deemed to have\] surrendered?[^fn_104a_53] — He[^fn_104a_54] raised the objection and he also removed it: This[^fn_104a_55] may, in fact, refer to[^fn_104a_56] one who holds no bond,[^fn_104a_57] but[^fn_104a_58] here we are dealing with a case[^fn_104a_59] where the debtor[^fn_104a_60] admits \[his liability\].[^fn_104a_61] But, Surely. R. Elai had stated: They[^fn_104a_62] taught. 'A divorced woman has the very same rights as a creditor'.[^fn_104a_63] Now, how are We to understand \[this ruling\]? If \[it refers to a divorcee\] who holds no *kethubah*, whereby \[it might be objected\] could she recover her due? Consequently \[it must refer to one\] who does hold a *kethubah*, \[from which it follows, does it not, that\] only a divorcee \[may recover her *kethubah*\] because she is not likely to have surrendered it, but that a widow \[is deemed to have\] surrendered?[^fn_104a_64] — Here also \[it is a case\] where the defendant[^fn_104a_60] admits \[the claim\].[^fn_104a_65]

R. Nahman b. Isaac stated: R. Judah b. Kaza learnt in the Baraitha of the school of Bar Kaza, If she[^fn_104a_66] claimed her *kethubah* [pg 104b]

she is again entitled to the original period.[^fn_104b_1] and if she produced[^fn_104b_2] the deed of the *kethubah* she may recover \[the amount of\] her *kethubah* at any time.[^fn_104b_3]

R. Nahman b. R. Hisda sent \[the following message\] to R. Nahman b. Jacob: Will our Master instruct us as to whether the dispute[^fn_104b_4] \[refers to\] one who produced a deed of the *kethubah* or to one who produced no deed of the *kethubah*,' and with whose ruling does the *halachah* agree? — The other replied: The dispute refers to one who produced no deed of the *kethubah*, but \[a woman\] who produced a deed of the *kethubah* may recover her *kethubah* at any time;[^fn_104b_5] and the *halachah* is in agreement with the ruling of the Sages.

When R. Dimi came[^fn_104b_6] he reported R. Simeon b. Pazzi who laid down in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi who had it from Bar Kappara: This[^fn_104b_7] was taught only in respect of the *maneh*[^fn_104b_8] and the two hundred *zuz*.[^fn_104b_8] To any additional jointure, however, the woman is always entitled.[^fn_104b_9] R. Abbahu in the name of R. Johanan, however, ruled: She is not entitled even to the additional jointure; for R. Aibu has laid down in the name of R. Jannai: The additional provisions[^fn_104b_10] of a *kethubah* are subject to the same rules[^fn_104b_11] as the *kethubah* itself.[^fn_104b_12] So it was also said:[^fn_104b_13] R. Abba laid down in the name of R. Huna who had it from Rab: This was taught only in respect of the *maneh* and the two hundred *zuz*. To any additional jointure, however, she is always entitled.[^fn_104b_14] Said R. Abba to R. Huna: Did Rab really say this?[^fn_104b_15] — 'Do you wish', the other replied, to silence me[^fn_104b_16] or to stand me a drink?'[^fn_104b_17] — 'I', the other replied, 'wish to silence you!'

The mother-in-law of R. Hiyya Arika[^fn_104b_18] was the wife of his brother,[^fn_104b_19] and \[when she became\] a widow lived in her father's bouse. \[R. Hiyya\] maintained her for twenty.five years at her paternal home \[but when\] at the end \[of the period\] she said to him. 'Supply me with my maintenance' he told her, 'You have no \[longer any claim to\] maintenance'. 'pay me \[then', she said'my\] kethubah'. 'You have no claim,' he replied- 'either to maintenance or to the *kethubah'*,[^fn_104b_20] She summoned him to law before Rabbah b. Shila. 'Tell me', \[the judge\] said to him,[^fn_104b_21] 'what exactly were the circumstances. 'I maintained her', the other[^fn_104b_21] replied. 'for twenty-five years at her paternal home and, by the life of the Master, I carried \[the stuff\] to her on my shoulder'. 'What is the reason', \[the judge\] said to him, 'that the Rabbis[^fn_104b_22] ruled, so LONG AS SHE LIVES IN HER HUSBAND'S HOUSE \[A WIDOW\] MAY RECOVER HER *KETHUBAH* AT ANY TIME? Because we assume that she did not claim it in order \[to save herself from\] shame.[^fn_104b_23] Similarly here also[^fn_104b_24] \[it may well be assumed\] that she did not \[previously\] submit her claim in order \[to save herself from\] shame.[^fn_104b_23] Go, and supply her \[maintenance\]'. \[As R. Hiyya\] disregarded \[the ruling. the judge\] wrote out for her an *adrakta*[^fn_104b_25] on his property. Thereupon he came to Raba and said to him, 'See, Master, how he treated my case',[^fn_104b_26] 'He has given you the proper ruling', the other replied. 'If that is the case', \[the widow\] said to him,[^fn_104b_27] 'let him[^fn_104b_28] proceed to refund me the produce[^fn_104b_29] \[he has consumed\] since that day[^fn_104b_30] to date'. 'Shew me' he[^fn_104b_27] said to her, 'your *adrakta*'.[^fn_104b_31] As he observed that it did not contain the clause,[^fn_104b_32] 'And we have ascertained that this estate belonged to the deceased', he said to her, 'The *adrakta* is not properly drawn up'.[^fn_104b_33] 'Let the *adrakta* be dropped'. she said; 'and let me receive \[the refund for the produce\] from the day on which the period of the public announcement terminated[^fn_104b_34] to date'. 'This',[^fn_104b_35] he replied. applies only to a case[^fn_104b_36] where no error has crept[^fn_104b_37] into the *adrakta*, but where an error occurs[^fn_104b_37] in the *adrakta* the document possesses no validity'.[^fn_104b_38] 'But did not the Master himself lay down', she exclaimed, '\[that the omission[^fn_104b_39] of the clause\] pledging property \[is to be regarded as the\] scribe's error?'[^fn_104b_40] — 'In this case', Raba told her, '\[the omission\] cannot be said to be a scribe's error, for even Rabbah b. Shila originally[^fn_104b_41] overlooked the point'.[^fn_104b_42] He thought: Since both belonged to him[^fn_104b_43] what matters it \[whether the widow distrains\] on the one or the other.[^fn_104b_44] But this is not \[the proper view\]. For sometimes \[the widow\] might go and improve those \[lands\][^fn_104b_45] while those belonging to her husband[^fn_104b_46] would be allowed[^fn_104b_47] to deteriorate and \[the heir might eventually\] tell her, 'Take yours[^fn_104b_48] and return to me mine',[^fn_104b_49] and a stigma[^fn_104b_50] would thus fall[^fn_104b_51] upon the court.[^fn_104b_52]

## CHAPTER XIII

***MISHNAH***. TWO JUDGES OF CIVIL LAW[^fn_104b_53] WERE \[ADMINISTERING JUSTICE\] IN JERUSALEM, ADMON AND HANAN B. ABISHALOM. HANAN LAID DOWN TWO RULINGS[^fn_104b_54] AND ADMON LAID DOWN SEVEN: — 55 {¶=13.1}

IF A MAN WENT TO A COUNTRY BEYOND THE SEA AND HIS WIFE CLAIMED MAINTENANCE, HANAN RULED: [pg 105a]

SHE MUST TAKE AN OATH[^fn_105a_1] AT THE END[^fn_105a_2] BUT NOT AT THE BEGINNING.[^fn_105a_3] THE SONS OF THE HIGH PRIESTS,[^fn_105a_4] HOWEVER, DIFFERED FROM HIM AND RULED THAT SHE MUST TAKE AN OATH BOTH AT THE BEGINNING[^fn_105a_3] AND AT THE END.[^fn_105a_2] R. DOSA B. HARKINAS AGREED WITH THEIR RULING. R. JOHANAN B. ZAKKAI SAID: HANAN HAS SPOKEN WELL; SHE NEED TAKE AN OATH ONLY AT THE END.[^fn_105a_2]

***GEMARA***. I Would point out an Inconsistency: 'Three judges in cases of robbery[^fn_105a_5] were \[administering justice\] in Jerusalem. Admon b. Gadai,[^fn_105a_6] Hanan the Egyptian and Hanan b. Abishalom'. Is there not an inconsistency between 'three'[^fn_105a_7] and 'TWO', and an inconsistency between 'CIVIL'[^fn_105a_8] and 'robbery'?[^fn_105a_9] One might well admit that there is no \[real\] inconsistency between the 'three' and the 'TWO' since he[^fn_105a_10] may be enumerating \[only those\] whom he con siders important[^fn_105a_11] and omitting[^fn_105a_12] \[the one\] whom he does not consider important. Does not, however, the inconsistency between 'CIVIL' and 'robbery' remain? — R. Nahman b. Isaac replied: \[Both terms may be justified on the grounds\] that they[^fn_105a_13] imposed fines[^fn_105a_14] for acts of robbery;[^fn_105a_15] as it was taught: If \[a beast\] nipped off a plant, said R. Jose. the Judges of Civil Law in Jerusalem ruled that if the plant was in its first year \[the owner of the beast pays as compensation\] two silver pieces.[^fn_105a_16] if it was in its second year \[he pays as compensation\] four silver pieces.[^fn_105a_17]

I point out \[another\] contradiction: Three judges of Civil Law were \[administering justice\] in Jerusalem. Admon, and Hanan and Nahum?[^fn_105a_18] — R. Papa replied: He who mentioned Nahum was R. Nathan;[^fn_105a_19] for it was taught: R. Nathan stated, 'Nahum the Mede also was one of the Judges of Civil Law in Jerusalem', but the Sages did not agree with him.

Were there, however, no more \[judges\]? \[Did not\] R. Phinehas. in fact, state on the authority of R. Oshaia that there were three hundred and ninety four courts of law[^fn_105a_20] in Jerusalem, and an equal number of Synagogues. of Houses of Study[^fn_105a_21] and of schools?[^fn_105a_22] — Judges there were many, but we were speaking of Judges of Civil Law only.

Rab Judah stated in the name of R. Assi: The Judges of Civil Law in Jerusalem received their salaries out of the Temple funds[^fn_105a_23] \[at the rate of\] ninety-nine *maneh*.[^fn_105a_24] If they were not satisfied is they were given an increase.

\[You say\] 'They were not satisfied'?[^fn_105a_25] Are we dealing with wicked men?[^fn_105a_26] The reading in fact is,[^fn_105a_27] \[If the amount was\] not Sufficient[^fn_105a_28] an increase was granted to them even if they objected.[^fn_105a_29]

Karna[^fn_105a_30] used to take one istira[^fn_105a_31] from the innocent[^fn_105a_32] party and one istira from the guilty party and then informed them of his decision.[^fn_105a_33] But how could he[^fn_105a_34] act in such a manner? Is it not written in Scripture, And thou shalt take no gift?[^fn_105a_35] And should you reply that this applies only where he does not take from both \[litigants\] since he might \[in consequence\] wrest judgment, but Karna, since he took \[the same amount\] from both parties, would not come to wrest judgment, \[it can be retorted:\] Is this permitted even where one would not come to wrest judgment? Was it not in fact taught: What was the purpose of the statement And thou shalt take no gift?[^fn_105a_35] If to teach that one must not acquit the guilty or that one must not condemn the innocent \[the objection Surely could be raised\]. It was already specifically stated elsewhere in Scripture, Thou shalt not wrest judgement.[^fn_105a_36] Consequently it must be concluded that even \[where the intention is\] to acquit the innocent or to condemn the guilty the Torah laid down, And thou shalt take no gift?[^fn_105a_37] — This[^fn_105a_37] applies only where \[the judge\] takes \[the gift\] as a bribe,[^fn_105a_38] but Karna took \[the two istira\] as a fee.[^fn_105a_39] But is it permissible \[for a judge to take money\] as a fee.[^fn_105a_39] Have we not in fact learned: The legal decisions of one who takes a fee for acting as judge are null and void?[^fn_105a_40] — This[^fn_105a_40] applies only to a fee for pronouncing judgment, while Karna was only taking compensation for loss of work.[^fn_105a_41]

But \[is a judge\] permitted to take compensation for loss of work? Was it not in fact taught: Contemptible is the judge who takes a fee for pronouncing judgment; but his decision is valid?[^fn_105a_42] Now, what is to be understood \[by fee\]. If it be suggested \[that it means\] a fee for acting as judge \[the objection would arise: How could be said,\] 'his decision is valid', when in fact we have learned:[^fn_105a_43] The legal decisions of one who takes a fee for acting as judge are null and void? Consequently it must mean[^fn_105a_44] a fee for loss of work,[^fn_105a_45] and yet it was stated, was it not, 'Contemptible is the judge etc.'? — This applies only to a loss of work that cannot be proved, but Karna received \[compensation for\] loss of work that could be proved. for he was \[regularly occupied in\] smelling tests[^fn_105a_46] at a wine store,[^fn_105a_47] and for this he was paid a fee.[^fn_105a_48] This is similar to the case[^fn_105a_49] of R. Huna. When a lawsuit was brought to him, he used to say to the \[litigants\]. 'Provide me with a man who will draw the water[^fn_105a_50] in my place[^fn_105a_51] and I will pronounce judgment for you'.

Said R. Abbahu: Come and see how blind are the eyes of those who take a bribe. If a man has pain in his eyes he pays away money to a medical man and he may be cured or he nay not be cured, yet these take what is only worth one *perutah*[^fn_105a_52] and blind their eyes \[therewith\]. for it is said in Scripture. *For a gift blindeth them that have sight*.[^fn_105a_53]

Our Rabbis taught: For a gift doth blind the eyes of the wise,[^fn_105a_54] and much more so those of the foolish; And pervert the words of the righteous,[^fn_105a_54] and much more so those of the wicked. Are then fools and wicked men capable of acting as judges?[^fn_105a_55] — But it is this that is meant: 'For a gift doth blind the eyes of the wise', even a great Sage who takes bribes will not depart from the world without \[the affliction of\] a dullness of the mind,[^fn_105a_56] 'And pervert the words of the righteous', [pg 105b]

even one who is righteous in every respect and takes bribes will not depart from this world without \[the affliction of\] confusion of mind.

When R. Dimi came[^fn_105b_1] he related that R. Nahman b. Kohen made the following exposition: What was meant by the Scriptural text, The King by justice establisheth the land, but he that loveth gifts overthroweth it? If the judge is like a king who is not in need of anything[^fn_105b_2] he establisheth the land, but if he is like a priest who moves to and fro among the threshing floors,[^fn_105b_3] he overthroweth it.[^fn_105b_4]

Rabbah b. R. Shila stated: Any judge who is in the habit of borrowing[^fn_105b_5] is unfit to pronounce judgment. This, however, applies only where he possesses nothing to lend to others, but where he possesses things to lend \[his borrowing\] does not matter.[^fn_105b_6] This, however, cannot surely be correct;[^fn_105b_7] for did not Raba borrow things from the household of Bar Merion, although they did not borrow anything from him? — There he desired to give them better standing.[^fn_105b_8]

Raba stated: What is the reason for \[the prohibition[^fn_105b_9] against taking\] a gift?[^fn_105b_10] Because as soon as a man receives a gift from another he becomes so well disposed towards him[^fn_105b_11] that he becomes like his own person, and no man sees himself in the wrong.[^fn_105b_12] What \[is the meaning of\] shohad?[^fn_105b_13] She-hu had.[^fn_105b_14]

R. Papa said: A man should not act as judge either for one whom he loves or for one whom he hates; for no man can see the guilt of one whom he loves or the merit of one whom he hates.

Abaye said: If a scholar[^fn_105b_15] is loved by the townspeople \[their love\] is not due to his superiority but \[to the fact\] that he does not rebuke them for \[neglecting\] spiritual[^fn_105b_16] matters.

Raba remarked: At first I thought that all the people of Mahuza[^fn_105b_17] loved me. When I was appointed judge[^fn_105b_18] I thought that some[^fn_105b_19] would hate me and others[^fn_105b_20] would love me. Having observed, however, that the man who loses[^fn_105b_21] to-day[^fn_105b_22] wins tomorrow I came to the conclusion that if I am loved they all love me and if I am hated they must all hate me.

Our Rabbis taught: And thou shalt take no gift;[^fn_105b_23] there was no need to speak of \[the prohibition of\] a gift of money, but \[this was meant:\] Even a bribe of words[^fn_105b_24] is also forbidden, for Scripture does not write, And thou shalt take no gain.[^fn_105b_25] What is to be understood by 'a bribe of words'?[^fn_105b_24] — As the bribe offered to Samuel.[^fn_105b_26] He was once crossing \[a river\] on a board[^fn_105b_27] when a man came up and offered him his hand.[^fn_105b_28] 'What', \[Samuel\] asked him, 'is your business here?' — 'I have a lawsuit', the other replied. 'l', came the reply, 'am disqualified from acting for you in the suit'.

Amemar was once engaged in the trial of an action,[^fn_105b_29] when a bird flew down upon his head and a man approached and removed it. 'What is your business here?' \[Amemar\] asked him. 'I have a lawsuit', the other replied. 'I', came the reply, 'am disqualified from acting as your judge'.

Mar 'Ukba once ejected some saliva[^fn_105b_30] and a man approached and covered it. 'What is your business here?' \[Mar 'Ukba\] asked him. 'l have a lawsuit', the man replied. 'I', came the reply, 'am disqualified from acting as your judge'.

R. Ishmael son of R. Jose, whose *aris*[^fn_105b_31] was wont to bring him a basket full of fruit[^fn_105b_32] every Friday[^fn_105b_33] but on one occasion[^fn_105b_34] brought it to him on a Thursday, asked the latter, 'Why the present change?' I have a lawsuit', the other replied, 'and thought that at the same time[^fn_105b_35] I might bring \[the fruit\] to the Master'. He did not accept it from him \[and\] said,'I am disqualified to act as your judge'. He thereupon appointed a couple of Rabbis to try the case for him. As he was arranging the affair[^fn_105b_36] he \[found himself\] thinking, 'If he[^fn_105b_37] wished he could plead thus, or if he preferred he might plead thus'.[^fn_105b_38] 'Oh', he exclaimed, 'the despair that waits for those who take bribes'![^fn_105b_39] If I, who have not taken \[the fruit at all\], and even if I had taken I would only have taken what is my own, am In such \[a state of mind\], show much more \[Would that[^fn_105b_40] be the state of\] those who accept bribes'.

A man once brought to R. Ishmael b. Elisha[^fn_105b_41] \[a gift of\] the firstfleece.[^fn_105b_42] 'Whence', the latter asked him, 'are you?' — 'From such and such a place', the other replied. 'But', \[R. Ishmael\] asked, 'was there no priest to whom to give it \[in any of the places\] between that place and this?'[^fn_105b_43] — 'I have a lawsuit', the other replied, 'and thought that at the same time[^fn_105b_44] I would bring \[the gift\] to the Master'.He said to him, 'I am unfit to try your action', and refused to receive \[the gift\] from him. \[Thereupon\] he appointed two Rabbis to try his action. As he was arranging this affair[^fn_105b_45] he \[found himself\] thinking, 'If he[^fn_105b_46] wished he could plead thus, or if he preferred he might plead thus'.[^fn_105b_47] 'Oh', he exclaimed, 'the despair that awaits those who take bribes! If I, who did not take \[the gift\], and even if I had taken it I would only have accepted that which is my due, am in such \[a state of mind\], how much more \[would that be the case with\] those who accept bribes'.

A man once brought to R. Anan a bale of small marsh fish.[^fn_105b_48] 'What is your business here', the latter asked him. 'I have a lawsuit', the other replied. \[R. Anan\] did not accept it from him, and told him, 'I am disqualified to try your action'. 'I would not now request', the other said to him, 'the Master's decision \[in my lawsuit\]; will the Master, however, at least accept \[the present\] so that I may not be prevented from offering my first-fruit?[^fn_105b_49] For it was taught: And there came a man from Baal-shalishah, and brought the man of God bread of the first-fruits, twenty loaves of barley, and fresh ears of corn in his sack;[^fn_105b_50] but was Elisha[^fn_105b_51] entitled to eat first-fruit?[^fn_105b_52] This, however, was intended to tell you that one who brings a gift to a scholar \[is doing as good a deed\] as if he had offered first-fruits'. It was not my intention to accept \[your gift', R. Anan\] said to him, 'but now that you have given me a reason I will accept it' — Thereupon he sent him to R. Nahman to whom he also dispatched \[the following message:\] 'Will the Master try \[the action of\] this man, for I, Anan,[^fn_105b_53] am disqualified from acting as judge for him'. 'Since he has sent me such a message', \[R. Nahman\] thought, 'he must be his relative' — 54 An orphans' lawsuit was then in progress[^fn_105b_55] before him; and he reflected: [pg 106a]

The one[^fn_106a_1] is a positive precept and the other[^fn_106a_2] is also a positive precept. but the positive precept of shewing respect for the Torah[^fn_106a_2] must take precedence. He, therefore, postponed[^fn_106a_3] the orphans' case and brought up that man's suit. When the other party[^fn_106a_4] noticed the honour he was shewing him[^fn_106a_5] he remained speechless.[^fn_106a_6] \[Until that happened\] Elijah[^fn_106a_7] was a frequent visitor of R. Anan whom he was teaching the Order of Elijah.[^fn_106a_8] but as soon as he[^fn_106a_9] acted in the manner described[^fn_106a_10] \[Elijah\] stayed away. He[^fn_106a_9] Spent his time[^fn_106a_11] in fasting, and in prayers for \[God's\] mercy, \[until Elijah\] came to him again; but when he appeared he greatly frightened him. Thereupon he[^fn_106a_12] made a box \[for himself\] and in it he sat before him until he concluded his Order with him. And this is \[the reason\] why people speak of the Seder Eliyyahu Rabbah and the Seder Eliyyahu Zuta.[^fn_106a_13]

In the days[^fn_106a_14] of R. Joseph there was a famine.[^fn_106a_15] Said the Rabbis to R. Joseph, 'Will the Master offer prayers for \[heavenly\] mercy'? He replied, 'If Elisha, with whom, when the \[main body of\] Rabbis had departed, there still remained two thousand and two hundred Rabbis,[^fn_106a_16] did not offer up any prayers for mercy in a time of famine,[^fn_106a_15] should I \[at such a time venture to\] offer prayers for mercy? But whence is it inferred that so many remained? — \[From Scripture\] where it is written, And his servant said: How should I set this before a hundred men.?[^fn_106a_17] Now what is meant by \[the expression.\] 'Before a hundred men'? If it be suggested that all[^fn_106a_18] \[was to be set\] before the hundred men \[one might well object that\] in years of famine \[all this\] is rather a large quantity. Consequently it must be concluded[^fn_106a_19] that each \[loaf was set\] before a hundred men.[^fn_106a_20]

When the \[main body of\] Rabbis departed from the school of Rab there still remained behind one thousand and two hundred Rabbis; \[when they departed\] from the school of R. Huna there remained behind eight hundred Rabbis. R. Huna when delivering his discourses \[was assisted\] by thirteen interpreters.[^fn_106a_21] When the Rabbis stood up after R. Huna's discourses[^fn_106a_22] and shook out their garments the dust rose \[so high\] that it obscured the \[light of\] day, and people in Palestine[^fn_106a_23] said, 'They have risen after the discourses of R. Huna the Babylonian' — When \[the main body of\] Rabbis departed from the schools of Rabbah and R. Joseph there remained four hundred Rabbis and they described themselves as orphans. When \[the main body of\] Rabbis departed from the school of Abaye (others say, From the school of R. Papa, while still others say, From the school of R. Ashi) there remained two hundred Rabbis, and these described themselves as orphans of the orphans.

R. Isaac b. Radifa said in the name of R. Ammi: The inspectors of \[animal\] blemishes[^fn_106a_24] in Jerusalem received their wages from the Temple funds.[^fn_106a_25] Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel: The learned men who taught the priests the laws of ritual slaughter received their fees from the Temple funds.[^fn_106a_25] R. Giddal said in the name of Rab: The learned men who taught the priests the rules of kemizah[^fn_106a_26] received their fees from the Temple funds.[^fn_106a_25] Rabbah b. Bar Hana said in the name of R. Johanan: Book readers[^fn_106a_27] in Jerusalem received their fees from the Temple funds.[^fn_106a_28]

R. Nahman said: Rab stated that the women who wove the \[Temple\] curtains received their wages from the Temple funds[^fn_106a_25] but I maintain \[that they received them\] from the sums consecrated for Temple repairs, since the curtains were a substitute for builder's work.

An objection was raised: The women who wove the \[Temple\] curtains, and the house of Garmo[^fn_106a_29] \[who were in charge\] of the preparation of the shewbread,[^fn_106a_30] and the house of Abtinas[^fn_106a_29] \[who were in charge\] of the preparation of the incense,[^fn_106a_31] received their wages from the Temple funds![^fn_106a_32] — There[^fn_106a_33] \[it may be replied\] the reference is \[to the curtains\] of the gates;[^fn_106a_34] for R. Zera related in the name of Rab: There were thirteen curtains in the second Temple, seven corresponding to the seven gates,[^fn_106a_35] one for the entrance to the Hekal,[^fn_106a_36] one for the entrance to the 'Ulam,[^fn_106a_36] two[^fn_106a_37] \[at the entrance\] to the Debir[^fn_106a_36] and two \[above them and\] corresponding to them in the upper storey.[^fn_106a_38]

Our Rabbis taught: The women who brought up their children for the \[services of the red\] heifer,[^fn_106a_39] received their wages from the Temple funds. Abba Saul said: The notable[^fn_106a_40] women of Jerusalem fed them and maintained them.

R. Huna enquired of Rab: [pg 106b]

May vessels of ministry[^fn_106b_1] be procured[^fn_106b_2] with the offerings consecrated to Temple repair? Are these \[a part of\] the equipment[^fn_106b_3] of the altar and were, therefore,[^fn_106b_4] purchased[^fn_106b_5] with the offerings consecrated to Temple repair, or are they rather among the requirements of the sacrifices and were, therefore, procured[^fn_106b_6] with the Temple funds? — 'They'. the other[^fn_106b_7] replied, 'may be procured[^fn_106b_2] with the Temple funds only'.

He raised an objection against him; And when they had made an end, they brought the rest of the money[^fn_106b_8] before the King and Jehoiada,[^fn_106b_9] whereof were made vessels for the house of the Lord, even vessels wherewith to minister[^fn_106b_10] etc. — The other[^fn_106b_11] replied: He that taught you the Hagiographa did not teach you the Prophets: But there were not made for the hose of the Lord cups[^fn_106b_12] etc. for they gave that to them that did the work.[^fn_106b_13] But if so, is there not a contradiction between the two Scriptural texts? — There is really no contradiction. The former is a case[^fn_106b_14] where after the collections were made \[for Temple repair\] there remained a balance,[^fn_106b_15] while the latter[^fn_106b_14] is a case where no balance remained.[^fn_106b_16] But even if there was a balance after the Collection had been made, what of it?[^fn_106b_17] R. Abbahu replied: *Beth din* make a mental[^fn_106b_18] Stipulation that if they[^fn_106b_19] be required they should be utilized for their original purpose[^fn_106b_20] and that if \[they would\] not \[be required\] they should be \[spent\] on vessels of ministry.

A Tanna of the school of R. Ishmael taught: Vessels of ministry were provided[^fn_106b_21] from the Temple funds; for it is said in Scriptures The rest of the money,[^fn_106b_22] now what funds shewed a balance?[^fn_106b_23] Obviously[^fn_106b_24] the Temple funds.[^fn_106b_25] But might it not be suggested that only the balance itself \[could be spent on the vessels of ministry\]?[^fn_106b_26] — As Raba said,[^fn_106b_27] The burnt-offering[^fn_106b_28] implies the first burnt-offering,[^fn_106b_29] so must the money[^fn_106b_30] imply the first money.[^fn_106b_31] 

An objection was raised: The incense and all congregational sacrifices were provided[^fn_106b_32] from the Temple funds; the golden altar,[^fn_106b_33] the frankincense[^fn_106b_34] and the vessels of ministry were provided from the residue of the drink-offerings;[^fn_106b_35] the altar for the burnt-offerings,[^fn_106b_36] the chambers and the courts were provided from the funds that were dedicated for Temple repair, \[and whatever was situated\] outside the court walls[^fn_106b_37] was provided out of the surplus of the Temple funds;[^fn_106b_38] and it is this that \[explains what\] we learned: The city wall and its towers and all other requirements of the city were provided from the surplus of the Temple funds?[^fn_106b_39] — This \[point[^fn_106b_40] is in fact a question at issue between\] Tannaim. For we learned: What were they doing[^fn_106b_41] with the surplus of the offerings \[for the Temple funds\]?[^fn_106b_42] Beaten gold \[plates that served as\] a covering for \[the walls and floor\][^fn_106b_43] of the Holy of Holies. R. Ishmael said: The surplus of the fruit[^fn_106b_44] \[was spent on the purchase of sacrifices\] for the dry season[^fn_106b_45] of the altar, while the surplus of the offerings \[for the Temple funds\] was spent upon vessels of ministry. R. Akiba said: The surplus of the offerings \[for the Temple funds was spent on sacrifices\] for the dry season of the altar while the surplus of the drink-offerings[^fn_106b_35] was used for \[the purchase of\] the vessels of ministry. R. Hanina, the deputy High Priest, said: The surplus of the drink-offerings \[was spent on sacrifices\] for the dry season of the altar, while the surplus of the offerings \[for the Temple funds was spent\] on vessels of ministry. And neither the one nor the other[^fn_106b_46] admitted that \[there ever was a surplus\] in the \[proceeds of the\] fruit.[^fn_106b_47]

What is \[meant by\] 'fruit'?[^fn_106b_48] — It was taught: What were they doing with the surplus of the offering \[to the Temple funds\]?[^fn_106b_49] They bought fruit at a low price and sold it at a higher price, and with the profits sacrifices were purchased for the dry season of the altar; and it is this that \[explains what\] we learned: The surplus of the fruits was spent on sacrifices for the dry season of the altar.

What is meant by 'neither the one nor the other admitted that \[there ever was a surplus\] in \[proceeds of the\] fruit'?[^fn_106b_50] — \[The following of\] which we learned: What were they doing with the surplus[^fn_106b_51] of the Temple funds? They purchased therewith wines, oils and various kinds of fine flour, and the profit \[resulting was credited\] to the sacred funds; so R. Ishmael. R. Akiba said: No sale for profit is made with the sacred funds nor out of those of the poor.[^fn_106b_52] Why \[may no sales for profit be made\] with sacred funds? — There must be no poverty where there is wealth. Why \[is\] no \[sale for profit made\] with the poor funds? — Because a poor man might come unexpectedly and there would be nothing to give him.

IF A MAN WENT TO A COUNTRY BEYOND THE SEA. It was stated: Rab ruled, [pg 107a]

An allowance for maintenance must be granted[^fn_107a_1] to a married woman,[^fn_107a_2] but Samuel ruled: No allowance may be granted[^fn_107a_1] to a married woman.[^fn_107a_2] Said Samuel: Abba[^fn_107a_3] agrees with me \[that no allowance is to be granted\][^fn_107a_4] during the first three months,[^fn_107a_5] because no man leaves his house empty. In a case where a report was received[^fn_107a_6] that he[^fn_107a_7] was dead there is no difference of opinion between them.[^fn_107a_8] They only differ when no one heard that he[^fn_107a_7] was dead. Rab ruled, 'An allowance for maintenance must be granted' since he[^fn_107a_7] is under an obligation \[to maintain her\]; on what ground however, did Samuel rule, 'No allowance may be granted'? — R. Zebid replied: Because it might well be assumed that he handed over to her some bundles \[of valuables\].[^fn_107a_9] R. Papa replied: We must take into consideration the possibility that he told her, 'Deduct \[the proceeds of\] your handiwork[^fn_107a_10] for your maintenance'.[^fn_107a_11] What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_107a_12] — The practical difference between them is the case of a woman who is of age[^fn_107a_13] but \[the proceeds of whose handiwork\] did not suffice \[for her maintenance\],[^fn_107a_14] or a minor[^fn_107a_15] \[the proceeds of whose handiwork\] is sufficient \[for her maintenance\].[^fn_107a_16]

We learned: IF A MAN WENT TO A COUNTRY BEYOND THE SEA AND HIS WIFE CLAIMED MAINTENANCE, HANAN RULED: SHE MUST TAKE AN OATH AT THE END BUT NOT AT THE BEGINNING. THE SONS OF THE HIGH PRIESTS, HOWEVER, DIFFERED FROM HIM AND RULED THAT SHE MUST TAKE AN OATH BOTH AT THE BEGINNING AND AT THE END. They thus[^fn_107a_17] differ only in respect of the oath but \[agree, do they not,\] that maintenance must be given to her?[^fn_107a_18] — Samuel explained \[this to refer to a case\] where a report had been received that \[the absent husband\] was dead.

Come and hear: If \[a husband\] went to a country beyond the sea and his wife claimed maintenance she must, said the sons of the High Priests, take an oath,[^fn_107a_19] Hanan said: She need not take an oath. If \[the husband\] came, however, and declared, 'I have provided for her maintenance'[^fn_107a_20] he is believed.[^fn_107a_21] Here also \[it may be replied\] is a case where a report was received that he was dead. But, did it not Say, 'If \[the husband\] came, however, and declared'?[^fn_107a_22] \[The meaning of the expression is,\] If he came after the report had been received.

Come and hear: If \[a husband\] went to a country beyond the sea, and his wife claimed maintenance, and he returned and said \[to her\], 'Deduct your handiwork for your maintenance', he is entitled \[to withhold it\]. If *Beth din*, however, granted the allowance before \[he returned\] their decision is valid.[^fn_107a_23] Here also it is a case where a report that he had died was received.

Come and hear: If \[a husband\] went to a country beyond the sea and his wife claimed maintenance, *Beth din* take possession of[^fn_107a_24] his estate and provide food and clothing for his wife, but not for his sons and daughters or for anything else![^fn_107a_25] — R. Shesheth replied; \[Here it is a case\] where a husband maintained his wife at the hands of a trustee.[^fn_107a_26] If so, \[should not maintenance be granted to\] one's sons and daughters also?[^fn_107a_27] \[It is a case\] where \[a husband\] made provision for the maintenance of his wife[^fn_107a_28] but not of his daughters.[^fn_107a_28]

Whence this certainty?[^fn_107a_29] — This, however, said R. Papa, \[is the explanation: This is a case\] where she heard from one witness that \[her husband\] had died. To her, since she could Marry on the evidence of one witness, we must also grant maintenance; to his sons and daughters, however, since they, even if they desired it, could not be allowed to take possession of his estate on the evidence of one witness, maintenance also may not be granted — What \[is meant by\] 'anything else'? R. Hisda replied: Cosmetics. R. Joseph replied: Charity. According to him who replied, 'Cosmetics' the ruling[^fn_107a_30] would apply with even greater force to [pg 107b]

charity.[^fn_107b_1] He, however, who replied, 'Charity' \[restricts the ruling to this alone\] but cosmetics \[he maintains\] must be given to her, for \[her husband\] would not be pleased that she should lose her comeliness.[^fn_107b_2]

Come and hear: A yebamah[^fn_107b_3] during the first three months is maintained out of the estate of her husband — Subsequently[^fn_107b_4] she is not to be maintained either out of the estate of her husband or out of that of the levir. If, however, \[the levir\] appeared in court[^fn_107b_5] and then absconded she is maintained out of the estate of the levir![^fn_107b_6] — Samuel can answer you: What possibility need we take into consideration in the case of this \[woman\]?[^fn_107b_7] If that of[^fn_107b_8] \[having been entrusted[^fn_107b_9] with\] bundles of valuables[^fn_107b_10] \[one could well object that such a levir\] is not well disposed towards her;[^fn_107b_11] and if that of[^fn_107b_12] \[the remission of\] her handiwork[^fn_107b_13] \[the fact is, it could be retorted, that\] she is under no obligation to give it to him.[^fn_107b_14]

Come and hear: A woman who went with her husband to a country beyond the sea and then came back and stated, 'My husband is dead', may, if she wishes, successfully claim her maintenance and, if she prefers, may equally claim her *kethubah*. \[If she stated, however,\] 'My husband has divorced me', she may be maintained[^fn_107b_15] to the extent of her *kethubah*![^fn_107b_16] — Here also \[it may be replied, it is a case\] where a report was received that he had died. Then[^fn_107b_17] why \[is she maintained\] only to the extent of her *kethubah*? — Because she herself has brought the loss upon herself.[^fn_107b_18]

Come and hear: In what circumstances was it laid down that \[a minor who\] exercised her right of refusal[^fn_107b_19] is not entitled to maintenance? It cannot be said, In \[those of\] one who lives with her husband, since \[in such circumstances\] her husband is under an obligation to maintain her, but \[in those\], for instance, \[of one\] whose husband went to a country beyond the sea, and she borrowed money and spent it[^fn_107b_20] and then[^fn_107b_21] exercised her right of refusal. Now, the reason \[why she is not entitled to maintenance is obviously\] because she exercised her right of refusal; had she, however, not exercised her right of refusal, maintenance would have been granted to her?[^fn_107b_22] — Samuel can answer you: What possibility need we provide against as far as she is concerned? If against that of[^fn_107b_23] \[having been entrusted with\] bundles of valuables \[it may be pointed out that\] no one entrusts a minor with valuables; and if against that of \[the man's remission of\] her handiwork[^fn_107b_24] \[the fact is, it could be argued, that\] the handiwork of a minor does not suffice \[for her maintenance\].[^fn_107b_25] What is the ultimate decision?[^fn_107b_26] When R. Dimi came[^fn_107b_27] he related: Such a case was submitted to Rabbi at Beth She'arim[^fn_107b_28] and he granted[^fn_107b_29] the Woman[^fn_107b_30] an allowance for her maintenance, \[while a similar case was submitted\] to R. Ishmael at Sepphoris[^fn_107b_31] and he did not grant her any maintenance. R. Johanan was astonished at this decision — What reason \[he wondered\] could R. Ishmael see that \[in consequence of it\] he allowed her no maintenance? Surely the sons of the High Priests and Hanan differed only on the question of the oath,[^fn_107b_32] but \[they all agree, do they not, that\] maintenance is to be given to her? — R. Shaman b. Abba answered him: Our Master, Samuel, in Babylon has long ago explained this \[as being a case\] where a report had been received that \[the absent husband\] had died. 'You', the other remarked, 'explain so much with this reply'.

When Rabin came[^fn_107b_27] he related: Such a case was submitted to Rabbi at Beth She'arim[^fn_107b_28] and he did not grant the woman[^fn_107b_30] any maintenance, \[while in a similar case which was submitted\] to R. Ishmael at Sepphoris[^fn_107b_31] \[the latter\] granted her an allowance for her maintenance. Said R. Johanan: What reason could Rabbi see for not granting her an allowance, when Hanan and the sons of the High Priests obviously differed only in respect of the oath[^fn_107b_32] but \[agreed that\] maintenance is to be given her? — R. Shaman b. Abba replied: Samuel in Babylon has long ago explained this \[as being a case\] where a report has been received that \[the absent husband\] had died. 'You', the other remarked, 'explain so much with this answer'. The law, however, is in agreement with Rab,[^fn_107b_33] and a married woman is to be granted an allowance for her maintenance. The law is also in agreement with a ruling which R. Huna laid down in the name of Rab, R. Huna having stated on the authority of Rab: A wife is within her rights when she says to her husband, 'I desire no maintenance from, and refuse to do \[any work for you\]'. The law, furthermore, agrees with a ruling of R. Zebid[^fn_107b_34] in respect of glazed vessels,[^fn_107b_35] R. Zebid having laid down: Glazed vessels[^fn_107b_35] are permitted[^fn_107b_36] if they are white or black,[^fn_107b_37] but forbidden[^fn_107b_38] if green.[^fn_107b_39] This,[^fn_107b_40] however, applies only to such[^fn_107b_41] as have no cracks[^fn_107b_42] but if they have cracks they are forbidden.[^fn_107b_38]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN WENT TO A COUNTRY BEYOND THE SEA AND SOMEONE CAME FORWARD[^fn_107b_43] AND MAINTAINED HIS WIFE, HANAN SAID: HE LOSES HIS MONEY.[^fn_107b_44] THE SONS OF THE HIGH PRIESTS[^fn_107b_45] DIFFERED FROM HIM AND RULED: LET HIM TAKE AN OATH AS TO HOW MUCH HE SPENT AND RECOVER IT. SAID R. DOSA B. HARKINAS: \[MY OPINION IS\] IN AGREEMENT WITH THEIR RULING. R. JOHANAN B. ZAKKAI SAID: HANAN SPOKE WELL \[FOR THE MAN\] PUT HIS MONEY ON A STAG'S HORN.[^fn_107b_46] {¶=13.2}

***GEMARA***. Elsewhere we have learned: If a man is forbidden by a vow to have any benefit from another [pg 108a]

the latter may nevertheless pay for him his *shekel*,[^fn_108a_1] repay his debt[^fn_108a_2] and restore to him any object he may have lost; but where a reward is taken,[^fn_108a_3] the benefit is to be given[^fn_108a_4] to the sacred funds.[^fn_108a_5] Now, one can well be satisfied \[with the ruling that\] he may 'pay for him his shekel' \[because by this payment\] he merely performs a religious act,[^fn_108a_6] for it was taught:[^fn_108a_7] It is lawful to withdraw[^fn_108a_8] \[from the funds of the Temple treasury\] on the account of that which was lost,[^fn_108a_9] collected[^fn_108a_10] or about to be collected;[^fn_108a_11] and \[the ruling that he may\] restore to him any object he may have lost' \[is also intelligible since thereby\] also he is performing a religious duty;[^fn_108a_12] but \[how could he be permitted to\] 'repay his debt' \[when thereby\] he undoubtedly benefits[^fn_108a_13] him? — R. Oshaia replied: 'This ruling[^fn_108a_14] is that of[^fn_108a_15] Hanan who said: HE LOSES HIS MONEY.[^fn_108a_16] Raba, however, replied: The ruling[^fn_108a_14] may be said \[to agree even with the view of\] the Rabbis,[^fn_108a_17] for here[^fn_108a_18] we are dealing \[with the case of a man\] who borrowed money on the condition that he does not repay it \[except when he is inclined to do so\].[^fn_108a_19] It is well that Raba does not give the same reply as R. Oshaia, since \[he wishes\] the ruling to agree even with the opinion of the Rabbis. On what ground, however, does not R. Oshaia \[wish to\] give the same reply as Raba? — R. Oshaia can answer you: Granted that he[^fn_108a_20] has no actual benefit;[^fn_108a_21] [pg 108b]

has he not \[some benefit in being spared\] shame?[^fn_108b_1] Another reading:[^fn_108b_2] There also he has benefit, the benefit that he \[need not\] feel embarrassed in the other's presence.[^fn_108b_3]

***MISHNAH***. ADMON LAID DOWN SEVEN RULINGS: — 4 IF A MAN DIES AND LEAVES SONS AND DAUGHTERS, IF THE ESTATE IS LARGE,[^fn_108b_5] THE SONS INHERIT IT AND THE DAUGHTERS ARE MAINTAINED \[FROM IT\][^fn_108b_6] AND IF THE ESTATE IS SMALL,[^fn_108b_5] THE DAUGHTERS ARE MAINTAINED FROM IT, AND THE SONS CAN GO BEGGING.[^fn_108b_7] ADMON SAID, 'AM I TO BE THE LOSER BECAUSE I AM A MALE!'[^fn_108b_8] R. GAMALIEL SAID; ADMON'S VIEW HAS MY APPROVAL.[^fn_108b_9] {¶=13.3}

***GEMARA***. What does he[^fn_108b_10] mean?[^fn_108b_11] — Abaye replied: He means this; 'AM I TO BE THE LOSER BECAUSE I AM A MALE and capable of engaging in the study of the Torah?' Said Raba to him: Would, then, he who is engaged in the study of the Torah be entitled to heirship, while he who is not engaged in the study of the Torah not be entitled to be heir?[^fn_108b_12] — But, said Raba, it is this that he[^fn_108b_10] meant: AM I BECAUSE I AM A MALE, and entitled to be heir in the case of a large estate, TO BE THE LOSER \[of my rights\] in the case of a small estate?'

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN CLAIMED FROM ANOTHER JARS OF OIL AND \[THE LATTER\] ADMITTED HIS CLAIM TO \[EMPTY\] JARS, ADMON RULED: SINCE HE ADMITTED A PORTION OF THE CLAIM HE MUST TAKE AN OATH,[^fn_108b_13] BUT THE SAGES SAID: THE ADMISSION OF THE PORTION \[OF THE CLAIM\] IS NOT OF THE SAME KIND AS THE CLAIM.[^fn_108b_14] R. GAMALIEL SAID; ADMON'S VIEW HAS MY APPROVAL.[^fn_108b_12] {¶=13.4}

***GEMARA***. From this[^fn_108b_15] it may be inferred that, according to the Rabbis,[^fn_108b_16] \[a man from\] whom one claimed wheat and barley and he admitted the claim to the barley is exempt \[from oath\]. Must it then be said that this presents an objection against a ruling which R. Nahman laid down in the name of Samuel? For R. Nahman laid down in the name of Samuel: \[A man from\] whom one claimed wheat and barley and he admitted one of them is liable \[to an oath\]?[^fn_108b_17] — Rab Judah replied in the name of Rab; \[Our Mishnah deals with the case of one from\] whom a certain quantity[^fn_108b_18] \[of oil\] was claimed.[^fn_108b_19] If so,[^fn_108b_20] what could Admon's reason be? — This, however, said Raba, \[is the explanation\]: Both[^fn_108b_21] \[agree\] that where \[the claimant\] said to the other, 'I have the contents[^fn_108b_22] of ten jars of oil in your tank',[^fn_108b_23] he claims from him the oil but not the jars, \[and if he said\], 'You owe me[^fn_108b_24] ten jars full of oil', he claims both the oil and the jars; they only differ where \[the claimant\] said to him, 'You owe me[^fn_108b_24] ten jars of oil'. Admon maintains that in this expression a claim for the jars also is implied, and the Rabbis[^fn_108b_25] contend that in this expression the jars were not implied.

The reason then[^fn_108b_26] is because 'in this expression the jars were not implied', but if the jars had been implied in this expression he would apparently have been liable \[to the oath\]. Must it consequently be presumed that this presents an objection against a ruling of R. Hiyya b. Abba? For R. Hiyya b. Abbah[^fn_108b_27] ruled: \[A man from\] whom one claimed wheat and barley, and he admitted one of them, is exempt \[from an oath\]? — R. Shimi b. Ashi replied: \[The making of such a claim\][^fn_108b_28] is the same as if one had claimed from another a pomegranate with its peel.[^fn_108b_29] To this Rabina demurred: A pomegranate without its peel cannot be preserved, but oil can well be preserved without jars![^fn_108b_30] \[The fact\] however, is that[^fn_108b_31] we are here[^fn_108b_32] dealing \[with the case of a man\] who said to another, 'You owe me[^fn_108b_33] ten jars of oil', and the other replied, 'The \[claim for the\] oil is a pure invention,[^fn_108b_34] \[and as to\] the jars, too, I owe you[^fn_108b_35] five and you have no \[claim to any other\] five'. Admon maintains that this expression implies a claim to the jars also and, since \[the defendant\] must take an oath in respect of the jars,[^fn_108b_36] he must also take an oath by implication[^fn_108b_37] in respect of the oil, while the Rabbis[^fn_108b_38] are of the opinion that such an expression does not imply a claim for the jars \[so that\] what the one claims[^fn_108b_39] the other did not admit, and what the latter admitted[^fn_108b_40] the former did not claim.

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN PROMISED[^fn_108b_41] A SUM OF MONEY TO HIS \[PROSPECTIVE\] SON-IN-LAW AND THEN DEFAULTED,[^fn_108b_42] [pg 109a] {¶=13.5}

LET \[HIS DAUGHTER\] REMAIN \[SINGLE\][^fn_109a_1] UNTIL HER HAIR GROWS GREY.[^fn_109a_2] ADMON RULED: SHE MAY SAY,[^fn_109a_3] 'HAD I MYSELF PROMISED THE SUM ON MY BEHALF I WOULD REMAIN \[SINGLE\][^fn_109a_1] UNTIL MY HAIR GREW GREY, BUT NOW THAT MY FATHER HAS PROMISED IT, WHAT CAN I DO? EITHER MARRY ME OR SET ME FREE'. R. GAMALIEL SAID: ADMON'S WORDS HAVE MY APPROVAL.

***GEMARA***. Our Mishnah does not \[uphold the same view\] as that of the following Tanna. For it was taught: R. Jose son of R. Judah stated, There was no difference of opinion between Admon and the Sages that, where a man promised a sum of money to his \[prospective\] son-in-law and then defaulted, his daughter may say[^fn_109a_3] My father has promised on my behalf, what can I do?' They only[^fn_109a_4] differ where she herself promised a sum of money on her own behalf, in which case the Sages ruled: Let her remain \[single\][^fn_109a_5] until her hair grows grey, while Admon maintained that she could say, 'I thought that my father would pay for me \[the promised amount\], but now that my father does not pay for me, what can I do? Either marry me or set me free'. Said R. Gamaliel: Admon's words have my approval.[^fn_109a_6]

A Tanna taught: This[^fn_109a_7] applies only to a woman who is of age but in the case of a minor compulsion may be used. Who is to be compelled? If the father \[be suggested\], should \[not the ruling. it may be retorted,\] be reversed?[^fn_109a_8] — But, said Raba, compulsion is exercised against the \[prospective\] husband that he may give her a letter of divorce.

R. Isaac b. Eleazar laid down on the authority of Hezekiah: Wherever R. Gamaliel stated, 'Admon's words have my approval', the *halachah* agrees with him. Said Raba to R. Nahman, Even in the Baraitha?[^fn_109a_9] — The other replied, Did we say 'In the Mishnah?' What we said was, 'Wherever R. Gamaliel stated'.[^fn_109a_10]

Said R. Zera in the name of Rabbah b. Jeremiah: As to the two rulings which Hanan has laid down, the *halachah* is in agreement with him who followed his view,[^fn_109a_11] but in respect of the seven rulings that were laid down by Admon, the *halachah* is not in agreement with him who followed his view.[^fn_109a_12] What does he[^fn_109a_13] mean? If it be suggested that he means this: As to the two rulings which Hanan has laid down, the *halachah* is in agreement with himself and with him who followed his view, and that in respect of the seven rulings that were laid down by Admon, the *halachah* is neither in agreement with himself nor with him who followed his view,[^fn_109a_12] \[it may be objected:\] Did not R. Isaac b. Eleazar lay down on the authority of Hezekiah that 'wherever R. Gamaliel stated, "Admon's words have my approval", the *halachah* agrees with him'? — What he[^fn_109a_13] meant, however, must have been this: As to the two rulings which Hanan has laid down, the *halachah* is in agreement with himself and with him who followed his view,[^fn_109a_14] but in respect of the seven rulings that were laid down by Admon, the *halachah* does not agree with him who followed his view[^fn_109a_15] but agrees with himself in all his rulings. But, surely, R. Isaac b. Eleazar laid down on the authority of Hezekiah that 'wherever R. Gamaliel stated, "Admon's words have my approval" the *halachah* agrees with him'. \[Does not this imply:\] Only[^fn_109a_16] where he stated;[^fn_109a_17] but not where he did not state? — The fact, however, is that he[^fn_109a_13] meant this; As to the two rulings which Hanan has laid down, the *halachah* is in agreement with himself and with him who followed him,[^fn_109a_14] but of the seven rulings that were laid down by Admon, there are some concerning which the *halachah* is in agreement with himself and with him who followed his view[^fn_109a_18] while there are others concerning which the *halachah* does not agree with him[^fn_109a_19] but with him who followed his view,[^fn_109a_15] \[the rule being that\] wherever R. Gamaliel stated, 'Admon's words have my approval' is the *halachah* in agreement with him, but not elsewhere.[^fn_109a_20]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN CONTESTS \[THE OWNERSHIP OF\] A FIELD ON \[THE DEED OF SALE OF\] WHICH HE IS SIGNED AS A WITNESS,[^fn_109a_21] ADMON RULED; \[HIS CLAIM IS ADMISSIBLE BECAUSE\] HE CAN SAY,[^fn_109a_22] '\[LITIGATION WITH\] THE SECOND[^fn_109a_23] IS EASIER FOR ME, SINCE THE FIRST[^fn_109a_24] IS A MORE DIFFICULT PERSON THAN HE'.[^fn_109a_25] THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED THAT HE HAS LOST HIS RIGHT.[^fn_109a_26] IF \[THE SELLER\][^fn_109a_27] MADE IT[^fn_109a_28] A \[BOUNDARY\] MARK FOR ANOTHER PERSON[^fn_109a_29] \[THE CONTESTANT\][^fn_109a_30] HAS LOST HIS RIGHT.[^fn_109a_31] {¶=13.6}

***GEMARA***. Abaye said: This[^fn_109a_32] was taught only \[in respect of\] A WITNESS, but a judge[^fn_109a_33] does not lose his title;[^fn_109a_34] for R. Hiyya taught Witnesses may not sign a deed unless they have read it[^fn_109a_35] [pg 109b]

but judges[^fn_109b_1] may sign even though they have not read it.[^fn_109b_2]

IF \[THE SELLER\] MADE IT A \[BOUNDARY\] MARK FOR ANOTHER PERSON. Abaye said: This was taught Only \[where it was\] FOR ANOTHER PERSON, but \[if it was made a boundary mark\] for himself[^fn_109b_3] he does not lose his right; for he can say, 'Had I not done that[^fn_109b_4] for him he would not have sold the field to me'. What \[possible objection can\] you have?[^fn_109b_5] That he should have made a declaration \[to that effect\]? Your friend \[it can be retorted\] has a friend, and the friend of your friend has a friend.[^fn_109b_6]

A certain man once made a field[^fn_109b_7] a \[boundary\] mark for another person,[^fn_109b_8] \[and one of the witnesses,\] having contested \[its ownership,\][^fn_109b_9] died, when a guardian was appointed \[over his estate\].[^fn_109b_10] The guardian came to Abaye[^fn_109b_11] who quoted to him: 'IF \[THE SELLER\] MADE IT A \[BOUNDARY\] MARK FOR ANOTHER PERSON \[THE CONTESTANT\] HAS LOST HIS RIGHT'. 'If the father of the orphans had been alive', the other retorted, 'could he not have pleaded, "l have conceded to him[^fn_109b_12] only one furrow"?'[^fn_109b_13] — 'You speak well', he said, 'for R. Johanan stated, If he submitted the plea, "l have conceded to you only one furrow", he is believed'. 'Proceed at any rate \[Abaye later[^fn_109b_14] told the guardian\] to give him one furrow'.[^fn_109b_15] On that \[furrow, however,\] there was a nursery of palm trees, and \[the guardian\] said to him, 'Had the father of the orphans been alive, could he not have submitted the plea, "I have re-purchased it from him"?'[^fn_109b_16] — 'You speak well', \[Abaye\] said to him, 'for R. Johanan ruled, If he submitted the plea, "I have re-purchased it from him" he is believed'.[^fn_109b_17] Said Abaye: Anyone who appoints a guardian should appoint one like this man who understands how to turn \[the scales\][^fn_109b_18] in favour of orphans.

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN WENT TO A COUNTRY BEYOND THE SEA AND \[IN HIS ABSENCE\] THE PATH TO HIS FIELD WAS LOST,[^fn_109b_19] ADMON RULED: LET HIM WALK \[TO HIS FIELD\][^fn_109b_20] BY THE SHORTEST WAY.[^fn_109b_21] THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: LET HIM EITHER PURCHASE A PATH FOR HIMSELF EVEN THOUGH IT \[COST HIM\] A HUNDRED *MANEH* OR FLY THROUGH THE AIR. {¶=13.7}

***GEMARA***. What is the Rabbis'[^fn_109b_22] reason? Does not Admon speak well?[^fn_109b_23] — Rab Judah replied in the name of Rab: \[The ruling[^fn_109b_24] refers to a field\], for instance, which \[the fields of\] four persons surrounded on its four sides.[^fn_109b_25] If that be so, what can be Admon's reason?[^fn_109b_26] — Raba explained: Where four persons[^fn_109b_27] succeeded[^fn_109b_28] \[to the adjacent fields\] by virtue of the rights of four \[persons respectively\][^fn_109b_29] or where four persons succeeded[^fn_109b_28] \[to them\][^fn_109b_30] by virtue of one,[^fn_109b_29] all agree that these may turn him away.[^fn_109b_31] They[^fn_109b_32] only differ where one person succeeded[^fn_109b_33] \[to all the surrounding fields\] by virtue of four persons.[^fn_109b_34] Admon is of the opinion that \[the claimant can say to that person,\] 'At all events[^fn_109b_35] my path is in your territory'; and the Rabbis hold the opinion \[that the defendant might retort,\] 'If you will keep quiet, well and good,[^fn_109b_36] but if not I will return the deeds to their respective original owners whom you will have no chance of calling to law'.[^fn_109b_37]

A \[dying man\][^fn_109b_38] once instructed \[those around him\] that a palm tree shall be given to his daughters but the orphans proceeded to divide the estate and gave her no palm tree. R. Joseph \[in considering the case\] intended to lay down that it involved the very same principle as that of our Mishnah.[^fn_109b_39] But Abaye said to him: Are \[the two\] alike? There,[^fn_109b_40] each one can send \[the claimant to the path\] away;[^fn_109b_41] but here, the palm tree is in their common possession.[^fn_109b_42] What is their way out?[^fn_109b_43] — They must give her a palm tree and divide \[the estate\] all over[^fn_109b_44] again.

A \[dying man\][^fn_109b_45] once instructed \[those around him\] that a palm tree shall be given to his daughter. When he died he left[^fn_109b_46] two halves of a palm tree.[^fn_109b_47] Sat R. Ashi \[discussing the case\] and grappled with this difficulty; Do people call two halves of palms trees a palm tree' or not? — Said R. Mordecai to R. Ashi, Thus said Abimi of Hagronia[^fn_109b_48] in the name of Raba: People do call two halves of palm trees 'a palm tree'.[^fn_109b_49] [pg 110a]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MAN PRODUCED A BOND OF INDEBTEDNESS AGAINST ANOTHER, AND THE LATTER PRO DUCED \[A DEED OF SALE,[^fn_110a_1] SHEWING\] THAT THE FORMER HAD SOLD HIM A FIELD,[^fn_110a_2] ADMON RULED; \[THE OTHER\] CAN SAY, HAD I OWED YOU \[ANYTHING\] YOU WOULD HAVE RECOVERED IT WHEN YOU SOLD ME THE FIELD'.[^fn_110a_3] THE SAGES, HOWEVER, SAY; THIS \[SELLER\] MAY HAVE BEEN A PRUDENT MAN, SINCE HE MAY HAVE SOLD HIM THE LAND IN ORDER TO BE ABLE TO TAKE IT FROM HIM AS A PLEDGE.[^fn_110a_4] {¶=13.8}

***GEMARA***. What is the reason of the Rabbis? Does not Admon speak well? — Where \[the purchase\] money is paid first and the deed is written afterwards, no one disputes that the \[defendant\] may well say \[to the claimant\], 'You should have recovered your debt when you sold me the field'.[^fn_110a_3] They only differ where the deed is written first and the purchase money is paid afterwards. Admon is of the opinion that \[the claimant\] should have made a declaration \[of his motive\],[^fn_110a_5] while the Rabbis[^fn_110a_6] maintain \[that the claimant can retort,\] 'Your friend has a friend, and the friend of your friend has a friend'.[^fn_110a_7]

***MISHNAH***. IF TWO MEN PRODUCED BONDS OF INDEBTEDNESS AGAINST ONE ANOTHER,[^fn_110a_8] ADMON RULED; \[THE HOLDER OF THE LATER BOND CAN SAY TO THE OTHER,\] 'HAD I OWED YOU \[ANY MONEY\] HOW IS IT THAT YOU BORROWED FROM ME?'[^fn_110a_9] THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: THE ONE RECOVERS HIS DEBT[^fn_110a_10] AND THE OTHER RECOVERS HIS DEBT.[^fn_110a_11] {¶=13.9}

***GEMARA***. It was stated: If two men produced bonds of indebtedness against one another, R. Nahman ruled: The one recovers his debt and the other recovers his debt.[^fn_110a_12] R. Shesheth said: What is the point[^fn_110a_13] in exchanging bags?[^fn_110a_14] The one rather retains his own \[money\][^fn_110a_15] and the other retains his.

All agree[^fn_110a_16] that if both \[litigants possess land of the\] best,[^fn_110a_17] medium or worst quality \[distraint for each on the other is\] undoubtedly a case of changing bags.[^fn_110a_14] They differ only where one \[of the litigants\] has land of medium quality and the other of the worst quality. R. Nahman is of the opinion that 'the one recovers his debt and the other recovers his debt' because in his view an assessment[^fn_110a_18] is made on the basis of the debtor's[^fn_110a_19] possessions,[^fn_110a_20] \[so that\] the owner of the land of the worst quality proceeds to distrain on the medium quality \[of the other\][^fn_110a_21] which then becomes with him the best; and the other can then proceed to take from him the worst only.[^fn_110a_22] R. Shesheth, however, said, 'What is the point in exchanging bags?' because he is of the opinion that an assessment[^fn_110a_23] is made on a general basis,[^fn_110a_24] \[so that\] eventually when the original owner of the medium land[^fn_110a_25] proceeds \[to distrain on the property of the other\][^fn_110a_26] he will only take back his own medium land. But what \[reason can\] you see, according to R. Nahman, that the owner of the worst quality of land should proceed \[to distrain\] first? Why should not rather the owner of the medium quality come first and distrain on the worst \[of the other\] and then let him distrain on it?[^fn_110a_27] — \[But this ruling\] applies only[^fn_110a_28] where the \[holder of the worst land\] submitted his claim first. But after all when they come to distrain, do they not come simultaneously?[^fn_110a_29] The fact, however, \[is that the ruling\] applies only[^fn_110a_28] where one \[of the litigants\] has best and medium land, and the other has only of the worst. One Master[^fn_110a_30] is of the opinion that an assessment[^fn_110a_31] is made on the basis of the debtor's[^fn_110a_32] possessions,[^fn_110a_33] while the other Master[^fn_110a_34] is of the opinion that an assessments is made on a general basis.[^fn_110a_35]

We have learned: THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: THE ONE RECOVERS HIS DEBT AND THE OTHER RECOVERS HIS DEBT![^fn_110a_36] R. Nahman explained this, according to R. Shesheth, \[as referring to a case,\] for instance, where one borrowed for a period often, and the other for one of five years.[^fn_110a_37] But how exactly are we to understand this? If it be suggested that the first \[bond\][^fn_110a_38] was for ten years and the second for five, would Admon \[it may be objected\] have ruled \[that the second can say to the first:\] 'HAD OWED YOU \[ANY MONEY\] HOW IS IT THAT YOU BORROWED FROM ME?' The time for payment[^fn_110a_39] surely, had not yet arrived.[^fn_110a_40] If, however, \[it be suggested that\] the first was for five years and the second for ten, how \[it may again be objected\] is this to be understood? If the time for payment[^fn_110a_39] had arrived,[^fn_110a_40] what \[it may be asked\] could be the reason of the Rabbis?[^fn_110a_41] And if the time for payment[^fn_110a_39] had not yet arrived,[^fn_110a_40] well, payment was not yet due and what \[it may again be asked\] is Admon's reason? — \[This ruling was\] required \[in that case\] only where \[the holder of the earlier bond\][^fn_110a_42] came \[to borrow\] on the day on which the five years had terminated.[^fn_110a_43] The Masters[^fn_110a_44] are of the opinion that it is usual to borrow money for one day[^fn_110a_45] and the Master[^fn_110a_46] is of the opinion that one does not borrow money for one day.[^fn_110a_47]

Rama b. Mama explained: We are here[^fn_110a_48] dealing with \[a case where one of the bonds was presented by\] orphans[^fn_110a_49] who are themselves entitled to recover a debt but from whom no debt may be recovered.[^fn_110a_50]

Was it not, however, stated, THE ONE RECOVERS HIS DEBT AND THE OTHER RECOVERS HIS DEBT?[^fn_110a_51] — \[The meaning is:\] The one recovers his debt, and the other is entitled to recover it but gets nothing. Said Raba: Two objections \[may be advanced\] against this explanation. Firstly, it was stated, 'THE ONE RECOVERS HIS DEBT AND THE OTHER RECOVERS[^fn_110a_51] HIS DEBT'; and, secondly, could not \[the other party\] allow the orphans to distrain on a plot of land \[of his\] and then recover it from them,[^fn_110a_52] in accordance with \[a ruling of\] R. Nahman, for R. Nahman said in the name of Rabbah b. Abbuha: If orphans collected a plot of land for their father's debt[^fn_110a_53] the creditor[^fn_110a_54] may re-collect it from them?[^fn_110a_55] — This is a difficulty.

Why could it not be explained \[that this is a case\] where the orphans owned land of the worst quality and the other owned best[^fn_110a_56] and medium quality, so that the orphans proceed to distrain on his medium land[^fn_110a_57] and allow him to distrain on their worst only? For, even though[^fn_110a_58] an assessment[^fn_110a_59] is made on a general basis[^fn_110a_60] is not payment from orphans' property recovered from their worst land only?[^fn_110a_61] — This applies only where \[the creditor\] has not yet seized \[their property\] but where[^fn_110a_62] he had seized it[^fn_110a_63] he may lawfully retain it.[^fn_110a_64]

***MISHNAH***. \[THE FOLLOWING REGIONS ARE REGARDED AS\] THREE COUNTRIES IN RESPECT OF MATRIMONY:[^fn_110a_65] JUDAEA, TRANSJORDAN AND GALILEE. \[A MAN\] MAY NOT TAKE OUT \[HIS WIFE WITH HIM\][^fn_110a_66] FROM ONE TOWN[^fn_110a_67] TO ANOTHER[^fn_110a_68] OR FROM ONE CITY[^fn_110a_69] TO AN OTHER. WITHIN THE SAME COUNTRY, HOWEVER, HE MAY TAKE HER OUT WITH HIM FROM ONE TOWN INTO ANOTHER OR FROM ONE CITY INTO AN OTHER[^fn_110a_70] [pg 110b] {¶=13.10}

BUT NOT FROM A TOWN TO A CITY NOR FROM A CITY TO A TOWN.[^fn_110b_1] \[A MAN\] MAY TAKE OUT \[HIS WIFE WITH HIM\] FROM AN INFERIOR[^fn_110b_2] TO A SUPERIOR[^fn_110b_3] DWELLING, BUT NOT FROM A SUPERIOR[^fn_110b_3] TO AN INFERIOR[^fn_110b_2] DWELLING. R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL RULED: NOT EVEN FROM AN INFERIOR DWELLING TO A SUPERIOR DWELLING, BECAUSE THE \[CHANGE TO A\] SUPERIOR DWELLING PUTS \[THE HUMAN BODY\] TO A \[SEVERE\] TEST.[^fn_110b_4]

***GEMARA***. One may readily grant \[the justice of the ruling that a wife may not be compelled to move\] FROM A CITY TO A TOWN, since everything \[necessary\] is obtainable in a city while not everything is obtainable in a town. On what grounds, however, \[can she not be compelled to move\] FROM A TOWN TO A CITY? — \[This ruling\] provides support for R. Jose b. Hanina who stated, 'Whence is it deduced that city[^fn_110b_5] life[^fn_110b_6] is difficult?[^fn_110b_7] \[From Scripture\] where it is said, And the people blessed all men that willingly offered themselves to dwell in Jerusalem.[^fn_110b_8]

R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL RULED etc. What \[is meant by\] PUTS \[THE HUMAN BODY\] TO A \[SEVERE\] TEST'?[^fn_110b_9] — In agreement \[with a saying\] of Samuel. For Samuel said: A change of diet is the beginning of bowel trouble.[^fn_110b_10]

It is written in the Book of Ben Sira: *All the days of the poor[^fn_110b_11] are evil*;[^fn_110b_12] but are there not the Sabbaths and festivals?[^fn_110b_13] — \[The explanation, however, is\] according to Samuel. For Samuel said: A change of diet is the beginning of bowel trouble.[^fn_110b_10] Ben Sira said: The nights also.[^fn_110b_14] Lower than \[all\] the roofs is his roof,[^fn_110b_15] and on the height of mountains is his vineyard,[^fn_110b_16] \[so that\] the rain of \[other\] roofs \[pours down\] upon his roof and the earth of his vineyard \[is washed down\] into the vineyards \[of others\].[^fn_110b_17]

***MISHNAH***. \[A MAN\] MAY COMPEL ALL \[HIS HOUSEHOLD\] TO GO UP[^fn_110b_18] \[WITH HIM\] TO THE LAND OF ISRAEL., BUT NONE MAY BE COMPELLED TO LEAVE IT. ALL \[ONE'S HOUSEHOLD\] MAY BE COMPELLED TO GO UP[^fn_110b_18] TO JERUSALEM,[^fn_110b_19] BUT NONE MAY BE COMPELLED TO LEAVE IT. \[THIS APPLIES TO\] BOTH MEN AND WOMEN.[^fn_110b_20] IF A MAN MARRIED A WOMAN IN THE LAND OF ISRAEL AND DIVORCED HER IN THE LAND OF ISRAEL, HE MUST PAY HER \[HER *KETHUBAH*\] IN THE CURRENCY OF THE LAND OF ISRAEL. IF HE MARRIED A WOMAN IN THE LAND OF ISRAEL AND DIVORCED HER IN CAPPADOCIA HE MUST PAY HER \[HER *KETHUBAH*\] IN THE CURRENCY OF THE LAND OF ISRAEL.[^fn_110b_21] IF HE MARRIED A WOMAN IN CAPPADOCIA AND DIVORCED HER IN THE LAND OF ISRAEL, HE MUST A GAIN PAY \[HER *KETHUBAH*\] IN THE CURRENCY OF THE LAND OF ISRAEL.[^fn_110b_21] R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL, HOWEVER, RULED THAT HE MUST PAY HER IN THE CAPPADOCIAN CURRENCY. {¶=13.11}

IF A MAN MARRIED A WOMAN IN CAPPADOCIA AND DIVORCED HER IN CAPPADOCIA, HE MUST PAY HER \[HER *KETHUBAH*\] IN THE CURRENCY OF CAPPADOCIA.

***GEMARA***. What \[was the expression,\] 'MAY COMPEL ALL'[^fn_110b_22] intended to include? — To include slaves.[^fn_110b_23] What, however, \[was the expression[^fn_110b_22] intended\] to include according to him who specifically mentioned 'slaves' \[in our Mishnah\]? — To include \[removal\] from a superior dwelling to an inferior one. What \[was the expression,\] 'BUT NONE[^fn_110b_24] MAY BE COMPELLED TO LEAVE IT' intended to include? — To include a slave who fled from outside the Land \[of Israel\] into the Land in which case his master is told,[^fn_110b_25] 'Sell him here, and go', in order to \[encourage\] settlement in the Land of Israel. What \[was the expression\] 'ALL[^fn_110b_26]  … MAY BE COMPELLED TO GO UP TO JERUSALEM' intended to include? — To include \[removal\] from a superior dwelling to an inferior one. What \[was the expression,\] 'BUT NONE[^fn_110b_27] MAY BE COMPELLED TO LEAVE IT' intended to include? — To include even \[removal\] from an inferior dwelling to a superior one; only since as it was stated in the earlier clause,[^fn_110b_28] 'NONE MAY BE COMPELLED TO LEAVE IT it was also stated in the latter clause,[^fn_110b_29] 'NONE MAY BE COMPELLED TO LEAVE IT'.[^fn_110b_30]

Our Rabbis taught: If \[the husband\] desires[^fn_110b_31] to go up[^fn_110b_32] and his wife refuses[^fn_110b_31] she must be pressed[^fn_110b_33] to go up; and if \[she does\] not \[consent\] she may be divorced[^fn_110b_34] without a *kethubah*. If she desires[^fn_110b_31] to go up[^fn_110b_32] and be refuses,[^fn_110b_31] he must be pressed to go up; and if \[he does\] not \[consent\] he must divorce her and pay her *kethubah*. If she desires to leave[^fn_110b_35] and he refuses to leave, she must be pressed not to leave, and if \[pressure is of\] no \[avail\] she may be divorced[^fn_110b_34] without a *kethubah*. If he desires to leave[^fn_110b_35] and she refuses he must be pressed not to leave, and if \[coercion is of\] no \[avail\] he must divorce her and pay her *kethubah*.[^fn_110b_36]

IF A MAN MARRIED A WOMAN etc. Is not this self-contradictory? It was stated, IF HE MARRIED A WOMAN IN THE LAND OF ISRAEL AND DIVORCED HER IN CAPPADOCIA HE MUST PAY HER \[HER *KETHUBAH*\] IN THE CURRENCY OF THE LAND OF ISRAEL, from which it clearly follows that we are guided by \[the currency of the place where the\] obligation[^fn_110b_37] was undertaken.[^fn_110b_38] Read, however, the concluding clause: IF HE MARRIED A WOMAN IN CAPPADOCIA AND DIVORCED HER IN THE LAND OF ISRAEL HE MUST AGAIN PAY HER \[HER *KETHUBAH*\] IN THE CURRENCY OF THE LAND OF ISRAEL, from which it follows, does it not, that we are guided by \[the currency of the place\] where collection is effected?[^fn_110b_39] — Rabbah replied: \[The rulings\] taught here \[are among those in which the claims relating to\] a *kethubah* are weaker \[than those of other claimants\],[^fn_110b_40] for \[the author\] is of the opinion that the *kethubah* is a Rabbinical enactment.[^fn_110b_41] R. SIMEON B. GAMALIEL, HOWEVER, RULED THAT HE MUST PAY HER IN THE CAPPADOCIAN CURRENCY. He is of the opinion[^fn_110b_42] that the *kethubah* is Pentateuchal.[^fn_110b_43]

Our Rabbis taught: If a man produces a bond of indebtedness against another \[and the place of issue\] entered[^fn_110b_44] therein was Babylon, \[the debtor\] must allow him to collect it in Babylonian currency. If \[the place of issue\] entered[^fn_110b_44] therein was the Land of Israel he must allow him to collect it in the currency of the Land of Israel. If no place of issue was entered[^fn_110b_44] he must, if it was presented in Babylon, pay him in Babylonian currency; and, if it was presented in the Land of Israel, he must pay him in the currency of the Land of Israel. If merely \[a sum of\] 'silver \[pieces\]'[^fn_110b_45] was entered, the borrower may pay the other whatever he wishes.[^fn_110b_46] \[This is a ruling\] which does not apply to[^fn_110b_47] a *kethubah*.[^fn_110b_48] To what \[ruling does this[^fn_110b_49] refer\]? — R. Mesharsheya replied: To that in the first clause,[^fn_110b_50] thus indicating that the law is not in agreement with[^fn_110b_51] R. Simeon b. Gamaliel who ruled that the *kethubah* is Pentateuchal.

'If merely \[a sum of\] "silver \[pieces\]" was entered the borrower may pay the other whatever he wishes'. May not one say that \[a 'silver piece' merely signified\] a bar \[of silver\]? — R. Eleazar replied: \[This is a case\] where 'coin' was mentioned in the bond.[^fn_110b_52] May not one suggest \[that it signified\] small change? — R. Papa replied: Small change is not made of silver.[^fn_110b_53]

Our Rabbis taught: One should always live in the Land of Israel, even in a town most of whose inhabitants are idolaters, but let no one live outside the Land, even in a town most of whose inhabitants are Israelites; for whoever lives in the Land of Israel may be considered to have[^fn_110b_54] a God, but whoever lives outside the Land may be regarded as one who has no God. For it is said in Scripture, To give you the Land of Canaan, to be your God.[^fn_110b_55] Has he, then, who does not live in the Land, no God?[^fn_110b_56] But \[this is what the text intended\] to tell you, that whoever lives outside the Land may be regarded as one who worships idols. Similarly it was said in Scripture in \[the story of\] David, For they have driven me out this day that I should not cleave to the inheritance of the Lord, saying: Go, serve other gods.[^fn_110b_57] Now, whoever said to David, 'Serve other gods'? But \[the text intended\] to tell you that whoever lives outside the Land[^fn_110b_58] may be regarded as one who worships idols.[^fn_110b_59]

R. Zera was evading Rab Judah because he desired to go up to the Land of Israel while Rab Judah had expressed \[the following view:\] Whoever goes up from Babylon to the Land of Israel transgresses a positive commandment, for it is said in Scripture, [pg 111a]

*They shall be carried to Babylon, and there shall they be, until the day that I remember them, saith the Lord*.[^fn_111a_1] And R. Zera?[^fn_111a_2] — That text[^fn_111a_1] refers[^fn_111a_3] to the vessels of ministry.[^fn_111a_4] And Rab Judah? — Another text also is available:[^fn_111a_3] *I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, by the gazelles, and by the hinds of the field, \[that ye awaken not, nor stir up love,[^fn_111a_5] until it please\]*'.[^fn_111a_6] And R. Zera? — That[^fn_111a_7] implies that Israel shall not go up \[all together as if surrounded\] by a wall.[^fn_111a_8] And Rab Judah? — Another *'I adjure you'*[^fn_111a_9] is written in Scripture. And R. Zera? — That text is required for \[an exposition\] like that of R. Jose son of R. Hanina who said: 'What was the purpose of those three adjurations?[^fn_111a_10] — One, that Israel shall not go up \[all together as if surrounded\] by a wall;[^fn_111a_8] the second, that whereby the Holy One, blessed be He, adjured Israel that they shall not rebel against the nations of the world; and the third is that whereby the Holy One, blessed be He, adjured the idolaters that they shall not oppress Israel too much'. And Rab Judah? — It is written in Scripture, *That ye awaken not, nor stir up*.[^fn_111a_11] And R. Zera? — That text is required for \[an exposition\] like that of R. Levi who stated: 'What was the purpose of those six adjurations?[^fn_111a_12] — Three for the purposes just mentioned and the others, that \[the prophets\] shall not make known the end,[^fn_111a_13] that \[the people\] shall not[^fn_111a_14] delay[^fn_111a_15] the end,[^fn_111a_13] and that they shall not reveal the secret[^fn_111a_16] to the idolaters'.

*By the gazelles, and by the hinds of the field*.[^fn_111a_17] R. Eleazar explained: The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel, 'If you will keep the adjuration, well and good; but if not, I will permit your flesh \[to be a prey\] like \[that of\] the gazelles and the hinds of the field'.

R. Eleazar said: Whoever is domiciled in the Land of Israel lives without sin, for it is said in Scripture, *And the inhabitant shall not say, 'I am sick', the people that dwell therein shall be forgiven their iniquity*.[^fn_111a_18] Said Raba[^fn_111a_19] to R. Ashi; We apply this \[text\][^fn_111a_18] to those who suffer from disease.

R.
